ADVERTISEMENT TO THE FIFTH EDITION. The Channel Pilot, Part 2, contains Sailing Directions for the northern coast of France, from Ushant to Dunkerque, together with the Channel Islands. The directions for the French coast were originally compiled from the Pilote Francais, edited by M. Givry from the valuable surveys made by M. Beautemps-Beaupre, between the years 1836-43 ; and also from the surveys of Captain Martin White, R.N., in the years 1812-29. The first edition of this work was compiled by Staff-Commander J. W. King, R.N., of the Hydrographic Department, Admiralty, from the above sources, and published in 1859. The directions for the Channel islands were prepared by Staff- Commander John Richards during the Admiralty survey of those islands in the years 1859-70, and published in March, 1870. The second edition of Channel Pilot, Part 2, was revised and corrected by Staff-Commander G. F. McDougall, R.N., of the Hydro graphic Department, in December, 1870, who embodied the Sailing Directions for the Channel Islands above alluded to. The third edition was revised by Staff-Commander G. H. Allen, R.N., in 1875. The fourth edition was revised by Staff-Commander Hitchfield, R.N., of the Hydrographic Department, in 1882. The present edition has been revised and corrected by Captain E. H. Hills, R.N., from information derived from the most recent charts and works published by the French Government, and from various other sources. In this edition, the construction of the work has been altered in conformity with the plan adopted in Channel Pilot, Part 1 ; the description of the French coast commencing in the West and proceeding regularly eastward. Seamen are invited to transmit to the Secretary of the Admiralty notices of any errors or omissions they may detect in this work, in order that the information may be applied for the benefit of navigation. Ushant or Ile d'Ouessant 19° 10' W. 18° 40' W. lie de Bas GENERAL OBSERVATIONS.— Having in Channel Pilot, Part I., given a full description of the outer soundings, currents, and various lines of approach to the English Channel, and described the southern coast of England from Land's End to the North Foreland, it is proposed in Part II., to repeat such portions as apply more particularly to the approaches to Ushant and to describe the northern coast of France from Ushant or Ile d'Ouessant to Dunkerque, including the Channel Islands. In this navigation, it is important the mariner should make himself acquainted with the general system of winds in the Channel, as well as with the subject of fogs and mirage ; and, therefore, a brief notice of these is given It is only necessary to add the caution that the wind has considerable effect on the strength and direction of the tidal streams, as well as on the range of the tides ; and, that winds from between N.W. and N.E., which are the smooth-water winds on the English coast, are those which produce the heaviest seas on the French shores. [Chap. I. 2 GENERAL OBSERVATIONS. It is desirable that the seaman should have a knowledge of the weather signals used at French ports in addition to the usual storm warnings ; also, of the signals established for indicating the depth of water at the entrance of French ports, and of the system adopted for colouring buoys and beacons ; the rules and regulations on these subjects are therefore given before proceeding to the description of Ushant. "WINDS.— The prevailing winds in the Channel are westerly, and they greatly preponderate over easterly winds. From October to March inclusive, westerly gales are most frequent, often lasting three or four days ; during May, June, and July, they are comparatively rare. South-westerly gales are very dangerous in the eastern part of the Channel, are generally accompanied by rain, and the wind, blowing in violent gusts, sometimes veers suddenly to N.W., North, or even to N.E., without losing strength, and causing a heavy sea on the French coast southward of Cape Grisnez. Should the wind continue from the northward with a rising barometer, its force usually moderates and the weather becomes fine ; but, should it back to the S.W. with a falling barometer, bad weather is sure to return. It has been remarked that gales which occur during spring tides are generally more violent and lasting than those which take place during neaps, and that they acquire their greatest strength at the beginning of the flood. Winds from North to N.E. are sometimes strong at both entrances to the Channel, but seldom acquire the force of a gale in its central portion except on the French shore ; they do not usually last so long nor does the wind shift as with those from the westward. They cause a heavy sea on the flood stream, and, during their continuance, the land is generally covered with a white fog resembling smoke, an appearance common during all easterly winds which sometimes, when of moderate force, blow with great persistence. South-easterly winds, accompanied by rain and a falling barometer, almost always become gales ; these are off-shore and therefore smooth-water winds on the French coast, but their continuance from that quarter seldom lasts long ; for, gales in the Channel being mostly of a cyclonic character and travelling eastward, a change of wind is to be expected, and the direction of the change depends on whether the position of the vessel is northward or southward of the track of the storm's centre. If southward of it, the wind veers from S.E. to South, and West ; if northward, it backs to East and North. Seamen should bear in mind the well-known rule for ascer-

Chap. L] 3 WINDS. — FOGS AND MIRAGE. taining the position of a storm's centre, or, in other words, of the area of low barometric pressure round which the wind circulates, when in the northern hemisphere, viz. — to face the wind, when this central depression will be from 8 to 12 points to the right of its direction. Careful attention to the barometer and to any changes in the direction of the wind give a sure clue to future probable changes. Moderate winds from N.W. to N.E. bring fine weather. In the Channel, during summer, regular land and sea breezes frequently become established in fine settled weather ; at night, it then falls calm and a heavy dew ensues. When there is little or no dew, it is a sign of an impending change of weather. Calms are of rare occurrence, even in summer, and do not last long. In winter, they are generally precursors of bad weather, of which there are no more certain indications than swell in the offing and surf on the coast during a calm. In some winters snow is abundant ; the wind is often fresh and baffling in snow squalls, and the falling snow effectually obscures all objects from view. After a snow shower, there is often great difficulty in recognizing the coast which may be in sight, the snow completely altering its aspect. A change from rain to hail often accompanies or precedes sudden changes in the wind from a southerly to a more northerly direction. The peculiar configuration of the land as well as the great rise and fall of tide in the Gulf of St. Malo appears to influence to a certain degree the winds and weather in that neighbourhood and amongst the Channel Islands ; remarks on these local winds will be found at page 193. Fog's and Mirage. — Fogs are frequent in all parts of the Channel. In summer, they generally hide the land in the morning only and disperse as the sun acquires strength. The moist haze accompanying westerly winds is more tenacious and only yields to a freshening breezy ; it then frequently turns to rain and marks the commence ment of bad weather. In the eastern part of the Channel, it is rare for the land to be entirely free from mist except previously to strong north-easterly winds, when it may be distinctly seen from a great distance. Westerly winds, as before remarked, frequently bring mist, rain, and low dense clouds, which conceal the land from view. With easterly winds, the haze which covers the land is dense in pro portion as the wind is strong and lasting. Mirage is most frequent on the French coast, especially in the bight between Cape Barfleur and Cape d'Antifer ; it is considered an A 2

GENERAL OBSERVATIONS. indication of fine weather if it tends only to enlarge the apparent size of objects ; but, when it distorts and renders them difficult of recognition, it is usually followed by rain or by strong easterly winds. When mirage is prevalent about sunset, it may be expected that as night draws on the Channel lights will become visible at much greater distances than under ordinary circumstances. SOUNDINGS.— South-westward of Ushant, the 100-fathoms line of soundings is from 65 to 75 miles distant from that island ; the whole extent of the edge of soundings may always be discovered in fine weather by the numerous ripplings in its vicinity, and, in boisterous weather, by the sudden alterations in the colour of the water from blue to a disturbed green. On the Parallel of Ushant, 48° 28' N., the 100-fathoms edge of soundings is much more distant ; here it is found in about long. 9° 35' W., but for 55 miles westward of this meridian are very irregular depths ; several spots having less than 100 fathoms, with depths between them in some cases of over 1,000 fathoms. At 20 miles eastward of 9° 35' W. the water shoals to 84 fathoms, but this parallel bordering so closely on the 100-fathoms edge of soundings, the depths are very irregular until as far eastward as 7° 30' W. The Little Sole Bank in long. 8° 58' W. is only 6 miles southward of the parallel of Ushant ; it has from 66 to 69 fathoms, is 9 miles in extent E.S.E. and W.N.W., and its southern edge is close to the 100-fathoms line, beyond which the depths increase rapidly. From the shoalest part of the Little Sole Bank, 66 fathoms, Ushant N.W. lighthouse bears E. by S. f S. 148 miles. Passing 6 miles northward of the bank, the depths are from 95 to 90 fathoms, fine light sand and pieces of ribbed shells ; 15 miles farther eastward and 135 miles from Ushant, 88 fathoms, with similar bottom, and, as far as long. 7° 30' W., the depth varies between 88 and 94 fathoms. As Ushant is approached, from this meridian, the progressive shoaling is very gradual, the 70-fathoms line being only reached in long. 6° 8' W. The north-eastern end of Parsons' Bank is, however, crossed in 6° 20' W., and here, within a distance of 6 or 8 miles, the depth decreases from 86 to 68 fathoms, and deepens again to 74 fathoms. The shoalest part of Parsons' Bank, however, lies southward of this parallel, and from lat. 48° 26' N., long. 6° 30' W., it has a depth of only 56 or 59 fathoms for about 6 miles to the south-westward. After passing eastward of this bank, the depths are 72 to 70 fathoms, coarse pale yellow ground resembling semi-indurated marl with a

Chap. L] SOUNDINGS— CURRENTS.— VARIATION. 5 mealy surface, interspersed with broken pieces of shells and a sub stance like chaff. At 27 miles from Ushant, the depths are from 66 to 63 fathoms, fine sand or sand and shells, and 66 fathoms has been found within 5 miles of the rocks. In thick weather, as a general rule, do not come into less than 70 fathoms when approaching Ushant from the southward or south westward, until certain of being northward of its parallel, and keep the lead constantly going ; but, observe that 53 or 54 miles from Ushant, less water may be found on the Kaiser-i-hind bank, which, from lat. 48° 4' N. long. 6° 19' W., extends for at least 11 miles N.E., with depths of from 66 to 63 fathoms ; deeper water, however, lies between this bank and the 70-fathoms line of soundings. ROUNDING USHANT.— Steam-vessels leaving the Channel for the southward should, if possible, sight and pass Ushant about 10 miles distant. Sailing vessels, except those from the western French ports, should not as a rule sight it, but, even with a fair wind, make every effort to obtain good westing, bearing in mind that the prevailing winds and set of the ocean being from that direction, have a tendency to set them towards Ushant and into the Bay of Biscay when southward of it ; therefore, it is of the highest importance to keep well to the westward. Steam-vessels entering the Channel from the southward should exercise great caution in rounding Ushant. The island is surrounded by dangers ; rocks are numerous, the channels intricate, fogs and thick weather common, and the tides strong. Round Ushant, the flood sets north-eastward and the ebb south-westward, at the rate of 3 or 4 knots during springs, the flood stream turning more eastward, and thus setting more directly towards the rocks, as the tide slacks. Between Ushant and the Saints, the flood tide sets eastward and the ebb westward. Steamers should round Ushant about ten miles distant unless bound for western French ports, when in clear weather it may be rounded more closely, but not nearer than five miles. When thick weather prevails, it should be given a wide berth. The old rule of not coming within a depth of 70 fathoms until northward of the parallel of Ushant is a safe one. Currents. — In approaching Ushant, the effect of current requires careful consideration, for, the currents in this vicinity being merely the prolonged movements of the water resulting from recent and probably remote gales, their actual direction may differ from that indicated by the run of the swell. It is known that westerly gales forcing the water into the Bay of Biscay cause it there to accumulate until it forms a head of water which then flows northward along the

6 [Chap. I. GENERAL OBSERVATIONS. French shore and north-westward across the mouth of the English Channel. This current does not seem to be frequently experienced to any great extent, but it may attain a rate of 1 or 1^ knots an hour, and the knowledge of its possible existence, coupled with the known strength of the tides in the neighbourhood of Ushant, should induce great caution in making that island. Variation Of the Compass.— The amount of variation for the year 1888 at the principal ports and headlands of the French coast and Channel Islands will be found at the head of each chapter. The general direction of the lines of equal variation is S.S.W. and N.N.E. (true). Strict attention should be paid to the correction of course required by the continuous change in variation when proceeding up or down Channel, especially if steaming or sailing at a high speed. The difference in variation between Ushant and Dunkerque is 3°, the variation decreasing as a vessel proceeds eastward. The annual decrease of variation at present is about 7-5'. BAROMETER. — The average range of the barometer in the higher latitudes, i.e. 50° to 60°, is about 1-5 inches, but, on extra ordinary occasions, ranges of 2" 75 and 3 inches have been recorded. In the northern hemisphere the effect of the veering of the wind on the barometer is according to the following law : — With East, S.E., and South winds, the barometer falls. S.W. winds, the barometer ceases to fall and begins to rise. „ West, N.W., and North winds, the barometer rises. „ N.E. winds, the barometer ceases to rise and begins to fall. By the knowledge of the barometric pressure at a number of places 100 or 200 miles apart, we may know with considerable certainty a few hours in advance, from which direction the wind may be expected to blow at any place, according to the law discovered by, and bearing the name of, Professor Buys Ballot. The rule is, " Stand with your left hand towards the place where the barometric reading is lowest and your right hand towards where it is highest ; you will then have your back to the direction from which the wind may be expected to blow." This rule applies to the northern hemis phere but must be reversed in southern latitudes. Thermometer. — The thermometer in the northern hemisphere rises with East, S.E., and South winds. With a S.W. wind it ceases to rise and begins to fall. It falls with West, N.W., and North winds, with N.E. winds it ceases to fall and begins to rise. The signals are made with a cone and drum painted black, which, when hoisted, appear as a triangle and square ; thus ; — t Southerly gale. — The cone point downwards means that strong winds are probable, at first from the southward (from S.E. round by South to N.W.). i Northerly g*ale. — The cone point upwards means that Za strong winds are probable, first from the northward (from N.W. round by North to N.E.). Very heavy gales.— The drum is hoisted with the JL I cone whenever a very heavy gale, southerly or northerly as W ""r the case may be, is probable, (with southerly gales above the Y |p cone; with northerly gales below the Cone). The drum is not used without the cone. Sudden shifts Of Wind. — No signal is employed to indicate a wind which is likely to shift suddenly, but it must be remembered that a southerly wind is much more likely to veer to a point north ward of West, than a northerly wind is to veer to a point southward of East. Consequently, when the South cone is hoisted and a vessel is at an anchorage open to the N.W. it is well to be prepared for the gale being finally from that quarter. Meaning Of Signals. — The hoisting of any of these signals is intended as a sign that there is an atmospherical disturbance in existence which will probably cause a gale from the quarter indicated by the signal used, in the neighbourhood, say within a distance of 50 miles, of the place where the signal is hoisted, and the knowledge of which is likely to be of use to the sailors and fishermen on that part of the coast. Its meaning is simply, " look out ! It is probable that bad weather of such and such a character is approaching you." WEATHER SIGNALS.— The following weather signals, in addition to the established storm warnings, have been adopted at the semaphore stations and at the principal ports and shipping places on the coasts of France : — 1. A flag, of any colour, indicates — Weather doubtful, barometer in- clined to fall. 2. A short pendant (Cornet) „ Appearance of bad weather, heavy sea, barometer falling.

[Chap. I. 8 GENERAL OBSERVATIONS. 3. A pendant indicates — Appearance of better weather, barometer rising. 4. A flag above Cornet „ The entrance of the port has be- come dangerous. 5. A flag below Cornet „ The life-boat is coming out. Note. — In fine settled weather no signal is made. FRENCH TIDAL SIGNALS— The following system of tidal signals was issued in August 1855 by the French Minister of Commerce and Public Works, and is now, with some variations, used at all the ports on the coast of France. The signals are made by balls and flags hoisted on a mast, on which a yard is crossed. The balls are black. A ball hoisted at the intersection of the mast and yard denotes a least depth of 10 feet (English) throughout the channel of the harbour. Each ball hoisted on the mast beneath the first denotes an additional depth of 3£ feet. Each ball hoisted above the first denotes an additional depth of 6^ feet. Each ball hoisted at the left yard-arm, looking from seaward, denotes an additional 10 inches. Each ball hoisted at the right yard-arm denotes an additional 1 foot 8 inches. To indicate the state of the tide, a white flag with a black cross is used ; also, a black pendant. These are hoisted at the mast-head immediately there are 6^ feet in the channel and lowered when the water has receded to the same level. During the flood, the pendant is above the flag ; at high water and during the top of the tide, the pendant is hauled down ; and, during the ebb, the pendant is hoisted below the flag. When the state of the sea is such as to prevent vessels entering the port, these signals are replaced by a red flag hoisted at the mast-head. It should be remarked that the signals are not necessarily complete at all ports, but, so far as they are used, their significations are always the same. Thus, at some places the depths are shown only at every 3£ feet, in which cases balls at the yard-arms are not required. At others, the depth of 6| feet, together with the state of the tides, is indicated by the flag and pendant, a ball being hoisted below them when there are 10 feet. In this latter case the mast has no yard.

By night, a red light is exhibited ; and, in those harbours where a single light is already established, a second light is exhibited and both show red lights. FRENCH SYSTEM of BUOYAGE.— A uniform system of colouring all buoys and beacons is observed on the French coast. In entering a port, buoys and beacons painted red with a broad white band a little below the top must be left to starboard, and those painted black to port. Those which may be passed on either side are painted with alternate red and black horizontal bands. This distinctive colouring of beacons applies only to the portion above the level of the highest tides ; below that level, all beacons, whatever their position, are painted white; as are also all warping buoys. The colours red and black are varied as circumstances require by chequers, vertical stripes, &c, in white. The small rocky heads in the frequented channels are painted in the same manner as the beacons, but only on such a portion of their surface as to render them sufficiently conspicuous.

Every buoy or beacon marking the sides of a channel bears either in full length, or abbreviated characters, the name of the shoal or rock which it is meant to distinguish and also its number, showing its numerical order in the channel. These numbers commence from seaward ; the even numbers on the buoys and beacons painted red with a white band, and the odd numbers on the black buoys and beacons. Those painted with red and black bands have names only, but no numbers. The letters and numbers, from ten to twelve inches in length, are painted white on the most conspicuous parts of the buoys and beacons. The masts of these beacons which do not present sufficient surface are surmounted for this purpose by a small board. All the jetty heads and beacon turrets are painted above the half-tide level, and on the former a scale of metres is marked commencing from the same level. USHANT, Or ILE D'OUESSANT, lies 10 miles westward of the western extreme of the coast of France. It is about 4£ miles long W. by N. and E. by S., about 2 miles wide, and its highest part, towards the North-east, is 195 feet above the level of the sea. In fine weather, the island is visible from a distance of from 15 to 20 miles, the outline appearing rugged and uneven, and the shore composed of precipitous rocky cliffs of granite formation. (See view on Admiralty chart, No. 2694.) It is surrounded by dangers but has three bays in which small vessels find temporary shelter. There are two light houses on the island ; one at the north-eastern extreme, the other at the north-western. | The inhabitants, about 2,500 in number, are chiefly employed in rearing cattle and as fishermen ; many of the latter are well acquainted with, and can act as pilots for, the passages in the vicinity, rendered * The French Government has given notice, dated 21st May, 1887, that, at the fog signal stations on the French coast, it is not always possible to determine the existence of fog banks in the offing ; and, that nearly an hour may always elapse from the time it is considered necessary to use the fog signal until the signal is first made. Mariners are therefore cautioned that, when approaching the land in a fog. they should not rely implicitly on these fog signals, but should always use the lead, which, in nearly all cases, gives sufficient warning to avert danger. j See Admiralty Chart : — Channels between lie d'Ouessant and the mainland. Chap. I.] USHANT. 11 dangerous by the numerous hidden as well as apparent rocks and islets lying between the island and the mainland. The people, generally, speak pure Breton. The only village on the island is Lampaul or Portspaul, situated at the head of a bay on the south-western side. In other parts the houses are scattered, forming only small hamlets. A post-boat communicates with Conquet on the mainland, at which place the produce of the island, consisting of soda, grain, sheep, and poultry is disposed of. Supplies. — Wood is scarce, but water and other supplies can be obtained in moderate quantities ; for fuel, the natives find a substitute in dried seaweed. LIGHTS. — North-west Light. — On Creac'h point, at the north western extreme of the island, is a circular tower, with black and white horizontal bands, from which is exhibited an electric, group) flashing, ivhite light, at 223 feet above high water ; the groups show every 10 seconds, each group consisting of two flashes, separated by an interval of 2-| seconds ; the interval between the groups being 1\ seconds. The light should be visible in clear weather 21 miles, but the intensity of the flashes will enable the glare to be seen consider ably beyond that distance. North-east Light. — A conspicuous white lighthouse, 85 feet high, stands on the northern side of the Baie du Stiff, near the north eastern extreme of Ushant, from the staircase tower of which, at 267 feet above high water, is exhibited provisionally, pending the alterations now in progress in the light, a fixed white light visible 14 miles, between the bearings of S. 31° E., through west, and N. 57° E. This lighthouse consists of two round towers united : the illumin ating apparatus formerly used at the Creac'h point light is being trans ferred and will be the permanent apparatus for the North-east light. Fog Trumpet. — At the western point of the island, two thirds of a mile south-westward of the North-west lighthouse, is the fog signal station. From it, during foggy weather, a powerful fog trumpet is sounded every forty seconds, giving two blasts, each of three seconds1 duration, separated by an interval of two seconds. The sound may generally be heard 3 miles in calm weather (See note, page 10.) A Life-Boat is stationed at Lampaul. Semaphores. — By using the Commercial Code of Signals, passing vessels can communicate with either the semaphore on Creac'h point, or that on the N.E. point, and by this means telegraphic messages may be sent to all the countries of Europe.

12 [Chap. I. USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. Baie du Lampaul is the port of Ushant ; it is on the south western side of the island, and is exposed to the whole force of south-westerly gales. It is only used by small vessels, although the water is deep over a sandy bottom which shoals gradually towards its head, thus rendering anchors less liable to drag with a westerly wind. A high rock named the Corce, the summit of which never covers, lies in the middle of the bay. The dangers to be avoided in entering this bay are the Jument rock, a ledge named the Basse Bridy, and the Leurvas rocks. The Jument rock, which uncovers 19 feet at the lowest tides, lies W.S.W. 1^ miles from the Runiou beacon, which is near Runiou point — the southern extreme of Ushant ; from the rock, Belanger mill open a quarter of a point eastward of the Corce rock, bears N.E. \ E. ; Basse Bridy ledge bears West 1^ miles from the Runiou beacon ; and, Leurvas rock S.W. by W. | W. a long half mile from the northern horn of the bay. Ushant North-east lighthouse kept a little open northward of the Corce rock about E. by N. leads into Lampaul bay, between Basse Bridy ledge and Leurvas rock. There is anchorage in from 12 to 7 fathoms, sandy bottom, northward of the Corce, which may be rounded close-to on all sides, but the small coasters using this port pass south ward of it and anchor near the head of the bay, southward of the Men-ar-Blanc rocks, where a mooring buoy is placed for the con venience of those weighing and requiring to run a warp out. The bay is rarely without much swell. Pilots. — The pilots reside at Lampaul, but have nothing but small open boats ; consequently, with a south-westerly wind and a flood tide it is seldom possible for them to board vessels. Should a pilot be required, it is important to attract their attention by signal, as so many outward bound vessels not requiring them pass close to the island. Chaussee de Keller.— At 2 miles N.N.E. £ E. from the western extreme of Ushant, and 3 miles N.W. by W. \ W. from the North east lighthouse, is Basse Callet, a small patch of 11 fathoms, with from 21 to 28 fathoms close round it, forming the western extreme of the Chaussee de Keller, which is the chain or causeway of rocks extend ing N.W. by W. \ W. 1\ miles from the western part of Keller isle. The marks for Basse Callet are, the North-east lighthouse on with Keller isle S.E. by E. \ E. : and, Belanger mill, the most westerly mill of Ushant, on with the western end of Callet rock S. by E. E. Baie de Beninou, the entrance to which is between Keller isle and the North extreme of Ushant, affords good shelter during

Chap. I.] CHANNELS BETWEEN USHANT AND THE COAST. 13 southerly winds, in from 7 to 12 fathoms water, sand and rocky bottom, but is quite exposed to the northward. Baie du Stiff, on the north-eastern side of Ushant, affords tem porary anchorage for small vessels but is open to the eastward and even with westerly winds there is always a heavy swell. The dangers to be avoided on entering are, the Men-Corn, Douellan rocks, and Ligounec bank, off its southern point ; and, the Gorle-bian rock in the middle of the bay. The Men-Corn and Gorle-bian rocks uncover at half tide and are both marked by stone beacon turrets showing 6 feet above high water, springs. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, on the shores of Ushant at 3 h. 32 m. ; ordinary springs rise 19^ feet, neaps 13f feet. Off the north-western coast of the island, the flood sets N.E. ; the ebb, S.W. CHANNELS between USHANT and the COAST.*— Nearly the whole space between Ushant and the French coast is studded with islets, rocks, and shoals, particularly in the direction of St. Mathieu point, which bears S.E. by S. 16 miles from Ushant N.W. lighthouse. A vessel is south-westward of all these dangers so long as this lighthouse is open westward of Runiou beacon bearing N. by W. There are three deep channels through these dangers, the Passage du Fromveur, Chenal du Four, and Chenal de la Helle ; the first only should be taken by a stranger, as the others are very intricate, with sunken rocks lying nearly in the fairway. The tidal streams also are very strong, running 4^ knots at springs, the flood setting to the northward. f Passage du Fromveur runs parallel with the southern coast of Ushant, along which are many rocks and rocky patches, but none extend more than half a mile from the shore. The principal danger is on the southern side of the channel, off the broken rocky isle of Loedoc, from which a rocky ledge extends W.N.W. nearly half a mile, and at its extreme is Men Tensel, a detached rock which uncovers 15 feet at the lowest tides. Most of the rocks on this ledge, however, are visible at half ebb, and there is generally' broken water over them at other times, but care must be taken to avoid a sunken rock with only 12 feet, about 1^ cables north-westward of Men Tensel. The channel at this spot is less than a mile in width. I. take the direction of the channel, about E. by N. £ N. and W. by S. \ S., but they are so rapid as to alarm persons unused to its naviga tion, especially at springs, when the whole surface of the water has the appearance of breakers. Youc'h and Men-Corn should each be given a berth of 3 or 4 cables in passing, and when the N.E. lighthouse is on with Men-Corn, or lie de Bannec is opened east ward of Loedoc, a course may be steered to the north-eastward as desired. If from the North or North-eastward ; round the eastern end of Ushant about a mile distant, and, steering about W.S.W., pass within 3 or 4 cables of Men-Corn, Youc'h, and Men-ar-froud, as just de scribed. When abreast of Men-ar-foud, or when Loedoc is eastward of E.S.E., the chief danger on the southern side has been passed ; and, when the southern end of Bannec bears E. \ N. and the western end of Ushant N. by E. \ E., a course may be steered to clear the Saints ; or, if bound to Brest, a S. by E. \ E. course for 10 miles, due allowance being made for tide, and an occasional bearing of the Pierres Noires lighthouse is very useful for this purpose, leads westward of the Pierres Vertes, the highest of which uncovers 7 feet at low water, springs, and also of the westernmost patch of the Pierres Noires, on which there are 13 feet at that time. A course may then be steered towards the Goulet de Brest, with the lighthouse on Petit Minou point on with the lighthouse on Portzic point bearing East. Chenal du Four. — Notwithstanding its many dangers, this channel is much used by vessels passing between Brest and the Channel ports, not only on account of the distance saved, but also from the comparatively smooth water found within it during westerly winds. Its southern entrance is about one mile S.W. of cape St. Mathieu, and the leading mark through, after the Grande Vinotiere beacon turret has been passed, is, the lighthouse on Kermorvan point on with that on St. Mathieu point, bearing S. \ E. ; but, the naviga-

J FOUR AND HBLLB CHANNELS. — L'ABERILDUT. tion of the southern part of the channel, from the entrance to this point, is rendered difficult by the numerous dangers, of which the chief are, the Vieux Moines and Bossemens Orientales rocks, the Basse du Chenal marked by a red buoy, and Basse des Renards by a black buoy. A course of about N. by E. leads towards the Grande Vinotiere beacon turret, between which and a rock with only 12 feet water westward of the Petite Vinotiere, and only a quarter of a mile south-eastward of the Grande Vinotiere, a vessel should pass, then hauling more eastward to bring the leading mark on, which mark must be strictly maintained to avoid the numerous shoals at the northern entrance, until the Four lighthouse bears E. by N. The St. Paul, Tendoc, and Valbelle shoals are passed close to on the starboard hand, and each is marked by a black buoy ; whilst the Basse St. Pierre, Chaussee des Pourceaux, and Platresses red buoys are left on the port hand. Chenal de la Helle lies westward of the Four channel, from which it is separated by the Platresses, a rocky ledge three quarters of a mile long North and South. The direction of this channel is about N.N.W. £ W. and S.S.E. E., and it unites with the Four channel about 2 miles northward of Kermorvan point. The COAST between Ushant and lie de Bas, 43 miles to the eastward, is moderately high and in clear weather may be seen from 15 to 18 miles off ; it is, however, fronted with rocks, some of which are nearly 3 miles in the offing and from a distance have the appearance of houses. Unless absolutely necessary, it is prudent to give this part of the coast a berth of 5 or 6 miles, especially at night when it should not be approached within a depth of from 46 to 36 fathoms ; the bottom at this depth is grey sand mixed with small pebbles, of various colours, resembling nuts. When it blows hard on a weather tide, a berth of at least 2 miles should be given to the northern coast of the ile de Bas, to avoid crossing the race or overfall produced by the uneven bottom extend ing from its northern shore. Tidal Streams. — Between Ushant and lie de Bas, the flood stream sets East and the ebb West. In the offing the flood turns about 2f hours after the time of high water at Porsal, which, at full and change, is about 4 h. 0 m. L'ABERILDUT.— The entrance to this tidal port bears E. by S. i S. nearly 11 miles from the eastern point of Ushant, and S. | E 3[, miles from the Four rock ; it is the only place between Brest and the river Abervrac'h where vessels drawing from 13 to 14 feet can

[Chap. I. 16 USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. enter at high water, springs, and be perfectly sheltered from all winds. At low water, the port dries completely out 2 cables beyond the entrance, but, the bottom being soft sand, vessels lie aground with great safety. It is much frequented by Brest pilots and fishermen from the adjoining coast ; a considerable trade is also carried on, the principal exports being stone and sand ; a great deal of the stone used in the Thames Embankment came from here. Directions. — To enter l'Aberildut ; when about 2 miles off the entrance, bring the tower of Breles church, seen amongst the trees about 2 miles inland, on with the tower of Lanildut church E. f S. ; this mark leads up to the entrance, passing about one cable northward of the Pierre de Laber rock, which uncovers 12 feet at low water and is marked by a beacon turret, and between the Trois Pierres on the North and Men-Garo rock on the South, which latter covers at equinoctial tides only. On arriving at the entrance, which is about 150 yards wide, pass about 50 yards southward of a black rock connected with the northern point of entrance by a jetty ; run on, keeping about 50 or 60 yards from the northern shore, and on rounding the point which forms the western side of the port of Laber, if having come in for shelter only, anchor when abreast of the first houses in that village ; but, if going to take in or discharge cargo, proceed on up to the quay where the grounding places are excellent, the bottom being sand and mud. The tide runs very strongly to the S.W. across the entrance during the first hour of the ebb, requiring a fresh breeze to stem it. It is advisable for a stranger to take a pilot, or, as there are none specially belonging to the port, fishermen do equally well. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in l'Aberildut at 3 h. 58 m. ; the tide rises 16 feet at ordinary springs, and 9f feet at neaps, above the grounding places off Laber, where the bottom dries about 9 feet at the lowest tides. Le FOUR is a large and remarkable black rock, broad at the top and 17 feet high, lying N.W. \ W. about a mile from Melgorne point, the north-western extreme of the coast of France ; and, E. \ S. 10^ miles from Ushant North-east lighthouse. LIGHT. — From a lighthouse on the Four rock, 85 feet high from base to vane, is exhibited, at 92 feet above high water, a light showing fixed white during thirty seconds, followed during the next thirty secoiuls by a group of eight distinct flashes with an eclipse between each flash ; thus the light is alternately fixed and flashing ; in clear weather, it is visible from a distance of 15 miles.

Chap. I.] ARGENTON.— PORSAL ROCKS AND PORT. 17 Fog Trumpet. — During thick or foggy weather, a steam trumpet sounds a blast of five seconds' duration, followed by an interval of silence of twenty seconds. (See note, page 10.) Argenton. — E. by S. \ S. about 1^ miles from the Four lighthouse, is the entrance to this little harbour, which dries at low water but has a bottom of sand and mud and is completely land-locked. The only practicable channel to the entrance is between the Four rocks and the Petit Melgorne, but its approaches are so barred by dangers as to render it hazardous for even the smallest vessels to attempt except in the hands of a skilful local pilot. A rather extensive fishery exists here, and the coasting trade is carried on by about 60 small vessels calling annually. Semaphore. — One and a quarter miles northward of the entrance to Argenton is a semaphore station on point Landunvez. ROCHES de PORSAL.— The body of this entensive ledge lies 4 miles north-eastward from the Four lighthouse and 5 miles west ward from the entrance of the Abervrac'h river ; the greater part of the rocks are covered at high water. The shoal patches on the outer part of the ledge extend 2\ miles, and the rocks that uncover, 1| miles from the coast. There is anchorage amongst, and several passages through them, but the navigation is too intricate to be attempted without a pilot. Tidal Streams. — Off the Porsal rocks, the tides turn two hours before high and low water by the shore. At springs, they set about East and West at the rate of 3 or 4 knots, and 5 knots or more near the shore, where they also turn half an hour sooner. Portsal Or Porsal. — This port, which is fronted by the rocb.es de Porsal, comprises three distinct bays ; at the head of the first stands the village of Portsal, the second is the bay iof Kersaint, and the third that of Tremazan, or du Chateau. The harbour is dry through out its whole extent by three quarters ebb, and vessels of 13 feet draught can enter only at spring tides ; the bottom is generally of sand, but a mass of rocks which cover only at high tides occupy the middle of the harbour. In bad weather, the swell and surf within the port are so great as to render it dangerous. There are no wharfs approachable by vessels, and loading or discharging is done by boats when the tide suits. Notwithstanding all its disadvantages, the vicinity of the large town of Ploudalmezeau causes a considerable and growing trade, 60 or 80 vessels unloading annually ; it has also an extensive fishery. 18 USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. [Chap. I. Several channels lead to Portsal but all are intricate and none should be attempted without a pilot. The leading mark for the South or inner channel is, lurch rock just closed in by Men Gouziane E.N.E. ; both of these rocks are marked by beacons. From the North-west, the leading mark through the reefs to the inner channel is lurch rock on with Ploudalmezeau spire. Life-Boat. — A life-boat is stationed at Portsal. CAUTION.— The coast in the vicinity of Porsal and Four rocks is of moderate height, but being bordered by numerous dangers it should not be approached at night or in thick weather within the depth of 45 fathoms ; the bottom at that depth is generally of grey sand mixed with flint and other stones. L'Aberbenoit. — Between Portsal and l'Abervrac'h is a deep bight encumbered by rocks and shoals, into which the river Aber benoit flows, forming a harbour of but little importance, but approached by a deep entrance channel on either side of the plateau de Rusven, a reef which dries in places at low water. The eastern passage is the broadest and deepest, but, with westerly winds, the western passage is preferred, as it gives more room to clear the broken water caused by the lie Guennoc. L'ABERVRAC'H. — The entrance to this river, nearly 6 miles eastward of Portsal and 4 miles westward of Correjou bay, is difficult of access, being much encumbered by numerous shoals, islets, and rocks. It, however, affords good shelter to wind-bound ships ; the outer roadstead is just within the entrance and about 1^ cables south eastward of the beacon on the Petit Pot-de-Beurre rock ; it has from 6 to 8 fathoms water over a sandy bottom. The inner road is 1^ miles in a S.S.E. £ E. direction from the outer road, and the least depth is 5 fathoms, except 1£ cables north-eastward of Cezon isle, where there are only 2\ fathoms. The whole space between the outer and inner roads affords good anchorage to vessels of the largest size. The roads are separated from the port by a mole about 260 yards in length, where vessels discharge cargo and where water may be obtained. There are also two beaching places on the left bank of the river, one in Anges bay, the other a little farther eastward in St. Antoine bay ; the bottom in both bays is soft mud and dries 6^ feet above the lowest tides. Great expense has been incurred in the beacons, lights, and buoyage of this harbour, but since the increase of steam navigation its trade steadily declines, though a large number of boats are engaged in the fisheries.

This light is 59 feet above high water, and in clear weather is visible from a distance of 6 miles. A. fixed white light from a white square tower on Lanvaon heights, which bears S.E. by E. \ E. If miles from the tower on Vrac'h ile. This light is 171 feet above high water, is visible through an arc of 36° from a distance of 14 miles, and when in line with the light on Vrac'h ile leads through the Grand chenal to the entrance of the Abervac'h. Two fixed lights are also exhibited on the left or western bank of the river, one white, at the head of St. Antoine creek ; the other green, on the eastern point of Palue beach ; when in line, they show the direction of the inner anchorage. These*lights, elevated respec tively 49 and 29 feet above high water, are visible 11 and 8 miles. Life-Boat. — A life-boat is stationed at Vrac'h ile. DIRECTIONS. — The Abervrac'h river can be entered by three channels, all of which are accessible to the heaviest ships at high water, and one, the Grand chenal, is available at any time of tide ; it leads in from the westward passing southward of Libenter ledge. The Chenal de la Malouine leads in from the northward between Malouine and Pendante ledges. The third is the Pendante channel between Libenter ledge and the Pendante ; its navigation is difficult, and should not be attempted without a pilot. The Grand Chenal is practicable for vessels of the deepest draught with a fair wind, and wide enough for coasters to turn through. In approaching it from the westward, as soon as they are seen, bring the steeple of Plouguerneau church and the white light towers on Vrac'h ile and on Lanvaon heights in line,, or, at night, the white and red lights in line bearing S.E. by E. \ E., which is the leading mark in ; but, when coming from the northward, the steeple of Ploudalmezeau church must be kept well open westward of the steeple of Lampaul church S.S.W. until the leading mark is on, in order to pass westward of the western patches of Libenter ledge ; there are never less than 25 feet on these patches, but a heavy sea runs over them in bad weather. In running through this channel, the leading mark must be kept exactly on, for although the vessel passes 1\ cables southward of the south extreme of Libenter ledge, which is marked by a black buoy B 2

This being the line of direction for the inner anchorage a berth may be taken as convenient, mooring N.W. and S.E. ; or, if capable of taking the ground, the vessel can steer for one of the beaching places. The Malouine Channel is about 120 yards wide at the narrowest part and can only be used with a leading wind. The beacon turret on the Petit Pot-de-Beurre exactly on with that on the Petite lie de la Croix S. by W. £ W. leads through in not less than 20 feet ; the beacon on the Petit Pot-de-Beurre should be passed close to on the starboard hand, when the vessels may anchor in the outer roads or proceed to the inner anchorage as before directed. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the entrance of the river Abervrac'h at 4h. 14m. ; equinoctial springs rise 29 feet, ordinary springs 22 feet, ordinary neaps 16 feet, and neaps range 10 feet. A He Vierge is a mass of rocks but little?above the level of the sea and without any vegetation ; between it and the shore is a passage used by coasters and small craft only, and also the little bay of Portz- Malo where they anchor close to the shore and ground as the tide falls. lie Vierge lies 2 miles eastward of the entrance to the river Abervrac'h, and N.W. by W. \ W. 2£ miles from the western point of Correjou bay; it may be recognised from some distance by the square lighthouse erected 109 yards from its eastern extreme. ILE VIERGE LIGHT.— The lighthouse exhibits, at 108 feet above high water, a fixed white light varied every four minutes by a red flash, preceded and followed by a short eclipse. The light, which is of the third order, is an excellent guide for the entrance to Abervrac'h and also for Correjou bay ; it is visible in clear weather from a distance of 17 miles ; the eclipses do not appear total within the distance of 6 miles. From ile Vierge, the lighthouse on Bec-pol, Pontusval, bears E. \ S. nearly 9 miles ; the shoals fronting this part of the coast, of which the principal are the Plateau du Lizen-Ven, Plateau du Guern, Plateau d'Aman-ar-Ross, and the Basses St. Tregarec, extend li

In coming from the westward, a vessel will clear all these shoals by keeping the tower of Ploudalmezeau church well open westward of ile Vierge until the lighthouse on Bec-pol bears S.E. by E. CORREJOU BAY.— In the western part of the bight named, is Correjou Bay ; Penenes isle lies in its northern part, and close north-eastward of the isle is Penvers ledge, which covers at high water with the" exception of three heads, one at its southern, the second at its eastern, and the third at its northern extreme. A short distance eastward of the eastern head is the north-western end of the Bazughen ledge, which from thence trends a quarter of a mile in a south-easterly direction, its highest head uncovering 10 feet at the lowest tides. The Garrec-Crom ledge, northward of the Bazughen, covers at high water with the exception of one head at its eastern extreme. The anchorage in this bay is south-eastward of Penvers ledge, and the depth is from 13 to 19 feet at low water, springs. The beaching place is southward of Penenes isle ; the bottom here is of sand, and it rises gradually towards the coast, at the foot of which it dries 16 feet above the lowest tides. Directions. — Correjou bay may be entered by two channels, the Western and Eastern channels ; the Western channel is between the coast and the southern part of the Lizen-Ven ledge ; the Eastern channel is between the Guern ledge and a ledge named the Chaussee de Carrec-Hir. To enter by the western channel, steer to the southward with the lighthouse on Vierge isle on a S. by W. bearing until the guard-house of Kerisoc is on with the northern head on Penvers ledge S.E. \ E. Proceed with this mark on until half way between this rock and the Andolven rocks, when ile Vierge lighthouse seen over a remarkable gap or cleft in the Andolven rocks, just to the left of the most northern rock, becomes the mark, and, passing northward of Penvers ledge, leads between Garrec-Crom and the Bazughen, and about 22 yards northward of a 4-feet patch nearly in mid-channel. Vessels may ancher in about 16 feet, sand, with this mark on, when Penven and Mean-Yan are in line. Do not haul more to the south ward for an anchorage before the highest head on the Garrec-Crom is northward of N.N.E., for the south-eastern head of the Bazughen bears S.S.W. from this head ; and, in steering to the southward, the highest head of the Garrec-Crom must not be brought more easterly than N. by E. \ E. so long as the southern head on Penvers ledge is

[Chap. I. 22 USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. shut in southward of the North point of the bay. The swell is much felt in this bay above half tide, and, as no marks can be given for leaving it at night, it should only be used in the finest weather. The leading mark through the eastern channel is the steeple of Plouguerneau church on with the Mean-Yan rock bearing S.S.W. \ W. ; this rock is on the south-eastern edge of the Guern ledge and uncovers 23 feet. The mark leads in not less than 7 fathoms until the vessel is about 1^ cables from the Mean-Yan, when steer a little to port to pass eastward of it. After clearing the south-eastern edge of the ledge, bring Plouguerneau church steeple to bear as before, and it will lead close westward of the Garrec-Crom, when proceed as before directed. Semaphore. — About a mile eastward of the anchorage in Correjou bay is a semaphore station on pointe de Kerisoc. Between the Baie de Correjou and Pontusval are the small tidal harbours of Treisseny and Kerlouan, of little or no importance. LIGHT. — On Bec-pol, Pontusval point, stands a square lighthouse, from whence, at 59 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed white light, with a red sector between the bearings S.E. by E. f E. and E. by N. % N. showing over the Basses St. Tregarec and the shoals westward, but which does not cover all the shoal ground when approached within 2 miles. The light is visible from a distance of 12 miles. PONTUSVAL, the entrance to which port is about one mile eastward of the lighthouse on Bec-pol and 1£ miles north-westward of the Greve de Goulven, is the only place on this part of the coast where the crew of a vessel, driven on a lee shore, could hope to be saved. It berths a large number of coasters, but the bottom is hard, and, in strong gales from the northward, it is not an unfrequent occurrence to see them wrecked at their anchors. The port completely dries out at low water as far as abreast of the western entrance point, and, from thence, the bottom gradually rises to the head of the port. A vessel is moderately well sheltered on the eastern side of the port in a little bay named La Chambre, in which the bottom dries 13^ feet above the lowest tides. The least depth in the entrance channel, until abreast of the western entrance point, is 13 feet; but, as the channel is bordered on both sides by sunken rocks and crossed obliquely by the tidal streams, it is not safe to enter without a pilot, and then only with a fair wind. Telegraph Cable.— The telegraph cable from Salcombe is landed at this port.

Chap. I.] 23 PONTUSVAL. — ANSE DE KERNIC. A Life-Boat is stationed at this port. Directions. — To enter Pontusval ; when about half a mile from the entrance, steer to the southward with the beacon on the eastern shore of the port, eastward of the Custom-house office, exactly on with the steeple of Plouneour church S. by W. W. This mark leads between the two rocks Blanche de l'entree and Ar-Neuden, only one third of a cable apart ; the former is on the western side of the entrance and its summit is always above water ; the latter, which has on it a beacon turret painted black with a short staff and ball, and 8 feet above the level of the highest tides, is on the eastern side and uncovers 12^ feet. When abreast of the Blanche de l'entree, steer a little more to starboard, to pass nearly midway between the Blanche du centre and Vran rocks ; the former lies on the western side of the channel and never covers, the latter on the eastern side and uncovers 27 feet. Pass rather nearer the Blanche than the Vran, and when near the Blanche du dedans, a rock one cable south-westward of Blanche du centre, steer for the Custom-house office on a S. by W. \ W. bearing and it will lead into La Chambre, on the eastern side of the port. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in port Pontusval at 4h. 25m., and the tide rises in La Chambre about 16^ feet at equi noctial springs, and 5 feet at neaps ; here the bottom dries 13j feet above the level of the lowest tides. The COAST. — From the lighthouse on Bec-pol, Pontusval, ile de Bas lighthouse bears E. |- S. 13J miles ; between the two are the Greve de Goulven, Anse de Kernic, Port Nevez, and other small bays and creeks, places of little or no importance, and so incumbered by rocks and shoals as to be very dangerous to approach. The most outlying shoal in the neighbourhood is Queyn Cos, with 3rj fathoms, its outer extreme is 2§ miles from the nearest land, and E. N. 4£ miles from Pontusval light. Greve de Goulven. — This deep sandy bay affords shelter from westerly winds to vessels that can take the ground, but it is difficult of access, its entrance being full of rocks. ANSE de KERNIC, or, as it is sometimes called, the port de Plouescat, has a narrow entrance choked by rocks awash ; it has a sandy bottom which dries at half tide, but, at high water, springs, there are from 6 to 15 feet ; it is reported to be gradually silting up, and much land has been reclaimed from the sea on its borders. It is used only by vessels of from 60 to 80 tons, but having neither quay nor wharf, they discharge cargo into carts alongside when left by the tide.

Approaching the anchorage from the westward, bring the spire of St. Pol-de-Leon college on with the Querelevran rock, which lies one cable southward of the western point of the isle, and anchor in from 5 to 6 fathoms, sand, when Golc'hedec rock, 2 cables north westward of the isle, bears N.N.E. 3 or 4 cables distant. ILE de BAS, or ile de Batz as it is frequently called, is a low Island not visible from the deck of a vessel at a greater distance than 9 miles, though the lighthouse near its western end may be seen much farther ; it lies immediately off the promontory of Roscoff, and when bearing S.S.W. becomes blended with the coast, from which it is only separated by a channel less than 7 cables wide at its narrowest part. It is about 2 miles long E.S.E. and W.N.W., and one mile wide ; it is bordered on its western, northern, and eastern sides by rocks and shoals extending from half a mile to a mile from the shore, one of the most prominent of which is the Penven, always above water, 4 cables northward from the central northern point of the isle, but most of the rocks cover at high water. From ile de Bas lighthouse, Pontusval light bears W. \ N. 13 J miles, and Triagoz light E. | N. 16£ miles.* LIGHT. — The circular lighthouse erected on a mound half a mile from the western end of the ile de Bas, exhibits a revolving ivhite light of the first order, which attains its greatest brilliancy every minute. The light is 223 feet above high water, and is visible in clear weather from- a distance of 22 miles ; in ordinary weather, the eclipses do not appear total within the distance of 12 miles. Semaphore.— There is a Semaphore station on the ile de Bas. * See Admiralty chart : Ile de Bas and adjacent islands, No. 2,745 ; scale, m = 5 • nches.

Chap. I.] iLE DE BAS — CHANNEL BETWEEN IT AND COAST. 25 The island has a population of about 1200, and on its southern side is the village and harbour of Porz Kernoch. The harbour is formed on its western side by a mole 570 yards in length connecting the shore with the Mai voch rock, marked on its south-eastern edge by a beacon; and, on its eastern side, by a short jetty connecting that shore with the ile aux Moutons. The harbour dries at low water, has 6 feet at half tide, and 19 feet at high water, springs ; it is but little used now, the coasting trade decreasing with the growth of steam navigation and improved means of land transport. A Life-Boat is stationed at the western end of the ile de Bas. CHANNEL between ILE de BAS and the COAST.— On account of its difficult navigation, this narrow channel is not much frequented except by vessels of light draught calling at Porz Kernoch or Roscoff. Vessels drawing about 19 feet may, however, if necessary, run through it with a fair wind at high water, slack. Anchorage. — The anchoring ground in this channel is comprised between the meridians of the chapel of Notre Dame de Bon Secours and the village of Porz Kernoch, and the depth is from 2 to 4^ fathoms. There is a long and narrow swashway with from 11 to 15 feet between the northern edge of the Traverse, a shallow shifting sand bank which bounds the anchorage eastward, and the sand-bank bordering the southern side of the isle ; and, although the stream here runs with great strength, coasters prefer it to the anchorage just described, as they are well sheltered, and, if necessary, can beach on the sands in Porz Kernoch, where the bottom dries only 6 or 7 feet at the lowest tides. Directions. — When bound through the channel between ile de Bas and the coast from the westward, Ste. Barbe western obelisk on with the white patch on the Loup rock S.E. f E. easterly, leads north ward of the Lavandieres rocks, which never cover, in not less than 5 fathoms towards the red beacon on the Oignon rock, which uncovers 22 feet and must be left to the southward. When about a cable west ward of this rock, or when the eastern mill on ile de Bas and the little pyramid beacon on Kernoch isle (seen over the mole) are in line, steer E.S.E. for the anchorage, leaving the red beacon on the Tehi bihan rock also on the starboard hand ; or, if not going to anchor, steer for point Pen-ar-Chleguer until the western mill (westward of Kernoch village) is on with Kernoch pyramid beacon ; this leads between Pen-ar-Chleguer point and Per Roc'h, marked by a black beacon turret, it also leads southward of the beacons of An-Oan and

ROSCOFF— This little tidal harbour is about a mile S.S.E. from the south-eastern extreme of ile de Bas ; it is formed by a mole or breakwater of solid construction extending with an outward curve from the western shore a distance of 575 yards. Works are also constructed at Penar-Vil, on the opposite side, to break the force of the sea during north-easterly gales ; in bad weather, however, the swell within the harbour is so great as to cause incon venience and even danger. The town has a population of about 2000, and a thriving trade is carried on by vessels up to 200 tons, both English and French ; fruit, vegetables, fish, &c, are the chief exports. The grounding places within the harbour dry from 12 to 19 feet at the lowest tides ; the breakwater affords the only quay accommodation. LIGHTS.— A fixed ivhite light, 22 feet above high water, visible 7 miles, is exhibited from an iron standard on the extreme end of the mole. A. fixed red light, 38 feet above high water, visible 8 miles, is shown on the south-western shore of the harbour. The two lights in line is the leading mark into the harbour by the northern channel. Directions. — Roscoff has several intricate approaches for fishing craft ; two channels only are available for vessels of from 150 to 200 tons, viz., that from ;he eastward, and that from the direction of the anchc:T,^e within ile Pighet ; for which latter, the leading mark by day is, the white spot on the magazine at the head of the harbour

The bays are separated from each other by Primel point, westward of which is Morlaix bay, with the entrances to the rivers Morlaix and Penze or St. Pol-de-Leon at its head ; and, eastward, the little harbour of Locquirec and the river Lannion. PLATEAU de la MELOINE is a group of rocky heads with deep water between them, commencing N. by E. 1^ miles from Primel point, extending 5 miles in an E. by N. \ N. direction and forming a most dangerous obstacle to navigation, especially to vessels

Barbe chapel, is on with the steeple of Roscoff church N.W. \ N. the vessel is at the entrance of the river and should proceed no farther without a pilot.
