Chap. I.] ST. POL-DE LEON.— MORLAIX. 29 Primel point. Two principal channels lead into it, the eastern or Chenal de Treguier, and the western or Grand Chenal ; the former, although not so deep as the latter, is generally preferred by coasters as its width admits of tacking. The channels unite between the isles Louet and Noire, which are half a mile apart, from whence the single channel takes a S. \ E. direction for 3 miles to the spot where it is joined by the little river Dourdu. Above this are quays on either side where vessels may lie aground, and a small gridiron, and still higher is the lock entrance to the wet dock or basin, nearly a mile in length, with a width of from 82 to 193 feet, and a depth of from 8f feet at the upper to 16f feet at the lower end. The dimen sions of the lock are much more than equal to the requirements of the basin. At the head of the basin is the town of Morlaix, with a population of about 16,000, and a railway station on the line connecting Rennes with Brest. The railway here crosses the river on a granite viaduct on 14 arches ; it is 973 feet in length and 183 feet above the level of the quays. The trade of the port is not large and decreases ; it is carried on by vessels averaging 70 or 80 tons, about 400 entering the port annually. A few small steamers also use the port, and vessels of large size the roadstead.* LIGHTS. — To enable vessels to enter Morlaix river at night, three lights are exhibited ; one from Noire islet, lying just within the entrance of the river, 4 cables south-eastward of Chateau du Taureau isle and half way between it and point Barnenez ; another from Louet isle If cables from point Pen Lann ; and, the third from Lande tower on the left or western bank of the river. Noire isle light is a fixed white light, varied every two minutes by a bright flash, preceded and followed by a short eclipse ; it is 46 feet above high water, and visible from a distance of 12 miles. Louet isle light is 52 feet above high water, fixed white, and visible 9 miles. Lande light tower exhibits, at 285 feet above high water, a fixed white light, visible in clear weather 15 miles. Louet isle light on with Lande light tower S. by W. £ W. westerly leads up to the Grand Chenal, but passes eastward of ile Ricard. Noire isle light on with Lande tower light S.S.W. \ W. leads through the Treguier channel. *See Admiralty chart, channels and road of Morlaix, No. 2,744 ; scale, m 5 inches.

30 USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. [Chap. I- Besides these three lights, a small fixed red light is shown from the southern side of Chateau du Taureau isle, over the northern part of Morlaix road. Fog Signal. — In foggy weather, a bell is sounded from Noire isle every quarter of an hour for a space of two minutes. When this bell is heard at Chateau du Taureau isle, the bell at that isle is also sounded. (See note, page 10.) Approaching Morlaix, or whilst waiting for a pilot, it is useful to know that with the whole of ile de Bas open northward of Tisaoson, a double-headed rocky islet three quarters of a mile from the eastern end of the ile de Bas, a vessel is northward of all the shoals in the mouth of the bay. DIRECTIONS.— Entering by the Grand Chenal into Morlaix river, steer towards the eastern end of ile de Bas until Tisaoson isle is seen. Having passed between the beacon turret on Astan rock and the black buoy off the Trepieds, 4^ miles apart ; with Tisaoson bearing W. by N. about 3 miles, and the beacon turret on the Duon rocks W.S.W. about 1^ miles, the vessel will be at the entrance of the channel and more than half a mile N.E. E. from the Basse N.E. du Pot-de-Fer, a 4-feet patch marked by a red buoy E. | N. 2^ cables from the Pot-de-Fer rock which uncovers 7 feet at the lowest tides. From this rock, Louet isle lighthouse is just open westward of Ricard isle S. 5 W. ; and, the beacon turret of the Duon rocks is on with the chapel midway between St. Pol-de- Leon and Roscoff. Lande light tower on with Louet isle lighthouse S. by W. \ W. westerly leads through the Grand chenal eastward of the Pot-de-Fer and Duon rocks, and between the Vielle rock which dries 23 feet and is marked by a red beacon turret, and the Stolvezen, a 1-foot patch marked by a black buoy on its northern edge. Vessels of light draught with a fair wind, or steamers with a proper rise of tide according to their draught, may continue with this leading mark on until abreast of the Calhic rock turret, passing eastward of Ricard isle and close to the beacon off its north-eastern end, as well as to that on the Marlouine rock which dries 4 feet at low water, springs. This is the narrowest part of the channel, as, only one third of a cable from the Marlouine rock, a small plateau of rocks on the opposite side is awash at low water. Before entering the narrows at Ricard ile, the Roche d'Equinoxe, with 1\ fathoms, lies exactly on the line of the leading mark ; it is easily avoided by opening the Lande light-tower westward of Louet isle lighthouse until past it.

Chap. I.] 31 MORLAIX. When abreast of the beacon on Calhic rock, steer about South to pass between the beacon on the Corbeau rock and that on the western part of the ledge extending from the northern end of Chateau du Taureau islet, and then S. E. past Louet isle and the red buoy marking the north-eastern edge of the Barre de slot ledge. When southward of Louet isle and clear of the Barre de slot, anchor as convenient in Morlaix road. Vessels of deep draught should pass westward of Ricard isle ; for which purpose, when abreast of Vezoul isle, they should quit the line of Louet and Lande light towers in line, and bring the Pierre de Carentec (white) on with the white gable of Kergrist farmhouse S.S.W. j W. westerly ; this leads between the Petit-Ricard and Noire rocks, both of which have beacons on them, and passes half a cable eastward of Fourche and Courgik beacons. When near the latter rock, which uncovers 14 feet, steer to bring the Paradis white beacon turret on with that of l'Enfer or Trepied Jaune S.S.E., which leads between the foul ground south-westward of Ricard isle and the Bezinnennou beacon up to the . Calhic rock, from whence the directions already given lead to Morlaix road. Caution. — Both the Calhic and Corbeau rocks extend a consider able distance from their beacon turrets into the channel, and great care is required in passing them. From the direction of the ile de Bas, the Grand chenal may be entered by passing southward of the Duon rocks ; for which the leading mark is, ile Pighet beacon turret on with the Moulin de l'Est, ile de Bas, N.W. This line passes close north-eastward of the Menk, Bisayers, Cochons noirs, and Vielle shoals, and leads up to the leading mark for the Grand chenal. Treguier Channel. — Vessels intending to enter by this channel must ascertain that the tide has risen sufficiently to enable them to pass over the shallow flat, nearly awash at the lowest tides, lying in the narrows of the channel, and a mile in extent north-eastward and south-westward of Blanche isle. If coming either from the west ward or eastward outside all the shoals, bring Lande light tower on with Noire isle lighthouse S.S.W. h W. as soon as they are seen ; this leads half a mile westward of the black buoy on the Trepieds ledge ; eastward of the Pierre Noire, Tourghi, Grand Areman, and Chambre rocks, all marked by beacons ; and, westward of the Jaune, Cadou, Vielle Chambre, and Plate rocks, and also of the beacons on Petit Aremen, Menheur, and Blanche isle. The Pierre Noire dries 5i feet, Tourghi 13 feet, Grand Aremen 13 feet, and Chambre 5^ feet ;

32 [Chap. I. USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. Cadou 12£ feet, Vielle Chambre 1£ feet, Petit Aremen 8 feet, and Menheur 13 feet. When abreast of the beacon on Blanche isle, steer W.S.W. until the western part of Ricard isle touches the eastern part of Chateau du Taureau isle S. £ E. easterly, which is the line of direction for Morlaix road and also for the channel of the river. Entering by this channel at night, bring Lande fixed ivhite light on with Noire isle fixed and flashing ivhite light S.S.W. \ W., to clear the reefs as before directed. Follow this line until the red light on the southern face of the Chateau du Taureau bears West, then steer towards it, keeping it on the starboard bow until it bears North, when the vessel will be in Morlaix road and may anchor as convenient. When near the Jaunes rock in the Treguier channel, or the Fourche beacon in the Grand chenal, vessels may, if necessary, change from one channel to the other, the leading mark for this purpose being, the beacon turret on ile de Callot open southward of the Colombier rock. Pilots. — Though the channels leading to Morlaix road and river are well marked by buoys, beacons, and lights, they are so narrow and intricate that a stranger should always take a pilot. Tides.— It is high water, full and change, .in Morlaix road at 4 h. 53 m. ; equinoctial springs rise about 31 feet ; ordinary springs 24 feet ; ordinary neaps 18 feet, and neaps range 12 feet. Tidal Signals, see page 8, should be made from Noire isle light house, but they are not attended to with regularity. It is better to trust to the indications afforded by the height of the water on the various rocks ; for instance, when the Cadou rock covers there are 17 feet in the Treguier channel. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on the high land, about one mile southward of Primel point and on the eastern side of Primel harbour. Anse de Primel.— When leaving Morlaix river for Lannion road, 10 miles E. by S. from Primel point, a vessel will pass the little harbour of Primel lying just westward of the point ; it has a very narrow entrance, vessels passing close to the Zamegues rock 38 feet above low water, and still closer to the red beacon on the Raoul rock where is the narrowest part and within which is a small anchorage where vessels of considerable draught may lie afloat at all times but the holding ground is very bad, and the few small craft which use this harbour usually ground on sandy bottom higher up the bay

Chap. I.] 33 MORLAIX. — PRIMEL. — COAST. — LANNION. Strong northerly winds cause much swell within the harbour, and, at such times, the entrance is frequently closed by breakers. Vessels bound for Lannion road may pass northward of the Chaises de Primel rocks by the marks given at page 28, and when these rocks bear S.S.W. they may steer about E.S.E. to pass a cable southward of the Taureau rock which lies in front of Lannion roads and uncovers 28 feet at the lowest tides. The steeple of Guiodel church, on the left bank of the river Lannion, a little open north ward of the guard-house on Serves point, the northern point of the river entrance, or, by night, keeping within the white sector of Begleguer light, leads to the anchorage in the roads, which is exposed to the westward, but well sheltered from North round by East and South to S.W. The Coast between Primel point and the Lannion river is foul and bordered with dangers. S.E. by E. \ E. 7 miles from Primel point is Locquirec, a little tidal harbour formed by partially enclosing a small bay on the eastern side of the promontory of that name by throwing out a stone pier about 130 yards in a south-westerly direction ; it affords indifferent shelter to a few small craft. Toul an-Hery, also an inconsiderable port, lies at the bottom of the sandy bay adjoining Locquirec, where the little river Douron falls into the sea. Toul-an-Hery affords better shelter than Locquirec, but it is more difficult of access. South-eastward from Locquirec point is pointe de Plestin with another deep sandy bay beyond ; and, N.E. \ N. 3i miles from Locquirec point is the Taureau rock off the bay of Lannion. The Farou and Felestrec, two dangerous rocks uncovering from 4 to 6 feet at low water, springs, lie between Locquirec and Lannion bay ; Lesangar mill on with point Landevelin leads westward of them and up to the entrance of Lannion river. Lannion roads and port. — The dangers in approaching Lannion are numerous but well marked. On the northern side the Crapeaud rock, 3£ miles north-westward from point Bihit, dries 13 feet at low water, springs, and has a beacon turret, as has also the Four rock which dries 12 feet ; and, a black conical buoy is moored westward of the f-fathom patch lying westward of the Crapeaud beacon turret ; the Taureau reef uncovers 28 feet. On the southern side is the red turret on the Kinierbel rock. The anchorage in the roads is in from 7 to 3^ fathoms. The entrance to the river, named the Guer or Leguer, is between the points Dourvin and Servet ; it is fronted by a bar which dries at low water from 3 to 5 feet. The town of Lannion, with a population of about 6,000, is 3^ miles from the A 2771. Wt. 7242. C

34 USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. [Chap. L entrance in a direct line and nearly double that distance following the sinuosities of the river, which is 160 yards wide at Lannion, and has entensive quays on either side considering its very limited trade. Vessels of 8 feet draught can enter the river at half flood, but its stream as high as Lannion is occasionally subject to the phenomenon known as the bore; this takes place only when strong south-westerly winds are veering to N.W., and always on the ebb ; the bore then comes up the river sometimes twice or thrice in one tide, and with sufficient violence to capsize small boats. LIGHT.— On Begleguer point, half a mile northward of the entrance to the river, from the western face of the keeper's house, is exhibited at 161 feet above high water and through an arc of 125°, a fixed light with green, ivhite, and red sectors, visible respectively 7, 13, and 9 miles. The green sector covers 80°, from N.N.E. easterly to E. by S. i S. The white sector covers 31^°, from E. by S. \ S. to S.E. by E. E. easterly. The red sector covers 31^°, from S.E. by E. | E. easterly to S.S.E. f E. easterly. The green sector shows over the Kinierbel rock and all the foul ground southward of the road stead ; the ivhite light, over the ground clear of all danger as far westward as the Chaises de Primel ; and, the red light, over the Taureau, Four, and Crapeaud rocks, which latter dangers are also covered when coming from the northward or eastward by the red sector of the Triagoz light. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station at point Bihit on the northern side of Lannion roads. Between Lannion and Perros bays is a promontory of which ile Grande, almost connected with the shore, and point Ploumenac'h or Mean Ruz, are the north-western and north-eastern extremes. Besides the Crapeaud and adjacent ledges already mentioned, the coast in this part is bordered by innumerable islets, rocks, and ledges, extending 2 miles from the north-western shore, and making any approach to it extremely dangerous. N. by W. i W. 5 miles from the centre of ile Grande is Triagoz lighthouse ; and, Sept-iles light house lies N. by E. 2f miles from point Mean Ruz. PLATEAU de TRIAGOZ.— This dangerous ledge is about 4£ miles in extent W. by N. N. and E. by S. \ S. and about one mile wide ; its eastern end, on which are high rocks always uncovered, lies W.N.W. more than 4 miles from the Sept-iles. There are numerous rocky patches on the body of the ledge, but near its western end there is one, named the Fouillie, with only 14 feet water, from which the Triagoz lighthouse is distant 3 miles S.E. £ E. ;

Chap. I.] PLATEAU DE TRIAGOZ. — SEPT-ILES. 35 ile de Bas lighthouse 14| miles W. by S. \ S. southerly ; and, the Fourchie, the highest rock at the eastern end of the ledge, 3 miles S.E. by E. The summit of the Fourchie is 34 feet above the highest tides. The channel between the plateau de Triagoz and the Sept-iles is 4 miles wide, safe, and clear of danger. LIGHT. — The lighthouse, 82 feet high, stands on Guen Bras rock, Plateau de Triagoz and, from it, ile de Bas light bears W. \ S. 16^ miles, and the Sept-iles light E. by S. \ S. 6^ miles. The lighthouse shows, at 98 feet above high water, a fixed white light varied by a flush alternately red and ivhite every half minute, visible in clear weather from a distance of 15 miles. Between the bearings N.N.E. \ E. and N. \ W., over the shoals westward of ile Grande, the light shows entirely red, the flashes being visible 15 miles and the fixed light 10 miles. Fog bell. — During foggy weather a bell is sounded every 4 seconds. (See note, page 10.) Caution. — At night, as soon as the light on ile de Bas is sighted, a vessel running eastward with the flood stream should steer to pass well northward of it, not bringing it westward of S.W. by W. \ W. after passing it, in order to clear the Triagoz ledge by 3 miles ; for, this stream sets strongly to the South-east and does not turn in the offing until 3£ hours after high water by the shore. The SEPT-ILES, or Seven isles, are high and barren, and in clear weather may be seen 21 miles distant. The lighthouse on them bears W. by N. northerly 16£ miles from Heaux lighthouse, and E. by S. £ S. 6^ miles from Triagoz lighthouse. The isles, with their rocks, ledges, and adjacent shoals, occupy a space 2\ miles wide and 4^ miles long in an E. by N. and W. by S. direction. LIGHT. — From a square lighthouse, 52 feet high, on the eastern end of the southernmost isle, the Ile-aux-Moines or Monk's isle, is exhibited, at 184 feet above high water, a fixed white light, varied every three minutes by a bright flash. The flashes are preceded and followed by short eclipses which do not appear total within the distance of 6 miles. The light is dioptric, of the third order, and is visible in clear weather from a distance of 20 miles, except when bearing about W. by S., when it is obscured through an arc of 3° by Rougic isle and the eastern end of Bono isle. Buoy. — To facilitate the navigation of the channel between the Sept-iles and the mainland, a bell buoy is moored southward of the Dervinis, the southernmost rocks of the group. c 2

36 USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. [Chap. I. A Life-Boat is stationed at the Ile-aux-Moines. The dangers between Sept-iles and the Plateau des Heaux mostly rise from depths of about 18 fathoms. Vessels passing outside Sept-iles and steering eastward should therefore keep well outside that depth. Sept-iles lighthouse kept bearing West until Heaux lighthouse is seen, and it, in turn, kept well southward of S.E. when within 5 or 6 miles of it, leads well outside all dangers. PLOUMANAC'H LIGHT.— On Mean Ruz, the north-eastern extreme of Ploumanac'h point, at 69 feet above high water, is exhibited from a square lighthouse a fixed red light, visible in clear weather from a distance of 5 miles. Semaphore. — There is also a semaphore station on Ploumanac'h point, and westward of the point is the little tidal harbour of Ploumanac'h. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Ploumanac'h at 5 h. 15 m. ; springs rise 24^ feet, neaps 18^ feet. ANSE de PERROS, li miles wide at the entrance, is 2\ miles south-eastward f ron Mean Ruz ; it affords good shelter from westerly winds to vessels that can take the ground. Those of light draught may lie afloat in the outer part of the bay, between which and the port at the head of the bay, the beaching places, on a bottom of muddy sand about 9| feet above the lowest tides, are excellent. Tome, a narrow islet nearly a mile in length N. by E. and S. by W., is one mile north-eastward from the western point of the bay ; its highest part is about a third of its length from the northern end. The little town of Perros-Guirec has about 2,800 inhabitants ; its port is protected on the east by the Lenquin jetty 165 yards in length, a great portion of which is available as a quay, the total quay frontage of the port being no less than 515 yards. There is little or no trade, the harbour being used chiefly as a refuge for coasters, which frequently run from the outer roadstead for shelter at high water, but in so doing run the risk of being neaped. LIGHTS. — At Nantouar, in Perros bay, two fixed white lights are exhibited ; that near the shore is 33 feet high and visible 10 miles ; the inner light, at Kerjean, 750 yards from the former, is 253 feet high and visible 14 miles. Nantouar light is attached to a white house ; Kerjean lighthouse is a white tower near a farm-house. The two lighthouses in line by day, or the lights by night, lead into Perros bay through the north-western passage.

Chap. I.] 37 ANSE DE PERROS. Two fixed white lights are also exhibited at the port of Perros, viz., a light 110 yards behind the Pigeon-house, elevated 89 feet, and visible 14 miles ; and, an inner light at Kerprigent, 3,133 yards from the other, elevated 259 feet, and also visible 14 miles. The two light houses in line by day, or the lights by night, lead into the bay through the eastern channel. The Pigeon-house light is attached to a white house, the Kerprigent is a small white tower. None of these lights are visible more than 18° on either side of the direction they are intended to indicate. A Life-Boat is stationed at Perros. Directions. — Coming from the westward in-shore, Rougic ile hidden by the ile de Bono, Sept-iles, leads between the Triagoz and all the shoals northward and eastward of ile Grande ; and, when the southern end of ile Tome is open of Mean Ruz, a course of about E. | S. leads between the Sept-iles and the northern end of ile Tome, bearing in mind that the tidal stream sometimes sets through this channel at the rate of 5 knots. If desirous of entering Perros bay from the north-westward, steer in for the southern end of Tome until Nantouar and Kerjean lighthouses are in line; with this mark on, pass westward of two pointed rocks named the Bilzic, marked by a black beacon turret, which lie nearly a mile off its western side and un cover 22 and 32 feet, and eastward of the Fronde rock, marked by a red spherical buoy, and of the red beacon turret on Bernard rock, nearly a quarter of a mile from the western point of the bay. Four patches, of which the highest is awash at low water, lie between his latter rock and the Pierre du Chenal, also marked by a red and black beacon turret ; therefore, at low water, do not proceed farther south ward than to have Perros church opening southward of the hill on the western point of the bay. But, if proceeding to the port of Perros-Guirec, with a proper rise of tide, be careful to haul to the westward in good time to bring the Kerprigent and Pigeon-house lighthouses in line, which mark leads up to the port, and great care is necessary, for a vessel overrunning this line will be upon the rocks.* Bound into Perros bay from the eastward, pass north-westward of the black conical buoy marking the Guazer rocks at the outer edge of the Four ledge, by not going southward of the line of the high steeple of Notre Dame de Clarte on with the highest part of Tome isle. This leading mark clears all the reefs extending from the mainland, including the Crebineyers, marked by a black buoy ; it also passes very close on the starboard hand the Pierre Jean Rousic, off the southern end of ile Tome, which uncovers one foot, and the Pierre du Chenal beacon turret, which bears about S.W. f S. half a mile from the southern end of Tome and which rock uncovers 14 feet. After passing close southward of this beacon, the vessel may anchor about 1^ cables south-westward of it, in from 11 to 14 feet water ; or, with a proper rise of tide, the same mark will lead her on past the beacon turrets on the Roc'h Hu and Barr Goalenou on the port hand, and the beacon of Craou on the starboard hand ; and, after passing the latter, she may haul up for the pier-head and enter the port. Vessels entering by the western channel should observe the caution already given and leave the line of the two former lights in one, the moment the Pigeon house and Kerprigent lights come in sight, to avoid overrunning their line of direction. PORT BLANC. — From Perros bay to point du Chateau, the western point of entrance to the river Treguier, the coast trends East 9 miles and is fronted by innumerable rocks both above and below water, extending from 1^ to 2 miles off-shore. About midway is a little inlet named port Blanc, with Chateau Neuf isle and the Four ledge on the western side of its entrance, and Leverettes and St. Gildas isles on the eastern side. The port is well sheltered and affords safe refuge for coasters during south-westerly gales but is open to winds from N.W. round by North toN.E., and vessels caught by such winds frequently run ashore under the lee of St. Gildas isle on a soft weedy bottom. With the wind eastward of N.E. the anchorage is considered preferable to that in Perros bay. The leading mark in is, Comtesse white mill on with the white beacon tower just eastward of the Voleur rock at the head of the port S. f E. A vessel will not have less than 22 feet by anchoring north-westward of the Louet, a large rock on the eastern side of the port, but better shelter in less water may be found farther in. If she can take the ground, good beaching places may be found East and E.S.E. of the Voleur, where the bottom is 10^ feet above the level of the lowest tides.

Chap. I.] PORT BLANC. — TREGUIER RIVER. 39 Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station at port Blanc. TREGUIER or JAUDY RIVER, the entrance to which is 9 miles in an E.S.E. direction from the north-eastern ledge of the Sept-iles plateau, and 3^ miles westward of the Heaux lighthouse, fully described at page 42, affords excellent, shelter but is difficult of access to sailing vessels, and, with gales from N.N.W. to E.N.E., a heavy sea runs at the entrance on the ebb. From the entrance nearly up to the little town of Treguier, a distance of 5 miles, the channel is generally over 300 yards wide and well marked by perches; near the town it narrows, and at one place is only 50 or 60 yards wide; the depths are from 6 to 2 fathoms. The town has about 3,000 inhabitants, has good quays with soft mud berths alongside, but being 16 miles from the nearest railway, has little or no trade. The river is spanned by a suspension bridge at Treguier. The three channels leading to the river entrance are, the Grande Passe, Passe du N.E., and Passe de la Gaine. Grande Passe leads to the entrance from the north-westward and is practicable for vessels of any draught. When entering by this channel, keep St. Antoine mill exactly on with the mill of Port de la Chaine, or, the white lighthouses of la Chaine and St. Antoine in one S.S.E. easterly, and the vessel will pass about 3 cables westward of the black conical buoy marking the Crublent shoal and the same distance eastward of the Renauds rocks, which never cover, and over a patch of 22 feet, which, with the leading mark on, is the least depth in this channel ; she will also pass about a cable eastward of Pierre a l'Anglais rock which uncovers 8 feet, and still closer to the red spherical buoy marking the Petit-pen-ar-Guezec shoal, the highest heads of which dry 3 feet ; and, 2 cables westward of the black beacon on the Corbeau rock, which uncovers 19 feet. By night, the red and white lights in line S.S.E. easterly lead through the Grande Passe. Passe du N.E. — The large spire of Treguier cathedral exactly on with the white tower on the Skeiviec rock, which tower is 30 feet above the level of high water, bearing S.W., leads to the entrance of the river ; but, this line crosses the Jument ledge, the western extreme of which lies N.W. by W. nearly 2 miles from Heaux light house and is marked by a red conical bell buoy moored off its northern edge ; the leading mark must therefore be left, both on entering and leaving the river, to pass westward of the ledge and buoy.

40 USHANT TO HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE. [Chap. I. Vessels not drawing more than 17 feet, having rounded the western end of the Jument, may, with this leading mark on, cross the Basses de Roc'h Hir after half flood, or if the Petit Roc'h Hir is covered. This rock lies on the north-eastern part of the ledge and uncovers 13 feet. This channel should only be used with smooth water. Passe de la Gaine, the most easterly channel, is practicable with smooth water for vessels of 14 feet draught after 3^ hours' flood, and is useful when approaching from the eastward if there is sufficient wind to stem the tide. The entrance is between the Heaux and Sark rocks ; the leading mark is, the white beacon wall in the south-eastern part of the village of Plougrescan on with the white pyramid of Men-Noblance, on the southern part of ile d'Er, bearing W. by S. This leads a vessel nearly half a mile southward of Heaux lighthouse and over the Pont de la Gaine, a narrow cut in the ledge extending from thu southern end of the Duono rocks with only one foot water at low water, springs. LIGHTS. — Three lights are exhibited at the entrance of the Treguier river. Near the harbour mill of port de la Chaine is a fixed ivhite light, 36 feet above high water, exhibited from the keeper's house which is white ; it is visible 9 miles. Near St. Antoine Mill is a fixed red light 105 feet above high water, visible through an arc of 16° on each side of the leading line for a distance of 9 miles ; the red light is distant three quarters of a mile S.S.E. easterly from the white light, and, when in line, they lead through the Grande Passe. From a lighthouse on the Corne rock, on the eastern side of the entrance, is exhibited a fixed light, 38 feet above high water, showing sectors of green, red, and white, as follows : — green on a W.S.WIy bearing, through an angle of 7^°, or between the Petit Pen-ar- Guezec and the shoal of port Beni ; red eastward of the green sector ; and ivhite on an E.N.E1j- bearing, through an angle of 7^°. The green light is visible only 4 miles, the red 5 miles, and the white 9 miles. Anchorages. — From abreast of the Skeiviec rock, 11 miles within the entrance, to the town of Treguier, the river is deep enough for coasters always to remain afloat. Tt has three anchorages, well sheltered from wind and tide, of which the best and most convenient is the Palamos anchorage, about 2 miles within the Skeiviec, where the depths are from 2\ to 4 fathoms.

L] TREGUIER RIVER. 41 Directions. — In steering through either of the channels for the entrance of the river, keep the leading mark on until the large spire of Treguier cathedral is on with the white tower on Skeiviec rock S.W. This latter mark leads into the river, but, before running in, make sure that the tide is sufficiently high for the vessel to pass over an 8-feet patch, a cable outside the ledge bordering the eastern side of Er isle, and also over the Pie bank on which there are only 6 feet at low water, springs. After passing between the beacon on the Taureau and Corne rock, which rocks are about 1^ miles within the Pen-ar-Guezec buoy, and, between them, the deep water channel is not more than three quarters of a cable wide, and southward of the Taureau bank, steer up the river keeping mid way between the rocks bordering its banks. At night, vessels entering the Treguier river should steer with la Chaine white light on with St. Antoine red light bearing S.S.E. easterly until la Corne green light is seen, then steer for it, keeping within its green sector. Pass a short distance westward of the Corne rock and anchor within the white sector of light, which marks the inner anchorage. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the entrance of the Treguier river at 5 h. 22 m. ; equinoctial springs rise about 35 feet, and neaps 21 feet. Off the town of Treguier, it is high water at 5 h. 32 m. ; springs rise 25 feet, neaps 18-j feet, neaps range 12 feet. The flood stream, which sets into this river, rounds the northern shore of Er isle until the bank connecting this isle to the main at low water is covered, which takes place at about half flood ; it then slackens at the entrance of the river and runs eastward. The rate of the flood within the river is never more than 3 knots ; that of the ebb rather less.

PLATEAU des HEAUX, composed of rocks, of which many are always above water, is about one mile in extent E.S.E. and W.N.W. and three quarters of a mile broad. At its north-eastern edge is the rock Men-Lem, which never covers, and can be passed on its north eastern side at 250 yards distance ; on the south-eastern edge is the rock Roc'h-ar-Hanap, which also never covers, and can be passed within half a cable. The lighthouse stands on the eastern part of the plateau. LIGHT. — Heaux lighthouse is a round tower, 159 feet high from base to vane, erected on the eastern part of the plateau des Heaux ; from it, the Sept-iles light bears W. by N. northerly 16£ miles ; the light on the Roches-Douvres N.E. \ N. northerly 15f miles ; and, the lighthouse on the Lejon rock S.E. \ S. 19 miles. From it, also, the Paon light at the north extreme of ile de Brehat bears S.E. S. southerly 4f miles ; and, the red conical bell buoy marking the north-eastern extreme of the Horaine ledge E. by S. f S. 7 miles. The light is 148 feet above high water and shows fixed ivhite with two red sectors, one north-eastward, the other south-eastward. It is dioptric, of the first order, and is visible in clear weather from a distance of 18 miles. The north-eastern sector is flashing red, through an arc of 19° between the bearings W. \ S. southerly and W.S.W. southerly, showing over the whole extent of the Barnouic ledge. The south-eastern sector infixed red, through an arc of 32° between the bearings N.W. \ N. and W. by N. \ N. northerly, showing over the Horaine, Echaudes, Men-March, and Ringue-Bras ledges. Vessels in the offing, with the white sector of light in sight, are clear of danger in the channel between Barnouic and Horaine ledges. Approaching from the eastward, having passed well northward of Horaine ledge, and having crossed the line of the leading lights of Bodic heights and Croix rock, Trieux channel, in line, a north westerly course may be steered, and the flashing red sector of light entered. THE COAST.— Baie de Saint Brieuc— Between the plateau des Heaux and ile de Brehat is the north-eastern entrance to the Trieux river, and on the opposite side of the ile is its eastern entrance. Between ile de Brehat and cape Frehel, distant 28 miles on a S.E. bearing, the coast line falls back forming the deep bight named the Baie de Saint Brieuc. The approach to the western entrance of the bay is indicated at night by the fixed white light on the plateau des Heaux, and in the day by the Creach-ar-Maout hill about 3 miles S.S.W. from the light. This hill forms the abrupt termination northward of the high land separating the river Trieux from the Treguier ; on its summit is a guard-house with a semaphore close to it. The bay is on all sides much encumbered by rocks and shoals both in-shore and in the offing. The land is generally high and may be seen in clear weather about 22 miles distant. In very clear weather, the summits of the central chain of Bretagne hills are visible, and amongst others the Mener-Bel-Air and the Mener-Bre ; the former rises southward, and the latter south-westward of the bay. When bound westward from cape Frehel, the parts first seen are cape d'Erqui and Bien-Assis wood on the eastern side, and then Plouha point and the small town of Plouzec on the western side of the bay. The Rade de Brehat, with the ports of Trieux, Paimpol, Portrieux, and Binic, are on the western side of the bay ; in the southern part is port Legue and the town of Saint Brieuc, with the large shallow Anse d'Yffiniac adjoining ; and, on the eastern side is the port of Dahouet, north-eastward of which is the high and steep point of Pleneuf, which juts out boldly from the land 3|- miles W.S.W. of cape d'Erqui ; the Verdelet, a conical shaped islet, lies 2 cables north westward of Pleneuf point, between which point and cape d'Erqui the coast is generally low and exposed to the North-west, but the rade d'Erqui affords good shelter with easterly winds. The hills, at this part, rise suddenly a short distance within high-water mark and unite with

44 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL [Chap. II. the high lands in the interior ; Bien-Assis wood, on their summit, may be recognised at a great distance. Cape d'Erqui is a lofty promontory terminating in a steep slope on its western face ; between it and cape Frehel, 1\ miles eastward, the shore is composed of high rocky cliffs, with the exception of a small sandy beach under the village of Pleherel. The little inlet, Bouche d'Erqui, lies 3 miles eastward of the cape of that name. CAUTION. — As all dangers between ile de Brehat and cape Frehel rise from soundings of less than 18 fathoms, the prudent seaman will at night or in thick weather keep without that depth. The off-lying dangers, Basse Maurice, plateau de Barnouic, and plateau des Roches-Douvres, are not included in this caution, they being surrounded by much deeper water. PLATEAU des ROCHES-DOUVRES.— This dangerous rocky ledge, the outermost of the off-lydng dangers fronting St. Brieuc bay, occupies a space 3^ miles long N.N.W. and S.S.E., and 2^ miles wide ; from it, rises a group of 12 rocky heads which never cover. The highest head of the plateau, is about 9 feet above the highest tides, and is in the middle of the group ; on it stands a white iron lighthouse. The north-western edge of the ledge bears N.E. by E., and the south-western edge E.N.E., about 15^ miles from Heaux lighthouse. For tidal streams in this vicinity, see page 196. LIGHT. — From the white iron lighthouse at 180 feet above high water, is exhibited a ivhite occulting light, showing a bright flash every four seconds, with a dark interval of three seconds. The light is visible in clear weather from a distance of 20 miles. From the lighthouse, Hanois lighthouse, Guernsey7, bears N.N.E. | E. 20 miles ; Gautier rock on Barnouic ledge bears S.S.W. 5 miles ; Heaux lighthouse S.W. \ S. southerly 15f miles ; Lejon lighthouse S. \ W. 22 miles ; and, the Minquiers light-vessel S.E. \ S. 24 miles. Fog Signal.— During foggy weather, a bell is sounded fourteen times at intervals of one second, then an interval of six seconds, then a double stroke, then another interval of six seconds, then fourteen strokes, &c. (See note, page 10.) PLATEAU de BARNOUIC— About 12 miles E. by N. £ N. from Heaux lighthouse, and N.E. \ N. 1\ miles from the Horaine rock, are the Gautier rocks, near the middle of the Plateau de Barnouic,

Chap. II.] ROCHES-DOUVRES AND ROC'H-AR-BEL SHOALS. 45 a dangerous: rocky ledge, of which the southern edge lies E. f N. from Heaux lighthouse. The Gautier rocks uncover 14 febt at the lowest tides, and are awash at low water, neaps. The Barnouic rock, of conical form, bears E. £ N. about three quarters of a mile from the Gautier rocks ; it uncovers 23^ feet, covers 2\ hours before high water, springs, and is awash at high water, neaps. This plateau, of which the Barnouic and Gautier are the highest rocks, extends from the Barnouic rock about one mile eastward, about 1\ miles S.S.W., 2\ miles N.W. by W., and 2 miles N.N.W. The most westerly rocky patches, one of which has only 3 feet water, bear E.N.E. 11^ miles from Heaux lighthouse. There are depths of from 10 to 15 fathoms on parts of the plateau, but the sea at times breaks over its whole extent. The Roches-Douvres and Barnouic ledge are separated by a channel more than 2 miles wide, carrying a depth of from 20 to 30 fathoms. It should, however, be avoided by sailing vessels, as the streams set with great strength over both ledges. If forced to pass through it, endeavour to keep nearer the Douvres than the Barnouic. A vessel will keep westward of both ledges by not bringing Heaux lighthouse more westerly than S.W. \ W. Basse Maurice is a small rocky patch in the channel between the Plateau de Barnouic and the shore ; from its shoalest spot of 7 fathoms, Heaux lighthouse bears W. f S. nearly 7 miles ; Paon light house, ile de Brehat, S.W. S. 6 miles ; the guard-house on Creach ar-Maout hill is on with the Louet rock W.S.W. westerly ; and, Plouha point is a little open westward of the Horaine rock, S. by W. Although the depth is never less than 7 fathoms on this shoal, it should be avoided in bad weather, as a heavy sea runs over it during a weather tide. Roc'h-ar-Bel. — This shoal patch of 20 feet lies at the north-eastern extreme of the great rocky flat extending 5 miles from the coast which separates the entrances of the rivers Trieux and Treguier, and of which the Heaux rocks form a part. From it, Heaux lighthouse bears W.^ N. 3| miles ; and, the guard-house on Creach-ar-Maout Hill is on with the Sark rocks. Carec-Mingui, a rocky patch of 11 feet, lies one third of a mile westward of the Roc'h-ar-Bel. Heaux lighthouse bearing W. \ S. leads southward of the Basse Maurice, and northward of the Carec-Mingui and Roc'h-ar-Bel shoals, over which shoals the tide, at springs, sets with a velocity of 5 knots.

46 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. II. Extensive rocky ledges, lying in a general easterly and westerly direction, extend 5 or 6 miles eastward and south-eastward of ile de Brehat, and on them several rocky heads dry at low water. The northernmost ledges are the Horaine and Echaudes ; the southern most, Men-Marc'h and Ringue-bras ; between them are navigable channels leading to Brehat road. Outside of the rocky limits, and 5^ miles from the nearest land, pointe de Plouzec, numerous banks of sand, under the general name of Banes de Sable, extend 4£ miles in a S. by E. direction from their northern end, near the eastern extreme of the plateau de Men-Marc'h ; on some of these banks the depth is as little as 2\ fathoms. PLATEAU de LA HORAINE is a rocky ledge, 1± miles in extent, N.E. and S.W., and one mile wide ; it has many rocky heads awash and nearly awash at low water, and one head, the Horaine rock, about a mile within the northern extreme of the ledge and bearing S.E. by E. § E. 6| miles from Heaux lighthouse and E. by N. £ N. 3 miles from Paon lighthouse, uncovers 22 feet at the lowest tides, and is awash about 2\ hours before high water. The Horaine rock is supposed to have a beacon on it, but it is washed away as soon as built and cannot be depended on ; from the rock, the white pyramid on Ar-Morbic rock is a little open westward of St. Michel chapel, ile de Brehat ; and, Ste. Barbe windmill is midway between two of the highest peaks of St. Riom isle. Basses du Nord are the most northern patches on the plateau de la Horaine. The shoalest spot, 10 feet, lies N.E. \ E. three quarters of a mile from the Horaine rock ; Basse du Nord-Est, with 9 feet water, bears E. \ S. three quarters of a mile from Horaine rock ; and Basse du Sud-Est with only 8 feet lies 1\ miles S.E. by E. \ E. from the Horaine rock. From this latter patch, the Horaine beacon, if in position, is on with Heaux lighthouse N.W. by W. \ W. There is a channel of from 10 to 12 fathoms, half a mile wide, between this Basse and the Horaine ledges. Buoy. — A large red conical bell buoy is moored at the north eastern edge of the plateau de la Horaine. PLATEAU des ECHAUDES lies south-westward of the Horaine, and its highest rock, the Echaudes, uncovers 8^ feet at low water, springs. This rock is near the southern part of the ledge and, from it, the guard-house on Creach-ar-Maout hill is on with the northern extreme of ile de Brehat W.N.W. ; the white pyramid on Louet

Barbe mill is a little open eastward of the summit of St. Riom isle S.W. \ S. Another rock, the Pain de Bray, uncovers only 2 feet. It is at the north-western part of the ledge and, from it, the Chandelier, a large rock off the north-western point of the ile de Brehat is seen between the Grand and Petit Pen-Azen rocks. The Pen-Azen rocks are half a mile off the northern point of ile de Brehat ; the Grand Pen-Azen uncovers 27 feet, the Petit Pen- Azen 15 feet at the lowest springs. The Petit Pen-Azen has on it a stone beacon turret, coloured with black and red bands. Buoy. — A black conical buoy is moored on the north-western edge of the Pen-Azen shoal. PLATEAU de MEN-MARC'H is south-eastward of the Horaine and Echaudes reefs ; and, between them is a channel leading to Brehat road. This ledge is 3 miles long E. by N. £ N. and W. by S. 5 S., and 1\ miles broad at its widest part ; the only rocky head visible at the lowest tides is the Men-Marc'h in the south-eastern part, which then uncovers 2 feet, and is at all times dangerous on account of the eddies in its vicinity. Numerous shoal patches of from 2 feet, near the western edge, to 2\ and 3£ fathoms at the north-western part of the ledge, lie westward and northward of this rock. Buoy. — A red conical bell buoy is moored off the north-eastern end of the plateau de Men-Marc'h. PLATEAU du RINGUE-BRAS is the next ledge southward of the Men-Marc'h, and between them is a channel leading to Brehat roads ; it is 3 miles long East and West, and about a mile wide at its broadest part towards the eastern end. The Basse de l'Ascension, the highest head on this ledge, is near its eastern extreme, and has only from 3 to 6 feet over it at the lowest springs. Directions. — Vessels from the westward bound to any of the ports in St. Brieuc bay, or to St. Malo or Granville, generally pass between Barnouic and Horaine ledges. This channel is 7 miles wide, the tidal streams follow its direction, and, as before stated, the Basse Maurice, the only rocky patch in the channel, need be avoided in bad weather only. A vessel using this channel should steer to pass within 4 miles of Heaux lighthouse, and as it is approached keep it well southward of

48 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. II. S.E. to avoid the dangers westward of it. When eastward of its meridian, it should not be brought to bear more northerly than W. £ N. until the guard-house on Creach-ar-Maout hill is on with the Sark rocks W. by S. \ S. The vessel is then eastward of the Roc'h-ar-Bel, and the lighthouse may be brought to bear W. f N., on which bearing it leads between the Basse Maurice and the red bell buoy of the Horaine. From the south-eastward, a vessel is in the fairway of this channel when Heaux lighthouse bears W. f N., and it is necessary to have it on this bearing before she is abreast of the plateau de la Horaine, which position will be ensured by not crossing the line of Ste. Barbe mill on with the highest part of the crest of St. Riom isle bearing about S.W. until the old mill on ile de Brehat, without sails, a red roof, and a broad white band below the roof, is quite open westward of the white pyramid on Ar-Morbic rock, or until the Heaux rocks appear quite open northward of the Sark rocks. To avoid the Roc'h-ar-Bel, Heaux lighthouse must be brought to bear W. £ N. Having passed westward of the meridian of Heaux light house, and until 5 or 6 miles from it, keep it well southward of S.E. to avoid all dangers westward of it. Tidal Streams. — Between the plateau de Barnouic and Basse Maurice the flood stream sets S.E. by S., and ceases about an hour after high water by the shore at ile de Brehat ; its greatest velocity, about 4^ knots, is at about half flood. The ebb runs in the opposite direction, and ceases about 5 hours before high water by the shore ; its strength is nearly equal to that of the flood. At a mile north ward of Heaux lighthouse, the flood sets S.E. by E., the ebb N.W. by W., with about the same strength. Close to the edge of the rocks it is somewhat stronger, running at the rate of 5 knots past the Heaux, over the Roc'h-ar-Bel, and both round and over the north eastern edge of the Horaine. The whirls and eddies occasionally met with in the channel between the Horaine and Barnouic ledges, are strong but not dangerous ; the most considerable is produced by the Basse Maurice. TRIEUX RIVER.— Four channels lead into this river; one only, the Grand Chenal or Trieux channel, is available for large ships at all times by day or night, and neither of the others should be attempted without the aid of a pilot, except in cases of urgent neces sity. The Trieux channel is the northern entrance between the Roc'h-ar-Bel and Horaine ledges. It may also be entered from the westward at any time of tide, by day, through the Moisie and Men-

Chap, il] TIDAL STREAMS. — TRIEUX RIVER. 49 du-Castrec channels by small vessels ; and, from the eastward through the Ferlas channel, between ile de Brehat and the mainland, which is a practicable channel for vessels of deep draught from half flood to half ebb, but can be used only by coasters at low water, springs. The river is tidal and navigable for small vessels as high as the little port of Pontrieux, a distance of 16 miles from the Paon lighthouse at its entrance. Above Pontrieux it is dammed, and the stream utilized by water-mills. Anchorages. — Several anchorages in the entrance of this river afford refuge to vessels of deep draught, . but they are difficult of access, especially on the ebb, when they should not be attempted without a pilot. As the holding ground is bad and the stream rapid, in the middle of the river, ships should anchor as near the edge of the mud-banks as possible on either side. Pomelin road is on the northern side of the river, about 21 miles within Paon light, and the marks for the best anchorage, in 30 feet and out of the tide, are, the old mill on Brehat just open northward of the ruins on ile Verte ; and, the new Mill of Loguivy seen between point du Gouern and Conan rock. A vessel should moor North and South in Pomelin roads. There is also anchorage north-eastward of this, near the outer edge of the mud-banks which uncover as far southward as the line of Croix rock lighthouse on with Loguivy mill ; vessels should moor here W.N.W. and E.S.E. Another good and well sheltered anchorage in which the streams have not much strength, and with sufficient room and depth for the largest ships, is near the edge of the mud-banks south-eastward of the ile de Bois, a high steep island close to the western point of entrance to the river. The anchoring ground here extends in a south-westerly direction from the line of the beacon on Vieille de Loguivy rock on with Arcouest mill ; anchor in 7^ fathoms with the two lighthouses at Coat-Mer in line ; and, Loguivy guard-house between the two mills, rather nearer the old mill than the new ; moor here also W.N.W. and E.S.E. The first anchorage within the river for a vessel of deep draught is near the right bank with Coat-Mer lighthouses in line, North, and N.W. of a large rock named Melus, which lies fronting the Douane or custom-house office on the Roc'h-ar-On ; a vessel of any size should not venture beyond this at night, but should anchor the moment Heaux light is shut in by the ile de Bois. There is room for two moderate sized vessels between Bodic light tower and Sabot du-Sud rock ; also, excellent holding ground on both sides of the A 2771. Wt. 7242. D

50 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. ii. river out of the strength of the stream southward of Coat-Mer cove, and south-westward of a water-mill abreast of the cove. Lezardrieux, a little port on the left or western bank of the river, nearly 2^ miles above the Custom-house office on the Roc'h-ar- On, is full of rocks and dries at low water of all tides. Vessels of light draught are neaped within it for 4 or 5 days ; but, at its entrance among the rocks, there is a bottom of soft mud, on which two or three coasters can ground without being neaped. Vessels can generally remain afloat in a narrow channel between this port and a rocky ledge in the middle of the river. Those bound up to Pontrieux, anchor here to wait for sufficient water when they arrive during neaps ; or, during springs, to await the aid of a local pilot, without whom no vessel should attempt the difficult passages in the river between here and Pontrieux. The first of these passages, named Ar-Toul-Tane, is at a sudden turn in the river, 4 cables above Lezardrieux suspension bridge, which bridge spans the river 108 feet above the lowest tides. The second passage is in the turn of the river under the high land and chateau of Roche-Jugut, one mile above which on its eastern side the Trieux receives the waters of the little river Leff. Pontrieux. — The little port of Pontrieux is on the right bank of the river, about half a mile below the town of that name, and 8 miles above Lezardrieux bridge. It has about 400 yards of quay frontage, all on the eastern side ; the berths at the foot of the quay dry about 22^ feet above the level of the lowest tides. The town is built on both sides of the river and has a population of about 2,500. Its trade is insignificant, and is carried on chiefly by coasters of from 30 to 100 tons, though vessels of 300 tons can ascend as high as Pontrieux. The nearest railway7 station is on the Paris and Brest line at Guincamp, about 10 miles distant. W. and N.W. by N. ; also white through an arc of 45°, between N.E. \ E. and E. \ S. ; and obscured towards the land through an arc of 45°, between N. \ E. and N.E. \ E. Directions. — Trieux Channel. — The leading mark for the main entrance of Trieux river is, Bodic and La Croix lighthouses in line S.W. by W. \ W. This mark leads south-eastward of Roc'h-ar- Bel, Men-du-Castrec, and Sirlots ledges, the latter having a red bell buoy at its eastern extreme ; and north-westward of Horaine, Echaudes and Pen-Azen ledges, the latter marked by a black conical buoy less than half a mile from the Sirlots buoy. On entering the river it also leads south-eastward of the red beacon turrets on Vieille de St. Mode, Rodello, Kerrannets, and Moguedhier rocks, and north westward of the beacon turret on Petit-Pen-Azen, coloured with black and red bands, as well as of all the dangers off ile de Brehat, including the large pointed rock Chandelier, bordering on the North the entrance to the Kerpont passage, and the black beacon turret of D 2
