The Gosrod beacon turret stands on a rock which uncovers about 13 feet, and is only three quarters of a cable eastward of the fairway. The red beacon turret on the Moguedhier is about 1£ cables N. by W. from the Croix lighthouse. Having arrived at a position 3 or 4 cables north-eastward of the Croix lighthouse, or before the vessel is abreast of the Moguedhier beacon turret, haul a little to starboard to pass a safe distance west ward of the Croix lighthouse ; after which, bring the keeper's house on Coat-Mer peninsula on with the square white tower of the inner light, which leads to the inner anchorage betweenile.de Bois and Coat-Mer. By Night, enter the river with Croix and Bodic lights in line, and when Bodic light is hidden by Croix light-tower, as it will be to an eye 8 feet above the sea, when it is 1,800 yards distant, open out Bodic light westward of Croix light and pass the latter on its western side. Afterwards, proceed with the two inner fixed red lights in line to the anchorage of Coat-Mer. Moisie Channel commences at the Moisie red beacon turret near the Sark rocks, and joins the Trieux channel near the red turret marking the Vieille de Saint-Mode. The flood stream, at springs, sets through at 4^ or 5 knots in the direction of the channel until near the rock Noguejou-bian, when it inclines south-westward towards ile St. Mode. The ebb is not quite so strong and takes more the direction of the channel as the tide falls. The leading mark is, the spire of the chapel of St. Michel, ile de Brehat, on with Rosedo white beacon tower S. E. The channel is very narrow, but is convenient for vessels of moderate length and draught entering the river Trieux with a scant wind. Men-du-Castrec Channel has its entrance between the shoals Ar-Mesclek on the West and Men-du-Castrec on the East, and joins the Trieux channel at the same point as the Moisie. The tidal streams run at the rate of 4i or 5 knots but follow the direction of the channel. The leading mark, the white pyramid on Arcouest point on with the red beacon turret of Vieille de Saint-Mode, leads through in mid-channel until near the latter, but over the eastern head of the shoal Ar-Gazec on which there are only 6 feet at low water, springs. As with the Moisie channel, this passage is used by vessels which cannot weather the Men-du-Castrec and Sirlots shoals not only in entering the Trieux river but also in making for Brehat road by the Kerpont or Brehat channels. (See page 57).

Chap. II.] 53 CHANNELS INTO TRIEUX RIVER. Ferlas Channel.— This channel is available by day for vessels of 8 feet draught at low water, springs ; for vessels of 13 feet draught at low water, neaps ; and, for vessels of any draught at high water. To run from Brehat road into Trieux river through this channel, with the best water, weigh when the rock at the south western point of Logodec islet has just covered ; it uncovers 22 feet at the lowest tides. Steer westward to pass midway between the beacon on the Piliers and that on the Vis -Argent rocks, and half a cable northward of the summits of Rouray, Conan, and Levret rocks, which latter border the southern side of the channel and never cover ; after passing the Piliers beacon turret, bring it on with the black beacon turret of the rade de Brehat, which leads half a cable southward of Rout-ar-Linen beacon, through the narrowest part of the channel, and southward of the Rompa rock and beacon turret, which, however, may be passed on either side at half a cable ; after passing it, bring it and the Piliers beacon in line, and this mark leads into the Trieux channel, southward of the Tranquet rock, and up to the direction of the two lighthouses of Coat-Mer in line. There is a passage connecting the Ferlas and Trieux channels east ward of the Tranquet and of the beacon on the Trou-blanc, named the Trou-blanc channel. The leading mark through is, the new mill of Loguivy, kept on astern, between the Conan rock and the steep declivity of tfce northern point of Gouern cove S. f W. There are also other intricate channels connecting the Ferlas and Trieux channels. Loguivy. — Near the western entrance of the Ferlas channel is the little fishing port of Loguivy, useful to pilots and fishermen but of no importance. The harbour dries from 6 feet at the entrance to 22 feet within, at low water, springs. Pilots. — The Brehat and Trieux pilots keep at sea when the weather permits, and in fine weather may be found cruising or fishing as far seaward as the Roches-Douvres ; fishing boats are often found near Heaux lighthouse, and their masters are generally good pilots and very useful until proper pilots are met with. If a vessel is bound to Pontrieux, or anywhere above the ile de Bois roadstead, a river pilot is required. The head quarters of these pilots is at Lezardrieux. Tidal Streams.— The tidal streams off the entrance of the Trieux river have been already noticed at page 48. Within the entrance, between St. Mode isle and La Croix lighthouse, they follow the

[Chap. II. 54 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. direction of the channel ; but, outside or north-eastward of Saint- Mode, they cross the channel with great strength, and it requires a fresh fair wind to keep the leading mark on. For time and rise of tides at the entrance of the Trieux river, see tides around ile de Brehat, page 59. ILE de BREHAT.— The south-western point of this isle is less than a mile from Arcouest point, and it extends from thence 2 miles in a N.E. by N. direction to Paon point, but is nearly divided into two about its centre. The most conspicuous objects on it are, the lighthouses on Paon point and on the little mound of Rosedo, St. Michel chapel, the northern mill, the southern mill (le Vieux Moulin) which has no sails, a red roof, and a white band 9 feet wide below the roof. The most remarkable irregularities of outline are at Paon point, at the small hill where the chapel stands, and at the hillocks crowning both points of entrance to port Clos. The isle appears distinct from the coast on a South, S.W., or North bearing, but, unless very near, it becomes blended with the land when bearing between W.S.W. and N.W. The white pyramids placed on the Ar-Morbic, Louet, and Quistillic rocks, which front the eastefn part of the isle, are also conspicuous objects and may be seen at some distance. lie de Brehat has a population of over 1,000, mostly hardy fisher men and sailors, and it has three small ports, viz., Port de la Corderie on its north-western side, port Clos on its south-western side, and port la "Chambre on its south-eastern side ; the first is entered from the Trieux channel, the last two from the rade de Brehat. The dangers already described surrounding this isle seaward are comprised between the lines of Heaux lighthouse bearing West, and the mill on the high land a little northward of Pomelin bay on with the south-western point of ile de Brehat N.W. by W. The tidal streams, especially at springs, rush with great velocity through this chain of dangers, and produce a violent race, which, at low water, can only be passed through without risk by the narrow cut called the Brehat channel, which is 2 miles long in a S. f W. and N. f E. direction, passes about a mile eastward of Paon point, between the rocky ledges fronting the eastern side of the isle and the plateau des Echaudes, and is fully described at page 56. A Life-Boat is stationed at Paon point, ile de Brehat. Port de la Corderie, on the north-western side of ile de Brehat, is a grounding place where vessels of moderate draught find shelter,

Chap. II.] ILE DE BREHAT. 55 and at this little port is the government store of buoys, moorings, &c. Its entrance, on the northern side of the Kerpont channel, is only half a cable wide and open to the westward, it is southward of the large rock Kervarec, south-eastward of which, at three quarters of a cable, is a rocky ledge marked by two black beacons. Only half a cable southward of these is a red beacon marking the extreme of the rocks on the southern side. Three mooring buoys lie in mid-channel to assist vessels in taking up their berths. Vessels lie aground on a bottom of mud and sand from the entrance to the head of the port. At the outer buoy it dries 5 feet, at the second buoy 8 feet, and at the inner buoy 9 feet, at low water, springs. The best berth for vessels of about 15 feet draught is 2 cables within the entrance ; the sea here is rough only when it blows hard at high water, springs. Small coasters lie eastward of this position, and sometimes in the middle of the little cove at the head of the port, where the tide rises from 5 to 6 feet less^ than in the channel. Port ClOS, on the southern side of ile de Brehat between the southern entrances of Kerpont channel and Brehat road, although difficult of access, affords refuge to coasting vessels capable of taking the ground. Three rocks, in a straight line N.E. and S.W., divide the entrance of this port into two parts. The most southern, named Men-Allen, is near low-water mark and uncovers about 19 feet ; the second is about half a cable further in, and also uncovers 19 feet ; the third is about a cable northward of the second and uncovers 26 feet, This latter rock is joined to the western shore of the port by a cause way, which serves as a landing place, and which, when uncovered, shelters the inner part of the port. The bottom at the foot of the causeway dries 1^ feet at the lowest tides ; the best berth is half a cable N.N.E. of the rock at the end of the causeway, where the bottom dries nearly 11 feet. Most vessels, however, lie outside the causeway, about half a cable S.S.E. of the rock ; the grounding places here are good, but anchors have but little hold, and at high water it is exposed to winds from between W.S.W. and S.S.E. Port la Chambre. — If surprised in Brehat road with strong easterly winds, a vessel that can take the ground will find good shelter in port la Chambre, between the south-eastern part of ile de Brehat and Logodec and Lavrec islets. It dries at low water, and its principal entrance, about half a cable wide, is between the rocks

[Chap. II. 56 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. at the south-eastern point of the isle, and those adjacent to the western side of Logodec. A vessel cannot proceed farther into this port than the large islet lying abreast of the northern end of Logodec, which divides the channel into two branches. The best berth is about three quarters of a cable southward of that islet, where the bottom dries about 9 feet. A clump of trees surrounding Ste. Barbe chapel bearing S.S.W., and touching the eastern side of a large rock named Chateau-de-1'lle- Blanche, leads to the entrance. Rade de Brehat, on the southern side of ile de Brehat, is the only place between Heaux lighthouse and cape Frehel in which vessels of moderate draught can find shelter during strong winds from N.N.E. to N.N.W. The good holding ground trends East and West, in the direction of the white guard-house on ile de Bois on with the southern face of a high rock named Men-ar-Vran W. by N..| N. ; its eastern limit is the eastern face of Mets de Goelo islet on with the Men-Gam rock S. £ E.; and, its western limit, Ste. Barbe mill on with La Trinite point S. by W. \ W. The best anchorage is with ile de Bois guard-house on with the southern face of Men-ar-Vran ; and, Ste. Barbe mill, or the trees of Ste. Barbe chapel, on with the summit of ile Blanche de l'Arcouest S.S.W. \ W. This chapel is on the high land at the head of Paimpol bay, 300 yards westward of the mill. The least depth in the road at low water, springs, is 3 fathoms. A vessel should moor E.S.E. and W.N.W. DIRECTIONS for approaching RADE de BREHAT from the WESTWARD. — If wishing to seek shelter in this road from strong winds between N.N.W. and N.N.E., when pilots are not to be found in the offing, wait if possible N.N.E. of Heaux lighthouse till half flood, when the tide will have risen in the vicinity of ile de Brehat about 18^ feet. At this time, a vessel may run through Brehat channel into Brehat road without risk, for the channel, which is only 2 cables wide at low water, is then half a mile wide. Chenal de Brehat. — Having rounded the Roc'h-ar-Bel ledge, the leading mark through Brehat channel is, the white pyramid beacon on the Cormorandiere rock on with the white beacon tower at Port Moguer, near Plouha point, bearing S. \ W. westerly; this line leads 6 cables westward of the Pain de Bray rock and leaves the whole plateau des Echaudes on the port hand, passing its nearest rock, the Cadic, which has 15 feet on it at low water, at 1£ cables. It also

Chap. II.] RADE DE BREHAT. — CHANNELS INTO. 57 leaves on the starboard hand, the Roc'h-ar-Bel at 4 cables, the Men du-Castrec at 8 cables, and the Pen-Azen rocks at 4 cables. Until southward of Paon point, both flood and ebb streams set strongly across the channel, as they do again when Ferlas channel opens, but under cover of ile de Brehat the tides take the course of the channel. Follow the leading mark given until the red tower on Men-Garo rock comes on with the white pyramid on Quistillic rock, then haul more to the westward and bring the beacon on Piliers rock on with Lannevez mill W. \ S. This latter mark leads into Brehat road, passing three quarters of a cable south-eastward of the Basse de Men-Garo, a small patch on which there are about 26 feet, and a long cable north-westward of the Cam-ar-Rat, another patch on which there are 23 feet, at half tide. Entering CHENAL de BREHAT from MEN-du- CASTREC or MOISIE CHANNELS.— Sailing vessels rounding Roc'h-ar-Bel from the westward, with the wind and tide from that direction, are liable to be set eastward of the entrance to the channel, and run a risk of being thrown on the Horaine or Echaudes ledges ; and, to those leaving the channel with easterly winds during the ebb, there is a similar risk of not being able to weather the Roc'h-ar-Bel, and other shoals on the western side. In the former case, and to avoid this risk, vessels pass in-shore of Roc'h-ar-Bel through the Moisie or Men-du-Castrec channels, see page 52 ; and, crossing the Trieux channel, proceed to Brehat road either by the Kerpont or Brehat channel. If taking the Men-du-Castrec channel with this object, the leading mark as already given is, the white pyramid on Arcouest point on with the red beacon turret on the Vieille-de-Saint-Mode ; this line should be held only until the Moisie beacon turret is on with Heaux lighthouse, and then this latter mark leads between the Sirlots and Men-du-Castrec ledges, northward of Pen-Azen ledge, into the Brehat channel. From half flood to half ebb, yessels of 14 feet draught may run through this passage without any risk. With the wind between N.N.W. and W.S.W., and, even at low water, pilots use it not only for vessels bound to Brehat road, but also for those bound to ports in St. Brieuc bay. If taking the Moisie channel, the leading mark through is, the spire of the chapel of St. Michel, ile de Brehat, on with Rosedo white beacon tower S. g- E. ; but, as this channel is very narrow, the services of a pilot are indispensable. As Vieille-de-Saint-Mode red beacon turret is neared, the mark should be opened a little as it leads

HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. II 58 very close to that beacon ; cross the Trieux channel in the direction of the entrance to the Kerpont channel, and proceed through it by the directions following. Kerpont Channel.— This channel separates ile de Brehat from ile Beniguet and leads into Brehat road, but is only practicable for vessels of moderate draught after 4 hours flood, when that stream begins to slacken. At low water, springs, a rocky ledge which dries 9 feet, named le Pont, connects the two islands ; between them, and over this ledge, the tide at its full strength runs at the rate of 6 knots. The leading mark through is, the guard-house on Arcouest point seen in the middle of the space between the high rocks bordering each side of the channel bearing S. by W. \ W. ; which mark may also be used for the Men-du-Castrec channel. The Kerpont channel is practicable for vessels drawing 14| feet so long as the Vieille-de-Saint- Mode rock is covered, the least depth in the Kerpont at that time being 16^ feet. The Kerpont has two outlets to the southward ; one, midway between the south-western point of Brehat and the Noires ledge marked by a beacon turret with red and black bands on its northern rock, and by a beacon on its south-eastern rock, the Vis-Argent, which rock uncovers 17 feet ; the other, between this ledge and the large rocks off the eastern side of Raguenezbras isle marked on their eastern edge by a beacon on a rock which uncovers 19 feet at low water ; the leading mark for this passage is, the rock Beg-ar-Raz on with the westernmost house of Brehat. APPROACHING RADE de BREHAT from EAST and S.E. — The channels by which the road can be entered from the eastward are not much frequented, as the tidal streams cross them obliquely, but there is sufficient water for vessels of deep draught to run through them even at low water. The first channel eastward of Brehat channel is that between the Horaine and Echaudes ledges on the North, and Men-Marc'h ledge on the South. The leading mark through is, the summit of the high rocky islet Menou, half a mile eastward of La Trinite point, on with the two mills of Lande-Blanche S.W. f W. ; the mills are nearly in line from this direction. Follow this mark until Arcouest mill is on with a large forked rock lying close north-westward of Blanche de l'Arcouest isle W. S. or until La Rade black beacon turret is on with the white pyramid on Arcouest point ; either of these marks lead up to La Rade beacon turret, from whence a direct course may

Chap. II.] CHANNELS INTO THE RADE DE BREHAT. 59 be steered for the road ; or, the leading marks for the Ferlas channel may be brought on if bound for the Trieux river, see page 53. The next channel to the southward is between Men Marc'h and Ringue-bras ledges ; the leading mark is, the highest point of St. Riom isle on with Lande-Blanche north-eastern mill S.W. by W. f W. until Arcouest mill is on with the large forked rock W. S., or until La Rade beacon turret is on with Arcouest white pyramid, either of which marks lead up to La Rade beacon turret. With a moderate breeze, the Ringue-bras can be crossed at neaps from half flood to half ebb, by keeping Lande-Blanche north-eastern mill on with the highest point of St. Riom isle. The Banes de Sable may also be crossed under the same circumstances of wind and tide, by keeping Arcouest mill on with the large forked rock as before described. To pass southward of the Banes de Sable, and it is not prudent to cross them at low water, springs, bring the white pyramid on Quistillic rock between the old Mill and St. Michel chapel, ile de Brehat ; this leads close southward of their southern extreme, a short distance southward of the Basse Pomoriou on which there are only 9 feet, and between Ca'in-ar-Monse rock, awash, and a small patch named the Carec Mingui on which there are only 8 feet at low water, springs. When Arcouest mill comes on with the large forked rock, or when La Rade black beacon turret is on with the white pyramid on Arcouest point, steer for it as before described. Approaching Brehat road from the south-eastward, the northern mill on Brehat on with Quistillic pyramid N. by W. \ W. leads close westward of the highest heads of the Basse St. Brieuc, 1| miles off Minar point and marked by a red buoy on their eastern side ; these rocks are awash at the lowest tides ; also, over the north-eastern extreme of the Calemarguiers ledge, a short distance westward of the highest part of a sand-bank between this ledge and the Charpentiers ledge, close north-eastward of the Charpentiers ledge, marked by a red beacon turret, and of the white pyramid on the Cormorandiere rock. Follow this leading mark until Arcouest mill is on with the large forked rock, or until Arcouest pyramid is on with La Rade beacon turret, when proceed as before for Brehat road. Tides and Tidal Streams.— It is high water, full and change, around ile de Brehat, at5h. 51m. ; equinoctial springs rise about 39 feet, ordinary springs 31 feet, and ordinary neaps 23i feet. In Brehat road, the direction of the stream at the commencement of the flood, or 5 hours before high water, is S.W. by W. ; its greatest rate is 2 knots at 2\ hours before high water when its direction is E.S.E.

[Chap. II 60 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. The ebb begins to run to the N.W. a few minutes after high water Its greatest rate, 1£ knots, lasts from 3 to 4 hours after high water, when its direction varies from W.N.W. to W. by N. Winds from E.S.E. to S.S.E. cause a heavy sea in the road during the flood ; the holding ground, however, is good. The streams are not strong in Ferlas channel, which is a continua tion westward of this road ; the flood follows its direction as long as the banks are uncovered ; it then sets towards Arcouest point. About 20 minutes before high water, an eddy comes from Paimpol bay and, after rounding Arcouest point, it sets with some strength towards the south-eastern point of ile de Brehat, and also crosses the eastern part of Ferlas channel towards the Kerpont. Its rate decreases about the time of high water, but it regains strength when the ebb stream makes, which latter stream takes the direction of this eddy until the banks are uncovered, when it runs westward in the direction of the channel. ANSE and PORT de PAIMPOL.— This deep bay, formed between the high points of Trinite and Plouzec, is dry throughout nearly its whole extent at the lowest tides. Guilben point divides the bay into two parts, and northward of this long neck of land are the port of Paimpol and the principal beaching places. The port is inaccessible except for boats at neaps, and has a depth of from 13 to 19 feet only at high water, springs ; the entrance is between the Kernoa pier which projects 200 yards from the southern shore, and the north extreme of the quays on the opposite shore. The little river Quinic flows through it and forms a very tortuous channel through the sands of the bay when they uncover. The harbour is about, 380 yards in length and 250 yards in breadth at its widest part, and the bottom is everywhere soft. The town of Paimpol has between 1,500 and 2,000 inhabitants and is a place of some importance from its extensive deep sea fishery, which employs about 40 or 50 schooners of from 120 to 200 tons. The quay frontage, including the pier, is not less than 450 yards in extent, the berths good, and any swell of importance very rarely felt. The bottom however being above the level of half-tide, vessels of any size arriving when the tides are taking off are liable to be neaped for several days. A wet dock 672 feet long and from 252 to 328 feet wide, with the sill at the entrance 16^ feet above the level of the lowest tides, has been lately constructed at this port on the eastern side of the tidal harbour. A life-boat is stationed at Paimpol.

Chap, il] PAIMPOL. 61 The bay of Paimpol is easily recognised from seaward ; on its northern side, by point Arcouest with a guard-house on its summit and its white pyramid beacon, northward of point de la Trinite, and by St. Riom isle, high, rocky, and with indented summit ; on its southern side, by the island Mets de Goelo, two thirds of a mile north-eastward from Plouzec point, high and with rounded grassy top sloping abruptly to the sea on all ides, with Torel, a little sugar loaf islet surmounted by a semaphore, between it and Plouzec point. Whilst, marking the off -lying reefs in the central part of the bay, are the Cormorandiere white pyramid and the two beacon turrets marking the Charpentiers and Gouayan rocks, 'the former red, the latter black. Anchorage. — There is anchorage both south-westward and south eastward of St. Riom isle, in the narrow channel separating the mud-banks of Paimpol bay from those which dry at the southern end of this isle. There is a red beacon on the Plateaux des Fillettes, southward of St. Riom. A vessel will have a good berth by mooring North and South, south-westward of the isle, in 4 fathoms, muddy bottom, with the guard-house on Arcouest point on with the northern extreme of Trinite point ; and, the white pyramid on the Cormorandiere rock between the white beacon turret on the Denou rock and the north-western rock of the Roho ledge. There is not much sea here, even during strong easterly winds, except at high water. The holding ground south-eastward of St. Riom isle is good but more exposed to easterly winds. It lies in the direction of the beacon on the Ar-Zel rock on with the summit of Blanche de Guilben isle W. f S. ; its north-eastern limit is Heaux lighthouse just opening out from behind Arcouest point ; and, its south-western limit, the guard house on Minar point a little open eastward of Plouzec point, Beaching Places. — The best grounding places in this bay are in front of port Paimpol, northward of Guilben point, and the most frequented are on the flat between the channel and the rocks which border the shore from the port to the point. The bottom is mud and sand, and dries about 16£ feet. The sea is rough here at high water, springs, when it blows hard from the eastward, but the bottom is soft, and the sea goes down before a vessel takes the ground. There is also a good beaching place between the extreme of Guilben point and ile Blanche de Guilben. The best berth is about li cables northward of the isle, where the bottom is soft mud a'nd is about 10 feet above the level of the lowest tides. Another good position, where vessels lie up during the winter, is in the northern

HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. II. 62 part of the bay, in front of the hollow in the shore under the high coast of Lande de Portz-don. At this place, a vessel drawing 10| feet will be neaped only one day. Port Lazo, also, in the south-eastern part of Paimpol bay under the high land of Plouzec point, is a good position to beach a vessel of moderate draught. The berths do not dry more than 9^ feet and are well sheltered. LIGHT. — From the gable end of the keeper's dwelling on Portz don point, on the northern shore, one mile from the entrance to Paimpol harbour, an occulting light is exhibited at 35 feet above high water showing red through an arc of 7^° between the bearings N.W. by W. \ W. and W. by N. f N. northerly ; and, white through an arc of 3^° between the bearings W. by N. f N. northerly and W. by N \ N. ; in all other directions the light. is obscured. The ivhite light is visible in clear weather from a distance of 11 miles ; the red light, from a distance of 7 miles. CHANNELS LEADING to ANSE de PAIMPOL.— There are five channels leading to the anchorages near St. Riom isle, viz., the Trinite, Lastel, St. Riom, Denou, and Jument channels; they are all difficult of access, lying in the midst of the dangers by which Paimpol bay is surrounded in all directions, and, of the five, two only, the Denou and the Jument, are, after half flood, practicable without a pilot. Trinite Channel, the entrance to which is southward of Brehat road between the Piliers rocks and those off the northern end of ile Blanche de l'Arcouest, is generally taken by vessels bound to Paimpol in charge of pilots, who have conducted them through the Moisie or Men-du-Castrec and Kerpont channels, see pages 52 and 58. It unites with the Lastel channel half a mile northward of Trinite point. Lastel Channel is a narrow passage southward of the Men- Gam rock and of the rocky ledge extending from the southern end of ile Blanche de l'Arcouest. Pilots generally take vessels to sea from Paimpol through this channel. St.- Riom channel is the narrowest of all, and is but seldom used. It is close to the north-western side of St. Riom isle, between it and the Vras rock.

Chap, ii.] CHANNELS INTO PAIMPOL BAY. 63 D6"nou Channel is just eastward of St. Riom isle, between Garap and Rohan-heir ledges. It carries a depth of 19 feet and has the advantage of lying in the direction of the flood stream, but it is narrow and, including the space which separates it from ile de Brehat, can only be navigated by the aid of a good local pilot, and with a fair wind. After half flood, if the leading mark can be seen, a vessel may run through without risk. Jument channel. — The entrance to this channel is about 1£ miles northward of Plouzec point, between two large and remark able rocks one mile apart in a N. by E. \ E. and S. by W. \ W. direction ; the one, named the Ost-Pic,is at the eastern extreme of Mets de Goelo island, the other at the south-eastern edge of the Roho ledge. The channel has only'7^ feet at low water, springs, but at half flood there are 22 feet on the bank extending from the southern part of the Roho ledge to the Jument rock. The Jument, Gueule, and Gouayan rocks divide this channel into two parts, both of which are practicable for vessels of moderate draught. The Jument uncovers 1\ feet, the Gueule 3 feet, and the Gouayan 16 feet at the lowest tides. The Jument and the Gouayan have beacon turrets, the Jument being painted with red and black bands, and the Gouayan, black ; the Gueule lies midway between the beacons, about half a mile E.S.E. of the Jument. Directions. — If bound to Paimpol bay from the northward, through the Brehat channel, and intending to run through the Denou channel to the anchorages under St. Riom isle, to the harbour of Paimpol, or to any of the beaching places in the bay ; having passed through Brehat channel by the directions already given at page 56, steer S.S.W. f W. with Rundavi mill on with the white beacon turret on Denou rock, which rock is only about a quarter of a mile E.S.E. from the eastern point of St. Riom isle. Pass within 25 yards westward of this rock as the Basse du Denou, nearly awash at low water, is but 60 yards westward of it, leaving a channel only 50 yards wide through which the tide runs with great strength. Having passed the Denou, the beacon on Ar-zel rock on with the summit of Blanche de Guilben isle W. f S. leads to the anchorage south-eastward of St. Riom isle, or the vessel may. be steered .for one of the beaching places in the bay. The leading mark given, Rundavi mill on with Denou rock, passes very closely westward of la Petite Moisie black beacon, the Moisie rock which does not cover, the Rohan-hier ledge, and the Guillaume rocks, of which the western but deepest end

64 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. II. touches the line of direction; and, eastward of Lei-Done, the north western rock of Bongreve ledge, the Garap ledge and red beacon, the Valve rock, and the rocks extending eastward from St. Riom. If the Jument channel be preferred ; having run through Brehat channel, bring the Ost-Pic on with the white pyramid on the Cormor andiere S.S.W. and the vessel will pass eastward of Cain-ar-Monse, a rock awash at the lowest tides ; when southward of this rock, or when the guard-house on Arcouest point bears W. N., steer south-eastward to bring Plouzec mill on with the eastern fall of Mets de Goelo islet S.W. by S. This line leads a cable eastward of the Cormorandiere bank. From thence, Plouzec mill on with the Ost-Pic S.W. leads eastward of the Charpentiers ledge, marked by a red beacon turret, and to the entrance of the channel. The leading mark into the anchorage is then, Bois-neuf mill on with Bervidic point, on which is a small pine wood. Pass northward of the beacon turrets on the Gouayan and Jument rocks and anchor, or steer for a beaching place as before directed. Approaching from the south-eastward, a vessel should pass between the coast and the off-lying shoals between Minar and Plouzec points, and between the Ost-Pic and the Calemarguiers rocks, by keeping the summit of the large rock at the south-eastern part of the Roho ledge on with the eastern point of Ar-Morbic isle N. \ W. This isle is on the eastern side of Brehat, and on this bearing appears as part of it ; its eastern point is high, well defined, and is the eastern extreme of land seen to the northward. Give the Ost-Pic a berth of about 2 cables in rounding, and from thence steer for the anchorages or grounding places, passing southward of the beacon turrets on the Gouayan and Jument. At night. — Vessels approaching Paimpol anchorages at night can only enter by the Jument channel; they should keep carefully within the limits of Portz-don ivhite light, bearing in mind that the light is obscured northward of this sector, and that it shows red southward of it. Coming from the northward through Brehat channel, a vessel should enter the sector of white light shown from Paon point, and keep within its limits until Portz-don white light is seen, towards which she must then steer ; Paon point light will then change to red, and finally become obscured ; half a mile farther, Heaux light will be masked by St. Riom isle when the anchor should be instantly let go, and the vessel will be in about 5 fathoms. Tides and Tidal Streams. — It is high water, full and change, at Paimpol at 6h. Om. ; springs rise 31 feet, neaps 231 feet ; but, the

Chap. II.] DIRECTIONS, PAIMPOL BAY. — GRAND LEJON. 65 bottom being above the level of half tide, there are only 13 feet in the harbour at high water, ordinary springs. The flood stream which enters Paimpol bay, after rounding the south-western part of ile de Brehat, sets S.S.W. and S.S.E. ; but, at about four hours flood, its direction is S.S.W. and S.W. and an «ddy begins to follow the windings of the shore from Mets de Goelo towards Arcouest point. The breadth of this eddy increases rapidly ; at one hour before high water it extends to the anchorage south-eastward of St. Riom isle, and at this time, and even after half flood, a vessel running from Brehat road to Paimpol with a light wind, had better pass eastward of St. Riom isle, and even of the Cormorandiere rock, rather than attempt the Trinite channel, which can only be taken when the wind is sufficiently strong to stem this eddy. The ebb stream follows the same direction as the eddy on the flood and forms an eddy behind each projecting point of the coast ; but, as the banks uncover, the body of the stream trends more and more towards Brehat, southward of which it divides, one part passing eastward of the isle ; the other, after crossing Brehat road, running through Kerpont channel, and between the islets and rocks westward of it. The velocity of both streams increases in the narrow channels, but around the Cormorandiere bank, as well as eastward of Mets de Goelo and of Minar point, it does not exceed 4 knots at springs and 2 knots at neaps. GRAND LEJON is the highest head of a rocky ledge 9 cables in extent in a N.E. by E. and S.W. by W. direction, nearly midway between ile de Brehat and Cape Frehel ; it is near the southern edge of the ledge, dries 23 feet at low water, and covers 2\ hours before high water, springs. On this head stands the lighthouse, and from it, Heaux lighthouse bears N.W. \ N. 19 miles, with Paon point lighthouse a little open westward and distant 14£ miles ; Harbour island lighthouse W.S.W. southerly 1\ miles ; and, Cape Frehel lighthouse S.E. by E. 14 miles. From it also, the steeple of Plourhan church is on with St. Quay Point and with the lighthouse on Harbour isle ; and, Turquet mill is on with the most southern of the high lands of Erqui S.S.E. \ E. The Bouillons, shoal patches of from 4 to 15 feet, lie nearly half a mile north-eastward of the lighthouse; and, the Basses du Sud-Est, with 2\ fathoms least water, lie three quarters of a mile southward of it. LIGHT. — From the tower on Grand Lejon rock, which is 76 feet high from base to vane, a light is exhibited at 52 feet above high A 2771. Wt. 7242 fi

Fog Signal. — In foggy weather, a bell is sounded twice every eight seconds with an interval of one second between the two strokes. (See note, page 10.) PETIT LEJON.— The highest head of the Petit Lejon bears S. by E. 3i miles from the Grand Lejon lighthouse and it uncovers only 9 feet. From it, the northern mill of Plevenon is on with the northern face of the Rohinet rock S.E. by E. \ E. ; and, Turquet mill, is on with the northern part of Lahoussaye point S.E. f S. Buoy. — A black bell buoy is moored off the western side of the Petit Lejon. Tides. — The tidal streams run with great strength in the vicinity of the Grand and Petit Lejon, and the sea is heavy in bad weather. The Coast.— From Pointe de Plouzec, Minar point bears S.S.E. E. 1£ miles. Rocks extend three cables from the foot of this point, which is high and surmounted by a white pyramid visible many miles seaward ; from it, St. Quay point bears S. by E. £ E. 7 miles, and the coast between is steep and inaccessible, except, during off shore winds, to boats on the beach of Brechech bay about If miles southward of Minar point, and on the beach fronting St. Quay village about three cables westward of St. Quay point. Plouha point, 4£ miles S. \ E. from Minar point and 1\ miles N.N.W. f W. from Bee de Vir, is the highest point in St. Brieuc bay ; it termi nates in a perpendicular rocky cliff, 330 feet high, and visible in clear weather 25 miles distant. Bee de Vir point is If miles north ward of St. Quay point, which is steep but much lower than the points northward of it. The Taureau rock, which uncovers 33 feet at the lowest tides, lies in the bight between Minar point and the Mauve rock, and is marked by a stone beacon tower painted with red and black bands. The

Chap. II.] LEJON ROCKS.— COAST.— SAINT QUAY ROCKS. 67 white pyramid on the Cormorandiere rock open about half a point eastward of Minar point, leads eastward of it. The Mauve is a large rock off point Gouine-Segal, 4 cables from the shore, and 3 cables north-eastward of the Pommier rock ; it never covers, and forms with other rocks surrounding it a ledge 4 cables long East and West. The Place de Greve, the Traverse, and the Oiseaux, are shoal patches nearly on the parellel of Plouha point, and 1£ to 2£ miles from it. The Place de Greve, the shoalest and nearest the shore, carries a depth of 3 fathoms, and, from it, the southern mill of Plouzec is on with the centre of the Mauve rock ; the other two patches have from 5 to 7 fathoms over them. Abreast of the Bee de Vir and a good half mile from the shore is the northern end of St. Marc bank, which, from thence, extends about a mile southward with a least depth of 2| fathoms. Anchorage. — The shore between Minar and Plouha points is clear of dangers, with the exception of those just described, and with off-shore winds may be approached within half a mile. With the wind between E.N.E. and South, however, a vessel should avoid approaching too near, as the streams set into the bight. If obliged by a calm to anchor, endeavour to do so when the steeple of Treveneuc church is on with the Comtesse de Gueredon, a large rock at the foot of Plouha point, bearing South. ROCHES de SAINT QUAY— This rocky group, fronting the western coast of St. Brieuc bay abreast of St. Quay point, covers a space nearly 5 miles long N.W. by N. and S.E. by S., and 2\ miles wide ; from its northern extreme, the steeple of Plouha church is nearly on with the rocks terminating Bee de Vir point, W. by N. \ N. northerly ; and, from its south-eastern edge, 3f miles from the nearest land, Etables church bears W. by N. f N., and Roselier point S. by W. \ W. 4^ miles. Harbour isle, the principal rock, is a large, round, steep, and isolated islet with a lighthouse on it, lying north-westward of the main group of rocks and islets, and one mile E.N.E. from St. Quay point; only 10 or 12 heads cover on this part of the group. The northernmost rock is the Tour de l'eau ; it uncovers 6 feet, and is about 6 cables northward of Harbour isle and nearly 2 cables in the same direction from the Madeux beacon turret, which is coloured red on its eastern side, black on its western side ; Plouha church steeple well open northward of Bee de Vir point, leads clear of the northern E 2

On the south-eastern part, all the rocks cover with the exception of the Houesse, the summit of which is 35^ feet above the lowest tides and only covers at the highest springs ; the Ronde and Longue rocks, which dry 25 and 26 feet respectively and are not covered at high water, ordinary neaps ; and, the Caffa rock, which uncovers 2 feet only. The Ronde is marked by a black beacon turret, and the Longue by a beacon turret with its north-eastern face painted white. The Caffa, the south-eastern head of the group, bears E. f N. 4 miles from the eastern pier-head of Port Binic. The highest head of the Comtesses rocks, off Point Pleneuf, on with cape Frehel, or Etables and Plourhan church steeples in line, bearing N.W. by W., lead south ward of it. Plateau des Hors lies eastward of the principal rocks of the St. Quay group and is separated from them by a channel 3 cables wide which is bounded on the West by the Petit Aubert, a rock which uncovers 12 feet, and on the East by a patch named Grande Place nearly awash at the lowest tides. The north-eastern rock of the ledge uncovers 4 feet ; the marks for it are, the Rohein rock seen between Turquet mill and the high lands of Erqui S.E. by E. \ E. ; and, the eastern peak of Mener-bel-Air mountain on with Pature point S. £ W. Buoys. — The following buoys mark these dangers on their eastern, south-eastern, and southern sides. A red bell buoy surmounted by a vane, is moored 3 cables east ward of the plateau des Hors. A red bnoy surmounted by a vane shaped like a double X is moored nearly 2 cables south-eastward of the Caffa rock. A black buoy is moored two thirds of a cable south-westward of the south-westernmost danger, the Roseliere, a rock which dries 9 feet, LIGHT. — The lighthouse on Harbour isle, the principal rock of the St. Quay group, is a square tower ; it exhibits a fixed white light at 49 feet above high water. The light is dioptric, of the fourth order, and in clear weather is visible from a distance of 10 miles. From the lighthouse, the eastern edge of the Banes de Sable bears N.N.E. 9 miles ; the Grand Lejon lighthouse E.N.E. northerlv 7i miles ; and, the Petit Lejon rock E. I S. 7§ miles. Chap. II.] PLATEAU DES HORS. — PORTRIEUX. 69 an interval of six seconds, a double stroke, another interval of six seconds, followed by fourteen strokes, &c. (See note, page 10.) PORTRIEUX is in the northern part of Portrieux bay half a mile southward of St. Quay point ; the St. Quay rocks, lying exactly in front of it, form a natural breakwater both to the harbour and roadstead ; it is used by vessels capable of taking the ground, and dries 13 feet at the lowest tides, but at high water, springs, it has from 26 to 19 feet, and at high water of the lowest neaps, 10 feet ; and, consequently, has more water than any other port in St. Brieuc bay. The town contains about 1,000 inhabitants, and, being a watering place, its population is more than doubled during the summer months. The harbour is formed by a stone pier, extending 373 yards in a southerly direction from the northern point, which pier also serves as a quay ; the harbour is 550 yards in extent North and South, and about half that width The navigable entrance between the coast and the pier being not less than 200 yards in width, there is sufficient space for small vessels to tack if the wind should be scant on entering or leaving A Life-Boat is stationed at this port. LIGHT. — On the pier-head at Portrieux stands a white iron light house, from which at 33 feet above the sea is exhibited a fixed red light, visible in clear weather 5 miles. Portrieux road, between the St. Quay rocks and the coast, has good holding ground and sufficient depth for vessels of 14 feet draught, It should not be used, however, with strong easterly winds, except at the lowest neaps, and then only when the shelter on the eastern side of the bay in Erqui road or under Pleneuf point cannot be reached. Anchorage. — The anchorage in this road is comprised within the following limits : — The Hergue and Pommier rocks in one (the Hergue is a remarkable rock N.N.W. 6 cables from St. Quay point and has a white beacon turret, the Pommier is a similar rock close to Plouha point, and has a whitewashed mark) ; the Hergue on with the foot of the steep declivity of Plouha point ; Caruhel Mill on with the Four rock white beacon turret ; and, Portrieux church on with the centre of Portrieux pier. The depths are from 14 to 18 feet between the southern limit and the line of St. Michel mill on with the pier-head. On this latter line, from West to East, there are from 10 to 20 feet, and, between it and the northern limit, from 11 to 12

70 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. II, feet. The best berth with most water is, with Etables steeple on with the Four rock ; and, St. Michel mill and the pier-head in line. Directions. — Vessels approaching either the roadstead or port of Portrieux from any direction, may do so by passing between St. Quay rocks and the coast, or by rounding the southern end of these rocks, according as tide and wind best serve. To pass between St. Quay rocks and the coast ; bring the Moulieres red beacon on with Four rock white beacon turret S. f W. This mark leads between the northern part of St. Quay rocks and St. Marc bank, and should be kept on until the vessel has arrived within 3^ cables N.E. by E. of St. Quay point, when Herflux and Longue beacon turrets will be in line and should be steered for, to clear the Mouliere rocks which uncover 15 feet, until the Four beacon turret is on with the lofty spire of Pordic church S. by W. f W. ; follow this direction until the leading mark for the southern part of the channel comes on, viz., the Hergue white beacon turret and Pommier rock in line N.N.W. \ W., passing between the conical black buoy of the Noirs on the port hand, and the red buoy marking the Pi-Alien shoal on the starboard hand. In steering with the Four beacon turret on with Pordic spire, if the vessel is above 14 feet draught, do not wait until the Hergue and Pommier rocks are in one, but leave that direction the moment the Hergue is on with Plouha point. The vessel, if not drawing more than 14 feet, may now either anchor in Portrieux road, as directed, or, if the tide suits, she may run on S.S.E. \ E. with Hergue and Pommier rocks in one, remembering that this mark leads over the Basse Meridionale de la Rade, a shoal of 6 feet ; close to another of 8 feet, 3 cables N.W. of the 6-feet shoal ; and, over the Traverse, a sand-bank which trends upwards of 1\ miles iii a S.S.W. direction from the southern part of St. Quay rocks and on which the least water is 4 feet, When Etables steeple is on with that of Plourhan N.W. by W. ; or, when cape Frehel lighthouse is on with the highest point of the Comtesse rocks, the vessel may either haul to the eastward with the latter mark on, or steer for port Binic, avoiding the Ours-Seul rock, which uncovers 9 feet and is 4 cables from the shore 1£ miles northward of that port, by not coming nearer the shore than to have the Four rock beacon turret on with Comtesse isle. Approaching the roadstead by the southern passage, it is necessary to ascertain that there is a sufficient rise of tide to cross the Traverse bank and other shoal patches just named. The height of the tide

Chap. II.] PORTRIEUX. — PORT BINIC. 71 by the Ronde and Longue rocks, which uncover 25 and 26 feet, is a useful indication of the depth on these shoals. To enter the port of Portrieux, the leading mark is Portrieux spire on with the extreme end of the pier ; this leaves at a short distance on the port hand the Four, Vache, and Pannerais rocks. The Vache uncovers 7 feet, and the Pannerais 12 feet, at the lowest tides. Pilots. — The pilots for Portrieux also take vessels to ports Binic and Legue ; they generally cruise as far seaward as the Lejons. No stranger should attempt the channel between the roches de St. Quay and the coast, or enter either of these ports without a pilot. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Portrieux at 6 h. 0 m. ; ordinary springs rise 32 feet ; neaps 23^ feet. The tidal streams in, Portrieux road follow nearly the direction of the Hergue and Pommier rocks in line. At springs, the greatest strength of the flood between Harbour isle and St. Quay point, as well as among the rocks northward of the road, is 4^ knots ; the strength of the ebb is rather less. PORT BINIC is less than 3 miles southward of Portrieux, and about 5 miles N.W. f N. from Roselier point ; it is at the head of a little bay half a mile wide and open to the eastward. It consists of an outer and inner harbour. The outer harbour is formed by the Penthievre mole which extends 384 yards from the northern point of the bay in a south-easterly direction, its outer portion turning abruptly southward ; at its outer end is the lighthouse. The inner harbour is greatly sheltered by this mole though, as the bay is naturally quite open eastward, the swell and sea caused by easterly gales are much felt in both. The entrance to the inner harbour is between two stone jetties ; the inner harbour is 550 yards in length eastward and westward, and has an average breadth of 93 yards. The berths at the foot of the eastern jetty dry 17 feet, and those near the landing creek at the upper end of the port 25 feet above the lowest tides ; those alongside l'Estacade, the southern jetty, are the highest, and are only used by vessels of small draught. The outer port has from 3 to 6 feet more water than the inner port and can be entered by vessels of about 10 feet draught at high water, ordinary neaps, and those of 14 feet can enter it from 1^ hours before to H hours after high water, springs. It affords good shelter, with winds from South round by West to N.N.W., but with strong winds from North round by East the shelter is bad, and vessels strike heavily before the

The town of Binic has over 1000 inhabitants and its chief industry consists in its extensive deep sea fishery, about 30 vessels averaging 170 tons, and carrying 1600 hands, leaving this port annually for the Newfoundland cod fishery. With this exception its trade is unimportant. LIGHT.— A fixed white light is exhibited from a circular granite tower on the mole-head at port Binic ; it is 36 feet above high water and is visible in clear weather 10 miles. Directions. — When bound to port Binic, if the wind is between N.N.E. and W.S.W. a vessel with a sufficient rise of tide, may pass between the coast and St. Quay rocks ; with the wind between N.N.E. and E.S.E. she can pass on either side of these rocks ; but, if between S.E. and S.W., she should keep eastward of them. With strong winds from N.E. to East, a vessel should always pass eastward of them, but, before venturing so far into the bay, a calculation should be made, allowing for the 'scend of the sea, that the tide has risen sufficiently high over the broad flats in front of the port to prevent all risk of striking the ground. Passing eastward of St. Quay rocks, which it is generally prudent to do at neaps ; if, after rounding their south-eastern extreme, it is found that the vessel cannot fetch port Binic, shelter may be sought under Roselier point, 5 miles south-eastward of Binic ; see also Directions at page 76. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at port Binic at 6 h. 3 m. ; springs rise 30 feet, neaps 22^ feet, When the Longue rock, at the southern part of the St. Quay group is awash, there are 14f feet at the foot of the outer pier-head of port Binic ; 11 feet at the entrance of port Legue ; 12i feet at the entrance of port Dahouet ; and, nearly 23 feet on the grounding places close southward of Roselier point. When the highest head of the Trahillions ledge or the Grand Lejon rock, cover, they both uncover 23 feet at springs, there are 1H feet at the outer pier-head of port Binic ; 7| feet at the entrance of Legue ; 9^ feet at the entrance of Dahouet. Anchorage. — Vessels waiting tide to enter port Binic or port Legue can anchor, in fine weather, abreast of Binic on a bottom of clayey mud in about 3 fathoms, with the Pommier rock and Hergue white beacon turret in line, bearing N.N.W. \ W.

II.] PORT BINIC. — THE COAST. 73 The COAST rises in height gradually from St. Quay point to Binic, between which place and Roselier point it is high and steep, except at Rosaires beach, south-eastward of Pordic Point, where boats can always land with off-shore winds. The bank bordering the coast dries out one mile abreast of Binic, and half a mile at Rosaires beach. On the bank northward of Binic are several rocks besides the Four and the Ours-Seul, 1^ miles southward of the Four, and both already described. Close westward of the Four is Fille rock, which dries 19 feet, and 2 cables southward of it is Noyes ledge, which dries 2 feet above the bank. The Equerrets, Petit-Gripet, and Grand-Gripet, are three small rocky ledges abreast of Rosaires beach, and dangerous to vessels borrowing too closely on the shore. The highest head of the Equerrets bears E. by S. \ S. 8 cables from the foot of Pordic point and uncovers about a foot. The highest head of the Petit-Gripet uncovers about a foot, and is about half a mile from the shore, with the Martin, a high rock which never covers near the shore northward of Roselier point, on with the foot of Roselier point S. by E. £ E. there are more than 14 feet water on this danger when the eastern extreme of the Martin rock is covered. The Grand-Gripet, with 2 feet over it, bears N. by E. f E. nearly 1\ miles from the Martin, the summit of which is then a little eastward of the principal house of a large farm on the high land. ROSELIER POINT, 5 miles S.E. f S. from port Binic, is high and steep on its northern and southern sides, but terminates in a gentle declivity on its eastern side. If a vessel can take the ground, there is excellent shelter close southward of this point, on the northern shore of a little bay called port Aurelle, protected from all winds from South round by West to N.E. The bottom, of muddy sand, dries only 3 feet above the lowest tides, so that, if of about 14 feet draught, she can run for shelter from two hours before to two hours after high water. The COAST between Roselier and Pleneuf points, which bear E. h N. and W. \ S. distant 6% miles from each other, falls back to the southward and forms the head of St. Brieuc bay, in which are port Legue, the Anse d'Yffiniac, and port Dahouet. Several dangers front this part of the shore, of which the farthest in the offing are the Trahillions, Basse Herbaut, Trois Tetes, and the

74 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. II. Daouet. The Trahillions form a rocky ledge, about three quarters of a mile in extent E.S.E. and W.N.W. at the edge of the bank, which, abreast of Guettes point, dries more than a mile from the shore at low water, springs ; the ledge is terminated at its eastern end by a rock which uncovers 23 feet on which is a beacon turret ; and, at the western end, by another rock which uncovers 83 feet, Basse Herbaut and the Daouet rock are both awash at the lowest tides, the latter being marked by a red spindle buoy moored off its northern side. The Trois Tetes, lying between the Herbaut and Daouet rocks, have only two feet over them, and their inner head, called the Armelent rock, has on it a red beacon. A vessel will pass outside all these dangers by keeping the summit of cape d'Erqui open northward of Petit Verdelet islet about the width of that rock ; or, by keeping Rohinet rock, off cape d'Erqui, on with the highest head of the Jaunes rocks, off Pleneuf point, N.E. by E. I E. ; and, 200 yards westward of the Trahillions, by keeping the spire of the church of St. Pierre at St. Brieuc, or the mill near the church, on with the houses of Sous-la-Tour, a little hamlet in front of Cesson tower, at the foot of the high land which forms the southern side of the entrance to the river Legue. LEGUE or PORT de St. BRIEUC is about a mile within the mouth of the river Gouet, the entrance to which is 1£ miles southward of Roselier point and between Chatern and Cesson points, the latter being the north-western extreme of Yffiniac bay. Legue owes its importance to the proximity of the large town of St. Brieuc, only a mile distant and with a population of 16,500. St. Brieuc is in direct railway communication with Paris and Brest, and also with the Morbihan coast line. The port extends to the bridge. above the town of Legue and has over 1,500 yards of wharfage, besides a wet dock 325 yards long and averaging 71 yards wide, which has, however, only 14^ feet water at spring tides. Between 500 and 600 vessels enter the port annually, their average tonnage being 54 tons, and one third of them are either English or Norwegian. A considerable steam traffic exists at certain seasons between here and the Channel islands. The port can only be entered by vessels of any size at springs, and is at all times difficult of access although well buoyed. The bottom between Cesson point and Sous-la-Tour hamlet dries 15 feet, the berths at the foot of the quay 20 feet, and those near the bridge 22 feet, above the lowest tides. On the summit of Cesson point are the ruins of Cesson tower, which tower serves as a landmark and can be seen from a distance of 15 miles. From a little northward of

Chap, ii.] LEGUE. — ANSE D'YFFINIAC. — DAHOUET. 75 Chatern point, the channel into port Legue is marked by beacons and buoys, red on the northern and black on the southern side. LIGHT. — A fixed ivhite light is exhibited from a circular tower on Aigle point, at the entrance of port Legue ; it is 43 feet above high water, and is visible in clear weather 10 miles. Bane de Chatern and Gallettes rocks are the only dangers to be avoided when entering port Legue. The bank trends in a S. by W. direction from Roselier point and rests upon Chatern point. The Gallettes is a small ledge which uncovers 10 feet, 3 cables eastward of Cesson point. Directions. — When bound to Legue, if from the westward, follow the directions given at pages 47, 56, 70, and 76, until southward of the St. Quay rocks ; or, if from the eastward, those given at pages 82-84, until past the Rohein rock ; then steer to bring Roselier and Cesson points in line S.W. by S., which will be the leading mark until within 2 miles of the former point ; then steer towards Pature point until the northern tower of the church of St. Michel, at St. Brieuc, is seen between the southern tower of the same church, on which there is a telegraph, and the most southerly houses of Sous-la-Tour hamlet, which mark leads to the entrance of the port. Vessels before bearing up for the port should carefully estimate the depth of water over the sands in its front by observing the height of the tide at the Longue rock, or at the Martin rock. When the eastern head of the latter is awash, there are only 3 feet in the channel from off point Aigle to Sous-la-Tour hamlet ; when the next head to this, is awash, there are 1\ feet at the same place ; and, when the Longue rock is awash, there are 11 feet. ANSE d'YFFINIAC— This deep bight, between Cesson and Pature points, is choked by- sands over which the tide flows at high water, but which are uncovered for miles at low water ; a good mark for their outer edge being, a line drawn from the Martin rock to the Trahillions beacon turret ; and, to keep well outside this edge, the mark is, Bien-Assis wood open northward of the old semaphore of Dahouet. DAHOUET.— The entrance to this little inlet bears E. \ S. 5§ miles from Roselier point, and is 1\ miles south-westward of Pleneuf point ; it is between the shore on the port hand and the pier-head on the starboard hand ; there is also a red beacon turret

76 HEAUX LIGHTHOUSE TO CAPE FREHEL. [Chap. II. on the Petite Muette rock in the entrance, to be left on the star board hand. The port is open to the North-west, but affords fair shelter to small vessels which can take the ground. The trade is chiefly with the Channel Islands but is very inconsiderable. There are about 300 yards of quay frontage, and the town or village consists of 30 or 40 houses, with about 200 inhabitants. The bottom of the harbour dries 13 feet above the level of the lowest tides abreast of the pier-head ; 18 feet in front of the western part of the quay ; about 22 feet at the angle of the quay ; and, 24 feet near the mill sluice at the head of the port, The principal dangers in approaching the port from the northward are, the Bignons des Jaunes, the Godiche, and the Daouet rock. The Bignons des Jaunes are, at the south-western edge of the Jaunes ridge and uncover 24 feet ; when they are awash there is plenty of water over the Godiche, 10^ feet at the entrance of the port, and 4 or 5 feet at the grounding berths within. The Godiche is a small patch of 7 feet half a mile westward of the Bignons, with the Petit Bignon a little open southward of the summit of the Jaunes. The Daouet Rock is three quarters of a mile north-west ward of the entrance of the port, and is awash at low water, springs ; it is marked by a red spindle buoy on its northern side. Should the buoy be gone, the small steeple of Pleneuf seen over the downs, and open about half a point northward of the steep coast northward of the point, leads northward of the rock. > Tides. — It is high water, fjn.ll and change, at port Dahouet at 6h. 5m. Springs rise 32 feet, neaps 23^ feet. Springs rise at the foot of the western part of the quay from 16 to 20 feet, neaps from 5 to 6 feet. When the Longue rock is awash, there are 12^ feet water at the entrance ; when the Bignons des Jaunes are awash there are IO5 feet, and when the highest head of the Trahillions covers there are 9^ feet. When southward of the St. Quay rocks, a vessel may haul up for Binic or steer for Legue as already directed. If for Dahouet, when southward of the Rohein which bears N. by W. 4| miles from the entrance of the port, the only dangers to be avoided are the Bignons, the Basse Godiche, and the Daouet rocks, already described. With the wind between S.W. and S.S.E. a vessel should always pass eastward of the Horaine, in rounding which take care she is not set too far eastward by the flood. When southward of the Grand Lejon, and to avoid the Petit-Lejon, do not open the summit of the Comtesses westward of the southern extreme of Bien-Assis wood ; and, in approaching the Rohein ledge, keep Guettes point well open westward of the Rohein rock until the vessel is southward of that rock. In standing to the westward, be careful not to approach too near the St. Quay rocks ; Pature point kept open westward of Mener-Bel-Air mountain, at least double the apparent distance between its eastern and western peaks, leads a safe distance eastward of them, and when cape Frehel lighthouse is on with the highest head of the Comtesses, or when Etables and Plourhan church steeples in line bear N.W. by W. she is southward of their south-eastern extreme. At Night, after rounding the Horaine, the Grand Lejon white flashing light is an excellent guide for entering St. Brieuc bay. A vessel should pass about two miles westward of it, and, on entering its western red sector, edge to the eastward to cross that sector and enter the white southern sector of light, having done which she should steer about S.S.W. between the St. Quay rocks and the Rohein, keeping carefully within the ivhite sector of Grand Lejon light, Having brought port Binic white fixed light to bear W. by N. \ N. she will be southward of all danger and ' may, if desired, haul up for it and anchor in from 3 to 5 fathoms to await daylight. The general aspect of the coast from pointe de Pleneuf to Cape Frehel has been already given at page 43. A description of the numerous rocks and shoals by which this shore is fronted will now follow. THE ROHEIN and COMTESSES ROCKS, are two rocky ledges, the first 5 miles and the second 3^ miles in a W.N.W. direction

The Rohein rock, at the south-western extreme of the Rohein ledge, is high above the level of the highest spring tides, and, from its isolated position, is easily recognized from some distance. This ledge is about one mile in diameter, many heads are uncovered at low water, and others awash, or nearly so. On its southern edge, eastward of the Rohein rock, the Basse Ronde uncovers 26 feet, and the Basses du-Sud-Est, 24 feet. At its northern extreme, the Basse des Daouelins is a dangerous patch ; from the least water on it, 3 feet, the extreme of cape Frehel is touching the southern side of the Rohinet rock E. by S. ; and, Pature point is a little open westward of the Rohein S.W. by S. The Comtesses are half a mile in extent E.S.E. and W.N.W., and uncover at low water throughout. The two westernmost heads are always uncovered. Between the Comtesses and the Rohein ledges, the Lue rock uncovers 24 feet at the lowest tides. Basse des Comtesses is a small ledge about a cable long, and its highest head, which uncovers 3 feet, bears N. W. half a mile from the highest rock of the Comtesses ; from it, this latter rock is on with the eastern face of the Verdelet rock S. \ W. PLATEAU des JAUNES, H miles northward of Pleneuf point and S.S.W. nearly 2 miles from the Comtesses, is nearly a mile in extent East and West, and the highest rocks on it never cover. There is but little water between this ledge and the Verdelet rock, but coasters pass between by keeping the whitened summit of the Rohinet rock open northward of the beacon turret of the Evette (the width of the turret). The Evette is one of the rocks of the Portes d'Erqui ledge. Guyomere and Ecarets ledges. — The water is shallow for a mile off-shore, between Pleneuf point and cape d'Erqui, and several rocky ledges nearly bar all approach to it at low water. The highest of these are, the Guyomere, the highest head of which uncovers 16 feet ; and, the Ecarets, which uncovers 2 feet at the lowest tides. The latter rock bears N.W. by N. nearly a mile from Carouel point, on which there is a stone windmill ; from it, Turquet mill is on with the southern extreme of the steep coast near Lahoussaye point E. by S. ; and, the northern extreme of Bien-Assis wood is on with a country house standing on the brow of a hill a little westward of a remarkable white spot in the steep declivity of the coast.

Chap. H.] ROCKS OFF ERQUI BAY. 79 The Trois Pierres uncover 23 feet and extend 1\ cables from the land in a south-westerly direction, just southward of cape d'Erqui, and form the northern boundary of the rade d'Erqui. Buoy. — A buoy shaped like a double cone, black, with vane, is moored 75 yards N.W. \ W. from the Trois Pierres. Plateau des Portes d'Erqui.— This ledge, about 1\ miles west ward of cape d'Erqui, has on it four rocky heads which uncover from 26 to 29 feet, and the greater part of the reef is awash at high water, neaps. The highest head is the Evette, near the eastern end, on which is a beacon turret ; one cable eastward of this is the Izard rock, at the edge of the ledge, which uncovers about 6 feet. Pierres-du-Banc are two rocky patches 3£ miles E. by S. \ S. from the Petit Lejon. There are never less than 2f fathoms water on them, but they are dangerous in bad weather when there is a heavy sea over them on a weather tide. They lie close together, with the eastern side of Verdelet rock on with Tournemine mill S.S.W. £ W. ; and, the summit of the Grand-Pourier rock between the Rohinet rock and the chapel on St. Michel islet S.E. \ S. southerly. The Landas are two rocks rising from the southern part of a ledge, 4 cables in extent East and West, on which there are only from 5 to 8 feet at the lowest tides ; the eastern rock is then awash and the western rock is uncovered 2 feet, These rocks lie midway between the Pierres-du-Banc and the Grand-Pourier ; from them, the lighthouse on cape Frehel is seen between Amas-du-Cap and Bonnetot rock (which lies three quarters of a mile eastward of the Landas and uncovers 20 feet), E. by S. f S. ; and, the chapel and mill of Pleherel are between the Rohinet and the Grand-Pourier S.E. -L E. Buoy. — A red spindle buoy is moored 240 yards north-westward of the plateau des Landas. GRAND-POURIER, ROHINET, and JUSTIERES, are the highest ledges of a rocky plateau, of which the south-western extreme bears N. by E. half a mile from cape d'Erqui ; it extends more than 2h miles in a north-easterly direction, and is L} miles broad at its widest part. The Rohinet never covers, the eastern summit of the Grand-Pourier only covers at the highest tides, and the Justieres uncover 28 feet. Except between the Justieres and Rohinet, nearly the whole plateau uncovers at low water, springs.

II. 80 Buoys.— Two red buoys mark the southern side of this plateau ; one is moored off its southern extreme half a mile from cape d'Erqui, the other on the south-eastern edge of the Justieres. The Bignons are half a mile eastward from the Justieres and uncover 6 feet. Several rocky patches of from 9 to 18 feet lie near them. Grande and Petite Liviere are two rocky patches north westward of cape Frehel. The Grande Liviere, with 14 feet water, lies N.W. \ W, westerly 3 miles from the cape, with the lighthouse nearly touching the southern extreme of the Amas-du-Cap. A vessel will pass northward of this patch by keeping the summit of Amas du-Cap on with the lighthouse. At night, the light should not bear more easterly than S.E. by S. Pleneuf point on with the low extreme of cape d'Erqui leads half a mile northward ; and, the spire of Plurien church on with the summit of the Renard rock, S.S.W. | W. leads about 2 cables eastward. The Renard never covers : it stands out in dark outline on the Bouche d'Erqui beach. The Petite Liviere, with only 9 feet, bears S.S.W. three quarters of a mile from the Grande Liviere. When on this patch, cape Frehel lighthouse bears S.E. by E. f E. 3 miles ; the summit of Amas du-Cap is on with the most southerly of two houses on the summit of the cape ; and, Garenne mill, the westernmost of two mills near the coast, is on with the north-western extreme of St. Michel islet, S.W. | W. The spire of Plurien church on with the Renard, which leads clear of the Grande Liviere, almost touches the eastern edge of the Petite Liviere. AMAS-du-CAP, a large and remarkable rock W. by N. f N 4 cables from the western extreme of cape Frehel, never covers ; when approached from the N.W., it is not easily distinguished from the granite cliffs behind it, but from eastward or westward, when clear of the land, it may be seen from a long distance and resembles a quoin with the point turned southward. Westward of Amas-du-Cap, between it and St. Michel islet, are several rocky clusters about three quarters of a mile off-shore ; the principal are, the Mouillee which uncovers 13 feet, the Malicorne, the Truie, nearly awash, and the Jars which uncovers 12 feet at the lowest tides. ERQUI BAY is a small beaching place on the southern shore of the peninsula terminated by cape d'Erqui, opposite the village of

Chap. II.] AMAS-DU-CAP. — RADE D'ERQUI. 81 Erqui which is in the south-eastern corner of the bay. Vessels ground on a bottom which dries about 16 feet above the lowest tides, and are sheltered from N.N.W. round by East to South. The southern side of the bay is formed by the lofty point of Lahoussaye, which is prolonged seaward by an islet and some rocks. A jetty is constructed in the northern angle of the bay, 1^ cables westward of the little hamlet of La Chaussee ; it affords safe shelter against westerly winds to vessels capable of taking the ground. The bottom at the foot of the jetty-head, which should be left to port on entering, dries 13 feet. About 150 coasting vessels enter this little port annually. Rade D'Erqui, close to the southward of cape d'Erqui, in front of Erqui bay, is the only anchorage on the eastern shore of St. Brieuc bay affording tolerable shelter from easterly winds. The holding ground is good, but it is prudent to leave it, especially in the winter season, if the weather is threatening and the wind likely to veer to the westward. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in Erqui roads at 6 h. ; equinoctial springs rise 43 feet ; ordinary springs 33£ feet ; and, ordinary neaps 24^ feet. Bouche D'Erqui. — This inlet is nearly 3 miles eastward of cape d'Erqui and about a mile in extent ; it dries at low water and its shore is formed of white sandy downs. About half a mile north ward of Champ du Port point, the western point of the inlet, is the islet of St. Michel which is joined to the coast at low water and on which stands a chapel. This is the only place on this part of the coast where, in bad weather and when compelled to do so, a vessel can run ashore with the hope of saving her crew. The vessel even might be saved if she were beached southward of Champ du Port point about an hour after high water. CHENAL d'ERQUI is the passage between the belt of rocks bordering the coast from cape d'Erqui to St. Michel islet, on the one hand, and the Grand Pourier, Rohinet, and Justieres ledges on the other. The depth is not less than 2\ fathoms in the fairway of this channel at low water, springs, when it can be navigated only by small coasters ; with a free wind, vessels of deep draught may pass through from half flood to half ebb. Anchorage. — If windbound with strong northerly gales, some shelter may be found during neaps by anchoring southward of the Plate St. Michel rock, with the Rohinet rock nearly touching the A 2771. Life-boat.— A life-boat is stationed at Pleherel, about 2 miles eastward of Bouche d'Erqui. DIRECTIONS.— Vessels bound eastward and surprised by easterly winds when in the neighbourhood of the Lejons, may bear up for shelter and run for the rade d'Erqui by the Landas channel, by that between the Rohein and Petit Lejon, or between the Rohein and the Jaunes to leeward of all the outer shoals, as wind and tide may best serve. Through the Landas Channel. — If far enough to windward, this channel, between the Petit Lejon and Pierres du Bane, is prac ticable for vessels of the deepest 'draught after half flood. Three sand-banks, dangerous only from the heavy sea they occasion when it blows hard on a weather tide, lie in this channel ; from the largest, on which there are 4| fathomB, Tournemine mill is on with the Verdelet rock S.S.W. £ W. Run through this channel with Tournemine mill on with the highest summit of the Comtesses S. by W. W. until Turquet mill comes on with Trois Pierres point, half a mile southward of cape d'Erqui, S.S.E. \ E. Follow this latter mark until within half a mile of cape d'Erqui, when steer for Erqui road. A vessel will keep east ward of the Petit Lejon by having the Verdelet rock open eastward of the summit of the Comtesses ; she will also pass north-eastward of the Basse des Comtesses, and of the Comtesses, by keeping Turquet mill in sight eastward of Lahoussaye point, which mark will also ensure her not being too close to the eastern part of the Portes d'Erqui, marked by a beacon turret. The dangers on the eastern side of the channel may be avoided by not standing eastward of the line of Turquet mill just touching the high land of cape d'Erqui. The Channel between the Rohein and Petit Lejon may be taken when seeking shelter in Erqui road, either on the flood or the ebb. The summit of the Comtesses on with the southern ex treme of Bien-Assis wood S. by E. \ E. easterly leads half a mile westward of the Grand Lejon and 2 cables westward of the Petit Lejon, close to the black bell buoy marking the latter. Steer with this mark on until past the Petit Lejon, when Turquet mill will be on with Lahoussaye point ; haul up for it, opening the mill a little eastward of the point to avoid the Comtesses, &c, and this will lead into the road as before.

Chap.jl.] CHANNELS INTO THE RADE D'ERQUI. 83 In following this route before half flood, great care must be taken to avoid the Daouelins and Comtesses patches, and the Izard rock, Portes d'Erqui, on the southern side of the channel, as well as the Petit Lejon on the northern side ; also, at low water and in bad weather, a 21-feet patch S. by E. \ E. three quarters of a mile from the Petit Lejon. The Channel between the Rohein and the Jaunes may be taken by a vessel too much to leeward for either of the others, and it is sufficiently deep for vessels of moderate draught even at low water. Having passed the Rohein rock, and in working up for the rade d'Erqui, when standing northward, cape Frehel lighthouse open southward of the summit of the Comtesses clears the southern part of the Rohein ledge ; and, the lighthouse on with the large pointed rock at the foot of cape d'Erqui clears the southern part of the Portes d'Erqui. In making the southern board, cape Frehel lighthouse open northward of cape d'Erqui leads northward of the Jaunes ; and, Turquet mill well on with the steep coast which separates the beach of Erqui bay from the beach of the large bay to the southward, keeps her northward of the Ecarets rocks which uncover 2 feet at the lowest springs. Pleneuf point bearing S.W. by W. leads northward of the Guyomere and of the Ecarets, and between the Portes d'Erqui and the cape. Through Erqui Channel. — If surprised by strong easterly winds between cape Frehel and St. Malo, a vessel may bear up for shelter in Erqui road by passing through the Erqui channel between half flood and half ebb. For this purpose, having rounded cape Frehel, steer to the westward with the southern end of Amas-du-Cap islet touching the extreme of the cape E. f S. ; this mark leads northward of the Jars, Truie, Malicorne, and Mouillee rocks between the cape and St. Michel islet, and of all the rocks fronting the coast until abreast of the red buoy of the Justieres, when the steep point of Pleneuf will open out ; bring it on with the rock forming the extreme of cape d'Erqui, bearing S.W. by W. \ W. westerly ; then, with this mark as a guide, steer to pass about 2 cables from this rock and round it into the road. The most dangerous part of this channel is when cape d'Erqui bears between S.S.W. and S. \ W. ; the vessel is then abreast of the rocky patches of the southern part of the Rohinet plateau which dry 5 feet at the lowest springs, and are marked by a red buoy at their edge. The Erqui channel may also be run for by passing through the shoal patches between the Petite Liviere and the Bignons rocks when F 2
