The leading mark through, is, the guard-house on Pleneuf point on with the rock at the extreme of cape d'Erqui S.W. by W. \ W., the new semaphore which stands a little inland of Pleneuf point being at the same time clear of the summit of the cape ; when the extreme of cape Frehel is on with the southern end of Amas-du-Cap E. f S. proceed as before. When running through the Erqui channel for any of the ports on the western coast of St. Brieuc bay, proceed as if bound for Erqui road until the highest summit of the Comtesses rocks is on with the Rohein W. by N. \ N. Steer westward in this direction passing 2 or 3 cables southward of the Comtesses and Rohein ; after passing the Comtesses, their highest point on with the Rohinet leads south ward of the Rohein and also of the St. Quay rocks. Or, keep St. Michel islet in sight and quite detached from Marre-aux-Rets point, the eastern point of the little bay immediately eastward of cape d'Erqui, which mark leads northward of the Portes d'Erqui ; the extreme of cape Frehel on with the large pointed rock at the foot of cape d'Erqui leads southward of this ledge and northward of the Jaunes. Tidal Streams. — The flood tide sets about East, and the ebb tide West through the Erqui channel ; at springs, both tides run at the rate of 4 knots. Round cape Frehel it runs with great strength, at least 5 knots, and there are strong eddies occasioning a heavy breaking sea in bad weather. To avoid these, although the cape is steep-to, vessels should give it a berth of one or two miles at such a time. CAPE FREHEL. — This promontory is the northern extreme of a high narrow neck of land a mile in length, 7£ miles eastward of cape d'Erqui and nearly 12 miles westward of St. Malo. It is bordered on all sides by steep perpendicular cliffs about 150 feet high, and in clear weather may be seen from a distance of 15 or 18 miles. On the summit of some level land near its extreme are two towers 113 feet apart, of which the southernmost, an octagonal tower 72 feet high, is the lighthouse ; it stands 550 yards S.S.W. from the cape. From the lighthouse, Heaux lighthouse bears N.W. \ W. 32^ miles ; Grand Lejon lighthouse N.W. by W. 14 miles ; Corbiere light, at the south-western extreme of Jersey island, N.N.E. easterly 29^ miles ; the Minquiers light-vessel nearly on the same bearing, 12^ miles ; and, Grand Jardin lighthouse at the entrance of St. Malo E.S.E. 9^ miles.

Chap. II.] ERQUI CHANNEL.— CAPE FREHEL. 85 LIGHT. — The lighthouse on cape Frehel exhibits a white light of the first order, which revolves every half minute. It is 259 feet above the level of high water, and is visible in clear weather 23 miles ; in ordinary weather, the eclipses are not total within the distance of 12 miles. Vessels from the westward prevented rounding cape Frehel during easterly winds by the ebb stream, may await the turn of tide under the lee of the cape by making short tacks within the following limits: — Amas-du-Cap seen between the extreme of the cape and the lighthouse ; Amas-du-Cap between two and three times its apparent breadth northward of the cape ; and, Plurien church spire between the Renard rock and the eastern point of Bouche d'Erqui. This latter point is steep and high, whilst the Renard, as before observed, never covers, and stands out in dark outline on the beach of Bouche d'Erqui.

Baie du Mont St. Michel - The COAST. — From cape Frehel lighthouse, pointe du Roc or cape Lihou, on the southern side of which promontory is the port of Granville, bears East southerly 29 miles nearly, and the lighthouse on Pierre de Herpin E. by S. 19^ miles. The general direction of the coast line from point to point is south-easterly for nearly 7 miles from cape Frehel to the ile des Ehbiens ; from thence it is easterly for 14| miles to pointe de Grouin, the western point of the large but shallow Baie du Mont St. Michel ; here the coast trends suddenly southward for about 6 miles, then eastward for about 15 miles, and, lastly, northward about 8 miles to pointe de Champeaux, the eastern point of the bay, which bears from pointe de Grouin E. f S. 10s miles, the coast line following the circuit of the bay being at least thrice that distance. From pointe de Champeaux, pointe du Roc bears North a little easterly 5f miles.* About half way between cape Frehel and pointe de Grouin is the large and important port and town of St. Malo, at the entrance of the river Ranee ; between it and cape Frehel are several small harbours and deep but shallow bays with anchorages fairly sheltered against westerly winds, but the whole of the coast between these two points is fronted by numerous dangerous rocks and ledges extending from one to 4 miles from the land. When 2 miles beyond pointe de Grouin, which is surrounded by rocks and islets for that distance, and under the shelter of which is the rade de Cancale, affording an excellent anchorage during westerly winds, the character of the approach to the shore alters, the whole of the southern and * See Admiralty chart : — Channel islands and coast of France, No. 2,669 b ; scale m = 0'5 inch.

Chap. III.] THE COAST. — SEVIGNES AND FRENAY BAYS. 87 eastern parts of the Baie du Mont St. Michel, and as far northward as Granville, being generally flat, shallow, and sandy. Between Cape Frehel and pointe de Grouin the general aspect of the shore is rocky, rugged, and moderately high ; but, within the bay of St. Michel, from pointe de Chateau Richeux eastward, it is very low, flat, and marshy. It again rises in. the vicinity of pointe de Champeaux, a bluff and nearly perpendicular headland, and from thence to Granville is of moderate height, the flat sands extending off it in this neighbourhood being interspersed by low, flat, rocky ledges. ANSE des SEVIGNES, between cape Frehel and Latte point, has many dangers within it, and should not be run for as a place of shelter in heavy weather from the S.W., on account of the great overfalls in it caused by the steepness of the coast, and the violent squalls off the land to which it is subject. Bane de l'Etendr^e lies off the northern part of Sevignes bay ; from the Etendree rock at its western end, which uncovers 14J feet, it extends about three quarters of a mile in a S.E. by E. direction, and is a quarter of a mile broad ; some parts of it are nearly awash at the lowest tides. Basse de la Latte and Basse Raimonde.— These rocks, lying southward of the bane de l'Etendree, render the approach to Sevignes bay or to within a mile of this rugged and precipitous coast very dangerous, though the fishermen congregate here occasionally in great numbers. The Latte bears N.N.E. E. 3^ cables from the fort on Latte point, and uncovers a foot at the lowest tides ; the Raimonde bears N.N.W. £ W. 4 cables from the fort, and uncovers 9 feet. A vessel passes north-eastward of the Latte by keeping St. Jacut mill well open of St. Cast point. BAIE de la FRENAY, between Latte and St. Cast points, affords good shelter with off-shore winds but is quite exposed to those from the N.E. The entrance is 2 miles wide, and from thence the bay trends 3i miles in a S.W. by W. direction to its head, but more than 2 miles of that expanse dries at low water. The surrounding land is high, and its northern shore free from danger. The holding ground is good, and the best anchorage is in from 4| to 5 fathoms, about half a mile off Cierge point, just southward of Latte point, with cape Frehel lighthouse seen between

88 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. [Chap. III. Cierge point and Latte fort. The only precaution to be used in taking up a berth is to make due allowance for fall of tide. At high water, vessels under 9^ feet draught can cross the high bank which dries out from the head of the bay, and reach the beach ing places of Portmieux and Port-a-la Due. Both are on the western shore, the first behind, and the latter about a mile south-westward of Muret point. The BourdinotS are two small r'oeky ridges, one 6 cables, the other 1tl miles E. \ N. from St. Cast point. The easternmost ridge, on which there are 34 feet water, is dangerous only when blowing hard ; but the westernmost ridge, on which the highest rock dries 7 feet, must be carefully avoided The marks for this rock are, Chesne windmill, in ruins, twice its width open westward of the Bec-Rond rock W. by S. \ S. ; and, St. Jacut highest windmill open eastward of the summit of Colombiere islet, which islet is half a mile westward of the Ehbiens, S.| E. A white beacon tower 30 feet high now stands near the ruins of Chesne windmill, which was destroyed by fire. Buoy. — A red bell buoy is moored one cable north-eastward of the western ridge of the Bourdinots. Grande Conchee rock well open northward of Cezembre isle E. \ S., or Tertre Morgan windmill in sight northward of St. Cast peninsula W. \ S., leads northward of both ridges. St. CAST POINT, 4 miles S.S.E. \ E. from cape Frehel, is high and nearly perpendicular on all sides. The approach to it is rendered dangerous at low water by the Bourdinots, by low- water rocks which extend 3 cables from the foot of the point, and by the Chelin, a small sand-bank with only 10 feet water N. by E. nearly half a mile from the point ; Teignouse point, the first point south ward of cape Frehel, on with Latte point, leads outside the Chelin bank and between St. Cast point and the Bourdinots ridges. Anse de St. Cast.— Southward of St. Cast point, in front of the village of Lille St. Cast, the coast forms a small bay which affords to vessels capable of taking the ground good shelter from westerly winds. The head of the bay, at three quarters of a cable from the shore, is of muddy sand, on which spring tides rise from 24 to 30 feet, and neaps about 15 feet. In steering for the beaching place, keep the village bearing about West, and do not approach the Bec- Rond rock within one cable.

CAST BAY. — iLE DES EHBIENS. 89 Arguenon bay. — From St. Cast point, at low water, dry sands connect the shore with the ile des Ehbiens and with the opposite coast in the vicinity of St. Briac harbour, the tw-o deep bays of Arguenon and Lancieux, separated by a narrow promontory ending in point Roche, being then dry throughout. The Arguenon river flows into the head of the bay of Arguenon. Vessels capable of taking the ground will find shelter from easterly winds on the eastern shore of this bay. They should be placed abreast of an old convent, with St. Jacut windmill bearing S.E. ; and, Ehbiens islet shut in by Chevet point. Here the tides rise from 19 to 26 feet at springs, and 9^ feet at neaps. The river Arguenon is navigable up to Plancoet, at springs, for vessels of about 9 feet draught. A ILE des EHBIENS, about a mile in circumference, is at the head of the bight between cape Frehel and St. Malo. It is surrounded by high rocks, and near its centre there is a large and conspicuous tower which may be recognised from a great distance. It is joined to the shore at low water by the bank of sand before described, which borders the coast from St. Cast point to the entrance to St. Briac. Close southward of Ehbiens there is a well-sheltered grounding place, much frequented by coasting vessels formerly but not much used since the channels into St. Malo have been well lighted and marked. It is formed by a natural causeway of shingle, always uncovered and uniting the south-western extreme of the island to some high rocks 2 cables to the South-west. The bottom is muddy sand and seaweed, and dries 7 or 8 feet above the lowest tides, which rise from 28 to 35 feet above it at springs, and 18 or 19 feet at neaps. The best place for grounding, sheltered from all winds, is about half a cable from the southern end of the island, with Agot island entirely shut in by the south-eastern extreme of Ehbiens. There is also anchorage in from 2 to 5 fathoms in the bay betweeen ile des Ehbiens and Agot, but it is open to northerly winds, and in the centre of the bay is the Platus rock, marked by a beacon turret painted with red and black bands ; on the eastern and southern sides of the bay are several rocks, of which the Mouliere, marked by a beacon, dries 31 feet, the Rochefort dries 39 feet, and the Gautrat dries 17 feet. Directions. — When running for the grounding place at the southern end of Ehbiens, as soon as the island is made out, steer to

St. BRIAC— This little tidal harbour has little or no trade, is difficult of access, and should never be attempted without a pilot. It is at the entrance of a narrow valley 1J miles eastward of Ehbiens and about three quarters of a mile southward of the high projecting point of Haye. The entrance, 2 cables wide, is between the Perronais beacon marking the westernmost rock of the ledge extending south-westward from the southern end of Perron isle, about one cable distant from it and which dries 12 feet, and a beacon on the extreme of a rocky ridge projecting northward from the peninsula of Lancieux ; this latter rock dries 15 feet at the lowest tides, and, in entering the harbour, a vessel should steer to pass between these two beacons. The channel narrows considerably half a mile within the beacons at the entrance, and a vessel has then to pass between rocky heads, marked by beacons, the highest of which uncovers 19 feet, leaving on the starboard hand the Banchot and Cheruette beacons ; on the port hand, the beacons on the Cheval and the Ane, and passing the Bouche beacon, in the middle of the channel, on either side ; after which she may anchor or ground as desired ; three warping buoys are placed to assist vessels to their berths. The tides run with great strength in the channel, and the harbour is exposed to a heavy sea with strong north-westerly winds. Pilots berth vessels N.N.W. of the town of St. Briac, with their heads towards the ebb stream, on a bottom of sand and mud, over which the tide rises from 20 to 26 feet at springs, and from 12 to 13 feet at neaps. There are 6 feet more water at the entrance of the harbour than here. In a little bight in the northern part of the harbour, vessels may lie, out of the stream and sheltered from all winds, on a bottom of soft mud ; but, if of more than 13 or 14 feet draught, they will be neaped for three or four days. The port of St. Malo is 4^ miles eastward of the entrance to St. Briac. Before proceeding to a description of it and of its numerous entrance channels it may be well to describe the off -lying

From it, cape Frehel lighthouse bears W.S.W. 11^ miles ; the Minquiers light vessel N.W. \ N. 9^ miles ; Chausey lighthouse East 11 miles ; Grand Jardin lighthouse at the entrance of St. Malo S. by W. \ W. 8^ miles ; and, the nearest rocks of the Minquiers group, fully described at pages 129-137, are only 5 miles distant to the northward. The rock occasions great overfalls during springs, and the sea breaks over it in bad weather. Basse des Sauvages are two rocky heads N.N.W. and S.S.E. from each other, and 2 cables apart. There are 39 feet on the northern head, 27 feet on the southern head, and from 14 to 16 fathoms around. The village of Hopitaux d'Erqui, seen between Amas-du-Cap and cape Frehel, leads half a mile south-eastward of the Sauvages ; the north-eastern extreme of Cezembre on with St. Malo church steeple S.S.E. leads north-eastward ; and, the church steeple on with the rock Muriers, at the south-western extreme of Cezembre, leads southward. The CatiS. — This rocky head has 25 feet water, with 14 and 15 fathoms around. From it, cape Frehel lighthouse bears W. f S. 3 miles ; the summit of Cezembre island S.E. by E. 7 miles ; and, the steeple of St. Malo church S.E. \ E. 9^ miles. The marks for the Catis are, the summit of cape d'Erqui seen exactly between cape Frehel and Amas-du-Cap ; and, the tower of Latte fort on with the hillock on Cierge point S.W. \ W. VIEUX BANC is a rocky ledge nearly 4 miles north westward of Cezembre isle, which generally betrays itself by a rippling. It is about 4 cables long E.S.E. and W.N.W., 2 cables wide, and has several heads with but little water on them. From the highest head, which uncovers 5 feet at low water, equinoctial springs, at the western extreme of the ridge, cape Frehel lighthouse bears W. by N. 6 miles ; and, Grand Jardin light S.E. 3| miles. Directions. — When steering eastward along the coast between cape Frehel and Grouin point, at or after half ebb, bear in mind that so long as the Herpin rock is twice its breadth open northward of the Rochefort black and red beacon turret, the vessel will pass northward of the Vieux bane, and of all dangers between it and the Rochefort ; also, that in coming from the eastward, with cape Frehel lighthouse open northward of the Rochefort, there is nothing to fear from the Tintiaux or from any of the shoals in the immediate vicinity of Grouin point ; this latter is, however, a very distant mark. ST. MALO.— The town of St. Malo stands at the mouth of the river Ranee, on the eastern side, on the small rocky island of Aaron. It was in former times connected with the mainland by the Sillon, a narrow causeway three quarters of a mile long ; in the construction of the modern Bassin-a-Flot, or inner harbour, this causeway has been greatly widened and strengthened and now forms the northern side of the basin, with extensive quays and railway accommodation. The whole area of the island is occupied by houses, and the walls are flanked by towers washed by the sea.* The manufactures are hosiery, cordage, soap, fishing nets, &c, but they are not extensive ; there is also a large tobacco factory. Ship building is carried on, and besides building slips there are two gridirons for repairs, but as yet no facilities for extensive repairs to iron hulls or machinery. Vessels are fitted out for the foreign and coasting trades, the former being chiefly with England and the northern countries of Europe, and for the whale and mackerel fisheries ; 1,197 vessels, of an aggregate of 192,935 tons, entered the port in the year 1886. The imports consist chiefly of coal, iron, pitch, &c. ; the exports of barley, butter, potatoes, fruit, wine, pro- * See Admiralty plan, port St. Malo and environs, No. 2,700 ; scale, m = h inches.

Regular steam communication is maintained with the Channel Islands, and from thence with England, by the steamers of the London and South-Western Railway; and there is regular communication with Cardiff, Hull, St. Brieuc, Granville, and Havre by lines of steamers. Steam ferries also ply between Dinard, on the opposite shore of the Ranee, St. Malo, and St. Servan. The population of St. Malo by the last census in 1886 was 10,500, and that of the adjoining town of St. Servan 12,163 ; St. Servan stands on higher ground and may be considered a suburb of St. Malo. ST. MALO PORT, situated south-eastward of the town, is large, well frequented, and, with St. Servan, has 2,560 yards of quay frontage ; it is difficult of approach, the flood rushing in with great strength, and equinoctial tides rising to the height of 4f feet above the level of low water of those tides. It is also inconvenient of access to vessels of deep draught during the winter months, owing to the fact of high water, full and change, occurring at 6 h. 5 m., i.e., before daylight in the morning and after dark in the evening. The port or inner harbour of St. Malo and St. Servan has been converted into a Bassin-a-Flot or wet dock, with an interior reservoir, used for laying up dismantled shipping, by means of a strong granite wall thrown across the entrance, having two openings, formed into locks with flood gates. The width of entrance of the largest lock is 58 feet, length 234 feet, and the tide rises above the sill from 14 feet at high water of the lowest neaps to 33J feet at high water, highest equinoctial springs ; see tides, pages 99.* The portion of the Bassin-a-Flot belonging to St. Malo has an area of 38 acres and a width of 153 yards ; that belonging to St. Servan an area of 29 acres and a width of 207 yards. Coals are always obtainable at from 18s. to 20s. per ton, from 3,000 to 4,000 tons being usually in stock; vessels coal alongside the quays, where there is always sufficient water for steamers of from 1,000 to 1,200 tons. The Mole des Noires, a neat and substantial stone pier, built on the Noires rocks at the south-western angle of the town, in addition to its great convenience for landing passengers, protects the port from the heavy roll of the sea, to which it would be other wise exposed with north-westerly winds. The pier is 1,290 feet long, about 16 feet wide, and at its head is a lighthouse. A Life-Boat is stationed at St. Malo. Pilots. — The St. Malo pilots cruise in all weathers in two cutters ; one is stationed near cape Frehel, the other cruises off the port, between it and the Chausey isles ; in bad weather, the latter frequently takes shelter under the lee of Cezembre island. ROADSTEADS. — There are two good roadsteads at the mouth of the river Ranee, where vessels of deep draught generally anchor to unload, or to await tide to enter the port ; they are, the Rade de St. Malo and the anchorage of Dinard. The Rade de Solidor, off the bay of that name and abreast of St. Servan, is too shallow and confined to receive vessels of large size.

MALO is on the eastern side of the entrance to the Ranee, 4 cables westward of the town of St. Malo ; it occupies a space about 2 cables long, North and South, is a cable wide, and has from 27 to 32 feet water throughout, It is bounded on the North by the Basse Broutard, on the East by the sand-bank which fronts the town and dries at low water, and on the South by the Plateau de la Ranee, the northern head of which bears S. £ E. 2f cables from the Broutard. The Petite Rade is southward of the plateau de la Ranee. Basse Broutard is a small rocky patch about 130 yards long E.S.E. and W.N.W., and 60 yards wide, with only 8 feet water ; from it, the sentry box on Varde point is seen between Grand and Petit Bey islets ; and, St. Hydeuc church steeple is a little open northward of the northern bastion of the ramparts of St. Malo, East a little southerly. Plateau de la Ranee. — This rocky ledge, 2£ cables in extent North and South and one cable wide, has on it six dangerous heads, two of which uncover, one 2 feet the other 3 feet, at the lowest tides, when there are from 1 to 2 feet only on three of the other heads, and 16 feet on the sixth, which is at the northern part of the ledge. Buoys. — Two buoys, one red the other black, mark the North and South-west extremes of this danger ; and, two mooring buoys lie in the outer part of the roads, nearly in line between La Ranee and Broutard shoals. Clearing Marks. — The mound on Garde Guerin point in sight between the Grand Vide rock and the steep point of Roche Pelee W. by N. northerly, leads half a cable northward of this ridge ; and, the western head of Bizeux rock on with the high rock at the foot of Bechard point S. \ E. leads a third of a cable eastward. To pass the same distance westward, keep the Merciere beacon on with the eastern head of the Bizeux S. by E. \ E.; and, to pass half a cable southward of the 2-feet head near the southern end of the ridge, keep the head of the Mole des Noires on with the outer angle of St. Louis bastion, the south-easternmost of the ramparts of St. Malo, E. by N. \ N. Anchorage. — The holding ground in St. Malo road is good, and vessels moor nearly North and South in the direction of the tidal

The best position is in the middle of the road, with the eastern head of the Bizeux on with the high rock at the foot of Bechard point ; and, the mound on Garde Guerin point a little open southward of the summit of the Grand Vide. Vessels of light draught _anchor a little eastward of this. The road is well-sheltered from all winds between West and N.E. round by South and East, but northerly and north-westerly winds, when they blow with any strength, send in a heavy sea during the time the ledges outside the river are covered, i.e. from 2 h. before to 2 h. after high water, at springs. The flood stream in the road never exceeds 3 knots ; and the ebb, which Bechard point turns towards the opposite shore, never runs with sufficient strength to prevent com munication with the port. When it blows hard from the westward, sailing vessels wishing to leave the road for the port, or for a more sheltered anchorage in the river, should not weigh until the ebb stream has fairly made, to enable them to work to windward. There is also fair holding ground in from 18 to 22 feet in the Petite Rade de St. Malo, a short distance southward and south-eastward of the Plateau de la Ranee. When at anchor in the centre of this road, the extreme of Bechard point is on with the middle of the Bizeux, and the outer angle of St. Louis bastion is open about half a point southward of the mole-head. ANSE de DINARD.— This bay is abreast of St. Malo on the western side of the Ranee, between points Dinard and Vicomte ; grounding places extend along its western shore, from the old ship yard below the village to the new one beneath the mill on Dinard point. The bottom here dries from 12 to 15 feet, with a very gradual slope towards the edge of the bank, springs rise above it from 18 to 24 feet, neaps 9 or 10 feet ; it is composed of stiff mud covered with seaweed, and when it blows hard from the N.E. vessels strike heavily in grounding, and, as the anchors of small vessels bite with difficulty, care should be taken to bury them in the mud at low water ; avoid also grounding eastward of the line on which Grande Conchee fort begins to open eastward of Dinard point, as the bottom there is deeply furrowed. Dinard Anchorage. — Vessels of deep draught, unable to enter port St. Malo during neaps, often await spring tides at this anchorage, where they are well sheltered from all but northerly winds. It is just outside the outer edge of the mud in Dinard bay, and is half a mile in extent from the Petit Palais A 2771. Wt. 7242, G

The best anchorage, where the depths are from 26 to 30 feet, is limited northward by the line of the Solidor tower seen between the extreme of Bechard point and the little fort ; and, southward, by the same tower open its own breadth northward of the high steeple of St. Servan church. This roadstead is the general rendezvous for vessels of war, and two mooring buoys are laid down in the northern part of it; the anchorage is preferable to that of St. Malo road, being better sheltered against the prevailing winds, though the holding ground, except close to the edge of the mud, is not so good, and the tides are stronger. Ships at this anchorage should always be ready to weigh or slip, as bad weather may at any lime make it necessary to take shelter farther up the Ranee. ANSE de SOLIDOR, on the western side of the town of St. Ser van, is a cable wide at the entrance, and its shores are almost entirely occupied by the military establishments of the town. Merchant vessels remaining some time in the bay are usually placed at the entrance, between the quai des Corbieres and the rocks at the foot of Solidor tower, where the bottom dries 12 or 13 feet, and springs rise from 25 to 32 feet above that level, neaps about 15 feet. A stone slip with a wooden platform at the end, for the accommodation of passengers from Dinard, extends from near the Solidor tower to the edge of the sands which dry ; this is very dangerous to vessels entering Solidor bay. When the Petit Bizeux rock is awash there are 15 feet water over the platform at the end of the slip. A small grounding place called St. Pere port, in the northern part of the bay at the foot of the peninsula of La Cite, northward of the Solidor tower, is about 84 yards wide, 270 yards deep, and will contain 14 or 15 vessels of the tonnage and draught of those employed in the Newfoundland trade. The grounding places towards the middle of this bay dry 10 feet. Vessels' of about 13 feet draught can enter at high water, neaps. Solidor Road is a small deep, parallel with the shore, 2 cables long North and South, and only about 80 yards wide between the beach which dries in front of Solidor bay and the Solidor bank, which also dries about 8 feet ; the soundings are shallow, and,

RIVIERE de LA RANCE.— The Ranee is tidal as far as Dinan, 14 miles above St. Malo, and navigable at high water the whole distance ; but, the last anchorage at which vessels of any size can lie afloat at low water is at Jouvente, only 3 miles above St. Malo. Tides and Tidal streams.— It is high water, full and change, at port St. Malo at 6h. 5m., equinoctial springs range 44f feet, ordinary springs rise 36|r feet, ordinary neaps 25£ feet, The water rises above the sill of the Great Lock 33|- feet at equinoctial spring tides, 28f feet at ordinary springs, and 18^ feet at ordinary neaps. The streams run with great strength during springs at the entrance of the Grande and Petite Conchee channels, the flood north-eastward, the ebb south- westward. Their rate is about 4 knots at half tide, across the Grand chenal de la Ranee until as far in as the Buron beacon turret. Southward of the Buron beacon turret the flood curves and sets into the river with the same velocity. The ebb from the river divides, one part running out by the Grand chenal, the other by the Decolle passage. Both streams take the direction of the latter passage and run at about the same rate. CHANNELS leading into the RANCE.— All the channels leading into St. Malo are between Garde Guerin and Varde points, through the midst of the numberless dangers by which the coast is so thickly studded. These channels lead between rocks, some always above water and many others which uncover between a quarter ebb and low water, and amongst sand-banks and shoals, of which some are dry or nearly awash at low water, springs ; several small islets, however — such as Cezembre, Grande Conchee, Harbour isle, the Beys, and the higher' rocks — serve as good marks by which these dangers may be avoided. Entering by the Grande or Petite Porte channels, there are not less than from 4 to 5 fathoms at low water ; this entrance is, therefore, navigable at all times by vessels of deep draught. Besides this channel there are five others through which pilots take vessels with a proper rise of tide ; they are, the Decolle, close to the land south-westward of the Grande Porte ; the Petite and Grande Conchee ; the Petits Pointus ; and, the Bigne. The four last are all eastward of the island of Cezembre. With easterly winds, pilots prefer entering the Ranee by the Conchee, in preference to the Grande or Petite Porte channels, the eddies with these winds not being so violent in the Conchee as in the other channels. DECOLLE PASSAGE lies close along shore westward of the entrance to the Ranee, from Dinard point to Decolle point, on, which latter is a semaphore ; it can be navigated by vessels of moderate draught from half flood to half ebb ; in case of need, those of deep draught may use it with a leading wind at springs, from one hour before until one hour after high water. Pilots prefer this channel with an off-shore wind, as the sea is then smooth ; its limits are defined by beacons placed on rocks, nearly all of which cover at high water, springs, and its western entrance is between Decolle point and the Mouilliere rock where its breadth does not exceed half a cable. Directions. — Vessels entering the Decolle passage from the westward generally pass between Agot, a high and narrow islet about one mile westward of Garde Guerin point, and Nerput, a high isolated rock which uncovers 40 feet 8 cables northward of that point, and on which is a red beacon tower 13 feet above high water. This entrance has the advantage of being directly with the tide, but in stormy weather it cannot always be taken, as breakers sometimes extend completely across the pass between Decolle point and La Mouilliere. The lighthouse on the Mole des Noires, St. Malo, just open north ward of the high rocks at the extreme of Decolle point E.S.E., leads between the Nerput rock and the Grande Brousse bank, on which there are only 11 feet water (but at the time of tide when this passage is navigable there are at least 30 feet over it), and 1\ cables northward of the Platier des Lardieres. Keep this mark on until

Chap. III.] ST. MALO. — DECOLLE PASSAGE. 101 the steeple of St. Hydeuc church is on with the summit of the Grand Buzard E. by S., which leads in the deepest part through the western entrance of the passage, about three quarters of a cable southward of the beacon on the Mouilliere rock ; if the Grand Buzard is covered, keep Parame church and St. Hydeuc windmill in sight between Fort Royal and Harbour isle, with the church the same distance north ward of the fort as the mill appears southward of the isle. Having passed these narrows, proceeding with La Latte fort on with the Nerput N.W. by ¥.|W, or with the southern mill of Talard, white , twice its width open northward of the Mole des Noires lighthouse and on with the end of the white mark on the Mole, the vessel may run eastward between the Petit Buzard and Petit Genillet rocks and between the Mouille and Rochardien rocks, all of which have beacons, and, when near the latter, the dome of St. Servan church will be seen between the two chimneys of the house in Fort la Cite, which from thence is the leading mark until the maregraphe at point Bechard is on with a little clump of trees between points Corbiere and Aiguille, or until the highest of the Cheminees rocks is on with the cleft in the Mouille rock, either of which marks leads into the fairway of the river between the Pierres d'Amourette and the Roches Bonnes, and between the Pourceaux rocks and Mi-Maree rock off Dinard point, all of which rocks are also marked by beacons. If the tide is low, the dome of St. Servan church will not be visible, but only the standard of the lightning conductor on its summit. The Mouille rock is at the western end of the Pourceaux bank, and it uncovers 39 feet at the lowest tides ; when it is more than 3 feet above water, a vessel must pass between Dinard point and the Pourceaux rocks by the directions just given, but when the Mouille is covered, or is less than 3 feet out of water, vessels of considerable draught may run across the bank between that rock and the Pierres d'Amourette rocks, there being then at least 4 fathoms over it. To cross the bank, steer E. by S. with the mound on Garde Guerin point, seen over the land of Decolle point, well open northward of the Grand Vide rock, which never covers ; this mark leads up to St. Malo road, where vessels generally anchor until there is sufficient water to enter the port. This passage is much used by vessels leaving St. Malo on the" ebb by the Decolle passage, the narrow and dangerous pass between the Pourceaux beacon turret and Dinard point being thus avoided. Vessels often pass northward of the Nerput rock and enter the Decolle passage either by running between the beacons on the

102 [Chap. ILL CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. Mouilliere and Petit Pot-de-Beurre rocks, or by passing close eastward of the beacon on the latter. Either of these channels has the disadvantage of a beam tide, but the former has a good depth of water and is nearly a cable wide. To steer through it, keep well northward of the Nerput, and bring the white marks of Roche Pelee and Pival in line bearing S.S.E. £ E. easterly ; this leads through the centre of the channel up to the leading marks already given for the Decolle passage, leaving on the starboard hand at 4 cables a 19-feet patch named Rat du Nord-Est, at nearly one cable the Basses des Marechaux, and at less than half a cable the outlying rocks of the Mouilliere. On the port hand, it passes two thirds of a cable from the Sauts-aux-Chiens, half a cable from the Grande Basse, and close past some rocks awash at low water extending more than a cable south-westward from the beacon on the Petit Pot-de-Beurre. To pass over the reefs and eastward of the Petit Pot-de-Beurre, bring St. Enogat mill on with the northern extreme of the little patch of white sand just westward of Pelee point S.E. by S. ; this mark leads over the Sauts-aux-Chiens, a rocky patch on which there are 10 feet at low water and from 30 to 36 feet at half flood, and half a cable eastward of the Petit Pot-de-Beurre beacon. When this beacon is passed, haul a little southward to enter the Decolle passage and to avoid a small rock which uncovers 4 feet a cable southward of the Grand Pot-de-Beurre. As soon as the leading marks for the Decolle passage come on, proceed as before directed. From St. Malo Road to Solidor Road. — When southward of the plateau de la Ranee, the two principal dangers to be avoided between St Malo and Solidor roads are the Rat de la Merciere and the Merciere ridges ; the former is a small isolated rock with only 4 feet water in mid-channel N.W. N. 3^ cables from Bechard point ; when the Pourceaux rocks are covered there are 17 feet on this danger, and 22 feet when the tide reaches the foot of the Pierres d'Amourette beacon. The Merciere ridge is half a cable westward of La Cite peninsula. The highest head on this ridge uncovers 20 feet at the lowest tides, covers a quarter of an hour before half flood at springs, and is marked by a beacon. At neap tides, vessels bound to Solidor road may pass on either side of the Rat de la Merciere ; but, at springs, they should keep as much as possible over towards the eastern bank of the river, to avoid the strength of the tide, and pass eastward of the Rat. For this purpose, .when abreast of St. Malo, keep the eastern head of the Bizeux rock and the Merciere beacon in one S. by E. \ E. until the

Chap. III.] ST. MALO. — GRANDE AND PETITE PORTE CHANNELS. 103 Mole des Noires lighthouse is on with St. Malo church ; then steer to pass three quarters of a cable westward and southward of the Merciere beacon. In case of necessity only, a vessel may run between the Merciere beacon and La Cite peninsula by keeping the Mole des Noires light house on with the north-western side of the Calfats rock ; but the tides run strongly in this passage, which is only two thirds of a cable wide and has a depth of 13 feet at low water. On account of the eddy during the flood occasioned by Bechard point, the most favourable time for entering Solidor road is at high water by the shore. Vessels entering before that time, when round ing Bechard point and for the space of about a cable East and West, experience the flood stream setting with great velocity south-westward, and the eddyr, not less strong, setting north-westward. The eddy begins to be felt near the shore about 2 hours before high water, and its breadth and strength increase as the tide rises. To enter the road, the tower of Grand Larron on with that of Solidor leads between Bechard point and the Solidor bank ; when within the latter, anchor as convenient ; but, to take up a safe berth, the services of a pilot are necessary. GRANDE and PETITE PORTE CHANNELS. — The Grande and Petite Porte channels are the only passages into the Ranee navigable at low water. They are westward of Cezembre island, are divided from each other by the Pierres des Portes and other rocks, and unite between the Grand Jardin and the Pierres de la Savatte, at the entrance of the Grand Chenal de la Ranee ; they may be used by vessels of the deepest draught at all times ; no large square-rigged vessel, however, should attempt either channel except with the wind free and of sufficient strength to enable her to keep the leading marks on and to stem the tide, bearing in mind that the course when within the narrows is about S.S.E. £ E. The tidal streams in the vicinity of the chain of scattered rocks which divide these two channels are very strong during springs, attaining a velocity of 4 or 5 knots, and making them always dangerous at low water, as well as at other times, when the wind iB fresh on a weather tide, by reason of the overfalls they occasion. A description of these rocks now follows : — The Buharats rocks, of wdiich the highest head has only 7 feet water, is the westernmost of this rocky chain, its shoalest spot bears W.N.W. H miles from Grand Jardin lighthouse, with the

104 [Chap. Ill CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. Nerput rock beacon turret on with the summit of the mound on La Haye point S.W. westerly ; St. Malo church steeple on with Petit Bey fort S.E. \ E. easterly ; and, Grande Conchee fort midway between the northern poirit of Cezembre and Meinga point E. \ S. Buoy.— A black bell buoy is moored off the southern side of the Buharats. The Pierres des Portes are three high rocks, of which the central one uncovers 37 feet, N.W. by W. 6^ cables from Grand Jardin lighthouse ; a beacon tower surmounted by a ball stands on the westernmost rock, which dries 25 feet at low water, springs, -and scarcely covers at high water, neaps. Several shoal rocky patches extend about 2 cables in a westerly direction from the beacon tower ; they are named the Couillons de la Porte, and, E. by N. \ N. at 2 cables distance are the Basses Nord-Est des Portes, with 11 feet water, extending a cable further in the same direction ; with the Basses a Louise and the Fontaines des Portes, with one shoal spot of only 3 feet, at their western end. Buoy. — A black conical buoy, with the word rock in white letters, is moored on the southern side of the Pierres des Portes rocks, nearly one cable S.W. by W. £ W. from the beacon tower. The Bunel, Hupions, &C. — The Bunel, the north-eastern rock of the chain, is the only one lying eastward of the Petite Porte channel ; it uncovers 12 feet, and bears N. \ E. 6 cables from Grand Jardin lighthouse. The Hupions, on which there are 27 feet water, and the Grande Hupee, with only 3 feet, lie, the first 6^, the other 5 cables N.N.E. from the beacon tower on the Pierres des Portes. The Grande Hupee is very dangerous ; the marks for it are, the highest head of the Pierres des Portes on with the summit of Bellefard point S. by W. £ W. ; and, the southern end of the fort on Varde point touching the northern side of the Petite Conchee E . by S. £ S. S.W. 2 cables from the Grande Hupee is the Rat des Courtis, of 27 feet ; and, westward one cable from it, La Nouvelle Decouverte, a patch with as little as 11 feet. Buoy. — A black and red conical buoy is moored off the northern side of the Bunel rock. THE GRANDE PORTE CHANNEL extends H miles in an E.S.E. direction from its commencement southward of the Buharats rocks to its junction with the Grande Ranee channel near

Chap. III.] ST. MALO. — GRAND CHENAL DE LA RANCE. 105 the Grand Jardin lighthouse, passing between the Pierres des Portes and Banquetiers rocks, northward of which latter and two thirds of a cable distant is the Boujaron rock, which uncovers 13 feet and is marked by a red beacon turret, and the Basse du Boujaron, awash at low water and nearly a cable N.E. £ E. from the turret. The eastern part, at the entrance of the Grande Ranee channel, is about 2 cables wide ; its limits are marked by an iron beacon surmounted by a ball on the outer rocks of the Grand Jardin, and by a similar beacon on the rocks off "the Pierres de la Savatte. Grand Jardin, Savatte, and Traversaine rocks.— The Grand Jardin beacon marks the northern side of the channel ; it stands on a rock which uncovers 19 feet S. £ W. 70 yards from Grand Jardin lighthouse. The Savatte or Pierre a la Vache beacon, on the southern side of the channel, is on the Pierre a la Vache, the easternmost rock of the Pierres de la Savatte ; it uncovers 22 feet and is awash at about half flood ; this beacon bears S.S.W. 3 cables from the lighthouse. The Traversaine, a rocky bank one cable in extent N.W. \ N. and S.E. \ S. and half a cable wide, lies in mid-channel between the two beacons ; it is steep-to and is dangerous at low water, having only 4 or 5 feet over it at that time. Buoys. — Besides the buoys already described, marking the northern side of the channel off the Buharats and Pierres des Portes, are the following three buoys : — 1. A red buoy moored about half a cable north-eastward of the Basse du Boujaron, from which the Pierres des Portes buoy bears N. £ W. Ii cables. 2. A red buoy northward of the Sou rock at the northern extreme of the Pierres de la Savatte, 2\ cables N.N.W. £ W. from the Savatte beacon, and 4£ cables S.E. by E. \ E. from the first buoy. 3. A red buoy near the south-western edge of the Traversaine, between and nearly on a line connecting the Savatte and Grand Jardin beacons, about 1\ cables from the former. GRAND CHENAL de la RANCE is 2\ miles long from the Grand Jardin to St. Malo road. It is bounded on the western side by the Pierres de la Savatte; by the Pierre Salee flats, which have from 3 to 12 feet on them ; by the Buron, an isolated conical rock which uncovers 24 feet and has on it a red beacon turret surmounted by a ball ; and, by scattered rocky heads as far up as the Pourceaux rocks. On the eastern side, it is bounded by the off-lying rocks of the Grand Jardin ; by the Pierres Gamier, of which the highest head

[Chap. Ill 106 CAPE FREKEL TO GRANVILLE. uncovers 5 feet ; and, by the rocky heads on the western slope of the Ouvras ridge, of which the greater part uncover at low water. The narrowest part of this channel is between the Basse du Buron, a small rocky head with only 3 feet, and the Buron rock ; they bear E. by N. h N. and W. by S. J S. from each other, and are 1^ cables apart. At 2 cables north-eastward from the Basse du Buron is the Ouvras beacon, on the highest head of that reef, which uncovers 17 feet. Buoys. — The eastern side of the channel is marked by the following four black buoys : — The first or outer buoy is moored near the south-western edge of the Pierres Gamier S.E. 3i cables from the Grand Jardin beacon. The second buoy is moored on the western edge of the Clefs d'Aval, the northernmost rocks of the Ouvras ledge ; it bears S.E. £ S. from the outer buoy. The third buoy is just westward of the Basse du Buron, and, with the Buron beacon turret opposite, marks the narrowest part of the channel ; it bears S. by E. \ E. easterly 4 cables from the second buoy. The fourth buoy is near the southern edge of the Ouvras ; it bears S.E. by S. 2^ cables from the third buoy. DIRECTIONS.— Grande Porte Channel.— The leading mark through this channel is, Grand Jardin and Rochebonne lighthouses in line E. by S. S. This direction leads two thirds of a cable southward of the Buharats bell buoy ; close southward of a rocky head of 20 feet ; a cable southward of the Pierres des Portes black buoy ; one third of a cable northward of the Basse du Boujaron red buoy ; and, only 50 or 60 yards northward of an 18-f eet patch north eastward of the Basse du Boujaron buoy. When nearing Grand Jardin lighthouse, alter course just before the lighthouse in Anse des Sablons comes on with Ballue light-tower, and then proceed with these objects in line S.E. by S. This course leads close past the edge of the 3-fathoms spur off the south-western end of Grand Jardin ; nearly half a cable eastward of the Traversaine bank ; close to the edge of Pierre Salee Flats ; and, from thence, in mid-channel between the red beacon turret on the Buron rock and the black buoys on the edge of the Ouvras, to the Rade de St. Malo. By night, the same directions will apply by using the lights. Or, when within 2 cables of Grand Jardin lighthouse, bring the Seminaire or college of St. Servan open about half the apparent breadth of its front eastward of the eastern angle of La Cite citadel

Chap, in.] ST. MALO. — DIRECTIONS. 107 S.E. by S. ; this leads half a cable north-eastward of the Traversaine and of the Pierre Salee flats, and three quarters of a cable eastward of the Buron rock beacon turret. At low water, care is necessary to avoid the 18-feet spur extending nearly half a cable south-westward of the Grand Jardin beacon, which may be done by keeping the leading mark slightly open until the beacon opens northward of the mound, then keep the fairway mark again. A vessel is eastward of the Traversaine bank when St. Lunaire mill _ is its own length westward of the Haumet rock. When rounding the Grand Jardin, another good mark leading to St. Malo road is, a large chimney in St. Servan open eastward of St. Servan church, so as to see daylight between them. The Grande Porte channel may be entered between the Buharats and the Pierres des Portes, and, with a leading wind, this route is the best at low water ; the leading mark is, the steeple of St. Enogat church on with the eastern side of Haumet rock S. by E. £ E. until the north-western windmill of Petite Parame is seen between the south-eastern mill and the south-eastern angle of Fort Royal S.E. f E. ; this leads southward of the Pierres des Portes black buoy, and mid-channel between the Pierres de la Savatte and the Traversaine bank up to the leading mark for the Grand chenel de la Ranee. The face of the mill as well as the south-eastern angle of Fort Royal are whitewashed, in order to be easily recognised at a distance. A good mark for passing between the Traversaine and the Pierres de la Savatte is, the Buron red beacon turret on with Sablons lighthouse S.E. by S., but this line must be quitted when the Traversaine bank is past as it leads over the Salee flats. Petite Porte Channel. — If entering the Grande Ranee by the Petite Porte channel, Harbour Island Fort open westward of Grand Jardin lighthouse S. by E., or the lighthouse on with the mill on Dinard point, leads through the clearest passage up to Grand Jardin ; but, to reduce as much as possible the turn round the southern extreme of the Grand Jardin, it is usual to pass through the chain of reefs farther westward. For this purpose, when approaching the entrance, bring the western end of Cezembre island on with the centre of the town of St. Malo S.E. by S., and, when within 2 miles of the island, steer to the southward to bring Grand Jardin and Ballue lighthouses in line S.E. by S. southerly ; this leads between the Grande Hupee and the Rat des Courtis, and northward of the Basse Nord-Est des Portes ; when within 2 cables of the lighthouse, steer to round the Grand Jardin and proceed as before directed.

108 [Chap. III. CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. After half flood, vessels of considerable draught may use this passage with perfect safety by bringing the leading marks for the Grande Ranee channel on from the offing, Sablons and Ballue lights in line S.E. by S. ; in this case, they will pass over the middle of the Basses Nord-Est des Portes. Grand Jardin lighthouse on with Jeannet windmill S. by W. £ W. leads between the Bunel rock and the shoals 2 cables westward of the western end of Cezembre ; but, in using this channel, a vessel must edge away to the South-west to round the Grand Jardin as soon as either Parame or St. Hydeuc church steeples open of the south western point of Cezembre. The PETITE CONCHEE CHANNEL is only practicable for vessels of deep draught between half flood and half ebb. Its entrance is 2 cables eastward of the Petite Conchee rock, between the Rousse and Ronfleresse' rocks, where the channel is less than a cable wide. The Petite Conchee is the only rock between Cezembre island and Grande Conchee that does not cover at springs ; the Rousse uncovers 33 feet, and the Ronfleresse 28| feet. Directions. — The western side of Petit Bey fort seen between La Cite citadel and the little fort on Bechard point, South, leads through the Petite Conchee channel nearly up to the Crapauds du Bey rocks, leaving the Rousse, the Rats, and the Queue des Rats westward ; and, the Ronfleresse, the Pierres aux Normands, and the Roches aux Anglais eastward. A beacon, on a rock which dries 12 feet, marks the centre of the Pierres aux Normands ; and, near the northern end of the Roches aux Anglais is a beacon on a rock which uncovers 11 feet ; the south-eastern part of this latter reef is also marked by a red buoy moored within its edge. The leading mark given passes within 50 yards westward of a sunken rock off the western point of the Ronfleresse, with only 3 feet at low water, springs ; it must be kept on until St. Lunaire mill, or the mound on Bellefard point, opens out southward of Harbour isle ; the vessel will then be 1^ cables westward of the beacon on^the Anglais, and should haul more to the westward to bring the western head of Bizeux islet on with the high rock at the foot of Bechard point bearing S. \ E. easterly, which mark leads between the Basse Sud-Est des Ouvras and the black buoy of the Crapauds du Bey up to St. Malo road. Crapauds du Bey. — These rocks, marked by the black buoy on their northern side just mentioned, bear N. by W. 2^- cableB from the Petit Bey fort, they uncover 5^ feet.

Chap. III.] ST. MALO.— CONCHEE CHANNELS. 109 GRANDE CONCHEE CHANNEL derives its name from the Grande Conchee rock, and, like that of the Petite Conchee, can only be entered by large vessels between half flood and half ebb, and is chiefly used by those from the north-eastward. The shallowest part, as with- all the channels eastward of Cezembre, is that over the flats in front of Grand and Petit Bey forts. The entrance is bounded on its western side by the Haies de la Conchee, the Rimponiere, and the Grande Conchee ; and, on its eastern side, by the Rousses and the Plate ; its position may be recognised by Grande Conchee fort, which may be seen from a great distance. Haies de la Conchae, Rousses, and Plate Rocks.— The Haies de la Conchee, 3 cables northward of Grande Conchee fort, is a ridge of high rocks whose summits do not cover. The Rimponiere between the Haies de la Conchee and Grande Conchee, dries 36 feet. The Rousses are rocks, of which one isolated head has only 6 feet water ; the marks for it are, the Grand Chevreuil a little open southward of the guard-house on the inner part of Meinga point ; and, Roche mill on with the eastern gable of the barracks of Petit Bey fort S.S.W. The Plate, half a mile S.E. from Grande Conchee, uncovers 18 feet, and has on it a stone beacon turret 10 feet above the highest tides painted in red and black horizontal bands. Although the sea is nearly always breaking on the Plate, its northern and western sides may be safely approached ; but, off its southern side are two small rocks, of which the Bouton, the most distant, uncovers 12 feet three quarters of a cable S. by W. from the beacon tower. Buoy. — The Bouton rock is marked by a red buoy moored south ward of it. Several other patches are scattered about the entrance to this channel ; the most dangerous are, the Becfer, the St. Servantine, and the Rat de St. Servan. The Basse de Becfer, with 15 feet water, lies North 2£ cables from the two north-westernmost heads of the Haies de la Conchee. The Basse de la Conchee, with 22 feet, bears N.E. £ N. 8 cables from Grande Conchee fort. The Rat de St. Servan with 12 feet, least water, lies E. £ N. 6^ cables, and the Teto, with 17 feet, the same distance E. £ S. from Grande Conchee fort. The Rat du Rocher, with 15 feet, is one mile distant E. N. from Grande Conchee fort. St. Servantine is a dangerous isolated rock, which uncovers 2 feet at the lowest tides ; the marks for it are, the summit of the Ronfleresse rock on with the foot of Garde Guerin point W. by

110 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. [Chap. III. S. £ S. ; and, St. Hydeuc steeple on with a mill 4 cables S. by E. £ E. from the steeple. Buoy. — A red bell buoy'is moored on the south-eastern side of the St. Servantine rock. As a guide to the depth of water over these shoals, it is useful to know that when the Ronfleresse is covered there are at least 25 feet over the St. Servantine ; and, that when the rock on which the Plate beacon turret stands is covered, there are 30 feet over the Rat de St. Servan, 33 feet over the Rat du Rocher, and 34 feet over the Teto rock. Directions. — When running for the Grande Conchee channel from the eastward, be careful to keep the mound on Garde Guerin point open northward of the Petite Conchee W.S.W. to pass northward of the Basse des Pointus which has 18 feet water, the St. Servantine, and the Rousses. The leading mark to enter the channel is, the Mole des Noires lighthouse touching the eastern side of Grand Bey island S. £ W. ; this mark leads 1£ cables eastward of Grande Conchee fort and 2f cables westward of the Plate beacon turret. Keep this mark on until abreast of the Roches aux Anglais, marked by a beacon and buoy as already described ; then haul to the westward round that buoy until the Crapauds buoy is on the port bow, and steer about S.W. by W.^W. between them, with Jeannet mill well open northward of St. Enogat steeple and on with the fall of the high land bordering the eastern side of the Anse des Etetes ; this mark leads northward of the Crapauds du Bey rocks, but it may be necessary to haul a little more westward to clear the buoy. When the westernmost head of the Bizeux is on with the high rock at the foot of Bechard point, steer with these two rocks in line for St. Malo road as before directed. A vessel may, if necessary, pass southward of the Crapauds du Bey rocks by keeping Jeannet mill exactly on with St. Enogat church. A good leading mark for the Grande Conchee channel from the offing, and one easily recognised, is, the south-western corner of La Cite on with the middle of Grand Bey islet S. by W. £ W. This mark, if followed after entering the channel, has the disadvantage of leading closely past the sunken dangers on its eastern side ; when abreast of the Anglais rocks, a vessel should haul to the westward as before. At night, in clear weather, vessels may enter by the Grande Conchee channel ; the Grand Jardin light kept opening and shutting

Chap. III.] ST. MALO.— CONCHEE AND PETITS POINTUS CHANNELS. Ill in with the southern side of Cezembre island leads northward of the St. Servantine up to the entrance ; then, with the Mole des Noires light opening and shutting in with the eastern side of Grand Bey, steer up the channel. When the high point of Dinard is still a little open westward of the Petit Bey, haul sharply to the westward to pass between the Roches aux Anglais and the Crapauds, observing that when the Mole des Noires light, after having been masked by the Grand Bey, reopens, and is about to be again masked by the Petit Bey, the vessel is nearly on the line of the Crapauds ; and, that when the light re-opens westward of the Petit Bey, she is westward of them and may bear up S.S.W. to enter the eastern limit of the Anse de Sablons green light, and then steer for the anchorage in St. Malo roads. The PETITS POINTUS CHANNEL is the next channel east ward of the Grande Conchee ; its entrance is between the St. Servantine red bell buoy and the Grands Pointus rocks, of which the highest head is 8 feet above high water level and is therefore an excellent mark for the entrance. The leading mark in is, Petit Bey fort a little southward of the guard-house on Dinard point S. W. £ S. This line leaves on the starboard hand the Plate rock and all the rocky patches named in describing the Grande Conchee channel, the nearest of which, the Bouton, is passed at 2£ cables ; and, on the port hand, the Basse Tangui of 14 feet, 4 cables N.E. from the Petits Pointus beacon ; the Petits Pointus, of which the highest head, marked by the beacon referred to, uncovers 33 feet ; the Letruns, a shoal 4 cables in extent North and South, which dries from 5 to 7 feet in patches and is marked near its southern edge by a red bell buoy ; the Letrun d'Aval patch, which dries 51 feet ; the Grand Dodehal, which dries 13 feet -and is marked by a beacon nearly 6 cables E. by S. £ S. from the Roches aux Anglais beacon ; the Petit Dodehal, which dries 3 feet 3 cables westward of the Grand Dodehal ; and, within half a cable of the leading line and between the Grand and Petit Dodehal, a small rock awash at the lowest tides. This channel, as well as all those eastward of Cezembre island, is only practicable for vessels of deep draught between half flood and half ebb. Directions. — Vessels from the eastward entering by the Petits Pointus channel, when westward of the Basse Grune, should steer with the mound on Garde Guerin point on with Grande Conchee fort W. by S. £ S. ; this leads between the Grands Pointus and Basse des Pointus, about 3 cables south-eastward of the latter.

112 [Chap. III. CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. Having arrived within half a mile of the St. Servantine red bell buoy, haul to the southward to bring on the leading mark for the channel just given, viz., Petit Bey fort a little open southward of the guard-house on Dinard point S.W. \ S., until the mark used when en tering by the Grande Conchee channel comes on — viz., Jeannet mill well open northward of St. Enogat church steeple and on with the fall of the high land on the eastern side of the Anse des Etetes, when proceed as before directed. By following the leading mark given, a vessel passes a cable west ward of the Basse Tangui, three quarters of a cable westward of the beacon on the Petits Pointus, and 2 cables westward of the Letrun d'Aval. The BIGNE CHANNEL is named after the Bigne rock, three quarters of a mile north-eastward of Varde point, and the highest rock in the vicinity of that point, its summit being 32 feet above the highest tides. This channel is not much frequented, but may be used by vessels of moderate draught with a leading wind, at springs, between half flood and half ebb. At neaps, it may be used by vessels drawing not more than 10 feet at all times of tide. Directions. — In steering for the entrance of the Bigne channel between the Tintiaux group, north-eastward of Meinga point, and the Rochefort rock black and red beacon turret, bring the Crolante rock, which lies at the foot of Varde point and uncovers 38 feet, on with the western side of Grand Bey fort S.W. by W. \ W. Run in with this mark on until the Bigne rock bears N.E. by N., or until St. Lunaire mill is on with Bellefard point W. by S. \ S. southerly, when keep it so until St. Jeannet mill opens northward of St. Enogat steeple ; then proceed as before. The first mark leads a cable south-eastward of the Basse aux Chiens, which lies half a mile south-eastward of the Rochefort and uncovers 3 feet ; about the same distance from the Basse du Durand, lying 6 cables southward of the Rochefort with only one foot water ; and, about half a cable south-eastward of the Petite Bigne, marked by a beacon at its eastern end. On the other hand, it leads within half a cable of the reef extending from the Durand, ef which some rocks dry 12 feet ; and, at a greater distance outside the Aiguillon and Graine-de-Lin rocks, the former uncovering 21 feet, the latter 12 feet. The second mark leads a cable northward of the Crolante and of the Cancalaise, a little rocky ridge which uncovers 9 feet ; and, about half a cable southward of the red bell buoy off the southern end of the Letruns.
