MALO.— BIGNE CHANNEL.— DIRECTIONS. 113 The third mark leads northward of the Crapauds du Bey as on enter ing by the Grande Conchee or Petits Pointus channels, but leads very close to the rock awash north-eastward of the Petit Dodehal. It is useful to know that when the Petite Bigne covers, there are more than 19 feet over the tail of the shoal extending northward from Grand Bey fort, which is the shoalest part of this channel. Vessels sometimes enter the Bigne channel with St. Malo church on with the Bigne rock S.W. \ W., and run in on the eastern side of the Rochefort until within a quarter of a mile of the Bigne, then edge away southward, to round the Petite Bigne at a safe distance, and then bring on the leading marks already given, and proceed as before. The tides in this channel between St. Malo and Varde point never have much strength ; they run strongly however north-eastward of that point. To St. Malo from the Westward.— When bound to St. Malo from the westward, with southerly winds, Ushant and the French coast may be kept aboard ; but, with northerly winds and at night, a prudent distance should be maintained off-shore until the fixed and flashing light on the Sept-iles, and the fixed light on the Heaux rocks, are made out. With the assistance of these lights, a position may be obtained about 4 miles northward of the Heaux, from whence a S.E. E. course for about 33 miles, following the directions at page 47, leads northward of the Roc'h-ar-Bel and Horaine ledge, and crosses the meridian of cape Frehel about 6 miles northward of the cape. The vessel is then in a good position to run for the entrance of the Ranee through the Decolle passage or Grande Porte channel, according to the state of the wind and tide. This route may be followed either with the flood or against the ebb with the wind from N.N.E. round by West to South, but if between S.W. and South it is better to give cape Frehel a closer berth. With a fresh leading wind, a sailing vessel passing the meridian of Heaux lighthouse at the commencement of the flood, or 5 hours before high water at St. Malo, should enter the Ranee by high water, the distance being about 43 miles ; but, with a foul wind, it takes two flood tides to make the passage." With a beating wind, make short tacks in sight of Heaux light house until the commencement of the flood, then stretch into the channel between the Barnouic and Roc'h-ar-Bel. The boards in this channel should not exceed 2 miles in length, but when eastward of the Horaine they may be extended to 7 or 8 miles. By following A 2771. Wt. 7242. H

[Chap. HI. 114 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. these directions, cape Frehel should be made towards the latter part of the flood, and the vessel may anchor or make short tacks under shelter of the cape during the ebb ; or, if not so far to windward, she may anchor in the rade d'Erqui, see page 82. Weigh again when the flood makes, and work up so as to reach, if possible by about half flood, one of the entrance channels to the Ranee. To St. Malo through Grand Ruet Passage.— The channel between the Roches-Douvres on the West, and Guernsey, Jersey, and the Minquiers ledge on the East, called by the French pilots the Grand Ruet, would seem from its great breath to offer a safe and easy route to St. Malo or Granville ; the streams, however, run through and across it with such velocity at springs, that, during westerly winds, with stream and wind in the same direction, a sailing vessel runs great risk of being drifted between the islands and dangers in their vicinity ; and, if surprised by fog or night, the danger is imminent, the constant changes in the set of the stream making the dead reckoning unreliable. At springs, with a westerly wind and flood tide, ships should keep well to the westward, make the coast of France about the Sept-iles, and proceed southward of the Barnouic ledge, as already described ; but, at neaps, with a steady northerly wind irrespective of tide, or, at springs, with an ebb tide and a westerly wind, a vessel may use this channel with due care as follows : — With a steady westerly wind, and being about 8 miles W.S.W. of the Hanois light off the western endof Guernsey, at the commence ment of the ebb or 2\ hours after high water at St. Malo, steer S. \ E. for about 38 miles, or until within 6 or 8 miles N.W. by N. of cape Frehel," when St. Malo may be steered for as before directed. This course leads about 4^ miles eastward of the Roches-Douvres lighthouse, which should be sighted to correct the reckoning ; 5£ miles eastward of the Barnouic ledge ; and, 9^ miles westward of the Minquiers. During nearly the whole of this run, the wind being on the starboard side counteracts the effect of the stream, which, for the first four hours will be on the port beam, the fifth hour a little on the bow, and at last on the starboard beam, the flood beginning earlier as the coast is neared. To St. Malo through the D^route Passage.— The shortest and best route from cape de la Hague to St. Malo, with fresh leading winds, is through the Race of Alderney,see pages 346-348, and between Jersey and Serk through the Deroute passage, see page 265, the

Chap. III.] ST. MALO BY GRAND RUET AND COTENTIN PASSAGES. 115 distance being about 75 miles ; it should not be used, however, by strangers at night during light winds or in thick weather. To take this route under the most advantageous circumstances, endeavour to enter the Race on the slack or last of the north-eastern stream, which is about 4 hours after high water at St. Malo. Having cleared the Race, steer about S.W. to enter the Deroute passage in mid-channel, and to ensure passing south-eastward of the Blanchard rock. This distance being run in about 2^ or 3 hours, or about the time of low water at St. Malo, continue the course so as to be in a good position westward of the meridian of the Minquiers at the first of the flood. This stream is felt more as the vessel advances southward ; it is therefore most necessary to determine by correct bearings the course to be steered, and to pay strict attention to the directions given at page 136, in passing those dangers. When clear of the Minquiers, steer for cape Frehel where pilots are always on the look out. To St. Malo through the Contentin Passage.— Full directions are given at pages 186-192 for this passage when bound to Granville ; the same directions should be followed for St. Malo until the vessel has arrived within 4 or 5 miles of the beacon turret on the Etat or Petite Canue, a remarkable rock on the northern edge of the Chausey group, which group is fully described in the following chapter, when she should keep to the westward so as to round the north-western part of the group about 1^ miles distant. When abreast of the Rondes de l'Ouest, a rocky ridge forming the western end of the group, steer S.W. or more southerly, keeping within 3 miles of the rocks until the ruins of the old castle on Grande lie open southward of the Corbiere, the high and remarkable rock at the south-western extreme of the Chausey group, E. by S. £ S.; then steer about S.W. S. for one of the channels into the Ranee. Great care must be taken to make proper allowance for the set of the tidal stream, which, in clear weather, can easily be done by frequent bearings of objects on the Chausey isles. At Night, when Chausey light is sighted, steer for it on a S.W. £ S. bearing until within 2 miles of the Chausey group, when Granville light will bear S.S.E. % E.; then keep to the westward so as to round the rocks at that distance. When abreast of the western end of the group, haul to the southward, taking care not to approach the rocks within 2 miles ; and, if the night is clear, by the time the light bears E. by N. both the Herpin and Grand Jardin lights will H 2

116 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. [Chap. III. be in sight. By the aid of these two, and of the St. Malo leading lights, the port may be entered at once by the directions already given ; or, if preferred, a position may be maintained off the port to await daylight. From St. Malo through Contentin Passage.— Vessels leaving St. Malo and intending to take this route, should so time their departure as to enable them to enter the Contentin passage with the first of the north-eastern stream, which makes 3J hours before high water at St. Malo. From one mile northward of the Grande Conchee, steer about N.E. I E. ; this line passes about 2 miles north-westward of the Rochefort beacon turret, and 4 miles south-eastward of the Sauvages, due allowance being made for tide. When within 3 or 4 miles of the Corbiere rock, steer to pass about 1^ miles westward of the Rondes de l'Ouest, clear of Corbiere bank. Round the north-western end of the group at the same distance, passing about 2 miles south-eastward of the Ardentes ; and, when the semaphore on the summit of Gros-Mont is on with the Enseigne beacon tower S. by W. steer to the eastward to bring the Etat and Huguenans beacon towers in line S. by W. \ W. westerly ; this mark on astern leads northward between the Shamrock knoll and the Marie ledge, when follow the directions given at page 190, and endeavour to run through the Race of Alderney with the last of the south-western stream. If after the first quarter flood, and unable to weather the western end of the Chausey group, bear up and pass round the eastern end, where, by that time, there will be a good rise of tide over the numerous shallow patches by which that part of the channel is encumbered, see pages 152-154. Granville church on with the northernmost chimney of the south-western barrack keeps a vessel half a mile northward of the Videcoq rock, marked by a red and black bell buoy ; and, Coutances cathedral on with Mont Martin church N.E. by E. £ E. leads between the Haguet and Admiralty banks, but over and amongst patches with as little as 3 feet at low water, springs, when southward of the latter. From St. Malo through the D^route Passage.— Vessels of deep draught bound eastward, leave St. Malo road when the flood begins to slack ; and, with a fair wind, when clear of the Ranee, they may adopt the Grand Ruet passage, see page 114 ; but, with the wind between South and West, the distance may be much shortened by running through the Deroute passage and the Race of

Chap. III.] DIRECTIONS FROM ST. MALO. — ROTENEUF. 117 Alderney. A vessel averaging 7 knots should reach the middle of this passage in 6 hours after leaving St. Malo, and from thence, steering for the Race with a fresh fair wind, may stem the remainder of the south-western stream. The Race would then be entered a little after the commencement of the north-eastern stream. French coasters generally adopt this route, and to ensure entering the Race on the slack or last of the south-western stream, they sometimes wait for a leading wind at anchor under the ile des Ehbiens. The Rochefort rock lies 1% miles north-westward of Meinga point, abreast of the little harbour of Roteneuf, and, with the Platier ledge which dries 3 feet, forms a rocky group 2£ cables long E.N.E. and W.S.W. and one cable wide. The highest head of the Rochefort shows at about 2 hours' ebb, uncovers 34 feet at the lowest tides, and does not cover at neaps. It is marked by a tower of masonry 13 feet above high water, painted with black and red bands, and surmounted by a ball. The marks for it are, the guard-house on the summit of Varde point its own breadth open westward of the Bigne S.W. £ S. ; and, St. Vincent mill on with the western bluff of Benard point, South. The mound on Garde Guerin point open northward of Grande Conchee isle leads northward of the Rochefort ; and, Parame church on with the Bigne leads westward. ROTENEUF.— This little harbour, about 4 miles eastward of St. Malo and midway between Varde and Meinga points, is about three-quarters of a mile wide and half a mile deep, but it is choked with sand, over which the tide only begins to rise at half flood ; the approach also is rendered dangerous by several rocks which cover. Vessels of 15 or 16 feet draught may beach within it at high water, springs, but they must keep within a quarter of a cable of Benard point, the eastern point of entrance, when passing it. Vessels ground and lay up for the winter in the creek eastward of this point, where the bottom is everywhere of sand and the shelter excellent. A remarkable tree open eastward of a large house leads up to the entrance of the harbour, passing eastward of the Rochefort and westward of the Hautieux and Guimereux rocks ; the Hautieux uncover 25 feet, the Guimereux, lying between the Hautieux and Benard point, 23 feet. Three off-lying rocks, always covered and very dangerous to deep vessels, lie eastward of the Rochefort ; they are the Basse Rault, Basse Grune, and Basse du Nid.

[Chap. III. 118 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. Basse Rault.— This rocky head lies 1% miles E. by N. \ N. from Rochefort beacon turret ; N. by E. £ E. 1\ miles from Meinga point ; and, W. by N. \ N. northerly 4£ miles from Pierre de Herpin light house. It has only 16 feet water, with from 9 to 10 fathoms round it, and should be carefully avoided at low water by vessels of deep draught, as also by small craft when it blows hard as it then causes a great swell. The marks for the Rault are, the mound on Garde Guerin point a little open southward of the Rochefort beacon turret W. by S. \ S. southerly ; and, the eastern slope of Meinga point almost shutting in Terquete mill. The mound on Garde Guerin point on with Grande Conchee fort W. by S. £ S. leads northward ; and, Mont St. Michel on with the Herpin rock S.E. \ E. leads well north-eastward. Basse Grune is a dangerous isolated rock, with only 7 feet on it and from 10 to 12 fathoms close around, lying N.E. \ E. 3^ miles from Meinga point ; and, N.W. \ W. 3^ miles from Pierre de Herpin lighthouse. It occasions great overfalls even in moderate weather, and is much in the way of vessels from the westward bound to Granville or Cancale road. The marks for it are, Rochefort beacon turret a little southward of the mound on Garde Guerin point W. by S. g S. southerly ; Granville church perceptibly open south ward of Granville lighthouse ; and, Cancale church its own length open westward of the eastern Haut-Bout mill S. \ E. Granville church in sight northward of Granville lighthouse E. \ N. leads well northward of the Basse Grune ; Garde Guerin mound on with Grande Conchee fort leads half a mile north-westward ; Mont St. Michel on with the Herpin rock S.E. E. leads southward between it and the Basse du Nid ; and, a vessel is eastward of it when Cancale church opens eastward of Haut-Bout eastern mill. In moderate weather, vessels of any draught may pass between the Grune and the Nid at all times by keeping Mont St. Michel on with the Herpin rock bearing S.E. \ E. The lights of cape Frehel, Pierre de Herpin, Granville, and Chausey are all visible from the Basse Grune ; from it, cape Frehel light bears W. \ N. 17 miles, Granville light E. \ N. 12 miles, and Chausey light N.E. \ N. 7f miles. Basse du Nid, a small rocky patch about 1^ miles S.S.W. \ W. from the Basse Grune, and \\ miles E. by S. \ S. from the Rault, has 17 feet water over, and from 8 to 9 fathoms round it. From it, Meinga point bears S.W. by W. \ W. 2\ miles ; the Herpin rock S E. by E. \ E. 2£ miles ; St. Malo church tower is seen over Varde

Chap. III.] DANGERS NORTH-EASTWARD OF ST. MALO. 119 point touching the Petit Chevreuil ; and, Mont St. Michel is on with the rocks extending from the northern point of Landes island. Mont St. Michel on with the Herpin rock S.E. \ E. leads well northward of it. When the Pierre de Herpin rock, on which the lighthouse stands, is covered, there are at least 37 feet water over the Grune, and 46 feet over both the Rault and Nid. The TINTIAUX are a group of rocks about 1£ miles long E.S.E. and W.N.W., and half a mile broad, their western end lying 4 cables north-eastward of Meinga point ; most of the rocks appear at 4 hours ebb, and the highest, near the centre of the group, dry about 30 feet at low water, springs, and do not cover at neaps. Rochefort beacon turret on with cape Frehel lighthouse, or on with Grande Conchee fort, leads northward ; and, Duguesclin fort bearing S.S.W., or Haut-Bout eastern mill on with the guard-house on Verger point, the eastern point of the first sandy beach westward of Grouin point, leads eastward. Tintiaux Passage, between the Tintiaux and the land, is used by coasting vessels with southerly winds ; the tide runs very strongly through it, but follows the direction of the channel. The leading mark when coming from the eastward is, the Bigne rock midway between Grand Jardin lighthouse and the south-western point of Cezembre isle, West ; this leads 100 yards southward of all the Tintiaux, and between them and the northern rock of the Cadins, which dries 3 feet. Give Meinga point a berth of a quarter of a mile in passing, and then run out between the Tintiaux and the Basse aux Chiens, with St. Vincent mill, on the heights at the head of Roteneuf harbour, touching the eastern part of the high land of Benard ; or, if entering St. Malo, bring the leading marks on for the Bigne channel, see page 112, if the tide is sufficiently high to take that channel. The Coast. — Meinga point, 3£ miles westward of Grouin point, is very remarkable ; it is nearly as high as cape Frehel, is narrow and steep on all sides, and extends in a slope more than half a mile northward. Between it and Grouin point, the coast presents nothing worthy of notice with the exception of the small bay between Nez and Nid points, where, in its south-eastern part, is a sandy beach defended by Fort Duguesclin. This fort stands 3 cables westward of Nid point on a rocky islet joined with the shore at low water by a ridge of rocks. There is also a semaphore station at point Besnard close by.

[Chap. III. 120 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. Vessels of deep draught should keep well off-shore between points Meinga and Grouin ; indeed, as previously stated, the navigation of this coast is so fraught with danger, both from its numerous rocks and strong tides, that the safety of his vessel calls for the utmost vigilance on the part of the mariner. POINTE de GROUIN, the western point of Mont St. Michel bay, is high, rocky, and precipitous on its north-western and south eastern sides, but forms a narrow slope towards the N.E. The sudden change in the direction of the coast at this point is very remarkable, and makes it easy of recognition at a great distance in the offing. Near its extreme is a semaphore, and farther southward the two windmills of Haut-Bout. North-westward of Grouin point and peninsula are many rocky patches from half a mile to one mile from the shore ; and, on its eastern side, Landes island, with the Herpin, Pierre de Herpin, Fille rock, and a few shoal patches extending 2 miles eastward of Grouin point, form a broken rocky barrier through which vessels pass when seeking shelter in Cancale road or in the anchorage off La Houle. He des Landes. — This high, narrow, rocky islet, steep on all sides and inaccessible when there is any swell on, lies 2 cables eastward of Grouin point, and, at high water, is about 4 cables long N.E. and S.W. and about a cable wide ; but, at low tide, it is lengthened 3 cables to the N.N.E. by some rocks then high above water and by others which are covered. Its direction is nearly parallel with the shore, from which it is separated by a channel called the Vieille Riviere, only 164 yards wide at its narrowest part, through which, at springs, the stream runs 6 knots. The eastern side is steep-to from end to end, there being from 18 to 20 feet water alongside the rocks. On the north-eastern part of the island .are the ruins of a fort and guard-house. The Pignonet rock, with only 10-jj feet, lies in mid-channel between the north-eastern extreme of Landes island and the Herpin rock. The Herpin rock is a high pyramid rock about 66 feet above the level of high water, springs, and its base a cable in diameter at low water. It bears E.N.E. three quarters of a mile from Grouin point, and is nearly 2 cables from the north-eastern extreme of Landes island ; its shape, great height, and isolated ' position, render it a remarkable object from a great distance.

Chap. III.] POINTE DE GROUIN. — PIERRE DE HERPIN. 121 Coasters find shelter under this rock with the wind from West round by South to East. There is also good anchorage in from 7 to 9 fathoms with the rock bearing N.W. £ W. from 1 to 1^ miles ; the ground, however, so far out, is rather coarse. PIERRE de HERPIN.— The highest head of this small rocky ridge, on which stands the lighthouse, uncovers 32 feet, and bears N.E. by E. \ E. three quarters of a mile from the Herpin rock. At springs, it begins to show at about one third ebb ; at neaps, it does not cover. Another rocky ridge, with from 22 to 24 feet water, lies S. by E. a quarter of a mile from the Pierre de Herpin. LIGHT. — From a circular lighthouse, 81 feet in height, on the Pierre de Herpin, at 61 feet above the level of high water, is exhibited a light alternately fixed white and flashing green for successive periods of SO seconds. • The fixed white light is visible at 17 miles; the flashing green light at 15 miles. From this lighthouse, cape Frehel light bears W. by N. 19^ miles ; the Minquiers light-vessel N.W. 21 miles ; and, Granville light, pointe du Roc, E. by N. £ N. 10 miles. The passage between the Pierre de Herpin and the Herpin rock, called the Grand Ruet, is the principal entrance to Cancale road from the North-west ; but, the Basse du Milieu, a shoal with only 4 feet W. | S. 2§ cables from the lighthouse, narrows the passage to 4 cables between it and the Herpin rock ; this passage is otherwise deep enough for vessels of any draught at all times. They should, however, pass within a cable of the Herpin on the flood, as this stream sets strongly over the Basse du Milieu and Pierre de Herpin ; the flood begins to make through the passage about 5£ hours before high water at St. Malo or Granville, and as it runs S.E. and E.S.E. there is no danger of being drifted over the Banchets. The Fille rock, E.N.E. 3 cables from Pierre de Herpin light house, is the easternmost of these dangers ; it uncovers 11 feet at the lowest tides. From it, Grouin point bears W.S.W. 2 miles ; the summit of the Herpin rock is on with the northern head of the Pierre de Herpin ; and, Bigne rock appears between the Grand Chevreuil, half hidden by point Meinga, and Cezembre island. Buoy. — A bell buoy, with red and black bands, marks this danger on its northern side. When the Pierre de Herpin covers, there are 19^ feet on the Fille, and a vessel is northward of both when Grouin point is open

122 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. [Chap. III. northward of the Herpin rock, and southward when the point is open southward of the Herpin. Cape Frehel on with the Herpin also leads southward. There are 8£ fathoms in the passage between the Pierre de Herpin and the Fille, and it may be safely used by keeping from 1^ to 2^ cables from the lighthouse ; but, this passage places a vessel too much to leeward if seeking shelter from strong westerly winds in Cancale road. Bane des Renardieres, of from 6 to 7^ fathoms, sand and shells, bears N.N.W. W. 1£ miles from the Herpin rock ; it is only a cable broad and half a mile in length N. by W. and S. by E., and lying nearly across the streams it causes a heavy sea on a weather tide. From its shoalest part at the southern end, the fort near Varde point appears midway between Grand and Petit Cheyreuil W. by S. f S. ; and, the Herpin rock is on with the north-eastern extreme of Pointe de Gogre, Mont *St. Michel bay. South-eastward of Grouin point, between it and point de la Chaine, is the Grande rade de Cancale, already referred to and presently described. Besides the dangers extending eastward from Grouin point, of which the Fille rock is the most eastern, there are, on the western side of the road, the Bane de Chatry ; on the northern side, the Banchets shoal ; and, on the eastern and southern sides, the Brehaut, Corbieres, ile de Rimains, and other rocks in-shore, of which the principal are the Petit Rimains and the Chatellier, above water ; a large rock near Chaine point which uncovers 22 feet and is marked by a beacon ; and, the Thomen rock within low water mark off La Houle, marked by two beacons on its northern heads. The southern head having been levelled has no beacon. Bane de Chatry runs parallel with the shore and bounds Cancale road on the West ; it has from 6 to 9 feet for a distance of half a mile on its shoalest parts, and is joined to the coast at Chaine point by a bed of sand, over which there are 11 or 12 feet ; its northern end is abreast of a small creek named port Mer, leaving between it and the shallows extending from the shore the Fosse de Chatry or Chatry deep, a swashway 3 cables wide, in which the depths are from 26 to 32 feet. From the northern part of the bank, Haut-Bout windmill is on with the northern declivity of Chatry point ; and, from its eastern edge, the Cormorandiere and the Hubert, two remarkable rocks adjoining Rimains island, are in line ; the Cormorandiere, at the

Chap. III.] DANGERS OFF THE RADE DE CANCALE. 123 northern extreme of the island, is high and pointed ; the Hubert, about three quarters of a cable eastward of the fort, is wedge shaped- The BANCHETS.— This bank of sand and broken shells of from 10 to 24 feet water is in the fairway of the entrance to Cancale road, 3 cables northward of the Corbieres bank, and E.S.E. three quarters of a mile from the old fort on Landes island ; together with the small knoll of 23Jj feet at 2 cables on its north-western side, it is dangerous to vessels of deep draught at low water, springs. The bank is 5^ cables long N. by W. and S. by E. ; the shoalest parts form two small ridges parallel to each other, and athwart the direction of the streams. On the north-western ridge are 17 feet, and only 10 feet on the highest part of the other, near the eastern part of the bank. The marks for the 10-feet ridge are, the steep point of Chateau Richeux open 1° eastward of Chaine point ; and, the slope of Grouin point open the same distance northward of the guard-house on Landes island. The sand forming this bank is said not to shift, but there is reason to think that the depths often change during strong gales. The mark for the small knoll of 23^ feet water is, Haut-Bout mill on with the northern point of port Mer bay. The mill just open southward of the point leads between this knoll and the Banchets ; and, on with the summit of the same point leads northward of the knoll. There are two other knolls, with 24 and 25 feet water, a cable northward of the Banchets. The Brehaut is an extensive flat of sand and rock south-eastward of the Banchets and half a mile eastward of the northern part of Corbieres bank ; the soundings are from 7 to 10 fathoms, but as the ground is very foul it should be avoided. Bane des Corbieres, bounding Cancale road eastward, is about H miles long from the line of Haut-Bout windmill on with the northern declivity of Chatry point, to the same windmill on with the Cormorandiere rock ; it is about half a mile wide and is joined to the sandy shore of Mont St." Michel bay by flats on which the depth decreases gradually from 20 to 8 feet, and from thence to the sands which dry. The general depths on this bank are from 2 to 4 fathoms, but a small patch about 3 cables long North and South with only 10 feet water rises on its southern part, about half a mile eastward of the fort on Rimains island. From the northern end of this patch, the guard-house on Chaine point is on with Cancale church steeple ; and,

124 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. [Chap. III. from the southern end, the steeple is between the Chatellier rock and Petit Rimains islet, which joins the northern end of that rock at low water. GRANDE RADE de CANCALE.— This excellent anchorage is northward of Rimains island, three quarters of a mile from the shore between Chatry and Corbieres banks ; it affords good shelter for ships of deep draught during westerly winds. A vessel should moor North and South with open hawse to the westward, and the best holding ground is with the Cormorandiere rock seen between Rimains island and the Hubert rock ; its eastern limit is, the Cormorandiere touching the eastern side of the fort on Rimains ; and, its northern limit, Haut-Bout mill on with the middle of Portz Picain, a small white sandy beach close southward of Chatry point. North easterly winds sometimes cause a swell, but vessels are seldom obliged by shifts of wind to weigh suddenly at this anchorage. There is also good holding ground in the southern part of the road in from 26 to 30 feet, clay and mud, about 2 cables eastward of Rimains island, with Cancale church steeple on with the middle of Rimains fort ; and, Grouin point a little open westward of Landes island. A vessel under 10 feet draught may anchor southward of Rimains island, with that island bearing North half a mile distant ; in running for this anchorage at low water, keep within a quarter of a mile of the island, to avoid the 10-feet patch on the Corbieres bank. At this anchorage, if unable to ride out heavy weather from the north-eastward, take the top of high water and run aground on the mud southward of Cancale church with good sail on ; here both vessel and crew will be saved. Buoy. — A large mooring buoy is placed about 5 cables S.S.W. h W. from the southern end of Rimains island ; there are only 4 feet water at this spot at low water, springs. Anchorage East of Corbieres Bank.— Vessels of deep draught sometimes anchor eastward of Corbieres bank, but they are less sheltered than in Cancale road and more exposed to north-easterly winds, which, when strong, throw in a heavy sea, causing vessels to roll heavily on a weather tide. The anchoring ground extends south ward from the line of Haut-Bout mill on with Portz Picain to that of Cancale church steeple on with the southern side of Chatellier rock. The best berth is in from 6 to 7 fathoms, blue tenacious clay, with Dol church steeple on with the foot of the eastern slope of Mont Dol : and, Cancale church steeple between the Chatellier and the fort on

Chap. III.] GRANDE RADE DE CANCALE. — FOSSE DE CHATRY. 125 Rimains. This position is 1£ miles outside Rimains island, but the Corbieres prevents a nearer approach, consequently that island affords but little shelter from the westward. Vessels remaining any length of time at this anchorage should sight their anchors occasionally, or they bury themselves deeply and are difficult to weigh. Merchant vessels generally prefer anchoring southward of the Corbieres bank, where the holding ground is good and the depth from 19 to 22 feet. The best birth is close southward of the line of Haut-Bout mill on with the Cormorandiere rock N.W. westerly, or with the mill between the fort and the northern point of Rimains island, but the safest position is in the southern part of Cancale road. Anchorage in Fosse de Chatry. — Vessels of moderate draught may anchor here in from 26 to 32 feet, with Haut-Bout mill on with Portz Picain ; and, Mont Dol on with the eastern point of Petit Rimains, the little island just northward of the Chatellier rock. This is a good anchorage during neaps, but, at springs, the streams run from 4 to 5 knots. Small craft may anchor a little more in-shore, but not west ward of the line of Mont Dol touching the western side of the Chatellier. Vessels that can take the ground are well sheltered with the wind from N.E. round by North and West to S.S.W. on the deposit of soft mud which borders the northern part of the little bay of port Mer. LIGHT. — On Fenetre rock, port of Houle, Cancale, a fixed red light, visible 6 miles, is shown from a circular tower at 33 feet above high water. The Fenetre rock is connected with the shore by a short pier above the level of high water, which, for the protection of coasters using the port, has lately been considerably lengthened with an elbow to the westward. La Houle, the port of Cancale, has a large fishing industry and valuable oyster beds ; its trade otherwise is insignificant, Its beaching places westward of the Fenetre are good and safe for small craft, The town of Cancale stands on the cliffs and La Houle at their feet ; their united population is about 6,000. St. Malo is about 8 miles distant by road. Directions. — When running from the westward for Cancale road from a position about 2 miles N.N.E. from Cezembre island, steer E. by N., keeping the mound on Garde Guerin point open northward of Grande Conchee fort, until Mont St. Michel opens of Grouin point ;

[Chap. III. 126 CAPE FREHEL TO GRAVILLE. then haul up for it, and keep the Mont on with the Herpin rock bearing S.E. \ E. ; this leads between the Grune and Nid shoals. When within about half a mile of the Herpin rock, steer through the Grand Ruet, passing only a cable eastward of the rock if the flood is run ning, as that stream sets strongly over the Basse du Milieu and Pierre de Herpin ; and, from thence, haul to the southward for the road. The passages between Grouin point and Landes island, called the Petit Ruet, and that between the north-eastern extreme of Landes island and the Herpin are too dangerous to attempt without a pilot. BAIE DU MONT ST. MICHEL, between Grouin and Champeaux points which bear E. £ S.-and W. £ N. from each other distant 10| miles, is much exposed to north-westerly and northerly winds ; the anchorages, however, off Cancale and La Houle in the north-western part of the bay, as just described, afford excellent shelter against westerly winds. The head of the bay falls back a great distance south-eastward, and nearly three fourths of it is occupied by an immense bank of sand which dries at low water. The Coast. — On the western side of the bay the land is high for the space of 4 miles from Grouin to Chateau Richeux point, and the coast generally steep. The low lands, called the marsh of Dol, begin at Chateau Richeux point and extend 15 miles eastward to the mouth of the river Couesnon, the course of which separates the department of Ile-et-Vilaine from that of La Manche. A strong dyke protects this marsh from the invasion of the sea, its surface being in several places below the level of high spring tides. The only remarkable rise on this part of the coast is the small isolated hill named Mont Dol, and a chain of hills, which, seen from the northward, seem to form a long promontory, of which the western extreme is known locally as point de Gogre. Mont Dol rises from the midst of the marsh land 6 miles south-eastward of Chateau Richeux point, and, on its flat top stands a windmill, a semaphore and a few cottages. Point de Gogre is the nearest point to the sea of the chain of hills about three quarters of a mile inland between Mont Dol and the river Couesnon. The little- harbour of Vivier is at the mouth of the river Guyoul S | E. about 7 miles from Grouin point ; it can only be entered by the smallest coasters having good pilots. Mont Dol semaphore bearing S. \ W. leads up to it, There is a small quay, alongside of which vessels lie to load or unload.

Chap. III.] MONT ST. MICHEL BAY. — CHAMPEAUX POINT. 127 . Small vessels can ascend the river Couesnon, at springs, as far as the town of Pontorson, but the navigation is difficult and seldom attempted. The entrance channel through the sands commences at the western foot of Mont St. Michel. Mont St. Michel and Tombelaine islet, rising from the sands in the eastern part of the bay, form by far the most remarkable objects on this part of the coast. Mont St. Michel is a pyramidal block of granite 4 cables in diameter, which at the highest tides is completely surrounded, but from which at low water the sea recedes to a great distance, leaving dry sands for about 6 miles. Its summit is surmounted by large buildings and an ancient abbey church, of which the steeples are 420 feet above the level of the beach. It bears South nearly 7 miles from Champeaux point, and in appearance strongly resembles Mount St. Michael in Cornwall. Harbour Lights. — On the western side of Mont St. Michel, from the Gabriel watch tower, at 41 feet above high water and 54 feet above the ground, is exhibited a fixed red light visible 6 miles through an arc of 180°. The light is shown only from the time the tide arrives at the foot of the Mont, 2 hours before high water, until H hours ebb. A fixed green light is shown from the eastern point of entrance to the Couesnon river, about 1,100 yards from the Mont. This light is not exhibited unless a vessel is expected. The two lights indicate the direction of the chenal de Couesnon. The Tombelaine is a barren islet almost as large as Mont St. Michel but much lower. It bears N. by E. \ E. 1£ miles from the Mont, and, when seen from the northward or southward, has the appearance of a crushed pyramid inclining to the eastward. A deep sandy bight lies eastward of Mont St. Michel and Tombelaine, from the northern shore of which Tombelaine is distant 1£ miles. The shore from thence continues very low for about 3 miles farther north ward, until near Champeaux point, when it begins to rise. CHAMPEAUX POINT is the eastern point of Mont St. Michel bay ; from it, pointe du Roc, Granville, bears North a little easterly 5£ miles. It is a bluff and almost perpendicular headland, un approachable from seaward on account of the broad flats which dry out a long way from the shore, but very useful as a landmark, especially for vessels navigating between Chausey and Granville, or bound northward by the Cotentin channel.

128 CAPE FREHEL TO GRANVILLE. [Chap. III. Between Champeaux point and Granville the coast curves slightly to the eastward and is generally of moderate height ; but, in some places it is low, sandy and dangerous to approach with westerly winds, being bordered by a sand-bank interspersed with flat rocks, which extend a mile from the shore. As Granville is approached, these dangers become more marked, but, as they especially concern the pilotage of that port, a full description of them is given in the next chapter.

129 CHAPTER IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE, INCLUDING PLATEAU DES MINQUIERS AND ILES CHAUSEY.* VARIATION in 1888. lies Chausey 17° 30' W. 18° 0' W. Cape de la Hague Before proceeding to a description of Granville and the adjacent shore, it will be well to give a detailed account of the vast beds of rocks and islets in the offing, which, in conjunction with the Channel islands to the northward, render the navigation and all approach to the ports on this coast so exceptionally dangerous. PLATEAU des MINQUIERS, situated 9 miles southward of Jersey, and 13 miles from the nearest French land both southward and eastward of it, is a tangled mass of reefs 16 miles long East and West, by 8 miles broad. The most dangerous part occupies a space near the middle, about 7 miles long East and West, by 4 miles broad. The masses of rock at this part lie closer together in ridges and are more elevated, a large number being generally awash at high water ; only a few scattered rocks rise from 10 to 20 feet above that level. These rocky groups are generally connected by extensive banks of shingle, gravel, and sand. There are, however, some narrow tortuous channels through this part of the reef, but from the strength of the tides and absence of good marks, the pilotage is too difficult for any but the fishermen by whom they are frequented. The whole of the sunken part of this reef, eastward, is studded w*ith dangerous rocks, of which some dry 7 feet at low water, but a far greater number are either just awash or have not more than from 3 to 6 feet over them at that time. The sunken part of the western end of the reef has comparatively few dangers, and at that part of the plateau there is some good clear ground for anchorage in 10 or 12 fathoms, so that a vessel set within the edge may anchor and remain until the turn of the stream favours her drifting away from it again. The. north-western rocky mass of the high part is called the Pipette group ; it is remarkable from having several flat-topped pillar-like * See Admiralty Chart : — Channel islands and coast of France. 130 [Chap. IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. rocks, and is a spot most fatal to shipping, more wrecks having taken place here than ajt any other part of the reef. The strength of the flood sets directly on it, and the stream is partially divided by it. Of the rocks which never cover, the most remarkable in order of magnitude are, Maitresse ile, Maisons, Haute Grune, Faucheurs, Figuier, Red Frouquie, Blanc roque, Calfateurs, Rocher du Sud, Grand Vascelin, and Pipette rocks. MINQUIERS LIGHT-VESSEL lies S.S.W. £ W. 1£ miles from the Brisants du Sud, at the south-western extreme of the Minquiers reef, in 21 fathoms water. The vessel is painted black, has two masts with a ball at each mast-head by day, and exhibits two fixed white lights, one 26 and the other 39 feet above the level of the sea ; in fine weather, the lights are visible 9 and 11 miles respectively, but in bad weather they cannot be shown at a greater elevation than to command a range of 8 miles. Fog Sig'nal. — During foggy weather a bell is sounded for one minute at intervals of three minutes. If an approaching vessel sounds her bell continuously, the fog bell of the light-vessel is also sounded continuously. (See note, page 10.) Maitresse ile, near the south-eastern side of the high middle part of the reef before referred to, is the largest islet of the group, although barely a cable long and half a cable wide ; it is also the highest, although only 25 feet above high water. There is a little soil on this islet and some faint traces of vegetation, but it is quite destitute of fuel or subsistance of any kind, nor is there any fresh water except that deposited in the interstices of the rocks by rain. Stone was formerly quarried from the western part of the ile and used in the construction of Fort Regent, St. Helier. In 1869 there were 17 small stone houses or huts on the islet belonging to the natives of La Roque point, Jersey, who, during the summer season, which is 8 months of the year, fish over all parts of the Minquiers reef. In August 1888, the condition of the ile was very similar, the number of houses being then 19, but one was without a roof ; the other 18 houses were all occupied by the Jersey fisher men, except one which had for some months been let to two French men engaged in making Hydrographic observations for their government. From 16 to 18 boats were engaged in the lobster fishery, each boat containing 2 men ; the boats lie on the south eastern side of the islet, where they receive partial shelter from the surrounding rocks. Vast numbers of lobsters are caught and

Chap. IV.] PLATEAU DES MINQUIERS. 131 sent to the London market ; also congers and a variety of other fish, all of which find a ready market at Jersey. The Maisons are three remarkable steep rocks with yellowish heads N.W. by W. £ W. 4£ miles from Maitresse ile ; they are the highest and most conspicuous rocks at the western side of the high central portion of the reef, although not so high as Maitresse ile, being only 15 feet above high water. Haute Grune, South nearly one mile from the Maisons, rises from the centre of a large mass of rock connected with the Faucheur by a reef, of which many of the highest heads are awash at low water, springs. The Haute Grune never covers, being 5 feet above the highest tides ; it therefore serves as a good mark for other dangers in the neighbourhood. The Grunes de Norman, a reef of which the highest head uncovers 14 feet, lies W. by S. h S. 5 cables from the Haute Grune. The Faucheurs is the name given to a large extent of rocks, of which three heads never cover ; they lie W. \ N. 3 miles from Maitresse ile, and S.E. by S. 1£ miles from the Maisons; they are remarkable from their superior size as compared with other rocks in the neighbourhood, and therefore of great service as a mark. The Figuier is a rock always above water N.W. by N. 1£ miles from Maitresse ile. Red Frouquie is a rock of nearly the same size, height, and character as the Figuier, about midway between it and Maitresse ile. Calfateurs are four small rocks, always uncovered, a cable east ward of Maitresse ile, with which they are connected at low water. Rocher du Sud is a large rock, always uncovered, S. by W. £ W. 4 cables from Maitresse ile. Grand Vascelin, N.W. by N. 3 miles from Maitresse ile, uncovers 43 feet. This is a large flat rock with two heads always, above water, very conspicuous from its size, and, from its position, a very useful mark. The Petit Vascelin bears N.E. by N. three quarters of a mile from the Grand Vascelin and lies close to the edge of the reef near deep water, but, being 13 feet lower than the Grand Vascelin, it is covered for a considerable period during spring tides. The Pipette Rocks are a considerable group at the north western extreme of the elevated part of the Minquiers reef. The highest point, like the Grand Vascelin, uncovers 43 feet and is there- I 2

The outer rock of the group is the Grand Haguet ; it covers at high water and bears N.W. nearly half a mile from the high head of Pipette ; N.W. £ W. 5 miles from Maitresse ile ; W. £ N. 2^ miles from the outer part of Petit Vascelin ; and, E. £ S. %\ miles from the Grune du Nord-Ouest. St. Peter's spire, Jersey, over the quarry at Le Fret point leads over the rock. The rocks just described are all within the limits of the middle or higher portion of the reef -, westward of this part, the most remark able are Deree Anglaise, Grune du Nord-Ouest, Brisants du Nord- Ouest, Brisants du Sud, and Deree Franchise. Southward, the danger line is marked by the Four, Souarde, and Sauvages ; see caution page 134. Eastward, numerous sunken rocks extend nearly 6 miles from Maitresse ile. Deree Anglaise is a small cluster of rocks, of which the largest and highest dries 27 feet and lies N.W. by W. £ W. 2 miles from the Maisons, Maitresse ile being on the same line of bearing. There is a 3-fathoms passage between this rock and the Maisons, but it lies very close past Deree, and is only half a mile wide ; a long string of rocks extends from the Maisons westward for \\ miles. Grune du Nord-Ouest, on the extreme northern edge of the plateau des Minquiers, bears W. £ N. 2^ miles from the Grand Haguet, the outer rock of the Pipette group ; and, N.N.W. \ W. 1^ miles from Deree Anglaise. This rock dries 5 feet at low water ; it is steep-to on its northern and eastern sides but has numerous sunken rocks southward and south-westward of it. Brisants du Nord-Ouest form the north-western extreme of the Minquiers reef and are connected with the Grunes du Nord-Ouest by a rocky sunken ledge. The highest head of the Brisants dries 3 feet only and lies with the Faucheur and Haute Grune in line S.E. £ E. At an elevation of 30 feet, Maitresse ile may be seen open northward of the Maisons, the apparent breadth of the latter, S.E. by E. £ E. ; Grune du Nord-Ouest bears E. \ S. \\ miles, the outer parts of the Pipette group and of Petit Vascelin being on the same line of bearing; and, St. Ouen spire, Jersey, on with the white house on the high land of La Moye bears N.N.E. £ E. From this rock, sunken reefs extend westward nearly a mile with from one to 2 fathoms water.

IV.] PLATEAU DES MINQUIERS. 133 Directions. — St. Ouen spire on with La Moye quarries, marked by a white streak on the cliff outside them, bearing N.E. £ N. leads three quarters of a mile westward of all these dangers, and if this line be preserved until the Minquiers light-ship bears S.S.E., a course shaped direct for her clears the Brisants du Sud, the south-western salient of the Minquiers reef, by 1£ miles. Chap. IV.] PLATEAU DES MINQUIERS. 135 Grune Gauvin uncovers 5 feet, and is the centre of a rocky mass of less height, about a quarter of a mile in diameter. It is about a mile within the northern edge of the Minquiers reef, and N. by E. i E. 2 miles from Maitresse ile." From Grune Gauvin, St. Peter's spire appears a little open of point de But and on with the eastern part of the town of St. Aubin beyond it, bearing North. The Caux des Minquiers extend from Le Rat rock in an easterly direction for 4^ miles, their eastern end, named the East Danger, forming the eastern extreme of the Plateau des Minquiers. The whole of this line is so thickly studded with rocks as to render the navigation amongst them perilous, even for boats, at low water ; but, as none of the rocks dry more than 7 feet, there is never less than 11 feet over them at half tide ; from half flood to half ebb, therefore, it is not at all uncommon for vessels of light draught to sail over them. From this rock, Seymour tower appears westward of Mont Orgueil, midway between it and Seymour house, N. \ E. easterly ; and, the-* Maisons and Figuier rocks in line W. \ N. northerly ; the reef extends from Turnabout rock eastward as far as. the East Danger. East Danger, the eastern extreme of the Minquiers reef, has only 3 feet over it, and lies E. \ N. northerly nearly 6 miles from Maitresse ile. From it, the Maisons are touching the northern side of the Figuier rock W. \ N. ; and, Seymour tower appears about midway between the inner part of Mont Orgueil castle and St. Martin's church, North a little westerly. 136 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. [Chap. IV. Directions.— As already stated, St. Ouen spire, Jersey, and La Moye quarry bluff, appearing as a white streak just westward of the white house of La Moye, in line N.E. £ N. lead three quarters of a mile clear of the western extreme of the Minquiers reef ; St. Ouen spire a little open westward of the Corbiere leads 4 miles west ward ; Amas-du-Cap midway between cape Frehel lighthouse and Tertre Morgan mill S. by W. £ W. westerly leads 1^ miles westward of the reef ; and, the Minquiers light-ship bearing S.S.E. clears the south-western extreme by 1£ miles. To clear the eastern end, St. Martin's spire and Seymour tower in line N.|W. leads from half to three quarters of a mile eastward of the bell buoy marking the eastern extreme of the reef. St. Peter's spire and Hermitage rock at St. Helier's in line N.N.W. \ W. is a wider mark, clearing the reef by 1\ miles. Chausey lighthouse on with the beacon on Enseigne islet S. \ E. leads 2 cables eastward of the reef. Coutances cathedral well open north ward of Agon church E. by S. \ S. leads three quarters of a mile northward of all the foul ground in the neighbourhood of the Caux des Minquiers. Eastward of East Danger there are 8 or 9 fathoms, gravelly bottom, and the soundings are tolerably regular. In foggy weather or at night, in rounding the western end of the Minquiers reef from the northward during the flood, a berth of at least 3 or 4 miles should be given it, and should anything less than 16 or 17 fathoms be obtained, haul out to the westward at once. The first part of the flood sets strongly over the reef, and no vessel should risk a near approach to its northern edge until 4 hours flood ; after which, the stream setting along and off the reef is no longer dangerous. During the first or dangerous part of the tide, Pipette rock is always above water, as well as other rocks eastward of it ; and, the sunken rocks westward throw up strong ripples. To round the eastern end of the reef ; if from St. Helier's, Jersey, after clearing the dangers near that port, bring St. Peter's spire a little open westward of the Hermitage N.N.W. \ W. to pass eastward of Icho bank, which lies 2£ miles southward of the coast of Jersey ; when St. Martin's spire comes on with Seymour tower N. \ W. run with that mark on past the bell buoy marking the eastern extreme of the Minquiers, and when Maitresse ile bears W. \ N. either haul up westward to pass between the Minquiers and Western Ardentes, or bear up eastward of the Ardentes. Chap. IV.] PLATEAU DES MINQUIERS. — ARDENTES. 137 Etat rock beacon turret, Chausey, on with Pointe de Champeaux S. by E. £ E., or, if these cannot be seen, a bearing of Chausey will lead eastward. To pass westward of the Ardentes, between them and the Western Ardentes, bring the Enseigne rock beacon turret, Chausey, a little open eastward of the beacon on Grande ile. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the Minquiers at 6 h. 6 m. ; springs rise 35 feet, neaps 26 feet. When navigating in the neighbourhood of the plateau des Minquiers, the state of the tide and the effect of the tidal stream on the vessel's course must be most carefully considered and allowed for. THE ARDENTES, 7h miles E.S.E. from Maitresse ile and 3^ miles northward of the Chausey group, consist of two small banks of sand, shells, and stones, each having also a few rocky heads which dry 6 feet at low water ; their western edge bears E.S.E. 7 miles from Maitresse ile. The banks are half a mile apart, in an E.S.E. and W.N.W. direction, and are steep-to all round. The marks for the southernmost rocky head of the western bank are, Granville light house on with the southern side of the Etat or Petite Canue rock S.E. by S., or, Granville church three times 'its own length open southward of the Canue ; and, the high land of La Tour point, Chausey, wholly open eastward of the Enseigne beacon turret S. \ E. Buoy. — A red buoy is moored off the south-eastern extreme of the eastern bank of the Ardentes.

The Western Ardentes are about three quarters of a mile south-westward of the Ardentes, and the bank is of much the same character as the latter, but no part of it ever uncovers ; it has a general depth of from 15 to 18 feet, except over one rock near its western end on which there are but 5 feet at low water. This spot bears N. £ W. nearly 3^ miles from the Rondes de l'Ouest, the north western rocks of the Chausey group ; and, from it, Mont St. Michel is in sight eastward of La Tour point S. by E. £ E. easterly ; the remarkable trees on Mont Huchon are nearly on with Agon church E. £ N. northerly ; and, Prince's tower appears a little open westward of Grouville mill N. £ W. Nearly midway between the Ardentes and the plateau des Minquiers is another rocky ledge of 3^ fathoms. Between the Ardentes and the Chausey isles there is a good clear channel with from 7 to 9 fathoms, but great care is required in its navigation, owing to the strength of the tidal streams. Anchorage is good near the middle of the channel ; but, to prevent danger in case of driving during the strength of the stream, care must be taken to anchor clear of the line of tide of any of the dangers. THE CHAUSEY ISLES, lying between the Plateau des Min quiers and Granville, form an extensive group of little islets and rocks 6£ miles long in an E.S.E. direction from the Rondes de l'Ouest to the Founet, the easternmost rock, about 3 miles wide, and occupying a space of nearly 16 square miles. Grande lie, Chausey, on the southern side of the group, is the principal and largest islet ; from the lighthouse on La Tour point, the south-eastern point of the ile, Grouin point bears S.S.W. 9^ miles ; Granville lighthouse S.E. by E. 8^ miles ; La Roque point, Jersey, N. W. 19 miles ; and, Maitresse ile, Minquiers, N.W. \ N. 11 miles. It is about a mile long N.N.W. and S.S.E., one third of a mile wide, deeply indented by small bays, of which the projecting points are topped by hills, and near its centre, which is rather high, is some cultivated land.* On the southern part of the islet are the lighthouse, a chapel, and a fort ; in the central part, the ruins of an old fort, a farm-house, several cottages in which about 200 stone-cutters reside, and two or three small blacksmiths' shops ; and, on the eastern summit of Gros- Mont, at the northern end, is a Semaphore. The lighthouse and Semaphore stand high, and are prominent objects from seaward in * See Admiralty plan of Chausey isles, No. 63 ; scale, m == 5 inches.

Grande lie has several granite quarries, of which a large quantity is sent to France. Longue lie, 6 cables eastward of the lighthouse, is very useful as a mark in rounding the south-western part of the group. On ile de la Meule, N.W. H miles from the lighthouse, are the ruins of a convent and a well of good water. The western part of the group contains 15 or 16 islets and numerous rocks. The Chausey group, although dangerous and intricate to navigate, is steep-to on the northern and western sides, but the southern side should be approached with caution especially at low water, when the eastern side is quite inaccessible to vessels of deep draught, on account of the sand-banks which almost close the channel between it and Granville. The anchorage generally resorted to by vessels of war is Port Marie road, off the southern side of Grande lie. There are several harbours among the rocks completely sheltered from all winds, of which Chausey Sound, between Grande lie and the Puceau rock to the eastward, is most used ; it is, however, very narrow, difficult of access, and only frequented by fishermen, stone boats, and other small craft capable of taking the ground. LIGHT. — A square lighthouse, 56 feet high, stands on the summit of the hill which crowns La Tour point, the south-eastern extreme of Grande lie ; it exhibits -a fixed white light, varied every four minutes by a red flash, which is preceded and followed by a short eclipse ; the eclipses are not total in ordinary weather within a distance of 6 miles. The light is of the third order, 121 feet above high water, and visible in clear weather 16 miles ; the lighthouse on with the Corbiere rock S.E. by E. £ E. has hitherto been considered to show the precise limits of the south-eastern part of the Minquiers ledge, but this line leads northward of the rock discovered south ward of the Souarde in July 1886. See page 134. The Corbiere is a high and remarkable rock at the south-western edge of the Chausey group N.W. by W. £ W. 1-^ miles from the lighthouse and about half a mile south-westward of Meule islet. Commencing with the Bane de la Corbiere in the West, and proceeding in order by the southern, eastern, and northern coasts, a description of the principal dangers which fringe the plateau of the Chausey isles will now be given.

[Chap. iv. 140 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. Bane de la Corbiere, off the western end of the Chausey isles and composed of sand and shells, extendsJL^ miles in a S. by E. and N. by W. direction with an outward curve, and is about 2 cables wide at its broadest part. Its general depths are from 3^ to 4^ fathoms, the shoalest water being near the middle of the bank. From the southern end in 4 fathoms, the Corbiere rock bears E. \ N. 8 cables ; and, from the shoalest part of 3^ fathoms, the lighthouse is on with the Corbiere S.E. by E. £ E. Between this bank and the isles, the depths are from 5 to 9 fathoms, the deepest water being near the isles. The Cancalaise is the highest head of a small rocky ridge a quarter of a mile from the southernmost rocks of the Chausey group and in the space between are several rocky patches with from 1 to 7 feet only. The ridge is a cable long East and West, and the highest head, at the eastern end, uncovers 12 feet at the lowest tides, at which time a rock is awash at the western end. The northern end of the eastern ile des Huguenans touching La Tour point E. £ S., is the mark for the highest head. To clear the Cancalaise when rounding the south-western end of Chausey, keep the Rondes de l'Ouest in sight westward of the Corbiere until the southern house on Longue ile comes well open southward of La Tour point. Basse du Cancalaise, a rocky patch about a cable in diameter, is \\ cables E. by S. of the Cancalaise ; the highest head, on its western side, uncovers 6 feet, and another head, on the northern side, uncovers 5 feet. Between the Basse du Cancalaise and the Chausey isles there are rocky heads which uncover from 4 to 8 feet. Basse du Chateau, of which the shoalest spot bears S.W. 4^ cables from Chausey lighthouse, is about \\ cables long N. by E. and S. by W. and one cable wide ; it has 14 feet water at its northern end, 20 feet near the middle, and 27 feet at its southern end ; from which, the highest and northernmost head of the Epiettes touching La Tour point bears N.E. northerly. The Huguenan beacon turret on with the highest head of the Pilliers E. \ N. leads 2 cables southward. Roches de Bratagne, about a cable southward of Bretagne point, form a ridge 1^ cables long N.N.W. and S.S.E. and one cable wide. The northern head of the ridge uncovers 16 feet, the middle head 14 feet, and the south-western head 12 feet at low water,

The mark for -the southernmost head of 11^ feet is, the beacon on the Epiettes nearly a sail's breadth open southward of La Tour point. The Tour Patches are three small rocky heads about 2 cables southward of La Tour point. The two westernmost patches have only 6 feet water, bear N. by E. \ E. and S. by W. \ W. from each other, and are about 50 yards apart. The eastern head has 11 feet water, and bears E. by S. \ S. half a cable from the south western patch. Basse des Epiettes.— This small patch, half a cable long N.N.W. and S.S.E., has two small rocky heads with only 3 feet water. The Enseigne beacon turret on with the eastern slope of Grande lie N. \ W. leads between the Basse des Epiettes and the Tour patches, but directly towards the Tonneau rock, which dries 12 feet about a cable south-eastward of La Tour point. Basse de l'lle Longue is a rocky head with only 3 feet water S. £ W. nearly 4 cables from Longue ile ; and, S.E. 8 cables from the lighthouse on La Tour point. From it, the Conchee rock touching the southern end of the eastern ile des Huguenans bears East ; and, the northern and southern heads of the Epiettes in line bear N.W. by N. Fis-Cous and Basses du FiS-C0US.— Midway between Longue ile and the Huguenans are the Fis-Cous and Basses du Fis-Cous, two rocky patches which may be dangerous to a vessel working along the southern side of the Chausey group. The Fis-Cous is about 50 yards in extent, uncovers 9 feet, and is marked by a beacon. It bears S.E. by E. 6^ cables from the southern end of Longue ile ; W. \ N. 7 cables from the Chapelle rock ; and, S.W. £ W. 3 cables from the Grand Cheval rock. A small rock. awash at low water, lies a cable eastward of the Fis-Cous. The Basses du Fis-Cous, about a cable in extent, lie one cable westward from the Fis-Cous. One head of this danger is awash at the lowest tides, and others have only from one to 4 feet over them. Gros-Mont semaphore on with Tourette rock (the leading mark for the south-eastern channel into Chausey Sound) N.W. W. leads very close south-westward of the Basses du Fis-Cous. A lies des Huguenans are small islets on the southern edge of the Chausey group 2 miles eastward of the lighthouse, and, with a few

142 [Chap. IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. rocks which join them at low water, form a small rocky cluster 4 cables long E.N.E. and W.S.W. On the summit of the largest and most eastern islet, is a stone beacon turret, which, when in line with a similar turret on the Etat rock N. by E. \ E. easterly, shows the western limit of the fishing grounds. The summit of the largest islet is covered with grass, and sheep from Granville often graze there. The Conchae. — This rock is half a mile eastward of the iles des Huguenans, on the eastern side of the Conchee passage ; its summit is about 20 feet above the highest tides. The Basse de la Conchee uncovers 7 feet about 3 cables E. £ S. from the Conchee. Haute Foraine, E. \ N. a long mile from the Conchee, is the easternmost high rock connected with the Chausey group and is marked by a beacon. Its advanced easterly position renders it very conspicuous, and Granville pilots use it in estimating the height of the tide. It uncovers 28^ feet at the lowest tides, and when it covers there are from 15 to 16 feet water at the entrance cf Granville harbour. A sand-bank of some extent, with 9 feet water, lies 3 cables north-eastward of the Haute Foraine. The Tomin is a small and dangerous rock which uncovers 18 feet a quarter of a mile south-westward of the Haute Foraine and a little northward of the line of the lighthouse on with the northern point of the largest of the Huguenans. The j Pignon, an isolated dangerous rock N.E. \ N. rather more than half a mile from the summit of the Haute Foraine, uncovers 10 feet at the lowest tides and does not show at ordinary neaps. A floating beacon is moored on this rock. A cable south-eastward of it there is a flat with only 2 feet water. The Founet, the easternmost rock of the Chausey group, uncovers 7 feet ; the marks for it are, the Canue and Etat rocks nearly in line N.W. \ N. ; Coutances cathedral its own breadth open eastward of Mont Martin mill E.N.E. ■ and, the top of Conchee rock perceptibly open southward of the little hillcock which crowns the southern point of the largest of the Huguenans bearing W. \ S. Buoy.— The Founet is marked on its south-eastern side by a red bell buoy.

Chap. IV.] 143 CHAUSEY ISLES. Basse du Founet, an isolated rocky patch with 3| feet only, bears N.N.E. \ E. 1£ cables from the Founet ; between it and the Pignon are patches of from 10 to 14 feet. Clearing Marks. — The summit of the Conchee rock on with the lighthouse on La Tour point W. by N. \ N., or on with the stone beacon turret on the largest of the Huguenans, leads southward of the Founet, Haute Foraine, and Tomin rocks ; and, the Etat rock twice its apparent breadth open northward of the summit of the Canue leads northward of the Basse du Founet. Even at low water, springs, Chausey pilots take vessels between the Founet and Pignon rocks, but strangers should use this passage only at low water, neaps, or at 2 hours' flood at springs, and then only when the Haute Foraine is uncovered or its beacon plainly visible. The Canue, or Grande Canue rock, never wholly covers ; it lies E. by N. \ N. northerly 3^ miles from Chausey lighthouse, and its summit is 6 feet above the level of the highest tides. South eastward of the Canue, a reef named the Canuettes, many of whose heads dry from 7 to 21 feet, extends 7 cables in the direction of the Founet. The Etat, or Petite Canue, is aremarkable rock on the northern edge of the Chausey group ; on its summit is a stone beacon turret, similar to that on the largest Huguenan, which bears from it S. by W. \ W. westerly ; it is painted with black and white horizontal bands. These turrets in line show the western limit of the fishing .grounds, and are also of great use as marks to lead between the Marie ledge and Catheue banks northward of Chausey isles. From the Etat rock, the Dechiree ledge, at the north-western extreme of the Chausey group, bears W. by N. \ N. 3^ miles. The northern edge of the plateau, which is here steep-to, is indicated by several rocks which seldom or never cover, of which the Selliere, 1^ miles westward of the Etat, is a useful mark ; and, by many more which uncover as the tide falls, of which the principal are, the Petite Entree, which uncovers 36 feet and is marked by a beacon; the Grande Entree, which uncovers 38 feet ; the Pointue, which uncovers 41 feet ; and the Dechiree ledge of which the highest part uncovers 33 feet. L'Enseigne, a small islet about 8 feet above the level of the highest tides, is one mile nearly within the northern edge of the

144 [Chap. iv. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. plateau, and 2 miles northward of La Tour point ; it is remarkable from the uniform convexity of its surface, and has a small white stone beacon turret on its summit. Rondes de la Dechirde, a rocky ridge at the north-western side of the Chausey group, is 3 cables long in a N.E and S.W. direc tion ; the northernmost head uncovers 39 feet, and the highest head, near the middle of the ridge, uncovers 45 feet, and therefore only covers at the highest equinoctial spring tides. There are several other low heads on the ridge ; that at its southern extreme, uncovers only 4 feet, with the north-western point of the Pointue rock touching the south-eastern extreme of the Dechiree E. by N. £ N. ; and, the light house on with the Chapeau rock S.S.E. \ E. easterly. Basse du Chenal. — This small rocky patch, between the Rondes de la Dechiree and the Rondes de l'Ouest, is exactly in the fairway of the entrance to the Rondes anchorage, is about three quarters of a cable from the northern extreme of the Rondes de l'Ouest, and has only 5 feet water. The marks for it are, the Pointue rock just open southward of the Dechiree E. by N . \ N. ; and, the lighthouse a little open south-westward of Gros-Mont semaphore S.E. by S. Rondes de l'Ouest is a rocky ridge, 6 cables long N.N.E. and S.S.W. and 2 cables wide, forming the western extreme of the Chausey group. Several of its heads never cover and serve as good marks for the south-western limits of the group. SOUND de CHAUSEY, so called from the secure anchorage it affords to vessels of light draught, trends N.W. by N. and S.E. by S. along the eastern side of the Grande lie, and occupies a space 6 cables long between La Tour point and Gros-Mont semaphore. At low water, springs, it is surrounded by rocks and banks of sand and mud, which form a natural harbour where vessels capable of taking the ground find capital shelter ; if remaining longer than one tide, or at springs, they should, however, moor head and stern to prevent tailing on the banks. The Sound is sheltered on all sides except from S.S.E. to E.S.E., and strong winds from that quarter throw in a heavy sea at high water. Fresh winds from N.N.E. to N.W. are also much felt, causing a heavy swell throughout the whole extent of the Sound from one hour before until two hours after high water. Although the deepest parts of the Sound do not dry, there remains but little water in them, and the soundings are very irregular. There are, however, two narrow gullies with space for three or four

Chap. IV.] CHAUSEY SOUND. — DIRECTIONS. 145 short vessels of from 10 to 11 feet draught to remain afloat. The largest, at the entrance of the Sound, is 325 yards long and from 55 to 65 yards broad, with depths of from 10 to 17 feet, but it is occupied by three mooring buoys for the use of the guard-vessel protecting the fisheries. The second is only 173 yards long, with from 8 to 15 feet, and is a little northward of the former, in front of the farm-house and chapel, and abreast of the Crabiere rock which uncovers 24 feet ; this anchorage also is usually occupied by one of the fishery cruisers secured with a mooring chain on each quarter and each bow. The best place for grounding is on the lowest part of the beach between the Crabiere and Tourette rocks, where the bottom is soft mud, but there are many scattered heads of rock beneath the mud, rendering the surface uneven and liable to damage vessels of any size ; those up to 60 or 65 feet in length may, however, beach here in safety. DIRECTIONS. — Two entrances lead to Chausey Sound, one from the southward between La Tour point and Longue ile, the other from the northward between the Enseigne and Etardiere. The first is the simplest and best ; it is divided into two channels by the Epiettes, and neither are practicable at low wTater. The South Channel, between La Tour point and the Epiettes, is accessible to vessels drawing 10 feet as soon as the Tonneau rock is covered, and there are 12 feet in mid-channel at 2 hours flood. In taking this channel, bring the Enseigne white beacon turret just in sight eastward of the eastern slope of Grande lie N. £ W., which leads between the Epiettes and La Tour patches. The beacon on the south-western rock of the Epiettes may then be steered for and approached to within half a cable ; then steer north ward in mid-channel parallel with the shore of the isle, and, if intending to run northward of the Crabiere, pass between it and the beacon half a cable eastward of it, giving the Crabiere a berth of at least 30 or 40 yards to clear the tail which runs out from it in that direction. The South-East Channel is eastward of the Basse des Epiettes ; the leading mark is, Gros-Mont semaphore on with the Tourette rock, a short steep point on the beach a cable north-eastward of the farm-house, N.W. \ W. When passing Longue ile, to clear the ledge off its southern end, open the semaphore a little westward of the Tourette, taking care to bring them quickly on again, after passing it ; A 2771. The mud bank referred to completely bars the channel, and can only be crossed by vessels above 10 feet draught after 2^ hours flood. When the highest head of the Loup covers there are 16 feet water on this bank. The North Entrance into Sound de Chausey is northward of the Enseigne, between the rocks extending 2 cables eastward of Pointue rock and the Grande Entree ; this latter is a small group of rocks, of which the highest head uncovers 38 feet, 3j cables eastward of the low rocks extending from the Pointue. The highest head of the Pointue uncovers 41 feet. The inner portion of this channel, southward of the Etardiere, is completely barred at low water by vast sand-banks uncovering generally only a few feet, but between the Sauniere and Vieux they dry as much as 15 feet in places. The greater part of the rocks being marked by beacons, strict atten tion to the following directions render it safe of access between half flood and half ebb to vessels up to 10 feet draught ; no stranger, however, should attempt so intricate and contracted a channel without a pilot. The channel from the entrance continues in a southerly direction between the western edge of a rocky group named the Longues, on the western edge of which is a beacon, and the Basse de l'Etardiere, a flat rock at 2 cables distance which uncovers 8 feet a cable eastward of the Etardiere, to which rock it is joined at low water, springs, by a sand-bank. From thence, the channel takes a W.S.W. direction between the Etardiere rock, which never covers, and the Enseigne ; and then, a southerly direction, leaving on the port hand the low rocks extending from the Petite Enseigne, the Sauniere a small islet 57 feet above the lowest tides, and the Petite Fourche ; and, on the starboard hand, the Massue and a rocky group eastward of the Vieux, and from thence to the Sound. The Massue has a beacon off its north-eastern extreme and a whitewashed rock at its south-eastern ; a rock with a beacon lies off the northern end of the Petite Fourche nearly in the fairway, and a vessel may pass it on either side. In entering by the North channel, the leading mark is, the light-
