IV.] CHAUSEY. — ENSEIGNE ANCHORAGE. — PORT MARIE. 147 house on with the Enseigne beacon turret S. \ E.; keep the lighthouse, however, twice its breadth open eastward of the beacon turret whilst passing eastward of the low rocks extending from the Pointue, and twice its breadth open westward whilst passing the Longues rocks. In passing the Basse de l'Etardiere, when the two white patches on the Massue and the Chapeau rocks are in line, or when the southern end of Meule islet is just touching the northern end of the Massue S.W. \ W., run in that direction until the lighthouse is on with the south-western point of Sauniere islet S. by E. E. ; this leads up to the Sauniere ; give it a berth of haif a cable in passing, and also leave the beacon off its southern end close on the port hand, and, after passing it, steer in mid-channel between the beacons marking the rocks on either side of the channel abreast of the Gros-Mont. Enseigne Anchorage is a small space where vessels of 10 feet draught, under the guidance of good pilots, may find shelter from S.W., South, or S.E. winds. With northerly winds, no vessel should anchor there except to await water through the North channel into Chausey Sound, as from its limited extent there is neither room to veer nor drive without tailing on the sand-bank, which, at low water, dries 1^ cables northward of the Enseigne. Run for this anchorage through the North entrance with the same mark as if bound for Chausey Sound until the vessel is well south ward of the Pointue ; then bring the lighthouse on with the south western slope of the Enseigne, and when the southern end of Meule islet touches the northern end of the Massue rock, anchor, and the vessel will be in the best anchorage and deepest water, 22 to 36 feet, sandy bottom, midway between the Basse de l'Etardiere and the Longues. Great care must be taken to estimate the height of the tide between half ebb and half flood, as the soundings, when south ward of the Pointue rocks, vary from 7 feet only to 22 feet at low water, and also to avoid a small rock with only 4 feet, nearly in the fairway of the entrance. PORT MARIE is the little bay between La Tour and Bretagne points, in front of which, 2 cables off-shore, is a small space capable of affording shelter from winds between N.W. and N.E. to two or three vessels of 10 feet draught, ANCHORAGES. — The inner anchorage off Port Marie, between the Bretagne rocks and Tour patches, is not more than 3 cables in extent. Approaching from the South-west, bring the Etat reck beacon K 2

148 [Chap IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. turret on with La Tour point N.E. by E. ; or, the northernmost and highest head of the Epiettes quite shut in by La Tour point leads over the Chateau patch, south-eastward of the Bretagne rocks, and north-westward of the Tour patches ; and, when Huguenans beacon turret is on with the Grand Cheval rock E. \ S., anchor in about 24 feet, sandy bottom. From the South-east, the westernmost point of Grand lie, forming port Homard, touching Bretagne point N.N.W. \ W., leads outside the Tour patches and north-eastward of the Chateau patch and Bretagne rocks ; when the northernmost head of the Epiettes is shut in with La Tour point, anchor. Port Marie Outer Road is a good anchorage for large vessels of war, and is, in fact, the principal roadstead of Granville, the greater part of the shipping bound for that port remaining here until the water on the banks is sufficiently high to proceed. The best position for a vessel of deep draught in this road is, with the lighthouse bearing N. by W. | W. distant from half a mile to a mile, in from 7 to 11 fathoms. When at anchor, Coutances cathedral should be open northward of the largest of the lies des Huguenans E. by N. £ N., and the Enseigne white beacon turret should be open eastward of La Tour point. Here she will be sheltered from the wind, if northward of N.W. by N. Should it be inclined to draw more westerly, with an appearance of bad weather, the first oppor tunity should be taken to weigh and get to windward with the ebb, or to run for shelter either to Cancale road, see page 124, or to the eastward or northwrard of the Chausey group, according to the direction of the wind. Conchee Anchorage. — With the wind from N.W. by W. to N.N.E. the Conchee anchorage in 4i or 5 fathoms is to be preferred ; the marks for it are, the old castle in ruins on Grande lie on with the Huguenans beacon turret W. by N. \ N., and the Selliere and Culas siere rocks in line N.W. by N. The Etat Anchorage.— With the wind southward of West, the anchorage under the Etat rock should be resorted to. Anchor in from 5 to 7 fathoms, half or three quarters of a mile from the rocks, with Chausey lighthouse on with the Canue, or on with the Etat beacon turret, according to the direction of the wind. Indeed, all the northern shore of the Chausey group affords shelter against southerly or south-westerly winds, and, being bold, may be approached without fear.

Chap, iv.] CHAUSEY ISLES. — ANCHORAGES. 149 Rondes de l'Ouest Anchorage, on the western side of the Chausey group under the Rondes de l'Ouest ridge, is the only shelter the group affords to large vessels during easterly winds. It can be reached at any time of tide either from Port Marie road or from the Conchee or Etat anchorages. When proceeding towards it from Port Marie road, keep Huguenans beacon turret on with the highest rock of the Piliers E. £ N. northerly, to pass southward of the Chateau patch ; and, when Gros-Mont semaphore bears N.E. \ N. haul gradually in, but not farther than to have the middle of Longue lie on with La Tour point, East, to avoid the Cancalaise. When the Ronde de l'Ouest, a large and remarkable round rock, is in sight westward of the Corbiere N. by W., haul in to within a quarter of a mile of the rocks, passing between Corbiere bank and the Chausey group, and anchor in from 7 to 9 fathoms, sandy bottom, half a mile westward of the Rondes de l'Ouest and the same distance north-eastward of the Corbiere bank, with the lighthouse midway between Gros-Mont and the western extreme of Grand lie, or touching the southern end of Meule islet, S.E. E. ; and, the Etat beacon turret about midway between the Enseigne beacon turret and the Grande Entree rock E. \ S. Anchorage between the Rondes de L'Ouest and the Dechiree. — This anchorage is similar to that of the Enseigne, and affords partial shelter with the wind from South round by East to N.E. It is about 3 cables long and 2 cables wide, and has from 3^ to 65 fathoms, sandy bottom. The entrance is 1\ cables wide E.N.E. and W.S.W. between the Basse du Chenal, a small rock with only 5 feet at the lowest tides, and a rock forming the south-western extreme of the Rondes de la Dechiree, which uncovers 4 feet. The leading mark in, is, the lighthouse on with Gros-Mont semaphore S.S.E. £ E. easterly, and when the Pointue rock appears midway between the Dechiree and Grande Entree rocks the vessel is in the middle of the anchorage. There is another anchorage called the Dechiree, eastward of that just described ; it is entirely surrounded by high rocks, which do not cover until the last quarter flood, forming between half ebb and half flood a natural harbour accessible at all tides, but no vessel should use it in changeable, boisterous weather, or without a good local pilot ; it is not more than 5 cables long and 2^ cables wide, the broadest part being between the Dechiree and a rock to the southward which uncovers 24 feet. To enter this anchorage, proceed as before with the lighthouse on

[Chap. IV. 150 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. with the semaphore S.S.E. £ E. ; and, when the Pointue is half its apparent breadth open southward of the Dechiree E. by N. \ N. the vessel is southward of the Rondes de la Dechiree and should haul to the eastward, taking care to avoid two rocky patches awash at low water, springs, on the southern side of the anchorage. When the lighthouse is on with Massue rock S.S.E., anchor in from 4 to 5 J fathoms water, with rather coarse ground. With the aid of a good pilot, the Enseigne anchorage and the northern channel into Chausey Sound are often entered by this route within 2 hours before or after high water. Beauchamp Anchorage is a quarter of a mile north-westward of the Huguenans, and, with a good pilot, in case of need might afford shelter, at springs, to one or two vessels of deep draught. It consists of a kind of basin or deep about 4 cables long N.N.E. and S.S.W. and 1^ cables wide ; it has from 5 to 6 fathoms at low water, springs, with excellent holding ground, between the lines of the lighthouse on with the southern extreme of the Ango rock, and of Gros-Mont semaphore on with the northern hillock of Grande Ancre or Saddle island. It is sheltered at low water, springs, by the rocks and surrounding sand and mud-banks, it is also tolerably well protected throughout the tide at neaps, but at high water, springs, fresh winds from N.W. to N.E. cause a heavy tumbling sea, which, however, soon subsides as the tide falls. Vessels usually moor N.N.E. and S.S.W., but, if intending to remain, they should be secured with anchors on each bow and quarter. Two sets of moorings with mooring buoys for the use of the small French steam-vessels employed in protecting the oyster fishery occupy the central part of the anchorage. Southern Entrances. — A vessel of considerable draught with a fair wind and an experienced pilot, may enter the Beauchamp anchorage from the southward at all times by passing betw*een the Grand Piliers and Tournioure rocks ; the latter has on it a beacon, which, however, is sometimes washed away and should not be depended on ; or, between the Tournioure and Chapelle rocks ; but these narrow passages cannot be used at all times without steam or a sufficiently commanding breeze to stem the tidal streams. The leading mark to pass between the Tournioure and Piliers is, the summit of Roche Noire on with the Culassiere rock N.N.E. Great care is required in passing the Tournioure at half flood, the stream immediately outside it setting strongly to the eastward,

Chap. IV.] CHAUSEY ISLES.— ANCHORAGES.— CHANNELS. 151 whilst between it and the Piliers it takes the direction of the channel. Having passed the Tournioure beacon, steer north-eastward towards the Petit Huguenan to get into the fairway, and then more northerly to pass midway between that islet and Roche Noire, after which the summit of the rock Caniard du Sud open westward of the Culassiere N. by E. E. leads to the anchorage. The entrance eastward of the Tournioure is the deepest but is Only 50 or 60 yards wide between the Tournioure and Chapelle rocks and should never be attempted during the strength of the tide ; the best time is within an hour of high water, and the nearer high water the better. A vessel having passed midway between the Tournioure and Chapelle rocks and also between Roche Noire and Petit Huguenan may proceed to Beauchamp anchorage as before directed. Passe de la Conchae, with a sufficient rise of tide, is the safest entrance to Beauchamp anchorage from the south ward for vessels of light draught ; it lies between the iles des Huguenans and Conchee rocks, and from thence north-westward between two mud-banks, which dry from 3 to 7 feet. The entrance is between the Gaillard d'Avant rock which uncovers 29 feet and has just northward of it the Artimon rock which uncovers 19 feet, and some small heads close south-westward of the Conchee which uncover from 9 to 17 feet. The leading mark is, the Selliere and Petite Mauvaise rocks in line N.N.W. until the lighthouse comes on with the middle of the Ango rock ; then haul to the westward for the anchorage and cross the mud-bank extending northward from the Huguenans. When the small heads close south-westward of the Conchee are covered and the Artimon rock is awash, there are not less than 13 feet on any part of the mud-bank which must be crossed in running for the anchorage. Passe Orientale de l'Etat.— The Beauchamp anchorage may also be reached from the north-eastward through this passage, which is a clear space through the rocks in the north-eastern part of the Chausey group ; the tide, however, must be sufficiently high for a vessel to cross the sand-bank, which extends over the greater part of the passage and dries from 2 to 5 feet above the level of the lowest tides. The entrance to this passage, 1| cables wide, is between the Pouillou rock which uncovers 32 feet, and some small rocky heads connected with the Petit Etat which uncover from 5 to 10 feet.

152 [Chap. IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. From thence the passage is bounded on the western side by the Caniard du Sud which uncovers 38 feet, and by the Mauvaise which is always above water ; and, on the eastern side, by the Plate du Hibou, a small rocky group of which the highest head uncovers 26^ feet, and by the Culassiere rock which is never covered. The leading mark is, Petite Ancre islet on with the Mauvaise S.W. £ W. until within about 1^ cables of the latter, then steer southward to pass between it and the Culassiere, and from thence to the anchorage. There are several other entrances to the Beauchamp anchorage on the northern and western sides of the group, of which two admit vessels up to 10 feet draught at low water, but all are so intricate as to be of use only to fishermen and coasters thoroughly acquainted with the localities. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the Chausey group, at 6 h. 9 m. ; equinoctial springs rise 46 feet, ordinary springs 35 feet, and neaps 26 feet ; neap range 17 feet. The stream turns at the eastern end of the group, between Founet and Pignon rocks, from 25 to 30 minutes earlier than in the middle of the passage between the Founet and the Roc de Granville ; that is to say, the flood begins to be felt about 4^ hours before the time of high water at Granville, and the ebb one hour after. Admiralty Bank. — This narrow ridge of sand lying between the Chausey isles and the mainland is not more than 2 cables wide, and extends 1^ miles N.E. by N. and S.W. by S. with only 7 feet water on the shoalest part close to its northern end ; from it, Granville lighthouse bears S.S.E. 4^ miles ; Coutances cathedral midway between the church and mill of Mont Martin N.E. by E. h E. ; the Conchee rock on with the easternmost of the ile des Huguenans W. \ N. ; and, the Etat beacon turret just northward of the Canue rock N.W. Coutances cathedral on with Mont Martin church N.E. by E. \ E. leads eastward of this bank ; the Etat twice its own breadth open northward of the Canue N.W. \ W., or Mont St. Michel twice its own breadth open westward of Champeaux point S. \ E. leads north eastward. DANGERS off GRANVILLE— The navigation between Granville and the Chausey isles at low water, springs, is rendered both difficult and dangerous for vessels drawing more than 7 or 8 feet by the numerous banks and knolls of sand, which form a

Chap. IV.] 153 DANGERS OFF GRANVILLE. bar having only from 14 to 17 feet water on the deepest parts, and with several patches of from 2 to 6 feet ; small coasters, however, by following the directions given for this passage, may pass between these banks and the Admiralty bank in not less than 10 feet at low water. Tombelaine bank.— The flats extending from 1£ miles W. by N. of pointe du Roc to Champeaux point, on which there are from one to 6 feet water, extend 3^ miles from the shore westward of St. Pair ; they then gradually narrow until nearly abreast of Champeaux point, where the bank again projects seaward in a long narrow spit having 9 feet at its outer end, which bears N.W. 4£ miles from Champeaux point. The highest of these flats are, the Tombe laine bank, awash at low water, springs, and another little ridge of sand which uncovers one foot. The northern part of this latter lies S.W. about 2^ miles, and the highest part of the Tombelaine S.W. £ W. 1£ miles from Granville pier-head light. Basse Dorriere is a small isolated rock, rising from a sandy bottom, with only 4 feet water ; it is a cable N.N.E. from the northern end of the Tombelaine bank, with Granville lighthouse bearing E.N.E. northerly one mile ; and, the pier-head light E. N. 1-ro miles. The Haguet bank is composed of a number of shoal heads with from 2 to 6 feet on them and from 9 to 15 feet between. It extends 2£ miles in a N. by W. and S. by E. direction, and the northern head with 6 feet bears N.W. N. 3£ miles from Granville lighthouse. Between this head and the southern end of the Admiralty bank there is a passage about a quarter of a mile wide with 11 feet water. Chausey lighthouse touching Chapelle rock W. by N. h N. is the leading mark through. The southern end is nearly joined to the Tombelaine bank by a narrow ridge of sand which almost dries at low water, springs, thus forming at that time the shallow bar between Granville and the Chausey isles before mentioned. Bane de Rondehaie, a small patch of sand, gravel, and rock, with 10 feet water, bears W. by S. S. 4^ miles from Granville lighthouse. The spire of Granville church open northward of the lighthouse leads nearly a mile northward of the bank ; the Culassiere rock, Chausey, on with the Huguenans beacon turret N. \ E. leads west ward ; and, Culassiere rock midway between the Huguenans and the Conchee N. \ W. westerly leads eastward.

154 [Chap. IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. There is a small knoll with 23 feet water N.N.W. about 3 cables from the Rondehaie. The Videcoq, a small rock which uncovers 2^ feet, has from 18 to 20 feet, sandy bottom, on all sides. It is westward of the Haguet bank, with Granville lighthouse bearing E. by S. southerly 3£ miles ; Chausey lighthouse N.W. N. 5^- miles ; Granville church is on with the second southernmost chimney of the south-western barrack ; and, the Culassiere rock is nearly on with the Conchee N. by W. \ W. westerly. Granville church on with the northernmost chimney of the south western barrack leads half a mile northward of the Videcoq rock ; the same church on with the southern chimney leads a quarter of a mile southward ; the Mauvaise rock on with the Conchee leads half a mile eastward ; and, the Mauvaise on with the Huguenans leads westward. Buoy. — The Videcoq is marked on its eastern side by a bell buoy painted with red and black bands. A small sand-bank about 8 cables long N.W. and S.E. and a quarter of a mile wide, with only 6 feet water, lies half a mile northward of the Videcoq. The Mauvaise rock midway between the Huguenans and Conchee N. by W. £ W., leads westward of it ; and, the three mills of Breville a little open northward of the foot of Menars point leads northward. Basse Parisienne is a small rocky ridge, steep-to, with 13 feet water over it and 6 or 7 fathoms on all sides ; from it, Granville light house bears E. \ N. 5h miles ; Chausey lighthouse N. by W. \ W. 5 \ miles ; and, Pierre de Herpin lighthouse S.W. £ W. nearly 5 miles. The marks for it are, Haut-Bout mill, on the highland of Grouin point, well open westward of the Herpin rock S.W. £ W. westerly ; and, Granville lighthouse between the steeple of Granville church and the barracks E. \ N. These barracks are high, and, standing on the top of the precipice of Roc de Granville north-westward of the steeple, are very conspicuous. The Petits Banes are six or seven small sandy ridges, with from 6 to 9 fathoms on them, S.S.W. 3i miles from Chausey light house ; they occupy a space \\ miles long N.W. and S.E. and half a mile wide. They are not dangerous, but when it blows hard they should be avoided by small vessels as they cause a heavy sea.

Chap. IV.] GRANVILLE AND OFF-LYING SHOALS. 155 GRANVILLE. — The port of Granville is between pointe du Roc and Gautier point, which latter bears S.E. by E. | E. 9 cables from the south-western extreme of Roc point. Gautier point is high, and on its summit is a fort which commands the entrance to Granville harbour. The town of Granville is built in the form of an amphitheatre at the foot of the eastern part of the high, narrow, steep peninsula of Le Roc, which is nearly a mile long W. \ S. and E. \ N., 300 yards wide, and united with the mainland by a narrow isthmus half a mile northward of Gautier point. The upper town is sur rounded by walls and occupies the eastern part of the peninsula ; the lower town stands on the isthmus at the entrance of a narrow valley enclosed between high hills, and watered by the little river Bosc which separates the suburbs from the lower town, its waters when swollen by rains running over the sands westward. The outer harbour is on the western side of the lower town at the foot of Le Roc, which, with the adjacent land, shelters it from winds from N.W. round by North and East to S.S.E., and the pier protects it from the heavy sea caused by south-westerly winds, but it is open from South to S.S.E. The water is smooth in the harbour when it blows hard from North to N.W., but vessels should then be well moored to resist the violent squalls which rush down from Le Roc. The pier is built on the rocks which uncover at the foot of the south western part of Le Roc. It begins at 65 yards westward of the last houses in the lower town, and from thence extends in a southerly direction about 390 yards ; it then turns eastward for about 210 yards, and is terminated by a broad pier-head. The eastern pier approaches the western pier from the north-eastward, leaving a passage about 142 yards wide between the pier-heads. A wet dock or basin, some times called the inner harbour, has its entrance from the eastern side of the harbour by means of a lock 246 feet in length and 54 feet wide, its outer sill is 8£ feet, and its inner sill 13| feet above the level of low water, springs, which latter is also the level of the bottom of the basin. Another small basin lies on the eastern side of the main basin and communicates with it by means of an opening, without gates, 39 feet wide ; vessels of 10 feet draught are neaped in this inner basin during the lowrest tides. The outer harbour dries at low water, but is accessible both at springs and neaps to vessels of considerable draught. The inner harbour or basin can only be entered from one to \\ hours before or after high water, according to the height of the tide. The outer harbour can be entered at ordinary neaps from 1^ hours before to 1^ hours after high water ; the bottom is mud, the berths, except by

[Chap. IV. 156 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. the eastern jetties, are good, and a sharp vessel will ground upright and lie in safety. There is a gridiron in the north-western part of the outer harbour. Granville is in direct railway communication with Paris, the distance occupying about 8 hours ; the steamers of the London and South-Western Railway Company also ply regularly between it and Jersey, thus connecting it with England. It has a considerable trade, but one of its principal industries, the oyster fishery, has entirely failed of late years. The rocky bed forming the base of the western part of Le Roc uncovers 3| cables in a southerly direction from pointe du Roc, and 2 cables North and N.W. from the north-western part of the peninsula, which latter part is marked by a beacon surmounted by a globe, the upper part of the beacon white, the lower part black. The Loup rock, the nearest danger to the harbour, is marked by a beacon turret painted with red and white bands ; it lies S.by W. £ W. 2£ cables from the extreme of the western pier, and uncovers 21 feet ; it forms a natural breakwater during south-westerly gales. The pier head lighthouse on with the gap which separates Le Roc from the hills north-eastward of it, leads a cable westward of the Loup ; and, the same lighthouse on with Granville church steeple leads half a cable eastward. The rock covers at half flood, at which time there are 10 feet between the pier-heads, 6 feet within them, and 16j feet over the Tombelaine bank. LIGHTS. — Granville lighthouse, a circular tower 43 feet high, stands on pointe du Roc or cape Lihou, and exhibits, at 154 feet above high water, a fixed white light of the third order, visible in clear weather 15 miles. From it, Chausey lighthouse bears N.W. by W. 8^ miles ; Pierre de Herpin light W. by S. £ S. 10 miles ; and, Senequet rock light N. by E. 15f miles. A fixed red light, dioptric and of the fifth order, is shown from a lighthouse on the western pier-head, on the western side of the entrance to the harbour. It is 40 feet above high water and visible 5 miles. A. fixed green light, visible 2 miles, is shown from a lamp-post on the eastern pier-head. Semaphore — There is a semaphore station close to the light house on pointe du Roc. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Granville at 6 h. 13 m. Ordinary springs rise 37 feet ; neaps 27£ feet ; neaps range 11\ feet. Equinoctial springs rise 7 feet higher than ordinary springs.

Chap, iv.] 157 GRANVILLE.— DIRECTIONS. Pilots. — Granville pilots cruise in the vicinity of the iles Chausey in decked two-masted boats. Vessels approaching Granville from the westward, however, during strong westerly winds, do well to haul up under the lee of Grouin point to secure a pilot, as at such times boats may not be able to keep the sea off Granville. Pilots take charge of vessels leaving Granville as far westward as cape Frehel, or as far northward in the Cotentin channel as the Banes Feles. A Life-Boat is stationed at Granville. DIRECTIONS.*— Entering Granville.— Bring the pier-head lighthouse open of the fall of the land under the eastern end of Garrison bluff, to pass between the tail of the Loup and the rocks on which the pier is built ; or, if wishing to pass eastward of the Loup rock, open Granville church its own breadth eastward of the light house. Give the pier-head, when rounding it, a berth of a ship's length only, shoot as far to the westward as possible when within it, and drop the anchor when convenient, A vessel drawing 10 feet must not attempt to round the pier-head until 4 hours flood, especially if there be any sea. All possible sail should be carried when entering the harbour, and, in the event of a sudden shift of wind, a vessel should be prepared either to anchor or to run out a hawser to the warping buoy between the Loup rock and the plateau Jean-la-Blanche. When it blows hard between N.W. and S.W., the great inequalities of the rocky ridge extending southward from Granville lighthouse occasion a heavy sea outside the mouth of the harbour, and the outer part of this ridge, which uncovers 9 feet at the lowest tides, is then very dangerous ; there is also a heavy breaking sea in the passage between the pier and the Loup with strong winds betw*een N.W. and West. This dangerous part is avoided by keeping St. Nicholas church steeple on with the southern slope of Gautier point. Should the wind be light, endeavour to maintain a position off the harbour, so as to be carried towards the entrance from 1\ hours before to half an hour after high water, while the stream is running East and E.N.E. *, but do not attempt to enter before high water, or the vessel may be carried westward of the pier, and even on pointe du Roc, by the eddy on the flood, which leaves the harbour after traversing the quays from East to West, and runs along the shore * Directions for navigating the Contentin passage between cape de la Hague and Granville will be found at pages 186-192.

[Chap. IV. 158 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. towards pointe du Roc. The strength of this eddy is from one to 1^ knots at springs, it runs from half flood to high water, and it is in order to stem it that plenty of sail should be carried when entering the harbour. When arriving off the harbour before there is sufficient water to enter ; if the wind is strong enough to stem the tide, keep southward of the line of St. Nicholas church steeple on with the southern slope of Gautier point. With the wind from N.E. round by North to W.N.W. keep northward of this line and make short tacks southward of the Chausey islets, between Chausey lighthouse and the Conchee ; and, with the wind from W.N.W. round by West to South, short boards should be made between Grouin point and the Parisiennne ridge, not standing southward of an imaginary line drawn from Pierre de Herpin lighthouse to Champeaux point. As soon as there is water sufficient to enter the harbour, steer for it, keeping the pier head lighthouse on with the gap which separates Le Roc peninsula from the hills north-eastward of the town ; this leads a cable westward of the Loup and to the entrance of the harbour. In working towards the harbour from the S.W., make a long board to the northward of the line of St. Nicholas church steeple on with the southern slope of Gautier point, but avoid being carried too far northward by the flood stream. The last board should be made south-eastward of the Loup, taking care to avoid the Norocher, a ridge of rocks of which parts uncover from 10 to 12 feet. From thence, stand for the harbour eastward of the Loup, on which side that rock may be approached to within half a cable without danger. Should the Loup beacon turret be washed away, Granville church steeple on with the pier-head lighthouse leads clear to the eastward. At low water, neaps, small coasters arriving off the harbour with the wind off-shore may anchor to await tide between the Loup rock and Tombelaine bank, where they will then find 10 or 12 feet water over a bottom of sand and broken shells ; at low water, springs, there are only 2 or 3 feet water here. There are also a few rocks in the eastern part of the anchorage, but with Mont St. Michel open of Champeux point, a vessel is 2 cables westward of them. Leaving Granville, a sailing vessel of deep draught should wait for a leading wind, and, if bound westward, advantage should be taken of off-shore winds, particularly those between East and South. If the wind is between E.S.E. and S.S.E. and strong enough to stem the tide, leave as soon as the vessel floats and steer to pass 2 or 3 miles northward of Cezembre island and.of cape Frehel.

Chap. IV.] GRANVILLE, DIRECTIONS. — THE COAST. 159 If between South and W.S.W., haul out to the warping buoys as soon as she is afloat and make sail from the outermost buoy. Short boards must be made as far as Thar point, 2\ miles southward of the harbour, and from thence they may be lengthened, coasting at a safe distance from the in-shore dangers as far as cape Frehel, to avoid being carried by the tides towards the Minquiers and. other off-lying dangers. In fine weather, the Minquiers light-vessel, together with the lights of Chausey, Granville, Pierre de Herpin, St. Malo, and cape Frehel, render this navigation as easy by night as by day. THE COAST. — From pointe du Roc, Granville, cape de Carteret, which is the western extreme of the first high land on the coast northward of Granville, bears N. £ E. easterly 33 miles, the whole of the coast line between the two points being low and receding slightly eastward. Six small harbours, capable of affording shelter to coasters of 40 or 50 tons, are within this space : viz., Regneville, Geffosse, St. Germain-sur-Ay, Surville, Port Bail, and Havre de Carteret, just eastward of the cape of that name. For the first 16 miles northward of Granville, the sandy beach bordering the coast dries in places at low water as much as 2^ miles from the shore ; northward of Geffosse it uncovers on an average about one mile, and, throughout the whole extent of this tidal seaboard, numerous reefs of rocks are scattered in all directions, rendering the approach to it exceedingly dangerous. The off-lying reefs and shoals between the coast and the Channel islands are also very numerous, causing the navigation between Granville and Cape de la Hague by this route, known as the Cotentin channel, to be both intricate and dangerous, the latter especially if surprised by foggy weather, though it is well lighted and buoyed. Coutances cathedral, about 6 miles inland and 14 miles N.E. from pointe du Roc, is lofty and a useful land-mark ,* it may be known by its two spires or turrets, which occasionally appear like the Reculvers in Kent. The church steeple of Agon, one mile inland, is a large square tower covered with tiles, and the little church steeple of Pirou 8 miles farther northward very much resembles it, From Coutances towards Granville, the interior of the country presents a moderates high but regular outline which terminates at Champeaux point, the bluff and nearly perpendicular headland 5£ miles southward of Granville. From Coutances northward, the character of the country alters, the interior being lofty though somewhat irregular, and between St. Germain and Barneville, 2 miles eastward of cape de Carteret, the inequalities become very marked and conspicuous.

160 [Chap. IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. The entrance to Regneville is 10 miles N.N.E. \ E. from Granville lighthouse. The coast between it and St. Germain trends N. by E. for 13 miles, and the shore is low, sandy, and bordered with downs. Among the most remarkable objects is Mont Huchon, about 2 miles northward of Coutances cathedral and 6 miles inland eastward of the entrance to Regneville harbour, and of the western part of the line of hills immediately northward of the harbour, on which stand the village and church of Agon. This part of the hills ends abruptly with steep slopes towards the sea, and, when seen from the north westward at a distance, presents the appearance of a high cape facing westward. The most conspicuous objects on the land between St. Germain and cape de Carteret are, Monts Gardon and Doville, and the hills of Benneville ; on the first stands the village of Mont Gardon and two mills, 3Jr miles from the sea, and 3 miles north-eastward from the town of St. Germain ; Mont Doville, 2\ miles northward of Mont Gardon and 6^ miles eastward of the entrance to Port Bail, has a windmill on its summit ; and, Benneville hills rise E.N.E. 4 miles from Port Bail and have three windmills on them. CATHEUE BANKS, including Catheue reef and Shamrock knoll, extend North and South 6 miles and lie nearly parallel with the line of coast ; they are chiefly composed of sand. Two patches near their middle dry at very lowT springs, at which time there are 6 feet at their southern end and 2 fathoms at their northern end. These banks are almost connected with the shore on their eastern side and, southward, with the shoal extending from pointe du Roc, from which point, their northern extreme is distant 11 miles ; they are only separated from the Ronquet reef off Regneville by a bed of sand which has from 2 to 12 feet over it at low water, at which time there is no navigable passage between the banks and the shore. The Catheue reef is a dangerous ledge about a mile long in a W.S.W. and E.N.E. direction and a quarter of a mile broad, lying between the northern end of the Catheue banks proper and the Shamrock knoll. It has several rocky heads, of which two uncover at the lowest springs, when the rest have from 3 to 6 feet over them. The highest head uncovers 24 feet near the middle of the reef W.S.W. 2£ miles from the westernmost head of the Ronquet reef; N. \ W. Sh miles from Granville lighthouse ; and, N.E. by E. £ E. 7£ miles from Chausey lighthouse. The marks for it are, Mont St. Michel thrice its width open westward of Champeaux point S. } E. ;

Chap. IV.] CATHEUE BANKS. — ROCHES D'AGON. 161 Chausey lighthouse on with the southern side of the Etat rock S.W. by W. westerly ; and, Coutances cathedral in line with Agon point E. £ N. northerly. Buoy. — A red bell buoy is moored half a cable south-eastward of the shoalest part of the Catheue reef. Champeaux point just open of pointe du Roc, South, leads eastward of Catheue banks and reef; and, Agon church steeple on with the southern slope of Mont Huchon, East, leads a safe distance northward of that reef and of the Shamrock knoll. Shamrock Knoll is a sandy ridge at the northern end of the Catheue Banks, one mile long N. by E. and S. by W. and 2 cables wide, with 3 feet on the shoalest part at its southern end, and 2 fathoms at its northern end. The southern end is only about 7 cables north-westward of Catheue reef, and between them is a patch of 6 feet. More than half a mile northward of the knoll are several patches of 2 fathoms. Roches d'Agon are a small group 3£ miles from the shore, half way between it and the northern extreme of the Shamrock knoll, and 1^ miles north-westward from the Ronquet beacon turret, with from 8 to 10 feet water close to them. They form, in conjunc tion with a bed of rocks on the beach, a continuous ridge extending westward from the direction of Agon steeple, and parallel with the Ronquet and Moulieres d'Agon rocks. The highest head of the Agon rocks uncovers 8 feet ; W.S.W. 4^ cables from it, another head uncovers 6 feet ; and, at a quarter of a mile westward of the latter, another uncovers 2 feet ; this head lies N.W. \ W. H miles from the Ronquet beacon turret ; and, S. \ W. rather more than 3 miles from the westernmost head of the Nattes. There are no marks available for the western head of the Agon rocks, which are extremely dangerous to approach between half ebb and half flood, and a heavy sea runs on them when it blow*s hard from the westward ; but, Hatainville sand-hills shut in by cape de Carteret N. £ E., or Champeaux point just in sight westward of pointe du Roc, South, leads one mile westward of the outer rock. Ronquet Rock, W. by N. \ N. %\ miles from Agon point light house at the entrance of Regneville Harbour, is the highest rock of a group a mile long, East and West, and half a mile wide. This rock is marked by a black beacon turret erected on its summit ; the A 2771. Wt. 17197. L

The next highest head, at the southern part of the group, uncovers 12 feet S. \ W. half a mile from the Ronquet beacon turret, with Grimouville church steeple a little open northward of Coutances cathedral E. \ N. ; and, Mont Martin windmill on with the guard house at the south-eastern point of entrance to Regneville harbour E.S.E. The latter mark also shows the direction of the western point of the group, which is three quarters of a mile westward of the Ronquet, and is terminated by a rock uncovering 5 feet. Until the establishment of the beacon turret on the Ronquet rock, the whole of this group was very dangerous when covered, as no marks can be given to indicate the position of its western edge which is 3 miles off-shore and bears S.E. \ E. 6 miles from the Marie ledge ; and, E.N.E. %\ miles from the highest head of the Catheue reef. Champeaux point just open westward of pointe du Roc leads well westward of it. r r REGNEVILLE is at the mouth of the little river Sienne, into which the river Soulles flows 4 miles in the interior ; the harbour is so choked with sand as to admit coasters only of about 8 or 9 feet draught at high water, springs. The bottom of the harbour, being chiefly sand and shells, is bad holding ground ; the anchors should therefore be buried to avoid driving with strong winds between W N.W. and S.W., to which the entrance is exposed. The entrance is between the Bee d'Agon, or Agon point, and the point on which the guard-house stands, which, on with Mont Martin windmill, is the mark for the south-western extreme of the Ronquet group ; several sand-banks lie in the fairway, and the action of the tides causes Agon point to grow constantly southward, the lighthouse originally built near the extreme being now more than 3 cables from it. Two channels lead to the entrance ; the deepest borders the southern side of the Ronquet group and the Moulieres d'Agon ; the leading mark for it is, the fort 3 cables north-westward of the extreme of Agon point seen between the steeples of Coutances and Grimouville E. £N. The other channel, named the Coliere, is not quite so deep but has the advantage of leading directly into the harbour and avoiding the turn south-eastward in rounding Agon point, The Caillou rock, which uncovers 17 feet, lies on the eastern side of this channel ; the leading mark is, Grimouville church steeple a little open eastward of

Chap, iv.] REGNEVILLE. — NATTES ROCKS. 163 the Custom-house, the last large house on the shore at the northern part of Regneville village, N.E. by E. \ E. Both channels, however, are subject to great changes caused by wind and weather, and with strong winds between N.N.W. and W.S.W. the sea breaks with great violence at the entrance. No stranger should ever attempt to enter without a pilot. LIGHT. — A fixed ichite light, dioptric and of the fourth order, is exhibited from a square tower on Agon point. It is 33 feet above high water, and visible in clear weather from a distance of 10 miles. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on the hill at Agon. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Regneville at 6 h. 20 m.; springs rise 35 feet, neaps 26 feet. The Nattes rocks are a small rocky group about 2 cables long N.W. and S.E. at the south-western extreme of the ridge extending from the Senequet, and N. -J- E. easterly 3 miles from the western edge of the Roches d'Agon ; they are the most western in-shore rocks which uncover between the harbours of Regneville and St. Germain. They lie W. N. 34 miles from the entrance of Blainville harbour ; S.W. 2j miles from Senequet lighthouse ; and, the marks for the highest head, which uncovers 3 feet only, are, Senequet lighthouse a little open westward of Pirou church steeple ; and, Coutances steeples on with the houses of Courtainville, a village built on a remarkable mound, E.S.E. Champeaux point just showing westward of Pointe du Roc, or Pirou steeple well open westward of Senequet lighthouse, leads outside the Nattes. Their western extreme, in 6 feet, bears N. E. 14 miles from Granville lighthouse, and is exactly in line between it and Cape de Cartaret lighthouse, being distant from the latter 19^ miles. Several small ridges of rock uncover from 3 to 5 feet at low water, springs, and form a chain a mile in length which extends from the Nattes north-eastward and joins the outer sunken rocks of the Senequet ridge. A heavy sea runs on all these rocks when it blows hard from the westward. Buoys.— A red bell buoy, with staff and reflector, is moored in 6 feet water off the western side of the Nattes rocks. At 1£ miles S.W. by W. from the Nattes rocks, and 2| miles E. by S. i S. from the buoy marking the Basse le Marie, is the Inter national buoy F, painted in red and white horizontal bands. L 2

Blainville Harbour, nearly midway between Regneville and Geffosse harbours, is a kind of lagoon almost filled with sand, and affording shelter to fishing boats at springs only. A buoy painted with red and black bands lies in the entrance, and there is also near the entrance a red beacon consisting of a mast surmounted by a ball. THE SENEQUET ROCK.— This rock, on which stands a light- house, almost forms a connecting link with the line of dangers extend ing from La Roque point, Jersey. It is 2 miles from the shore, 2^ miles N.W. from the entrance to Blainville, and uncovers 27^ feet. It is the highest head of the rocky ridge which extends eastward from it to the shore, south-eastward to the Klebet rocks, south-westward as far as the Nattes rocks, and north-westward 8 cables. This outer part is very dangerous, as it greatly contracts the passage between the Senequet rock and the Bœuf. The outer most head is awash at the lowest tides, with Senequet lighthouse just open southward of Blainville church steeple S.E. The space for more than 2 miles between this head and the Nattes is equally dangerous, being one continued chain of rocks, of which the highest uncover from 6 to 8 feet ; when it blows hard from any direction between North and South round by West, there is a heavy sea on them. Mont Gardon church steeple between the summit of Mont Doville and St. Germain church steeple leads a safe distance outside both the Nattes and the outer rocks of the Senequet. LIGHT. — The Senequet rock lighthouse is a circular tower 75 feet high, from which, at 56 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed red light, visible in clear weather 12 miles. From it, Granville lighthouse bears S. by W. 15§ miles ; Chausey lighthouse S.W. southerly 14i miles ; and, Cape de Carteret lighthouse North 17£ miles. BASSE le MARIE, a rocky ledge nearly 4 cables long, East and West, and 2 cables broad, lies nearly midway between the northern extreme of the Catheue banks and the south-easternmost patch of the Southern Anquettes, about 3 miles distant from both. Its highest head, at the eastern end of the ledge, uncovers 4| feet at the lowest tides; near the middle another head is awash, and at the western extreme another has 15 ft. over it at the same time. The ledge has from 4 to 7 fathoms round it, with sandy bottom mixed with pieces of shell. From the highest head, the western

Chap, iv.] SENEQUET, MARIE, AND BŒUFS ROCKS. 165 edge of the Nattes rocks bears E. £ N. 4^ miles ; the Bœuf rock beacon turret N.N.E. \ E. 4| miles ; and, the highest head of Catheue reef S.S.E. \ E. \b\ miles. Coutances Cathedral is its own breadth open southward of Agon church E. by S. \ S. ; and, Rozel manor house, Jersey, is on with Archirondel tower N. by W. £ W. westerly. Coutances cathedral its own breadth open northward of Agon church tower leads northward of the ledge but close to it ; Mont Martin church and mill in line S.E. by E. \ E. leads southward ; the Etat beacon turret, Chausey, midway between the iles des Huguenans S. by W. \ W. leads between it and the Catheue ; and, the Etat on with the Conchee S. \ W. leads westward of it, as does also Hamon rock exactly on with the western apex of Grande Ancre islet. Buoy. — A bell buoy with red and white bands is moored half a mile eastward of Basse le Marie. CHAUSSEE-des-BŒUFS are ledges of dangerous rocks 2\ miles long, East and West, and one mile wide. Their outer edge is 4^ miles south-eastward of the Grande Anquette beacon turret ; 6 miles from high-water mark on the French shore ; and, they appear above water at 4 hours ebb, some heads showing only at low water, and many more being always covered. In the vicinity of these rocks the ground is very foul and dangers are scattered in all directions, principally, however, northward, westward, and eastward of them; amongst them are depths of from 4 to 7 fathoms. The Bœuf rock, the highest rock of the group, is about one third from the eastern end of the Chaussee, and is marked by a beacon turret painted with red and white bands, 10 feet above high water, and surmounted by a mast and globe. The marks for this rock, which uncovers 18 feet at the lowest tides, are, Seymour tower, Jersey, touching the southern side of the Grande Anquette rock N.W. £ W. ; Icho tower on with Noirmont tower N.W. by W. \ W. ; and, Hatain ville sand-hills seen between capes de Carteret and Flamanville. The Bœuf rock is surrounded for the space of 4 cables by small rocky heads which uncover 4 or 5 feet. The Bœuftins, half a mile westward of the Bœuf and nearly a mile within the western edge of the reef, are small detached ridges, of which the highest uncovers 9 feet. Basse Occidental des Bœufs, half a mile north-westward of the Chaussee-des-Bœufs, is a very small detached rock with only

166 [Chap. IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. 4 feet water; it bears about W.N.W. one mile from the northern rock of the Bœuftins which dries 7 feet. From the Basse, Prince's tower, Jersey, appears a little open eastward of Grande Anquette N.W. \ N. northerly ; Coupe turret on with St. Catherine's breakwater light house N.N.W. £ W. ; and, the steeple of Coutances cathedral just open northward of Blainville church steeple S.E. by E. \ E. Basse Nord-Ouest des Bceufs is a small ridge of rocks 3 cables long East and West, rising from rocky shallow ground a mile in extent, and united to the Chaussee-des-Bœufs by a rocky bed on which are from 4 to 5 fathoms. The highest head of this ridge uncovers 2 feet ; from it, Seymour tower a little open south ward of the South hill, Jersey, bears N.W. by W. ; and, the Bœuf beacon turret between the church steeples of Mont Martin and Agon S.E. S. southerly nearly 2 miles. Basse Jourdan. — This small rocky ridge, a cable long East and West with only 2 feet water, lies E. £ S. 1£ miles from the Bœuf beacon turret, but only 9 cables from the eastern head of the Chaussee-des-Bœufs which is nearly awash at low water ; and, N.W. £ W. 3^ miles from Senequet lighthouse. The marks for it are, Blainville church on with the northern sandy point of Blainville harbour, or with the southern side of the Senequet rock ; Gouville church open northward of Mont Huchon S.E. by E. h E. ; and, cape de Carteret on with the highest of the Hatainville sand-hills, which are seen from a great distance on account of their whiteness and the contrast between them and the dark land of capes de Carteret and Flamanville. Buoy. — A red and black bell buoy with staff and reflector is moored close to the eastern side of the Basse Jourdan. Bœuf Patch, 1^ miles northward of the Basse Jourdan, is H miles long N. £ W. and S. \ E., and its greatest width, near the northern end, is less than half a mile. It has a general depth of 3 faihoms, with 2^ fathoms near the northern end. The marks for the shoalest part are, Vesly church touching the extreme of the western point of entrance to St. Germain E. by N. ; Coutances cathedral just open northward of Liverville church S.E. ; and, Agon church just open eastward of Senequet lighthouse S.S.E. \ E. easterly. There is a 5-fathoms channel a mile wide between the Bœuf patch and the Chaussee-des-Bœufs, for which the leading mark is, Bergerie house, just northward of Noirmont point, Jersey, on

Clearing Marks.— Hatainville sand-hills shut in by cape de Carteret N. £ E. leads eastward of Basse Jourdan and of the Bœuf patch. Coutances cathedral twice its own breadth open southward of Blainville church steeple S.E. by E. £ E. easterly leads 2 cables clear of the south-western extreme of the Chaussee-des-Bœufs ; Prince's tower open westward of Grande Anquette beacon turret N.W. £ N. leads westward of them ; and, Grande Anquette and Icho towers in line N.W. by W. £ W. lead 3 cables northward of the 2-feet rock on the Basse Nord-Ouest des Bœufs. W. clears the western side. DIRECTIONS. — Vessels navigating in the northern vicinity of the Chaussee-des-Bœufs between half ebb and half flood, the most dangerous time, must be careful to keep Bergerie house open north ward of Seymour tower, and Bouley signal-station a quarter of a point open northward of Rozel mill,* when it will be also just open of Rozel manor-house. Southward of the Anquettes and the Bœufs, for a long distance, the sea is much encumbered by sunken rocks and banks of sand and gravel having from 4 to 6 fathoms over them ; indeed, from the southern Anquettes in the direction of Basse le Marie and the iles Chausey, scarcely a spot is quite free from one or the other, and in boisterous weather the whole of that space is one continuous sheet of broken water. The proper channels, lying eastward and westward of this accumulation of shoal ground, are pretty clear. The Chaussee-des-Bœufs and Anquettes being so beset on all sides by danger, the utmost caution is necessary, especially in large vessels, to navigate with any degree of safety between or near them ; the best time is between half flood and high water, but there exists only one continuous leading mark for the passage between them, viz., the church of St. Pierre-les-Moutiers, which has a very low * In July, 1886, the arms of Rozel mill had been removed, rendering it difficult of recognition by a stranger. — Staff Capt.
