The mark is useful, however, when coming from the northward, but too distant to be of much service when entering this passage from the southward, unless the weather is unusually clear. From the northward, the leading mark given must be carefully preserved until the white house at La Moye, Jersey, opens south ward of Le Fret point N.W. \ W. ; or, until Coutances cathedral appears midway between Blainville and Agon churches E.S.E. ; and, it must always be remembered that both tides set obliquely across the vessel's course. St. GERMAIN BAY.— Anchorage.— This bay is formed by the land receding eastward between the Senequet rock and cape de Carteret ; it affords shelter in its northern part from winds between N.N.E. and S.E. in 5 fathoms, good holding ground of sandy clay ; but, southward of the Feles banks, vessels should nowhere approach the land nearer than 3^ miles, to avoid several patches of from 4 to 8 feet water only. The best anchorage is, with cape de Carteret light house about N. \ E., and Pirou telegraph tower from S.E. to S.E. by E., but nothing southward of this latter bearing for fear of fouling the sub-marine telegraph cable. Telegraph cable. — The electric cable from Fliquet bay, Jersey, see page 249, runs direct to Pirou on the French coast, where the position of its shore end is marked by a tower and its direction at sea indicated by the tower being on with Pirou church steeple S.E. by E. E. The telegraph tower is easily recognized, as it stands quite alone near the beacon southward of St. Germain harbour ; it is white, 17 feet in diameter, 28 feet high, and surmounted by a green disc, on which is painted in large letters the word Telegraphe. Vessels should avoid anchoring or dredging anywhere near the line of the cable. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at St. Germain at 6 h. 20 m. ; springs rise 34 feet, neaps 25 feet. Sac-de-Pir0U rocks, 1^ miles from the coast just outside the strand which dries at low water, are H miles north-westward of the

Chap, iv.] ST. GERMAIN BAY. 169 little harbour of Geffosse, and S.S.W. £W. 4 miles from the entrance of St. Germain. They are the western part of a long ridge, 6 cables wide, which extends north-eastward to the shore ; the highest head uncovers 5 feet, and the westernmost head 4^ feet. The marks for the western head are, Mont Survent church steeple, on the high land 4 miles in the interior, just open northward of Geffosse church steeple S.E. E. ; and, Bretteville church steeple open westward of the hill which rises a little westward of the old semaphore on the western point of entrance to St. Germain N. by E. \ E. easterly. A sand-bank, one mile long North and South and half a mile wide, with from 4 to 8 feet water, lies two thirds of a mile westward of these rocks and 2 miles from the coast ; it is dangerous to vessels working up in-shore, and may be avoided by keeping Mont Gardon church steeple open northward of the guard-house of the battery on the western point of entrance to St. Germain N.E. \ E. There are also two small sand-banks with 7 and 8 feet water over them between the Sac-de-Pirou and the Senequet rock ; in fact, at 2\ miles from the shore, between the Senequet and St. Germain, the depth does not average more than 15 feet. Senequet lighthouse on with Ronquet beacon turret S. \ W. westerly leads well outside this depth. GEFFOSSE, E.N.E. 3£ miles from Senequet lighthouse and 4^ miles southward of St. Germain, is a very small harbour, only capable of affording shelter to fishing boats of about 10 tons burthen ; it is quite open to W.N.W. and when it blows hard from that quarter there is a nasty tumbling sea at the entrance. St. GERMAIN-SUR- AY.— This little harbour lying N.E. by N. 7^ miles from Senequet rock lighthouse and S. by E. \ E. 12 miles from cape de Carteret, admits vessels drawing 7 or 8 feet at high water, springs, but a vessel of that draught will be neaped within it for 5 or 6 days. The sand-banks, both inside the harbour and at the entrance, are so liable to shift that it is not prudent to enter without a pilot. It is well sheltered on all sides except from S.W. to South, and strong winds from that direction send in a heavy sea. The strand uncovers 1^ miles outside the entrance, and the Cabot with several other rocks rise from it exactly in the fairway. The channel leading to the harbour is very narrow, and is between the Cabot and a rock about the same height 3 cables N.N.W. from it. The leading mark in is, St. Germain church steeple on with a remarkable gap in the sand-hills on the long, narrow, eastern point of entrance bearing N.E. When the Cabot is covered, there are 4 or 5 feet at the entrance.

170 [Chap. IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. The Cabot Rock is at the south-eastern extreme of a ridge extend ing H miles westward from the western point of entrance to St. Germain. It is the highest and nearest rock to the entrance, un covers 25 feet, and bears S. £ E. 8 cables from the guard-house on the western point of entrance, with the guard-house just open eastward of the old semaphore. The southern part of this ridge does not cover during neaps, and they are the highest rocks between St. Germain and cape de Carteret. A sand-bank, with only 7 feet water and from 18 to 22 feet around, lies 1£ miles outside the ridge and W. N. 2j miles from the old semaphore. This little bank is extremely dangerous to coasters working up along shore, and, as no marks for it can be given, they should keep from 2^ to 3 miles from the land. SURVILLE, 5 miles northward of St. Germain and S.S.E. 7£ miles from cape de Carteret, is a small harbour with a sandy bottom, and does not admit vessels drawing more than 7 feet at high water, springs. The bottom outside for 3 miles south-westward of it is very uneven, several little ridges with from 8 to 18 feet rising from it, A small rocky ridge with only 4 feet over the highest head and from 12 to 19 feet close to, lies W.S.W. 1£ miles from the entrance ; no marks can be given for this dangerous reef. BASSES de TAILLEPIED — The Basses de Taillepied and Banes Feles lie nearly midway between the Ecrehos rocks, fully described at page 252, and the shore ; and, the centre of the shoals, about 4£ miles S.S.W. from cape de Carteret ; they form one bank and occupy a space 4 miles long N.W. \ W. and S.E. i E. and about 2 miles wide, the body of the shoals lying south-westward of that line. The Basses de Taillepied form the western side of the shoal. extend 3 miles N. by W. \ W. and S. by E. i E., and are 3 cables broad. They consist of from 20 to 25 rocky heads, of which the highest, in the northern part of the chain, uncovers 2 feet at the lowest tides ; at which time, the other heads have from one to 14 feet over them. The marks for the rocky head of 8 feet near the northern end, from which cape de Carteret bears S.W. \ W. 4-^ miles, are, Rozel mill, Jersey, just showing northward of Maitre ile, Ecrehos, W. by SA S. ; and, Mabire windmill on with the eastern slope of the hill of cape de Carteret N.E. by E. From the rocky head of 9 feet at the southern end, Plemont point, Jersey, open northward of Ronez point bears W. by N. \ N. ; and, St. Pierre steeple well open eastward of cape de Carteret. N.E. by N. northerly.

Chap. IV.] BASSES DE TAILLEPIED.— PORT BAIL. 171 r- r BANCS FELES, forming the eastern side of the shoal, consist of about 20 narrow parallel ridges of coarse sand and shingle, averaging about 3 cables in length. The ridges lie close together nearly at right angles to the flood and ebb streams, and occupy a space 2 miles long N.W. and S.E. by half a mile wide. Three of the ridges dry at the lowest tides, and then there are from 2 to 4 feet over the remainder. From the north-western extreme of the Banes Feles, which has on it a patch of 13 feet, cape de Carteret lighthouse bears N.E. by N. 4r*V miles, and the Trois-Grunes N. by W. \ W. about the same distance ; near the south-eastern extreme is an 8-feet patch, from which the lighthouse bears N. \ E. f>\ miles, and Caillourie islet in the entrance of Port Bail E.N.E. 3f miles. Clearing Marks. — Mont Orgueil castle, Jersey, on with Maitre ile S.W. £ W., or St. Pierre spire on with cape de Carteret lighthouse, a very close mark, leads northward of these shoals in 3i fathoms ; Rozel mill on with Coupe point W. i N. leads southward ; cape Flamanville on with cape de Carteret North a little easterly leads very close to their south-eastern extreme ; and, the leading lights of Port Bail in line N.E. by E. \ E. or the steeple of Port Bail between the mills of Cartelet, leads 3 cables south-eastward of it ; these mills stand 600 yards eastward of the mill of Bien-Aime. St. Martin's spire, Jersey, on with St. Catherine's breakwater lighthouse W. by N. leads southward of the Ecreviere, Taillepied, and Feles banks. The passage between the Banes Feles and the French coast is 2j miles wride, with patches of from 6 to 12 feet in it ; it is the channel generally used and the leading mark is good. That between the Taillepied and the Ecrehos rocks is 1^ miles wide, with a patch of 11 feet in its southern entrance, but no leading mark for it can be given ; from the great rapidity of the streams, there is generally a turbulent sea in this passage even in the finest weather, and in rough weather it is exceedingly dangerous for small vessels to attempt it. PORT BAIL.— The entrance to this harbour is 8 miles northward of St. Germain and S.S.E. £ E. 4^ miles from cape de Carteret lighthouse ; it is the best harbour between cape de la Hague and Granville, but its trade is quite insignificant and it is only accessible at spring tides for one hour before or after high water, and, at high water, neaps, boats of 6 feet draught cannot always enter. The bottom of the harbour is sand, which dries from half ebb to half flood.

[Chap. IV. 172 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. The entrance is not more than a cable wide and is open to the S.W. ; it is between the southern point of the harbour and La Caillourie, a sandy islet on which stands a Custom-house station and the outer leading light, on point Dune, its south-eastern end. The islet is from 25 to 30 feet above the level of the bottom of the harbour, and bears S.W. by W. \ W. 5| cables from the village of Port Bail. South-eastward of it is a bed of pebbles and small stones about a cable in extent, which should be avoided ; and, southward of it, a rock which does not cover. The little river Grise discharges itself into the harbour. LIGHTS. — Two fixed harbour lights are established at Port Bail, the inner red light being shown from the church tower, and the outer white light from a staff erected by a little white hut at point Dune, distant from the inner light S.W. by W. \ W. 953 yards. The red light is visible in clear weather 9 miles, the white light 7 miles, and when in line they lead into port. The lights are visible 16° on either side of the leading line ; they are brightest when in line, and their brilliancy decreases as the limit is approached. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on the sand-hills at the outer northern point of entrance. Directions. — The leading mark into this harbour is, the two lights in line, or the steeple of Port Bail between the two mills of Cartelet N.E. by E. \ E. The berth where the tide rises highest is on the bed of the fresh water stream E.N.E. and East of the southern point of entrance, but it is an uneasy position when it blows hard from N.N.W. ; here the tide rises from 16£ to 19£ feet at springs, but, in running in, the lead must be kept going to avoid the bank of the stream. The best berth, but with 2>\ feet less water, is about 2 cables south-westward of the guard-house near the shore 3 cables S.S.E. of the church steeple ; here a vessel is sheltered on all sides except from W.N.W. Coasters, trading between here and Jersey, take up a position in the bed of the stream in front of the village. A black buoy marks the entrance of the channel, and, between it and the entrance points are some mooring buoys where vessels may moor head and stern in the direction of the channel ; the position, however, is completely exposed, and no vessel should make use of these buoys except in fine settled weather. The Jument and Grand Rocher are two rocks south-westward of the entrance to Port Bail. The first is at low- water mark, 1\

Chap, iv.] 173 PORT BAIL. — CAPE DE CARTERET. miles from the southern point of entrance, and uncovers 11^ feet ; the other is 1^ miles from the same point, about 7 cables southward of the Jument, and uncovers 14£ feet. Basses de Port Bail are three small rocky ledges and a small sand-bank fronting the entrance of Port Bail. The first has two rocky heads, each with 6 feet water, and lies about a mile from the shore, with Gouey steeple between Port Bail steeple and Caillourie islet E. \ N. ; and, cape de Carteret lighthouse N. by W. \ W. The second is very small, with 8 feet water, W.S.W. 4 cables from the first, and S. \ E. easterly 4 miles from cape de Carteret lighthouse. The third ledge, with 9 feet, lies North 6 cables from the second, Y\ miles from the shore, and S. \ E. 3^ miles nearly from the cape, with Omonville church steeple on with the extreme of the southern point of entrance to the harbour E. by S. The small sand-bank has 8 feet water, and is about 1£ miles from the shore, with Gouey steeple on with the summit of Caillourie islet E. by N. \ N. northerly. Several other rocky patches lie northward of the Basses de Port Bail, from half to three quarters of a mile outside low water mark, and in the direction of the entrance to Havre de Carteret. CAPE de CARTERET is the western extreme of the steep hill which bounds the entrance of de Carteret harbour on its western side. This hill is the first high land on the coast northward of Granville, and is separated from the high land of the interior by a valley nearly 600 yards wide, almost entirely filled by drift sand from the neigh bouring sand-hills. The cape is rather higher than Rosel point, 6 miles northward of it, and may be seen in clear weather 17 or 18 miles distant ; it terminates in an abrupt declivity, beneath which is a cliff of sloping rocks. The lighthouse, a square tower, stands about 100 yards eastward of the extreme of the cape, and a semaphore is near it. From the lighthouse, Granville lighthouse bears S. \ W. westerly 33 miles ; cape de la Hague lighthouse N. \ E. easterly 21£ miles, cape Flamanville and Nez de Jobourg projecting seaward of this line ; and, St. Catherine's breakwater lighthouse, Jersey, S.W. by W. £ W. 12 miles. LIGHT. — Cape de Carteret lighthouse exhibits a revolving ivhite light, the eclipses succeding each other every half minute, and not being total in ordinary weather within 8 miles. The light is of the second order, 262 feet above high water, visible in clear weather from a distance of 23 miles, and seldom hidden by fog.

174 [Chap. iv. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. HAVRE de CARTERET, a mile eastward of cape de Carteret and N.N.W. | W. 4 miles from Port Bail, admits vessels of 10 to 1H feet draught, at springs, for half an hour before and after high water. The entrance, about half a cable wide, is between two stone jetties, which cover at high water, springs, are above water at neaps, and are marked by beacons at their outer ends. The western jetty, commencing at the foot of the steep eastern part of the cape, is about 640 yards long ; the eastern jetty does not project quite so far seaward. The harbour is open to the southward, and during the time it is accessible the stream runs strongly across the entrance north-westward, but between the jetties it takes their direction until they cover, when it again runs across the direction of the channel at the surface. The ebb stream runs with great velocity out of the harbour. This little port is quite useless for purposes of shelter and the trade is insignificant ; supplies of any description can only be obtained with difficulty and in small quantities. It is 24 miles distant from Cherbourg by road, and is occasionally visited by small passenger steamers from St. Helier. Directions. — The leading mark for the channel into de Carteret harbour is, de Carteret steeple on with the door of the life-boat house. A small red buoy marks a bank nearly in mid-channel at the entrance ; there is, however, more water over the bank than over the berths in the harbour, but it is best to pass westward of the buoy where there are 3 feet more water than on the bank. When the inner part of the western jetty is awash there are 10 feet in the channel, but above this, where the grounding berths are, there are then only from 6 to 8 feet. A Life-Boat is stationed at Havre de Carteret, THE COAST.— Northward of cape de Carteret the coast is re markable from the white sand-hills of Hatainville, so useful to the mariner as a land-mark. Four miles northward of them is Rosel point, bluff and rocky, with dangerous reefs extending more than a mile from it; 3^ miles northward of it is cape Flamanville, also high and bluff ; the Anse de Sciotot, with a low and sandy shore in its southern part but high and rocky as cape Flamanville is approached, lying between them. Northward of cape Flamanville is port Dielette, and the extensive Anse de Vauville affording good shelter in easterly winds; the southern shore of this bay is low and sandy, rising to high land in the interior ; the northern part is high and rugged, terminating in

Chap. IV.] HAVRE DE CARTERET. — COAST. — TROIS-GRUNES. 175 the precipitous Nez de Jobourg, 320 feet above the level of the sea and 9g miles northward of cape Flamanville. From this point, the land falls towards cape de la Hague, which is distant 3 miles and is low, sandy, and surrounded by off-lying dangerous rocks, on the highest of which, the Gros du Raz, stands the lighthouse. There are no hidden dangers in the offing between cape de Carteret and cape Flamanville except the Plateau des Trois-Grunes ; but, from the broad sandy beach between those capes, shallows, which must be avoided at low tide, extend off-shore from 1£ to 2\ miles. The most prominent parts of these shallows are, the Roches du Rit, the Basse Bihard, the Caillou, and the Bane de Surtainville ; the first dries, the others break at the lowest tides. Northward of cape Flamanville, the offing is still clear of danger until the Nez de Jobourg is approached, south- west ward from which point, distant from 1 to 2^ miles and with a clear passage in-shore of them, are the Basses St. Gilles, Huquet de Jobourg, Huquets de Vauville, and other dangerous reefs, on which some heads uncover as much as 15 feet, and all of which may be avoided by keeping Rosel point well open of cape Flamanville. PLATEAU des TROIS-GRUNES.— The northern edge of this dangerous reef bears W. by N. £ N. 3£ miles from cape de Carteret lighthouse ; it is about a mile long N.W. and S.E., from 2j to 8 cables wide, and has from 6 to 9 fathoms round it. It consists of a dozen rocky heads, of which two uncover from 3 to 5 feet at the south-eastern extreme of the ledge and are half a cable apart. From the highest head, which dries 5 feet, cape de Carteret light house bears E. £ S. 3i miles ; the southern extreme of the roches du Rit E. I N. 3 miles ; the summit of cape de Carteret is between the lighthouse and the little battery at the foot of the cape ; and, Rozel mill, Jersey, is just open south-eastward of Grande Rousse rock, Ecrehos group, S.W. £ W. westerly. There are 4 or 5 rocky heads on the north-western part, of which the highest has 5 feet water ; from it, the northernmost of two remark able mills at Vislet, or Brenier, a little open southward of the southernmost fort on cape de Carteret bears E. by S. | S. ; and, the western part of Mont Orgueil castle on with the eastern side of Petite Rousse rock, Ecrehos, S.W. \ S. The overfalls in the vicinity of the plateau des Trois-Grunes are very violent. Buoy. — A conical buoy marked with the letter K. and painted in horizontal black and red bands, is moored S.W. by W. W. about

176 [Chap. IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. 3 cables from the south-eastern and highest head of the Trois- Grunes. Dependance should not be placed upon this buoy being in position as it frequently breaks adrift. Clearing Marks. — The Vielle rock, Ecrehos, on with Mont Orgueil castle S.W. leads 3^ cables south-eastward of the highest head on the ledge ; the square tower of Barneville church in sight southward of cape de Carteret E. \ S. leads three quarters of a mile southward ; St. George's church steeple on with the foot of the southern slope of the hill of cape de Carteret S.E. by E. \ E. leads 6 cables northward of the northern part of the ledge (this steeple may be easily identified by the parsonage, a long white house which appears in this direction) ; the south-eastern fort on the cape shut in by the western pitch of the cape, on which there is a battery, or Bonneliers shut in northward of the cape, also leads clear to the northward ; and, Mont Orgueil castle its own apparent breadth open westward of Grande Rousse rock S.S.W. £ W. leads westward. By Night, cape de la Hague light on with the Nez de Jobourg leads over the centre of the shoal ; the light well open westward of the Nez clears its western side. This is a useful mark from the northward in clear weather, but the light can seldom be seen so far southward as the Trois-Grunes. A bank of sand and broken shells lies 3^ miles north-westward of the Trois-Grunes, and 4^ miles N.E. by N. from the Drouilles shoals ; it has 9 fathoms on it and from 11 to 14 fathoms around, is about 4 cables long N.E. and S.W. and a cable wide, and is not of itself dangerous, but causes a strong overfall which small vessels should avoid when it is blowing fresh. Roches-du-Rit. — Between cape de Carteret and Rosel point, the sands uncover from one quarter to three quarters of a mile from the shore, and several rocky ledges rise from them, of which the most dangerous are the Roches-du-Rit, Their southern end is about 8 cables N.W. by N. from cape de Carteret lighthouse ; from thence, the outer part of the ledge extends N. by W. \ W. one mile, termina ting in this direction 1£ miles N.N.W. from the lighthouse. Shoal water of from 2 to 3 fathoms extends 7 cables westward of the reef and for double that distance to the northward. The Nez de Jobourg open half a point westward of cape Flaman ville N. £ E. easterly leads close westward of the rocks ; and, the white steeple of Port Bail on with the foot of the escarpment under the battery at the extreme of cape de Carteret S.E. \ S. leads south-

Chap. IV.] ROCHES-DU-RIT. — BANC DE SURTAINVILLE. 177 ward, but, this mark cannot be seen at low water, the intervening sand-hills then hiding the steeple. Care must be taken not to approach the cape too closely at low water, as rocky heads with only 4 or 5 feet water extend half a mile westward from the light house. BANC DE SURTAINVILLE consists of four long narrow ridges of sand and broken shells occupying a space lty miles long N.W and S.E., extending 2 miles from the shore, and in some measure united with the beach. There are from 18 to 22 feet on the two western ridges, 11 to 21 feet on the middle, and 19 feet on the south-eastern ridge. These little ridges lie athwart the streams and occasion a heavy sea when it is blowing fresh. Basse Bihard, the outermost of these dangers, is a small rocky flat north-westward of the Bane de Surtainville, with a narrow channel of 8 fathoms between them, 21r miles from the shore ; it is 1^ cables long N.W. and S.E., and three quarters of a cable wide, with only 6 feet water over its highest head ; from which, cape de Carteret lighthouse bears S. by E. £ E. h\ miles ; Rosel point N.E. by E. £ E. 2^ miles ; and, Pieux church open northward of Rosel point and on with a remarkable red-tiled house near the beach N.E. £ E. At low water it is very dangerous, and the over falls cause a heavy sea over it at all times of tide. The CaillOU rock is an isolated head with only 12 feet water E. \ S. half a mile from the Bihard, from which it is separated by a sandy bottom with from 7 to 8 fathoms ; it is close to the northern edge of the Bane de Surtainville, and still more dangerous than the Bihard as there are no marks for it. Clearing Marks. — Cape de Carteret lighthouse kept eastward of S.S.E. \ E. until Rosel Chapel is open northward of the northern part of Rosel point leads outside all these shoals. Jobourg church steeple on with the extreme of cape Flamanville N. by E. \ E. leads between the two western ridges of the Surtainville bank, and 1£ cables eastward of the Caillou rock. By night, cape de la Hague light just open westward of the western slope of the Nez de Jobourg leads half a mile outside these shoals and well outside all foul ground off Rosel point. ROSEL POINT bears NA E. 6 miles from cape de Carteret, and S. \ E. 3;^ miles from cape Flamanville, and terminates in a bluff A 2771. Wt. 7242. M

[Chap. IV. 178 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. rocky promontory on the summit of which stands a guard-house. The point is skirted by rocks running off nearly 3 cables in a S.W. and 6^ cables in a N.N.W. direction from the foot of the cliffs, and, westward of it, there are less than 3 fathoms a mile from the point ; to avoid this foul ground, it should not be approached nearer than 1^ miles, nor within the depth of 10 fathoms. Anse de Sciotot, between Rosel point and cape Flamanville, affords shelter from winds between E.N.E. and S.E. in from 7 to 10 fathoms, sandy bottom. The shore is low and sandy from the head of the bay to Rosel point, but high and rocky towards cape Flamanville. Cape Flamanville is a high bluff point with a guard-house and semaphore on its summit ; from it, the Nez de Jobourg bears N. £ E. easterly about 9 miles. It should not be approached nearer than three quarters of a mile, nor within a depth of 10 fathoms, as it is skirted by dangers extending half a mile from the shore ; they, however, may be avoided by day or night by keeping cape de la Hague lighthouse in sight westward of the Nez.* High granite cliffs form the shore from cape Flamanville as far as Dielette, beyond which the low sandy shore of the Anse de Vauville commences. DIELETTE, in the southern part of Vauville bay 2 miles north-eastward of cape Flamanville, has two harbours sheltered from N.E. round by East and South to S.W. by the high land, and from S.W. round by West to North by the new granite pier constructed about 360 yards westward of the old pier, and form ing the outer harbour, which is exposed to so much swell and surf that it is very little used ; but the new pier breaks the sea and greatly increases the security of the old harbour, which, however, affords anything but good grounding places. The outer harbour has in its entrance a depth of 3 feet at low water, springs ; the outer pier extends from the shore in a northerly direction 252 yards to the Rognouse rocks, which there form its foundation, and then curves eastward 155 yards to the eastern part of those rocks. The channel between the end of this pier, on which stands a lighthouse, and the shore rocks northward of it, marked by a beacon near their edge, is about 164 yards wide. The bottom of the outer harbour consists of soft sand with a few ledges of rocks one to 6 feet above the sand, which rocks were being removed in May 1881. t * See Admiralty chart : — Cape Flamanville to St. Marcouf islands, No. 1106. f Commander C. V. Anson, H.M.S. Dasher.

Chap, iv.] DIELETTE. 179 The beacon on the northern side of the channel stands on a rock which uncovers 17 feet E. by N. \ N. 197 yards from the end of the new pier, and N. £ W. 344 yards from the old pier-head. This rock is on the southern edge of the rocky bed joining the shore north eastward of the harbour, and which, in rough weather, greatly breaks the force of the sea. The channel lies in a north-westerly direction, and is narrowed by low rocky ledges, which uncover at low water a cable outside the beacon and new pier-head. In rough weather, these ledges cause a heavy sea, to be avoided by keeping in the direction of the channel, which, near the entrance of the old harbour, is suddenly narrowed by the Pierre de la Riviere, a rock dangerous to vessels working in ; it lies E. by N. \ N. 95 yards from the old pier-head. The old or inner harbour admits vessels of about 10 or 12 feet draught, at springs ; but, the entrance is so surrounded by rocks that access to it is hazardous except at high water and with a leading wind. The pier forming the old harbour is about 186 yards in length. The entrance is 72 yards wide and open to the N.N.E. ; it is between the old pier-head and the extreme of a little pile of loose stones on the steep eastern shore of the harbour. The sand at the entrance dries 16 feet above the level of the lowest tides, and from thence the bottom, of hard sand and gravel, takes a gentle ascent to the level of high water, neaps. The best position for grounding is about two thirds the length of the pier from the pier head, but, as the bottom is hard, precautions must be taken to prevent the vessel falling over. Although such extensive works have been accomplished in the construction of this harbour, a few fishing boats only belong to the port and its trade is very insignificant, being represented by about 60 small coasters, averaging 40 tons, calling annually. A. Life-Boat is stationed at port Dielette. LIGHTS. — Two fixed harbour lights are exhibited at port Dielette, and when in line S.S.E. £ E. easterly they lead through the channel to the harbour. The outer light, at the new pier-head, is a, fixed light, and shows white seaward on its opening of cape Flamanville all round to the bearing of S.S.E., and red towards the land, over the Huquets de Jobourg, and all the shoals south-westward of the Nez. When within the white light, therefore, a vessel is westward of and outside all danger. The light is 34 feet above high water, and in clear weather is visible from a distance of 9 miles. M 2

180 [Chap. IV. GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. The inner light is red and 75 feet above high water ; it stands on the shore and is shown from a mast on a wooden hut ; it is 510 yards S.S.E. £ E. easterly from the outer light, and is visible 13 miles. A small green light indicates the position of the old pier-head. Directions.— The direction of the channel leading to port Dielette is pointed out by the tops of two remarkable little conical hills, forming the northern boundary of the valley of Dielette. When within a mile of the port, open the summit of the hill on which are the ruins of an old semaphore a little northward of the summit of the other hill, and keep a good look out for the beacon, and for the lighthouse on the new pier. Steer to pass about half a cable northward of the lighthouse, and then, if bound into the old harbour, steer direct for the old pier-head, which round as closely as possible in order to avoid the Pierre de la Riviere. With moderate winds from West round by North to N.E., these directions can be followed from half an hour before to half an hour after high water by vessels drawing not more than 10 feet ; but, when the wind is fresh from that quarter, they can only enter at high water, springs. With the wind between West and South, a position should be gained south-westward of the harbour before bearing up for the lighthouse. With a head wind, the channel should not be attempted without a pilot. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in port Dielette at 6 h. 40 m. ; springs rise 27 feet, neaps 20£ feet. The tide rises above the bottom at the entrance of the inner harbour, which dries 16 feet above the level of the lowest tides, 17 feet at extraordinary springs, 14 or 15 feet at ordinary springs, and about 4 or 5 feet at neaps. ANSE de VAUVILLE, between cape Flamanville and the Nez de Jobourg, affords good shelter against all winds from South round by East to N.E. in from 4 to 12 fathoms, fine hard sand. This bay is much resorted to by merchant vessels and coasters over taken by a calm, unable to save their tide through the Race of Alderney, or waiting for sufficient water to cross the flats southward of cape de Carteret ; they should, however, be prepared to weigh and gain an offing if the wrind veers to the westward. When the wind is off-shore, and particularly from the S.E., there is a heavy surf on the beach which renders landing impossible ; but, one mile from the shore the sea is smooth and there is but little swell. At the head

Chap. IV.] ANSE DE VAUVILLE. — NEZ DE JOBOURG. 181 of the bay between Siouville and Vauville, distant from each other 4i miles, the shore at the foot of the high land is low and covered with sand-hills. NEZ DE JOBOURG.— From near Vauville, the coast rises and for about 4 miles consists of rugged cliffs 300 feet high, intersected by deep and narrow valleys, terminating westward in this high bluff promontory, 420 feet above the sea level, which may be seen in clear weather at a distance of 24 miles. There is a semaphore station on its summit, a small hummock, of which the slopes extend to the edge of the nearly perpendicular cliffs on its western side. About 1£ miles inland, eastward of the Nez, stands Jobourg church, a con spicuous and useful sea-mark. Northward of the Nez, 3 miles distant, is cape de la Hague, low and sandy ; and, south-eastward of it, the high rugged coast for 2\ miles is bordered by rocks as far as 3 cables from the shore ; of these the most dangerous are, the Huitriere, the Sidman, the Foraine, the Brequets, and the Ronde. The three first uncover from 10 to 11 feet at the lowest tides, and the Ronde 15 feet ; ' the Brequets never cover. The Dossier e Rock. — The Nez de Jobourg is surrounded by a rocky barrier extending one mile north- westward and terminating in the Basses de la Dossiere, two rocky flats having only 9 feet water on them. The Dossiere rock, 4 cables northward of the Nez, uncovers 16 feet and is the highest rock of the barrier. It gives a useful indication to the local pilots of the state of tide in the offing, as it covers at about half tide by the shore, at which time the flood or northern stream begins to be felt round the Nez and in the Race of Alderney. The Greniquet rock on with the low point of cape de la Hague leads close westward of the foul ground surrounding the Nez. South-westward and southward of the Nez de Jobourg and occupying a space of nearly 2^ miles W.N.W. and E.S.E. are several dangerous shoals, with a passage between them and the coast, of which the principal are the Huquets de Jobourg, the Basses St. Gilles, the Huquets de Vauville, and the Calenfriers. HUQUETS de JOBOURG is the general name of the whole of this rocky range, which lies parallel with and about 1£ miles from the shore, between the bearings S.W. by W. and S. by E. from the Nez de Jobourg. The highest heads at its western and eastern extremes are, the Basses St. Gilles and Huquets de Vauville.

[Chap. IV. 182 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. Basses St. Gilles are three rocky heads at the western end ; on the highest, at the north-eastern point of the Basses, there are only 7 feet water. The western head, with 19 feet, lies at the western extreme ; and the third, a small isolated rock with 5 fathoms, lies a quarter of a mile southward of the 7-feet rock. Huquets de Jobourg. — The highest rock on the central part or Huquets de Jobourg proper, between which and the St. Gilles is a passage half a mile wide with from 9 to 11 fathoms, uncovers 13 feet, The Calenfriers, two small rocks at the north-western part of the reef, uncover 2 feet. Huquets de Vauville are one third of a mile eastward of the Huquets de Jobourg and form the eastern extreme of the range ; they are of small extent, and the highest head which uncovers 15 feet, is considered a half tide rock by the pilots, who, when awaiting in Vauville bay the most favourable moment to cross Alderney race, weigh when its summit is about 2 feet above water, and gain an offing in order to pass westward of the St. Gilles. Clearing Marks. — Rosel point well open of cape Flamanville S. £ E. leads 6 cables westward of the Basses St. Gilles ; and cape de la Hague lighthouse on with the summit of the Greniquet rock N. by E. £ E. easterly leads a quarter of a mile eastward of the 7-feet head, midway between it and the Huquets de Jobourg. By night, keeping within the white sector of Dielette pier-head light leads south-westward of all the dangers. When running through the Race of Alderney from the southward, it is prudent not to shut in Rosel point, and at night not to bring cape de la Hague light more northerly than N.E. \ N. unless within an hour of high water, until well clear of these rocks. CAUTION. — The flood or north-eastern stream begins to gain strength when the Huquets de Vauville and the Dossiere rock cover, and runs with great rapidity towards the dangers just described, and over the rocky barrier surrounding the Nez de Jobourg ; a sailing vessel, therefore, entering the channel, one mile wide, which separates the Huquets de Jobourg from the coast, is liable to be set on this barrier, unless the wind is favourable and sufficiently strong to ensure her stemming the stream. Directions. — Having passed through the Race of Alderney from the northward and intending to anchor in Vauville bay, the best shelter, with the wind between N.E. and East, is on the northern side

Chap. IV.] HUQUETS DE JOBOURG. — CAPE DE LA HAGUE. 183 of the bay under the high land south-eastward of the Nez de Jobourg ; but, to avoid the dangers off the Nez, do not bring cape de la Hague lighthouse northward of N.E. \ N., and keep Rosel point well open of cape Flamanville, until the Nez bears N.E. \ E. and Vauville church E. by S. \ S., when stand in for the anchorage on the latter bearing. With the wind between East and South, the best shelter is under the high land of cape Flamanville on the southern side of the bay ; in rounding that cape, however, from the southward, care must be taken to avoid the foul ground off it, which, at night, may be done by keeping cape de la Hague light in sight westward of the Nez, or by not standing into less than 10 fathoms until well north ward of the cape, when a berth may be taken up by a bearing of port Dielette white pier-head light, observing that the light turns to red if brought southward of S.S.E. CAPE DE LA HAGUE,* the north-western extreme of Normandy, 3 miles northward of the Nez de Jobourg, is low and sandy. From it, the eastern extreme of Alderney bears W. by N. £ N. 8J miles, and the western end of Cherbourg break water is 11^ miles distant on a S.E. by E. bearing. The most con spicuous objects in the vicinity of the cape are, the lighthouse on the Gros du Raz rock W. \ S. half a mile from the cape, the tower of Jobourg church, the village of Auderville with its small church tower, not easily distinguished, and the church of St. Germain de Vaux with its square tower surmounted by a spire. LIGHT. — From the lighthouse on the Gros du Raz, the largest rock in the vicinity of cape de la Hague, is exhibited, at 154 feet above high water, a fixed ivhite light, visible in clear weather from a distance of 18 miles. The light is dioptric, of the first order, and is seldom obscured by fog or mist. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at cape de la Hague at 7h 6m. IV. 184 DANGERS surrounding Cape de la Hague— From l\ miles southward of the lighthouse to the roches du Houses, one mile eastward of the cape, the coast is skirted by many dangers, rendered all the more formidable by the violence of the tidal streams in their vicinity. Local pilots, under favourable circumstances, sometimes take vessels of less than 15 feet draught alongshore between the detached rocks and the beach, for, during fine weather, the tides there are less rapid and the sea less disturbed than in the wide channel of the Alderney Race. No vessel, however, should attempt this passage without an experienced pilot. The principal dangers in the vicinity are the Greniquet, Diotret, Foraine, and Noires ledges, lying westward and southward of the cape ; and, the Grunes, Becchue, Ronde, and Houffet rocks, lying northward and eastward of it. The Greniquet, of which the summit is 8 feet above high water, springs, is 3 cables from the shore abreast of Calenfrier, and S. by W. £ W. westerly one mile from the lighthouse. The Diotret bears N.N.E. 3J cables from the Greniquet, and its summit, which is 26^ feet above low water, is covered at high equinoctial tides. The Foraine, the westernmost rock, is nearly a mile from the shore immediately fronting the little harbour of Goury, and W. £ S. three quarters of a mile from the lighthouse, with Cape de la Hague semaphore appearing thrice the width of the lighthouse south ward of it. The rock is of a conical form, uncovers 14 feet, and, being a half -tide rock, is a valuable guide for the state of the tidal streams ; for, as with the Dossiere near the Nez de Jobourg, when it covers, the north-eastern stream begins to be felt in the Race of Alderney, and the south-western stream when it uncovers ; this rock is, however, extremely dangerous to vessels passing in its vicinity, on account of the streams setting directly over it. The steeple of Pieux church, on the high land eastward of cape Flamanville, on with the large rock forming the extreme of the Nez de Jobourg leads 3 cables westward of the Foraine, but this church being 13 miles distant from the rock, is visible in very clear weather only. The valley of the Dielette open westward of the Nez de Jobourg, or Flamanville church steeple midway between cape Flamanville and the Nez, also leads westward of the Foraine rock.

Chap, iv.] DANGERS ROUND CAPE DE LA HAGUE. 185 Buoy. — An automatic whistle buoy, painted red, is moored with the Foraine rock bearing South a little easterly about 3 cables, and cape de la Hague lighthouse E. £ S. about 8 cables. The Noires. — The space north-eastward of the Foraine, between it and the Gros du Raz, is filled with shoals and rocks called the Noires, of which the highest, midway between the lighthouse and the Foraine, uncovers 21 feet. The Galet, a sunken rock with only one foot water, lies N.N.E. half a mile from the lighthouse. The Grunes. — The Grande Grune, a dangerous reef with only 2 feet water on the shoalest part, lies N.E. by N. about three quarters of a mile from the lighthouse and half a mile from the shore. The Petite Grune is about 3-^ cables eastward of the Grande Grune ; it is about a quarter of a mile in length N.E. and S.W., and has on its middle two rocky heads which uncover about a foot. It is about half a mile from the shore, and the sea breaks with great fury during a weather tide both on it and on the Grande Grune. The Becchue, a large rock about 4 cables from the shore and E. by N. 1-f miles from the lighthouse, is the northernmost of all the rocks which do not cover between the lighthouse and St. Martin bay ; its summit rises 4 feet above the level of high water, springs. At low water, a number of rocky heads appear in a curcuit of a quarter of a mile around the Becchue ; the Porchet, the westernmost of these heads, uncovers 4 feet and is about midway between the Becchue and Petite Grune. The Ronde, N.E. by N. 2 cables from the Becchue, uncovers 5 feet and is the outermost rock in this direction. At 4 cables S.E. by E. from the Becchue is the outer extreme of the Houffet rocks, on which are several heads 3 or 4 feet above the level of high water, springs. Clearing Marks. — Cape de la Hague lighthouse on with the pitch of the cliff of the Nez de Jobourg leads a quarter of a mile westward of the Grande Grune. The north-eastern extreme of the Houffet rocks on with the Esquina rock near the eastern shore of St. Martin bay, the largest and highest of all the rocks near the coast between cape de la Hague and Omonville, bearing S.E. E., leads a cable northward of the northern head of the Petite Grune. The

S. leads north ward of the Houffets, 3^ cables northward of the Ronde, and three quarters of a mile northward of the Grunes. GOURY. — This little harbour, or grounding place on a beach of pebbles and gravel at the head of a small elbow in the shore, is about half a mile southward of cape de la Hague lighthouse ; it is sheltered by the land from winds from N.N.W. round by North and East to S.S.W., and protected from the heavy swell which sometimes rolls in from the westward by a stone jetty about 123 yards in length, and by the rocks upon which it is built. The harbour affords a useful shelter for small coasters, and the supplies for the lighthouse are embarked from it, but it has no trade of the least importance. The entrance, bearing E. | N. 3 cables from the Diotret rock, is between two large rocks joining the shore ; that on the southern side, named Jet d'Amont, is awash at high water, neaps ; and, that on the northern side, Jet d'Aval, is about 2 feet above that level. The harbour dries 11 or 12 feet above the lowest tides, has from 10 to 15 feet water at high water, springs, and from 6 to 7 feet at neaps, but it is inaccessible during strong N.W. or S.W. winds on account of the heavy sea ; in any case, since it can only be entered at high water, that is to say, when the stream is at its greatest speed in the Race of Alderney, the approach to it must always be difficult and often dangerous, and no vessel should attempt it without a pilot. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in Goury harbour, at 7 h. 6 m. ; springs rise 22 feet, neaps 17£ feet. A Life-Boat is stationed at Goury. DIRECTIONS— COTENTIN PASS AGE— Between Cape de la Hague and Granville. — This passage is along the western coast of the peninsula of Cotentin and over the sandy flat which extends from the shore nearly the whole of the distance between cape de Carteret and Granville. Coasters use it at all times of tide, but sailing vessels of deep draught bound to Granville seldom attempt it, as it can only be done with a leading wind sufficiently strong to stem the flood stream with which they have to contend at the time that harbour is accessible, and they must also wait for water over the flats between the Banes Feles and the coast ; large vessels generally take the Deroute channel, passing westward of Jersey and of the Minquiers. The streams in the Cotentin passage run nearly parallel with the

Chap. IV.] GOURY. — COTENTIN PASSAGE. 187 shore, their strength, at springs, being from 4 to 5 knots, and from 2\ to 3 knots at neaps. Winds between South and East are the most favourable for entering the passage from the southward, and between North and East from the northward. In fine weather, a vessel bound northward may run through it with the wind from South to S.W., and, if bound southward, with the wind from North to N.W. ; but, it is imprudent to enter it from either direction with the wind blowing strongly between S.W. and N.W., or in thick weather. In running through this passage from the northward, it must be borne in mind that the south-western stream begins to be felt in the Race of Alderney at half ebb by the shore at cape de la Hague, or about 4 hours after high water at Granville or St. Malo ; and, that even if the Race is passed through during the last of the north eastern stream, it is quite impossible to reach Granville before low water in the passage, at which time there is not sufficient depth for a vessel of deep draught over the flat between the Banes Feles and the shore, and she must of necessity anchor to wait for sufficient water, which there will not be until at least one quarter flood, at springs, when there are about 24 feet in the fairway with the leading mark on, and 7 feet over the shoalest part of the Banes Feles. Anchorage. — Several anchorages with fair shelter against easterly winds exist along this coast, but the leading marks should be care fully attended to ; and, in case of thick weather wdien these cannot be discerned, vessels should anchor in such a depth as to allow for the fall of the tide, which, along this coast, is as much as from 30 to 42 feet at equinoctial springs, and from 14 to 20 feet at ordinary neaps, the greatest rise and fall being experienced as a vessel pro gresses southward. If waiting for water to cross the Feles flats, anchorage may be found, as already described, in Vauville or Sciotot bays, or under cape de Carteret. The best position at the latter place is in 4 or 5 fathoms, with the lighthouse just open westward of the fort on the western pitch of the cape, and distant about 2 miles. There is anchorage also farther South in Port Bail, St. Germain, and Regneville roads, but these can be used by small vessels only, as there are not more than from 2\ to 3 fathoms in either at low water. From the Northward, having passed through the Race, and having given the Nez de Jobourg a berth of at least 3 miles to avoid the Huquets de Jobourg, steer for cape Flamanville, and from thence, as the vessel advances southward, keep the perpendicular point of the Nez well open westward of cape Flamanville, so as to

IV. 188 GRANVILLE TO CAPE DE LA HAGUE. have cape de la Hague lighthouse also open of the Nez, which leads westward of the Basse Bihard, the outer patch of the Bane de Surtain ville, and westward of the Roches-du-Rit. When abreast of the latter, Port Bail and Gouey churches come in sight southward of cape de Carteret, then haul in gradually towards the land to avoid the Trois-Grunes and to shut in the north-western peak of the lofty light-coloured sand-hills of Hatainville, with the dark, bluff, and nearly perpendicular point of cape de Carteret N. £ E., which is the fairway mark between the Banes Feles and the coast, see also page 171, leading over the tail of these banks in from 12 to 15 feet at the lowest tides. If there is water enough to proceed, keep this leading mark on, passing 3 or 4 cables eastward of the red and black bell buoy marking the Jourdan ridge, and westward of the foul ground off the Senequet rock lighthouse ; but, in passing this foul ground, the vessel must haul to the westward a little and Hatainville sand-hills must be again opened out. Cape Flamanville on with cape de Carteret leads just clear south eastward of the tail of the Banes Feles in deeper water than the leading mark given ; but, if this latter mark is used, directly the banks have been passed the Hatainville sand-hills should be brought on with cape de Carteret as before. Rosel point in sight westward of cape de Carteret leads nearly midway between the Jourdan ridge and the foul ground off the Senequet, but at this distance Rosel point, having high land behind it, is not always well defined. When passing the Senequet rock, having hauled to the westward as described, steer to bring Champeaux point just open of pointe du Roc, Granville, bearing South, which, if the state of the tide and the vessel's draught admit, leads up to pointe du Roc, in-shore of the Catheue banks ; but, as the vessel advances southward, if there is not sufficient water over the banks, look out for the remarkable trees on Mont Huchon, about 2 miles northward of Coutances, and do not bring them on with Agon church until the Etat beacon turret, Chausey, is on with the iles des Huguenans S. by W. \ W. This mark leads westward of Catheue banks, and when Coutances cathedral comes on with Bee d'Agon or Agon point, steer towards Granville, and, after passing the Canue rock, keep the Etat well open northward of it until Mont St. Michel is within twice its breadth of Champeaux point bearing S. \ E., or until Coutances cathedral is on with Mont Martin church N.E. by E. \ E., either of which marks lead eastward of the Admiralty bank. When Chausey lighthouse opens southward of the iles des

As early as 2 hours' flood there will be 11 feet over the Catheue, the Founet, and the Haguet banks. French pilots generally proceed through the Cotentin passage as follows : — By day, run through Alderney Race if possible during the last of the north-eastern stream : then, if the vessel's draught be not too great to pass without risk between the Banes Feles and the land at low water, steer to the southward for cape Flamanville, and, passing it, bring Jobourg church steeple on with the extreme of the cape N. by E. \ E. ; this mark kept very carefully on leads eastward of the Basse Bihard, and of the Caillou rock, and over the Bane de Surtainville in not less than 3 fathoms. When the steeples of Port Bail and Gouey open of cape de Carteret steer S.S.E., so as to be about 2\ miles from that cape when it is on with cape Flamanville bearing North. From thence, capes de Carteret and Flamanville in line lead between the Banes Feles and the main, and as far southward as the Senequet ; but, when abreast of St. Germain, a vessel may sheer in a little towards the coast and anchor north-westward of the Sac-de- Pirou rocks, to avoid the strength of the northern stream ; or, if the wind is strong enough, she can proceed, steering about S. by W. \ W. to pass midway between the Jourdan and the western extreme of the foul ground off the Senequet, In case the bell buoy marking the Jourdan should be out of position, she will be certain of passing eastward of that shoal by keeping the Hatainville sand-hills shut in by cape de Carteret. As soon as Coutances cathedral is on with Blainville church, steer S.W. between the Marie ledge and the northern extreme of the Catheue banks, and continue on this course until Agon church tower is on with Mont Huchon E. i N., or until the beacon turrets on the Huguenans and the Etat are made out ; when, kept in line, they lead up in the fairway. If bound to Granville, run on with these beacon turrets in line until the Tombelaine rock opens a sail's breadth west ward of Champeaux point S. £ E. ; keep it so, and after passing the Founet, marked by a red bell buoy, steer for the harbour according to wind and tide. This latter mark is generally used by the pilots, as they consider it leads in the deepest water over the sandy bed north-westward of Granville and over the bar which unites Le Roc with the Chausey islets, and also clears the dangers eastward of these islets as well as those surrounding pointe du Roc

At Night, when through Alderney Race, and having given the Nez de Jobourg a berth of at least 3 miles, steer towards cape Flamanville ; as that cape is approached, keep cape de la Hague light opening and shutting in with the Nez N. by E. easterly, which mark leads a safe distance westward of the Basse Bihard, but directly towards the Trois-Grunes. To avoid these latter, when cape de Carteret light bears S.E. by S. steer towards it on that bearing for H miles, when the vessel will be about 34; miles from the light and H miles from the north-western edge of the Roches-du-Rit, From thence, steer S. by W. until the light bears E. | N., then S.S.E. \ E. until it bears North, when keep it on that bearing and steer South past the south-eastern end of the Banes Feles, of which banks the vessel will be clear as soon as Port Bail leading lights are in line bearing N.E. by E. \ E. Cotentin Passage from the Southward.— Vessels from Granville bound to harbours eastward of cape de la Hague or on the northern side of the English channel, if their draught admits and with a leading wind, generally run through the Cotentin passage. 193 CHAPTER V. THE CHANNEL ISLANDS; JERSEY, WITH ITS APPROACHES AND ADJACENT DANGERS. VARIATION IN 1888, 17° 50' W. GENERAL REMARKS.— A section of Jersey, if taken from North to South, would decline nearly in the form of a wedge, of which the highest part would be the northern shore, whereas a section of Guernsey would decline in a contrary direction, or from South to North ; yet these distinguishing features do not immediately appear on sighting these islands from the westward. Seen from that direction, at a distance, both islands appear level ; the low land of Braye du Valle in Guernsey, and that of St. Clement in Jersey, being yet below the horizon. The outline of Guernsey, however, is some what more irregular than that of Jersey, and its western shore has more verdure, and appears of a deeper shade than Jersey, whose western shores have suffered considerably from the encroachments of the sea sand ; so much so, that the colour of the land between Corbiere and Etac points is affected by it.* Both islands may be seen in clear weather from a distance of 25 miles. As the land is approached from the westward, however, the northerly slope of the land in Guernsey, as contrasted with its southerly slope in Jersey, should prevent the possibility of either island being mistaken for the other. Winds and Weather. — The prevailing winds of the English channel, see page 2, are those which affect the weather of the Channel islands ; local causes, however, produce certain modifications, and it may be useful to give the result of local observation and experience. Winds from S.S.E. round by South to W.N.W. are prevalent during the winter months, and the latter predominate ; fortunately, against the severity of this wind both Jersey and Guernsey offer good shelter for shipping. During the summer months and equinoxes, the winds are variable and uncertain. * See Admiralty charts : — Channel islands, Nos. 2,669 a, b ; scale m = 0'5 inch and, Jersey island, No. 62 a, b, and e with Views ; scale m = it) inches. Note. — The soundings in this Chapter are reduced to a zero corresponding with the range of a 37 feet tide ; the lowest tide registered in Jersey between 1861 and 1869 fell 22 inches below that level. A 2771. Wt. 7242. N

[Chap. v. 194 THE CHANNEL ISLANDS. When easterly winds set in during the winter season, they are thought to last longer and to blow with more uniformity in this neighbourhood than elsewhere. Southerly and south-westerly winds, during that period, are almost always accompanied or followed by stormy weather, which seldom or never clears up until the wind veers to North-west, as it usually does. The weather in the vicinity of Alderney does not always correspond with that at Jersey and Guernsey ; it being frequently local or peculiar to itself, owing perhaps to its proximity to the north-western angle of the French coast at Cape de la Hague, or to the island being in the very vortex of the tides, which are there in a constant state of rotation, especially at new and full moon. At those times, a difference of four points in the direction of the wind has been experienced ; viz., an E. by N. wind at Guernsey and Serk, and a N.E. by N. wind at Alderney, both blowing at the same time during a south-western tide, lightly or moderately in the neighbourhood of the former, while vessels near Alderney were under double-reefed sails. During the north-eastern stream, the wind has often been observed to be S.W. by W. at Alderney, while at Herm it was West, with similar variety in strength ; and this without any perceptible cause, the attraction of the tides or deflection caused by the French coast line excepted, or any difference in the barometer at the two places. Southerly, south-easterly, northerly, and north-easterly winds also invariably blow from Alderney in strong irregular gusts ; more parti cularly the first and last. Gales from S.W. and N.W. send in the heaviest sea amongst the islands, to which the strength of the tides greatly contributes ; the worst period is from half flood to half ebb, after which the western stream keeps much of the sea out in the offing. Refraction. — To show the variable effects of refraction caused by atmospheric conditions, it may be noticed that from a station near Verclut guard-house in Jersey, the top of the south-eastern battlement of Seymour tower should exactly coincide with the line of the visible horizon at low water, equinoctial spring tides ; sometimes, however, when viewed from this position, it has appeared considerably below that line, and in several instances above it. In this case the line of sight passes over the rocky surface of the Violet bank, over the sandy strand in its vicinity, and over the sea beyond, being at a mean height of 64 feet above it. Similiar variations in refraction have been observed on the French coast opposite, between the steeples of Coutances cathedral and the summits of the trees in that neighbour hood, and also in the vicinity of Cancale.

Chap. V.] WINDS AND WEATHER. — APPROACHES. — SOUNDINGS. 195 The Approaches to the Channel islands present'jpeculiar diffi culties to the stranger. The outlying rocks fronting their coasts, the strength and ever varying direction of the tidal stream, and the rough sea occasioned by it in bad weather, are all elements of danger ; the mariner may, however, overcome these difficulties by careful study of the charts and attention to the sailing directions. Soundings. — Near and between the Channel islands there is nothing remarkable in the soundings, either in depth or quality of ground, to assist the mariner uncertain of his position. But, for vessels approaching from the westward in thick weather, it may be useful to note the following facts : viz., that a depth of 35 fathoms keeps a vessel in the offing, outside or westward of the Roches- Douvres and Guernsey ; that there are as much as 33 fathoms between Guernsey and the Casquets, close to the Casquet S.W. bank on which there are as little as 4 fathoms ; and that, although on some small gravel knolls near Hurd's Deep, apparently heaped up temporarily by the combined action of gales and tides, there may have been found at times as little as 20 fathoms, such knolls, if they exist, may be easily distinguished from the large banks near and amongst the islands by their inferior size and by the greater surrounding depths. An increase of depth from 40 to 50, or to 65 fathoms, indicates a position N.W. of Guernsey, somewhere in the western part of Hurd's Deep ; and, depths of from 70 to nearly 100 fathoms are obtained only northward of the Casquets and Alderney, in the eastern part of the Deep. The bottom of Hurd's Deep is remarkable for large patches of black mud, although there is also much rocky ground and other substances. Between the Deep and the islands, and amongst them, the ground has no distinctive character, but consists of rock, gravel, granitic sand, and other coarse ground ; near the banks, however, and round their bases, it is generally of fine sand. Eastward of the Channel islands, from Alderney down to Jersey, the soundings are a safe guide in approaching the French coast to within a reasonable distance. A line drawn from the eastern end of one to the other of these islands is nearly parallel with the French coast and distant from it about 9 miles ; at the northern part of this line, near Alderney, there are 23 fathoms over clean ground, decreasing to 15 or 16 fathoms as Jersey is approached, with some deeper w-ater, coarse rotten ground, and occasionally oyster beds. Eastward of this line, the water shoals very gradually towards the French coast, and southward of Jersey the numerous reefs render all approach to that coast very hazardous. N 2

196 [Chap. V. THE CHANNEL ISLANDS. Heavy gales cause considerable temporary alterations in the outlying sand-banks and exposed beaches of the islands ; south westerly gales heaping up large quantities of sand and shingle, and north-easterly gales washing them away again. It is well known that the Chateau and Ecreviere banks, eastward of Jersey, vary in height as much as 6 feet from this cause ; and, it is probable, therefore, that the Bane de la Schole, the Casquet bank, and others, vary from similar causes. All these variable banks, however, consist of fine sand and gravel, with sharp narrow ridges ; they are not, therefore, very dangerous to shipping, except from the confused sea and tide ripples over them in bad weather. TIDAL STREAMS.*— Near Guernsey, and northward of that island', the true Channel stream prevails ; the great body of the flood running about E. by N. whilst the tide is rising at Dover, and the ebb W.S.W. when it is falling at that place ; but, near to and south eastward of the Roches-Douvres, the flood stream sets S.E. into the gulf of St. Malo, and the ebb N.W. out of it ; the change there taking place an hour after high and low water by the shore, and near the time of half Hood and half ebb at Dover. Thus what is called tide and half tide prevails at Guernsey and amongst the islands to the N.E., whilst at Jersey, and along the southern shore of the gulf, as well as westward near the Roches- Douvres, the stream is more regular ; the former resulting from the direct action of the channel stream, the latter from an interruption of the southern portion of that stream by the coast of France, and its diversion into the gulf of St. Malo. The centre of the Deroute channel, between the Roches-Douvres and Guernsey, may be considered to mark the separating boundary of these two streams, for, along this line and to the eastward they run side by side, blending and separating in varying direction and force according to the state of the tide. It should be noted that the tidal stream around and between the Channel islands changes in direction by a rotary motion from right to left, the changes being apparently caused by the differences in the action of the two streams just described, and by the peculiar form of the shores of the gulf ; that is to say, the direction of the stream makes a complete circuit of the compass in a little over 12 hours, or in the duration of an ebb and a flood tide. It is also worthy of remark that the action of the streams near the northern and southern parts of the gulf, are nearly the * Sœ also Tidal streams, pages 265-267 and 271-274.

Chap, v.] TIDAL STREAMS. 197 reverse of each other ; there being slack water from Roches-Douvres eastward along the southern shores of the gulf when the stream is running at its maximum rate northward of cape de La Hague and Alderney, and vice versa. About the time of half ebb at Dover and first quarter flood by the shore at Guernsey, the stream sets sharply into the gulf on both sides and continues to run in south-eastward until half flood by the shore, and slack and change of stream in the offing, both of which occur almost simultaneously with low water at Dover. A division of the Deroute stream now takes place ; the northern part sweeping E.N.E. through the Deroute, Russell, Swinge, and Race channels, and then uniting with the east-going Channel stream northward of Alderney ; the southern part, near the Roches-Douvres, setting into the gulf south-eastward past Jersey and the Minquiers until near high water by the shore ; after which, although the main body of the stream to the southward slacks, its northern border turns off north eastward past Jersey and then northward, rejoining the Deroute stream. Close along the southern shore of the gulf, the ebb stream begins to run out westward soon after high water ; farther out in the Channel, but within the Roches-Douvres, an hour later ; at a position 8 miles N.W. of the Roches-Douvres, the stream changes at 2 hours ebb ; and, farther northward, near Guernsey, as already noticed, the slack and change of stream take place soon after half ebb by the shore, at which time also the south-western stream makes down through the Race, Swinge, and Russell channels, and through the Deroute channel between the Pierres de Lecq or Paternosters and Serk. In the offing westward of Guernsey, the stream seldom exceeds 3 knots until that island is approached, near which it sometimes attains the rate of 4| knots. In the Russell channels, it exceeds 5 knots, and it runs at about the same rate between Jersey and the Minquiers, and nearly 4 knots in the centre of the Deroute channel between Jersey and Serk. The Race and Swinge streams sometimes attain the rate of 7 knots or more. The average duration of the north-eastern stream is 5£ hours, and of the south-western stream 6£ hours. The rapidity with which the tides rise and fall, and their velocity, are greatly influenced by the wind ; strong north-eastern gales retarding and south-western gales accelerating their progress in a very remarkable degree. South-westerly gales also cause the Race stream to run three quarters of an hour longer north-eastward than it otherwise would do, though north-easterly gales have not a similar effect upon the south-western stream.

198 [Chap. V. THE CHANNEL ISLANDS. The tides put in and take off in all this neighbourhood very sud denly, and the general run of springs takes place about half an hour earlier than neaps ; the strength and direction of the wind making a difference of 2 or 3 feet in the rise or fall of the tide. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at St. Helier, Jersey, at 6 h. 29 m., mean spring range 31^ feet ; at Guernsey at 6 h. 37 m., mean spring range 26 feet ; and, at Alderney, at 6 h. 46 m., mean spring range 17+. feet. Caution. — In approaching the Channel islands, constant and careful allowance should be made for the set of the tidal stream. If from the westward, and being southward of the parallel of Alderney, a south-easterly set may with certainty be expected, which will increase in intensity as Guernsey is neared ; and, between that island and the Roches-Douvres, a considerable indraught is always found, especially with north-westerly gales. If a vessel should happen to be near the islands during a long winter's night, but westward withal, the following observations might be worth consideration. With northerly, north-westerly, or westerly winds, it is not prudent to lay her head north-eastward betw*een low water and half flood unless the depth of water exceeds 34 fathoms, because at that time the wind and tide unite in driving the ship south-eastward. With southerly, south-westerly, or westerly winds, it is equally imprudent to lay a vessel's head south-eastward between half flood and high water, and for a similar reason, both wind and tide then driving her north-eastward. With easterly winds the islands become a weather shore, and may consequently be made free with as occasion may require ; and, by attention to the set of the streams, a position taken before dark may be preserved within 3 or 4 miles, if a vessel can carry close-reefed topsails and foresail ; what is lost on one tide being nearly regained on the other, if the wind enables her to lie across either. This calculation may be made with a degree of certainty off St. Malo, Granville, or cape Flamanville. When making the Casquets or any of the rocks or islands in thick foggy weather, never run close home with the stream, but wait until the turn of the tide would set you off-shore in the event of getting suddenly into danger. In westerly gales, avoid passing close to windward of any of the banks on a weather tide ; and, it is well to remember that at such times, with the western stream running in the offing, there is a very heavy se westward of the islands, but comparatively smooth water

Chap, v.] 199 TIDAL STREAMS. — JERSEY. within them and along the coast of France ; so that a vessel leaving Alderney at 2 hours ebb, and pushing through the Race before the W.S.W. stream makes down, may run a considerable distance towards Jersey in smooth water. On entering or leaving any of the narrow channels between the islands, be careful to make early allowance for the different sets of tide sure to be met with at such places. JERSEY, ITS APPROACHES AND ADJACENT DANGERS. JERSEY. — The form of this island is that of a parallelogram, its greatest length E.S.E. and W.N.W. being 94. miles, and its breadth 5£ miles. The middle of the island, in an E.S.E. and W.N.W. direction, presents a uniform level surface about 280 feet above the mean height of the sea, its northern shore being from 100 to 150 feet higher. Jersey thus, as already described, slopes to the southward, and to this circumstance may probably be attributed the pre-eminence it enjoys in the richness of its productions, its luxuriance, and the peculiar mildness of its climate. Granite and syenitic rocks are the principal formations. The interior is well wooded, fertile, and intersected by deep and beautiful valleys running from South to North, through which numerous streams find their way to the 1owt land on the southern coast ; several occasionally uniting before discharging themselves into the sea. Jersey possesses several good bays or roadsteads besides its artificial harbours. The best anchorages are in Gorey roads on the eastern side of the island, and in St. Aubin bay on its south-eastern coast ; in either of these, a good and well found ship may ride out the heaviest gales from any quarter in safety. The principal artificial harbour, fully described at page 210, is at St. Helier, the chief town of the island, at the eastern side of St. Aubin bay. There are also smaller harbours at St. Aubin on the western side of the bay, at Gorey, at Rozel, and at other places, but they all dry at low water, springs. Jersey has its own legislature, the States, consisting of the Lieut.- Governor and the Bailiff of the Royal Court, appointed by the Crown ; twelve Jurats (Judges) of the Royal Court, elected for life by the rate-payers ; the Rectors of the twelve Parishes into which the island is divided, and the Constables of the same ; also a Deputy for each parish, St. Helier having three Deputies, elected in the same manner but for three years only. Appeals lie to the Queen in Council.

[Chap. V. 200 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. This island, like Guernsey and Alderney, is, for ecclesiastical pur poses, in the diocese of Winchester. Each parish has its own church, the spires of which serve as the principal landmarks. The old Norman French is the language chiefly spoken, but English is rapidly coming into use. The population of the island, according to the census of 1881, amounted to 52,445 ; of which number, about 28,000 form the population of St. Helier. A great part of the island is laid out in orchards, cider and apples being among its chief exports; Jersey cattle, as also granite, red gravel, china clay, vegetables, and fruit are exported, and early potatoes are raised in large quantities for the London market. The chief imports are grain, flour, and cattle from France ; and, timber from Sweden, Norway, and North America. Ship-building was formerly carried on with great success, and Jersey produced some very fine and fast vessels of from 500 to 1,200 tons burthen, but since 1870 this trade has been in a state of decay. In that year, 446 vessels and one steam-tug belonged to the island, measuring 48,812 tons in the aggregate and employing 4,014 seamen ; sixty of these vessels, manned by about 600 seamen, were employed in, or connected with, the Newfoundland cod fishery. Telegraph cables. — The telegraph cable connecting Jersey with Guernsey, and thus with England, is landed a little eastward of Grosnez point. That connecting Jersey with France is laid from Fliquet bay to Pirou ; see pages 168, 249. PILOTS. — The following is extracted from the Law on Pilotage issued by the States of the island of Jersey in January 1857, and still in force : — " The master of every vessel bound to this island, and arrived one mile West of the Corbiere rock, shall lay his vessel to, as soon as a pilot is in sight, and take a pilot on board as soon as one presents himself, on pain of paying such pilot the highest rate of pilotage. " Fishing boats and vessels admeasuring forty tons and less shall not be liable to take a pilot, but all other vessels employed in the coasting trade shall be liable to do so, paying half the pilotage dues when it has been ascertained that they are employed in the coasting trade only, unless it be otherwise provided by the tariff. " When the weather is so stormy as to prevent a pilot from boarding a vessel at sea, the master of such vessel and the pilot shall so steer that the pilot boat may take the lead and serve as a guide, and such vessel shall be liable to the same pilotage dues as if the pilot had boarded her.

Chap, v.] GOVERNMENT. — PILOTS. — ASPECT. 201 "Any pilot passing a vessel coming to the island shall be liable to a penalty of five pounds sterling, unless such vessel have already a pilot on board, or the weather is so stormy as to prevent the pilot boarding her. " Every pilot shall have a flag striped horizontally red and white, 6 feet long and 4 wide, which, on boarding a vessel and taking charge, he shall direct the master thereof to hoist at the peak as a signal that a pilot is on board, under the penalty of five pounds sterling against the master refusing to do so. " Any pilot undertaking to pilot a vessel shall, when required so to do, exhibit to the master or mate of such vessel his warrant, together with this law and tariff annexed thereto, under the penalty of thirty shillings." ASPECT OF JERSEY.*— The first objects distinguishable on approaching Jersey from the westward are, the churches of St. Peter and St. Ouen, St. Ouen windmill with St. Peter's barracks, an extensive range of buildings on the sandy heights, and now and then the turret of St. Mary's church, together with Prince's tower or Hougue Bie, appear among the trees in the interior of the island. St. Peter and St. Ouen churches stand high : the spire of the former is lofty, the latter has only a tower. On a nearer view, the lighthouse on the Corbiere rock and then Rocco fort and towTer and the four martello towers on the sandy beach in St. Ouen bay present themselves, as also the tower on l'Etac point and the remark able rock, known as the Pinnacle, between that point and Grosnez point ; and finally, the declining land to the south-eastward, with its well-wooded surface and its shore of sand and rock. Jersey is encompassed by dangers rendered doubly formidable by the great rise and fall, as well as by the rapidity, of the tides. On the north-western and western sides are the Bane Desormes, Rigdon bank, and the shoals surrounding the Corbiere rock ; but the most remarkable are, the Pierres de Lecq or Pater-Nosters, the Drouilles, and the Ecrehos, on the northern and north-eastern sides ; the Violet bank surrounding the south-eastern angle ; and, the Minquiers ledge, from 7 to 10 miles distant, with many other rocks, fronting the whole of its southern shores.
