The descriptions of the other reefs and shores of the island com mencing on the N.W., with the Bane Desormes, follow successively the western, southern, eastern, and northern coasts. Bane Desormes, 3^ miles N. \ W. from Grosnez point, and the same distance from the highest of the Pierres de Lecq rocks, is a bank of rocky ground one mile long N.N.W. and S.S.E. and a third of a mile wide ; the depths are generally from 12 to 15 fathoms, except near its extremes, where are two conical masses of rock, that on the northern end having 23 feet water, and that on the southern end 1\ fathoms. The latter bears from the former S.S.E. distant three quarters of a mile. On the 23-feet rock, which is small and pointed, with from 9 to 12 fathoms close around, the white house on La Moye is only just shut in behind the outer part of Pinnacle point S. \ W. ; and, the south western high rock of the Pierres de Lecq shut in with Belle Hougue point, nearly to the outer part of its high bluff, bears S.E. La Moye white house on with Rocco tower, South a little easterly, leads westward ; Tour de Rozel just shut in with Belle Hougue point S.E. \ E. leads southward ; and, the Corbiere rock just in sight outside the Pinnacle S. by W. \ W. leads eastward of the Bane Desormes. Grosnez point is the high precipitous bluff at the north western extreme of the island ; from it, St. Martin's point, Guernsey, the nearest point of that island, bears N.N.W. \ W. westerly 14£ miles. On the summit of the point are the ruins of an old fort. From Grosnez point, the land trends eastward towards Plemont point and the northern side of Jersey, and southward towards St. Ouen bay ; in this direction, the coast continues high and rugged nearly as far as l'Etac point, southward of which the high land recedes from the shore. ST. OUEN BAY forms the western coast of Jersey between l'Etac point and the Corbiere. As already described, its shores are low and sandy, but quickly rising to the level of the plateau of the interior. Southward of St. Peter's barracks, standing conspicuously on the high land, is the Quenvais, an extensive district covered with sand and forming a remarkable feature on this coast, Anchorage.— St. Ouen bay affords good shelter in easterly winds, but no vessel should anchor in it with the wind from the westward. The greater part of the bay being rocky and foul, the anchorage is limited to a space about half a mile square near the southern part, between the Great bank and Rocco tower ; here a vessel is well

Chap, v.] 203 ST. OUEN BAY. sheltered from the tide, and may lie in about 7 fathoms, sandy bottom, with St. Ouen mill a little open northward of the square fort on the beach, between Nos. 2 and 3 towers, bearing E. by N. £ N. northerly. The anchorage is easy of access and may be safely entered by large vessels without pilots. An extensive reef, dry at low water, stretches off 7 cables westward of the Rocco tower, and from thence extends alongshore southward in the direction of the Corbiere rock, which it unites with Corbiere point; the whole of this reef is covered before high water except a small rocky mass near the middle. Between the Rocco tower and l'Etac, there is a fine beach of white sand, but, at low water, it is fringed with rocks throughout, and off l'Etac point it dries out for three quarters of a mile ; the greater part covers before half flood and no part is visible at high water. Rigdon Bank, of which the outer edge is nearly 2 miles west ward of l'Etac point, consists of ridges of rocks, the interstices being filled up with sand and gravel ; it is about a mile long, E.N.E. and W.S.W., and 2 cables wide. The general depth is from 3 to 5 fathoms but two rocks have only 11 feet over them ; of these, one is near the middle, the other at the north-eastern extreme. The bank is very steep-to on the outside, and between it and the Etac reef is the Swash way channel, about a third of a mile wide, with a general depth of 6 fathoms ; this channel is frequently used by vessels of from 200 to 300 tons. Plemont and Grosnez points in line E. £ S. lead northward of Rigdon bank. La Moye white house midway between Flat and Sharp rocks S.S.E. southerly, or St. Peter's spire open southward of No. 2 martello tower S.E. £ E., leads south-westward ; and, St. Peter's spire open eastward of No. 1 martello tower S.E. £ S. leads north eastward of it, The best leading mark through the Swrashway between Rigdon bank and the Etac reef is, the highest heads of the Pierres de Lecq or Paternoster rocks about half a point open of Grosnez bluff N.E. by E. £E. West rock, called by some of the fishermen Grey bank, is li miles westward of Rigdon bank ; it is a mass of rock, very steep on the outside, 1^ cables long N.E. and S.W., and more than a cable wide, on which are from 7 to 10 fathoms except near the middle where there are only 6 fathoms. From this spot, St. Peter's spire a little open northward of the small square fort on the beach bears S.E. by E. -}• E. easterly ; and, the highest of the Pierres de Lecq is open 8° of

The channel between West rock and Rigdon bank is more than a mile wide, quite clear, and has from 12 to 17 fathoms water. Great bank extends N.N.W. \ W. 1^ miles from the Corbiere rock, and is 3 cables wide. It consists entirely of sand and has from 7 to 9 fathoms except at two spots where are narrow ridges of fine sand with as little as 5 or h\ fathoms. The outer ridge is at the northern extreme of the bank, close to deep water, and is about 2 cables long E.S.E. and W.N.W. ; its centre bears N.N.W. \ W. westerly \\ miles from Corbiere lighthouse. The inner ridge is similar to the outer, but only about half the length ; its centre bears N.W. £ N. 9 cables from Corbiere lighthouse. Between the ridges, there is a good channel in to the anchorage, rather more than half a mile wide, with regular soundings of from 8 to 9 fathoms, sand. St. Ouen mill a third of the distance between No. 2 tower and the small square fort southward of it, on the beach, bearing E. by N., touches the northern extreme of the Great bank. The Jument, a whitewashed rock Z\ cables eastward of the Corbiere, touching the inner side of the Corbiere S.E. 4. S. leads westward ; and, the Jument on with the high-water rock midway between Corbiere rock and point, S.S.E., leads eastward. St. Ouen mill a little open northward of the square fort E. by N. £ N. northerly leads over the bank, midway between the two shoal ridges, in 9 fathoms water. Corbiere point, at the south-western end of Jersey, is a small low bluff with a flagstaff on the summit and two small houses at its side. Just within the point the land rises at a steep slope and unites with the high table land of La Moye. CORBIERE ROCK, a quarter of a mile westward of the point and connected with it by a reef which dries after the last quarter ebb, is 70 feet above high water and very remarkable. It stands prominently out from the coast line, is the principal landmark for vessels approaching from the westward, is a signal station, and is in telegraphic communication with St. Helier's ; it may be seen in clear weather 10 or 12 miles distant. On it stands a circular stone light house, 62 feet in height from base to vane ; from it, the Minquiers light-vessel bears S.S.W. \ W. 174. miles, this line crossing the Brisants-du-Nord-Ouest of that shoal ; and, the Hanois lighthouse N.N.W. \ W. westerly 23£ miles.

Chap, v.] CORBIERE ROCK AND LIGHT. 205 LIGHT. — Corbiere rock lighthouse exhibits at 119 feet above high water a /Lced white light round seaward between the bearings S. by E. easterly and N. by W. westerly. In-shore of the limits of the ivhite light, two sectors of red light are shown, one north-eastward over the Rigdon bank and from thence to the land ; the other, south eastward over the Vracheres and the adjacent dangers between them and the shore. The light is dioptric, of the second order, and in clear weather the ivhite light is visible 17 miles. Fog Signal, — During fogs a bell is sounded three times in quick succession at intervals of thirty seconds. Caution. — Mariners must be very careful when navigating within the limits of either sector of red light. The principal dangers off and near the Corbiere are the Green rock, the Boiteaux, Boue, Frouquie, and Noirmontaise rocks. Green rock, the outermost danger, has 11 feet water ; it bears N.W. hy W. £ w. 6£ cables from the Corbiere lighthouse and 2 cables from the Boiteaux rocks on the same line of bearing. The marks for it are, St. Ouen mill just eastward of No. 3 martello tower N.E. by E. \ E. ; and, the Jument rock on with La Moye Point S.E. £ E. Another rock, with only 8 feet water, lies E.N.E. one cable from the Green rock. The Boiteaux are two rocks only 60 yards apart between the Green rock and the Corbiere ; they uncover 9 feet distant 4£ cables from the Corbiere. From the southern Boiteaux, St. Ouen church is open southward of No. 4 martello tower N.E. by E. \ E. ; and, the white house on La Moye is on with the northern side of the peak of the Corbiere rock S.E. by E. \ E. easterly. The Boue rock bears N.W. northerly 3§ cables from Corbiere lighthouse and uncovers 20 feet, or rather before half ebb ; it is at the inner part of the sunken reef in-shore of the Boiteaux. The Frouquie is at the outer edge of the reef extending from Rocco tower and fort to the Corbiere, from which latter it bears N. \ W. 5 cables ; and, from the Boue rock N.E. easterly 3 cables. The Frouquie covers 6 feet at high water, springs. Noirmontaise reef lies a quarter of a mile westward of the Corbiere, and dries 4 feet at low water. Another reef, one cable westward of the Corbiere, has 4 feet only over its shoalest part ; and, a large rock S. by E. one cable from the Corbiere, uncovers after the first quarter ebb. Clearing marks. — St. Ouen windmill open northward of No. 3

CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. martello tower leads outside and northward of the Green rock and of other rocks north-westward of the Corbiere ; and, La Moye white house on with the Jument rock leads 3 cables southward of the Green rock and half a cable southward of the Noirmontaise reef. The Frouquie Pass is between the Frouquie and Boue rocks. The clearing marks for the outer and inner parts of the Great bank, see page 204, are the best leading marks by which to enter this pass from the northward ; for, should both the Boue and Frouquie rocks be covered, a vessel cannot go too near the former so long as the Jument is in sight inside the Corbiere, nor can the Frouquie be touched without opening the Jument eastward of the high rock between Corbiere point and rock. There is a small rock 1^ cables westward of the Frouquie with only one foot water ; from it, the Jument rock and a beacon pole on the western side of the high rock between Corbiere point and rock are in line. With this exception, there is a clear 2j-fathoms passage more than a cable wide ; no vessel should, however, attempt to run through until half tide, that is to say, until the Boue rock is nearly awash ; it is then quite safe for vessels under 15 feet draught. At about this time, therefore, enter the pass midway between the Frouquie and Boue rocks, with the Jument midway between the Corbiere rock and the large rock off Corbiere point ; and, when St. Ouen church tower is on with the high rocky mass south-westward of Rocco tower N.E. £ E., steer for the Corbiere rock until within one cable of it, when it must be rounded at the distance of three quarters of a cable only ; and, run out to the southward when the Pinnacle rock is nearly on with the outer part of the Corbiere. There is a narrow deep water channel between the Green rock and the Boiteaux ; also, a narrow channel between the Noirmontaise and Boue rocks, close to the Corbiere and leading to the Frouquie pass, but the space between the Boiteaux and Boue rocks, and from the latter to within one cable of the Corbiere, is so thickly studded with sunken rocks as to be very dangerous even for boats, at low* water, and should be avoided. Jument rock, very useful as a sea-mark, has a large white patch painted on it ; from it, Corbiere lighthouse bears N.W. 3^ cables ; and, it is one cable from the high bluff next eastward of Corbiere point, with which bluff it is connected by a reef dry at low water. Half a cable outside the Jument is a dangerous rock which dries only at the last quarter ebb ; it should not be approached therefore nearer than a quarter of a mile.

Chap, v.] FROUQUIE PASS. — ST. BRELADE BAY. 207 LA MOYE POINT is a high cliffy bluff one mile eastward of the Corbiere ; on the high land behind the point is a conspicuous white house, very useful as a sea-mark ; it was used as a look-out house in connection with the signal post formerly existing on these heights but now superseded by the signal station established at the Corbiere lighthouse. The quarries at La Moye, showing at a distance as a white mark in the bluff are also useful in clearing the Minquiers reefs. La Moye point is safe of approach from the westward, but 1£ cables off it there is a rock with only 6 feet water ; close eastward of this rock and probably connected with it are the Kaines, a dangerous rocky group of which the highest covers only at the last quarter flood. The outer sunken rock of the Kaines lies 2% cables from the shore. Corbiere lighthouse kept open southward of the Jument until Tabor chapel, in St. Brelade bay, opens out eastward of Grosse Tete, leads clear of all these dangers. r ST. BRELADE BAY, near the south-western end of Jersey, between La Moye and Le Fret points, is much contracted by the ex tensive reef fringing its eastern shore, and the anchorage is further cut up by the Fournier and Fourche rocks. There is always less sea on the western than on the eastern side of the bay, but it is very inferior to St. Aubin bay as an anchorage and more exposed to southerly gales ; nevertheless, small vessels, and even large open boats, anchored within it off port Bouilly, have been known to ride out safely fresh gales from this the most exposed quarter. Approaching St. Brelade bay from the westward, the most remark able objects seen are, Grosse Tete, the high square rock under the rugged land of La Moye on the western side of the bay ; and, Noirmont tower standing prominently out at the end of the low point of that name to the eastward. On opening out the eastern side of the bay clear of Grosse Tete, the white sandy beach appears, and two martello towers, one on each side of Grouin point at the head of the bay ; beyond are villa residences and scattered groups of houses ; whilst, above all, on the high land near the middle of the bay, stands Tabor chapel, a plain white building with slate roof forming the principal landmark in it. Near the middle of the bay are the Fournier and Fourche rocks, about 2^ cables W.N.W. and E.S.E. from each other. The best anchorage is about a cable north-eastward of the Fournier ; the ground is quite clean up to the base of this rock, which is of very small extent. The Fournier dries 9 feet and the Fourche 10 feet at low water, springs.

[Chap. V 208 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. The other but less important rocks of the bay are, the Fournier du Havre, which dries 17 feet 2f cables north-eastward of the Fournier ; the Platte Houmet, which dries 12 feet in the bight nearer the shore ; and, the Rousse rock, 60 feet high, with the Rousse- Frouquie just northward of it, on the eastern side and outer part of the bay. St. Brelade bank is an uneven bed of rocks, commencing half a mile South of La Moye point and extending eastward nearly three quarters of a mile ; the least water, 29 feet, is near the middle of the bank. Le Fret bank, 3 cables off Le Fret point, is 3^ cables in extent N.W. and S.E. and of an oval form. Several rocks on its eastern side have from 22 to 24 feet on them, and one on the western side has only 14 feet ; the marks for it are, Nicolle and Noirmont towers in line E. by S. ; and, the western martello tower in St. Brelade bay on with the Rousse-Frouquie N.N.E. | E. At 2 cables eastward of Le Fret bank and in the direction of Noirmont tower, there is another rocky bank on which the least water is 20 feet. Corbiere lighthouse on with La Moye point leads in-shore of this bank, of Le Fret, and of St. Brelade bank ; and, the two first-named may be cleared on their southern side by opening Corbiere lighthouse a little southward of the Jument. Directions. — A vessel from the north-westward bound to St. Brelade or St. Aubin bay, on nearing the shore of Jersey, should keep Plemont point open of Grosnez point until Corbiere lighthouse bears eastward of S. by E. in order to clear the Rigdon shoal. When St. Peter's spire opens southward of No. 2 martello tower she will be southward of the shoal, and from thence should steer to round the Corbiere about a mile distant, avoiding the Green rock and other off-lying reefs by keeping St. Ouen windmill open northward of No. 3 martello tower in St. Ouen bay until the white house on La Moye is on with the Corbiere lighthouse. When La Moye white house opens southward of the Jument rock E. by S. S., or when the outer part of the high table land within Noirmont point is open of Le Fret point, a vessel is clear of the Noirmontaise reef and of all dangers south-westward of the Corbiere, and may run for La Moye point until Motte islet, off point le Croc, is just shut in behind Noirmont point, and Noirmont tower bears S.E. by E. h E., which mark leads between the Kaines off La Moye point and St. Brelade bank, until Tabor chapel is on with, or a little open of,

Chap. V.] ST. BRELADE, PORTELET, AND ST. AUBIN BAYS. 209 Battery point N.E. £ E., which then becomes the leading mark through the western pass to the inner anchorage off St. Brelade. Tabor chapel kept bearing N.E. \ N. leads up to the inner anchorage eastward of the Fournier rock. Anchor within the Fournier rock in from 4 to 5 fathoms, fine sand, on or between either of these lines, when La Moye bluff comes on with the outer part of Grosse Tete W. by N. £ N. Large vessels may anchor outside the Fournier in 8^ fathoms, gravel, with the western pass leading mark on, and the Jument rock just shut in with La Moye point. The holding ground in this bay is remarkably good. PORTELET BAY, between Le Fret and Noirmont point, is a bad anchorage ; it is small, and still further contracted by rocks extending westward from Noirmont point, as well as from the centre of the bay westward of Janvrin tower, which, together with the rapidity of the tidal stream across the entrance, render it dangerous of approach even for vessels of the smallest size. The danger is increased by Portelet ledge, an isolated mass of rock S.W. by S. 2\ cables from Janvrin tower ; from the shoalest spot of 2 feet on this ledge, the white house on La Moye over a remarkable sharp-peaked rock semi-detached from Le Fret point bears N.W. \ W. ; and, Noirmont tower appears northward of the high part of Pierre au Poisson, which lies midway between that tower and the ledge. Noirmont tower southward of the Pierre au Poisson leads just southward of Portelet ledge. If compelled to anchor in Portelet bay, the best berth is in 4^ fathoms, sand, with La Moye point just shut in with Le Fret point, and Janvrin tower N.E. In case of necessity, a vessel may anchor outside and eastward of Portelet ledge in 6 fathoms, with Corbiere lighthouse nearly on with La Moye point N.W. \ W. ; Janvrin tower N. by E ,\ E. ; and, Elizabeth castle just open southward of Noirmont tower E. \ N. ST. AUBIN BAY.— The whole of the anchorage in this fine bay, though surrounded by rocks, is free from foul ground and sheltered from all winds but those from S.S.E. round by South to W.N.W., and partially so even from them. South-westerly gales send in a heavy rolling sea between half flood and high water, but as the water falls the sea subsides, the rocks in the offing greatly contributing to break its force. The town and harbour of St. Helier occupy the north-eastern side of the bay, and the little town of St. Aubin, with its castle on a A. 2771. Wt. 17197. 0

Both towns have stone pier harbours, where vessels lie aground at low water on a soft muddy sand ; the tide, at low water, springs, receding half a mile from St Aubin harbour, and half a cable outside the entrance, of St. Helier new harbour. A strong mole or breakwater projects from the northern side of St. Aubin castle, sheltering a pier within, where vessels frequently refit and unload, grounding, how ever, at low water. Elizabeth castle is built on a craggy rock on the eastern side of the bay fronting the harbours of St. Helier, and about three quarters of a mile south-westward of the town ; the top of its high central tower or keep being 144 feet above the low water level. On the site of this castle formerly stood an Augustine monastery built in honour of St. Helier, a recluse, whose hermitage, on the summit of a high rock, \\ cables southward of the castle, still exists. Elizabeth and St. Aubin castles are insulated every tide, and afford shelter respectively to the two harbours, by breaking the swell wrhich rolls into St. Aubin bay during south-westerly gales. ST. AUBIN HARBOUR.— Several rocks lie scattered south ward and westward of St. Aubin castle, most of which uncover at low water. The two largest and most conspicuous are the Grosse and the Platte, very close together and 1£ cables from the castle ; the Grosse is the highest and shows about the first quarter ebb ; both rocks are marked by beacon poles. Another group of rocks lies 2 cables southward of the Grosse, the north -easternmost head drying 7 feet at low water. Haule house open eastward of St. Aubin castle breakwater leads eastward of these rocks ; and, eastward of this line, the bottom is all fine sand. At half flood, there are 8 feet water inside St. Aubin castle pier, at which time the water begins to flow into the entrance of St. Aubin harbour. The passage westward of St. Aubin castle is not passable for boats until half flood. The population of the little town of St. Aubin is about 1000. There is direct communication between it and St. Helier by railway. The chief import is coal and the only export red gravel. No stock of coal is kept on hand for shipping, the port of St. Helier being so near at hand. About 46 vessels of an aggregate tonnage of 3700 tons enter the port annually. Water of first rate quality may be procured from pumps on the quay at St. Aubin harbour. ST. HELIER, the chief town of Jersey is built on low land open southward but overlooked and sheltered northward by a

Chap, v.] 211 ST. AUBIN AND ST. HELIER HARBOURS. semicircular elevated plateau completely commanding it. The town is well built, and, as previously stated, contains about 28,000 in habitants, more than half the population of the island. It has a college and several churches, whose spires, together with Fort Regent on the eastern side of the town, are the most prominent objects from the sea. There is no Sailor's Home, but a large general hospital is available in case of accident or illness. The English quarantine laws are in force, and vessels from the Mediterranean or from infected ports are not permitted to enter the port until pratique has been granted by the Custom's authorities. In 1886, the total arrivals at St. Helier were 2139, and their net tonnage 316,616 tons. Steamers run between Jersey and South ampton, London, Plymouth, Bristol, and other English ports ; and, to Granville, St. Malo, St. Brieuc, and de Carteret, in France. St. Helier has a well-supplied market, where fresh meat and poultry may be purchased at about the same prices as in London. Fish is scarce, vegetables and fruit abundant and cheap. St. Helier Harbours5 are on the north-eastern side of St. Aubin bay. The old harbour is completely enclosed by the new harbour constructed between the years 1840-50 at a cost of 170,000^., from designs by Mr J. Walker, C.E. Both are alike in form, the new harbour being in fact a repetition of the old on an extended scale ; except that the form of the entrance to the new harbour is inferior to that of the old, permitting the south-westerly swell to range freely into it in heavy gales, to the great injury of vessels compelled to remain there at such times. The harbours are nearly rectangular, narrow in proportion to their length, with the entrances near their south-western corners. The old harbour is about 1,900 feet long by 300 feet wide ; it dries 11 feet at the entrance and 25 feet at its northern end, and has 8 feet water at its entrance at half tide. The outer harbour, enclosed by the Victoria and Albert piers, is 2,600 feet long by 500 feet wide ; it dries 3 feet between the pier-heads and 17 feet at its northern end ; it has 16 feet in its entrance at half tide, the ground rising gradually within the pier-heads for a distance of about 300 feet where there are 13 feet at that time ; the bottom is fine sand and mud through out. Coal can always be obtained, though the stock on hand is usually not large, from 300 to 400 tons, and the price from 18s. to 22s. per ton ; it is placed on board vessels alongside the quays where the available depth at high water, neaps, is about 18 feet ; but, it must be borne in mind that all the berths are dry at low water. Good water may be obtained from pumps on the inner quay of the old harbour. A Life-Boat is stationed at St. Helier. ANCHORAGE.— There is sufficient room for several vessels to lie at single anchor in St. Aubin bay ; but, if moored, the hawse should be open to the South-west from September to March when the prevailing winds are from that quarter. The best berth is within the Diamond rock, with St. Saviour's church tower just open northward of St. Mark's spire and on with the high rock between Gros du Chateau and the Vrachere E. by N. N. ; or, Fort Regent signal-post, seen over Elizabeth castle, on with Gros du Chateau E. \ N. ; and, Haule house on with the northern extreme of St. Aubin castle breakwater N. by W. £ W., in 20 feet at the lowest spring tides. This spot is N.N.E. nearly 2 cables from the Diamond rock. Vessels wishing to lie as near as possible to St. Helier, may anchor outside the Diamond rock in 5 fathoms, with Haule house on the same bearing, and with St. Mark's spire touching the south-eastern Hermitage rock N.E. by E. This last position should only be used in fine or moderate weather, but at the anchorage within the Diamond rock, vessels of 18 feet draught may ride out a heavy southerly gale in safety, being out of the strength of .the tidal stream and the swell and sea being broken by the outlying rocks, especially when the water is below the level of half tide. During neap tides, vessels of 22 feet draught may safely anchor inside the Diamond rock, but, for deeper vessels, there is no safe anchorage on any part of the southern coast of Jersey in very bad weather. PASSAGES into ST. AUBIN BAY.— Nine passages lead into St. Aubin bay, viz. ; the North-west, Western, South-west, Sillette, Danger rock, Middle, Hinguette, South, and Eastern. In westerly gales, the best time to pass through any of these channels is between first quarter flood and high water. The first of the ebb throws up a very dangerous overfall off Noirmont point, and when the westerly tide has fairly made, overfalls which continue with more or less intensity according to the height of the ocean swell and strength of the wind, extend across all the channels until the ebb'tide slacks. NORTH-WEST PASSAGE is only 1£ cables wide at the narrowest part between point Le Fret and the rocky bank of that

It being the steam-packet route between Southampton, Guernsey, and St. Helier, is indeed more used than any of the other channels. Directions. — Having rounded the Corbiere, see page 208, and having passed between La Moye point and St. Brelade bank by shutting in Motte islet with Noirmont point and having Noirmont tower bearing S.E. by E. | E., run direct for the tower until Corbiere lighthouse is on with La Moye point N.W. \ W. which mark leads midway through the narrowest part of the channel off Le Fret point in 8 fathoms. WESTERN PASSAGE, between the Hubaut reefs and St. Brelade bank, is rather more than a quarter of a mile wide at its narrowest part, between the Petite Grune and le Fret bank where there are from 7 to 9 fathoms water, but the Passage rock with only 14 feet lies in the fairway of the entrance. It is, however, the most direct route to St. Aubin bay and St. Helier harbour from the westward, one leading mark only being required, but as the marks are not easily made out in hazy weather, the North-west passage is probably the best and safest. Directions. — The leading mark is, the white patch on the sea wall at Greve d'Azette and the Dog's Nest beacon in line E. by S. ; this almost touches the northern side of the Passage rock, and passes only half a cable northward of the Petite Grune, therefore in entering the channel from the westward, to clear those reefs, keep the white patch on the sea wall at Greve d'Azette well open northward of the Dog's Nest beacon until Tabor chapel is on with Le Fret point, after which they may be brought in line, and, as already described, lead up to the entrance of the Little road. Should the white patch at Greve d'Azette be obscured, De Pas tower on with Noirmont tower W. \ N. northerly will do equally well, but, to clear the 20-feet rock eastward of Le Fret bank, the Her mitage rock should be opened clear of Noirmont point before shutting in Tabor chapel with Le Fret point ; and, if all objects eastward and

V. 222 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. near the town are invisible whilst the land about Noirmont and La Moye are tolerably clear, which is often the case in very fine weather, Noirmont point may be approached to the distance of a cable ; but, in passing eastward of it, do not shut in the white house at La Moye with Le Fret point until St. Aubin castle opens out ; this clears the dangerous rock between, and outside the line of, Noirmont tower and Pignonet beacon. After passing Pignonet beacon, bring Noirmont tower a little open northward of it, and, when about a quarter of a mile eastward of the beacon, anchor until the weather clears. SOUTH-WEST PASSAGE is between the Vracheres and the Grunes Vaudin, eastward of the Grande Grune, and westward of the Grand Four. The narrowest part of the channel is between the 6-feet sunken rock at the northern part of the Grand Four, and another rock with 20 feet over it ; these rocks bear from each other W. by N. \ N. and E. by S. \ S. and are 2 cables apart. Directions. — Admiral Saumarez's house, a yellow building named The Firs about half way up the slope of the hill north-eastward of St. Matthew's church, on with Noirmont tower N.E. \ E. leads mid way between the Frouquie of the Vrachere and the Grunes Vaudin ; enter the channel therefore on this line and run on it until the white patch in the sea wall at Greve d'Azette is on with the Dog's Nest beacon E. by S. when proceed as before directed. As the leading mark given leads very close past the western side of the Grand Four, it is recommended that on the flood vessels should run in on it only until Tabor chapel is on with the upper part of the slope of Le Fret bluff, and then use that as the leading mark until the eastern leading mark comes on as before. Tabor chapel is here given as the most conspicuous mark, but this leading line approaches the Grande Grune rather nearer than is desirable ; for the middle of the channel, Tabor chapel should be shut in altogether, and the Pic-nic hotel, a house with a white gable on the low land westward of the chapel, should be brought in line with the extreme of point Le Fret. As there are overfalls and strong eddies from the rocks in this channel on both ebb and flood, it should be avoided except in fine weather. SILLETTE PASSAGE is between the Sillette rocks and the Grunes aux Dardes, the channel between them being less than 2

Directions. — The Sillette passage should only be attempted by a sailing vessel with a fresh leading wind, as both tidal streams set right across it. The leading mark is, the western martello tower, white, in St. Aubin bay on with the eastern side of Grosse rock, on which there is a beacon, N by E. £ E. This leads 1\ cables eastward of the Poches-a- Suie rocks on which there are only 4 feet water, midway between the Sillette and Grunes aux Dardes, one cable eastward of the Petit Four, llj cables eastward of the Pignonet beacon, half a cable westward of the Grunes du Port, and very close inside the western head of the Junees. MIDDLE PASSAGE is between Danger rock and the Grunes aux Dardes on the western side, and the Tetards, Hinguette reef, and Grunes St. Michel on the eastern side. The narrowest part of the passage would be more than half a mile wide but for two sunken rocks, with only 14 and 15 feet over them, southward of the Grunes St. Michel and distant from it nearly half a mile, thus dividing the channel into two. The westernmost of these two rocks has 15 feet water, and is near the middle of the channel at its entrance ; it bears from Danger rock E.S.E. 44, cables. The best channel is between Danger rock and this 15-f eet rock ; here the ground is clean and the soundings regular in about 7 fathoms ; the eastern side of the Middle passage is rocky and the depths irregular. Directions. — Mont Plaisir house touching the western side of St. Aubin castle tower North a little westerly, leads through the Middle passage, passing 1^ cables westward of the 15-feet rock, 24 cables east ward of Danger rock, and rather less from the Frouquie of the Grune aux Dardes on which there are 5 feet water, 1£ cables westward of the Rouaudiere buoy, 1^ cables eastward of the Grunes du Port, and outside but very close to the Junees sunken rocks. To anchor in St. Aubin bay, haul to the eastward when the eastern end of Almorah terrace comes on with the Vrachere, marked by a beacon, and the innermost high rock northward of Elizabeth castle, to clear the Diamond rock ; and, anchor as convenient wmen Haule house is open eastward of St. Aubin castle tower. DANGER ROCK PASSAGE is between the Grunes aux Dardes and Danger rock and is at this part 3 cables wide with bk

224 [Chap. V, CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. fathoms water near the middle, but two rocky patches of 16 and 17 feet lie close south-eastward of the leading line. This passage, like the Sillette, is dangerous at times for sailing vessels, and should not be taken without a pilot. Steam-vessels, however, whose captains are acquainted with the pilotage, use it as the most direct passage to the Little road from the south-westward. Directions. — Bring St. Mark's spire on with the south-eastern rock off the Hermitage N.E. by E. ; this mark leads nearly 1^- cables southward of the southernmost rock of the Grunes aux Dardes, awash at low water, and rather farther from the Danger rock ; it also passes more than 14_ cables clear of the outer 7-feet rock of the Rouaudiere, and close eastward of an 8-feet rock off the Oyster rocks ; between this 8-feet rock and the Bieuse rock, marked by a beacon pole, and as far eastward as the Oyster rocks, the ground is quite clear of rocks. HINGUETTE PASSAGE, between the Hinguette reef and the Tetards, is 34. cables wide, has 7 or 8 fathoms water, and is a good and safe passage at slack watei, but at other times requires careful allowance for the tide, which sets right across it, Directions. — Enter this passage with St. Mark's spire on with the Dog's Nest beacon N.E. 4, N. and run through between the Hinguette reef and the Tetards. After passing inside the Hinguette, St. Matthew's church comes on with the Gros du Chateau rock, North, which mark leads between the Cloches rocks up to the entrance of the Little road. SOUTH PASSAGE is between the Tetards, with only 2 feet water, and some rocky patches to the eastward on which the shoalest spot has 14 feet. The channel is 2 cables wide, has 8 fathoms water, but is not so safe as the Hinguette or as the Eastern passage. Directions.— St. Matthew's church tower, a dull greyish-white building, seen between the heads of the Gros du Chateau rock, North, leads through about mid-channel, and between the Cloches up to the entrance of St. Helier Little road ; but, if proceeding to the anchorage in St. Aubin bay, when St. Peter's spire is on with Lower Blanc Pignon N. by W. 4. w. steer with it as the leading mark up to the anchorage. Near low water, St. Peter's spire may be lost sight of before arriving at the anchorage, in which case care must be taken to note some other object in the line of direction.

Chap, v.] ST. HELIER LITTLE ROAD.— DIRECTIONS. 225 EASTERN PASSAGE.— The narrowest part of this passage is between Demie de Pas, which dries 20 feet and on which is a beacon pole, and a rock with 11 feet water. The latter rock bears W.N.W. 3 cables from Demie de Pas beacon, and, from it, the 9-feet rock, see page 218, bears N. by W. £ W. one cable. The ground outside Demie de Pas is clean up to the foot of the rock, which is not more than 40 yards from the beacon. Directions. — The new mill on the beach at Millbrook, just in sight or opening of the high rocks on the western side of the Hermitage N. £ W. leads 1£ cables westward of Demie de Pas, and three quarters of a cable eastward of the 11 and 9-feet rocks just described. A vessel may therefore run in on this line until the white patch in Greve d'Azette bay is on with Tas de Pois white rock, after which she should edge to the N.W. to bring the leading mark for the South pas sage in line, St. Matthew's church on with Gros du Chateau rock ; this leads up to the entrance of the Little road ; or, St. Peter's spire on with Lower Blanc Pignon leads up to the anchorage in St. Aubin bay. ST. HELIER LITTLE ROAD.— DIRECTIONS.— When bound from St. Aubin bay into the Little road it is best to weigh at about half flood, at which time there are 16 feet water between the flier-heads of the new harbour, and 8 feet between the pier-heads of the old harbour ; at high water, highest springs, there are 36 feet at the entrance of the new harbour, and 27 feet between the pier-heads of the old harbour. Proceeding from the anchorage in St. Aubin bay, or from the west ward, into the Little road, it must be borne in mind that the channel inside or northward of the Oyster rock is now, 1888, practically closed by the works of the Elizabeth breakwater in progress. Vessels must therefore always keep southward of the Oyster rock, as follows : — From St. Aubin bay, or from the Westward, the channel is between the western Cloche rock with 8 feet water and the outer Oyster rock with 7 feet ; it is 14^ cables wide and has from 4-^ to 5 fathoms water. Steer between the Oyster and Cloches rocks, with the white patch on the sea wall at Greve d'Azette ami the Dog's Nest beacon in line, until St. Mark's spire is on with the white patch at the Albert pier-head N.E. £ E., which mark leads into the Little road ; but, after passing the.Platte rock, edge to the northward until St. Mark's spire is on with the northern white patch A, 2771. From the Southward.— Pass between the Cloches rocks with St. Mark's spire on with Victoria pier lighthouse N.E. % E. ; and,when inside the Oyster rocks, proceed by the marks just given for the Little road or for the harbour entrance, as may be required. From St. Aubin Eay over the Bridge* to the Little road or St. Helier harbour. This passage is only fit for small craft at high water ; in taking it, steer to pass half a cable northward of the Vrachere rock, on which is a small beacon pole, or run in with St. Mark's spire on with the northern side of the hospital until De Pas tower opens northward of the northern white patch on the Albert pier, with which mark run over the Bridge (this part has only one foot water at half tide), and either enter the harbour or haul out into the Little road. CAUTION. — In entering the harbour, allowance must be made for the tide, which, at or near springs, runs in and out with consider able strength. The most dangerous time for a vessel to enter is at about half flood ; at that time, vessels are frequently forced over against the sand-bank fronting the South pier of the old harbour before they have time to turn their heads up the harbour. GENERAL DIRECTIONS.— In beating along the southern coast of Jersey, it should always be borne in mind that the available space between the outer shoals off Noirmont point and the Minquiers ledge is but 8 miles, and between the Violet bank and the Minquiers only 6| miles. Small vessels working up towards the narrows of the western channels, when eastward of the Kaines, may stand into St. Brelade bay until the Jument rock is on with La Moye point ; and southward, until the southern extreme of Elizabeth castle is on with Noirmont point, East, When in the narrows of the western channel, before half flood or after half ebb, backing and filling is recom- * This passage may become closed as the works, recommenced at the Elizabeth breakwater, proceed ; see note, page 211.

Chap. V.] ST. AUBIN BAY. — GENERAL DIRECTIONS. 227 mended with a beating wind ; if with the flood, the vessel's head should be off-shore, and, if with the ebb, in-shore. Between half flood and high water, a vessel may act according to her draught, for, at half tide, there are at least 13 feet over all the rocks in the offing of St. Aubin bay, with the exception of the Pignonet, Hinguette, and Sillette, on which there are then only 9, 8, and 7 feet respec tively. If bound to the Little road or to St. Helier harbour, it may be useful to know that St. Mark's spire touching the southern side of Close rock leads 60 yards northward of the Rouaudiere ; and, the same spire on with the False Hermitage leads well southward of it. A vessel from the north-westward running for shelter in St. Aubin bay during a gale from that quarter, should keep \\ miles outside the Corbiere to avoid the breaking sea near it, especially between half ebb and lowr -water ; and, when the land of Noirmont is well open, steer for its point until Grosnez point comes on with the Corbiere, when haul up for La Moye and bring the marks for the North-west passage on, see page 221, where much less sea will be found than in either of the others. In heavy westerly gales, the whole space between the outlying rocks off Noirmont point is a confused mass of breakers ; clouds of driving spray create an impenetrable mist, obscuring all marks near the level of the sea, and the beacons marking rocks are all out of sight ; but, even under such circumstances, the North-west passage may be safely taken by those acquainted with it, as both Le Fret and Noirmont points are safe of approach for large vessels to the distance of one cable. On arriving abreast of Noirmont point, attend to the directions given at page 222 ; or, do not shut in La Moye white house with Le Fret point until the white martello tower in St. Aubin bay opens eastward of St. Aubin castle to clear the Pignonet rocks, as the first of the flood sets right over these rocks into St. Aubin bay. It may be useful to repeat that when Haule house comes on with the western end of the wall extending westward from St. Aubin castle the vessel is midway between the Grunes du Port and the Diamond rock : and, that St. Saviour's church tower just open northward of St. Mark's spire and on with the high rock between Gros du Chateau and the Vrachere rock beacon E. by N. J N. leads up to the anchorage in St. Aubin bay, well clear of the Diamond rock. Approaching from the w estward, the Frouquie rock, off Le Croc point, on with Seymour tower E. by S. leads outside all the shoals P 2

[Chap. V. 228 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. off Noirmont point and St. Aubin bay until near the Tetards, when the tower should be brought nearly on with the Rousse rock, just northward of the Icho tower. From the eastward, the white house on La Moye on with Le Fret bluff N.W. 4. W. westerly leads outside all the rocks off St. Clement's bay, and of the Frouquie and Demie de Pas, up to the leading mark for the Eastern passage. The COAST eastward of St. Helier is low and sandy to La Roque point, the south-eastern extreme of Jersey, distant 54/ miles E. by S. £ S. from Noirmont point, and also northward of La Roque point as far as Mont Orgueil bluff, which bears from La Roque point N.N.E. £ E. 2 miles, the bight between them being named Grouville bay, off which, at one mile S.E. 4, E. from Mont Orgueil castle, is good anchorage for vessels of the largest size. The southern part of this coast is inaccessible to shipping, it being fringed by extensive reefs which dry in some parts around La Roque point 2 miles from the shore at low water, springs. The outer edge of these reefs on the southern side is generally steep to and, fortunately, well marked by a number of large rocks, which, although sometimes nearly awash at high water, are never entirely covered. Two stone towers, each about 45 feet above the high-water level, also mark these reefs — viz., the Icho tower, about 3 miles south eastward of the Little road of St. Helier ; and, Seymour tower, off La Roque point, 1£ miles farther eastward and near the middle of the Violet bank. VIOLET BANK is the general name applied to the south-eastern part of the great reefs eastward of St. Helier. It extends rather more than 2 miles from La Roque point, and consists of gravel, shingle, and sand, interspersed with numerous ledges of sharp-pointed rocks, the whole bank drying at low w*ater, springs. The greater part of the bank covers at half flood, at which time there is a foot of water over the inner part of the ridge of sand and shingle extending from La Roque point to Seymour tower ; this, the lowest part of the ridge, is near La Roque point and is the most favourable spot for the passage of boats. At high water, the bank is entirely covered and is then only marked by the Conchiere rock at its southern extreme, by Seymour tower near the middle, by Karame rock, at this time awash, on the South-east, and by Little Seymour rock, also awash but marked by a pole and basket beacon, near its eastern side. From half flood to half ebb, the stream runs with a velocity of 6 knots, at springs, over the Violet bank and through the Violet

Chap. V.] VIOLET BANK. — ICHO AND SEYMOUR TOWERS. 229 channel in a1 north-easterly direction, turning northward through Gorey roads where its strength is about 44, knots. As before remarked, the reef eastward of St. Helier, as well as the southern edge of the Violet bank, is well marked by conspicuous rocks, which, together with the principal sunken dangers along this line, will now be described. Tas de Pois, or White rock, bears S. by E. £ E. 7 cables from the Dog's Nest beacon, see page 213. Although only 5 feet above high water, springs, it is very remarkable from its upper part being well whitewashed all round, and from there being another rock, rather larger and black, 1^ cables eastward of it. Dangerous rocks, which never show, extend If cables westward of it ; and, a quarter of a mile north-westward is a rocky group, of which the Trois Grunes, the highest heads, uncover 20 feet, A chain of rather high rocks extends from the White rock to the shore. The Frouquie, S.E. £ S. 74, cables from White rock, is 3 feet lower than the White rock, and therefore nearly awash at high water, springs. A chain of high rocks extends from the Frouquie to point Le Croc, of which the inner and highest is Motte islet, which is about 22 feet above the level of the highest tides. This line of rocks marks the limit of the Greve d'Azette, the first bay eastward of St. Helier. The coast between Motte islet and La Roque point recedes slightly and forms St. Clement's bay. A dangerous reef extends W.S.W. 2\ cables from the Frouquie. Demie de Pas, the westernmost rock of a cluster bearing W.N.W. half a mile from the Frouquie and S. \ W. 4 cables from the White rock, dries 20 feet, is steep-to outside, and is marked by a pole beacon. La Moye white house on with Le Fret point N.W. \ W. westerly leads \\ cables outside all the rocks off Demie de Pas and the Frouquie. Between the Frouquie and Icho tower, no rocks are visible at high water to mark the outer edge of the reef, but, at half tide and less, it is well marked by the Rouget rock, which is close to the edge of deep water and bears S.E. \ S. 6^ cables from the Frouquie ; also, by the Jinquet which dries 25 feet half a mile E.S.E. from Rouget rock; and, 3 cables eastward of the Jinquet rock is the Grande Frouquie, which bears W. by S. £ S. 3 cables from the Icho tower and is 7 or 8 feet above the level of the highest tides. ICHO and SEYMOUR TOWERS bear from each other East and West and are 1| miles apart. Icho tower is surrounded by high

[Chap. V. 230 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. rocks, and in this respect differs from Seymour tower,_which at high water rises abruptly from the sea and is completely isolated. Echiquelez Rock is one of the principal sea-marks near Icho tower, from which it bears S. by E. 4| cables. Its summit is 5 feet above the highest tides ; it is steep-to on the outside westward, but S.S.E. i E. li cables from it is a half -tide rock ; and, north-westward, in line between it and the Jinquet, are several dangerous rocks, of which the farthest dries 5 feet at low water and lies 1^ cables S.S.W. from the Grande Frouquie. Between Echiquelez rock and the Conchiere, the edge of the reef curves outwards nearly a quarter of a mile beyond a straight line connecting those rocks. Icho Bank is a dangerous, rocky, irregular ridge about 4^ cables long in a N.N.W. and S.S.E. direction, and 1^ cables wide ; the least water, 2^ fathoms, is at the northern extreme, and bears S.W. \ W. 2\ miles from the Icho tower ; from this shoal spot, La Platte Roque martello tower just open northward of Icho tower bears N.E. \ E. ; and, St. Peter's spire open eastward of Lower Blanc Pignon house N. by W. \ W. westerly. On other parts of the bank there are from 3 to 5 fathoms water. The channel between this bank and the rocks fronting Icho tower is nearly 2 miles wide and clear of danger. The Conchiere Rock, 2 miles from La Roque point at the southern extreme of the Violet bank, dries 41 feet, and is therefore never covered, although sometimes awash. From it, Mont Orgueil castle and Seymour tower are exactly in line N. £ E., the latter distant \\ miles. A reef extends \\ cables southward from the Conchiere ; therefore that rock should not be approached nearer than a quarter of a mile. A good clearing mark for the line of reef just described between the Frouquie and Conchiere rocks is, Corbiere rock lighthouse touching La Moye point until the Grande Anquette beacon is well open southward of the Conchiere rock. VIOLET CHANNEL.— A sunken reef, commencing at the Conchiere rock, extends eastward 1^ miles on the bearing of the Echiquelez and Conchiere rocks in line. Northward of this line for rather more than a mile, the entire space is shoal water with rocks innumerable ; so that, at low water, it is difficult for a stranger to find his way through them even in a boat. From the Conchiere

Chap, v.] VIOLET CHANNEL. — DANGERS. 231 eastward, the southern edge of this reef is well marked at the last quarter ebb by a long string of rocks called the Route en Ville ; its eastern extreme is bounded by the Petit Four, a rock with 2 feet water ; and, the reef may be said to extend northward as far as the Cochon, Noire, and Grande Haisse rocks. The navigable part of the Violet channel is between this sunken part of the Violet bank and the Plateau de la Frouquie, the rocky bank to the southward on which are the Goubiniere and Rousse Platte rocks, and the Anquette rocks to the eastward. The narrowest part is between the Petit Four and the sunken rocks westward and north-westward of the Petite Anquette, where it is about half a mile wide ; the general depth is from 5 to 6 fathoms. Anquette Channel leads out eastward between the Grande and Petite Anquette rocks from the middle of the Violet channel. The general depth of water is from 6 to 7 fathoms, rather deeper than in the Violet channel, but, from the absence of good leading marks, the passage is more difficult, Near the point of separation of the Anquette and Violet channels, with Prince's tower and Little Seymour beacon in line, and with the Grand Anquette beacon turret bearing E. S., is a rock with 23 feet water and another near it with 25 feet, Though nothing less than these depths has been found, caution is necessary with large ships passing this part of the channel at low water. Vessels of about 15 feet draught should wait until the flood tide has fairly made, and, w-ith any swell on, should not pass through until the first quarter flood. DANGERS in VIOLET CHANNEL.— The Conchiere rock, see preceding page, is the principal mark at the western entrance of the Violet channel. Taxe Rock, 6£ cables eastward of the Conchiere, dries 10 feet at low water ; from it, the Conchiere and Echiquelez rocks are exactly in line bearing N.W. by W. \ W. Route en Ville Rocks. — A quarter of a mile south-eastward of Taxe rock, with Echiquelez rock open southward of the Conchiere, is the highest rock of the Route en Ville, which dries 11 feet ; West rock dries 6 feet half a cable W. f S. from it ; and, another rock, a cable eastward of the highest head, dries 10 feet. From these rocks eastward, and close to deep water, the Route en Ville chain extends for about half a mile with an outward curve ; most of the rocks are nearly awash at low water. Petit Four, with 2 feet water, is at the eastern extreme of the Violet bank ; from it, Karame rock just shut in with the outer part of the high table land above Noirmont point bears N.W. by W. 4 W.; the sentry-box of Coupe guard-house, a stone turret on the summit of Coupe bluff, seen over the end of the bluff just within the break water house at Verclut point N. \ W. westerly ; and, Grande Anquette beacon turret on with the northern side of Petite Anquette rock S.E. by E. On the southern side of the Violet channel the following are the principal rocks : — PLATEAU DE LA FROUQUIE.— The Goubiniere dries 20 feet at low water ; it is at the western end of the Plateau de la Frouquie, very little eastward of Orgueil castle, Seymour tower, and Conchiere rock in line, and distant from the latter nearly 1^ miles. From the rock, La Moye white house over the outer part of Le Fret point bears N.W. \ W. There are several rocks northward of the Goubiniere ; the Canger rock is the most northern, it dries 16 feet, and is one cable distant from the Goubiniere. Frouquier Aubert Rock, formerly marked by a beacon turret, which, however, has been washed away (1883), is at the south-western edge of the Plateau de la Frouquie, 1£ miles south-eastward of the Goubiniere ; it uncovers 26 feet at low water and does not cover at neaps. From it, St. Peter's spire is on with the white patch on South hill ; and, St. Martin's spire is a good sail's breadth open eastward of Seymour tower N. \ W. westerly. Rousse Platte Rock is at the eastern side of the Plateau de la Frouquie, and E. £ S. rather more than a mile from the Goubiniere ; it is a large flat rock about half a cable in diameter and dries 14 feet.

Chap. V.] PLATEAU DE LA FROUQUIE.— ANQUETTE ROCKS. 233 Between this rock and the Goubiniere are several rocks, of which one dries 15 feet, another dries only 4 feet but is the most dangerous, as it stands prominently out towards the channel. Pierre des EnfantS, 2\ cables S. by E. 4 E. from the Rousse Platte, is 7 feet higher than that rock, and is therefore a very useful mark when the Rousse Platte is covered by the tide. ANQUETTE ROCKS.— Petite Anquette lies 2h miles E. by S. £ S. from the Conchiere rock, and, with the Seal rocks and Maraine reef, forms the eastern boundary of the Violet channel. Seal Rocks form part of the extensive reef northward of the Petite Anquette, on which one of the most dangerous ridges is known as the Seals. The western Seal dries 4 feet N.N.W. \ W. 3£ cables from the Petite Anquette. A rock with only 12 feet water lies If cables westward of the western Seal ; and, the Maraine reef, with as little as 3 feet water, lies N.N.E. more than 6 cables from the Petite Anquette. All these rocks are probably connected with the Petite Anquette. Grune Le Feuvre has only 6 feet water at its shoalest spot, which bears N.E. £ N. 1^ miles from the Petite Anquette. Grande Anquette Rock lies E. by S. \ S. 3^ miles from the Conchiere rock and S. E. £ E. 3^ miles from Seymour tower ; the rock covers about 8 feet above half tide, but it is marked by a stone beacon turret painted in horizontal bands of red and white, 20 feet above high water, and surmounted by a staff and ball. From the beacon, Petite Anquette rock bears N.W. by W. £ W. three quarters of a mile ; Rousse Platte rock W. £ S. southerly 2\ miles ; Grande Arconie, which dries 9 feet, S.S.E. \ E. easterly one mile ; and, Porpoise rock, which dries 4 feet, S.W. by W. westerly 8i cables. Anquette Patches form a small rocky bank, with from 16 to 20 feet on its eastern end, N.E. \ N. one mile from the Grande Anquette ; from the eastern shoalest spot of 16 feet, Seymour tower on with the

234 [Chap. V. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. Motte rock bears W.N.W. ; and, Rozel mill* twice its apparent breadth open westward of St. Catherine's white martello tower N.N.W. £ W westerly. Another bank of rock and gravel lies E. by S. £ S. 2 miles from the Grande Anquette, and N.W. 4, N. Z\ miles from the Bœuf beacon turret; from its shoalest part of 15 feet, Rozel mill a little open eastward of St. Catherine's martello tower bears N.W. by N. ; and, Grande Anquette beacon turret and the Conchiere rock in line W. by N. \ N. PLATEAU DE L'ARCONIE — Some dangerous sunken rocks with as little as 3 feet lie a quarter of a mile E.S.E. from the Anquette beacon turret ; and, the space southward of it for the distance of \\ miles is occupied by a vast shoal called by the French the Plateau de l'Arconie ; some of the rocks on this shoal begin to uncover soon after the last quarter ebb, at springs ; others are only awash at low water, springs, and by far the greater part never uncover at all. Grande Arconie Rock, which dries 9 feet, is at the eastern side of the plateau ; the Porpoise rock, drying 4 feet, marks its western boundary ; the Grand Four rock, drying 7 feet, and with several small rocks drying 2 feet in its vicinity, lies just within its south western extreme ; and, Grune la Hauche dries 6 feet one mile S.E. by E. \ E. from the Grand Four, and 1\ cables S. by W. £ W. from the Grande Arconie. The channel between Plateau de la Frouquie and Plateau de l'Arconie is \\ miles wide and has 5| fathoms water, but its free navigation is impeded by a string of rocks extending across at unequal distances from each other between the Pierre des Enfants and the Grand Four ; some are awash, others have 5 or 6 feet over them at low water, springs. The great strength of the stream at this part of the channel and the absence of good marks render its navigation extremely perilous near low water ; no vessel should attempt to pass through, therefore, until after the first quarter flood. Coupe guard-house a little open eastward of the breakwater house at Verclut point N. £ W., the same mark as for the northern entrance * Staff Captain J. S. Watts, R.N., reported in July 1886 that the arms of Rozel mill had been removed, thus rendering it difficult of recognition as a mark. It has a white dome roof, the body of the mill being of a reddish colour. Just north-east ward of it is a white house with a black roof.

Chap. V.] ARCONIE AND OTHER ROCKS. — DIRECTIONS. 235 of the Violet channel, leads through the best part of the channel but close to the outlying rocks off the Grand Four, and over one sunken rock which must be avoided. Anquette Gravel Banks or Southern Anquettes commence near the the south-western extreme of the Plateau de l'Arconie, and extend 5 miles south-eastward in an almost continuous line. They consist of a number of narrow ridges of fine gravel. having generally a depth of from 3 to 4 fathoms, except on one detached bank near the south-eastern end, where there are only 2 fathoms. The marks for this spot are, the white house at La Moye just northward of Frouquier Aubert N.W. £ W. westerly ; Grande Anquette beacon turret a little within Verclut point N. by W. £ W. ; Bœuf beacon turret E.N.E. northerly 3 miles ; and, Basse le Marie bell buoy S.S.E. 34, miles. There are good 7-fathoms channels on either side of this bank. La Moye white house on with Le Fret point N.W. £ W. westerly leads south-westward of the southern Anquettes, of the Plateau de la Frouquie, and of all the rocks bordering the southern shore of Jersey, up to the leading mark for the Eastern passage into St. Aubin bay ; and, this line passes 1J miles northward of the Icho bank. Directions. — Violet Channel. — If bonnd eastward from St. Helier through the Violet channel, having cleared the dangers outside the Little road, keep the Corbiere lighthouse just in sight open of La Moye point N.W. \ W. until Orgueil castle, seen over the low* land of La Roque point, comes on with Icho tower ; at which position, about half a mile from the outer edge of the reef, the Grande Anquette beacon turret will be a little open southward of the Conchiere rock E. by S. \ S. From hence, steer S.E. by E. £ E., parallel with the outer edge of the reef, the depth being from 5 to 7 fathoms. The Conchiere rock should be passed atabout 4 cables, and, when eastward of it, bringtheEchiquelez rock on with Noirmont tower N.W. £ W. for a leading mark until Prince's tower is on with Seymour tower ; if the distance from the Conchiere and Route en Ville rocks has been correctly preserved in passing them, the Rousse Platte should now bear about S.W. 34 cables, and the Grande Anquette beacon turret E. \ N. Now steer N.E. \ N. to pass through the deepest part of the channel or, to pass through the middle of it, steer E. \ N. for the Grande Anquette beacon until La Roque tower is on with Seymour tower, or until Coupe mound just open eastward of Verclut point bears N. £ W.,
