V. 236 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. with which mark run towards the Petit Four; and, when northward of a line drawn from the Conchiere to the Grande Anquette, edge to the eastward to bring Coupe guard-house open of Verclut point N. £ W., which mark leads 2£ cables eastward of the Petit Four, one cable eastward of Giffard rock, and through Gorey outer road. For mid-channel through the latter, however, the vessel should again edge away to the westward when Gorey lighthouses are in line N.W. northerly, until Coupe mound is just open of Verclut point as before. The narrowest part of the Channel being between the Petit Four and Petite Anquette, it may be useful to know that the stone turret on the summit of Coupe point and the breakwater house at Verclut point exactly in line N. £ W. leads a cable outside the Petit Four ; at this position, Rozel mill touching the northern side of Mont Orgueil castle bears N. by W. 4, W. ; and, St. Catherine's white martello tower is on with Archirondel red tower. When abreast of the Petit Four, Earame rock just shut in with the high land above Noirmont point bears N.W. by W. 4/ W. ; and, the Grande Anquette beacon turret open northward of Petite Anquette S.E. by E. easterly. Small vessels may haul out eastward of the Chateau bank when Echiquelez rock is open northward of Karame rock, but vessels of very deep draught should not do so until Icho and Seymour towers are in line, in order to avoid the Stony banks 6 cables north-westward of Grune le Feuvre, on which there are only 25 feet at low water. GROUVILLE BAY, which derives its name from a hamlet near St. Clement's church, is on the eastern side of Jersey between La Roque point and Mont Orgueil. Its outer Southern boundary commences on the north-eastern side of the Violet bank and is very rocky ; numerous masses of rock lie scattered along the low- water line to the northward, which line is nearly a mile from the shore in the southern part of the bay; there are also many rocks within as well as outside this line. Grouville bay, at low water, is very picturesque with its vast expanse of fine white sand rising with a gentle slope towards the shore, bounded on the South by Seymour tower and the rugged rocks of the Violet bank, and on the North by Mont Orgueil and its venerable castle. The Horn Rock, N. W. by N. 74, cables from the Giffard rock and one mile southward of the Equerriere beacon, is the outer rock of the Frouquies de la Greve, dries 16 feet, and is marked by a staff and horizontal cross beacon.

Chap, v.] GROUVILLE BAY. — GOREY. 237 Amongst other rocks on the southern side of the bay is Little Seymour rock awash at high water and marked by a pole and basket beacon, from which a long string of rocks extends eastward forming the low-water boundary of the bay. Among the most important of these rocks are, the Cochon at the outer edge, which dries 7 feet ; the Grande Haisse, which dries 22 feet ; and, the Noire, which dries 14 feet, the latter nearly a mile outside Little Seymour beacon. Four cables outside the Noire, is the Giffard, a most dangerous rock in approaching Grouville bay from the southward ; 74, cables northward of it and in the centre of the bay is the Horn rock, just described ; and again, northward of the Horn rock is the Road rock of 9 feet water. The Giffard has only one foot over it at low water ; from it, Little Seymour beacon bears W. by S. h S. southerly nearly 1^ miles; the Horn rock beacon N.W. by N. 7.4,i cables ; and, a depth of 12 feet water on the South Ridge sand of the Bane du Chateau N.E, by E A E. 4 cables. From Giffard rock, Rozel mill a little open westward of Crete guard-house bears N.N.W. ; and, Little Seymour beacon open northward of Gros Etac rock W. by S S. Road Rock, 4 cables N. by W. from Horn rock beacon, and H cables outside the Grune du Port, has 9 feet water ; from it, St. Catherine's white martello tower just shut in with La Crete point bears N. by W.; and, No. 5 martello tower on with the extreme end of the high table land southward of Grouville mill W. \ S. A 14-feet patch lies S.S.E. one cable from the Road rock. A small rock, with 26 feet water, lies 2i cables from Road rock in the direction of Verclut point ; half way between this and the Dasher rock, and about 1£ cables distant from each, is the Inner Road rock with 16 feet water. From this rock, St. Catherine's tower is just shut in with La Crete point N. by W.; and, Gorey pier lighthouse is open northward of the Ecureuil beacon, the latter being 2 cables distant. GOREY TOWN AND HAREOUR, at the northern end of Grouville bay, are immediately under Mont Orgueil castle. The little town contains about 1,000 inhabitants ; it is considered to be particularly salubrious and has railway communication with St. Helier, and by steamer with the coast of Normandy. It has a fair trade in vegetables, fruit, coal, cattle, timber, &c. Supplies of all kinds can be obtained, including coal in limited quantities, but vessels requiring coal, unless it can be shipped during tide time, 4 or 5 hours, have to lie aground in their berths. Hospital accommodation is available in case' of sickness or accident,

238 [Chap, V. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. The harbour is formed by a stone pier built out from the south western part of Orgueil head. The accommodation for vessels is very limited ; the outer berth alongside the pier having a depth of only 9 feet at half tide, and, at low water, springs, the sand dries one cable outside the pier-head ; nevertheless, vessels of 300 tons may occasionally be seen here, and about 300 vessels of all sizes enter the port annually; as it is the' headquarters of the oyster fishery, a number of sloops of from 30 to 50 tons belong to the place. Two small warping buoys are moored at the entrance to assist vessels arriving or leaving, the outer buoy about a cable south -west ward of the pier-head, the other about 80 yards westward of the pier. About 135 yards westward from the pier-head is a space formerly paved with flat stones for depositing oysters and marked by a beacon ; this artificial oyster bed is, however, now (1887) much broken up and the beacon removed. With this exception, the bottom of Gorey harbour consisting of mud and sand, is good for grounding. Sharp vessels not provided with legs should always get a pier berth and list inwards, assisted by mast-head tackles to the shore, to prevent falling over at low water. During severe gales, a vessel strains less in taking the ground, is better sheltered, and experiences less 'scend in this harbour than in any other in the Channel islands. Mooring Buoy. — A mooring buoy is placed in 11 feet, with Gorey slip just open of the pier-head, and Horn rock and Ecureuil beacons in line, distant only one cable from the latter. The ground chain of these moorings lies North and South, there are 38 fathoms on each arm, and the anchors are of 24 and 30 cwt. A cable within the bouy there are 7 feet, and 3£ fathoms at the same distance outside, but close to their north-eastern side is a rock with only 7 feet at low water, equinoctial springs. LIGHTS. — From Gorey pier-head n fixed white light is exhibited at 35 feet above high water. On the slope of the hill in the face of the wall below Gorey church tower, at 535 yards N.W. \ N. from the pier-head lighthouse, and 119 feet above high water, is exhibited a fixed red light, visible 8 miles. The two lights in line lead northward of the Frouquies de Greve, and of the Road, Fisherman, and Azicot rocks, and southward of the Ecureuil rock; in passing which latter, the red light should on no account be opened northward of the white light,

Chap, v.] GOREY. — DANGERS. — DIRECTIONS. 239 DANGERS. — The principal dangers in the immediate neighbour hood of the Port of Gorey are the following : — The Equerriere is the largest and most conspicuous rock off Gorey harbour ; it bears E. by S \ S. southerly 4^ cables from the pier-head, dries 35 feet, and is marked by a pole and fish-tail beacon. Another rock, drying 14 feet, lies two thirds of a cable S.E. £ S. from it. Dasher Rock, with 2 feet water and from 18 to 20 feet close to, lies S. by W. \ W. about one cable from the Equerriere rock. The Ecureuil, 14 cables S.W. of the Equerriere, dries 14 ifeet and is marked by a pole and basket beacon. Fisherman Rock, with 8 feet water, lies S. by W. 2 cables from the Dasher rock. Other rocks which abound here, though smaller, are very dangerous, such as the Azicot rock, 2 cables outside Gorey pier-head, which dries 5 feet and is marked by a spar buoy ; the Guillimots, a group of rocks S. by W. i_ W. 2\ cables from the Azicot, of which group the outer rock dries 6 feet and is marked by a spar buoy ; the Burons, a rocky group 2 cables south-eastward from the Guillimots, of which the highest rock lies to the N.E. and is also marked by a spar buoy ; and, the Grune du Port, with 5 feet water 3| cables outside the Burons, on a line connecting Gorey pier-head and Horn rock beacon, but 3£ cables inside the latter. Directions. — To enter the Inner road or Gorey harbour, three channels are available according to the state of the tide. For the southern channel, the leading mark by day is the red lantern in the face of the wall below the church tower on with the pier-head N.W. \ N., and, by night, the two lights in line. For the middle channel, the northern end of the white house at the top of Hardway on with the pier-head N.W. by W. \, W. westerly leads between the Equerriere and Ecureuil rocks up to the mooring buoy in the Inner road. For the northern channel, the leading mark is, the chimneys of Fort William on with the pier-head bearing West southerly ; as this leads close past the Arches rocks, which dry 15 feet, it will be well to open the chimneys a little southward of the pier-head before the Equerriere and Ecureuil beacons are in line. If entering the harbour, having approached it by either of these channels, run up to the entrance, passing on either side of the Azicot

240 [Chap. V. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. spar buoy, but leaving both the warping buoys near the pier-head on the port hand in rounding it, and be careful not to approach the pier too closely, as the tide sets round it to the eastward with great strength after half flood, at springs. When the Horn rock is awash, there are 10 feet water just off the end of Gorey pier and 5 feet at the outer berth alongside it. The Tres Grunes lie 2 cables outside and eastward of the Equerriere rock, and are awash at low water. Little Seymour beacon on with Seymour tower S.S.W. leads three quarters of a cable eastward, but passes over a 25-feet rock just outside them, which rock is the extreme end of the ledge, the water being deep close up to it, To clear this outer rock when passing the Tres Grunes in a large vessel, Little Seymour beacon should be kept perceptibly open west ward of Seymour tower. Northward about 1^ cables from the Tres Grunes is the Pacquet rock with 2 feet water ; within and north-westward of which, at about the same distance, are the Arches rocks, a small group which dry 15 feet, their south-eastern rock being marked by a spar buoy. Northward of these again, and within 3 or 4 cables of Mont Orgueil, are the Grand Houmet, Le Mont, Seven Grunes to be pre sently described, and many other rocks, the ground here being very foul. BANC du CHATEAU. — This extensive bank of sand, gravel, and shells, lies off Grouville bay nearly parallel with the low water line of the shore and distant from it rather more than a mile, except at its northern end which approaches Mont Orgueil within 1\ cables ; it forms a great natural protection to the anchorage in Gorey roads. Within the 5-f a thorns line, the bank is rather more than 2 miles long by 4 cables w ide ; the main body has a general depth of 3 fathoms, gravel bottom ; from this base rise numerous narrow sandy ridges extending across the bank in an E.S.E. and W.N.W. direction. Near the middle, for about a mile, these ridges are so close together as to form almost one continuous bank, and have accordingly been named the Middle bank. At very low tides, this part occasionally dries. The North Ridge is nearly 4 cables within the northern end of the Chateau bank, and has from 10 to 12 feet water ; just south ward of it is a smaller ridge with only 5 feet, The South Ridge, with from 12 to 16 feet water, forms the south western and southern edge of the bank close to deep water,

Chap, v.] BANC DU CHATEAU.— ANCHORAGE. 241 The Chateau bank is much affected by the weather and by the action of the tidal streams ; the upper part, within a particular and limited space, is continually shifting, and during westerly winds the ridges of the sand-banks are so sharp that, when awash, a boat may easily knock them down in passing over. At such times the banks are about 4 feet higher than with easterly winds. Clearing Marks. — Grouville mill on with the southern side of Mont Orgueil bluff W. by S. £ S. southerly clears the 5-fathoms line at the northern end of the bank. Icho tower and Little Seymour beacon in line W. by S. lead close past its southern end. Coupe guard-house turret on with the breakwater house under Verclut bluff N. £ W. clears the north-western corner and leads down its western side nearly in mid-channel ; and, Coupe guard-house turret on with St. Catherine's breakwater lighthouse N.N.W. \ W. leads eastward of the bank as well as of a rocky 5-fathoms patch outside. Tongue Sands are two small shoal banks nearly 1 and 2 miles respectively eastward of the South ridge of the Chateau bank, but separated from it and from each other by good sound channels of deep water. They are of the same character as the Chateau bank, having sharp ridges of fine sand. The least water on the eastern bank is 36 feet, and on the western bank 23 feet. From the 23-f eet ridge, Coupe turret oj>en eastward of St. Catherine's lighthouse bears N.N.W. \ W. ; and, Icho tower open northward of Little Seymour beacon W. by S. southerly. Anchorage. — Between the western side of the Chateau bank and the 5-fathoms line fronting Grouville bay is the Outer road, a safe anchorage and large enough to accommodate several vessels of deep draught, it being a mile long North and South by nearly half a mile wide. The eastern limit is marked by Coupe guard-house turret being on with the breakwater house .at Verclut bluff, and its western limit by St. Catherine and Archirondel towers in line. At its northern extreme, Gorey pier-head open southward of the Equer riere beacon bears W. by N A N. ; and, at its southern end, No. 4 martello tower and the Horn rock beacon are in line W. £ N. The space included within these lines has a depth of from 6 to 8 fathoms with an even bottom of gravel and shells, and the best line on which to anchor is Grouville spire on with Fort Henry. The Inner road is within the 5-fathoms line of Grouville bay, between the Road and Inner road rocks, and between the Equerriere beacon and the Burons rocks. In-shore of this space are the A. 2771. Wt. 17197. Q

242 [Chap. V. CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. Government moorings marked by a large buoy in 11 feet, but with a 7-feet rock close to on its north-eastern side, as already described. The best line on which to anchor in the Inner road is, with Prince's tower open northward of Fort William the apparent breadth of the latter. The anchorage in Gorey roads is the only place in the Channel islands, or on the French coast from St. Malo to Cherbourg, where a squadron of heavy ships might find good shelter in a westerly or north-westerly gale ; and, with proper charts and sailing directions, the approach is sufficiently easy for any seaman to take his ship in without the aid of a pilot, in clear weather. DIRECTIONS.— Grouville Bay.— The approach to Grouville bay from the direction of the Violet channel has been already given, see page 235 ; when running for this bay from the northward, and having cleared the Pierres de Lecq, the Drouilles, and other dangers near the northern end of Jersey by the directions hereafter given, see pages 256-265, avoid the foul ground off Nez du Guet and Coupe point by giving each a berth of at least a quarter of a mile in rounding them ; Belle Hougue bluff open northward of Tour de Rozel point N.W. \ W. leads outside the dangers off Coupe point and 6 cables northward of the Pillon rock off Verclut breakwater ; La Roque No. 1 martello tower on with the Equerriere beacon S.W. S., or Seymour tower and Little Seymour beacon in line, leads east ward of them but over the Fara ledge of 21 feet. The North Channel into Gorey road is between Fara ledge and the northern end of the Chateau bank, and is there only a quarter of a mile wide with a depth of 6 fathoms in mid-channel, but it has a depth of 4 fathoms for a width of 4 cables and is therefore perfectly safe for large ships. Entering this channel from the northward, keep Belle Hougue bluff open of Tour de Rozel point until Little Seymour beacon is just open westward of Seymour tower S.S.W., which mark leads inside the Chateau bank up to the anchorage. At any time after the first quarter flood, the heaviest ships may enter the North channel either with the mark just given or with No. 1 martello tower at La Roque point on with the Equerriere beacon S.W. £ S., passing over the Fara ledge ; the former has the great advantage for long heavy ships of making the turn to the lead ing mark through the Outer road, Coupe mound open of Verclut bluff, much less abrupt. To anchor as near the shore as possible, Coupe guard-house turret

Chap, v.] 243 GROUVILLE BAY. — DIRECTIONS. may be shut in a little over Verclut point ; but, Little Seymour beacon should be kept perceptibly open westward of Seymour tower until Fort William is open southward of the Equerriere beacon to clear the Tres Grunes, or until the best anchoring lines, already given, are approached, when anchor as convenient. The South Channel is between the southern end of the Chateau bank and the reefs northward of the Anquettes, and, as the narrows are reached, between the Giffard rock and the South ridge of the Chateau bank, where it is only 3^ cables wide. The water is deep throughout, there being not less than 8 fathoms in mid channel at the lowest tides. Approaching this channel from the northward, to clear a rocky bank of 32 feet outside the Chateau bank, keep Coupe guard house turret outside St. Catherine's lighthouse N.N.W. \ W. westerly, until Prince's tower comes on with Gorey pier-head, after which the guard-house may be brought inside the lighthouse as far as the outer arches of the breakwater ; and, when Icho tower opens southward of Little Seymour beacon, haul in round the southern end of the bank. Rozel mill over Crete bluff clears the inside part of the South ridge ; but, the leading mark which clears the Giffard rock by 1£ cables is, Gorey spire on with the pier-head, marked by a white patch, N.W. £ N. until Coupe mound open of Verclut bluff bears N. £ W., with which mark run up to the anchorage in the Outer read, anchoring as before directed. A large vessel working into the Outer road through the South channel should not open Icho tower southward of Seymour tower until Coupe guard-house is westward of the middle of St. Catherine's breakwater, in order to clear the Stony banks, of 25 feet least water, northward of the Petite Anquette. From Grouville Bay to the South-eastward.— Bring Gorey spire open a little westward of the white patch at Gorey pier-head N.W. £ N. and run out until Icho tower is midway between Seymour tower and Little Seymour beacon W. £ S. ; haul out to the eastward on this line until Coupe guard-house opens eastward of St. Catherine's lighthouse, which mark leads clear of all danger off the Anquettes. To the Southward through the Bœuf Channel.— After clearing the Anquettes as described, bring Coupe guard-house turret on with St. Catherine's lighthouse N.N.W. £ W., and, with this mark Q2

[Chap. V. 244 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. on, steer to the southward. As the line of Icho and Noirmont towers in one is approached, Coupe turret may be brought a little westward of the lighthouse ; and, when southward of this line and clear of the Grande Arconie, Coupe turret should be brought westward of the lighthouse at least one third the distance to Verclut point, to clear the western side of the Basse Occidentale des Bœufs ; from whence, if bound for Granville, the same mark on astern and a S.S.E. course lead past the Basse le Marie bell buoy and up to the leading marks for the Cotentin .channel, see pages 186-190 ; or, if bound westward, a S.S.W. course leads to the channels between the Anquette gravel banks, see page 235, which banks may be always known and avoided by the tide ripples over them, and when La Moye white house opens of Le Fret point N.W. \ W., the gravel banks are passed and a vessel may haul to the westward. In passing through this channel, it should be remembered that Coupe turret touching the outer part of St. Catherine's lighthouse leads over the Anquette north-eastern patch, and also over the Basse Occidentale des Bœufs, the cross mark for the latter being Bergerie house on with the Rousse Platte rock N.W. £ W., or Coutances cathedral open northward of Blainville steeple S.E. by E. \ E. A small vessel bound southward from Gorey on the flood, may pass inside Grune Le Feuvre and the Anquette north-eastern patch by bringing St. Martin's spire open northward of the white patch on the northern side of Mont Orgueil castle at least the width of the patch N.N.W. £ W. At or before half flood, a small vessel may also pass between the plateau de la Frouquie and the plateau de l'Arconie by keeping Coupe turret on with the breakwater house at Verclut point N. f W. until the white house at La Moye is on with Le Fret point N.W. \ W., when she may haul to the westward. Approaching the Bœuf channel from the southward, if the marks on Jersey are indistinct, Mont Huchon, on the French coast, on with the sandy point of Blainville river entrance E. by S. \ S., or Coutances cathedral on with the southern end of Blainville village and well open southward of Blainville church S.E. by E. \ E. easterly, lead up until they can be made out. It is, however, generally difficult and often impossible to distinguish the marks for this channel owing to their distance ; a vessel of deep draught should therefore only attempt it in charge of an experienced pilot and during the upper half of the tide ; nor should square-rigged vessels ever attempt to work through except under such conditions.

Chap. V.] GROUVILLE BAY. — DIRECTIONS. — ANNE PORT BAY. 245 From Grouville Bay through the Violet Channel.— Run out as before with Gorey spire open westward of the white patch on the pier-head N.W. £ N. until the northern side of Gros Etac rock is on with Little Seymour beacon W. by S. 4, S. southerly. The vessel is then abreast of the Giffard rock, and Coupe guard-house turret a little open of Verclut point N. f W. becomes the leading mark with which to enter the Violet channel ; and, when approaching the narrows, be particular that Coupe guard-house turret is only just open eastward of the breakwater house at Verclut point. As a check, it is useful to know that if any part of St. Catherine's white martello tower shows eastward of Archirondel red tower you are quite far enough to the eastward. Another good mark for the middle of the channel when abreast of the Petit Four is, Rozel mill (without arms) touching the northern side of Mont Orgueil castle N. by W. 4, W. When abreast of the Petit Four, Karame rock just shut in with the high land above Noirmont point bears N.W. by W. } W. ; and, Grande Anquette beacon turret open northward of the Petite Anquette S.E. by E. easterly. From this position, steer to bring Coupe mound open of Verclut point and use it for the leading mark ; or, if the Rousse Platte rock is uncovered, steer direct for it on a S.W. bearing until Grande Anquette beacon turret bears E. 4, N. In either case, steer west ward with the Anquette beacon turret on that bearing until Icho tower is on with the Conchiere rock, when the vessel is clear of the Route en Ville reefs and may steer to pass 3 or 4 cables southward of the Conchiere rock. ANNE PORT BAY, between Grouville and St. Catherine bays, is small, and outlying rocks render the approach to it dangerous ; there is, however, good anchorage off it, occasionally used by fishing boats and other small craft in fine weather. The principal dangers are the Seven Grunes and the Cloches rocks. The Seven Grunes, form a long straggling reef extending 3£ cables eastward from the Grosse Moie ; the highest rock, near the middle of the reef, uncovers 7 feet, and the outer Grune, called Le Mont, has 5 feet water over it. The Cloches Rocks extend in an E. by S. ± S. direction 54, cables from Crete point to a rock with only one foot water ; they are the southern rocks of the Fara or St. Catherine's bank and several heads in-shore of the one-foot rock dry from one to 5 feet. Between the Cloches rocks and the Seven Grunes is the anchorage ; it is 24, cables in extent North and South, has an even depth of 44, or 5 fathoms, and is sheltered from the tide.

246 [Chap. V. CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. ST. CATHERINE'S BAY, on the eastern Shore of Jersey northward of Mont Orgueil castle, though much encumbered by rocks, affords excellent anchorage for small craft in 2 or 3 fathoms water, with a bottom of muddy sand covered with very long grass and seaweed ; it is difficult, however, for a sailing vessel to enter or leave except with a leading wind. The bay is completely sheltered from northerly, westerly, and south-westerly winds ; but, south-easterly and easterly winds blow right in and near high water cause a short, turbulent, chopping sea ; as the tide falls, however, the sea subsides. A harbour of refuge was begun in this bay in the year 1847. The northern pier or breakwater was completed in 1855, and extends 826 yards S.E. £ E. from Verclut point, the northern extreme of the bay, and over the rocky bed formerly called the Pierre Mouillee ; it has a depth of 5 fathoms at its outer end at low water, and on the pier-head stands the lighthouse. The pier has a lofty parapet, and, alongside it, a steam-vessel of large size might coal, water, land, or embark troops, with any wind from N.N.E. round by "West to S.W. The southern breakwater was designed to extend in an easterly direction from the point near Archirondel tower across the Fara reef Of this, however, only about 200 yards has been built, and the work discontinued. Should the southern pier ever be completed and a harbour formed it might prove useful in bringing Jersey into closer commercial relations with France ; but, from the great strength of the tides across the entrance of the bay, and from the dangerous rocks near, it is now difficult of access to sailing vessels in bad weather, and only fit for ordinary use by steam-vessels. LIGHT. — A white octagonal iron lighthouse, 30 feet high from base to vane, stands on the outer extreme of the parapet wall of Verclut breakwater. It exhibits a fixed white light of the fifth order at 60 feet above the level of high water, and is visible in clear weather from a distance of 12 miles. DANGERS off and in ST. CATHERINE'S BAY.— The approach to St. Catherine's bay from the South-east is completely barred by St. Catherine or Fara bank, a large bed of rocks about half a mile square, of which the outer part extends three quarters of a mile eastward of Archirondel tower. The rocks begin to uncover about the last quarter ebb, many show at low water but by far the greater number never dry. On the southern edge of the bank are the Cloches, already

Chap. V.] st. Catherine's bay.— dangers. 247 described ; on the eastern side, the Fara rock, half a cable wide, which dries 9 feet and, with a pole beacon in its centre, is the most con spicuous rock ; also, on the eastern side, the Grune du Nord which dries one foot ; and within, on the North-west and North, the Basses de Fara, and the Etot rock which dries 10 feet. Fara Ledge, about one third of a mile south-eastward of the Fara beacon, is a rocky bank about a cable in length E.S.E. and W.N.W., rather more than half that width, and about the same distance detached from a depth of 2 feet on the edge of St. Catherine's bank. The least known depth is 21 feet near its eastern end, but there may be a foot or two less. No. 2 martello tower in Grouville bay and the Equerriere beacon in line S.W. just clears the south-eastern side ; and, Little Seymour beacon on with Seymour tower S.S.W. touches its western extreme. This latter mark also leads over the outer part of St. Catherine's bank in 28 feet but close to a 17-feet patch ; Coupe guard house on with St. Catherine's lighthouse N.N.W. W., or a little open eastward of it, leads outside the Fara ledge and reef and between them and the Eureka and Pillon rocks up to the lighthouse. Eureka Rock, with 12 feet water, lies 2\ cables from the light house, with the northern side of the breakwater slightly open, and No. 4 martello tower just shut in with Orgueil point. The Pillon Rock has only 4 feet water ; it bears due North 1^ cables from the Eureka rock, and is 2 cables from the breakwater end. From the rock, St. Martin's spire is on with the lighthouse ; and, No. 3 martello tower is just shut in with Orgueil point. Within St. Catherine's bay, in line between the lighthouse and Archirondel tower and nearly 2 cables from the lighthouse, is a rock with only 8 feet water ; another rock with only 7 feet lies northward of a line drawn from the lighthouse to St. Catherine's martello tower, with Coupe guard-house just showing over Verclut point. Caution.— During spring tides, the stream sets with great velocity over St. Catherine's bank into the bay and also round the end of the breakwater, for which due allowance must be made in entering or leaving the bay. Anchorage. — There is barely room for one large ship to anchor in St. Catherine's bay. The best berth is in 5 fathoms water about a cable distant from the breakwater and \\ cables westward from the lighthouse.

248 [Chap. V. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. Small vessels may anchor farther up the bay in 2 fathoms, with St. Martin's spire on with the southern extreme of the bluff northward of St. Catherine's martello tower W. by N. J N. ; and, Seymour tower on with Grosse Moie S. by W. One cable in-shore of this, there is only one fathom, and the same distance off-shore 3£ fathoms. The bottom is a mixture of fine sand and mud throughout. Directions.— From Grouville to St. Catherine's Bay — Run out from Gorey Inner road with Prince's tower open north ward of Fort William until Little Seymour beacon is just westward of Seymour tower, which mark clears the Tres Grunes and foul ground outside them ; having passed these, bring Little Seymour beacon and Seymour tower exactly in line S.S.W. to pass inside Fara ledge, in 23 feet ; or, No. 2 tower a little open south-eastward of Equerriere beacon S.W. to pass outside Fara ledge. With Coupe guard-house on with St. Catherine's lighthouse, a vessel is clear of all the rocks of St. Catherine's bank, and may steer for the lighthouse, hauling into the bay, when a cable distant from it, with St. Martin's spire nearly shut in over the bluff northward of St. Catherine's martello tower for a leading mark, and anchoring as convenient by the marks just given. There is another passage into this bay from the southward between the Cloches and Crete point, which, though much encumbered by rocks nearly awash at low water, may be useful occasionally to small craft with pilots. A very useful mark for this small channel during the lower part of the tide is, St. Catherine's martello tower on with the eastern side of Little Fara rock to clear Le Mont, the outer rock of the Seven Grunes ; and, having passed that danger, open the tower a little inside the Little Fara before passing Crete point, to clear the rocks along the inner part of St. Catherine's bank. A vessel may pass close inside the Little Fara in 9 feet at low water, ordinary springs. Coupe Point is a bluff about 180 feet high, and so named from its being connected with the neighbouring land by a narrow neck of little more than half that height. On the summit of the bluff is a ruined guard-house surmounted by a stone sentry box or turret, which serves as a conspicuous and very useful mark. An extensive range of farm buildings stands near the edge of the plateau south ward of and overlooking the Coupe ; two high rocks lie half a cable outside the bluff, from which a dangerous reef extends 2 cables eastward.

Chap. V.] ST. CATHERINE'S BAY.— DIRECTIONS.— FLIQUET BAY. 249 FLIQUET BAY is between Verclut and Coupe points, and affords good shelter from south-westerly winds, but is quite exposed to those from South round by East and North to W.N.W. As Gorey road affords no shelter with southerly winds, vessels bound to Gorey harbour, during strong winds from that quarter and not able to save their tide in, may anchor under shelter of the breakwater until two hours flood, when they will still have sufficient southerly tide to enable them to reach the road by the time there is water enough to enter the harbour. No vessel, however, should anchor in this bay with the intention of remaining longer than a tide, for a shift of wind to S.E. or N.E. would place her in a dangerous position. The bottom is hard sand, free from any foul ground except the Brayes, a small group of rocks which dry and extend If cables from Coupe point ; and, the Coupe rock, with 10 feet water, S.E. by E. h E. 4^ cables from Coupe guard-house turret, and North a little easterly 5f cables from St. Catherine's lighthouse. The white patch in the centre of the northern side of the breakwater on with Mont Orgueil castle leads outside the Coupe rock. Telegraph Cable. — The electric cable between Jersey and France is laid in a S.E. by E. \ E. direction from Fliquet bay to Pirou on the French coast, see page 168. The shore end in Jersey is at the white martello tower in Fliquet bay, on which is painted in black letters the word Telegraph, surmounted by a green disc. To prevent damage to the cable, or loss of anchors, grapnels, or dredges, by the fishermen, the following directions are given : — The course of the cable is distinctly indicated by the two towers, which are a sufficient guide during the day for clearing it. Fishing boats without a compass may avoid it on the South by not opening the Tour de Rozel northward of Coupe point ; and, on the North, by not shutting in the guard-house in Bouley bay with the Tour de Rozei. Anchorage. — From the northward, Seymour house, on the hill northward of Gorey, on with or a little eastward of the breakwater house under Verclut point S.S.W. \ W. leads between the Brayes and Coupe irock ; and, from the eastward, Rozel mill on with Fliquet telegraph tower W.N.W. leads between the Pillon and Coupe rocks. The best anchorage, with southerly or south-westerly winds, is in 6 fathoms midway between the breakwater and the Coupe rock, with Nez du Guet and Coupe point in line N.W. \ N. ; and, the Martello tower on the hill northward of Mont Orgueil castle on with the centre of the breakwater S.S.W. f W. Care is required in taking up

[Chap. V. 250 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. this anchorage, as it is only a cable northward of the telegraph cable. With westerly winds, anchor nearer Coupe point in about the centre of the bay. • ■ ROZEL BAY.— N.W. \ N. nearly one mile from Coupe point is Nez du Guet, and between them is Rozel bay, which, being exposed to all winds from S. by E. round by East to N.W. by N., is only used as an anchorage to await sufficient water to enter the harbour. In addition to the foul ground off the points of the bay, there is a rocky group called the Hiaux, which uncovers 3 feet, one cable from the western shore and 1£ cables from the pier-head, Avith Rozel hotel on with the white patch on the pier-head ; and, also a sunken rock with 5 feet water on the eastern side of the entrance to the harbour, one cable from the shore. Rozel Harbour. — This small but useful harbour in the western part of Rozel bay has a stone pier capable of affording shelter to 20 small cutters, such as are employed in the oyster fishery. A great quantity of cider is shipped here during the summer months, and the harbour affords berthing places to six vessels of from 40 to 50 tons. North-westerly winds cause a great range, so that vessels fre quently carry away the large hawsers used in mooring alongside the pier. Gorey harbour is preferable to Rozel in every respect. The mouth of the harbour is much obstructed by a large, flat, half tide rock, on the southern side of the entrance, between which and the pier-head there is only room for two small vessels to enter abreast ; with a foul wind, vessels are obliged to kedge in or out. Directions. — Entering Rozel harbour from the northward, keep St. Catherine's lighthouse in sight outside Coupe point until the Royal hotel at Rozel is southward of the white patch on the pier-head W. by S., which mark leads southward of the Hiaux, and to the entrance of the harbour. Give the pier-head a close shave, to avoid the half tide rock just described. If waiting tide to enter the harbour, the best anchorage is in the north-western part of the bay, with the Royal hotel on with the white patch on the pier-head, and the lower and upper part of the wall of Nez du Guet fort in line, or, the two chimneys of the guard-house in the fort in line. To keep outside the Hiaux, do not shut in the Tour de Rozel with the Nez du Guet. Tides.— It is high water, full and change, in Rozel bay at 6 h. 15 m. ; springs rise 30 feet, neaps 2H feet.

Chap. V.] ROZEL HARBOUR. — BOULEY BAY. 251 Tour de Rozel forms a most useful mark ; it is a conical mass of rock 155 feet high, detached from the point within it, and about 4 cables westward of Rozel bay. A half-tide rock, the Demie de la Tour, lies three quarters of a cable outside it ; with this exception the approach to it is quite safe. BOULEY BAY, on the northern side of Jersey, between Tour de Rozel and Belle Hougue point, affords good shelter with the wind from W. by N. round by South to S.S.E. The only dangers in and near this bay are, the Oyster rocks, the Troupeurs, the Sambues, and the Grune de Vicard, a small rock near the western shore. Oyster Rocks are 2f cables in-shore of the Troupeurs, 1^ cables N.N.E. from Meulet point, and dry 13 feet at low water. Troupeurs Rocks, near the middle of the bay, are the two highest heads of a small rocky bank, which bear from each other about N.E. and S.W. one third of a cable ; the outer head has 10 feet water, the inner head 7 feet. From the outer head, the inner high rock of the Pierres de Lecq is a little open of Belle Hougue point N.W. \ W. westerly ; and, the western side of Meulet point on with the western side of the high cliff immediately above it S. by W. \ W. The whole of the Pierres de Lecq well open of Belle Hougue point leads northward of the Troupeurs ; and, the largest rock of the Pierres de Lecq group, near the middle, shut in behind Belle Hougue point leads southward. The Sambues are nearly 4 cables eastward of Belle Hougue point, and extend nearly a quarter of a mile from the shore ; they uncover soon after half ebb. Coupe guard-house turret on with Tour de Rozel point S.E. f S. leads outside the Sambues, Troupeurs, and all shoal ground off Belle Hougue point. Grune de Vicard is nearly a cable from the shore between the two guard-houses and has 2 feet water over it. Anchorage. — To anchor outside the Troupeurs in from 8 to 10 fathoms, gravel bottom, keep the whole of the Pierres de Lecq at least a point open of Belle Hougue point, or Coupe guard-house open of Tour de Rozel point ; and, the white tower of Castle house, on the high land overlooking the bay, on with Bouley pier S.W. \ S. Or further in, with the white tower of the Castle house open of the pier S.W. by W. ; and, Belle Hougue point, seen over the land, a little

[Chap. V. 252 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. northward of Vicard point N.W. f N. in 5 fathoms, fine sand. This is a safe anchorage with southerly winds, but open to those from the northward. Directions. — To enter Bouley bay from the eastward, steer in with the slate-roofed house, on the western side of the bay above the pier, on with the pier end, West ; this leads between the Demie de la Tour, on which the tide sets strongly, and the Troupeurs rocks up to the anchorage in 4£ fathoms. Vessels anchored in this bay during south-westerly gales should be prepared to weigh directly the wind begins to veer to N.W., and run either to St. Catherine's bay or Gorey road. BELLE HOUGUE POINT, about a mile westward of the anchorage in Bouley bay, is the highest and, except Grosnez, the most remarkable headland on the northern coast of Jersey. From it, a reef of sunken rocks extends 2 cables off-shore ; this reef is cleared on its north-eastern side by keeping Coupe turret open of the Tour de Rozel, and, on its northern side, by keeping Plemont point in sight outside Ronez point. Off the north-eastern coast of Jersey are the Ecrehos and Drouilles shoals, which, with their off -lying banks and rocks, together cover a distance of 7§ miles N.W. £ W. and S.E. \ E., and have an extreme width of 2^ miles. Between them and Jersey is Le Ruau, a clear, navigable channel, 2\ miles wide at its narrowest part, and greatly protected during north-easterly gales by these reefs. ECREHOS ROCKS, about one third of the distance between the north-eastern coast of Jersey and cape de Carteret, are at the eastern part of these reefs, and are separated from the Drouilles to the westward, and the Ecreviere banks to the eastward, by very narrow and shallow channels. The main group of the Ecrehos rocks occupy a space near the centre of the reef 1\ miles in extent North and South and 8 cables wide, the whole of which space dries before low water. Maitre ile, 60 feet high, is the largest of the group, and is at the south-eastern extreme of this part of the reef ; along the steep eastern side of the reef, to the north ward, are the rocky islets Marmotier, Blanc ile, Tas de Pois, and Vielle ; the two latter being conical rocks 50 and 54 feet high respec tively. On the south-western side are the high rocks Cotes and Colombier ; and, northward of them, the Grosse Tete and Petite Tete, the latter being the only one that ever covers with the tide.

Chap, v.] ECREHOS ROCKS. 253 Maitre ile, Marmotier, and Blanc ile are the largest of the Ecrehos group, and on each there are huts for the use of fishermen. Maitre ile alone is large enough to preserve its soil from being swept away by wind and sea and is therefore the only islet having any vegetation, which consists of coarse grass and a few stunted shrubs. Large rats abound, but neither fresh water nor fuel are to be found on any of these islets, which are, however, visited by Jerseymen during the summer season, for the purpose of fishing and cutting vraic. Maitre ile being one of the principal stations for the survey of Jersey, the exact position of the instrument is marked by a pole surmounted by a barrel with a large pile of stones at its base ; it stands on the highest part of the island near the middle, and is a conspicuous and useful beacon. Along the eastern side of the main reef of the Ecrehos, but sepa rated from it by a narrow channel, is a tangled mass of rocky reefs, narrow at its northern end near the Vielle but widening and increasing its distance from the main reef as it extends southward, with an outward curve to abreast of Maitre ile, from which its outer edge is a mile distant. Here the rocks suddenly terminate and the Ecreviere bank, of gravel and sand, commences and extends nearly 2 miles farther southward. Of the rocky reef described, only those rocks used for sailing marks, viz., the Bigorne, Sabloniere, and Grande Galere, need special notice. Bigorne, a very remarkable horned rock, 20 feet above high water, lies 4 cables eastward of Maitre ile. Sabloniere and Grande Galere, If and 2f cables north-eastward of Bigorne, are not so high but never cover. Ecreviere Rock, the south-easternmost of the Ecrehos group, covers 8 feet at high water, springs, and bears E. by S. three quarters of a mile from Maitre ile. The Ecreviere bank extends from the Ecreviere rock to its southern edge in 5 fathoms S. fry E. f E. nearly 2 miles. Its greatest breadth, near the northern end, is half a mile, and it tapers off to about 2 cables wide at its southern extreme. The bank is very steep along its western side ; its surface consists of a number of ridges of fine gravel and sand, convex to the south westward, nearly parallel with and close to each other, drying from 3 to 5 feet, and separated only by narrow channels from 3 to 8 feet in depth. The stream setting over this bank causes a confused sea in bad

[Chap. V. 254 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. weather. Bigorne rock and Tas de Pois in line N.N.W. \ W. mark the direction of the southern end of the bank, and, by opening these objects of each other one point either way, the end of the bank may be rounded as necessary. Grouville mill on with Orgueil bluff leads over the bank a quarter of a mile within its southern extreme, where it is awash at low water. St. Martin's spire on with the upper house on the northern side of Verclut point bearing West, or Rozel mill open southward of Coupe turret W. \ N., leads clear of its southern end. Ronde Selhere, the southernmost of the Ecrehos rocks, uncovers 7 feet ; from it, Marmotier islet appears on with the high eastern extreme of Maitre ile, and St. Martin's spire open northward of Fliquet tower bears W. by S. Another rock of similar character and appearance, but drying 8 feet, lies If cables north-westward of this ; and a third, the Petite Noire, drying 12 feet, about the same distance northward, the three rocks forming nearly an equilateral triangle. A reef, awash at low water, lies one cable eastward of the Ronde Selhere. These rocks may be cleared on their south-western side by shutting in Plemont point behind Ronez point. St. Martin's spire on with Fliquet tower W. f S. southerly leads southward. Tas de Pois on with the eastern side of Marmotier N. by W. \ W. leads between Ronde Selhere and the Ecreviere bank. To keep outside the Grande Noire rocks the whole of Petite Rousse rocks must be well open southward of the high rocks of Maitre ile. Bigorne rock, seen mid way between Sabloniere and Grande Galere rocks N. E. \ N. clears the Ronde Selhere rocks on their western side and leads up to the Maitre ile anchorage. Anchorage for small vessels only may be found southward of Maitre ile and within Ronde Selhere. The best berth is in 5 fathoms, gravel, with Marmotier houses just open eastward of Maitre ile, North ; and, Bigorne midway between Grande Galere and Sabloniere N.E. \ N. Large vessels should anchor in 8 fathoms, gravel, outside the line of Ronde Selhere rocks and Ecreviere bank, with Tas de Pois on with the eastern extreme of Marmotier. Nipple Rock forms the outer western corner of the western entrance to Maitre ile inner anchorage ; the rock near its centre dries 16 feet ; at this spot, the Grande Galere is open southward of Maitre

Chap. V.] ECREHOS ROCKS. 255 ile N.E. by E. \ E. ; and, Grosse Tete is open westward of Colombier, North. The Vraic, a rock which dries 5 feet, lies S.E. by E. f E. 3 cables from the Nipple rock ; Sabloniere and Bigorne rocks in line lead over the Vraic rock. The Demies are two rocks scarcely a cable apart, whose summits dry 18 and 19 feet and are just at the half-tide level ; the outer rock bears N.W. northerly 6 cables from Nipple rock and is nearly 5 cables westward of the Ecrehos main reef. From the outer Demie, Mar motier open southward of the Cotes rocks bears E.N.E. ; the Vielle open northward of Colombier N.E. \ N. ; and, St. Martin's spire over the Coupe W.S.W. Several rocks uncover \\ cables westward of the Demies, and sunken dangers with only 5 feet water lie nearly 3 cables in that direction. Rouquet reef consists of several detached masses of sunken rocks on the northern side of the Ecrehos reef and separated from it by narrow channels of deep water. The highest rock of the eastern mass is awash at low water ; from it, St. Catherine's lighthouse mid way between the martello tower northward of Mont Orgueil and the end of the plateau above Gorey bears S.W. f S. ; and, Maitre ile beacon midway between Grosse Tete and the Vielle S.S.E. \ E. Petite Rousse Rock has three heads from 12 to 14 feet above high water and is on the north-western side of the Ecrehos reef, distant from the Grosse Tete W. by N. \ N. northerly 8^ cables ; the whole space between, except a narrow and tortuous channel, is choked with rocks, of which a great number uncover every tide. Dangerous rocks, of which some uncover and others are awash at low water, are thickly scattered over the space between the Petite Rousse and the Demies; others lie between S.S.W. and S.W. by S., extending 6 cables from the Petite Rousse, and one dangerous reef uncovers 3 feet 4 cables S.W. by W. from it. On its northern side also, it is closely encumbered by rocks, of which the Table rock which uncovers 23 feet at 2| cables distance in a N.E. \ N. direction, is one of the principal. Grande Rousse Rock is 22 feet above high water and bears N.W. by W. \ W. 6 cables from the Petite Rousse, from which it is divided by a narrow navigable channel, and, like the latter, is surrounded by dangerous reefs. St. Catherine's lighthouse on with the martello tower northward of Mont Orgueil S.W. \ S. southerly leads between the Grande and Petite Rousse.

256 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. [Chap. V. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the Ecrehos rocks at 6 h. 32 m. ; springs rise 31 feet, neaps 22^ feet. The DROUILLES.— This rocky group is about 3 miles west ward of the main body of the Ecrehos, and 3^ miles northward of Coupe point. It is about 2 miles in diameter and consists of broken detached reefs, the whole covering with the tide, except three small rocks near the south-western side, of which the Burons are the two largest. The Burons are conical, about 7 feet above high water, and only a few fathoms apart. Although small, they are most useful marks to vessels navigating the Ruau channel ; 2^ cables south-west ward of the Burons is the Frouquie, a large rock 8 feet lower than the Burons and awash at high water. The Joli is a small pinnacle rock which dries 6 feet W.S.W. 7 cables from the greater Buron. From the rock, Maitre ile beacon on with the middle of the Cotes bears S.E. by E. f E. ; and, Rozel mill open eastward of the Tour de Rozel S.S.W. southerly. The Hau is a rock with 12 feet water S.S.W. \ W. 3^ cables from the Joli ; this rock forms the northern boundary of the Ruau channel at its narrowest part. Platte Rock is one of the largest of the Drouilles group ; it is their south-eastern boundary and forms the western side of the southern entrance to l'Etoc channel. It dries 33 feet at low water, equinoctial springs. From the rock, Rozel mill on with Nez du Guet fort bears S.W. \ S. southerly ; and, the greater Buron N.W. \ W. westerly 8 cables. Among the less important rocks of the Drouilles group are, the Grese, which bears North nearly half a mile from the Platte and uncovers 29 feet ; Noire Roque, N.E. by E. a quarter of a mile from the greater Buron, which dries 35 feet ; Clump rock, marking the northern visible extreme of the group, dries 15 feet ; and, the Grunes, an extensive bed of rocks visible only near low water, half a mile westward of Clump rock. The Kosem, the northernmost sunken rock of the group, has 12 feet over it at low water. Le But, with only 8 feet water, is the western head of a group of rocks, of which several uncover from 4 to 6 feet. It bears W. \ N. northerly 8^ cables from the greater Buron. Another rock, with 21 feet water, bears W. by N. \ N. If cables from Le But ; this is the westernmost danger of the Drouilles.

Chap. V.] DROUILLES ROCKS— PASSE DE L'ETOC. 257 Clearing Marks.— Verclut point shut in by Coupe point, or Rozel mill well open westward of the Tour de Rozel S. by W., leads westward of the Drouilles. Maitre ile beacon open eastward of Grosse Tete S.E. £ S. clears their northern extreme. Seymour house and the breakwater house, Verclut point, in line S.S.W. £ W. clears their eastern side and leads through the Passe de l'Etoc. The Vielle and Grande Rousse rocks in line E. \ S. southerly lead southward of them. THE RUAU CHANNEL, between the Drouilles rocks and Jersey, is at its narrowest part 2£ miles wide, from 12 to 18 fathoms deep, and free from danger, but the confused sea caused by a strong weather tide over the rocky uneven bottom is sometimes so violent as to resemble breakers. The northern entrance to the Ruau, between the Drouilles and Pierres de Lecq, and sometimes called the Drouilles channel, is 4^ miles wide and free from danger ; the approach from the westward, between the Pierres de Lecq and Jersey, is also roomy and safe ; and, any sea man with a good chart may safely take his vessel through the Ruau channel and into Gorey outer road without a pilot. When the marks are indistinct, or at night, vessels should endeavour to keep in mid-channel when passing between the Pierres de Lecq and the Jersey coast, and through the Ruau channel. PASSE DE L'ETOC is the principal passage between the Drouilles and Ecrehos reefs ; it leaves to the westward the whole of the Drouilles rocks ; and, to the eastward, the Grande Rousse, Etoc, and Fierco rocks, besides the Grune du Nord-Ouest, Grune du Sud- Ouest, and many others. The narrowest part of the channel is between the Platte rock and Grune du Sud-Ouest, where it is only 3 cables wide. Grune du Sud-Ouest, on the eastern side of the southern entrance to the Passe de l'Etoc, bears S. by E. \ E. half a mile from the highest part of the Platte rock, and has 5 feet water. From the rock, Seymour house is a little open eastward of the breakwater house under Verclut point ; and, Maitre ile beacon on with the southern side of the Cotes rock bears E.S.E. Another 5-feet rock bears N.E. \ N. 1§ cables, and, a third rock with 8 feet water, 2\ cables E. \ S. from the outer Grune. A patch of 13 feet also lies on the western side of the leading mark for the Passe, but distant only 3 cables from the outer rock of the Grune du Sud-Ouest on a W. f N. bearing. A. 2771. Wt. 7242. Giffard and Bonne Nuit Bays.— Fremont point, a high bluff, is 8 cables westward of Belle Hougue point ; between them are these two small bays divided from each other by Crete point, on which is a fort. Giffard bay, the easternmost of the two, is small, but the ground is clean.

Chap.V.] PASSE DE L'ETOC— RONEZ,SOREL, AND PLEMONT POINTS. 259 Bonne Nuit bay may be easily recognised by St. John's barracks, a long range of low buildings near the middle of it ; also, by Mont Mado mill, which stands on the high land above and westward of them. Near the middle of the bay, about 2 cables from the shore, is the Cheval, a large black rock which only covers at high spring tides, with several sunken rocks half a cable outside it. A reef extends 2£ cables northward from Fremont point ; at its outer extreme is the Demie, a rock which dries 16 feet. Anchorage.— The best berth is about a quarter of a mile north ward of Crete point, in from 6 to 8 fathoms, sand and gravel. A vessel here is well sheltered from southerly and westerly winds, but should be prepared to slip in case of a sudden shift of wind to the northward. Shamrock Bank is a bed of rocks nearly 400 yards in diameter, The least water, 9 feet, is at the southern part of the bank, and there are from 6 to 12 fathoms close round it. From the 9-feet rock, Fremont point well open westward of the Demie rock bears S. f E. 6 cables ; Plemont hotel just within the outer part of Ronez point W. by N. £ N. ; the western house of St. John's barrack is a little open eastward of Fremont point ; and, Tour de Rozel is over the outer extreme of Belle Hougue point. Plemont and Ronez points in line W. by N. N. northerly lead in-shore of the Shamrock bank, a close mark for the 9-feet patch. St. John's Bay, between Fremont and Ronez points, is but a slight indentation of the coast ; its shore is, moreover, so fringed with rocks as to be almost inaccessible, and outlying rocks extend in some parts nearly 2 cables from the shore, between which and the Shamrock bank is a passage 4 cables wide. Strangers are advised, however, not to attempt passing through this channel without a pilot, nor to approach the land hereabout nearer than a mile. This part of the coast is remarkable from the extensive granite quarries which add to its naturally barren and wild appearance. RONEZ, SOREL, AND PLEMONT POINTS, unlike Belle Hougue and Grosnez points, are all low at their outer extremes, but rise at rather steep inclines to the high level plateau, which is the remarkable feature of the northern coast of the island, at distances of but little more than a quarter of a mile. Ronez and Sorel points are steep-to, but between and half a cable outside them is the Grune de Vicq, a sunken rock with only 3 feet R 2

Plaine Point has a reef extending half a cable from it; outside of which, however, it is steep-to. From Plaine point to Greve de Lecq the coast is cliffy, pre cipitous, and dangerous of approach, having outlying reefs and sunken rocks extending more than a quarter of a mile from the shore. GREVE DE LECQ BAY is near the middle of the bight between Sorel and Plemont points ; its position may be recognised at a distance by a whitewashed martello tower over the middle of its high sandy beach. The anchorage off Greve de Lecq is good and safe with all except northerly winds ; the best position is in from 9 to 6 fathoms, sand, with Greve de Lecq martello tower bearing between S. by W. and S.S.W. \ W. from 4 to 6 cables distant ; at the inner and western position, Plemont point is open of the Grand Becquet. The dangers in or near Greve de Lecq are as follows : — The Demies, of which the highest dries 16 feet, 1§ cables from the eastern headland of the bay, and N.E. by N. 3^ cables from the white martello tower. This rock is surrounded by others which dry at low water to the distance of half a cable, and the ground between them and the shore is rocky and foul. Grune de Becquet, with 21 feet water, bears N.E. £ E. 5f cables from Grand Becquet head. From the rock, Grosnez point seen over the low point of Plemont bears W. by N., and Greve de Lecq martello tower S. by W. Grune de Douet, with 12 feet water, is 3^ cables in-shore of the Grune de Becquet, and E. f N. 3 cables from Grand Becquet head. GREVE AU LANCON BAY, between Plemont and Grosnez points, is small but remarkable from its fine level white sandy beach, which, however, unlike Greve de Lecq, is entirely covered by the tide long before high water ; at which time, the sea rolls into the numerous caverns of the cliffs bounding the bay, cutting off all communication with the high land above and imparting a wild aspect to the coast. The dangers here are, a rock which dries 14 feet one cable from the shore, on the western side of the bay ; and the

Chap, v.] GREVE DE LECQ. — PIERRES DE LECQ. 261 reef extending a cable from Plemont point, which dries at low water. Small vessels bound southward round Grosnez point between half flood and half ebb, and unable to stem the tide, may advantageously anchor in this bay until half ebb, when the southern tide will have made and favour their proceeding through the swashway ; or, if eastward bound between the Pierres de Lecq and the island, and having anchored on the ebb, they can weigh at low water and carry a fair tide as far as Coupe point. The best anchorage is off the middle of the bay, with Grosnez bluff bearing about West, in from 9 to 6 fathoms, sand, but the holding ground is not good and a sailing vessel approaching or leaving the bay must be prepared for unsteady flaws of wind from the high land and varying eddies of tide. Caution. — No sailing vessel should anchor in any of the bays along the northern shore of Jersey with a northerly wind, but, should a vessel be surprised at anchor by a sudden shift of wind to that quarter, it may be advisable not to weigh until the weather tide makes, in order to ensure getting out. PIERRES DE LECQ or PATERNOSTERS is a rocky group, of which the western end in 5£ fathoms bears N.E. by N. 2f miles from Grosnez point ; they are nearly abreast of Greve de Lecq bay, and their central and highest rock bears N.N.E. northerly 2f miles from the white martello tower in that bay. Four large rocks, from 20 to 30 feet above high water, lie near the middle but towards the south-eastern side of the reef ; the Great rock is the most southern and highest of these ; from it, the reef dries in numerous places north-westward for nearly a mile ; and, south-eastward of the Great rock, are rocky banks, of which the outer one, with 20 feet water, is distant 6 cables from it. The most dangerous rock in this quarter is the Grune de Lecq, which dries 2 feet and bears S. by E. £ E. 4^ cables from the Great rock. Clearing Marks. — Corbiere lighthouse on with Pinnacle point S. by W. i W. leads between the Pierres de Lecq and the Bane Desormes. A nearer mark for the former is St. Peter's mill on with Greve de Lecq flagstaff S. by E. \ E. The Tour de Rozel shut in behind Belle Hougue point S.E. \ E. leads south-westward of them.
