GENERAL DIRECTIONS.— The necessity for taking regular and careful soundings cannot be too deeply impressed on the mind of the mariner when approaching the Channel islands, or when navigating amongst them at night or in thick weather ; for, although the islands and reefs generally are steep-to, so that the lead may give little or no warning of their near neighbourhood, it is possible for a vessel to be set inside their boundaries without seeing them, when a knowledge of the depth might enable her to anchor and thus save the vessel. Mariners are also cautioned against placing dependence on making out the distant marks for out-lying dangers, many of which can only be distinguished in very clear weather and by those acquainted with the localities. Moreover, there are extensive banks of gravel and sand amongst the islands as well as other occasional irregularities in the bottom, which the careful pilot would know how to turn to account in estimating his position ; and, on the French coast eastward of the islands, the soundings are generally so regular that the lead may be taken as a safe guide in estimating distances from that shore. When the position is uncertain and the lead is hove, it is often useful to keep it on the ground for a minute or two in order to note the direction and strength of the tidal stream. For, as the streams vary considerably both in strength and direction, according to position, and as diagrams giving precise information on this subject are engraved on the charts, a reference to the chart with the know ledge thus gained may be very useful. When the stream is running strongly, tide ripples and overfalls always make their appearance over sunken rocks, out-lying banks, or other exposed places ; in foggy weather, therefore, such indications may be turned to good account. In thick weather an anchor should always be ready when navigating among the islands ; but, before letting go, if possible, always turn the vessel's head to the tide, or there will be great danger of snapping the cable.

Chap. V.] GENERAL DIRECTIONS.— APPROACH BY NIGHT. 263 APPROACHES BY NIGHT.— From the "Westward- Endeavour to make either the Hanois or Roches-Douvres light and fix the position of the ship accurately by bearings before shaping a course for the Corbiere light or for Grosnez point, according to whether the vessel is proceeding by the southern or northern coast of the island. Should a vessel pass inside the line of these lights in thick weather without seeing them, the lead ought to be frequently hove until the Corbiere light is seen and the position ascertained beyond doubt. On the meridian of the Hanois, 34 fathoms will be obtained, shoaling to 32 and 30 fathoms along the Deroute channel as far as Serk ; whilst, southward of a line drawn from the Roches- Douvres to Grosnez point, the depths vary between 26 and 23 fathoms. If bound for St. Helier, when within 2 or 3 miles westward of the Corbiere it is safest to heave to and wait for daylight. In thick weather, do not approach the Corbiere into less than 17 or 18 fathoms, and lay the vessel's head N.W. by N. during the whole of the flood, as the stream sets strongly down towards the Minquiers, and many vessels have been lost on that reef through neglecting this precaution. A steam-vessel of light draught with a good pilot, in a fine clear night and during the upper half of the tide, may safely proceed from this position to St. Helier harbour. Having brought the Corbiere light to bear East distant 2^ or 2 miles, she should steer direct for Noirmont point, which should be approached within a quarter of a mile, and, from thence, she should steer out a little to ensure clearing the Pignonet rock ; then, E. by S. for the entrance of the Little road, keeping a look out for the green and red leading lights on Albert pier, and when they are in line keeping them so up to the entrance of the harbour ; see also directions, pages 221-228. From the South-west. — Do not approach the reefs fronting St. Aubin bay into a less depth than 10 or 12 fathoms ; should this depth be obtained and the vessel's position be doubtful, anchor if practicable and wait for daylight. From the North-west. — From St. Peter Port, Guernsey, steer so as to sight the ivhite light on the Corbiere rock on a S. by E. E. bearing, which on a clear night will be done shortly after passing St. Martin's point ; take care not to lose sight of the white light, and when Grosnez point bears E.S.E., if it be desired to pass outside West rock, on which, however, there, are 6 fathoms, steer

[Chap. V. 264 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — JERSEY. S.W. by S. until past that danger, after which steer to pass 2 or 3 miles westward of the Corbiere, where a vessel should heave to and wait for a pilot or for daylight. Should there not be too much swell, a vessel could anchor for a time on the Great bank in from 5 to 8 fathoms N.W. by N. about 1£ miles from Corbiere light ; or between this position and No. 4 martello tower in St. Ouen bay, where the water is generally smoother and the tide not so strong. From the Northward.— Having made cape de la Hague light, enter the Race of Alderney, see page 346, as near mid-channel as possible, and, from thence, steer S. by W. or S.W. by S., according to the state of the tide, passing 4 or 5 miles eastward of the Bane de la Schole. Should the weather be clear, the position of the ship may be ascertained and the course regulated by the coast lights with accuracy. If the lights are obscured, it is best not to enter the Race until daylight ; but, if compelled to do so, remember that a moderate depth and good anchorage may always be secured by hauling in towards the French coast.* Should there be too much swell to anchor, and the weather be moderately clear, Serk is very steep-to and safe of approach except on a north-westerly bearing, in the direction of the Blanchard rock. During the upper half of the tide, if it is desired to maintain a position near Serk, bring the middle of that island to bear S.W. ; and, during the lower half, N.N.E. ; in calm weather, the drift will then be away from the island. From the middle of the Race towards the eastern coast of Jersey, to pass through the Drouilles channel, steer as directed until cape de Carteret light bears E. by S. St. Catherine's light should now be seen if the weather is clear, and, kept opening and shutting in with Coupe point S.S.E., it leads nearly midway between the Drouilles and Belle Hougue point. When inside the Drouilles, open St. Catherine's light of Coupe point, and do not approach Jersey nearer than a mile ; after passing the light, bring it to bear N.N.W. \ W. from one to 1^ miles distant, and anchor in about 9 fathoms until daylight. Should St. Catherine's light not be seen when cape de Carteret light bears E. by S., proceed with caution ; bearing in mind that from the northernmost of the Pierres de Lecq, cape de Carteret light bears E. \ S., and that a line drawn from the one to the other clears * In easterly winds there is good anchorage in Vauville bay southward of cape de la Hague, and all along the coast to nearly abreast of cape de Carteret 3 or 4 miles from the land in from 12 to 14 fathoms ; see also pages 180-183 and 187.

Chap, v.] APPROACH BY NIGHT.— TIDAL STREAMS. 265 the northern extreme of the Drouilles reef by a mile. The Drouilles are all so low that they would hardly be seen at night until a vessel was amongst them ; but, as they are faced on their northern side by a fringe of sunken reef or bank, the lead, if carefully attended to, should give warning of their neighbourhood. The Pierres de Lecq being steep-to on the eastern side and some part of the rocks always visible, are much safer to approach at night than the Drouilles. Of course neither these nor any other dangers should be approached under circumstances of difficulty with the tide. Grosnez bluff bearing W. by S. just clears the inner or southern edge of the Pierres de Lecq reef. If bound through the Deroute channel round the western coast of Jersey, from the middle of the Race steer S. by W. or S.W. by S., as before directed, until cape de Carteret light bears E.S.E., to clear the Blanchard rock off Serk ; then haul out westward into the Deroute channel clear of the Pierres de Lecq and of the Bane Desormes, and when the Corbiere white light is in sight bearing S. by E. £ E. a S. by W. course may be steered until within 2 or 3 miles abreast of the Corbiere rock, where a vessel should heave-to and wait for day light, or act as already directed in coming from the westward. TIDAL STREAMS. — Along the northern and southern shores of the island, between Grosnez point and Belle Hougue point on the North, and between Corbiere rock and Seymour tower on the South, the whole of the flood stream runs eastward and the jebb westward, following the trend of the land, and each for 6 hours, the velocity at springs being about 4 knots, and at neaps about 2 knots. In Grouville, St. Catherine, and St. Ouen bays, the stream runs northward between half flood and half ebb, and southward between half ebb and half flood, with a velocity in each case of 4| knots at springs and 2^ knots at neaps ; the streams consequently meet off the four extremes of the island, viz., Coupe point, Grosnez point, Corbiere point, and the Conchiere rock. The rotary changes of direction of the tidal stream round Jersey being the governing cause of the various sets close to its shores, some description of its action is necessary. Assuming, therefore, the time of high water and a position about 4 miles S.W. of St. Helier, the stream which has been hitherto setting S.E. and East now quickly alters its direction to N.E., which a glance at the chart will show is full on to the southern coast of the island, making the space included between the assumed position and the land what pilots call the crown of the tide, and causing slack water as the shore is approached.

266 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— JERSEY. [Chap. V. The northern side of the island, at this time lying in the lee or eddy, slack water is caused there also ; but, along the eastern and western coasts, the tide is setting northward at its full strength. At half ebb, the offing stream has veered round from North to N.W. and S.W. ; the crown of the tide is now on the eastern side of Jersey, and the western side is in the lee or eddy, causing slack water at this time in Grouville and St. Ouen bays at the opposite ends of the island, the stream at the same time running at its full strength westward along the northern and southern coasts of the island. At low water, the stream is setting from the northward on to the northern shore of Jersey, making the crown of the tide on that side and the lee on the southern side of the island, causing slack water on those sides whilst the stream is running with its full strength southward along the eastern and western sides. At half flood, the crown of the tide is on the western coast, the lee on the eastern side with slack water on those sides, whilst the stream is setting with its full strength eastward along the northern and southern shores. A careful consideration of this rotary action of the tidal stream serves to explain all peculiarities of the tides in the bays of the island. Thus, at Noirmont point near half flood, when the eastern stream attains its full strength, there is an outset from St. Aubin bay, which runs with considerable strength between Pointe de But and the Pignonet rocks, and is perceptible within the bay as far as St. Aubin castle ; at first, this is a mere eddy of the flood stream originating under Noirmont point, but as, after half flood, the stream shifts from East to N.E. and sets right on the Hermitage rocks and Elizabeth castle, the very gentle incline of the sandy shore here and the great space to be covered causes the level of the sea at this part of the bay to be considerably raised above that of the western side, and the water of course runs off in the direction of the lower level. On referring to the chart it will be seen that the form of the bay tends to deflect the stream from a north-easterly to a northerly direction ; it is not, therefore, difficult to understand why the small eddy under Noirmont point, when reinforced by the westerly flow round the head of the bay, becomes the continuous outset from Noirmont point just described ; this outset runs for 9 hours, viz., from half flood to high water and during the whole of the ebb ; it attains its greatest strength about an hour after high water, and at this time, during a westerly gale at spring tides, it throws up a dangerous breaking sea or race off Noirmont point.

Chap, v.] TIDAL STREAMS. 267 From similar causes, viz., the shifting and impinging on the land of the offing stream, the tide sets northward across the mouth as well as into the harbour of St. Helier during the whole of the flood, and southward during the ebb, except near the Bridge inside Eliza beth castle, where the tide sets north-westward from the last quarter flood until the Bridge is awash at one foot less than half tide. In the offing, south-westward and clear of the island, the strength of both tidal streams runs in a N.W. and S.E. direction, remain ing longer near those points than any other ; and, it has been already shown that near high water it quickly changes its course to East and North-east, at this latter point running full on the island and making high water there. It does not, however, continue in this direction for any length of time, but veers round by North to a north-westerly direction, where its shifting movement is much slower ; the strength of this north-western stream is felt at half ebb on the southern coast of Jersey. To arrive at a right understanding of the force and effect of the ocean swell along the southern coast of Jersey in westerly gales it is necessary to follow this changing direction of the offing stream. An hour before high water, on the slacking of the south-eastern stream in the offing, the western stream sets round Noirmont point to the westward, checking the advancing westerly swell during gales from that quarter, and causing it to break heavily. As this natural breakwater forms off Noirmont point and its outlying reefs, the water within and to leeward, both in St. Aubin bay and St. Helier road, becomes smoother, and, as the western or ebb stream increases in strength so does the swell continue to decrease. After the tide has fallen below half ebb, the outlying reefs, gradually uncovering, assist materially in blocking out the swell, but, after low water, the offing stream changes, and the westerly swell rolls in again with the eastern stream, increasing in force with the rising tide, until again checked by the slacking of the offing stream and the making of the western stream in-shore.

268 CHAPTER VI. GUERNSEY, HERM, AND SERK, WITH THE RUSSELL CHANNELS. VARIATION in 1888, 18° 10' W. In the opening pages of the preceding chapter the appearance of Guernsey, when first sighted from the westward, as contrasted with Jersey, is fully described, and general information given on the approaches to the Channel islands, as well as on the peculiarities of wind and weather, soundings, and tides, so far as the islands generally are affected. A particular description of Guernsey, Herm, and Serk now follow.* GUERNSEY — The most remarkable objects which first present themselves when running for the south-western end of Guernsey are, the light-tower on the Hanois rocks, the white castellated tower of Fort Grey in the centre of the sandy bay of Rocquaine, Plein mont guard-house, Torteval church spire, and Eree tower, on a hummock at the northern part of Rocquaine bay, near Lihou island. Pleinmont guard-house is on the heights southward of the bay near the bluff. Torteval church, with its round tower surmounted by a high steeple, stands at a little distance inland and is as conspicuous in this part of the island as Catel and Vale churches are in the northern part.f As the coast is approached, the northern part of the island sloping gradually northward from the high southern plateau begins to rise above the horizon, presenting a surface diversified with houses, churches, windmills, and groups of trees, all of which become still more conspicuous if seen from a north-westerly direction. * See Admiralty charts :— Channel islands, No. 2,669 a, b ; scale m = 0'5 inch ; and Guernsey, Serk, and Herm islands, 3 sheets, No. 262 a, b, c, with Views ; scale m = t'O inches. To reduce all the depths and heights given in this Chapter as well as in the Admiralty chart of Guernsey to the lowest or highest tides, subtract 3 feet 9 inches from the depths or add that quantity to the heights. ■\ See views on Admiralty chart, No. 262 c.

Chap. VI.] GENERAL DESCRIPTION.— APPROACH. 269 The western shore of Guernsey is studded with precipitous rocks, of which many are wholly detached from the land. On the high land above St. Martin's point at the south-eastern end of the island is a stone column, erected in honour of Lieut-General Sir John Doyle ; it is 96 feet high, with its summit 424 feet above the level of low water. Another remarkable object is the Victoria tower, 100 feet high and 322 feet above low water, erected on the heights above St. Peter Port to commemorate the visit of Her Majesty the Queen in 1846. It is a square tower, slightly tapering from its base, sur mounted by a battlemented gallery, with square turrets at its angles. The island of Guernsey is nearly in the form of a right-angled triangle, the north-western side forming the hypothenuse, the length of which is about 8 miles. The land on the southern side is high and steep, its general elevation being about 300 feet ; the highest part is Hautnez, over Icart bay, which is 363 feet above the level of low water, but it gradually lowers towards the North, where, in some places, it is little above the sea level. The island is encompassed by many dangerous rocks, of which the principal are the Hanois, Sambule, and Grunes, on the western and north-western sides ; the Braye rocks with several others on the northern side ; and, on the north-eastern and eastern sides lie the Amfroque rocks, together with the islands of Herm and Jethou, which are also themselves surrounded by numerous rocks and ledges. Guernsey contains 16,000 acres of land, which is fertile and highly cultivated ; its population in 1881 was 32,379, and it does not grow grain enough, nor raise a sufficient number of cattle to supply its inhabitants. Approach from the Westward.— Vessels bound to Guernsey from the westward should not approach the island in thick weather within a depth of 40 or 38 fathoms, unless their position has been well ascertained previously. Careful allowance should also be made for the flood stream setting in towards the island. The water is deep 2 cables westward of Hanois lighthouse, see page 275 ; but,from it, dangerous rocks extend S.S.W. 3^ cables, N.N.W. 1\ cables, and North one mile. The Grune de l'Ouest, or du Nord-Ouest, a rock which dries 10 feet at low water, springs, and which was formerly considered the northernmost danger off Guernsey, bears N.E. \ E. nearly 5 miles from Hanois lighthouse ; but, as several sunken rocks on which the sea breaks heavily in bad weather have been discovered outside it, of which the Boue Blondel, the most western, has only 5£ fathoms water and bears from the lighthouse

[Chap. VI. 270 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— GUERNSEY. N. by E. | E. 3^ miles, it is recommended that, to clear all these dangers, vessels from the South or West passing westward of Guernsey at night, should not bring Hanois light westward of South until the Casquets light bears E.N.E. Anchorages. — Rocquaine and Perelle bays, on the western coast of Guernsey, are so surrounded by rocks as to be unsafe of approach for any but the smallest vessels ; there are, however, several anchorages on the southern side, especially at Icart and Petit Port bays, where, with the wind off the land, a vessel may stop for a tide ; but even they are not safe for a stranger to approach, and no vessel without a pilot should close the southern coast so as to shut in the North point of Serk with Jerbourg bluff. St. Peter Port road, on the eastern side of the island, affords good shelter except with the wind between S.W. by S. and S.E., and the holding ground is excellent. There is also good anchorage at the northern end of the Great bank, on the eastern side of the island, as well as on the northern coast off Fort Doyle, and in Ancresse, Grand Havre, Cobo and Vazon bays ; but, at most of these places it is necessary to employ a pilot. Pilotage. — By ordinance of the Royal Court of Guernsey it is enacted, that every pilot boat shall carry a flag, half red and half white, the white part uppermost ; the letter P shall be marked in black on the white part, and the pilot's number in white on the red part near the centre of the flag ; the whole under penalty of a fine, at the discretion of the court. And, that every ship or vessel of above 50 tons burthen, new admeasurement, shall be bound to take a pilot, both on her arrival in this island and on her departure, on pain of paying the usual pilotage to the pilot who shall first have presented himself for the purpose of undertaking the conduct or pilotage thereof. Steam-vessels and yachts are excepted, also ships or vessels putting into the roads in consequence of stress of weather or contrary winds and putting to sea again, provided they do not load or unload merchandise or ballast. In case a pilot is prevented by tempestuous weather from getting on board a ship or vessel at sea such ship or vessel and the pilot boat shall so manage as to enable the pilot boat to take the lead and serve as a guide, and such ship or vessel shall pay the same pilotage as if the pilot had actually gone on board.

Beacons. — When beacons marking rocks in the vicinity of Guernsey require renewing, it is the intention of the Government that, as far as possible, each beacon shall be capped with the initial letter of the name of the rock on which it stands. The carrying out of this principle has been commenced ; thus, for instance, the Vermerette beacon in the Passe Percee instead of bearing a triangle as formerly, is now surmounted by the letter V in white. Tidal Streams.* — The eastern or flood stream makes close in-shore soon after low water along the southern and north-western coasts of Guernsey, whilst the south-western stream is still running at its strength in the offing 4 miles westward of the island ; between these positions the streams vary in strength and direction as one or the other is approached. The flood stream between Guernsey and the rocks projecting from the south-western end of Jethou island takes two different direc tions ; one part runs directly through the Great road and Little Russell channel ; the other branches off nearly at right angles and runs eastward towards Jethou, passing through the before-mentioned rocks and into the Great Russell. The ebb stream takes exactly the reverse direction, the stream from the Great Russell, after having passed through the rocks of Jethou, uniting with that through the road, and both setting south-westward. With Grande Braye rock a boat's length open westward of Brehon tower, a vessel keeps in the stream which sets through the road and Little Russell, but the Grande Braye on with Brehon tower places her in the indraught of the Great Russell. It is high water in the Great and Little Russell channels at the same time as at St. Peter Port, viz., at 6 h. 37 m., full and change, the last half of the falling and the first half of the rising tide occurring with the south-western stream ; and, the last half of the rising and first half of the falling tide with the north-eastern stream. In other words, at low water by the shore at St. Peter Port the south-western stream has been running nearly 3 hours and is at its strength, and at high water by the shore the north-eastern stream has been running nearly 3 hours and is also at its full strength. Thus, off the eastern end of the island, the streams turn at about half tide by the shore and run nearly 5^ hours each way, allowing something more than a quarter of an hour for the slack at each change of stream. In the Great Russell, the strength of the north-eastern stream runs E.N.E. and of the south-western stream W.S.W. ; and, in the Little Russell the direction of the two streams at their greatest strength is N.E. \ E. and S.W. \ W. nearly. At the north-eastern entrance of the Little Russell, however, between the Braye and Amfroque rocks, the stream takes the direction of that in the offing, viz., the first two hours of the flood directly for the northern end of Herm island, gradually joining the south-western stream through the Russell, and the last hour of the flood as well as the first of the ebb joining the north-eastern stream. To understand the various sets of the tides in the Russell channels, and round the outer shores of this group of islands, it is necessary to consider their governing cause, viz., the rotary change of direct ion in the offing stream, which in one tide runs in regular succession from every point of the compass. At high water by the shore, as just shown, the stream is setting E.N.E. fairly through the Russell channels, and is then at its greatest strength, coinciding nearly with the general direction of the offing stream, which, at this time, westward of Guernsey is running E. by N., and eastward of Serk N.N.E. Three hours after high water, or at half ebb, the direction of the offing stream in its progressive change from North to West, &c, is setting about N.W. by N., which a glance at the chart will show to be right across the northern entrance of the Russell channels, producing, as might be expected, a slack tide in the Great Russell under the lee of Serk, and still more so in the Little Russell, protected as it is by Herm, Jethou, and the numerous rocks northward and southward of those islands. At low water the offing stream has got round to W.S.W.,

Chap, vi.] 273 TIDAL STREAMS. and as this is about the direction of the Russell channels, the south western stream at this time attains its greatest strength. After low water, the island of Guernsey appears to obstruct some what the free course of the main stream into the channels eastward of it ; and, at half flood, partly owing to this obstruction and partly to the rising waters at the northern and southern ends of the island being pretty evenly balanced, and notwithstanding the strong easterly stream along its northern and southern shores, slack water prevails throughout the whole extent of the Russell channels. The rising tide on the southern side gradually prevailing, forces the flood or north-eastern stream through these channels, attaining its greatest strength, as before stated, near high water. Consideration of the foregoing general remarks is necessary in order to understand the great diversity in the set of streams and eddies about these islands. It must be also remembered that a body of water once set in motion continues to move onward for some time after the removal of the originating force ; thus, the Russell streams continue to run south-westward for some time after the source of supply has been cut off, and until the greater and more rapid rise of tide southward of Guernsey causes a reversal of the stream. The south-westerly streams, when they meet the first of the eastern stream off St. Martin's point, blend with it and make a south-eastern stream which, at springs, runs with considerable strength from the northern end of the Great bank south-eastward for some distance outside the Tetes d'Aval, but is not felt inside the Great bank, nor near St. Martin's point. The value of a thorough knowledge of the tides may be illustrated by following the track of a Guernsey boatman on a trip to the eastern side of Serk and back. He will take a fair tide the whole distance. Leaving Guernsey road a little after low water, he proceeds with a fair tide to the S.E., outside the Tetes d'Aval until he meets the eastern stream, with which he sails southward of Serk. Near l'Etac de Serk he runs into a northerly stream, which accompanies him along the eastern side of the island as far as Le Creux. On his return to Guernsey he will round the northern point of Serk about an hour after high water, at which time the turning of the offing stream towards the North removes the pressure of the Great Russell stream from the Bee du Nez and causes an eddy from it to the Givaude rock off Brecqhou, and he will carry an eddy or counter stream as far as the Givaude rock, outside of which he will meet the true stream setting north-westward at 2 hours after high water. Close to the coasts of the Channel islands, as well as in the offing outside them, the general drift of the tidal stream appears to corre spond with its rotary motion from right to left ; for, it has frequently happened that floating objects near the shore have been seen succes sively on their northern, western, southern, and eastern coasts. Moreover, part of a wrecked vessel having drifted from a rock near the Casquets during calm weather was known to take a south-westerly course, and to drift with a rotary motion through a succession of parabolic tidal curves at the rate of about 4 miles per day, round the western and southern coasts of Guernsey, several miles distant from the island, and up the Deroute and Race streams ; whilst other parts of the same wreck, having probably drifted off the rock at the com mencement of the western stream, and having therefore . been set farther out westward, were met with about the same time several miles within and eastward of the Roches-Douvres. Such examples prove the existence of a drift which coincides with the shifting movement of the tidal stream ; south-westerly from the Casquets, southerly past Guernsey, easterly and southerly between Guernsey and the Roches-Douvres, and northerly when eastward of the islands. The easterly and main branch of this drift, as already noticed, passes up the Deroute and Race channels, and it seems highly probable that after clearing the Race of Alderney it turns off west ward past that island, reunites with its own stream again off the Casquets, and repeats the same round as before in endless succession. This drift, commonly known as the " indraught of the gulf of St. Malo," was formerly supposed to exist only during fresh westerly breezes, and doubtless its strength is greatly increased at such times, but there is now no doubt that between the Casquets and the Roches- Douvres it is continuous, and with a rate proportioned to the strength of the tidal stream. These facts serve to show that vessels going round the islands, as well as those navigating the channels between them, may occasionally shorten their passages materially by following the curves of the tidal streams instead of taking direct courses. HANOIS LIGHT.— The light tower on the Bise rock, the south western rock of the Hanois group, one mile off the western end of Guernsey, exhibits, at 100 feet above high water, a revolving red light of the first order, which attains its greatest brilliancy every forty-five seconds, and is visible in clear weather from a distance of 12 miles all round the horizon except when obscured by the island of Guernsey between the bearings W. by S. £ S. and N.W. \ W. ; the line of eclipse in this latter direction passes 3§ miles south-westward of l'Etac de Serk, and over the Pierres de Lecq rocks off the northern coast of Jersey. The light tower is of gray granite and 117 feet high from base to vane ; from it, the Casquets lighthouse bears N. E. by E. 21^ miles ; Corbiere lighthouse, Jersey, S.S.E. h E. easterly 23£ miles ; and, the Roches-Douvres S.S.W. f W. 20 miles. Fog Signal. — A bell is sounded in thick or foggy weather every fifteen seconds from Hanois lighthouse. The rocks and shoals of the Hanois group, referred to at page 269, are more particularly included and described under the head of " Rocquaine bay," in the following pages ; a brief description of the outer dangers in approaching the north-western coast of Guernsey being first given. COAST.— The north- western side of Guernsey should not be approached nearer than 3^ miles, several dangerous rocky ledges lying off it, of which those most to be feared are the Grande Etacre, Sambule, Soufleuresse and Boin, and the Grunes de l'Ouest or du Nord-Ouest. The Grande Etacre dries 19 feet at low water, springs ; the Sambule 16 feet ; the Soufleuresse 10 feet ; the Boin 3 feet ; and, the Grimes de l'Ouest 10 feet. ROCQUAINE BAY, between Lihou island on the North and the Grosse rock on the South, is H miles wide ; it is fronted by numerous groups of rocks as well as by isolated ones, of which many are always above water ; a far greater number uncover with the falling tide, and those which never uncover are still more numerous. The anchorage in this bay is well sheltered from northerly, easterly, and southerly winds ; but, westerly winds send in such a heavy sea, especially between half flood and half ebb, that a sailing vessel caught in the bay under such circumstances could not possibly get out. The holding ground, consisting generally of fine gravel and sand covered with grass and sea-weed, is not good. It is only frequented by fishermen of the neighbourhood, or occasionally by vessels calculated to take the beach ; nevertheless, at the anchorage in the south-western part of the bay off Pezerie point, a vessel of not more than 12 or 13 feet draught, well moored, would ride securely all the year round under any circumstances of wind and weather.

TroiS P6"res bank is the largest and most conspicuous rocky group in the northern part of Rocquaine bay ; the Pendante, its outer rock, is 50 feet above low water and bears W. \ S. one mile from Lihou lower house. The other Trois Peres rocks are about the same height, but nearly a cable within the Pendante. Rocks of nearly the same height are also on the eastern front of this reef. A 15-feet passage exists between the Trois Peres bank and Lihou island, for which the leading mark is, Torteval spire on with the north-eastern side of Fort Grey ; but, neither this nor any other passage into Rocquaine bay should be attempted without a pilot, unless under most urgent circumstances. Hanois bank, from h\ to 8 cables westward of the Pendante rock, extends in a N.W. \ N. and S.E. \ S. direction for about half a mile, and the Haut Fourquie, the highest rock, is on its inner part and dries 10 feet ; two other rocks dry 5 feet near its outer extreme. ST. PETER PORT, the capital of Guernsey, stands on the eastern shore of the island, and, in 1881, its population numbered 16,658. From the sea, it has rather an imposing appearance, but it is irregularly built. It is the seat of government of the northern division (or Bailiwick, as it is termed) of the Channel islands, which includes Alderney, Serk, Herm, and Jethou. Its old tidal harbour, carrying a depth of 20 feet alongside the quays at high water, springs, and 10 feet at neaps, is enclosed by the new harbour, formed between two breakwaters, with a depth in its outer part of 10 feet at low water, springs. The principal articles of export are cider, apples, potatoes, grapes and other fruits, building stone, and granite in a broken state for the repair of roads. The imports are British manufactures, coal, wine, sugar, coffee, and other provisions, grain, and cattle — the two latter

[Chap. VI. 282 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— GUERNSEY. chiefly from France. In the year 1862 the number of vessels belonging to the port was 128, their total registered tonnage 19,679 tons, and they were manned by 1,053 seamen. In the year 1886, including the little port of St. Sampson's, 2,172 vessels, of an aggregate tonnage of 363,220 tons, entered the port. There are two patent slips, but no dock accommodation, and no appliances for the repair of iron ships or machinery; moderate repairs on wooden vessels up to about 400 tons can be effected. Communication. — St. Peter Port is in telegraphic communication with England by cable from its north-eastern point to Dartmouth, and with France through Jersey, also with Alderney by cable from Ancresse bay ; it is in daily communication by steamer with Southampton and Jersey all the year round, and with Weymouth daily in summer, but bi-weekly in winter ; with London, Plymouth, Cher bourg, and St. Brieuc weekly ; with Bristol and Morlaix periodically ; with Alderney bi-weekly ; and, with Serk, thrice a week regularly, and almost daily in summer. There is no railway in the island. Supplies. — Coal in small quantities can be obtained at St. Peter Port, the stock in hand averaging about 200 tons, and the price from about 11. to 11 2s. 6d. per ton. Vessels coal alongside the wharf in 11 feet at low water, springs. The only accessible watering place for vessels formerly was at Fermain bay, about a mile northward of St. Martin's point, where, with the wind from N.N.E. round by West to S.W., boats with long hoses may fill at pleasure almost any quantity ; but pipes are now laid from the large reservoir at Havelet to the harbours, where water is now supplied at a shilling a ton. St. Peter Port market furnishes fresh meat, fish, vegetables, and fruit in abundance at a cheap rate. Harbours. — The old tidal harbour of St. Peter Port, 4| acres in area, is enclosed by piers of masonry 25 feet high, with an entrance 80 feet wide facing the East. On the southern pier-head is a white wooden lighthouse 20 feet in height. The depth at high water springs, between the pier-heads is 24| feet, and 14| feet at neaps ; the average depth along the quays on the same tides being respectively 20 and 10 feet. South-eastward of the old harbour stands Castle Cornet, connected with the mainland by a massive granite causeway and wooden viaduct. The new harbour works comprise two esplanades, one on each side of the old harbour, running parallel with the sea front of the town, and averaging together 2,500 feet in length and 150 feet in breadth. From the extremes of these esplanades extend two break-

Chap, vi.] 283 ST. PETER PORT. waters, one on either side and equi-distant from the old harbour ; being 2,500 feet apart at the base and projecting eastward so as to enclose the natural sandy bay in front of the town, the whole space of both harbours thus enclosed being about 73 acres, of which all but about 23 acres dries at low water, springs. The South or Castle breakwater is carried across the rocky isthmus, by which, at low water, Castle Cornet is connected with the main, and terminates at the north-western bastion of the Castle, being 1,900 feet in length. The southern face of this break water consists of an upright wall and parapet of rough masonry 15 feet above the level of the highest tides, and along it is a level road way and footpath 120 feet wide. On the northern side and under the lee of this arm it is proposed to construct a wet dock or basin ; a boat camber is also to be constructed. From the north-eastern angle of Castle Cornet outwards, a rough stone breakwater projects 600 feet farther eastward, its end marked by a circular granite light house 40 feet high from base to vane. These works effectually screen the entrance of the harbour from the most exposed quarter, the southward, and add greatly to the security of the anchorage in the road. The North or St. Jullien's breakwater and landing pier begins northward of the old harbour, at the end of the esplanade, and extends in an easterly direction about 1,400 feet as far as the head of the Blanche rock, from whence it takes a southerly direction, a little outside the line of Castle Cornet, for nearly 900 feet, leaving an entrance between the pier-end and the rocks off Castle Cornet of 370 feet in width, and completely sheltering the pool within. This pier has three capital landing stages for steamers along the inner side of its outer part, having 9, 8, and 3 feet respectively at the lowest spring tides, at which time there are 10 feet at the entrance near the pier-head, and 6 feet near the middle of the pool, from whence the water shoals gradually and regularly towards the shore. The bottom of the harbour is almost entirely of fine sand, except on the southern side, where is a rocky ledge marked on its edge by two buoys, one red, the other black.* A Life-boat is stationed at St. Peter Port. * The depths as well as heights, &c, appearing in this Chapter and in the Admiralty chart of Guernsey, are reckoned from a zero of low water, mean springs. The lowest tide registered at Guernsey from 1858 to 1868 fell 3 feet 9 inches below that zero. On February 10th 1887, the lowest tide on record took place, the tide falling 1 feet si inches below the zero and the range of the same tide being 33 feet 6 inches. The least range of tide recorded in Guernsey is 6 feet ; it took place both on the 7th April and 16th September 1858.

284 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— GUERNSEY. [Chap. VI. ST. PETER PORT ROAD fronts the town north-eastward of Castle Cornet. The holding ground is excellent, and the road affords good shelter against all winds, except those from between S.W. by S. and S.E., which send in much swell and sea, especially on the ebb tide, rendering this anchorage then unsafe. Under such circumstances, smoother water may probably be found under the lee of the Great bank, where a vessel will be much safer than in the road, as, in the event of parting, she may run through the Little Russell and anchor off Fort Doyle or in Ancresse bay. A vessel should, if possible, lie at single anchor in St. Peter Port road, always keeping a second anchor ready ; but, if compelled to moor, the anchors should be laid in the direction of the stream. The best anchorage is within the folloAving limits : — Southern limit, St. Peter Port church on with Castle Cornet breakwater end ; northern limit, Sardrette rock beacon and Victoria tower in line ; western limit, the outer angle of Castle Cornet on with the white beacon on Fermain point ; eastern limit, the Anfre beacon on with the eastern extreme of St. Martin's barracks. Within this space, there are from 5 to 11 fathoms, fine sand ; farther southward, the bottom is coarse and the depth increases to 20 fathoms. There is a government 2£ inch mooring chain laid down in 5 fathoms, about 2 cables north-eastward of Castle Cornet breakwater lighthouse, and, within the harbour, are several small mooring and warping buoys. Tides.— It is high water, full and change, at St. Peter Port at 6 h. 37 m. ; equinoctial springs rise 33 feet, ordinary springs 26 feet, neaps 18f feet ; neaps range 111 feet. The general level of the sea is liable to be depressed or raised 2 or 3 feet, or even more, by strong easterly or westerly winds. See note page 283. LIGHTS.— On the outer end of Castle Cornet breakwater, at the southern side of the entrance to the outer harbour, is a fixed white light 46 feet above high water, and visible 9 miles. It shows as a bright light from North round by East to South, and as a dim light landward, from South round by West to North. From the light house, the Longue Pierre rock beacon bears S. by W. f W. nearly 2 miles ; Tetes d'Aval rocks buoy S.E. by S. 2\ miles ; Rousse rock E.N.E. 2\ miles ; Platte rock N.E. f E. 2\ miles ; and, the Roustel rock black buoy N.E. by E. \ E. easterly 2\ miles. On the outer end of the northern, St. Jullien's, breakwater is exhibited a faint green light. On the southern pier-head of the old harbour is exhibited a red fixed light, visible 3 miles ; it is 34 feet above high water and may

Chap. VI.] ST. PETER PORT ROAD. — DIRECTIONS. 285 be seen from the Russell channels, and also from the southward when St. Martin's point is rounded. When bearing W. by N. a N. it leads into the harbour. Northward of St. Peter Port, the eastern shore of the island is fronted by rocks and ledges and is very foul ; the outer and most important of these dangers are included in the description of the Little Russell channel ; see pages 295-298. Within 1^ cables of the elbow of the St. Jullien breakwater, are three rocks marked by beacons. The Sardrette marked by a pole surmounted by a barrel, dries 19 feet, and borders the roadstead ; the Goubeau rock, marked by a black cone beacon surmounted by a pole and cross, striped black and white, is less than a cable northward of the Sardrette ; and, the Roche-a-deux-Tetes, with a black beacon, lies one cable in-shore of the Goubeau. Directions. — A vessel from the westward bound to St. Peter Port or to the anchorage off the eastern side of Guernsey, and intending to pass southward of the island, should, as before stated, make careful allowance for the flood stream, if it be running, as it sets in towards the land. Rounding Pleinmont point, give the light house on the Hanois rocks a berth of at least 1^ miles, to avoid the Hanois and Bise banks ; and, to clear the Hanois rocks, keep Corbiere point or La Moye point well open of Pleinmont point and of the Tas de Pois d'Aval rock S.E. by E. f E. To clear Pleinmont ledge and all dangers between it and La Moye point, do not shut in Lihou island with Pleinmont point until Serk church, which stands northward of the mill, is open of Jerbourg point. When abreast of La Moye point, open the northern point of Serk southward of Jerbourg point, or keep Pleinmont bluff open of Corbiere point, to avoid the Balleine rock, awash at low water, W.S.W. 2\ cables from Icart point. After passing this point, keep Sommeilleuse guard-house, a ruin standing on the edge of a high and remarkable cliff a short distance eastward of La Moye point, open southward of Icart low point until Brehon tower opens east ward of the Longue Pierre beacon, or until the ruin of Herm mill touches the northern side of the high land of Jethou ; these marks lead outside the Grunes de Jerbourg. Rounding St. Martin's point, Saumarez monument on with the end of Castle Cornet breakwater N. by E. \ E. is the leading mark between the Anfre rock and Great bank, keeping St. Martin's barracks open southward of the Anfre beacon until Salerie battery opens of Castle Cornet breakwater, or until the breakwater lighthouse

286 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — GUERNSEY. bears N.N.W. When the town church comes open of the breakwater, anchor in the road as convenient, or run into the harbour if the tide serves. To pass eastward of the Great bank, keep Vale mill about midway between Mont Crevelt tower and Vale castle, and touching the eastern end of the breakwater of St. Sampson harbour, N. \ E. ; and, when the town church is shut in behind Castle Cornet, haul in for the anchorage. At night, when running for this anchorage from the north-east ward, through the Great Russell, see page 299, steer south-westward until the red light on the South pier-head of St. Peter Port old harbour well open southward of Castle Cornet bears N.W. by N., which mark leads southward of the Tetes d'Aval and over the northern part of the Great bank in from 21 to 25 feet water. On nearing the castle and running for the harbour, bring the red light open northward of the white light on Castle Cornet breakwater, and, with the red light bearing W. by N \ N., anchor in the road or run on into harbour. The red light touching the southern part of Castle Cornet leads between the Tetes d'Aval and the buoy marking them, and only 150 feet southward of the rocks, and across the Great bank in 21 feet water. Steering for the Little Russell, see page 295, from the northward, keep the Casquets light on a N.E. by N. bearing until Castle Cornet breakwater light bears S.W. by W. \ W., this being the line of bearing for the central track. This passage, however, should never be attempted at night by a stranger, nor even by a person acquainted with the place, unless in a steam-vessel of light draught or at near high water. From the westward and southward by night, after passing St. Martin's point, steer to the eastward until the old harbour red light is seen clear of Terres point bearing North ; kept in sight on this line, it leads a quarter of a mile eastward of the Longue Pierre beacon. When St. Martin's point bears S.W \ W., steer N.E. by N. to pass between the Anfre rock and the Great Bank ; and, when Castle Cornet breakwater white light bears N.N.W., steer N. by E. until the red light bears W. by N. \ N., after which proceed as before directed. ST. SAMPSON'S HARBOUR is on the eastern side of Guernsey, 1^ miles northward of St. Peter Port, between Vale Castle and Mont Crevelt, and is dry at low water. The site now forming this harbour was originally the eastern entrance to an arm of the sea which severed the northern portion of Guernsey from the main island. About the

Chap. VI.] ST. SAMPSON AND BORDEAUX HARBOURS. 287 beginning of this century the strait was embanked at each end, and since then the intervening land has been reclaimed. The harbour is rectangular in form ; its extreme length being about 1,900 feet N.W. and S.E. with an average width of 500 feet, and containing a water area of 22 acres at high water, springs. At low water, springs, this space is dry, and the tide ebbs for a considerable distance outside the pier-heads. The entrance between the pier-heads is 120 feet wide, and the depth at high water, ordinary neaps, 15 feet. At this time there are 12 feet along the southern pier, and 11 feet for a length of 150 feet along the South quay, from which spot it gradually shoals to its western end. There are two small patent slips in this harbour. A rocky patch, with 10 feet water, lies near the centre of the channel leading to St. Sampson's harbour ; from this patch, the Grunette beacon, representing the figure of a man, is just touching the southern side of Mont Crevelt battery ; and, St. Peter Port church is just open eastward of the Vivian rock beacon, painted with black and white rings. Directions. — The approach to this harbour is difficult, being athwart the tidal streams, and having the Crabiere, Grunette, Grande Demie, and other rocks off the entrance. The most dangerous of these is the Crabiere, in the fairway of the entrance, and distant about 200 yards from the head of Mont Crevelt breakwater ; it has, however, been reduced in height, having now 9 feet on it at half tide. The best entrance to the harbour is between the Crabiere and the Grunette beacon ; this passage, however, is not above half a cable wide, and the leading mark is, the Grunette beacon on with the southern tangent of the breakwater until close up to the beacon, when pass 50 yards northward of it and steer in between the pier heads. The bottom is blue clay covered with a layer of sand. A Life-Boat is stationed at St. Sampson's harbour. Bordeaux Harbour, half a mile northward of St. Sampson, is quite insignificant and used only by fishermen. Here small craft lie aground, but, as the entrance only admits vessels of about 10 tons, a further description is needless. One mile northward of Bordeaux harbour is Doyle fort, standing on the north-eastern point of Guernsey, off which lie the Brayes, Platte Fougere, and other rocks included in the description of the Little Russell channel, see pages 295-298 ; between these rocks and the shore is the narrow channel named Doyle's Pass, see page 298.

[Chap. VI. 288 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— GUERNSEY. Half a mile westward of Doyle's fort is Ancresse bay, and, westward of it, the land trends in a W. f S. direction about 6 miles to Lihou island. The shore end of the telegraph cable connecting with Dartmouth is landed near Doyle's fort. ANCRESSE BAY, on the northern side of Guernsey, west ward of Fort Le Marchant, affords good shelter for small craft during south-easterly, southerly, and westerly winds, in from 6 to 2 fathoms water. Victoria tower on with No. 6 martello tower, near the middle of the bay, S.S.W. § W. leads up to the anchorage. The bottom is muddy sand, and excellent holding ground. The telegraph cable from Alderney is landed here. GRAND HAVRE, 8 cables westward of Ancresse bay, has its entrance between Mont Guet on the North and Rousse point on the South, on both of which points are martello towers ; Vale church is near the shore at the head of the Havre. It affords excellent anchorage for small vessels in from 14 to 9 feet water, the bottom of sand and grass, with good shelter against southerly and easterly winds ; north-westerly winds, however, send in a heavy swell and sea between half flood and half ebb, though, with good ground gear, little danger is to be apprehended. For vessels capable of taking the ground, there is a safe place on the south-eastern side of Rousse point. The Rousse de Mer, a dangerous rock which uncovers at a quarter ebb, lies in the fairway of the entrance, and on each side of it are many more rocks. From the Rousse de Mer, Saumarez monument just shut in with the south-western angle of Vale church bears S. by E. \ E. ; and, the watch-house on the highest part of Lihou island on with the highest part of the Grand Saut Roquier W. by S. f S. Directions. — The dangers off the entrance to Grand Havre are so numerous that it can be safely approached by only one channel. This channel lies between the Rousse de Mer and Main rocks ; the former dries 20 feet, the latter 5 feet, at low water, springs. Victoria tower on with the rocky point just eastward of Rousse point martello tower S. f W. westerly* leads in until Saumarez monu ment opens south-westward of Vale church ; then steer for the high rocky bluff near the middle of the bay, and anchor when about mid way between the towers on the entrance points in about 10 feet water. A vessel of only 6 feet draught may anchor with Noirmont guard-house on with Rousse point martello tower, and Victoria * See View nn Admiralty Chart, No. 262, b.

Chap, vi.] GRAND HAVRE. — DANGERS OFF. 289 tower about midway between Rousse point and the rocky bluff near the middle of the bay. Roque Noire, Boue Corneille, L'Etac, and Saut Roquier Rocks, lying three quarters of a mile from the coast between Grand Havre and Grande Roque point, extend about the same distance -in an E. by N. and W. by S. direction. They dry respectively 42, 32, 49, and 48 feet, and being always above water, serve to distinguish this part of the coast when the dangerous rocks around them are covered. Grande Roque point has on it a rocky hummock, from which it takes its name, and on which stand a small fort and watch tower. The HoffetS are dangerous rocks, most of which uncover only at low water ; the outer head, then awash, bears N. by E. \ E. 1\ cables from the Roque Noire ; the Mouliere uncovers 10 feet nearly midway between it and the Roque Noire, and the Gripe de Rousse 3i cables eastward of the Mouliere has but 3 feet over it. The Rousse de Mer dries 20 feet, only 2\ cables eastward of the Gripe de Rousse, and is itself surrounded by rocky heads, some of which uncover. Victoria tower on with Rousse point martello tower S. f W. leads f>\ cables eastward of the outer head of the Hoffets and 1^ cables eastward of the Rousse de Mer ; the Petite Braye open northward of Roque au Nord leads northward of the Hoffets ; and, Torteval spire on with Fort Houmet S.W. southerly leads 2 cables westward of them and clear of all dangers up to the Grand Saut Roquier. Some dangerous rocks, awash at low water, and one which uncovers 11 feet, extend W.N.W. nearly 2 cables from the Grand Saut Roquier ; others outside and northward of them are always covered ; the outer rock, called the Moulrette, has 27 feet water and bears N.N.W. \ W. 4£ cables from the Grand Saut Roquier. There is a good channel inside all these rocks, and anchorage, secure from easterly winds, will be found inside the Grand Saut Roquier. The leading mark through the channel is, the lower house on Lihou island touching the outer corner of the Mouilliere rock W. by S. \ S. ; there is also a channel between the inner head of the Hoffets and the Boue Corneille, but neither channel should be attempted without a pilot. Plaquiers Rocks, with 8 feet water, lie half a mile westward of the Grand Saut Roquier and 1\ miles S.E. \ E. easterly from the outer and highest rock of the Grunes de l'Ouest, with Victoria tower A. 2771. They may be cleared by keeping Victoria tower well open on either side of Grande Roque tower. COBO and VAZON BAYS, half way between Grand Havre and Rocquaine bay, have good anchorage in easterly winds ; but, with westerly winds, there is generally a rolling swell along this coast on the flood tide, and this, together with the numerous outlying rocks, renders these bays dangerous of approach. The principal dangers off these bays inside the Grunes de l'Ouest, described with the other outer dangers at page 275, are the Susanne, which dries 7 feet S.E. by E. a quarter of a mile from the Grunes de l'Ouest ; the Grunette, which dries 3 feet, S. by E. \ E. half a mile from the Grunes de l'Ouest ; the Boue Auber, which dries 8 feet, E. by S. | S. nearly half a mile from the Sambule ; and, the Flabet, which dries one foot, about midway between the Grande Etacre and Sambule. There are also the Colombelle, which dries 2 feet, N.W. 4r| cables from the Conchee rock at the entrance of Perelle bay ; the Messellettes, nearly awash at low water, N.N.E. half a mile from the Conchee ; the Boue Vazon, which dries 7 feet, and lies with St. George's tower, white, on with the south-western angle of Fort Houmet, and the watch-house on Lihou island just open inside the Conchee ; the Fourquies, awash at low water, S.W. 2\ cables from the Boue Vazon; the Petit Etat, which dries 20 feet N.N.W. \ W. 2f cables from Fort Houmet ; and the Gros Etat, which dries 34 feet midway between them and at the outer edge of the rocks off Fort Houmet. The Mouilliere, N. f E. 6£ cables from Fort Houmet, is 4 feet above high water, springs ; it is surrounded by rocks, of which many uncover ; they extend rather more than a cable westward but not more than three quarters of a cable northward of the Mouilliere. The lower house on Lihou island on with the Conchee rock W.S.W. westerly leads northward of these rocks. Directions. — To approach Vazon bay from the north-eastward, run in with Torteval spire well open westward of Fort Houmet ; and, as the land is neared and before passing Grand Saut Roquier, be careful to bring Torteval spire on with Richmont fort flagstaff S.W. by S., which mark leads midway between the Grunettes and Mouilliere and nearly a cable eastward of the Boue Vazon ; within which, anchor as convenient in from 6 to 8 fathoms, sand.

Chap. VI.] COBO AND VAZON BAYS.— HERM AND JETHOU ISLANDS. 291 To run out of the bay between the Grunettes and Boue Auber, bring St. George's tower on with the north-eastern side of Fort Houmet. The lower house on Lihou island on with the Conchee leads nearly a cable northward of the Boue Vazon ; and, St. Matthew's church on with the south-western end of Fort Houmet leads out between the Sambule and Colombelle. Perelle Bay, westward of the Conchee rock, affords good shelter to fishing boats at low water, but is only safe for such as can take the beach in the event of a westerly gale setting in. In running round from this bay to Rocquaine bay, Hanois lighthouse open eastward of the Trois Peres leads inside and eastward of the rocks extending in that direction from the Grande Etacre. HERM and JETHOU ISLANDS, off the eastern end of Guernsey, together with the Amfroque rocks on the North and the Ferriere and other rocks on the South, extend rather more than 5 miles in a N.E. and S.W. direction, and divide the Great and Little Russell channels from each other. Herm is 1£ miles long, half a mile wide, 232 feet above the level of low water, and its centre bears East 3 miles from the entrance to St. Peter Port. The little island of Jethou is half a mile south-westward of Herm and 16 feet higher. The rocky islets Crevichon and Fauconniere are connected with Jethou at low water, the former on its northern side, the latter on its southern side ; the summit of each is marked by a white stone conical beacon. The Ferrieres, most conspicuous rocks southward of Jethou, never cover with the tide. The northern head of the Barbees, their outer or north-western rock, bears W.S.W. 6^ cables from Jethou, and is marked by a staff and barrel beacon. The Demie Ferriere, or Demie de Muse, as it is locally known, uncovers 12^ feet 3 cables S. f W. from the Barbees, and one cable eastward from the Muse rock, which itself dries 2\ feet ; it also is marked by a beacon 10 feet above high water, with the distinguishing letter M in black. There are good ship channels between these rocks, and also between the Ferrieres rocks and the Tetes d'Aval, which lie half a mile S.S.W. £ W. from the Demie Ferriere, and 1^ miles from Jethou, but they should not be attempted without a pilot. The Tetes d'Aval and other principal rocks southward, westward, and eastward of Jethou are included in the description of the two Russell channels, according as they affect the navigation of the one or the other. The Grande Amfroque, the outermost rock showing above high water, has two peaks, is nearly three quarters of a cable in diameter, and 78 feet above low water. It is surrounded by dangerous rocks, of which the easternmost is the Bonne Grune, with 14 feet water, which bears from the Grande Amfroque E. £ S. southerly 1£ miles, and is at the western side of the entrance to the Great Russell channel. The Selle d'Amfroque, bearing N.E. by E. half a mile from the Grande Amfroque, has 17 feet over it ; and, within it, to the westward, lie the Demies du Nord and the Petite Amfroque, which uncover with the tide. Beacons. — There are two conical stone beacons on the Grande Amfroque 105 feet apart, bearing S. by E. southerly and N. by W. northerly from each other ; the southern beacon is 35 feet above the rock, surmounted by a cross, and painted black and white in horizontal bands ; the northern beacon is 20 feet high, surmounted by a round cage, and painted white. Cul de l'Autel and Longue Pierre Rocks.— At 6 cables West from the Grande Amfroque lies the Cul de l'Autel, a table rock 58 feet above low water ; and, between the Cul de l'Autel and the northern point of Herm, at nearly equal distances and about the same height, 70 feet, are the Longue Pierre and Traiffe rocks, and also Godin islet, which, as well as the Longue Pierre, is covered with a light soil, on which grow a variety of wild flowers ; the Traiffe is near the south-eastern side of the Longue Pierre, and resembles a ship under sail. Besides these are many others of minor importance which the tide never covers, as well as numerous tidal rocks and ledges, and many which never uncover at all. Platte Boue Rock, three quarters of a mile northward of the Grande Amfroque, is the northernmost danger off Herm, at the eastern side of the entrance to the Little Russell, and consists of three heads ; the western head has one foot water, and the southern head 3 feet at low water, springs. It is about 20 feet in diameter and steep-to all round, except in an E.N.E. direction, where, at the distance of 165 yards, there is a rock with 15 feet over it. The marks for the Platte Boue are, Catel spire on with the canteen house at the gate of Vale castle, showing at its south-eastern angle, W. by S. southerly ; the Grande Moie, the highest detached

Chap, vi.] AMFROQUE ROCKS. — PASSE PERCEE. 293 rock on the eastern side of Serk, just open eastward of the Grande Amfroque S. by E. easterly ; and, the Grande Amfroque beacons in line S. by E. southerly. Clearing Marks. — Doyle's column, Guernsey, on with the Brehon tower S.W. £ W. leads 5 cables, and Tautenay beacon tower, black and white vertical stripes, on with Doyle's column, leads 1^ cables north-westward of Platte Boue rock. Tautenay beacon tower on with Brehon tower is a very close mark, clearing its northern side by only half a cable ; and, Catel spire on with the north-western angle of Vale castle W. by S. £ S. also clears it on the same side by less than a cable. The channels through and amongst these rocks and islets are extremely intricate, and are rendered dangerous by the rapidity and variety of the tides ; two of them, however, are sometimes used for ships by the Guernsey pilots, viz., Hayes channel, between Godin islet and the Longue Pierre rocks ; and, Passe Percee, between Herm and Jethou. Hayes Channel. — This channel has a rock awash at low water at its eastern entrance, exactly in line between the Longue Pierre and Godin. Entering the channel from the eastward, to sail southward of this rock, keep Vale mill in sight southward of the Pierre de la Moue until past that line. Pass a cable northward of the Pierre de la Moue, and then haul gradually westward until the high land of Serk at Banquette point comes over Godin, and then haul to the south-westward with Longue Pierre and Grande Amfroque southern beacon in line, until the peak of Godin just open northward of the northern extreme of Galeu bears S.E. \ E., which mark leads into the Little Russell between the Tautenay ledge and the rocky banks extending from the northern point of Herm. Anchorage out of the strength of the tide and with good holding ground may be found South of Tautenay ledge by bringing the peak of Godin between the two sharp peaked rocks of Galeu S.E. £ E.; and, Brehon tower on with the Rousse rock beacon S.W. by W. \ W. There is good anchorage also south-westward of this, inside the Cavale rock, in 6 fathoms, sand, with the Pierre aux Rats, a small stone obelisk on the northern part of Herm, on with the Mouison niere rock S.E. ; and, Brehon tower between the Rousse rock and the Blanche. Passe Percee. — The dangers to be avoided in running for the Passe Percee from the eastward are, the Fourquies, described at

VI. 294 page 299, which uncover near low water half a mile from the land, north-eastward of the Goubiniere rock, and right in the fairway ; and, farther in, the Meulettes rocks, on the starboard, and the Tinker rocks on the port hand. Vale castle touching the south-western end of Herm N.W. \ N. leads eastward of the Fourquies ; and, Vale mill, the north-easternmost on Guernsey, touching the north-eastern side of Jethou N.N.W. \ W. westerly leads westward. Meulettes and Tinker Rocks.— Meulettes rocks dry 3 feet about half a cable from the southern point of Herm, and the Tinker about twice that distance eastward of Jethou. The Vermerette rock beacon, surmounted by the letter V painted black, on with the Percee rock which dries 34 feet, leads westward of the Meulettes ; and, the western side of the little green plat on the Hermetier, half a point eastward of the highest part of the Mouette, leads eastward of the Tinker. Directions. — To run through the Passe Percee into the Little Russell, after clearing the Fourquies, bring Vale mill open westward of both the Percee and Corbette rocks, the latter marked by a beacon, N.W. by N. ; this mark clears by 60 yards the outer point of the Percee rock, which is covered at half tide, and leads through the middle of the channel, of which the narrowest part and least depth, 14 feet, will be found in line between the beacon marking the northern extreme of the rocky bank extending from Jethou and the Vermerette beacon. With a proper rise of tide, the same leading mark will carry a vessel right through to the Little Russell, giving the Corbette beacon a berth of half a cable in passing southward of it, but, at this part, there are only from 8 to 12 feet at low water, springs. To carry the deepest water, when Saumarez monument opens northward of Brehon tower, about the apparent breadth of the tower, take it as the leading mark to clear the Etacre rock which dries 3 feet ; when abreast of the Etacre, the Victoria tower is on with the Creux rock beacon, a staff with a black cap or truck, with which mark haul to the westward and proceed up to the Creux rock ; round it, on its southern side, at half a cable to get into the Little Russell, passing between it and the Alligande beacon 2\ cables S.S.W. W. from it, and distinguished from it by being sur mounted by the letter A, painted black. Anchorage.— Between Herm and Jethou, off the Mouette rock, is the Rosiere anchorage, where small vessels may find good shelter from all winds, except those from S.W. round by South

Chap. VI.] PASSE PERCEE. — LITTLE RUSSELL CHANNEL. 295 to S.E. ; the best entrance is from the Great Russell channel. One great convenience attends this anchorage, viz., that the tide runs 9 hours southward and only 3 hours northward ; the southern stream commencing at low water by the shore, and setting directly into the Great Russell during the whole of the flood and until half ebb, when the northern stream begins and runs with but little strength until low water. A vessel, therefore, caught here by a southerly wind may always, at half ebb, run northward through the Passe Percee into the Little Russell channel, and, from thence, to the anchorage inside the Cavale rock or into the Great road. LITTLE RUSSELL CHANNEL, between Herm and Guernsey, is much contracted by the numerous rocks projecting from each island as far out as the Roustel on the Guernsey side, and the Rousse rock on the side of Herm, which two rocks are little more than 3 cables apart. The wind from N.N.W. round by North and East to S.E. is a leading wind through this channel from the northward, and, without the certainty of a leading wind, no square-rigged vessel of deep draught should attempt its navigation. The entrance to the Little Russell from the northward is between the Braye rocks on the western side and the Amfroque rocks on the eastern. The approach to both these groups is exceedingly dangerous, both on account of the tides which flow across the entrance to the Russell channels, and also from the numerous rocks, hidden and visible, by which they are encompassed ; of which the most dangerous are, the Platte Boue and the Boufresse in the neighbour hood of the Amfroque, and the Roques de Braye, or Platte Fougere, in the vicinity of the Braye. Fairway Buoy. — To facilitate the navigation of the Little Russell, a Courtenay's automatic signal buoy is moored in 30 fathoms north-eastward of the entrance. It is a red conical buoy with Guernsey fairway in white letters on it. From the buoy, the Amfroque beacons in line bear S. by E. easterly 2f miles ; and Grande Braye beacon W. by S. S. 2| miles. The following are the principal rocks on the western side of the Little Russell channel : — Braye Rocks. — The Grande and Petite Braye rocks are about a mile from the shore off the north-eastern point of Guernsey ; they are within a quarter of a mile of each other and both are surrounded by outlying dangerous rocks. The Grande Braye is 10 feet above high water, springs, and has on it a tripod beacon surmounted by a cross ; the Petite Braye is 2 or 3 feet lower.

296 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — HERM AND JETHOU. [Chap. VI The Roques de Braye, or Platte Fougere, appear at about half tide ; the ground is clean one cable eastward of them. An iron frame beacon, surmounted by a red cone 12 feet above the highest tides, stands on the north-eastern rock. Canupe and Corbette Rocks.— Nearly midway between the Platte Fougere and Corbette rock, which latter lies 3|- cables S.E. by E. J- E. from the Houmet Paradis, dries 16 feet, and is marked by a staff and red ball, lie the Canupe rocks, whose south eastern head, named the Petite Canupe, appears only about the last quarter ebb, uncovering 8 feet, and is marked by a wooden beacon painted black surmounted by the letter C in white.
