Platte Roque dries 10-|- feet S.S.W. f W. 5£ cables from the Corbette ; it is marked by a beacon mast painted with black and white bands. About a cable E.S.E. from the beacon is a rock awash at low water ; and, from this rock towards the Corbette, on a line curving outwards towards the channel, are several dangerous rocks which should be carefully avoided when passing. Boue Agenor, with only 4 feet water, is the south-western and inner danger on this side of the Little Russell, of which it is necessary to caution strangers. From it, the Coal hole, under Vale castle, on with the end of St. Sampson breakwater bears N. by E. \ E. ; and, Hougue des Quertiers just open north-eastward of the ruin of Ivy castle N.W. by W. Two rocks, one of 9 feet water, lie nearly a cable S.W. by W. \ W. from the Agenor ; another of 12 feet at nearly the same distance S.W. \ S. ; and a third, the Trois Grunes of 13 feet, at 2 cables N.E. by E. \ E. The following are the principal rocks on the eastern side of the Little Russell : — . . The Platte Boue, described at page 234 ; the Boufresse, which dries 8 feet at low water ; the Tautenay, just awash at high water, and marked at its north-eastern end by a beacon tower 22 feet high painted in black and white vertical stripes and surmounted by a staff ; the Cavale, which dries one foot at low water ; the Rousse rock ; and, the Boues Gennete, lying nearly midway between the

Chap. VI.] DANGERS IN LITTLE RUSSELL CHANNEL. 297 Rousse rock and Brehon tower, but far outside their line and in the channel. Rousse Rock. — The Rousse rock is 8 feet above high water, springs, and is marked by an iron beacon, consisting of a cross with an anchor fluke at each point ; it bears N.W. \ W. westerly 6 cables from the north-western point of Herm. A dangerous string of rocks, awash at low water, projects in a W. by N. direction 60 yards from the Rousse. Clearing Marks. — To pass north-westward of all these rocks, keep Catel spire a quarter of a point open northward of Vale castle W. by S. \ S. ; and, when the north-eastern extreme of Serk is on with the middle of the Grande Amfroque, or when the two beacons on the Grande Amfroque are in line, a vessel is abreast of the Platte Boue. The mark given, Catel church a quarter of a point open northward of Vale castle, leads into the fairway of the Little Russell. Doyle's column on with Brehon tower is a good clearing mark for the rocks on the eastern side of the Little Russell as far as the Ca vale, to clear which the column must be opened one side or the other of Brehon tower ; a vessel is abreast of the Cavale when the Pierre aux Rats obelisk is on with the Mouissoniere rock S.E Doyle's column on with Brehon tower also clears the rocks extend ing from the Rousse, but leads inside the Boues Gennete. THE ROUSTEL is the most dangerous rock in the Little Russell, as it lies exactly in mid-channel and does not uncover until 4 hours ebb. From its shoalest head, the Rousse beacon bears S.S.E. | E. 3h cables ; a sunken rock connected with the Roustel E.N.E. half a cable ; the Corbette beacon N.N.W. 5^ cables ; the Platte Roque beacon W. \ N. northerly half a mile ; and, the Grune au Rouge S.W. by W. £ W. nearly one mile. Grune au Rouge is another rock lying in mid-channel abreast of the Brehon tower, from which it bears N.W. \ N. northerly 3£ cables, it is of small extent, and has only 3 feet over it at low water, springs. Buoys. — A black buoy is moored about 20 yards S.W. from the Roustel ; and a red buoy 50 yards N.N.E. from the Grune au Rouge. Directions. — The best leading mark to the entrance and through the Little Russell channel when approaching it from the northward is, St. Martin's point just open westward of Brehon tower S.W.

CHANNEL ISLANDS.— GUERNSEY, HERM, AND JETHOU. [Chap. VI. 298 westerly ; no other mark is so conspicuous or shows so quickly the alteration of the vessel's position.* It leads in 6i cables eastward of the Guernsey fairway buoy and on the eastern side of the channel, between the Roustel and Rousse rocks, and directly towards the Boues Gennete ; when the high land at the north-eastern end of Serk begins to shut in with the northernmost bluff land of Herm, or when Saumarez monument appears within its breadth of Mont Crevelt tower W. £ N., a vessel is between and abreast of the Roustel and Rousse rocks. Near this position, Belvidere house, a large building on the bluff eastward of Fort George, will be on with a white patch just within the eastern extreme of Castle Cornet, which mark leads more than half a cable eastward of the Grune au Rouge, about a cable eastward of the Agenor and all other dangers, and up to the anchorage in the road. This mark leads right up through the Little Russell, and is the only leading line that answers this purpose ; but, as it leads rather near the Grune au Rouge, on approaching and in passing that rock, keep the northern angle of Belvidere house on with the southern angle of the white patch, bearing in mind that the red buoy being on the north eastern side of the Grune au Rouge tails some distance from it when the north-eastern stream is running. To pass north-westward of the Roustel and Grune au Rouge, bring the near angle of Castle Cornet, marked with a vertical white stripe, on with Fort George signal-post, which leads three quarters of a cable westward of the Roustel, and one cable westward of the Grune au Rouge. When Brehon tower is on with Herm tower, a mill without sweeps one third from the southern end of the island, open the leading marks a little either way, to clear the Trois Grunes and the Agenor, and run on until the town church opens southward of the old harbour lighthouse, then haul in for the anchorage. If compelled to beat through the Little Russell, it may be useful to note that St. Martin's point open eastward of the Brehonnet rock, which dries 16 feet a cable westward of the Brehon tower, clears the Roustel ; and, St. Martin's point open one side or the other of the Brehon rock clears the Boues Gennete also on either side. THROUGH DOYLE PASS— To enter the Little Russell by this channel, keep the windmill on the island of Serk just open northward of the northernmost high land of Herm and on with the Mouisonniere, a remarkable pointed rock on the sandy beach of Herm, bearing * See view on Admiralty chart, No. 262, b.

Chap, vi.] RUSSELL CHANNELS. — DOYLE PASS. 299 S.S.E. £ E., which mark leads through the Pass between the Roque au Nord and the Grande Braye, inside the Brune Pierre which uncovers 4 feet, and between the Grune la Fosse and the Vraic, both awash at low water, into the fairway of the Little Russell. The greatest caution must be used in taking this channel near low water to preserve the leading mark ; the narrowest part is between the Grune Pierre and the rocks off Homptol, its width here being only 217 yards. With the leading mark on, the Pierre aux Rats obelisk appears a little to the left of the Mouisonniere. GREAT RUSSELL CHANNEL is bounded on its north western side by the islands of Herm and Jethou, and by the Amf roques and other rocks north-eastward, eastward, and southward of them ; and, on the south-eastern side, by the islands of Serk and Brecqhou and the rocks in their vicinity. This channel, which is the eastern passage to Guernsey, is about two miles wide and easy of access even to strangers.* The following are its principal dangers on the north-western side, commencing from the northward : — Bonne Grune Rock, with only 14 feet water, is the outer danger at the northern entrance of the Great Russell. It bears E. by N. \ N. 3£ miles from the northern end of Herm ; and, E. \ S. southerly 1£ miles from the Grande Amfroque; it is cleared to the eastward by opening the western extreme of Little Serk of the eastern extreme of Brecqhou. Noire Pute Rock, 1\ miles south-eastward from Herm mill, is never wholly covered, though at equinoctial tides it is sometimes nearly awash. A string of rocks awash at low water extend from it north-eastward nearly 1\ cables. From the Noire Pute, Doyle's column appears a quarter of a point open southward of the Grande Fauconniere. Grands Bouillons Rocks, having only 9 feet water, lie between the Noire Pute and the Fourquies. From them, the Caquorobert, a large rock in the form of a hay-stack projecting from the eastern side of Herm on with the north-eastern low sandy point of that island, bears North ; and, the Noire Pute E. by N. \ N. %\ cables. Fourquies Rocks dry 7 feet S.E. by E. \ E. easterly 6^ cables from the summit of the Grande Fauconniere rock, Jethou island ; * See views on Admiralty charts, No. 262, a and b.

CHANNEL ISLANDS.— HERM AND JETHOU. [Chap. VI. 300 from their centre, St. Martin's point on with the Goubiniere rock bears W. by S. ; and, Vale castle on with the sandy beach on the north-eastern side of Crevichon island N.W. £ N. Goubiniere Rock, is 10 feet above high water, springs, lies South 4 cables from the Grande Fauconniere, and W. by S. 6 cables from the Fourquies. At \\ cables W. by S. \ S. from the Goubiniere, the Anon rocks uncover 8 feet at low water, springs. Bane des Anons, 3 cables southward of the Anon rocks, have 18 feet over their shoalest spot ; from it, the Goubiniere bears N.E. \ N. 4£ cables ; and, Mont Crevelt tower on with the western side of the Grosse Ferriere N.N.W. TETES d'AVAL ROCKS bear S.W. \ S. nearly 1^ miles from Jethou island and are awash at low water, springs. The marks for them are, Herm mill, without arms, on with the Petite Fauconniere, a remarkable red-headed rock on the beach between the Grande Fauconniere and Jethou, N.E. \ E. ; Vale mill its apparent breadth open westward of Vale castle N. \ W. ; and, the lighthouse on the South pier-head of St. Peter Port old harbour shut in with Castle Cornet N.W. \ N. Buoy. — A conical buoy, with black and white horizontal stripes, lies about 120 yards south-westward of the middle head of the Tetes d'Aval. Vessels should pass southward and westward of the buoy. Sardriere Rock, with 8 feet water, lies 1£ cables south-east ward of the Tetes d'Aval, with St. Martin's spire on with the northern side of Fermain beacon N.W. by W. £ W. ; and, the Selle Roque, off the south-eastern side of Herm, twice its apparent breadth open westward of the Goubiniere N.E. \ E. easterly. The dangers on the eastern side of the channel are all near the shores of either Serk or Brecqhou ; those only which require special notice being the Givaude rock and the Grune. Givaude Rock, about 70 feet high, forms the eastern boundary of the Great Russell channel. It is 1\ cables off the western end of Brecqhou, and, from its north-western point, a reef extends nearly one cable. The Neste, a pointed rock which dries 20 feet, lies N.N.E. £ E. 1\ cables from the Givaude on the outer edge of a reef extending from Brecqhou.

Chap. VI.] 301 GREAT RUSSELL CHANNEL. The Grune can scarcely be called a danger, as there are never less than 48 feet water over it ; it is about 1£ miles westward of Brecqhou, and causes heavy tide ripples and a dangerous sea in bad weather. From it, the Grande Amfroque on with the Noire Pute bears N.N.E. £ E. ; and, Victoria tower half the breadth of Castle Cornet open northward of the castle N.W. £ W. Directions. — The course from the middle of Alderney Race to the northern entrance of the Great Russell channel is about S.W. by W., and the distance 18 miles. In approaching this channel from the north-eastward, however, great care must be taken to avoid the Bane de la Schole, described at page 345, lying nearly in the direct line between Alderney Race and the entrance. Having entered the channel with the western extreme of Little Serk open eastward of the eastern extreme of Brecqhou as the lead ing mark in order to clear the Bonne Grune ; bring St. Martin's point a quarter of a point open southward of the Goubiniere rock W. £ S. ; this leads southward of the Noire Pute, the Grands Bouillons, and the Fourquies. Run on with this mark until the Grande Amfroque is its own apparent breadth open south-eastward of the Selle Roque N.E. \ N. This latter mark must be preserved until the lighthouse on the South pier-head of St. Peter Port old harbour opens southward of Castle Cornet, or until St. Martin's spire, seen over the trees, is on with the martello tower in Fermain bay ; either of these marks leads southward of the Sardriere and Tetes d'Aval ; after having rounded which, steer for the Great road. There is a good channel between the Tetes d'Aval and the Ferriere rocks ; the mid-channel leading mark is, Victoria tower half way between Castle Cornet flagstaff and the northern angle of the castle wall bearing N.W. \ W. This channel, however, should not be attempted unless in case of emergency, the difficulty of the tides rendering its navigation hazardous. When turning through the Great Russell, the island of Serk may be approached to about half a mile without fear, as there are no rocks more than a quarter of a mile from the shore between the Bee du Nez and Brecqhou island ; but, when standing towards the western point of Brecqhou, and southward of it, take care to keep the Grande Amfroque its own apparent length open westward of the Givaude rock N. by E. E., to clear the Dents and Hautes Boues. Standing northward towards Herm and Jethou, do not shut in St. Martin's point with the Goubiniere when eastward of the latter,

302 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — SERK. but keep it a quarter of a point open ; this clears the Fourquies, Grands Bouillons, &c. ; then proceed as before directed. The north-eastern stream of tide slacks half an hour sooner on the south-eastern side of the Great Russell, that is to say, under Serk, than on its north-western side. SERK.— This island is 3£ miles S.E. by S. from Herm, and divides the Great Russell from the Deroute channel. It is 1^ miles wide and 2£ miles long, including Little Serk, with which it is connected by the Coupee, an isthmus or narrow causeway. It is lofty and precipitous throughout, and its highest part, at the base of the windmill near the centre of the island, is 375 feet above the level of low water. The small island of Brecqhou, on its western side, is separated from it by the Gouliot pass, a narrow channel only 70 yards wide, through which the tides run with great velocity. There is no town in Serk, but a small hamlet or group of cottages on the north-eastern side of the island is called La Ville. The island constitutes one Royal Fief or Manor, held direct from the Crown. There are forty original copyhold farms, averaging 15 acres each, the title to which descend in succession to the eldest sons, or if no sons, to the eldest daughters of their occupants. The island is fertile, highly cultivated, and, besides supplying all the wants of its inhabitants, exports largely in cereals and vegetables to Guernsey. Its rocky coast abounds with fish, and especially with crabs and lobsters. All able-bodied men are organized as militia, of which there are about 140 of all arms. Its total population is about 550. There is a church, where the Anglican service is con ducted in French, and two endowed schools. A close approach to Serk on all but the north-western side is difficult, not only from the numerous rocks which encompass it, but also from the rapidity and irregularities of the tide in its immediate vicinity. These difficulties, however, may be easily overcome if attention is paid to the leading marks and run of the stream ; and, the island affords good shelter against almost all winds, as may be seen by following the descriptions given of the different bays. Creux Harbour. — There are several small inlets in the rocky coasts of Serk, where fishermen haul up and secure their boats in stormy weather ; the most noted and frequented is Creux harbour, so called from a subterraneous passage in its neigh bourhood. It is on the eastern side of the island, and is the general

Chap. VI.] CREUX HARBOUR.— ROCKS AROUND SERK. 303 rendezvous for landing and shipping goods, as well as the principal resort of the fishing and other island boats. It is protected by a small jetty and affords perfect security to small craft ; its entrance is, however, only 60 feet wide, and it dries at low water, springs. The best anchorage off it is with Pin rock on with the Grande Moie, and point Terrible on with High Cliff. Water.— On the south-eastern side of Serk there is a tolerable run of water in Ixcart bay, on the northern side of Baleine bay, westward of Chateau point ; the stream during the winter season is very copious, and water may be procured with off-shore winds without difficulty. It is the only accessible watering place round the island, with the exception of an inconsiderable drain in port du Moulin, on its north-western side, and another of similar character at Creux harbour. ISLETS and ROCKS around SERK— The following islets and rocks, always above water, lie off the coasts of Serk : — The Noire Pierre, 2 cables from the shore off Banquette point on the north-eastern coast, is a small square rock 11 feet above high water and steep-to all round. The Petite Moie, 57 feet above high water, is a rocky mass, steep-to except at its northern point, off which, at the distance of 60 feet, there is a sunken rock. The Grande Moie, off Robert point, is a larger rocky mass 91 feet high and dangerous to approach, especially on its eastern side. The Burons, are a cluster of craggy rocks 66 feet above high water in the form of a half moon, rising nearly perpendicularly from the sea, steep-to on their south-eastern side, but dangerous to approach from any other quarter. They lie about 1^ cables distant in front of Creux harbour, and between them and Serk is the Goulet pass, which dries half way across at low water, springs ; the deepest water, 4 feet, being the outer rocks of Creux. Through this pass the tides run with great strength both ways, but especially about half flood, setting right for and over the Founiais and Grune de Nord rocks on the northern side, and over the Pierre Carree on the southern side ; this pass, therefore, should not be attempted in a sailing vessel, except in a case of the greatest emergency.

304 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS. — SERK. The Conchee, about half a mile southward of the Burons and 1^ cables south-eastward of point Terrible, is a square rock, 11 feet above high water, whitened at the top, and having sunken rocks close-to on all sides. The Baleine Rock, in Baleine bay, is 20 feet above high water, and has a rocky reef extending 70 feet from its north-eastern side ; it is 1£ cables from the shore. Pierre du Cours is a small rock awash at high water and very steep-to on its south-eastern side. As its names implies, it is a useful guide to vessels passing inside the Etac de Serk. Etac de Serk is a rocky islet about 200 feet high off the southern end of Little Serk. In form it resembles a hay-stack and is very conspicuous both from its appearance and position. It is steep-to on its eastern side, but a reef extends half a cable south westward from it ; and, from its northern end, a ledge of rocks which dries 10 feet extends 1£ cables in the direction of the Pierre du Cours. On the south-western side of Little Serk are numerous rocks, the most conspicuous of which are the Moie du Port Goury, a square topped rock, 62 feet above high water ; the Moie de la Bretagne, a peaked rock, 57 feet high ; and, the Moie de la Fontaine, 57 feet high and close to the shore. THE GIVAUDE ROCK is described at page 300. The Moie Batard, a square rock of a whitish colour, about 20 feet above high water, lies off the north-western coast of Brecqhou. BLANCHARD ROCK, nearly 1£ miles eastward of Serk, has 7 feet over it at low water, ordinary springs, but only 3 feet at the lowest equinoctial tides. From it, the Conchee rock on with a remarkable cavity, or chasm, called the Convache, northward of the Coupee, bears W. by N. northerly ; and, the high water point of the Bee du Nez touching the southern overhanging part of the Gorge, a rock at the south-western end of the Petite Moie, N.W. \ N. Chateau point open southward of the Conchee N.W. by W. £ W. leads southward of the Blanchard ; the Corbiere rock off the south western point of Jersey touching the land about cape Grosnez S. by W. + W. leads a mile eastward ; and, the northern bluff land

Chap, vi.] 305 BLANCH ARD ROCK. —BALEINE BAY. on Herm in sight north-eastward of the Bee du Nez N.W. leads northward. Many rocks lie within the Blanchard and eastward of the Burons, and between them are navigable channels of from 10 to 26 fathoms water ; they are, however, seldom used by any but the island boats, on account of the impetuous whirl of the tide in this neighbourhood. BALEINE BAY, on the south-eastern side of Serk, betwfeen the Baleine and Conchee rocks, may be resorted to in winter or summer, as it affords excellent anchorage in from 3 to 7 fathoms, sand, fine gravel, and broken shells, and good shelter with the wind from N.N.E round by North to West. Notwithstanding the numerous overfalls and various discoloura tions of water which appear on all sides on approaching this bay, the only shoals are the Tetes de la Conchee, the Gripe, the Vingt Clos, the Balmee, and the Demie Balmee. The Tetes de la Conchae are the outermost of these, and never have less than 6 fathoms water over them. The Gripe, directly in the fairway of the entrance to the bay, has only 6 feet at low water, springs ; from it the Conchee is on with the Goulet rock N.N.E. \ E. ; and, the Balmee on with the Pignon bears West. The Balmee, which uncovers at a quarter ebb, lies within and westward of the Gripe, with the Baleine in line with the Coupee N. £ W. ; and, the Western side of the Burons touching the outer or north-eastern part of point Terrible N.E. £ E. easterly. On this latter line of bearing, three quarters of a cable north-eastward from the Balmee, is the Demie de Balmee, a small rock, which dries 9 feet at low water. The Vingt ClOS bank, 4 cables southward of the Balmee and extending 3 cables farther in that direction, is also about 3 cables east ward of the Etac de Serk ; it consists of sand and shingle interspersed with rocks ; one head at the northern end of the bank dries 3 feet, and two others southward of it have only 3 feet water over them. The southern end of the Coupee on with the Baleine N. by W. \ W. leads nearly 2 cables north-eastward of the bank ; and, Doyle's column open southward of the Etac de Serk N.W. by W. westerly leads south ward. The sand and shingle of this bank is continually shifting ; its inclination being entirely governed by the tide and -wind. A 2771. Wt. 7242. U

[Chap. VI. 306 CHANNEL ISLANDS.— SERK. Directions. — From the eastward, Chateau point open southward of the Conchee leads into the anchorage of Baleine bay, northward of the Gripe : and, from the southward, Serk mill open westward of Chateau point N. \ W. leads in between the Gripe and the Balmee ; in either case, anchor when the western extreme of the Burons comes on with point Terrible. GREVE de la VILLE, on the north-eastern side of Serk, gives its name to an anchorage affording good shelter for small vessels during westerly or southerly winds in from 6 to 9 fathoms water ; but, the ground being sand and rock, the anchor is likely to come home unless riding with a long scope of cable. It has also this inconvenience ; should the wind suddenly shift to the north ward or north-eastward at low water, the tide running southward for 3 hours after that time, a sailing vessel could not possibly weather the strong in-draught of the Goulet pass, the effects of which are perceptible half a mile north-eastward of it, and she must there fore either ride at anchor until the offing tide slacks, or, if hard pressed, must at least hold on until there is water enough over the neck of the Goulet. Dangers off Greve de la Ville. — The Sardriere rock, with 29 feet water, bears East 2^ cables from the Bee du Nez. The Jolicot rock dries 5 feet S.W. three quarters of a cable from the Sardriere ; and, the Moulinet rock dries 8 feet just eastward of the Bee du Nez, and only 150 feet off-shore. The Jolicot and Moulinet bear East and West from each other, and are 1\ cables apart ; there is a safe 6-fathoms channel between them, in entering which, from the westward, be careful to have the peak of the Grande Moie well in sight eastward of Banquette point before hauling in. The peak of the Grande Moie on with Banquette point just clears the Moulinet ; and, the same peak over the middle of the Pecheresse rock leads over the Jolicot. The Pecheresse bears E. \ S. 2^ cables from the rifle target on the summit of the Grune, and covers at high water, springs, but only to the depth of 2 feet; its in-shore point is long and straggling, narrowing the channel between it and the island to one cable. A rock with 7 feet water bears E. \ N. nearly one cable from the Pecheresse ; and another, the Grand Boue which dries 3 feet, E. by S. \ S. rather more than one cable from it.

Chap. VI.] GREVE DE LA VILLE. — BANQUETTE BAY. 307 The Pavlaison rock, awash at low water, lies N.E. nearly a quarter of a mile from the Noire Pierre, which rock, together with the Petite Moie and Grande Moie off the southern side of the Greve de laVille, have been already described. Directions. — There are two entrances to the Greve de la Ville — one from the northward between the island and the Noire Pierre, and one from the southward (which is very narrow) between the island and the Grande Moie. The leading mark from the northward is, the Noire Pierre on with the Chapelle, a remarkable hollowed rock on the shore of which the upper part is whitewashed, bearing S.S.W. \ W. ; or, the Chapelle half a point open eastward of Banquette point S. \ W. ; between these limits a vessel may also work in. The Noire Pierre is steep-to on all but its southern side. No leading mark can be given for the southern channel to this anchorage between the Grande Moie and the island. It never has less than 3 fathoms, but a rock awash at low water lies 150 feet within the Grande Moie, and is connected with it under water ; care must, therefore, be taken to pass nearer to Robert point, which is steep-to, rather than in mid-channel. A cable northward of Robert point also a dangerous reef extends half a cable from the shore ; and, the Demie, a half-tide rock, lies half a cable S.W. from the Petite Moie. Anchorage. — The best anchorage is between Petite Moie and the island, with the eastern extreme of the Burons just open of Robert point S. by E. \ E. ; outside this line the stream runs strongly ; within or westward of it the stream is scarcely perceptible. There is good anchorage on the north-eastern side of Serk, outside all the rocks, in from 14 to 19 fathoms, fine clean sand, with St. Martin's point, Guernsey, on with the Corbee du Nez W. \ N. ; and, the Chapelle rock midway between the Noire rock and Banquette point S. by W. This anchorage, however, can only be used in fine weather, with the wind between West and S.S.W. BANQUETTE BAY, on the north-western side of Serk, affords good shelter against easterly, south-easterly, and southerly winds in from 5 to 10 fathoms, coarse sand interspersed with small black stones and pieces of sea-weed. Should the wind chop round to the westward, a vessel at anchor here may even then be able to weather the Bee du Nez, and from thence may push to sea, or haul under the lee of the island. There are several rocks and ledges in the bay, of which the principal are those now to be described. U 2

308 [Chap. VI. CHANNEL ISLANDS.— SERK. Episseresses Rocks, with 13 feet water, bear N.W. \ W. a quarter of a mile from the Autelets rocks. Between the Episseresses and port du Moulin are several dangerous rocks. The Guillaumez Rock, which covers 6 feet at high water, bears E. by N. \ N. 3 cables from the Episseresses, and is about half a cable off-shore. The Grune de GouliOt, with 6 feet water, bears N. \ E. 2 cables from the eastern end of Brecqhou. The Petite Banquette is a narrow bank of fine sand with a sharp ridgy apex. It is about 2 cables in extent, North and South, and has 16 feet on the shoalest part near the middle, from which the Platte Roque, off port du Moulin, bears E. by S. \ S. 2 cables. In heavy gales from the north-eastward or westward, this bank has been reported to shift a cable or more in one tide, which here runs south-eastward from low water to half flood, and south-westward from half ebb to low water. Anchorage. — The best deep-water berth in Banquette bay is in 9 fathoms, with Givaude rock on with Moie Batard S.W. by W. W. ; Little Serk mill, without arms, on with the western side of Gouliot island S. £ W. ; and, Manor tower and North cliff of port du Moulin in line S.E. £ E. r GRANDE GREVE is the anchorage on the south-western side of Serk, between Brecqhou and Little Serk. It takes its name from the great beach of fine white sand under the Coupee uniting Serk with Little Serk. The approach to it is much encumbered by rocks, but there is plenty of room notwithstanding, and good shelter from S.S.E., East, and N.E. winds, in from 7 to 11 fathoms, fine sandy bottom with pieces of shells. It is not prudent, however, for a sail ing vessel to remain at anchor here if the wind shifts northward or southward of the points specified ; for a W.S.W. wind, from the long fetch it commands, brings in a heavy swell, and the obstruction caused by the weather tide coming through the Gouliot pass, raises it to such a height as to preclude the possibility of a vessel riding out even a moderate gale. Should a vessel, therefore, be caught by a westerly wind at this anchorage, she should immediately endeavour to get out either to the westward or through the Gouliot pass, which latter may with con fidence be taken at half flood.

Chap. VI.] GRANDE GREVE. — DIRECTIONS. 309 Dangers off the Grande Greve:— The Hautes Boues are a group of rocks off the north-western side of Little Serk. The outer north-western rock dries 4 feet, and bears N.W. by W. 4 cables from the Moie de la Fontaine, a high rock close in-shore and 60 feet above the high water level ; there is deep water close to this north western rock, northward and westward of it, but a string of dangerous rocks extend from it 3^ cables in a S.S.W. direction; there are also numerous rocks within this line to the eastward, of which five heads dry at low water. There is no safe channel for large vessels inside the Hautes Boues. The Dents, a rocky mass off the south-western end of Brecqhou, are awash at high water, springs. They are steep-to and safe of approach from the southward. The Baveuse is a large rock N. £ E. 1\ cables from the Moie de la Fontaine. It covers 4 feet at high water and is surrounded by other smaller rocks. From the Baveuse, in the direction of the Gouliot pass, there are several dangerous rocks, of which the Boue de Baie has only 3 feet, and another rock three quarters of a cable northward of it only 2 feet water. From the Boue de Baie, the Baveuse bears S.S.W. £ W. 2 cables ; the Chapelle, a large rock northward of Jeu point, is on with that point ; and, the Pierre au Norman appears in the middle of the chasm between the Moie du Gouliot and Tour islet. Directions. — The leading mark for the inner anchorage in the Grande Greve, passing northward of the Hautes Boues and south ward of the Boue de Baie, is, the southern end of the Coupee on with Jeu point E. by S. \ S. southerly. Serk mill on with the gap in the outer part of Longue point, bearing East, leads southward of the Dents and northward of all dangers in the bay until the Pierre au Norman is on with the eastern end of Brecqhou, which mark then leads southward to the anchorage. The best anchorage mark is the Pierre au Norman on with the eastern point of Brecqhou, and about two thirds of the Coupee roadway open southward of the south-eastern point of Serk. A good position in the outer part of the bay in about 12 fathoms is, with Serk mill on with Longue point, and the Givaude between Brecqhou and the Dents. It should, however, be observed that as Serk mill will be hidden behind the intervening high land of Longue point before a vessel arrives abreast of the Dents, it is necessary to look out in time for another object in the same line of direction.

[Chap. VI. 310 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — SERK. Tidal streams around Serk.— It is high water, full and change, at Serk at the same time as at St. Peter Port, viz., at 6h. 37m., and there is about the same rise and fall, see page 284. The direction of the streams in the immediate vicinity of the island is subject to great variety, it being governed by the configuration of the land. On its north-eastern side, there is a space in which an eddy or slack tide exists during the whole of the six hours that the stream is running north-eastward in the Great Russell and Deroute channels ; this expanse of g slack water extends about 2 miles from the land, gradually contracting in width as it increases its distance from the shore. The marks for its north-western and south-eastern limits are, the western end of Brecqhou island on with the Corbee du Nez ; and, the Etac de Serk just appearing eastward of the land at Le Creux. The ordinary limit of its distance from the land is attained when Vale mill comes on with the Sardinias rock off the eastern side of Herm. Outside the north-western and south-eastern limits here given, even at the distance of a cable, run the true Russell and Deroute streams. The stream in Baleine bay, in Terrible bay, and in the neighbour hood of the Conchee, Baleine, and Balmee rocks, runs north-eastward 7j hours and south-westward for only 4j hours. The first begins an hour after low water by the shore and runs until 2^ hours ebb, when the south-western stream commences and runs faintly for the remaining 4i hours, or until an hour after low water again. The streams on the north-eastern side of Serk, in the Greve de la Ville, and in the neighbourhood of the Grande and Petite Moie rocks, &c, run %\ hours S. by E. and only 3^ hours N. by W. The southern stream commences at 4 hours flood and runs until half an hour after low water, when the northern stream commences and runs faintly for the remaining 3^ hours, or until 4 hours flood again. The southern stream above mentioned, on the north-eastern side of Serk, and the northern one on the south-eastern side, branch off to the eastward of the Burons, where they meet and unite with the Deroute stream, which sets directly both ways, and runs for equal spaces of time on both tides. A curved line drawn from 3 or 4 cables southward of the Etac de Serk through the Grune Noire to the south eastern limit of the space of slack water before mentioned, on the north-eastern side of the island, divides the irregular streams in shore from that of the Deroute ; and, this line continued from this spot close round the Bee du Nez towards the Givaude rock, and from thence to within 3 or 4 cables of the Etac de Serk again, divides the regular Russell stream from the irregular streams within it.

Chap, vi.] 311 TIDAL STREAMS. — OYSTER GROUND. The stream on the north-western side of Serk begins to run to the southward at the Bee du Nez, and from thence along the land towards Brecqhou island, at three quarters flood ; near Brecqhou, it meets with the stream from the Gouliot pass, which latter, prevailing, carries it with a curve north-westward into the Great Russell, where it unites with the regular stream. The stream begins to run north eastward along the shore of the Moie du Gouliot towards Bee du Nez at three quarters ebb, and so continues until three quarters flood again. The stream on the south-western side of Serk in the neighbour hood of the Hautes Boues, Bretagne, Sercul, &c, runs 4^ hours northward, and only 1^ hours southward ; the former stream com mences at half flood and runs for one hour, it then suddenly turns and runs south-eastward for 1J hours, or until half an hour before high water by the shore, at which time it again as suddenly veers to the northward and sets in that direction for the remaining 3^ hours, or until half ebb. The stream in the Gouliot pass runs for equal spaces of time, corresponding to that in the Great Russell, and does not partake of the irregularity of the tides in its vicinity. On the contrary, the force and shape of the flood stream, acquired by the contracted and peculiar form of the channel between Serk and Brecqhou, is continued until it falls into the Russell channel ; the same is the case with the ebb until it unites with the stream south-westward of the Hautes Boues. Oyster-Ground. — About 11 miles in a north-easterly direc tion from Coupe point, the north-eastern extreme of Jersey, and nearly 14 miles in a south-eastern direction from the middle of Serk, is an extensive oyster ground, the marks for which are as follows ; the island of Jethou on with the Bee du Nez, Serk ; Rozel mill on with the Burons de Drouilles ; and, the two high heads of the Pierres de Lecq on with point Grosnez. There is very little difference in the depths of water in its neighbourhood.

312 CHAPTER VII. THE CASQUETS ISLETS ; BURHOU ISLAND ; ALDERNEY ISLAND ; BANC DE LA SCHOLE ; AND ALDERNEY RACE. VARIATION IN 1888, 18° 10' W. The islands and rocks which occupy so large a portion of the space between lie de Brehat and cape de la Hague extend northward as far as the parallel of that cape, where their northern portion forms a chain 9 miles long W. by N. \ N. and E. by S. \ S., and 3 miles wide. This chain is formed by three distinct groups, viz., by the Casquets islets and rocks at its western end, by the island of Alderney at the eastern end, and by Burhou island and its rocks in the centre. They are separated from the coast of France by the Race of Alderney, a channel 8 miles wide, and from the island of Guernsey and its islets by a space about 12 miles wide. CASQUETS ISLETS and ROCKS,* so named, probably, from their remarkable helmet or cap-like appearance, lie N.W. by W. \ W. 6 miles from Alderney old telegraph tower, and form a group half a mile in length W.N.W. and E.S.E. by from 1 to 2 cables in width. The largest and highest of the rocks form a mass near the centre of the group, on which stand the lighthouse and two other stone towers ; all three towers were lighthouses until 1877, when the north-western tower was raised to its present height and maintained as the lighthouse, the eastern tower was reduced in height and con verted into the fog-horn station, and the southern tower reduced in height and made into a store-house. The rocks are 90 feet above high water, and, at low water, all this central mass is connected and extends 3 cables in a W.N.W. and E.S.E. direction, with a width of 1£ cables at its widest part, abreast of the lighthouse. Eastward from this central mass, for 1\ cables, lie six high rocks detached from each other at low water by narrow gullies through which the tide rushes with great velocity ; the eastern rock is the Colotte, it is 33 feet above high water, very steep-to. * See Admiralty plan with views :— Alderney and Casquets, No. 60 ; scale, m = 4 inches.

Chap, vil] CASQUETS ISLETS AND ROCKS. 313 The entire group is as steep as a wall on the southern and eastern sides, though separated on the latter side by only 2 cables from the Fourquies rocks, which dry 13 feet ; but, on the northern side, between point Colotte and the lighthouse, are two small detached heads which uncover at low water ; they are, however, only a quarter of a cable distant from the central mass. On the western side, rocks, presently described, extend nearly 4 cables, and render that side dangerous of approach. LIGHT. — From the lighthouse, which is 75 feet high and coloured white, is exhibited, at 120 feet above high water, a flashing white light, showing three successive flashes of about two seconds duration each, divided by intervals of about three seconds of darkness, the third flash being followed by an eclipse of about eighteen seconds. The light is visible in clear weather from a distance of 15 miles. Fog Signal. — During thick or foggy weather a powerful siren trumpet at the eastern tower gives three blasts of two seconds duration each, in quick succession, every five minutes. Between the first and second blasts, and also between the second and third, intervals of three seconds occur. Landing. — The Little Casquet rock, three quarters of a cable southward of the lighthouse and 53 feet above high water, shelters a landing-place for boats on the main rock at an inlet named Petit Havre ; there is also a landing-place on the eastern side of the Little Casquet rock, and another in a rocky bight on the northern side of the main group. The possibility of safe landing at either of these places is com municated to an approaching vessel by the hoisting of a flag on the platform staff between the towers. When landing can be effected at Petit Havre, a blue flag is hoisted ; when at the southern cove on the easterrk side of the Little Casquet, St. George's Ensign ; and, when at the northern landing-place in the north-eastern cove, a red flag. When no flag is shown, landing is not considered to be safe anywhere. The following are the rocks lying off the western side of the Casquets : — Auquiere Rock, three quarters of a cable W.N.W. from the western end of the main group, is one third of a cable in diameter and 44 feet above high water. Sunken rocks extend a third of a cable northward of the Auquiere, as well as westward and southward

314 CHANNEL ISLANDS. — CASQUETS, ALDERNEY, &C. [Chap. VII. of it. There is a boat channel between it and the Casquets, but it is very narrow, owing to a ledge of sunken rocks which extends nearly half way across from the western point of the Casquet group, and it is rendered still more dangerous by other rocks to the southward which dry at low water ; it should only be used, therefore, in cases of urgent necessity. Noire Roque, or Black Rock, lies W. £ S. 3^ cables from the lighthouse, and W.S.W. westerly nearly 2 cables from the Auquiere ; it is a quarter of a cable in diameter, about 16 feet above high water, and is craggy and unapproachable. Noire Roque Ledge, with only 8 feet water, lies N.W. \ W. westerly 1\ cables from Noire Roque. Its position is generally indicated by a strong ripple, and, with any swell, the sea breaks furiously over it. A sunken rock with only 4 feet water lies midway between Noire Roque and the Auquiere ; no vessel ought, therefore, to attempt to pass between them. Eight-Fathoms Ledge.— N.W. by W. \ W. 7 cables from the Auquiere is a bank of sunken rocks, on which the least water obtained when surveyed was 13 fathoms, but there is said to be as little as 8 fathoms. The bank is from 40 to 50 yards in extent, and rises suddenly from soundings of 25 and 27 fathoms ; although it cannot be touched by vessels even of the deepest draught, it is never theless dangerous, for it causes violent eddies at all times, and during fresh winds the sea breaks on it. Anchorage can be safely attempted only on the south-eastern side of the Casquets, and while the south-western stream is running, and then only by a steam-vessel. The best spot is in 15 fathoms, fine sand ; the north-eastern tower bearing N. by W. \ W., and Fort Albert on with the Ortac rock seen between the Equet and Fourquie rocks. This position, although 1\ cables from the rocks, is quite safe in fine weather when carefully taken up ; it is sheltered from the tide by the Casquet rocks. At 100 yards within it the depth is 8 fathoms, and at the same distance outside 23 fathoms. CAUTION.— The great strength of the tidal stream near these rocks renders an incautious approach to them during foggy weather extremely hazardous; it is therefore recommended at such times never to run for them with the tide, but either to wait for slack

Chap. VII.] DANGERS AROUND THE CASQUETS. 315 water or until the stream in its usual rotary changes turns from the desired direction ; or, to alter the position of the vessel astream of the rocks to leeward, in order to approach them against the tide. Should a shoal cast be obtained when running for the Casquets in thick weather, the vessel's head should be immediately turned against the tide ; after which, haul out cautiously into deep water. Fourquie and Equet Rocks.— A bank of pebbles, sand, and broken shells, with from 6 to 10 fathoms water, extends nearly a mile E.S.E. from Colotte point ; the Fourquie, before mentioned, separated by a channel only 2 cables wide from Colotte point, is near the western end of this bank, and the Equet near its eastern end. The Equet is rather a long,straggling,and dangerous rock ; its northern head is the highest part and dries 7 feet ; this head bears from the north-eastern Casquet tower S.E. by E. £ E. 1^ miles. A detached rocky bank with as little as 33 feet lies one third of a mile eastward of the Equet. The Fourquie dries 13 feet at low water and is steep-to except on its eastern side, where there is a detached sunken rock. The Fourquie bears S.E. by E. E. more than half a mile from the north-eastern tower ; and, S.E. E. 2\ cables from Colotte point. There is no safe channel between the Fourquie and Equet rocks, nor is it safe to approach the eastern side of the latter nearer than half a mile. Whirling eddies, thrown up by the tide rushing over the rugged bottom at these parts, render a vessel involved in them quite unmanageable. The tide sets fairly through the channel between the Fourquie and Colotte point, and, in it, there are 10 fathoms water over a tolerably even bottom ; a steamer may, therefore, safely pass through it in fine weather ; but, near spring tides, with any swell on, it is not prudent to attempt it. South- westward and southward of the Casquets are several extensive banks on which the least known depth is 4 fathoms, but from the overfalls and heavy sea over them in bad weather they are then very dangerous ; they seem to be formed by a deposit caused by the turn of the stream between low water and half flood ; for, near them at this time, the last of the westerly Channel stream, after passing between the Ortac and the Casquets, meets the south-easterly stream then running south-westward of the Casquets. A description of these banks now follows. CASQUET S.W. BANK.— The shoalest spot of 4 fathoms on this bank lies S.W. southerly 4^ miles from the Casquets lighthouse ; the bank is of fine gravel, sand, and shells, 3£ miles long within the

CHANNEL ISLANDS.— CASQUETS, ALDERNEY, &C [Chap. VII. 316 20-fathoms line, in a N.N.E. and S.S.W. direction, and nearly a mile wide. The highest part of the bank is near the middle, close to its western side ; the 10-fathoms line here includes a space just 2 miles long and barely a quarter of a mile wide, the shoal part of 4 fathoms being half a mile within its south-western end. From it, Alderney old telegraph tower bears East a little northerly ; and, Doyle's column on with the north-eastern extreme of Guernsey S.W. £ S. Doyle's column on with Vale mill S.S.W. £ W. leads rather more than a mile westward of the S.W. bank. The channel between the S.W. and S.S.W. banks is from one to 2 miles wide, and has from 22 to 29 fathoms water. CASQUET S.S.W. and S.S.E. BANKS are steep ridgy banks of fine sand, within and eastward of the S.W. bank and lying nearly across the south-western entrance to the Ortac channel. The northern point of the S.S.W. bank in 18 fathoms bears S.W. \ S. nearly 1^ miles from the Casquets lighthouse, and, from this, it extends due South rather more than 1\ miles, after which the water deepens and the tail of the bank turns off to the eastward. This bank is a quarter of a mile wide within the 20-fathoms line ; it has a short ridgy apex with depths of from 12 to 13 fathoms, and 11 fathoms on the shoalest part near the middle. The Casquet S.S.E. bank is rather more than 3 miles long within the 20-fathoms line in a N.E. and S.W. direction, and three quarters of a mile wide ; its south-western end, after the water deepens to 18 fathoms, turns off north-westward and unites with the S.S.W. bank. A narrow ridge of shoal water, a mile in extent, runs along the middle of the S.S.E. bank ; it has 4| fathoms at its north-eastern end, and only 4 fathoms at its south-western end, with irregular soundings of from 5 to 8 fathoms between. From the north-eastern shoal spot of 4^ fathoms, Tourgis beacon over the middle of Clonque fort bears E. £ N. northerly ; and, the Clonque and Tourgis fort beacons in line E. by N. northerly, the same mark as for the Pierre au Vraic, passes over the top of the bank midway between the shoal spdts at its extremes. At the north-eastern extreme of the 10-fathoms line, the Casquets lighthouse bears N.W. by N. nearly 3 miles, and at the south-western extreme N. \ W. westerly ?>\ miles. The shoal spots are difficult to pick up, being generally the summits of sharp ridges of sand and very steep ; the ridges appear to run rather across the bank in an E.S.E. and W.N.W. direction, but in all probability they shift with the turn of the tide.

Chap, vie] CASQUET AND POMMIER BANKS. 317 Anchorage.— Vessels should avoid anchoring on the S.S.W. bank, there being at all times a strong ripple over it ; but, on the S.S.E. bank, in fine weather, vessels cruising in the vicinity may anchor with advantage. The best anchorage is in from 6 to 10 fathoms, with the Ortac rock midway between Renonquet and Verte-tete N.E. easterly, and the Casquets N. by W. £ W. Clearing Marks.— To clear the Casquet S.S.E. bank outside and southward of the 10-fathoms line, keep the Etac de la Quoire open half a point southward of the Orbouee rock E. \ N. To clear it to the northward, the inner top of the Great Coque Lihou touching the northern side of the Coupe rock E. by S. \ S. leads more than half a mile northward of the northern shallow spot in 10 fathoms. Verte tete behind the Ortac N.E. £ N. leads clear to the eastward ; and, the western side of Renonquet on with the eastern side of the Ortac rock N.E. £ E. leads clear to the westward. CASQUET MIDDLE BANK is about midway between the northern parts of the S.S.W. and S.S.E. banks ; it is nearly circular, about 4 cables in diameter, and has from 15 to 20 fathoms water, with gravel and broken shells bottom. The general depth round all the Casquet banks is from 22 to 25 fathoms. POMMIER BANKS, on the western side of the Ortac channel, are two extensive and dangerous groups of sunken rocks, divided by a narrow 12-fathoms channel. The highest head is near the western end of the western bank ; it has only 13 feet water, and lies E. by N. \ N. northerly 1^ miles from the Casquets ; from it, the Ortac rock appears midway between Alderney old telegraph tower and the south western brick kilns S.E. \ E. ; and, Casquets lighthouse and north eastern tower nearly in line bear W. by S. \ S. southerly. From this 13-feet rock, the eastern end of the eastern bank bears E. \ S. one mile. The least known depth on this bank is 5 fathoms, but there may be 2 or 3 feet less. Clearing Marks. — The north-eastern and south-eastern Casquet towers in line S.W. \ W. lead three quarters of a mile north-westward ; the Noires Putes midway between the Ortac rock and Renonquet S.S.E. \ E. leads nearly half a mile eastward ; and, St. Anne's church steeple on with the Ortac S.E. by E. \ E. easterly leads half a mile south-westward of them and southward of the Danger rocks ; it is also the best leading mark for entering the Ortac channel between the Pommier banks and Equet rocks.

CHANNEL ISLANDS.— CASQUETS, ALDERNEY, &C. [Chap. VII. 318 Danger Rocks, with 21 feet water, lie 7 cables southward of the Pommier banks and E. \ S. 2 miles from the Casquets. These rocks are very little more than half a cable in extent East and West, but there may be a few feet less water on them than that given ; they must therefore be approached with caution. The channel between Danger rocks and the Equet bank has 15 fathoms, and is nearly three quarters of a mile wide ; it is therefore quite safe for a vessel under perfect command in fine weather; but, in bad weather, and especially at spring tides, no vessel should attempt it ; indeed at such times, neither this nor any of the channels between the Casquets and Ortac should be used, for the entire space is then covered with tremendous overfalls, in which the largest vessels would be quite unmanageable ; even during fine weather there are overfalls, but being then confined to the shoalest parts, they serve to mark the positions of the highest rocky heads, and thus rather contribute to the safety of the navigation. Speedy Rock, nearly half a mile N. W. from the Verte-tete, marks the northern boundary of the Ortac channel on its eastern side ; the shoalest spot known has 33 feet water ; from it, the outer high rock of the Etacs on with the high central rock of Renonquet bears S. by E. £ E. ; and, Fort Albert flagstaff the apparent breadth of the fort open southward of the Great Nannel S.E. by E. Verte-tete Reef, north-eastward of the Ortac rock, marks the northern extreme of the dangerous rocks, stretching north-westward more than a mile from the western end of Little Burhou islet. There are three high rocks on this reef, of which the Cone rock, the most remarkable, is the westernmost ; it bears N.N.E. £ E. 8 cables from the Ortac rock ; and, E. \ S. 3^ miles from the Casquets. It is of sugar-loaf form and about 20 feet above high water ; it is detached from the main reef at all times of tide, is very steep-to on its northern side, but, at three quarters of a cable westward, there is a small pointed rock which uncovers 6 feet. The principal rock of the Verte-tete reef is 13 feet higher and much larger than Cone rock ; it has, moreover, two heads ; the south western and highest is flat at the top ; the other, a quarter of a cable north-eastward of it, being lower, smaller, and peaked. A reef, dry at low water, extends nearly a cable eastward of the high head of Verte-tete, and a sunken rock bears E.N.E. about one cable from it ; with the exception of the dangers described, those of the Verte-tete rocks which are always above water, are very steep-to on the northern side.

Chap. VII.] VERTE-TETE. — ORTAC ROCK AND CHANNEL. 319 ORTAC ROCK.— At 3£ miles E. by S. \ S. from the Casquets lighthouse lies this remarkable, huge, and nearly inaccessible rock ; it is 79 feet above high water, and may be seen in clear weather 9 or 10 miles distant. Its southern side is steep-to, having 8 fathoms within half a cable of the rock, but a sunken ledge, with only 11 feet at its outer edge, extends 1£ cables N.W. by W. from the rock, and, from it, Clonque fort is just in sight southward of the Ortac. From the highest part of this ledge three quarters of a cable south-west ward of the Ortac, with 14 feet water, Fort Albert flagstaff is just in sight southward of the Ortac rock. To pass westward of the ledge when coming from the southward, keep Fort Albert flagstaff well open southward of the Ortac rock until Verte-tete bears N.E. by E. Between Ortac, Verte-tete, and Burhou island, are scattered many dangerous sunken rocks and ledges, near and amongst which the streams run with great velocity. ORTAC CHANNEL is bounded on its eastern side by the Ortac rock and ledge, just described, and by the rocks extending from Renonquet and Verte-tete, with the Speedy rock as its northern and eastern boundary ; and, on its western side, by the eastern Pommier bank, Danger rocks, and the Equet reef, already described. There is also, near mid-channel, the Dasher rock, with 6£ fathoms water ; vessels may pass on either side of this rock, but the passage on its eastern side is the best. The northern entrance of the Ortac channel, between the eastern Pommier bank and Speedy rock, is more than a mile wide ; its narrowest part, eastward of the Dasher rock, is nearly three quarters of a mile wide ; at this part, the Great Nannel rock appears a little open northward of the high head of Renonquet E. by S. ; this mark leads over the Dasher rock, from which, the outer high rock of the Etacs, off the western end of Alderney, touching the north-eastern side of the Ortac bears S.E. \ S. The general depth in this channel is about 15 fathoms, with toler ably regular soundings, but the bottom is rocky and foul throughout ; anchoring, therefore, except when unavoidable, is not to be thought of. The tides here run with great strength, especially near high or low water, and, at springs, they attain a velocity of more than 7 knots ; in the course of their rotary change of direction they set across the channel, and, although when running in this direction their strength decreases, an incautious pilot might soon be swept amongst dangerous rocks. From these and previous remarks, it should be understood that these channels are at all times hazardous for sailing vessels, and even for steamers unless those who navigate them possess consider able local knowledge.

VII. 320 Directions. — To pass through the Ortac channel from the north ward, bring the Ortac rock to bear S. \ E. and steer direct for it on this bearing ; and, when the Great Nannel comes on with the Verte tete E. by S. \ S., steer S.S.W. W., which course leads through the channel about 2£ cables westward of the outer part of the Ortac ledge. As before stated, when the Great Nannel is nearly on with the northern part of the highest head of Renonquet, a vessel is abreast of the Dasher rock, southward of which the deep-water channel is nearly two miles wide. When bordering on the northern side of the Ortac rock, the ledge off it may be cleared by not bringing the Great Nannel nearer to Burhou reef than the middle of the water gap or channel between it and Renonquet ; when fort Albert is open southward of the Ortac rock, a vessel is southward of the Ortac ledge ; and, when Noir Houmet, a high rock on the southern side of Burhou island, opens southward of the Ortac, she is clear of the Equet and of all danger to the southward. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the Casquets and at the Ortac rock at 6 h. 45 m. ; equinoctial springs rise 24 feet, ordinary springs 15^ feet, and neaps 10 feet. Tidal Streams. — Although the tidal stream in the immediate neighbourhood of the Casquets preserves the rotary character so frequently alluded to, it varies much in strength and direction, according to position. On their northern side and to the eastward, for instance, when outside the influence of the Ortac channel, the slack and change of stream takes place as in the offing, the great body of the flood setting E. by N. and the ebb W. by S. ; but, west ward of the Casquets, the strength of the stream is principally felt in three different directions, viz. : — at 2\ hours flood, South 3-7 knots ; at one hour ebb, E.N.E. 3-0 knots ; and, an hour before low water, W. by N. 3d knots ; between these points, a continuous stream sets westward, southward, and eastward, the only slack occurring between 3 and 4 hours ebb. On the south-western side of the Casquets, between half ebb and low water, there is an eddy nearly 2 miles wide and of considerable strength. Between low water and 2 hours flood, this eddy extends farther eastward and increases in breadth ; and, for a time, it thus continues but gradually becomes weaker and finally disappears at about half flood. Eddies exist also on the north-eastern side of the Casquets, but their action is exactly the reverse of those on the south western side.

Chap, vil] 321 TIDAL STREAMS. — BURHOU ISLAND. The stream in the Casquets channel — that is, in its immediate draught — begins to set south -westward exactly at half ebb by the shore, and runs in that direction for 6 hours, or until half flood ; and, the contrary is the case with the north-eastern stream, for there is neither high nor low water slack here. The stream, which begins to run north-eastward at half flood through the Ortac channel, gradually turns more northward after passing the Ortac rock and sets N.N.E. until it again unites with the stream flowing eastward past the northern side of the Casquets. The south-western stream of this channel, which commences at half ebb, sets right over the Equet and the Fourquies, to avoid which rocks the utmost care must be taken. On the south-western side of the Ortac rock, there is an eddy nearly 1^ miles in extent between half ebb and one hour's flood ; after which, the stream on the southern side of the Ortac gradually inclines westward, setting directly for the Casquets at 2 hours flood, until it runs into the last of the south-western stream in the Casquet channel. There is no eddy of consequence on the north-eastern side of the Ortac rock. BURHOU ISLAND lies East 1£ miles from the Ortac ; it is nearly level towards the middle, though huge rocks crop out near the extremes, and it is fringed with reef. The western part of Burhou is cut off from the main part at high water, the portion thus detached being called Little Burhou. The two islands together are 6 cables long East and West and nearly 2 cables wide, their rocky peaks being about the same height, 87 feet above high water ; they are covered with a light soil, on which grow coarse grasses and a variety of wild flowers ; the soil is burrowed in every direction by rabbits, formerly very numerous, but now nearly exterminated by the Alderney fisher men ; their holes are now frequently the breeding places of various kinds of sea birds, and, among others, ot the stormy petrel, which resorts to these islands during the breeding season. There is a small anchorage on each side of the island and a refuge for fishermen and shipwrecked mariners on the low saddle near the middle. The landing places are in two small coves near the refuge, one on either side of the island. No fresh water can be obtained except such as may be deposited by rain in the interstices of the rocks. Burhou Reef. — The eastern side of Burhou is clear of danger to within half a cable of the shore, but a reef extends westward of Little Burhou for half a mile, and the whole of it, with the exception of a A. 2771. There is a 5-fathoms channel between Burhou reef and the rocks extending 4 cables eastward of the Ortac rock, and also a very narrow channel called the Passe de la Maure, northward of Burhou reef, and leading into the Little Swinge ; only the most expert pilots amongst the Alderney fishermen can navigate either of these channels with safety. Dangers northward of Burhou Island.— The following rocks and ledges lie north-westward, northward, and north-eastward of Burhou island, effectually closing all approach to it from that direction except by one narrow channel between the Maquereaux reef and the Nannels: — Renonquet Reef, on the northern side of the Passe de la Maure and a quarter of a mile within the Verte-tete, see page 318, is nearly three quarters of a mile long East and West ; its western end is low and covers with the tide for 3g cables, but, near the eastern end, is a group of high rocks about 1^ cables in diameter which never cover. The highest of this group is 43 feet above high water and about 3 cables south-eastward of the high head of Verte-tete, in line between it and the peak of Little Burhou. White Rock is 2\ cables eastward of the highest Renonquet ; it is small, 20 feet above high water, steep-to, and safe of approach on its northern side. Only one other rock eastward of this, near the Renonquet group, is visible at high water ; this is a small head 10 or 12 feet above high water S.E. by E. \ E. 1^ cables from White rock ; therefore, the White rock eastward, the Verte-tete westward, and the Renonquet rock in the middle, form together a remarkable group for recognition by the mariner set in here during foggy weather. Maquereaux Rocks. — A sunken reef, 2 cables in extent North and South and a cable wide, is half a mile eastward of the White rock ; three heads near the middle of the reef have only 4 feet water, and there is no safe channel through the chain of rocks between the Maquereaux and Verte-tete. The outer Etac on with the saddle rock of Burhou just westward of the refuge S. \ W. leads eastward of the Maquereaux rocks ; and, the Casquet towers their apparent breadth open northward of Verte-tete W. \ N. leads one cable northward. Anchorage. — The eastern clearing mark given is also the best leading mark with which to run in for the anchorage on the northern

VII.] DANGERS ROUND BURHOU. — SWINGE CHANNEL. 323 side of Burhou, should a vessel be compelled to use it ; in such a case, anchor in 7 fathoms, sand, a little westward of the leading line, with the outer Etac between it and the western peak of Burhou ; and, the Ortac on with, or just southward of, the northernmost high-water head of Burhou reef. The Nannels, said to be an English corruption of Les Nianaises, is a reef about 4 cables long East and West and 2\ cables wide ; it forms the north-eastern part of the Burhou group, and consists of enormous and curiously shaped rocks, of which some are always above water and others cover and uncover with the tide. The Great Nannel, the highest, is 52 feet above high water, and is near the middle of the south-western part of the reef. The Little Nannel, the next in height, is only 16 feet above high water, and is at the north-western end of the reef, one cable distant from the Great Nannel. Other but smaller rocks above high water extend 2 cables in an easterly direction from the Great Nannel. The end of the group in this direction is the Pierre de But ; this rock covers near high water. The Boues de But, two sunken rocks having 9 feet over them, lie one third of a cable eastward of the Pierre de But. The Cordonnier, a small rock drying 3 feet, lies 1\ cables southward of the Great Nannel. The width between Burhou and the Nannels is just 2 cables ; the Equet, a rock near the middle which dries 6 feet at low water, divides the passage into two channels, through which the tide rushes into the Little Swinge with great velocity. The Emprone Reef, N.N.E. 3 cables from the Great Nannel, is lh cables long East and West by three quarters of a cable wide ; it has four rocks which uncover, the highest 2 feet, and other rocks awash. The sea breaks furiously on this reef, especially with fresh north westerly winds. Round Rock dries 9 feet midway betwreen the Nannels and the Emprone. Clearing Marks. — The Casquet towers open their own apparent breadth northward of Verte-tete W. \ N. lead northward of the Emprone reef and of the Nannels, a close mark for the former ; and, Alderney mill open eastward of the Grosse rock S. £ E. easterly leads eastward. The SWINGE CHANNEL divides Burhou island and its rocks from Alderney ; it should never be used by a stranger except in clear X 2
