Its narrowest part is included in the space bounded by the rocks fringing the southern shore of Burhou island on the one side, and by the Barsier and Corbet rocks on the other. It is here only three quarters of a mile wide, but, when past these rocks in either direction, it soon widens. The bottom is rocky throughout and very uneven ; the average depth at its narrowest part is about 10 fathoms. There are several dangerous rocks, presently described, in the Swinge, and there is much broken water, even in the calmest weather, caused by the rapidity of the stream over the rugged bottom. There are also two overfalls, caused solely by the tide, of which the danger is much increased in bad weather. During easterly winds, on the north-eastern stream, overfalls extend nearly across from Burhou island to the outer end of Alderney break water. With westerly winds, on the south-western stream, they extend from the Ortac rock to the Etacs. Both may be avoided by following the directions hereafter given. See pages 327, 328. DANGERS in the SWINGE.— Approaching the Swinge from the south-westward, besides the Ortac rock and other dangers already described on the northern side, are also the Boues des Kaines and North rock, with other rocks in-shore of them adjacent to Burhou island ; near the centre of the entrance is the Pierre au Vraic, with Richards and Ellis rocks to the eastward ; and, on the southern side of the channel, bordering the coast of Alderney, are the EtacB banks, South rock, and the Barsier and Corbet rocks, before mentioned as being at the narrowest part of the Swinge, besides many other rocks and ledges closer in-shore. Boues des Kaines. — The outer head of these rocks is awash at low water ; it lies S.S.W. £ W. 3 cables from the high water rocky mass at the south-western end of Burhou reef ; from it, Fort Albert flagstaff just inside the outer end of Grosnez fort bears E. by S. \ S. ; and, Long rock a little open westward of the south-western rocky mass of Burhou reef N.N.E. \ E. easterly. There is a channel between these rocks and the Burhou reef barely 1\ cables wide. North Rock, with 11 feet water, lies 2 cables S.E. \ E. fromNoir Houmet, off Burhou island ; from it, the Great Nannel is seen in the gap just within the easternmost, high, semi-detached rock of Burhou, bearing N.N.E. \ E. easterly; and, the Ortac rock just open southward of the half-tide reef south-westward of Noir Houmet W. by N. northerly.

Chap. VII.] SWINGE CHANNEL.— PIERRE AU VRAIC. 325 Anchorage. — The entrance to the anchorage on the southern side of Burhou island is just westward of the half -tide reef of Noir Houmet ; vessels find excellent shelter here in about 5 fathoms during the south-western stream. Pierre au Vraic. — This dangerous rock, which dries 5 feet at low spring tides, is immediately in the stream of the Swinge channel ; from it, the Casquets lighthouse bears N.W. 4 W. 4 miles ; the Ortac rock N. £ E. 1 miles ; and, the outer and highest of the Etacs, near the western end of Alderney, E. \ N. 1£ miles. In form and size this rock is like a small boat bottom up, and it is surrounded by deep water ; at 1^ cables both southward and westward of it there are 26 fathoms, and within that distance, as also in-shore of it, from 14 to 16 fathoms. The marks for the Pierre au Vraic are, the inner peak of Great Coque Lihou on with the Coupe rock E. by S. 4 S. ; and, the conical beacon on the slope of the high land just within Fort Tourgis on with the beacon in Clonque fort E. by N. northerly ; these marks are also used to clear the rock on either side. Tourgis beacon on with northern end of Clonque fort leads 2 cables northward of the Pierre au Vraic. By night, Cape de la Hague light opening and shutting in with the southern end of Alderney also leads close northward of it. Richards and Ellis Rocks are on a rocky bank rather more than half a mile south-eastward of the Pierre au Vraic, and are 2\ cables distant from each other. Richards rock has 5£ fathoms water, and there are 23 fathoms within a cable southward of* it ; from the rock, the outer Coque Lihou a little open northward of the inner Noire Pute bears E. £ S. ; and, the Great Nannel just within the outer eastern high rock on Burhou N.E. by N. northerly. Ellis rock bears N. 4 W. 2\ cables from Richards rock ; it appears, however, to have nothing less than 85 fathoms water. The Great Nannel on with the eastern end of Burhou leads a third of a mile eastward of these rocks. Large ships should not pass between Richards rock and the Pierre au Vraic. The Etacs Bank is nearly half a mile W.N.W. from the Etacs rocks ; the least known depth, 26 feet, is near the southern end. To pass outside this bank, keep the Great Noire Pute open westward of the Coupe rock until the Great Nannel is over the eastern end of Burhou island, or until Tourgis beacon comes near the northern end of Clonque fort.

CHANNEL ISLANDS.— CASQUETS, ALDERNEY, &C. [Chap. VII. 326 South Rock, with 5 fathoms, lies with the western end of the Great Noire Pute touching the eastern side of the inner rock of the Etacs S. £ E. ; and, the northern upper extreme of Fort Albert a little open southward of the inner part of Grosnez fort E. \ S. There is another head with 5^ fathoms at the western end of this same rocky bank ; it bears from South rock S.W. by W. \ W. 2\ cables. Both of these heads may have less water than is here given ; in approaching them from the westward, it is useful to remember that you cannot pass over the western head so long as the Great Noire Pute is in sight westward of the Etacs ; and, proceeding eastward, you are clear of the eastern head when the whole of the Great Noire Pute is eastward of the inner rock of the Etacs. Barsier Reef is a dangerous rocky group northward of the Clonque rock, from which it bears N. by W. 4 cables. The eastern heads of the Barsier dry 5 feet, and the western head is just awash at low water, springs. The eastern head of the highest Barsier bears S.W. by W. \ W. 2 cables from the Corbet rock ; the western head of the reef is on the same bearing three quarters of a cable from its eastern head. The eastern head of the outer Noire Pute on with the western end of Alderney S. \ W. westerly, clears the western side of the Barsier reef by half a cable ; and, Fort Albert flagstaff on with the flagstaff of Grosnez fort E. £ S. leads clear of its northern side about the same distance, but directly over the reef in-shore of the Corbet rock. Corbet Rock is half a mile N. by E. easterly from Clonque fort, and N.W. by W. \ W. half a mile from Tourgis point ; it is never wholly covered, though at very high springs it is awash. There is a small detached rock outside the Corbet which dries at low water ; it is 40 yards distant, with the Corbet rock and Tourgis fort in line. The Corbet is attached to Alderney by a dangerous low-water ledge of rocks, and both tidal streams run over this ledge with great rapidity. The long western mark for the Corbet is, the north-eastern Casquets tower a little open southward of the Ortac rock W. by N. | N. ; and, the southern extreme of the Casquets just shut in with the southern cide of the Ortac leads northward of the Corbet and through the narrows of the Swinge. Between the Corbet and the eastern end of Burhou the streams rush with great velocity, and during a weather tide the sea breaks nearly across the Swinge ; the smoothest water then is generally near the Corbet. Other rocks and shoals nearer in-shore off the north-western and northern coasts of Alderney are fully described at page 334.

Chap, vie] SWINGE CHANNEL. — TIDAL STREAM. 327 DIRECTIONS— From the Southward through the Swinge. — Steer for the south-western end of Alderney, and, on approaching the Pierre au Vraic, be careful to open Tourgis beacon northward of Clonque fort, in order to pass northward of it ; or, to pass inside and southward of the Pierre au Vraic, bring Clonque fort on with the western end of the Etacs until the Great Nannel just within the eastern end of Burhou bears N.N.E. £ E., which marks lead eastward of Richards rock and outside the Etacs bank and the Boues des Etacs; proceed with the latter leading mark until Fort Albert flagstaff is on with the flagstaff in Grosnez fort ; the vessel is then northward of the South rock and of Barsier reef, and may round the Corbet rock at the distance of a cable if desired. After passing the Corbet, a course may be shaped out into the English Channel or for Alderney harbour, bearing in mind that more than one third of the breakwater at its outer end has now been washed away and forms a dangerous submerged reef, see page 331, for which a good clearing mark is, the Ortac rock seen between Noir Houmet and Burhou island ; the chief dangers southward of this line are the Jumelles rocks, described at page 335. Large ships should pass westward of the Pierre au Vraic and up through the middle of the Swinge, on the western side of the South rock bank and lj or 2 cables northward of Corbet rock, along which route nothing less than 8 fathoms will be met with, clearing the outlying rocks in passing by the marks just given in describing those dangers. By Night, it is useful to remember that the Casquets light is eclipsed by the Ortac rock when bearing W. by N. \ N. northerly ; the line of eclipse on the southern side of the Ortac passes nearly a cable northward of the Corbet rock ; the Casquets light is seen again on the northern side of the Ortac at the distance of 1^ cables northward of the Corbet rock. THE TIDAL STREAM must be carefully considered and allowed for in navigating the Swinge. The first of the eastern stream sets on Alderney, but, after high water, it turns off to the northward and north-westward. Therefore, entering the Swinge from the southward on the first of this stream, it is advisable under ordinary circumstances to pass westward of the Pierre au Vraic, and, eastward of it, at the latter part of the tide ; in thick weather, however, the Alderney shore should be closed with, but cautiously at all times, and the vessel anchored on or near the Orbouee bank or in the West bay

CHANNEL ISLANDS.— CASQUETS, ALDERNEY, &C. [Chap. VII. 328 anchorage until clear enough to proceed, see page 342. No vessel should attempt to pass through the Swinge with the tide in foggy weather, for, at springs, the stream runs from 7 to 8 knots, and under such circumstances it is evident that, should a vessel come suddenly into danger, her destruction would be inevitable. The strength of the stream in the Swinge— that is, between Burhou island and the Corbet rock — sets straight through both ways at high and low water ; like the stream in the Casquet channel, it begins to set south-westward at half ebb exactly, and runs in that direction for 6 hours, or until half flood ; and, the contrary is the case with the north-eastern stream. Westward of the Narrows, a branch of the north-eastern stream sets through between Burhou island and the Ortac rock, especially after high water by the shore ; and, eastward of the Narrows, it curves round the Emprone to the north-westward, where both branches uniting with the Casquets channel tides, and ultimately with that of the English Channel, again set eastward. The last two hours of the south-western stream in the Swinge gradually veers towards the South as it recedes from the draught of the Swinge passage. The average velocity of the north-eastern stream during springs is 7£ miles ; that of the south-western stream, 6| miles per hour. When passing through the Swinge from the northward, on the first of the south-western stream, proceed along the Alderney shore, past the Etacs, and eastward of the Pierre au Vraic. After low water, keep Burhou island and the Ortac rock aboard, taking care to clear the North rock and Boues des Kaines, and making due allowance for the set of the south-eastern stream, which will be met with after clearing the Casquet banks. In westerly gales, it is particularly necessary to take the above prescribed routes to avoid the overfalls, which shift their positions through a regular course according to the direction of the stream. At such times, the Swinge is only navigable by steam-vessels of large size and power, and even then at some risk. Vessels from the northward and eastward, as well as those from Alderney, bound to Guernsey or Jersey during westerly gales, should endeavour to push through the Race or Swinge channels directly the north-eastern stream begins to slack, the sea being then comparatively smooth ; for, as the south-western stream makes against the gale, so does the sea rise and become dangerous ; and, as during the strength of this stream both the Race and Swinge channels are covered with broken water and highly dangerous, it is recommended at such times that vessels anchor in Alderney harbour, and there wait for a tide or for a lull in the gale.

Chap, vil.] TIDAL STREAM. — ALDERNEY ISLAND. 329 ALDERNEY or AURIGNY ISLAND,* is 3| miles long, East and West, by 14 miles wide at the widest part, which is near the western end. The Rond But, one third from the western end, is 306 feet above the sea, and is the highest part of the island, though the hill on which the windmill stands, half a mile westward of it, is nearly the same height, and at the old telegraph tower the land is only 10 feet lower. Alderney may be seen in clear weather at the distance of 22 miles ; its eastern extreme bears W. by N. f N. nearly 8 miles from Cape ,de la Hague lighthouse ; and, E. by S. \ S. 8j miles from the Casquets. The appearance of the island from a distance is wild and gloomy, nor does it improve on a nearer view. The southern and western coasts are high precipitous cliffs, intersected by narrow valleys and fronted by outlying rocks, among which the most conspicuous are the Coque Lihou and Noire Putes groups to the southward, and the Etacs and Clonques to the westward ; the latter are crowned by a fort, which commands the Swinge channel. The northern and eastern sides are not nearly so high, and the coast consists of a series of bays of sand and gravel separated from each other by steep projecting points ; but, with the exception of the small bays of Braye, enclosed by the breakwater which forms Alderney harbour, Plate Saline, and Corblets, the intervals of beach are inaccessible, on account of the outlying rocks, which forbid all approach. The heights along the southern and western coasts are covered with heath and furze, but the interior is generally cultivated and fertile. There are but few trees on the island, and these only in the valleys near the town, where the neighbouring hills afford some shelter from the wind. St. Anne, the town of Alderney, is near the middle of the island ; it is well built, paved, and lighted with gas ; it has a large and hand some church, St. Anne's, besides several chapels. In addition to the town, villages sprang up at Craby, Braye new town, and Mannez, during the progress of the breakwater and forts, for the convenience of those engaged on the public works and at the quarries. Alderney has no dock accommodation nor any facilities for the repairs of shipping or for coaling steamers, no stock of coal, in fact, being kept for that purpose. Its trade in 1886 was represented by 223 vessels entering the port during the year, of an aggregate tonnage of 23,904 tons, besides which 204 passing vessels took refuge under its breakwater. The island abounds with springs of excellent water. Fuel is imported from England, and cattle for fresh meat from * See Admiralty chart : — Alderney and the Casquets, No. 60 ; scale m=i inches.

CHANNEL ISLANDS.— CASQUETS, ALDERNEY, &C. [Chap. VII. 330 Cherbourg ; these necessaries are nevertheless to be obtained almost at the same prices as at Guernsey, owing to the regular steam communication now existing between Alderney, Cherbourg, and Guernsey. Stone is occasionally exported to England, and the island is in telegraphic communication with Jersey by cable from its south western end, and thus with England and France. Until the building of the breakwater, Alderney possessed but two small insecure harbours, both of which dry at low water neaps, viz., Longy bay or Baie du Catel, on the south-eastern side of the island, and the old artificial harbour of Braye on the northern side. Alderney forms part of the Bailiwick of Guernsey, and is included in the military command of the Lieutenant-Governor of that island ; it forms one parish under the patronage of the Crown, named St. Anne, of which the area is 1,962 imperial acres at high water, springs. The land was originally divided into small parcels among the in habitants, but the Government has purchased about a third of it for public works. The Civil Government or States consists of a judge appointed by the Crown, six jurats, and twelve douzeniers, who are elected by the inhabitants. In 1881, the population of Alderney, exclusive of the military, was 1,522, a great decrease having taken place consequent on the completion of the large Government works which had been so many years in progress. The ordinary garrison consists of a battery of Royal Artillery, besides the island militia, who are organized as artillery and reported to be very efficient. The forts along the northern, eastern, and south eastern shores of Alderney form a great feature in the appearance of the island on those sides ; of them, Fort Albert is the most conspicuous, standing on the crown of a remarkable conical hill which rises from the comparatively low land at the north-eastern part of the island. The Approach to Alderney on every side but from the north eastward, is dangerous from the numerous outlying rocks ; and, the dangers of the navigation are greatly intensified by the strength of the tidal streams ; therefore, a stranger should close with the island only on its north-eastern side, from which direction Alderney harbour may be approached and entered by attending carefully to the directions given. ALDERNEY HARBOUR, on the northern shore of Alderney, as originally formed by the breakwater, enclosed the old harbour of Braye, as well as the anchorage in the road fronting it, and also the harbour of Craby, which latter was built chiefly to shelter the

Chap. VII.] ALDERNEY HARBOUR. — BREAKWATER. 331 vessels employed in laying the foundations of the breakwater and other Government works. The rocks encumbering the harbour were removed, and the anchorage rendered clear ; but, on account of the rocky nature of the bottom, vessels using their own anchors had always to ride with a good scope of cable when there was much wind. The harbour afforded good shelter from all but easterly winds, which sent in much sea.* The BREAKWATER was commenced in 1847 and completed m 1870 ; as constructed, it extended from Grosnez point straight for 1,000 yards N. 74° E., when it curved northward for 173 yards, with a radius of 500 yards, and from thence straight to the end N. 54° E. for a further distance of 436 yards. It was built on an artificial bank of rubble stone or pierres perdues, the main part being 40 feet wide, and 6 feet above high water, springs. Unfortunately, the strength of the breakwater has proved unequal to the requirements of the position, and its partial destruction, commenced during a violent gale from the eastward on the night of 8th January 1879, has gone on until by May 1887, the whole of the outer part, for an extent of 642 yards, had disappeared, leaving the inner part standing for a distance of 967 yards from fort Grosnez, the present visible end above water terminating so abruptly as to be easily mistaken by a stranger, unaware of the destruction that has taken place, for a finished end, and thus con stituting a great danger should the clearing marks not be made out, or be carelessly disregarded. The outer submerged portion now forms a reef visible in parts at low water, of which the most conspicuous portion is about 1,300 yards from fort Grosnez, or about 330 yards from its present outer end. The value of the harbour as a refuge is necessarily greatly impaired by the destruction which has taken place, but it has been decided that its repair shall not be undertaken. At the inner end of the breakwater there is a slipway for boats and small vessels, with steps at the lower end descending to the level of low water, springs ; there is also a flight of landing steps on the inner side 930 yards from the shore, and therefore close to its present visible outer end. The inner part of the breakwater is provided at short intervals with iron ladders from low water to the quay level ; in order that large ships might lie alongside, it was originally provided with mooring chains and bollards, but the destruction of so large a portion has rendered that impossible. As before remarked, the rocks inside the Breakwater were for the most part removed by blasting ; of these, the Tetes Champignons N.W. by W. three quarters of a cable from Roselle point now have 16 feet water. Another group W. by S. 2 cables from Roselle point now have 12 feet over them ; and, at the position of a former half tide rock there are 22 feet water. The Aiguillons rocks are eastward of those removed by blasting. They consist of a group of eight heads which dry at low water ; the Great Aiguillon, the easternmost rock, is N.N.E. h E. 1^ cables from Bibette head. The Small Aiguillon is the outer or northernmost of the group and bears due West nearly half a cable from the Great Aiguillon. A beacon turret was erected on this latter rock, but it was washed away during the winter of 1886-1887 and is not to be replaced. A dangerous reef of sunken rocks, with from 10 to 6 feet water, extends two thirds of a cable northward of the Great Aiguillon ; it may be cleared on the western side by keeping the flagstaff in Fort Albert open westward of the Small Aiguillon when that rock is uncovered ; and, the same rock on with the outer Grois rock E. by N. \ N. leads clear of a 16-feet rock off Bibette head. LIGHTS. — Two fixed red lights are exhibited at the head of the harbour to mark the fairway channel by night ; the lower light is visible in clear weather 5 miles, and is exhibited through a long tube which screens it in every direction except on a line through the middle of the fairway ; this light is shown from a white tower on the parapet of the old pier at Braye and is 25 feet above high water, springs. The upper light is exhibited from a pillar on the site of the old lecture room S.W. £ W. 370 yards from the lower light ; it is 55 feet above high water, and visible in clear weather from a distance of 9 miles. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in Alderney harbour at 6 h. 46 m.; mean springs rise 11 \ feet ; neaps rise 12£ feet ; neaps range 8 feet. Braye Old Harbour, within Alderney harbour, is formed by a sheltering pier projecting in an easterly direction from the western side of Braye bay ; it dries at low water, neaps, and was very insecure before the breakwater was built ; even now it is very inferior to the little harbour of Craby.

Chap. VII.] BRAYE AND CRABY HARBOURS. — DIRECTIONS. 333 The best time to enter Braye harbour is on a rising tide between half flood and high water ; at low water, there is a depth of 8 feet between the iron beacons placed one on either side of the entrance on the two rocky masses just outside the pier-head. The western beacon has a circular eye on the top ; the eastern one, a cross. No leading mark is required, but the pier-head should be rounded as closely as possible. Craby Harbour, also within Alderney harbour, was constructed by the Government in 1850, in the creek between Braye old harbour and Grosnez point. In addition to the shelter of the breakwater, this harbour is protected by two small piers having an entrance between the pier-heads 40 feet wide and open to the North-east. This harbour is 100 yards long from West to East, and 90 yards wide ; it affords 230 yards of quay frontage, sufficient to berth four colliers of about 150 tons burthen ; it dries out to the pier-heads at low water, springs, and at half tide there are 9 feet between the pier-heads. DIRECTIONS. — From the north-eastward, in hazy weather, it is prudent to obtain a bearing of cape de la Hague, when a vessel may stand boldly for the north-eastern end of the island ; but, to avoid the outlying rocks, should the weather be so thick that land cannot be discerned at the distance of 2 miles, neither the cape nor the island should be approached within that distance. When nearing either the cape or the island, the tides must be care fully considered, especially during the south-western stream, as it sets strongly over the Blanchard and Brinchetaie ledge ; and, it may be useful to note that on nearing the eastern end of Alderney, the Great Coque Lihou rock open south-eastward of the island keeps a vessel in the stream of the Race, and the Casquets light open north ward of Burhou island keeps her in the Swinge or Channel stream. See also page 348 for approaching the harbour entrance when coming from the south-westward round the eastern end of the island. In clear weather, a vessel may stand direct for the island. The leading mark into the harbour can then be seen 5 or 6 miles distant ; it is, the tower of St. Anne's church on with the pier-head of Braye old harbour S.W. 4. W. westerly ; and, to clear the outer end of the submerged portion of the breakwater, vessels from the northward or westward rounding the breakwater must be careful to keep the beacon on King's battery wall well open eastward of the Hornet des Pies beacon until the leading mark for the harbour comes on.

CAUTION. — It is necessary to repeat, and the special attention of the mariner is drawn to the fact, that the present visible end of the breakwater terminates so abruptly as to resemble a finished end. Vessels unaware of the destruction that has taken place, and rounding the breakwater without paying strict attention to the marks and directions given, run the risk of almost certain destruction on the submerged portion, which extends 642 yards beyond the present visible end. The strength of the west-going tide, especially at springs, also sets directly on to the submerged end for about 9 hours out of 12, which is an additional reason for the closest attention being given to the leading marks. It need scarcely be added that a vessel should be always ready for anchoring promptly in case of necessity. See also Tidal streams, page 344. When the eastern stream is running, the submerged end of the breakwater may be safely passed by keeping the beacon on King's battery wall on with the beacon on Hornet des Pies. By night, on account of the strength of the tides in this neigh bourhood, no vessel should attempt ito enter unless in charge of a pilot or of some person with good local .knowledge. The leading mark is, the harbour red lights in line bearing S.W. £ W. ; run in on this line, making careful allowance for the set of the tide. From the northward and westward, do not bring the Casquets light northward of West until the harbour lights are in line, and, on approaching the harbour, be very particular to have them exactly in line before shutting in the Casquets light with Burhou island, when a vessel will be close up to the submerged end of the breakwater. Near high or low water, springs, the stream sets across the entrance of the harbour with great velocity, and great caution is then necessary in entering. To ensure avoiding the rocky patches outside the Aiguillons on the one side, and the toe of the breakwater on the other, the bearing of the upper light should on no account be altered more than a quarter of a point on either side, and the lower light never lost sight of. If not desirous of using the Government moorings, anchor in about 5 fathoms, with the high light open northward of the low one. DANGERS N.W. and NORTH of ALDERNEY.— The outer dangers in these directions have been included in the description of the Swinge channel, see page 325, &c, those nearer the shore are the following : — The Etacs, the most remarkable of all the rocks near the western end of the island, with itheir off-lying shoals, form the southern

Chap. VII.] DANGERS N.W. AND NORTH OP ALDERNEY. 335 boundary of the Swinge channel. They consist of a group of four ; the highest is 128 feet above high water ; the centre of the group is 2 cables from the shore off the western end of Alderney. The Boues des Etacs extend W.N.W. 1| cables from the outer Etac ; their north-western head has only one foot water. The eastern end of the outer Noire Pute on with the western end of the Coupe leads half a cable westward of them ; and, the northern or low part of Tourgis fort on with the southern part of Clonque fort leads the same distance northward. The Clonques are three high rocks attached to the western shore of Alderney by a rocky ridge uncovered at low water ; on this ridge, there has been constructed a roadway to communicate with Clonque fort, which fort stands on the two rocks nearest the land. A wooden beacon stands in the rear of the fort, on the south-eastern head of the Clonque. Platte Boue, Founiais, and Ozard Rock, are off the Clonques on about a W. \ S. line of bearing from the fort ; the Platte Boue is close to the main reef ; the Founiais, which dries 6 feet, nearly 2 cables from the fort ; and, Ozard Rock, on which there are 4 feet water, nearly 3 cables from it. Ozard Rock is very small ; from it, the western end of the great Noire Pute just open eastward and clear of the inner rock of the Etacs bears S. £ E. ; and, Tourgis beacon on with the northern tangent of Clonque fort E. £ N. Querouelles Rocks. — The outer edge of this reef bears N.N.W. 4 W. 2\ cables from Clonques fort, and is nearly 2 cables southward of the Barsier reef, already described, with from 4 to 8 fathoms water between them. The Querouelles dry 8 feet at low water, springs. Caution. — There is no safe passage inside the Querouelles and Barsier reefs, even for boats, and the first of the flood sets right on them ; at this time, therefore, a wide berth should be given them in passing. The Grosse, a large and prominent rock 14 feet above high water, springs, is steep-to and may be approached within half a cable. It lies E. S. 4 cables from the Corbet ; and, North 2 cables from Tourgis point. The Jumelles are two small ridges of rock which uncover at half tide East 8 cables from the Corbet, and 3 cables from the shore of Platte Saline bay.

VII. 336 Braye Rocks are a group of four heads, of which the outermost seldom covers though awash at high water, springs ; the three others, named the Follets, show at half tide. The outer Braye lies N.E. \ E. 2£ cables from the outer angle of Grosnez fort and a cable from the breakwater. A rock with only Z\ feet water lies E.N.E. one third of a cable from the outer Braye. DANGERS N.E. OF ALDERNEY.— The principal dangers on the north-eastern side of Alderney besides the sunken rocks north-eastward of the Aiguillons, included in the description of Alderney harbour, see page 332, are the Grois, the Platte, the Ledge, and the Sauquet. Grois Ledge is an extensive and dangerous reef off Etoc point ; it extends 2^ cables between the bearings N. by E. and N.E. from the tower of the fort on that point, which fort should not be approached on these bearings within half a mile. The outer Grois, a peaked rock, and the highest of the reef, is awash at high water, springs, and bears N by E. \ E. easterly 2\ cables from the flagstaff of the fort. Several heads show at half tide and many more at low water. The stream rushes over this reef with great velocity. The depth is 13^ feet 1\ cables W.N.W. of the outer Grois, and the Boues briees, awash at low water, are half a cable eastward of the Grois ledge. The Ortac rock and Noir Houmet in line and well open of the breakwater W. £ N. leads half a cable outside the ledge. Platte Rock, S.E. £ E. easterly 3| cables from the outer Grois. uncovers 4 feet. From it, the Ortac just open northward of Etoc point bears W. by N. ; and, the Bon-Ami, the high rock on the eastern side of Corblets bay, on with old Corblets barracks S.W. 4 S. southerly. The ground between the Platte and the outer extreme of the Grois reef is foul and should not be approached by any vessel. The Ledge, or Fosse de la Bande, is a reef of considerable extent, with 13 feet water. It bears E. by S. two thirds of a mile from the outer Grois rock, with that rock on with the Ortac W. £ N. northerly ; and, the Honore, a high conical shore rock at the western end of the Mannez quarries, on with the small round tower of the barracks on Essex hill. The long western mark to clear the dangers off the north-eastern shore of Alderney is, the Casquet towers open northward of Burhou island W. by N.

OF ALDERNEY. 337 Sauquet Rock, 2 cables southward of the Ledge and 1^ cables north-eastward of Homeaux Florains reef, on which is a small fort, uncovers 3 feet at low water, springs, with the tower of Etoc fort on with the Ortac rock W. by N. Great Nannel on with Grois rock W.N.W. leads just northward of it. The outer Grois rock and the north-eastern point of Burhou island in line lead between the Ledge and the Sauquet. The south-western stream running down towards Alderney divides in the vicinity of the Sauquet rock, one part running through the Race of Alderney, the other through the Swinge ; its tendency is to throw vessels near the Sauquet rock right on it. A berth should therefore be given it of 3 or 4 cables. DANGERS E. and S.E. of ALDERNEY.— The principal dangers off the eastern side of the island are the Brinchetaie ledge, the Boufresses, and the Blanchard ; and, south-eastward of port Longy, the Race and Inner Race rocks and other rocky patches. The Brinchetaie is a dangerous group of rocks forming a ledge extending south-eastward from Houmet Herbe, off the eastern point of Alderney. The outer tidal rock is 3 cables from the shore and uncovers 11 feet ; the inner rock uncovers 16 feet. Several shoals, awash at low water, equinoctial springs, extend south-eastward of these rocks as far as one third of a mile from the coast. Raz island flagstaff on with the southern extreme of Essex castle ; or, the high Noire Pute, inner Coque Lihou, and southern side of the Etac de la Quoire in line bearing W. by S., leads southward of the Brinchetaie ; and, the outer part of Quenard fort on with the inner part of Homeaux Florains fort leads eastward. Boufresses Reef is nearly 4 cables westward of the Brinchetaie and closer in-shore, its outer end being 1£ cables eastward of Raz island fort ; it uncovers to a considerable extent at low water. Raz island flagstaff on with the middle of Essex castle leads southward. Blanchard Bank is composed of rock, gravel, granite stones, and shells. At its western extreme, which bears E. by S. 6 cables from Houmet Herbe fort, there is a mass of rock with only 2£ fathoms water ; from thence, the bank extends 2 cables, in the same direction, to the Blanchard rock with only 12 feet water, which lies at the eastern edge of the bank, nearly three quarters ot a mile from Houmet Herbe. Between its western end and the rocks nearer the shore off the eastern end of the island, there are from 9 to A. 2771. Wt. 17197. Y

The Blanchard is very dangerous, especially at its eastern extreme, which rises quite suddenly from soundings of 20 and 25 fathoms, causing, during springs, eddies and a heavy sea on a weather tide. Race and Inner Race Rocks.— Three unconnected rocky patches lie south-eastward of Longy bay, stretching off from the tails of the Brinchetaie and Blanchard at the several distances of half a mile, 9 cables, and 1£ miles from the latter. On the Race and Inner Race rocks, the two outermost, there are only 18 feet water, and 4i fathoms on the patch nearest the Blanchard, which bears no special name. From the Race rock, the old telegraph tower is three times its own length open southward of the Etac de la Quoire ; and, Doyle's column, Guernsey, is nearly on with the Grande Amfroque, a very distant mark only to be distinguished in the clearest weather. From the Inner Race rock, St. Anne's mill is twice its own length open southward of the Rousset rock ; and, from the northern patch, St. Anne's mill is on with the southern angle of Essex fort. Clearing Marks. — To pass southward of the Brinchetaie, Boufresses, and Blanchard rock, and northward of the Race and Inner Race rocks and of the 4^-fathoms rocky patch, keep the high Noire Pute, inner Coque Lihou, and base of the Etac de la Quoire in line W. by S. To pass northward of the Blanchard, the mark is, Grois rock on with the Great Nannel W.N.W.; or, if near high water when the Grois rock is not easily distinguished, the north-eastern extreme of Chateau de l'Etoc just open northward of the Homeaux Florains. Doyle's column just open northward of the northernmost bluff land on Herm S.W. by W. £ W. leads well southward of all these rocks, as does also cape de la Hague lighthouse not brought southward of East, or the Casquets lighthouse kept in sight southward of Alderney. SOUTH COAST OF ALDERNEY. — Longy Bay, or Baie du Catel, is on the south-eastern side of Alderney and dries at low water, neaps ; it affords but little shelter except to small coasting vessels capable of taking the ground, and, since the con struction of Alderney harbour, is but seldom used. The entrance is between Raz island, on which there is a fort, and the Queslingue rock. The distance between these points is less than 2 cables, and this small space is divided into two entrances of equal width by a rock in the centre, which dries 2 feet ; moreover, both tides set

Chap. VII.] 339 SOUTH COAST OP ALDERNEY. violently across the entrance of the bay, therefore no stranger should attempt to enter it unless compelled to do so, when the following directions should be observed. Directions. — The best time to enter Longy bay is with the wind between N.W. and S.W., and between 2 and 5 hours ebb ; a vessel may then run aground, and on the succeeding tide she may be hauled up under Essex nunnery on the sandy beach at the western side of the bay. The leading mark in with these winds is, the Nunnery just shut in by the land westward of Queslingue rock N. \ E. until near the rock, and then by rounding its rocky point within half a cable, the fairway sunken rock in the entrance is avoided. Longy road off Longy bay affords good shelter from northerly and north-westerly winds in from 10 to 14 fathoms, sand, gravel, and shells. Anchor with the whole of Fort Albert just shut in with, and seen over, the western point of Longy bay N. by W. \ W.; and, the Grande Folie rocky peak just open eastward of Raz island fort N.E. \ N. This berth is in about 9 fathoms, 1\ cables from the shore. A better anchorage and more out of the tide may be found off the middle of Tchue bay, just westward of the Rousset rock ; anchor here in 7 or 8 fathoms H cables westward of the Rousset, with the western side of Raz fort touching the eastern side of Queslingue rock. The Roque Pendante is a remarkable overhanging rock on the summit of the bluff, within the Rousset rock, and south-westward of Essex castle ; it may be seen from a distance of 9 or 10 miles on an easterly or westerly bearing, but on altering the bearing on either side it soon shuts in with the island and can only be distinguished from a very short distance. Queslingue and Rousset rocks are high and peaked ; they are within 2 cables East and West of each other and close to the shore. The Etac de la Quoire is about off the middle of the southern coast of the island, at half a cable only from the shore and connected with it at low water. It is a conical rock, about 60 yards in diameter and 106 feet above high water, or 10 feet lower than the Great Coque Lihou. Bonit Rock bears S. by W. h W. westerly 44 cables from the Etac de la Quoire. This dangerous rock is of small extent and Y 2

The marks for it are, the Grande Folie eastward of Longy seen between the Rousset and Queslingue rocks N.E. £ E. ; and, the Etac de la Quoire on with a beacon on the adjoining shore N. by E. \ E. ; the latter mark leading rather on the eastern side of the rock. The Bonit may be avoided by not approaching Alderney nearer than a mile, by keeping the Casquets in sight southward of the island, or by keeping the inner Noire Pute open southward of the outer Coque Lihou. Noire Roque, which is 15 feet above high water, bears N.W. 4. N. 34. cables from the Bonit and is 2 cables from the nearest shore ; it is exactly in line between the Etac de la Quoire and the great Coque Lihou ; it is steep-to all round, but has a 4-feet patch only a cable distant north-eastward, between it and the land. Alderney South Banks extend from the Bonit rock in a south-westerly direction more than 1^ miles ; the general depth on the main bank is 15 fathoms, gravel, from which as a base there arise seven small sand-banks, one with as little as 6 fathoms water. These small banks have sharp ridges, which lie in a N.E. and S.W. direction ; the largest is less than a quarter of a mile long. The shallow spots commence nearly 6 cables S.S.W. £ W. from the Bonit. A vessel from the eastward may pass inside them by keeping the Coupe rock a little open southward of the outer Coque Lihou, until the Grande Folie opens westward of Queslingue rock ; and, outside, by keeping the Verte-tete rock open westward of the outer Noire Pute N. by W. \ W. westerly, until Grande Folie is on with Raz island fort N.E. \ N. northerly. By night, the Casquets light N.W. \ N. leads one mile south westward of Alderney South banks, and half a mile on the same side of the Pierre au Vraic. Cape de la Hague light kept bearing north ward of East also leads southward of Alderney South bank. Some of the heaviest overfalls in the Race are caused by these banks, which must therefore be avoided in bad weather. Coque Lihou Rocks are off the south-western end of Alderney, nearly a mile westward of the Etac de la Quoire, and a quarter of a mile from the shore. They consist of a group of three. The Great Coque Lihou, the middle and easternmost, is much larger and higher than either of the others, being 116 feet above high water ; it bears S.S.E. -\ E. 6 cables from Alderney old telegraph tower. A bank of sand, extending 2£ cables eastward from the Great Coque Lihou, has on

Chap. VII.] DANGERS OFF SOUTH COAST OF ALDERNEY. 341 it as little as 1^ fathoms. It makes a convenient anchorage for fishing boats and small craft in fine weather. There is a 5-fathoms channel inside the Coque Lihou rocks close to the Alderney shore ; it is only a cable wide and therefore not to be attempted by a stranger. Rocks awash at low water extend from the Coque Lihou rocks more than half way across to the Alderney shore ; and, a continuous sunken chain unites them to the Joyeux rocks, a scattered group extending W.N.W. about half a mile from the Coque Lihou rocks and north-eastward from the Noires Putes. The Noires Putes are a group of rocks, four in number, three of which are always uncovered ; the two outer rocks are much larger and higher than the others ; these lie East and West from each other and are rather more than a cable apart. The western rock is flat topped, and 55 feet above high water ; the eastern rock has a peak near its eastern end 76 feet high ; it is known as the Great Noire Pute, and bears S-W. by S. three quarters of a mile from the old telegraph tower. The group is quite steep-to on the outside. The Aiguillons, Coupe, and Orbouee, three rocks respectively 18, 22, and 6 feet above high water, lie between the Noires Putes and the Etacs, in a W.S.W. direction from each other, and half a mile from the south-western extreme of Alderney ; they form the southern boundary of the Fossee Malieres or West bay anchorage. The Coupe, the middle of the three, is sometimes called the Cocked hat, which it somewhat resembles in appearance ; it is one of the marks for the Pierre au Vraic. The Orbouee, the outer rock of the group, is awash at high spring tides ; it is connected with the Coupe under water, is steep-to on the southern and western sides, but has a rock with only 2 fathoms water one cable N.W. by N. from it. Orbouee Bank, extending S. by W. rather more than half a mile from Orbouee rock, consists of gravel, sand, and broken shells ; its general depths are 8 and 9 fathoms, but near its outer end there are only 3£ fathoms. This part rises from the main bank in a narrow ridge of fine sand, very difficult to pick up, and thrown up apparently by the turning of the stream. From the shoalest spot, the Great Nannel is a little open westward of the outer rock of the Etacs ; and the Etac de la Quoire is on with the northern part of the outer Noire Pute. The bank may be cleared by keeping the Pierres de But open westward of the Etacs N. by E. E. easterly until the Etac de la Quoire opens south-eastward of the Noires Putes E. by N. £ N.

VII. 342 Anchorage.— West bay.— The best anchorage at the western end of Alderney is in the Fossee Malieres or West bay ; anchor here in 9 or 10 fathoms, gravel, with the Great Nannel or with the Refuge on Burhou island touching the outer end of the Western Etac ; and, Great Coque Lihou open clear inside the Aiguillons S.E. by E. £ E., or the Great Noire Pute appearing midway between the Coupe and the Aiguillons. Here a vessel will lie out of the tide. There is anchorage also a quarter of a mile outside the Orbouee rock in 7 fathoms on a S.S.W. bearing from the rock, but it is exposed to the full force of the flood stream and therefore not safe. Tidal Streams.— The tidal stream round Alderney is subject to changes and variations very similar in character to those round Guernsey and Jersey, but with local peculiarities, arising principally from the more prominent position of Alderney on the edge of the true Channel stream, and also, in a great degree, from the different form of the island itself as compared with the others. At Alderney, as well as round Guernsey, the direction of the tidal stream revolves from East round by North to West and South, running from every pioint of the compass during one whole tide, an ebb and a flood. As at Guernsey, the stream attains its greatest strength about high and low water by the shore, but, as might be expected from the situation of Alderney, its direction at this time is different, coinciding more nearly with the Channel stream. Thus the strength of the stream, flood and ebb, on the northern side of Alderney and the Casquets, runs about E. i N. and W. \ S. ; whilst round the Guernsey group, at the same time, its general direction is about E.N.E. and W.S.W. This change in direction may be considered as taking place on a line passing close northward of the Casquets, past the Nannels, north ward of Alderney and of cape de la Hague. A glance at the chart best illustrates how the north-eastern stream, after passing through the Race, Swinge, and Ortac channels, is turned in an easterly direction in uniting with the Channel flood stream ; also how, on the south-western stream, the Channel ebb stream running in a westerly direction past cape de la Hague, Alderney, and the Casquets, is deflected through the channels between these places in a more southerly direction. This description, however, only applies to the periods of high and low water; in its transition from one to the other, peculiarities occur requiring a more particular description. The North-eastern stream begins to make through the Race and Swinge channels when the tide has risen three hours, and it attains its greatest strength, 7 to 8 knots, about the time of high water by the

Chap, vii.] TIDAL STREAMS ROUND ALDERNEY. 343 shore. An hour after high water, the stream, in the course of its rotary change of direction, is setting about N.E. by E. and begins to abate in strength, still veering in direction and slacking in strength ; at 3 hours after high water, it sets faintly to the N.W., causing a short slack in the Swinge, and also on the north-western side of Burhou, after which the south-western stream comes down and rushes through these channels with a velocity nearly as great as the flood or north eastern stream. After low water by the shore, the tide begins to veer to the southward and abate in strength ; an hour and a half after low water, the stream is setting from the northward on Alderney and Burhou, causing extensive slacks or eddies southward of these islands ; and, at half flood, the offing stream, now very weak, sets south-eastward, causing a dead slack for a short time in all the channels between Alderney and the Casquets. Having thus described the general course of the main tidal stream round Alderney, it is necessary to describe some of the most im portant eddies caused by the peculiar turning of the streams and the obstruction offered by islands and rocks. Alderney, the Casquets, and intermediate rocks, all narrow in propor tion to their length and each lying on a line of direction nearly East and West, are in the line of both tidal streams when at their strength ; therefore, at these times, the resistance they offer to the free course of the stream is small and the eddies under them insignificant ; but, as the stream in its rotary change of direction moves out of this line, extensive eddies or in-shore streams are formed under the lee of Alderney, alternately on its northern and southern shores. On the northern shore of Alderney, the in-shore stream commences at the Sauquet rock and extends -westward as far as the Corbet rock, and within that rock southward of the main channel of the Swinge, running 9 hours westward and only three eastward, the western stream commencing an hour before high water and the eastern stream at 2 hours flood. Along the southern side of the island, between Orbouee rock and Raz island, there are 9 hours of eastern and but 3 hours of western in-shore stream ; the eastern stream commences one hour before low water, and runs along the land towards Longy and beyond it during the whole flood and until 2 hours ebb. In the neighbourhood of Longy, meeting with the south-western stream of the Race, it suddenly veers and unites with it ; the western stream commences at 2 hours ebb and sets towards the Orbouee for 3 hours, or until 5 hours ebb, at which time it joins the south-western stream from the Swinge. The general courses and action of these two great eddies or in-

CHANNEL ISLANDS.— CASQUETS, ALDERNEY, &C. [Chap. VII. 344 shore streams are exactly the reverse of each other. They may be easily understood by reference to a chart of Alderney and by careful perusal of the foregoing remarks ; but, as the northern eddy sets across the entrance of Alderney harbour, at times with great velocity, and then constitutes the principal danger in entering that harbour, a more particular description of its action will now be given. The direction of the eastern stream half an hour before high water, about which time it attains its greatest strength, is about East ; this being the line of direction of Alderney, it runs full on the western point of the island by which the stream is now fairly divided, one part rushing through the Race along the southern side of the island between 7 and 8 knots, the other through the Swinge at about the same rate, leaving a small eddy previously noticed under the eastern end of the island near the Sauquet rock. At high water by the shore, the turning of the offing stream from an easterly to a northerly direction relieves the pressure of the Swinge stream from the end of the breakwater ; and, at this time during a spring tide, the Swinge stream is running eastward at the rate of 3 knots 120 yards outside the breakwater, the intermediate space being occupied by the stream setting westward round the breakwater, also at the rate of 3 knots. This latter is the in-shore stream or eddy ; it commences in the eddy near the Sauquet rock, and begins to set westward, as before stated, an hour before high water. At this time, the western stream sets round the end of the breakwater, in volume a mere thread, but it gradually increases in magnitude as the turning of the offing stream removes the pressure of the Swinge stream from the breakwater. The most dangerous time in dealing with this tide and eddy is at about high water, when they set past each other, separated by only a few feet, at the rate just given ; great caution must therefore be used in taking a long vessel into harbour at this time. The breakwater obstructing the course of the western stream is the cause of the danger, and the stream is, of course, strongest near the outer end of that structure ; therefore, at high water, it is advisable to enter the harbour a little southward of the mid-channel course rather than risk a too near approach to the breakwater end. An hour after high water, the inner edge of the east-going Swinge stream is removed to the distance of 2 cables from the breakwater end, and both streams beginning to abate in strength, the danger gradually ceases.* * The destruction of the outer end of the breakwater in some degree modifies the conditions affecting this stream and eddy. To the mariner it should give rise to additional caution, in order to avoid being caught by the eddy on the port bow and set on to the submerged portion of the breakwater.

VII.] TIDAL STREAMS. — BANC DE LA SCHOLE. 345 At 2 hours ebb, the Swinge stream, now slacking fast and veering westward, sets on the Nannels ; the western stream running past the end of the breakwater at the rate of three knots, meeting the eastern stream in the Swinge a little outside the Corbet rock, unites with it and both set towards the Nannels. Within the Corbet rock, the western stream sets down in-shore to the western end of the island. At half ebb by the shore, the offing tide is setting faintly north westward and there is slack water in the Swinge, but only for a few minutes, after which the westerly stream makes through the Swinge and immediately commences to run past the breakwater end with renewed strength until low water by the shore, gradually slacking as the offing stream veers from W. S. to the southward. Whilst the direction of the stream is veering through the latter section of its course, there is slack water at the entrance of Alderney harbour ; after a short interval, at 2 hours after low water, the stream sets across the end of the breakwater in an E.S.E. direction. BANC DE LA SCHOLE, 7 miles S.S.W. from Alderney, lies nearly in the direct line between the Great Russell channel and the Race of Alderney. Like most other banks between the Channel islands, it consists of a mixture of fine gravel, sand, and shells ; it is very steep-to on the southern and western sides but shoals gradually on the north-eastern side. Within the 5-fathoms line, it is 1^ miles long N. by E. and S. by W. and one third of a mile wide at its greatest width near the middle, tapering off to a mere ridge at the extremes. The 10-fathoms line includes a space 24, miles long N.N.E. and S.S.W. and three quarters of a mile wide, whilst the 20-fathoms line includes a length of 5 miles by 1^ miles. The top of the bank is very narrow and consists of small semi-circular ridges of sand convex to the S.W., over which the general depth is 3 fathoms at the lowest spring tides ; near the middle of the bank, however, as little as 2 fathoms has been found, with some spots close by of 2\ fathoms. St. Martin's point, Guernsey, appearing midway between the Grande Fauconniere rock and the south-western end of Herm island, points to the shoalest spot. The soundings taken on this bank at different times tend to show that its higher parts are continually varying in altitude ; it is probable, therefore, that, within a limited space, it also shifts its position as influenced by tide, weather, &c. The position of the shoalest spot on the bank did not alter perceptibly, however, from 1861 to 1869 ; the marks for it are — Alderney old telegraph tower N. by E. £ E.

Clearing Marks. — Doyle's column, Guernsey, on with the Grande Fauconniere rock W. by S., the Etac de Serk open eastward of the Burons, or cape de la Hague lighthouse N.E. by E. \ E., leads south-eastward and southward of the bank. Doyle's column on with or just open northward of the northernmost bluff land on Herm S. W. by W £ W.,the Gouliot pass open westward of the Bee du Nez, Serk, or cape de la Hague lighthouse E. by N., leads north-westward and northward ; and, the whole of Burhou shut in behind the Etacs and Noires Putes N. £ W. leads along the eastern side of the bank at the distance of about 2 miles. It must, however, be borne in mind that these marks are all distant and can only be made out in fine clear weather. Between low water and half flood, it is advisable to pass eastward of the Bane de la Schole ; but, between half ebb and low water, westward, because in both cases the tide favours the attempt. In bad weather, if the wind and tide are ever so obliquely opposed to each other, the sea breaks very dangerously on all parts of the bank. The RACE Of ALDERNEY is the strait between Alderney and cape de la Hague, deriving its name from the violence of the tidal streams through the strait. Here, as in the Swinge and Ortac channels, the stream sets south-westward at half ebb by the shore' and runs in that direction, with the variations presently given, for 6 hours, or until half flood; and, the contrary is the case with the north eastern stream, for there is but little slack water in the Race. The greatest strength of the south-western stream lasts for about 2\ hours ; it begins 5 hours after high water at Alderney and ends 4| hours before the following high water. The greatest strength of the north-eastern stream continues about 2 hours ; that is, from one hour before high water at Alderney until one hour after. During equinoctial springs, the velocity of the south-western stream is nearly 7 knots, and of the north-eastern stream nearly 8 knots ; at neaps, 5J knots. The first 2£ hours of the south-western stream in the Race, from half ebb to low water, sets W.S.W. ; and, the last 2 hours, from low water to half flood, S.W.; and, the contrary for the first and last 'h\ hours of the north-eastern stream, which, between half flood and high water, sets very strongly round cape de la Hague. There are therefore 5± hours south-western and 6^ hours north eastern stream, that is, half an hour's difference between the Race tide and that in the Ortac and Swinge channels.

Chap, vii.] 347 ALDERNEY RACE. — DIRECTIONS. In boisterous weather, if the wind and stream are ever so obliquely opposed, the sea breaks in all parts of the Race, as if it were over small knolls or patches, which makes it difficult and often dangerous for small vessels to pass through ; at such times, there are heavy overfalls over all the sunken rocks and banks, all of which must of course be carefully avoided. DANGERS in the RACE.— The Race rock, Inner Race rock, and Blanchard, described at pages 337, 338, have respectively 18, 18, and 12 feet water. There is a rocky 13-fathoms bank W. j S. 3 miles from cape de la Hague lighthouse, which, although not dangerous, throws up a strong overfall, and should be avoided. The fairway of the Race lies between this bank and the Race rock ; the distance between is 3£ miles ; the soundings in this, the narrowest part of the Race, are regular, between 22 and 24 fathoms, and the bottom rocky throughout. Middle Rock, or Milieu, an isolated head with 7 fathoms water lies S.S.E. £ E. 4£ miles from Alderney old telegraph tower ; from it, the Casquets bear N.W. \ W. 9i miles ; and, cape de la Hague lighthouse E. by N. %\ miles. When the tide is running strongly, the position of this rock is marked by a breaker or overfall, and there is at all times a ripple over it. The clearing marks given on the preceding page for the Bane de la Schole also clear the Milieu, and it may be easily avoided by attending to the directions given for passing through the Race. Another patch of 9 fathoms lies 2 miles S.W. by S. from the Middle rock, between it and the Bane de la Schole. DIRECTIONS. — When running through the Race of Alderney from the northward, if bound for the Deronte or Russell channels, it is at all times best to take the fairway of the channel described, bearing in mind that the north-eastern stream between half flood and high water by the shore sets very strongly round cape de la Hague, off which there project many sunken rocks, see page 184, 185 &c. Vessels bound for Granville, or other ports on the French shore in the Cotentin channel, round cape de la Hague more closely, clearing its rocks and shoals by the marks given at the pages referred to. The direct course from the Race to the Little Russell channel is about W.S.W.; and, from the Casquets, about S.S.W. \ W. There fore, if bound from"either the Race or Casquets to the Little Russell, between low water and half flood, or between high water and half ebb, allowance must be made for the stream, which obliquely crosses

CHANNEL ISLANDS.— CASQUETS, ALDERNEY, &C. [Chap. VII. 348 the courses during these periods, and great care must be taken to avoid the Middle rock and the Bane de la Schole. From the South-westward.— To pass outside Alderney South banks, in approaching the Race from the south-westward and passing along the southern coast of Alderney, keep the Verte-tete rock open of the Noires Putes rocks N. by W. i W. westerly until the Grande Folie comes on with Raz island fort ; or, pass inside the banks by the marks given at page 340. After passing the Bonit rock, bring the high Noire Pute on with the Great Coque Lihou, which mark leads midway between the Inner Race and Blanchard rocks. When Fort Albert comes on with the Grande Folie, the high Noire Pute may be brought on with the Etac de la Quoire, and so kept until Etoc fort flagstaff opens northward of the fort on the Homeaux Florains, to clear the Blanchard, after which steer as required out into the Channel ; or, if bound for Alderney harbour, steer North until the Outer Grois rock is on with the Great Nannel W.N.W. to clear the Sauquet rock ; after which, steer about N.W. by N. until the Ortac rock is on with the southern extreme of Burhou W. N., which will be the leading mark until the marks for the harbour come on, when a vessel may haul in for the harbour by the directions given at page 333. By Night. — The Casquets light N.W. i N. leads a mile south westward of Alderney South banks, and cape de la Hague light kept bearing northward of East clears them on the southern side ; therefore, run for cape de la Hague light bearing about E. 4/ N. until the eastern end of Alderney bears N.N.W. £ W. to clear the Race rock, after which, steer north-eastward through the Race and out into the Channel ; or, if bound for Alderney harbour, steer N.E. by N., and when cape de la Hague light bears S.E. by E. E., or when the Casquets light opens northward of Alderney, steer more northerly, according to circumstances, to bring Alderney harbour red lights in line S.W. £ W., when proceed as directed at page 334, bearing in mind that the Casquets light on with, or kept opening and shutting in with, the eastern end of Burhou island leads just 2 cables northward of the Grois and of the Ledge.

VIII. by keeping one or two miles northward of the two windmills on Alderney in line, because it is nearly in that direction that the separation of the west-going Channel stream takes place, one part running towards the Race and the other passing northward of Alderney. In clear weather, these windmills may be seen from the masthead from abreast of St. Martin's bay. If overtaken by a calm, vessels should anchor if within 7 or 8 miles of the land. Pilots recommend a position in about 20 fathoms water, a little northward or north-eastward of the Mermistin rock, which rock is about a mile from the shore between Omonville and Querqueville point. Fosse de la Hague. — The soundings round cape de la Hague are very irregular, and the violent eddies in its vicinity during the north-eastern stream are caused by the great mass of water flowing over the rugged uneven bottom towards and round the cape. At three miles W. by N. N. from cape de la Hague lighthouse, com mences the western part of the Fosse de la Hague, which, from thence, trends E. \ N. nearly 8 miles, its central part curving northward away from the cape and terminating 34, miles from the coast on the meridian of the eastern part of St. Martin's bay. The soundings throughout the whole extent of this deep are from 36 to 58 fathoms, its extreme width is less than a mile, and there are about 30 fathoms round it. The COAST. — The Cotentin peninsula, of which cape de la Hague is the north-western and cape Barfleur the north-eastern extreme, forms the narrowest part of the English Channel until the Straits of Dover are approached ; the Bill of Portland bearing N. \ W. westerly, only 51 miles, and St. Catherine point, Isle of Wight, N.E. northerly 57 miles from cape de la Hague. The coast of France, after trending almost due North from the eastern shore of the Baie de Mont St. Michel, here makes an abrupt turn eastward, cape Barfleur bearing from cape de la Hague E.S.E. 27 miles, the coast between the two capes receding still more to the southward ; and, nearly midway between them, is the important naval station and arsenal of Cherbourg. The aspect of this line of coast, viewed from the northward, is that of a moderately elevated table-land, presenting an appearance of high cultivation. As the shore is neared, Cherbourg breakwater and forts are seen, and cape de la Hague itself then appears, low and sandy, though the land becomes high close at hand. This is also the case eastward of Cherbourg, and especially between cape Levi and cape Barfleur,

Chap. VIII.] 351 THE COAST. — ANSE DE ST. MARTIN. where the shore is low and sandy, though the adjacent high lands are close at the back, thus giving a generally rocky and precipitous appearance to the coast when viewed from the offing. Basse du Houffet and Le Fliart.— From the Houffet rocks, about one mile eastward of Cape de la Hague, to the western point of St. Martin's bay, the coast is bordered by irregular rocks which uncover at low water, and off it are many shallow patches. The Basse du Houffet, the farthest out, is dangerous only on account of the high sea on it occasioned by the eddies ; it lies E. by S. h S. 6 cables from the Houffet rocks and has 5^ fathoms water over it. The Fliart, nearly a mile south-eastward of the Houffet rocks, and N.N.W. 2 cables from the Herbeuses, at the entrance of St. Martin's bay, is the principal rock of those which uncover along this part of the coast, its summit drying 11 feet above the level of the lowest tides. Shoal patches extend E. by N. 3 cables from the Fliart, and upon their outer extreme there are only 6 feet water. Buoy. — A red buoy is moored on the outer extreme of the Fliart shoal patches. ANSE de St. MARTIN.— This bay is 2 miles eastward of cape de la Hague, and is bounded on the eastern side by the high rocks of Martiauroc and Esquina, and on the western side by the Herbeuses. It is open to winds from N.W. to N.E. which throw in a heavy sea when they blow with any strength, but it is well sheltered from all other winds, especially those from the opposite quarters. The western point of the bay is the termination of a projecting range of hills, on the top of which stands the church of St. Germain de Vaux ; it may be easily known by the Herbeuses rocks, which are a prolongation of the point, as well as by a fort commanding the approach to a tolerably good anchorage E.S.E. and S.E. of the point, where small craft find shelter with the wind from W.N.W. round by West to S.S.E., but where they are greatly exposed if it blows strongly from the north-eastward. The Herbeuses are large rocks rising from 30 to 40 feet above high water, springs, and are joined to the western point of the bay by rocks which uncover and which extend N.N.E. 3 cables in a direct line from that point. The ground is foul round the Herbeuses, and shoal patches with only from one to 3 feet water, lie N.E., E.S.E., and S.S.E., H cables from their northern extreme.

352 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. Buoy. — A red buoy is moored on the N.E. extreme of the patches extending eastward of the Herbeuses. The western shore of the bay is precipitous and bordered by rocks which uncover at low water ; but, in its south-western angle, at the entrance of the valley of St. Germain de Vaux, there is a small beach of pebbles and gravel which covers at the first half hour's flood. A similar beach forms the head of the bay, and half way up the hill behind the beach stands the church and village of St. Martin. The eastern shore is low, but the adjoining land rises gently to the top of a spur of hills running out towards Jardeheu point, separating the rivulet which passes St. Martin from that which empties itself into Omonville harbour. From the middle of the beach at the head of St. Martin's bay to Jardeheu point, the shore is bordered by rocks which dry ; outside these are others in separate groups, of which the most remarkable are the Martiauroc and the Esquina ; the former is covered only at high springs, the latter is one of the largest rocks in the bay and has two heads very near each other, one rising 30 feet above the highest tides. Several ledges, of which some uncover, extend half a mile north-westward of the Martiauroc and form a sort of causeway terminated by the Parmentiere, a rock with only 3 feet water. Buoy. — The Parmentiere rock is marked by a black buoy off its western edge. The opening into the bay is about three quarters of a mile wide between the Herbeuses and the Martiauroc, but the only channel by which vessels can enter and get up to the anchorage under the fort, without a pilot, is barely a quarter of a mile wide, and is between the Parmentiere rock black buoy and the red buoy marking the ledges eastward of the Herbeuses rocks. JARDEHEU POINT is a small round hill covered with herbage and separated from the hills inland by a narrow isthmus which covers at high tides ; upon its summit there is a mass of large rocks, and it may be easily recognised when bearing S.E. or N.W. ; it is surrounded by rocks and shoals which extend 6 cables northward. The largest and most remarkable of these rocks, the Coque, bears East 3 cables from the point and is 3 feet above the highest tides. The Hures de la Coque, a rocky ledge, extends N.N.E. 3 cables from the Coque, at which distance the depth is only 5jj fathoms, and it causes violent eddies which small vessels must be careful to avoid. One of the rocks on this ledge, lying N.N.E. \ E. one cable from the Coque, uncovers 10 feet at the lowest

Vin.] 353 TIDAL STREAMS. tides ; it covers near the time of half flood by the shore, and it may be useful to know that when it covers, the flood or eastern stream is running 2\ or 3 miles from the shore between Omonville and Cherbourg. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on Jardeheu point. Basse Brefort, on which there are only 2\ feet water, lies N. by E. \ E. half a mile from Jardeheu point and the same distance N.W. by N. from the Coque. The marks for this shoal, which is dangerous to coasters, are, the summit of the Esquina rock on with a village half way up the hill westward of Jobourg church tower ; and, the Coque entirely concealing the Foireuse, a large rock lying S.S.E. £ E. from it. TIDAL STREAMS.— The sudden change in the direction of the flood or north-eastern stream after passing cape de la Hague occasions a great eddy north-eastward and eastward of that cape, which extends even beyond Omonville and runs along the coast, following a direction opposed to the stream in the offing for nearly nine hours, that is, from 2\ hours before, to 65 hours after the time of high water by the shore. This eddy begins to form off the entrance of St. Martin's bay about half an hour after the north-eastern stream has commenced in Alderney Race, and its strength increases with that stream ; but, as it runs to the N.W., and, when near the Becchue rock, comes into almost direct opposition to the stream flowing East and E.S.E. out of the Race, it causes a cross sea which is violent in proportion to the rate of that stream. Towards the time of high water in St. Martin's bay, or a quarter of an hour after high water at Goury and a quarter of an hour before it at Omonville, when the stream is at its greatest strength, this confused sea extends nearly 2\ miles from the shore, to the line of Jobourg church tower on with the Herbeuses rocks. The violence of the sea decreases as the north-eastern stream slackens, and totally ends about a quarter of an hour before the south-western stream begins in the Race. A similar cross sea takes place round Jardeheu point from the meeting of the eddy, which runs north-westward along the shore at Omonville, with the stream of flood which comes from W.N.W. between the Esquina rock and the Basse Brefort. This confused sea is also violent and extends into the offing as far as the line of Jalletin guard-house on with cape de la Hague lighthouse. It commences at A. 2771. Wt. 17197. Z

VIII. 354 the same time as that near the Becchue but ends 15 or 20 minutes before high water at Omonville; as soon as it ceases, the counter stream or eddy runs round Jardeheu point and extends without interruption from Omonville to the Houffet rocks. The Foireuse, a rock midway between the Coque rock and Omonville harbour, is close to the outer edge of a rocky flat which runs two cables off the intermediate low shore, and its rounded sum mit is 2 feet above the level of the highest tides. A rocky ledge extends half a mile eastward of the Foireuse, and its eastern extreme, on which there are only 4 fathoms water, rises suddenly from soundings of from 17 to 23 fathoms and lies in the direction of the church tower at Digulleville a quarter of a point open southward of the church tower at Omonville W.S.W. The highest rocks on this ledge uncover 8 feet. OMONVILLE.— This small harbour lies in a slight indenta tion of the coast one mile south-eastward of Jardeheu point and is well sheltered from N.N.W. round by West to S.E. ; but, with strong winds between North and East it is only completely sheltered whilst the rocky ledge which joins the land on its northern side remains uncovered. At neap tides, the highest rocks of this ledge break the waves, and the swell only enters the harbour ; but, during high springs, when all the rocks are covered, there is much sea in it. The position of the harbour may be easily recognised from a distance by the village of Omonville, situated at the bottom of a valley, the slopes of which are highly cultivated ; by a large fort erected on the eastern point of the indentation ; by an old semaphore called the Vigie, on the top of the hill, at the foot of which stands the fort ; and, by a large mass of rock on the summit of the hill bounding the valley on the North. The harbour is only two cables long East and West, and barely a cable wide in the space where vessels may anchor between the rocks. The depths increase gradually from the beach on its western shore to 7 fathoms at the entrance. In the deepest part of the harbour, the soundings vary from 5 to 7 fathoms over a rocky bottom, in the cavities of which are deposits of stiff yellow mud, where anchors hold firmly ; but, as these deposits are of small extent, it is probable that the anchors take hold in the fissures of the rocks. A Life -Boat is stationed at this port. Directions. — When standing for Omonville harbour with light winds from S.W. or S.E., or during calms after half flood, some

Chap. VIII.] OMONVILLE. — QUERQUEVILLE POINT. 355 caution is necessary to avoid missing the entrance. Under such circumstances, a vessel should be in a position south-eastward of the entrance, so as to have the eddy, described at page 353, and which runs 2\ knots at springs, favourable for entering. With all other winds, when they are sufficiently strong to ensure stemming the stream, a vessel may run directly for the entrance, taking care, when rounding the rocky ledge which extends half a mile eastward of the Foireuse rock, to have Digulleville church tower half a point open southward of Omonville church tower. The pilots affirm that it is possible to enter the harbour, whatever may be the state of the sea, if a vessel can carry sufficient sail to ensure good steering. There is no difficulty in leaving except with a strong easterly wind. Tides. — It is high water in Omonville harbour at full and change, at 7h. 29m. ; springs rise 15£ feet ; neaps 12i feet. The Coast from Omonville trends S.E. \ E. easterly 6 miles to Querqueville point. From half a mile south-eastward of Omonville to within three quarters of a mile of Urville church, it is high and precipitous, intersected by deep valleys, and terminates in perpen dicular cliffs of grey rock, with no remarkable object on them except a peak of rock resembling a wall in ruins and named Castel Vendon. Half a mile S.S.E. from Omonville fort, a rocky ledge runs out about a quarter of a mile from the shore, and, with this exception, the coast from Omonville to the eastern end of the cliffs is steep-to at any time of tide, the rocks bordering it not extending more than half a cable from the shore. The Mermistin is a rocky flat lying E.S.E. 2 milesfrom Omonville, and a mile from the cliffs of Castel Vendon ; it is about 3| cables long East and West and 2\ cables broad, with from 6 to 7 fathoms water, and from 10 to 15 fathoms close round it ; from its eastern end, Urville and Nacqueville church towers are in line bearing S. by E. £ E. QUERQUEVILLE POINT. — Three quarters of a mile westward of Urville church, the hills take a south-easterly direction and leave between their last slopes and the shore a low narrow plain which terminates eastward at Querqueville point, distinguished by a heavy fort and a lighthouse. » The shore along this low part of the coast is bordered by a beach of sand, gravel, and rocks, which uncovers at low water, and, in several places, extends as far out as 3 or 4 cables from the land.
