CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. 356 beach is a rocky bank with irregular depths extending nearly a mile from high water mark. Raz de Bannes, the north-western part of this rocky bank, lies between the bearings N. \ W. and N.E. from Urville church tower, and many of its rocks uncover ; the highest dries 44, feet, and, N.W. half a mile from it, at the north-western extreme of the bank, is a small shoal patch of only 5 feet water. A beacon turret is erected on the Raz de Bannes N.W. westerly 3£ miles from the western end of Cherbourg breakwater ; it is 10 feet above high water, springs, is painted red with a white top, and is surmounted by a mast with an iron ball. It is a valuable landmark for vessels approaching Cherbourg from the westward in thick weather. Plateau de Nacqueville, off Nacqueville point, is the north eastern part of the same rocky ledge, and, from its eastern extreme, the western part of the Redoute des Couplets, on the summit of a hill southward of St. Anne's bay, is on with the outer wall of the circular battery of Querqueville fort. Large vessels should avoid crossing the plateau at low water as the tide causes much rippling over it, and there is a small 9-feet patch 3| cables from the shore. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station a short distance westward of Querqueville village and church. A Life-Boat is stationed at Querqueville point. Anchorage. — A vessel, waiting a favourable time to enter Cherbourg road, may anchor between the Plateau de Nacqueville and Querqueville point in 1\ fathoms, good holding ground of muddy sand. The best position is, with the lighthouse in Fort Imperial, Pelee island, on with the lighthouse in Fort Central on Cherbourg breakwater S.E. by E. \ E. easterly ; and, the guard-house at Fort Roule a little southward of the circular battery at Querqueville fort S.S.E. \ E. Tidal Streams. — One cable northward of the Mermistin ledge, which is at the eastern limit of the great eddy described at page 353, the eastern flood stream begins 3h. 45m. before high water at Cherbourg and at first sets 'southward at the rate of one knot ; from 2 to 3 hours before high water at Cherbourg, it runs S.E. with a velocity of from 34, to 4 knots when its direction again changes to the south ward. One hour after high water, it runs S.S.W. but its rate does not

Chap. Vin.] CHERBOURG. 357 exceed a knot, and, as its strength decreases, it assumes a more westerly direction and finally comes to an end about 2 hours after high water at Cherbourg. The direction of the western or ebb stream varies only from West to N.W. from the time of its commencement until 4^ hours after high water at Cherbourg ; but, as its speed decreases, it turns successively to all the points between N.W. and West, where it ends 3h. 45m. before high water. Its greatest velocity, about 3^ knots, occurs from 4 to 5 hours after high water at Cherbourg. At 3 or 4 miles northward of the Mermistin and of Querqueville point, the flood stream begins 3 hours before, and ends about 3 hours after, high water at Cherbourg. Generally speaking, at that distance from the coast, eastward of the Mermistin, and also in the middle of the English Channel, the changes of the tidal streams take place at the times of half flood and half ebb at Cherbourg ; see Tidal stream table, page 383. CHERBOURG.* — Cherbourg is a sea-port town, naval station, extensive arsenal, and fortress of the first class. The popu- lation of Cherbourg proper was 37,013 in 1886, and that of its suburbs about 10,000 more. The town stands at the mouth of the river Divette and has a considerable trade ; its principal exports being butter, eggs, vegetables, and other provisions ; the imports, coals, guano and other manures, wood, &c. Coals, usually Welsh, are always available for steamers, a coal hulk containing about 400 tons being moored in the roads, alongside of which steamers lie to coal, the price being about 20 francs per ton, but varying consider- ably ; the stock in hand on shore is usually from 3,000 to 4,000 tons. Vessels in the Commercial port can also coal alongside the quays in about 12 feet water. Supplies of all kinds are plentiful, and ordi- nary repairs to sailing vessels or steamers can be executed, there being a gridiron and slips available, as well as a dry dock in the Commercial port, but for complicated repairs of machinery this port is not recommended. The dry docks and other appliances of the arsenal are, of course, not generally available for mercantile purposes. There is no sailor's home at Cherbourg, but, in cases of sickness or accident, sailors are admitted to the Civil or Marine hospital, on the recommendation of Her Majesty's Consul, with guarantee of expenses. The number of merchant vessels entering the port in 18 St) was 612, and their aggregate tonnage 224,757 tons. * See Admiralty plan of port de Cherbourg. No. 2.602 ; scale, m = 6 inches.

358 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. Steamers run five times weekly to Southampton, once a week to Guernsey, and the transatlantic steamers call, the Royal Mail from the West Indies fortnightly, and the Hamburgh steamers from New York weekly. The Western railroad brings Paris within 9 hours distance, and connects with Le Mans, Granville, St. Malo, Caen, and by branches with Brest, Havre, Saint Lo, &c. The service of the electric telegraph is very complete from all points served by the railway, and the Semaphore service by the coast is very efficient and enables marine messages sanctioned by the authorities to be rapidly conveyed to almost all points of the coast. Rade de Cherbourg is comprised within the space between Querqueville point and Pelee island, which bears from Querqueville point E. by S. £ S. distant 3£ miles. The roadstead is sheltered on its northern side by the breakwater, and its southern limits are the shores of St. Anne and Cherbourg bays. The area of the sheltered portion, with 3 fathoms depth and upwards, is about 1,650 acres ; with 4 fathoms and upwards, 1,350 acres ; with 5 fathoms and upwards, 900 acres. The shelter afforded by the breakwater to the roadstead is very remarkable and vessels now ride in safety and remain during the winter where formerly they dared not anchor. The Breakwater is a magnificent structure which rises from a depth of from 6 to 7 fathoms at low water, and shelters the road stead from all northerly winds. It consists of a foundation of rubble stone deposited a pier re perdue up to the level of low water, equinoctial springs ; this is 4,060 yards in length and its base about 100 yards wide, having a long foreshore to seaward and its harbour side standing at an angle of 45°. Upon this foundation is built a wall of masonry, nearly vertical, 33 feet wide at the base and decreasing to 27 feet at the top, which, with the parapet, rises 23 feet above the level of high water, springs. The breakwater does not extend in a straight line but has two arms of unequal length, each diverging 5° towards the harbour, the western arm being about one third longer than the eastern. The work was begun in the year 1784, was several times interrupted, but was brought to a successful close in 1853. The chief engineers employed on it were De Cessart, De Lamblardie, Cachin, Fouques-Duparc, Virla, Bonnin, and Reibell, and they have constructed a work of which France may be justly proud. It is defended by Fort Central placed at the point where the arms diverge, by forts at each end,

Chap, viii.] 359 CHERBOURG. named respectively Forts de l'Ouest and de l'Est, and by an inter mediate battery on the western arm.* Buoys. — A large black buoy marks the western extreme of the foundation of the breakwater, and a red buoy its eastern extreme. Pilots. — The Cherbourg pilots usually cruise between the western entrance and point Jardeheu in open boats which cannot keep the sea in bad weather ; they have, however, one decked boat fit to cruise in any weather. A Life-Boat is stationed at the western end of the breakwater. LIGHTS. — The approach to Cherbourg is facilitated at night by the following lights : — Querqueville point. — A fixed white light 59 feet above high water and visible 9 miles, is shown from a white circular tower in Querqueville fort. Fort Central. — A fixed white light with a flash every three minutes and visible at 13 miles, is exhibited, at 66 feet above high water, from a small circular stone tower, painted white, standing in Fort Central on the breakwater ; it bears from Querqueville light E. by S. \ S. southerly 2\ miles. lie Pele"e. — A fixed white light, visible 9 miles, is shown from a circular tower on the north-eastern bastion of Fort Imperial on Pelee island, at 85 feet above high water ; it bears from Fort Central flashing light S.E. by E. 4, E. easterly 14 miles. Breakwater, West end. — A fixed red light, 62 feet high, and visible 8 miles, marks the western head of the breakwater. * The first idea of sheltering Cherbourg bay by an artificial work dates as far back as 1665, but the first real project was in 1775 by M. de la Bretonniere, Capitaine de Vaisseau. In 1781 the proposal of M. de Cessart, engineer, to form a breakwater by sinking frustra of cones filled with stone was adopted, and the first cone was sunk in 1784. After 18 such cones had been sunk this plan was abandoned in 1788, and that of depositing stone a pierre perdue was adopted and followed up with occasional intervals until the breakwater reached above high water, but as in that form it could not withstand the force of the sea, M. Fouques-Duparc proposed, in 1829, a vertical wall of masonry based upon the rubble foundation rising from the level of low water of equinoctial spring tides. Such a wall was begun in 1832 and carried on to completion at the close of 1S53. Since then the forts have been in progress. The whole cost of the breakwater has been 2,671,491?., or at the rate of 220?. a lineal foot, measured from end to end of the foot of the embankment. — Bo/inin, SurV Aeheeement de la Digue de Cherbourg. Paris, 1857.

CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. 360 Breakwater, East end.— A fixed green light, visible 7 miles, 62 feet above high water marks the eastern head of the breakwater. Harbour lights.— A fixed red light is shown at 33 feet above high water, from a stone tower, painted white, standing at the end of the eastern jetty of the port du Commerce, visible about 6 miles ; and, a fixed green light, visible 2 miles, 15 feet above high water, from the head of the western jetty. St. Anne's hay is two miles wide from Querqueville point to Fort du Hornet, and its shore, on which are several batteries, is low and almost entirely bordered by rocks which uncover at low water. Of these, the Rochefort, a large rock at the head of the bay is about 2 cables from high-water mark, and a mile south-eastward of Quer queville fort ; its summit rises 2 feet above the level of the highest tides. The water is not deep in this bay, there being as little as 3£ fathoms in parts half a mile from the shore. Not more than 17 feet will be found at the extreme of a rocky projection extending Z\ cables eastward from the outer wall of the circular battery on Querqueville point, and only 3 feet at 4r| cables south-eastward from the fort, and nearly 4 cables from the shore. Rocky ground, on which there are only 12 feet water, lies E.N.E. half a mile from the Rochefort rock, with the summit of that rock nearly on with Henneville church tower ; and, N.W. westerly 9 cables from Fort du Hornet. This 12-feet patch is much in the way of large vessels beating in or out of Cherbourg road, and should be avoided, at springs, from one third ebb to two thirds flood, and at all times of tide during neaps. A heavy swell is thrown on the beach of this bay when the wind is strong between N.W. and N.E., and it is then dangerous to anchor in it, the bottom being uneven and rocky. Fort Chavagnae stands on a small rocky patch fronting St. Anne's bay, midway between Querqueville fort and the western end of the breakwater ; the patch is about three quarters of a cable long and from 50 to 60 yards wide. The water is deep on the southern side, but shoal for a cable north-eastward of the fort, and the sea breaks heavily with strong gales between N.W. and N.E. ; and, during a weather tide, the sea is much agitated by it ; it is dangerous to approach in calm weather, as the ebb sets directly on it. Cherbourg bay is bounded on its western side by the Tenarde and other rocks off Fort du Hornet, and on its eastern side by

Chap, via.] CHERBOURG. 361 the Flamands rocks and Pelee island. The town of Cherbourg and the port du Commerce occupy the head of the bay, and the establishments of the port Militaire the western side, between the town and Fort du Hornet. The shore is low from the front of the town to the Flamands and is bordered by a sandy strand a quarter of a mile wide at low water, with shallow flats of less than 3 fathoms extending 3 or 4 cables farther out. The low land adjoining the shore of this bay soon rises into high hills, between which are the valleys of Roule and Tourlaville. The entrance to the Roule valley is between two hills of unequal height southward of the floating basin of the port du Commerce ; the eastern hill, Mont Roule, is steep and crowned. by Fort Roule at only three quarters of a mile from the shore, which fort commands all the neighbourhood ; on the top of the western hill is a telegraph. Tourlaville valley is eastward of Roule valley and only separated from it by the range of hills, of which Mont Roule forms the north western extreme. The entrance to this valley is wide but it rapidly narrows farther inland. The T^narde is a rocky ledge with three dangerous heads N.E. 2 cables from Fort du Hornet ; it is one cable long W.N.W. and E.S.E. and half a cable wide ; there are 14 ft. water on the western, 6 ft. on the middle, and 9 ft. on the eastern head. The eastern head is at the eastern extreme of the shoal N.E. £ E. 24 cables from the flagstaff on Fort du Hornet, with Nacqueville church tower on with the smallest tower of Querqueville church bearing W.N.W. ; and, the top* of the group of trees surrounding Fief farm half a mile south-eastward of Fort Roule on with the end of the western jetty of the port du Commerce, S. 4 E. The small church tower at Querqueville kept exactly between the tall spire of that church and the tower of Nacqueville church leads a quarter of a cable northward of the dangerous parts of the Tenarde. There are from 19 to 21 feet of water over rocky bottom between the Tenarde and the shore, but a rocky flat, with a 13-feet patch at its extreme, extends E. \ N. 2 cables from the flagstaff of the fort. Buoy. — A red buoy in 5 fathoms marks the north-eastern extreme of the Tenarde ; it is about one third of a cable out side the eastern shoal head, and N. E. 4 E. easterly 2\ cables from the flagstaff of Fort du Hornet. The Roches des Flamands are close to the eastern shore of the bay and their highest parts uncover at low water. A strong fort,

CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. 362 erected on these rocks is approached from the shore by a causeway and drawbridge. Shoal ground with from 7 to 18 feet water extends 4 cables north-westward from the Fort des Flamands ; and, northward and north-eastward of the rocks, this flat extends still farther from the shore, being separated from the eastern end of the breakwater by only 3 cables. Port d'EchOuage.— On the eastern side of Fort des Flamands is this small harbour, chiefly used by vessels of not more than 300 tons burthen laden with timber for the use of the dockyard. A canal connects it with the Mare de Tourlaville to the eastward, where building timber is stored, and which is 50 acres in extent. The Port du Commerce or Mercantile harbour consists of an Avant-port or outer tidal harbour with the channel leading to it, and a Bassin-a-Flot or wet dock formed by damming and excavating at the mouth of the little river Divette which waters the Roule valley. The bottom of the entrance channel is a mixture of sand, mud, gravel, and shingle, and dries at low water, equinoctial springs ; the channel is between two stone jetties running parallel with each other and 55 yards apart ; the western jetty being only half the length of the eastern jetty, and both marked by the lights described at page 360. The Avant-port admits vessels of about 15 feet draught, at springs, and 9 or 10 feet at neaps. Just within the inner end of the western pier is a repairing slip, with the custom-house adjoining. At 60 yards southward of this slip, a pier has been constructed pro jecting eastward from the western quay, its object being to protect the Avant-port from the swell which sets in with strong north westerly winds. This outer port is surrounded on three sides by quays built of granite, and, within the short pier just described, is 328 yards long in a N.N.E. and S.S.W. direction, 212 yards wide, and dries at low water. Its eastern side, where the old naval arsenal stood is exclusively appropriated to Government vessels, but the southern and western quays, 590 yards in extent, are for the use of merchant vessels. The bottom is hard, and, except in front of the repairing slip and about half way along the western quay, where the bare rock is exposed, it consists of a mixture of sand, gravel, and a little mud. At the foot of the quays, the bottom is level and dries about 7 feet above the level of the lowest tides ; here vessels would lie in safety but for the swell and surf which, though much diminished, still sets in through the channel when the wind

Chap. Vin.] 363 CHERBOURG.— PORT MILITAIRE. blows strongly between West and North, notwithstanding the short pier before described which was built to remedy this evil. Under any circumstances, therefore, vessels should only wait in the outer harbour until there is sufficient water to enter the wet dock. Warping buoys are placed in the centre of the harbour to assist vessels going into the basin, and the shoalest spot over which they have to pass is about 1\ feet above the level of the lowest tides. The Bassin-a-Flot is 440 yards long and 137 yards wide, having an area of 12 acres ; it communicates with the outer harbour by gates 42 feet wide, and the water rises above their sill, which is 15 inches above the level of the lowest tides, 19 to 21 feet at extraordinary springs, 17 to 18| feet at ordinary springs, and about 13 feet at neaps. The gates remain open about an hour and a half, but are closed with a falling tide. There are building and repairing slips at the head of the basin, and a dry dock 224 feet 4 inches in length on the blocks by 46 feet wide at the entrance, and with 19 feet 4 inches over the sill at high water, springs. Works are now (1888) in progress for deepening the Bassin-a-Flot, the outer harbour, and the entrance channel ; it is hoped that an average increase of depth of from 4 to 6 feet will eventually be gained, but the date of completion of the works is uncertain. As vessels are not permitted to enter without pilots, and as a pilot can always board a vessel in the small roadstead, it is unnecessary to give directions for entering the channel leading to the port du Commerce. The Port Militaire or Dockyard is north-westward of the town of Cherbourg, and occupies a space of about 220 acres of the level ground at the foot of the Equeurdreville and Couplets hills. It is especially appropriated for vessels of war, and is planned as a first class naval dockyard ; it is surrounded by fortifications, Fort du Hornet being its principal defence towards the sea. The Port, properly so called, consists of three extensive basins. The outer tidal basin or Avant-port, of 16 acres, communicates with the roadstead by a short channel opening eastward, in which the least depth is 15 feet ; and, with the Bassin-a-Flot, the northern or Charles X. basin of 15 acres, by gates 59 feet wide, having their sill 134; feet below the level of the lowest tides. Both these basins have been formed in the solid rock to a depth of about 32 feet below the same level. An inner basin named the Bassin Napoleon III., of 20 acres in extent, was opened in August 1858. It has seven first-class building

364 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. slips, and one dry dock on its western side, four dry docks on the northern, and two double dry docks on the southern side. There are also four building slips on the southern side of the Avant-port, making eleven in all, and seven docks. The two longest docks are 490 feet in length over all with 80 feet width of entrance ; the shortest dock is 246 feet in length by 60 feet width of entrance, and all the docks have a uniform depth over the sill at low water, springs, of 27 feet. The quays and docks are faced with fine granite from Dielette, Flamanville, and Chausey. On the northern side, sur rounding the docks, are the steam factory and workshops for repairing vessels. Time Signal. — The time signal is made from the look-out of Fort l'Onglet, Quay Napoleon, at an elevation of 35 feet above the sea. It is made by a metal disc about three feet in diameter ; the disc is placed in a vertical position five minutes before the signal is made, and is dropped to a horizontal position at the instant, by electricity, from the Naval Observatory. The time signal is made at 10 hours A.M. Paris mean time, equivalent to 21h. 50m. 39s. Greenwich mean time ; and repeated at lOh. 2m. Paris mean time, equivalent to 21h. 52m. 39s. Greenwich mean time. When not in use, the disc is inclined at an angle of 45°. A r ILE PELEE is what remains of the long point which formerly extended nearly 14; miles northward from the coast, but was separated from it by the action of the sea, leaving a shallow channel between it and the mainland nearly half a mile wide. This island is a flat of bare rock, nearly covered at high water ; but, at low water, springs, it is about three quarters of a mile long from North to South by half a mile wide, and is in the form of a horseshoe concave towards the East ; its highest point is a heap of stones awash at high water, equinoctial springs. Fort Imperial stands on the western point of the island, and defends the eastern entrance to Cherbourg road. The south-western bastion of the fort has on it a flagstaff, and the fixed ivhite light already described is exhibited from the north-eastern bastion ; both bastions are sufficiently high to be seen at the distance of 10 or 12 miles from seaward. The north-western and north eastern extremes of the island are marked respectively by the Tromet and Happetout beacon towers, and, its south-eastern extreme, by the Pont de l'lle beacon. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on the south-eastern and highest part of fort Imperial on lie Pelee.

Chap. VIII.] CHERBOURG.— ILE PELEE FLAT. 365 DANGERS on ILE PELEE FLAT.— The principal dangers which do not uncover upon the rocky flat forming the base of Pelee island are, the Basse du Chenal, the Basse de Happetout, the North western point of the flat, and the Truite rock. Basse du Chenal is a rocky ledge about a cable in diameter, of which several parts are nearly awash at low water. It is at the western entrance of the narrow channel which separates Pelee island from the main, one third of a mile from the shore, and its western edge S. \ W. 64; cables from the lighthouse on Fort Imperial. The spire of Querqueville church, seen between the small tower of that church and an isolated house on the high ground southward of the village of Nacqueville, points to the centre of the ledge. The channel between Pelee island and the main is very shallow, many spots being nearly awash at low water, springs. Basse de HappetOUt, a small isolated rocky patch with only 13 feet water, is at the north-eastern extreme of the dangers of Pelee island. It lies E. \ N. northerly nearly one mile from Fort Imperial lighthouse, with the high battery of Fort du Hornet just open north ward of the lower battery of Fort Imperial ; and, the small houses adjoining the eastern part of the barrack at the Becquet de Denneville on with the houses of a farm on the height above the limestone quarries called the Becquet cliffs. A little westward of the Happetout is another patch with 3 fathoms water. The rocky flat of Pelee island extends 2 cables in a northerly direction from the northern side of the island, and as the sea is always disturbed upon it, and the soundings vary from 9 to 23 feet, it is prudent for vessels to avoid approaching its northern edge. The spire of Querqueville church well open northward of Fort Central leads clear of it. The North-west Point of the Flat has 4 fathoms on it at low water, but less than half a cable within or eastward of it, are some rocky heads with from 14 to 11 feet. The flood stream sets strongly towards this point, which becomes very dangerous when with westerly winds the stream is at its greatest strength. Buoy. — The north-western point of this flat is marked by a black buoy, lying N. by W. £ W. 44 cables from Fort Imperial lighthouse. The Truite rock, at the western point of the flat on the eastern side of the Passe de l'Est or eastern channel into Cherbourg road, is about half a cable long from East to West and 60 yards wide. The

366 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. shoalest spot on the eastern end of the rock, where there are only 3| feet water, bears N. W. 520 yards from Fort Imperial lighthouse ; and, E. £ S. southerly 3f cables from the lighthouse at the eastern end of the breakwater. The marks for the western outer end of the rock, in 10 feet, are, the end of the eastern jetty of the port du Commerce seen a little within the eastern side of the square tower of Cherbourg church ; and, the barracks at Becquet open half their length southward of the outer wall of the low battery and south western bastion of Fort Imperial. Buoy. — This rock is marked off its north-western edge by a black buoy, similar to that on the north-western point of the flat ; and, although there is much less sea in the vicinity of the Truite than at the north-western point of the flat, both buoys are liable to drift from their exposed positions, and more dependence should be placed on the landmarks given than on the buoys being in their places. The Pelee bank is the sand-bank extending westward from Pelee island into the most sheltered part of the Grande Rade. There are from 20 to 25 feet on its western extreme S. by W. a quarter of a mile from Fort Central. It limits the roadstead for deep ships on its northern and north-eastern sides, but there is excellent shelter for vessels of moderate draught between it and the eastern arm of the breakwater. ANCHORAGES in RADE de CHERBOURG.— The prin- cipal anchorages for ships of war and large vessels are, the Grande Rade and the Western anchorage ; and, for smaller vessels, the Petite Rade and the Eastern anchorage between Pelee bank and the eastern arm of the breakwater. St. Anne's bay does not afford good anchorage, as the soundings are irregular, the holding ground bad, and vessels are exposed to great danger if caught there - by northerly winds which throw in a heavy sea. The Grande Rade is bounded on its northern and north eastern sides by the Pelee bank, on its eastern and southern sides by the sandy bottom adjoining the shore, and its western limit is the meridian of Cherbourg church. The bottom in the northern part of the road is for the most part composed of schistose rock in a state of decomposition, and the holding ground is good ; immediately southward of this rock the bottom is of fine muddy sand which is not sufficiently stiff to hold well, but it improves on nearing the

Chap. Vin.] 367 RADE DE CHERBOURG. shore and the holding ground is good in the southern part of the road, especially southward of the line of Nacqueville church tower on with the spire of Querqueville church. A short distance south ward of this line, however, there is not sufficient depth at low water for large vessels to anchor. The pilots moor vessels S.E. and N.W. and veer cable to meet the alternate streams of flood and ebb, which, however, are generally weak ; it is advisable always to keep a clear hawse and to be pre pared to withstand winds from the north-westward, which are frequent. Fresh winds from N.W. to North throw a heavy sea into some parts of the roadstead, but it is well sheltered from strong N.N.E. winds ; those from E.N.E. to E.S.E. raise a heavy swell from the time of half flood to half ebb by the shore. A great part of the Grande Rade is occupied by government moorings and buoys. The "Western anchorage is about 2 cables southward of the western arm of the breakwater and parallel with it for an extent of 8 cables ; the bottom is of fine sand and broken shells, with depths of from 7 to 8 fathoms. Vessels of all sizes may ride here in safety. The Petite Rade has good holding ground and is southward of the Grande Rade, in the space which is sheltered by Fort du Hornet from westerly winds and the sea occasioned by them. Its northern limit is defined by the outer wall of the round battery on Querqueville point on with Fort du Hornet ; southward of this line, the soundings decrease rather rapidly from 26 to 16 feet. About 2 cables north westward of the best anchorage in this road, are two small isolated rocky banks occupying together a space of about a cable from S.W. to N.E. ; there are 26 feet on the shoalest part of the northern bank, and 28 feet on the southern bank which is the smaller of the two and is on the line which marks the northern limit of the road ; this part is occupied by four large mooring buoys used by ships swinging to adjust their compasses. Other mooring buoys lie in the southern and eastern parts of the Petite Rade, but there is a consider able space clear for vessels to lie at their own anchors. Vessels use the Petite Rade when awaiting sufficient water to enter the port du Commerce ; those of deep draught arriving during neaps and obliged to wait for higher tides to enter the port du Commerce, should moor with open hawse to the S.W. and with the longest scope of cable on the north-western anchor ; if a gale from the northward appears probable, they should lay out a third anchor with

368 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. a good scope of cable to the N.E. Strong gales from S.W. to S.E. are very much felt at this anchorage and vessels are liable to be driven out close to the breakwater, where, Avith such winds, the sea is greatly disturbed. The Eastern Anchorage is that between the Pelee bank, described at page 366, and the eastern arm of the breakwater ; it is used chiefly by merchant vessels seeking shelter during gales from N.N.W. round by North to E.N.E. Its limits are from the meridian of Fort Central, where it is 24; cables wide, to about 1^ cables westward of the eastern end of the breakwater where it is only 1^ cables wide. The bottom at this anchorage is sand, mixed with a little mud in some places, and the depth which decreases towards the bank, varies from 26 to 32 feet ; vessels should not anchor here with strong winds from W.N.W. round by South to S.S.E. as the holding ground is not good with those winds. CHANNELS into the RADE de CHERBOURG— Ships of war and vessels of deep draught enter Cherbourg road by the channels round both ends of the breakwater. The Passe de l'Ouest, between the western end of the breakwater and Fort Chavagnae, is the best and is about half a mile wide. Passe de l'Ouest. — There is no difficulty in entering this channel with a leading wind, vessels having only to approach the western end of the breakwater on about a S.S.E. bearing, and, on nearing it, to pass midway between it and Fort Chavagnae ; but those of deep draught turning in with the flood stream must be careful to avoid the rocky patch on which Fort Chavagnae stands, also the rocky ground with 12 feet water E.N.E. half a mile from the Rochefort rock, and the Tenarde shoal ; it would be imprudent to turn through at night except the weather be clear and moonlight. The Channel between Forts de Querqueville and Chavagnae is not so wide as the Western channel and should only be used by large ships in cases of necessity, and then only between half flood and half ebb. No sailing vessel should attempt it during calm weather, as there would be great risk of being drifted on the rocks at the head of St. Anne's bay by the eddy on the flood caused by Querqueville point ; neither would there be any advantage in hugging the shore of this bay with land winds, as they frequently come in gusts from the openings of the valleys, especially when it blows hard from the South-west.

Chap. VIII.] CHERBOURG.— CHANNELS.— DIRECTIONS. 369 Passe de l'Est is between the eastern end of the breakwater and the two black buoys, before described, marking the most dangerous spots on the western edge of Pelee island flat, viz., the North-west point of the flat and the Truite rock. The narrowest part of the channel is 24 cables wide between the breakwater and Truite buoys, and has in it from 28 to 32 feet, but, besides being narrow, this channel has the disadvantage of being crossed obliquely by the tidal streams, rendering it dangerous for sailing vessels with light winds and impracticable during calms ; there is, however, no difficulty or danger in a steamer or with a commanding breeze. Vessels from the eastward intending to run through this channel on the flood, should be careful to give a good berth to the North west point of Pelee island flat, keeping rather westward of the exact line of the channel until that point is passed, as the flood stream sets strongly towards it. Octeville church just open eastward of the fort on the eastern end of the breakwater S.W. 4 W. leads in clear of the North-west flat of lie Pelee, should the buoy be gone ; and, on closing the fort, alter course so as to pass between the Truite black buoy and the red buoy off the eastern end of the breakwater. This channel is available for ships of the deepest draught between half flood and half ebb. The shallow channel southward of Pelee island trends in a W. by N. and E. by S. direction, is 54; cables long and a cable wide, and carries a depth of about 6 feat in its western part and from 2 to 6 feet in its eastern part, except on its southern side where are two rocks with less than one foot water bearing respectively from the Greves beacon N.N.E. If cables and N. by W. £ W. 1^ cables. This channel is bounded on the northern side by the Basse du Chenal and the rocks southward and south-eastward of Pelee island ; and, on its southern side, by the low-water rocks along the shore and by the two rocks just described which are more than a cable outside the rocks which dry ; the highest of these latter is the Vieille which dries 10 feet above the level of the lowest tides and covers at one third flood, but is also marked by a beacon which bears W. by N. 4 N. 2| cables from the Greves rock beacon. From the Vieille, Nacqueville church tower is on with the small spire of Querqueville church, and, as long as it is covered, a vessel in charge of a pilot and drawing less than 12 feet water may enter this channel. DIRECTIONS.— Approaching Cherbourg from the Westward. — The western end of Cherbourg breakwater bears S.E. 4 E. easterly 85 miles from Start point ; S. by E. easterly A. 2771. Wt. 17197. 2 A

370 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. 59 miles from the Bill of Portland ; and, S. by W. £ W. 59 miles from the entrance to the Needles. When bound to any French port east ward of cape de la Hague from the westward, the best landfall to make is the coast of England, proceeding exactly as if bound for an eastern English port, as directed in Channel Pilot, part I., until arrived at a proper position to haul over towards the French coast- Thus, when bound for Cherbourg, proceed by the English shore until abreast of the Start, when having ascertained the vessel's position and the weather being clear, a course may be shaped to make the Casquets ; or, bearing in mind the great strength and variety of tide in the neighbourhood of the Casquets and to avoid all danger of being carried through the Ortac, Swinge, or Race channels, especially should the weather be at all doubtful, it may be better to make Portland and then stand across for the French coast, shaping a course about half a point westward of cape Barfleur. The ship's position may then be accurately fixed by cross bearings of capes de la Hague and Barfleur by day or of their lights by night ; the white side of Mont Roule is also a conspicuous object by day, being visible at a distance of 20 miles in clear weather. Should it be determined to make the Casquets, consider carefully the direction of the wind and tidal streams as well as the state of the weather, which, unless clear, may render the approach to these islets not only difficult but dangerous. On nearing them, great care must be taken to avoid being set southward of them, especially whilst the tide is flowing on their shores, when there would be great risk of being drawn into the Swinge channel and being obliged to cross Alderney Race at the time the sea is most agitated. From a position about 9 miles N.W. of the Casquets, the course to be steered must depend greatly upon wind and tide. With the wind anywhere from W.S.W. round by North to N.N.E., and making due allowance for tide, a course of about E. \ S. for 14 miles leads 5 miles northward of all danger up to the meridian of the western point of Alderney, when cape de la Hague lighthouse should bear about S.E. £ S. 13 miles ; then an E.S.E. course for 11 miles leads to a position from which the lighthouse, well open of the land, bears S.S.W. 6^ miles ; and, from thence, a course steered S.S.E. £ E. easterly for 14^ miles leads to the western entrance into Cherbourg road. These courses keep a vessel a safe distance outside the dangers, and also outside the strong streams of tide running through the Ortac and Swinge channels and Alderney Race ; but, with the wind between W.S.W. and S.S.W., and the north-eastern stream running through these channels, to prevent being drifted too far northward,

Chap. Vin.] 371 CHERBOURG. — DIRECTIONS. an E. by S. £ S. course may be shaped from the first position given (N.W. 9 miles from the Casquets) which leads about 2\ or 3 miles from the shore on the meridian of cape de la Hague, and Cherbourg road can then be gained without difficulty ; whereas, with south-westerly winds, if during the flood the meridian of cape de la Hague should be crossed at 6 or 7 miles from the shore, a sailing vessel runs great risk of missing the entrance to Cherbourg road. During the ebb stream, with a fresh breeze, a heavy sea will be found off the entrances of all these channels. At Night. — Approaching the western channel into Cherbourg road, when eastward of cape de la Hague, keep its light in sight over the land until Querqueville fixed white light bears S.S.W., then stand to the southward until the fixed ivhite light in Fort Imperial, lie Pelee, opens southward of Fort Central fixed and flashing light, after which the seaman must be guided by the red light on the western end of the breakwater. The most unfavourable winds for a sailing vessel to approach Cherbourg from the direction of the Casquets, are those from the eastward, and especially a south-easterly wind. With a moderate breeze, however, from these quarters, the sea is generally smooth, and, during the flood, the passage is not difficult ; but, on the ebb, it is absolutely impossible, and she should then make a long board to the northward and endeavour to hold her own until the stream slacks : then, the shore should be again approached to take advantage of the first of the flood, and long boards made in order to reach the road stead or a position eastward of its meridian, so as to enter with the latter part of the flood or the beginning of the ebb. On account of the great strength of the tidal streams, calm and fog are chiefly to be feared when making this passage, and, if threatened by either, every effort should be made to get into the middle of the Channel where the streams are much weaker than near the French coast. From the Eastward. — The course and distance from 2 miles southward of the Royal Sovereign light-vessel to cape Barfleur is W.S.W. southerly 89 miles. Vessels coming from the North Sea or from the northern part of the English channel and bound for Cherbourg with the wind between North and East, after clearing Dover strait, generally steer direct for cape Barfleur, but with other winds they should endeavour to confirm their reckoning by the bearings of some headland on the English or French coasts ; thus, with northerly 2 A 2

CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. 372 winds Beachy head should be made, and, with southerly winds, cape d'Antifer, or the lighthouse at Fecamp, which latter may be seen at the distance of 18 miles.* The most unfavourable winds for making this passage are those between N.W. and W.S.W. ; but, as the change of stream in mid Channel does not take place until 2 or 3 hours after it does so near the shore, it is often possible to keep in a favourable stream 8 or 9 hours out of the 12. Approaching cape Barfleur during the flood, in order to avoid being drawn into the bay of the Seine or into Barfleur race, where the tide runs with great violence, do not stand into less than 22 fathoms water, which depth may be found about 2 miles from the cape ; the same distance and depth should also be preserved on the ebb, to keep outside the race and the short chopping sea off that cape on a weather tide. Between cape Barfleur and cape Levi, do not stand into less than 26 fathoms as the dangers between these capes extend 24 miles from the coast ; and, a berth of at least two miles should be given to cape Levi to clear the foul ground off it. To avoid being embayed between cape Levi and Pelee island, where a sudden shift of wind might place her in difficulty, and also to avoid the dangers on Pelee island flat, a large vessel turning to windward between the cape and island should not stand farther southward than to have Querqueville spire on with the northern end of Fort Central ; at night, she should tack when Fort Central light bears West. Leaving Cherbourg. — Sailing vessels bound westward from Cherbourg do well not to leave the road until the wind is sufficiently settled to carry them clear of the English Channel. They generally stand out through the western channel at the commencement of the ebb, and, if the wind is light, after rounding Fort du Hornet, borrow towards the breakwater to avoid drifting on the Chavagnae rock, the ebb making directly towards it. When on the meridian of cape de la Hague, and 6 or 7 miles from it, they steer about W.N.W. until the Casquets bear S.S.E. when a W. by S. course takes them out of the channel. These courses lead out of the influence of the streams running through the Casquet and Swinge channels and Alderney Race, and in the direction of the offing streams, and also sufficiently near the island of Ushant to admit of taking a departure from it if the weather is clear ; if the weather is not favourable, the chief object is to make • * Se." Chap. VIII.] CHERBOURG.— DIRECTIONS.— TIDAL STREAMS. 373 westing, and Ushant should be given a wide berth ; see page 5. If bound into the Gulf of St. Malo and intending to pass through the Race, vessels should endeavour so to time their leaving Cherbourg as to be at the entrance of the Race towards half ebb by the shore ; that is, at the end of the north-eastern stream in that channel, and they should then steer so as to pass through the centre of it ; see page 347. Bound eastward from the Rade de Cherbourg with a westerly wind, weigh towards half flood ; or, if in the Bassin-a-flot of the port du Commerce, quit it as soon as the gates are open and run out by the eastern channel, see page 369. When well clear of this channel, a vessel leaving the road at half flood by the shore will have the beginning of the Channel flood stream, and if favoured with a fresh breeze, she will carry that stream for 8 or 9 hours to the eastward. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in the port du Commerce, at 7h. 49m., and, as before stated, the water rises above the sill of the Bassin-a-flot (which is itself 15 inches above the level of the lowest tides) at extraordinary springs from 19 to 21 feet ; at ordinary springs 17 to 184; feet ; and, at neaps, 13 feet. Strong westerly winds in the entrance of the English channel cause the tides in the Avant-port to rise one or two feet higher, even during calm weather in the vicinity of the port, and easterly winds have a contrary effect. With violent westerly winds, at springs, the sea frequently flows over the quays of the outer harbour. The mean duration of the flood is 5h. 45m. ; and, of the ebb, 6h. 35m. Tidal Streams.* — The flood stream begins to be felt in the Grande Rade half an hour after low water by the shore and ceases three quarters of an hour after high water ; its direction is south easterly and its rate about 2 knots. The greatest speed of the north-western or ebb stream hardly ever exceeds H knots unless the the wind is strong from N.E. or East. In the Western anchorage, the flood stream commences about an hour after low water on the shore and ends an hour after high water. The streams are feeble throughout the whole extent of both this and the Eastern anchorage. The Petite Rade is in the eddy of the flood stream occasioned by the projection of Hornet point. This eddy extends as far as the northern limit of the road and forms a counter stream which sweeps * See also Table of Tidal Streams, page 3«3.

374 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. along the shore in a W.N.W. direction from about 3 or 4 cables eastward of the entrance to the port du Commerce to the head of the bay, and then northward along the boundary wall of the dockyard. It begins about half flood by the shore and continues until high water ; its greatest rate is about 14; knots, at springs, and its rate decreases towards high water. The ebb stream follows the same direction and at half ebb, when it is at its greatest strength, its rate is about 2 knots. About half a mile northward of the western channel into Cherbourg, the flood stream, which runs S.S.E. and S.E., commences about 14 hours after low water by the shore, and ceases lh. 20m. after high water, its greatest speed being 3 knots. The ebb runs N.W. by N. at nearly the same rate. In the entrance channel, the flood stream first takes a S.S.W. direction, but, as it gains its greatest strength, which is about 2 knots at springs, it inclines towards S.S.E. The direction of the ebb varies from N.N.W. to N.W., its rate being nearly the same as that of the flood. The flood stream ceases at the western end of the breakwater about an hour after high water in the port Militaire. The flood stream begins to be felt in the eastern channel into Cherbourg one hour after low water by the shore, and ceases one hour after high water. Its direction is E. by S. between the breakwater and Truite buoys, and its greatest speed at from 4 to 5 hours flood by the shore, is 2^ knots ; but, a little northward of this position, the stream runs East 34 knots. At the North-west point of Pelee island flat, as well as on its northern edge, its direction is E.N.E., and its greatest velocity 4 knots. The eddies formed by the uneven rocks on the flat produce a violent and dangerous race. The ebb experiences fewer variations and its rate is rather less than the flood. It runs along the northern edge of Pelee island, and, from thence, West, until the rocks are uncovered ; but, outside the flat and breakwater, its direction is W.N.W. The streams between Pelee island and the land run E.S.E. and W.N.W. and their greatest strength is from 24 to 3 knots. The Coast between Pelee island and cape Levi, which bears from it E. £ S. 4 miles, forms a bight where sailing vessels should avoid getting embayed. From the Flamands rocks to the middle of this bight, the shore is low and broken into small projections, of which the most remarkable is Heu point in front of Bretteville village. A short distance inland are the calcareous cliffs known as Becquet

Chap. VITI.] TIDAL STREAMS.— PORT DU BECQUET. 375 quarries, one of the most remarkable objects in the neighbourhood of Cherbourg. Brique point, with its steep sides covered with verdure, is also conspicuous ; it bears E. £ N. 1£ miles from Heu point and on it is a mound. One cable W.S.W. of this is Le Castel, another mound of similar form ; on its summit stands a guard-house. The tower of Maupertuis church, about 2 miles eastward of Bretteville church, is a useful landmark for this part of the coast. PORT du BECQUET, 14, miles south-eastward of Pelee island and three quarters of a mile westward of Heu point, is in front of a group of houses close to the shore. It is formed by a pier running parallel with the shore and closed at the western end, the entrance being at the eastern end ; it is a grounding place about a cable long and less than half a cable wide, surrounded by quays of dry stone work ; in it there are only from 12 to 15 feet at high water, springs, and it is specially intended for boats loading with stone from the Becquet quarries. A Life-Boat is stationed here. LIGHTS. — There are two leading lights at Port du Becquet shown from iron standards bearing from each other N.E. 4_ N. and S.W. 4_ S. and 76 yards apart ; the inner light is red, 29 feet above high water, and visible through an arc of 16° on either side of the centre of the channel, its intensity diminishing towards the extremes. The outer light is white, and 26 feet above high water. They should be seen in clear weather respectively 9 and 7 miles, and, when in line, they lead up to the entrance of the port mid-way between the pier-end and a beacon tower marking a mass of rock 1£ cables eastward of the pier. The Grunes de Bretteville is the rocky ground three quarters of a mile wide extending perpendicularly from the shore between Heu and Brique points ; at the outer edge, Nacqueville church tower is on with the Happetout rock, the north-eastern point of Pelee island. The depths are tolerably regular, from 13 feet near the shore to 9 or 10 fathoms about a mile off. The only dangerous spot is a head of rock with only 12 feet water, 54 cables from the shore, with Le Castel bearing S.E. by E. 4. E. ; and, Bretteville church tower S.W. Cape Levi Port is in the bight three quarters of a mile south-westward of the cape ; the shore is not accessible even at

376 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. high water, except where a small cove has been formed into this little port by means of a jetty of stone work, which was formerly almost destroyed by the sea but was re-built in 1861-64, and now affords good shelter to the fishing craft and coasters frequenting the bay. To improve the approach to this little harbour at night, it is proposed shortly to erect a lighthouse on the jetty. A black beacon turret stands on a rock off the entrance ; it should be left on the port hand in entering. Anchorage. — At 3 or 4 cables West and W.N.W. from the jetty, there is good holding ground in 9 fathoms, muddy bottom, where vessels bound eastward against a fonl wind may wait in safety during the ebb tide. This anchorage is protected by Fort Levi, which stands on the northern point of the bay, and a good berth is, with the semaphore seen midway between the fort and cape Levi lighthouse. CAPE LEVI is low, being the northern termination of some low hills detached from the high lands of the interior. On the highest parts of these hills stand two houses, very close to each other, which may be seen from a considerable distance ; the northern house is an old semaphore station and the other a guard-house. Several rocky patches which uncover extend as far as 4 cables north-eastward from the cape. The outer patch is terminated by the Bieroc, a remarkable rock with a rounded head 5 or 6 feet above the level of high water. LIGHT. — On the extreme of Cape Levi stands a square light house, from which at 115 feet above high water, is exhibited a. fixed white light, varied by a red flash every three minutes, visible in clear weather from a distance of 13 miles. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on a mound about 13 feet high, 383 yards south-eastward of the lighthouse. CAPE LEVI RACE is occasioned by the strong tides and uneven rocky ground which extends N. by E. E. 2 miles from the cape. This rocky ground is in some places half a mile wide, is elevated considerably above the general level of the bottom, and, as it lies across the direction of the tidal streams, it causes a heavy sea, especially on a weather tide. It is stated by local pilots that with strung easterly winds on the flood, at springs, this Race is as dangerous and the sea as bad as in Alderney Race.

Chap. VIII.] CAPE LEVI. — ANSE DE LA MONDREE. 377 Some patches rising from the rocky bottom in this Race are dangerous even for small vessels at all times of tide ; they are the Bieroc patch, Basse du cap Levi, Pierre Noire, and Tete Septentrionale or northern head of the race. The Bieroc Patch is small and rocky, with only 3 feet water H cables northward of the Bieroc, from which it derives its name. Basse du Cap Levi is a rocky ledge about 2 cables long N.N.W. and S.S.E. and 14^ cables wide ; at its south-eastern point is a dangerous 13-feet patch N.N.W. £ W. half a mile from the Bieroc. The Pierre Noire or Black rock bears N. 4 E. one mile from the summit of the Bieroc ; it is one of the most dangerous rocks in the race, having only 7 feet over it at the lowest tides. Buoy. — A black bell buoy is moored outside the north-eastern extreme of this danger ; it, however, occasionally breaks adrift. The Tete Septentrionale is at the north-western extreme of the rocky bottom, N. 4/ W. 14 miles from the Bieroc ; E. by N. rather more than 6 miles from Fort Central on Cherbourg breakwater : and, N.W. by W. 4 W. 84 miles from cape Barfleur lighthouse. There are 33 feet on this rocky head at low water, but as it rises precipitously from soundings of from 19 to 25 fathoms, it causes great eddies, and the sea breaks on it in bad weather. Vessels of moderate draught in charge of pilots, may, if the weather permits, pass through the race between the Basse du cap Levi and the Pierre Noire, at low water ; but, large vessels should always pass northward of the race. The Coast between cape Levi and cape Barfleur, which are distant 8 miles from each other and on the same parallel of latitude, is generally low and sandy, but the adjacent lands rise at a short distance from the shore and are joined to the hills in the interior by slight undulations of which the highest are, Carneville heath, the woody mound at St. Pierre, the hills bounding Saire valley, and Pernelle hill. ANSE de la MONDREE, immediately eastward of cape Levi, between the Bieroc and Blanche rocks, is about 14 miles wide and recedes three quarters of a mile ; there is good anchorage on its

CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. 378 western side, in 1\ fathoms, muddy bottom, where vessels turning to windward against westerly winds may wait during the flood ; but, it must be used only in the finest weather, for should a vessel surprised at anchor here by strong winds from N.W. to N.E. be compelled to weigh during the flood, she would be driven amongst the numerous dangers off the coast to the eastward. The best anchorage is with the Bieroc bearing N.W. by N. ?>\ cables ; and, the Semaphore on cape Levi about W.S.W. With strong northerly winds, no landing can be effected in this bay, nor upon any part of the coast between Capes Levi and Barfleur, except in Roubaril cove near the latter cape. Roubaril cove. — This small cove is half a mile westward of cape Barfleur and, in it, coasters, under the care of good pilots, may take refuge in time of need. The local fishermen state that, in case of necessity, a vessel under 12 feet draught could be saved by running into it at high water. The cove is about half a cable wide and a cable deep, and the rocks bordering its sides are always un covered. The water flows into it at about half flood. DANGERS Off the COAST.— The coast between capes Levi and Barfleur is studded with dangers, of which some extend 24 miles into the offing ; between them and the shore are some winding channels, through which coasting vessels with good pilots may pass even at low water. The Sen is a small isolated rock, just awash at the lowest tides, 8 cables from the shore in a N.E. by N. direction from Coqueville church. Basses du Sen. — These shoals are numerous separate patches, extending westward, northward, and eastward of the Sen rock. The shoal northward of the rock is 8 cables long and 34; cables wide ; it has two dangerous rocky heads, of which one has only 44 feet water ; on the other, which from its position is called the Tete du Milieu, or Middle head, there are 54 feet. North-westward of this shoal are four isolated rocky heads, with from 21 to 31 feet water ; from the Tete du Nord-Ouest, the outer of these heads, Gatteville church tower on with a rock at Neville point which is awash at the highest neaps, bears S.E. 4. S. southerly ; and, St. Pierre church tower on with a house at Coqueville, which on that bearing appears to stand a little westward of the church tower of that village, S. by W. westerly.

Chap. VIII.] DANGERS OFF THE COAST. 379 A fifth rocky head with 9 fathoms water lies N. by E. three quarters of a mile from the Middle head, with Fort Central light house on Cherbourg breakwater bearing W. f S. 9£ miles ; and, cape Barfleur lighthouse S.E. easterly 6 miles ; it is dangerous only on account of the heavy sea occasioned by the eddies. There are no dangers between the Sen shoals and cape Levi race, and 6 or 7 fathoms water will be found at the outer edges of the rocks and banks which extend as far as 6 cables from the coast. The Renier, a small rock uncovering 4 feet, is a mile from the shore at the northern angle of a triangular rocky flat, of which the base is towards the shore. This flat has a number of rocky heads which uncover at low water. Basses du Renier. — These shoals are from one to 1J miles north-eastward and northward of the Renier rock ; they form three distinct patches, the Basse du Sud-Est, Basse du Centre, and Basse du Nord-Ouest ; the Basse du Sud-Est has 21 feet water, the Basse du Centre, 15 feet, and the Basse du Nord-Ouest, 26 feet. Buoy. — A black bell buoy is moored just outside the 15-feet spot on the Basse du Centre. The Basse du Nord-Ouest is the outermost danger between cape Levi and cape Barfleur ; it is about 2^ miles from the shore and less than a quarter of a mile within the 21-fathoms line of soundings bordering the coast. From its shoalest spot of 26 feet, cape Barfleur lighthouse bears S.E. 4 S. southerly rather more than 5 miles ; and, Fort Central lighthouse on Cherbourg breakwater W. \ S 104^ miles. One mile E.S.E. from the shoalest part of the Basse du Nord-Ouest is a small patch with 8 fathoms water ; and, as it rises precipitously from soundings of from 14 to 19 fathoms, it occasions eddies and over falls which are dangerous to cross during strong winds. The eddies caused by both the Renier and Sen shoals raise a heavy sea during a weather tide. The Roquette, a small isolated rocky patch of only 4 feet water, lies N.N.E. about 1\ miles from Neville point ; and, N.W. \ N. 3 miles from cape Barfleur lighthouse. There is another patch with 5 fathoms S.S.E. 2 cables from the Roquette, and many others lie between the Roquette and the Renier.

380 CAPE DE LA HAGUE TO CAPE BARFLEUR. [Chap. VIII. Plateau des EquetS is a rocky ridge S.E. \ S. about one mile from the Roquette and N.W. by N. nearly 2 miles from cape Barfleur lighthouse ; it is of a circular form, about 3 cables in diameter, and has four dangerous heads, of which the highest rises from its southern part and uncovers nearly 2 feet ; there are from 2 to 5 feet on the other heads. Haut-Fond des Equets, a rocky patch of 28 feet water, with from 10 to 12 fathoms round it, lies 1£ miles from the coast, 54^ cables northward of the Plateau des Equets, and about N.N.W. \ W. 2\ miles from cape Barfleur lighthouse. The marks for it are : — the tower of St. Pierre church seen between the church tower and redoubt at Retoville ; and, the small tower of Gatteville church on with a powder magazine on the shore near the guard-house at Gatteville. Bane de Saint Pierre is a collection of sand and broken shells, extending in a south-easterly direction 1£ miles from the plateau des Equets, and terminating at the depth of 25 feet N.N.E. \ E. 54 cables from cape Barfleur lighthouse. The shoalest part of the bank, which is about half a mile wide, has three patches of from 4 to 6 feet water, and the sea breaks with great violence on them during a weather tide ; this must cause these depths frequently to vary, but the body of the bank remains stationary. Directions. — Vessels of deep draught, and even small craft without pilots, should keep outside the dangers just described, which extend as far as 24 miles from the coast between cape Levi and cape Barfleur ; and, the directions given for approaching Cherbourg from the eastward, at page 371, should be attended to. At night, in clear weather, bearings of Fort Central light on Cherbourg breakwater and of cape Barfleur light, as well as that on Cape Levi, greatly assist the mariner in avoiding these dangers, which should not be approached within a depth of 26 fathoms ; but, in thick weather, vessels should keep well off the coast, as the lead does not give sufficient warning of their proximity. Tidal Streams. — At 24 miles from the coast between cape Levi and cape Barfleur, the flood stream commences about the time of half flood by the shore, and ends at half ebb. It attains its greatest speed at the time of high water, and the ebb at the time of low water by the shore. From the northern part of cape Levi race to two or three miles in the offing, the direction of both streams, during their

Chap. Vin.] CAPE BARFLEUR. — LIGHT. — RACE. 381 greatest strength at springs, is East and West, and the rate of the flood is from 34_ to 4 knots, the ebb something less. Outside and amongst the Sen and Renier shoals, their direction is E.S.E. and W.N.W., and their rate about the same ; but, as the meridian of cape Barfleur is approached, the flood stream inclines more to the South east and its strength increases. At 2 miles northward of cape Barfleur, the flood runs S.E. 5 or 6 knots ; the ebb, N.W., with nearly equal velocity ; see also Table, page 383. CAPE BARFLEUR and LIGHT.— Cape Barfleur, or pointe de Gatteville as it is frequently called by the French, is the western extreme of the Baie de la Seine ; it is a low point, off which in a S.E. by E. direction at about one mile, as also on its north-western side, are some rocks which uncover at low water. Two towers of unequal height, about 80 feet apart, stand at the extreme of the point and serve to mark its position by day. The highest or southern tower is the lighthouse, and exhibits a revolving white light, of the first order, which attains its greatest brilliancy every half minute. The light is 236 feet above high water, and may be seen in clear weather from a distance of 23 miles ; beyond a distance of 12 miles the eclipses are total between the bright faces, but within 12 miles there is a faint continuous light. Semaphore. — The northern tower on cape Barfleur was the first built, and served as the lighthouse until the year 1836 when the southern tower took its place ; the northern tower has been converted into a semaphore station. When the sun shines on these towers the lighthouse may be seen 15 or 16 miles distant, and the semaphore tower at 11 or 12 miles. They are difficult to distinguish when at some distance north eastward of them on account of the high land at their back ; this land, however, has a remarkable break in its formation, which assists to mark their position ; — it is the valley of the little river Saire, called Coupee du Vaast, which lies S.W. by W. 4 W. 54^ miles from the lighthouse. Pernelle hill is also a remarkable object, and attracts particular notice by means of the church on its summit ; it bears S.W. by S. 4£ miles from the lighthouse, and when seen from S.S.E., N.N.E., or N.N.W., it has the appearance of a promontory sloping gradually towards the sea. BARFLEUR RACE. — This race is occasioned by the violence with which the tidal streams rush over the rocks forming a submarine

These rocks are based on the flat joining the land and extending about a mile, from East to S.E. from the lighthouse, as far as the line of Pernelle and Monfarville church towers in one. They form three separate reefs ; the first, with from 7 to 25 feet water, extends E. by N. half a mile from the light house ; the second, separated from the first by a deep called the Breche-du-Raz, has a rock with only 17 feet water lying E. 4 S. about 65 cables from the lighthouse ; the third, named the Ridin de Quenanville, is southward of the others and separated from them by another deep about 4 cables wide. This latter reef, 2 cables wide, extends half a mile in an E.S.E. and W.N.W. direction, and its shoalest spot of 7 feet lies with Reville church spire on with the western side of a cluster of houses at the chateau of Monfarville ;* and, the guard-house on the summit of the eastern point of Roubaril cove touching the southern part of the highest of the houses (light keepers' dwellings), about 14 cables south-westward of the lighthouse. Barfleur race is especially dangerous at springs, when the streams run through at the rate of 8 or 9 knots, and, with a fresh wind, and especially with strong north-easterly gales, the sea breaks violently throughout its whole extent. The broken water in the race, however, depends generally upon the velocity and the hour of the tide, and it sometimes extends to a great distance in an easterly direction from the lighthouse. At neaps, the streams are not so strong and the race is quieter. At slack water, and with a moderate breeze, the extension of the race is only a strong rippling, and the most agitated part of it is not more than 2 or 3 cables wide. Fishermen, under these circumstances, cross it, passing through the Breche-du-Raz. Barfleur pilots also take small vessels through it at this time ; and, to do so, they only carry sufficient sail to steer well, so as to avoid the broken water and to keep the vessel's head to the sea. Vessels entering the Baie de la Seine from the westward, should avoid Barfleur race by giving the cape a berth of at least 2 miles in rough weather, and of 14^ miles in fine weather. * This chateau stands one mile southward of Barfleur church, and being of a brown colour it contrasts strongly with the trees surrounding it.

384 CHAPTER IX. BAIE DE LA SEINE— CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. VARIATION IN 1888. Cape Barfleur ... 17° 40' W. Cape D'Antifer - - - 17° 10' W. BAIE DE LA SEINE is the deep bight comprised between cape Barfleur and cape D'Antifer, which latter bears from the former E. by S. 5 S. southerly, distant 55 miles. The coast of the bay recedes from this line about 24 miles towards the mouth of the river Orne, and its circuit, without taking into account the shores of the Seine estuary and of the Grand Vay, is about 96 miles.* It is open to all winds from N.W. round by North to N.E., and a heavy sea is thrown into it when they blow with any strength. At springs, the tidal streams, as described at page 452 (see also Table, page 454) run at the rate of 3 or 4 knots, and all the harbours within its circuit, except Havre, become completely dry before low water ; during neaps, there is little water in any of them even at high water, and they are, consequently, not then accessible to vessels of deep draught. A vessel embayed here, therefore, during strong northerly winds is in a dangerous position. All the indentations'of the shores of the bay, which lie out of the fair line of the tidal streams, are blocked up by sand and by the accumulations deposited by the rivers. The principal headlands and harbours are well lighted, and thus distinctly marked at night ; but, unfortunately, the lights as well as the characteristics of the coast by day, are frequently obscured by haze and fogs, which at times prove very embarrassing. THE COAST.— From cape Barfleur, the coast trends southward 5| miles to pointe de Saire ; it is generally low and of rocky granite formation with reefs extending some distance from the shore. Seen from the offing the land here appears well wooded, church steeples * See Admiralty Chart :— North Coast of France, sheet XI., Barfleur to cape D Antifer, No. 2,618, scale, m = (>•"> inch.

Chap, ix.] BAIE DE LA SEINE. — SOUNDINGS. 385 showing here and there above the trees. As previously mentioned, Pernelle hill and church, three miles north-westward of Saire point, is a conspicuous object on this part of the coast. From Saire point, the land falls back westward, forming at three miles southward of that point the Rade de la Hougue ; the little ports of Barfleur Reville, St. Vaast, and La Hougue, all lying between cape Barfleur and the Grande Rade de la Hougue. From La Hougue, the shores of the bay are generally low and sandy, with off-lying shoals and sand-banks in the western part ; but, eastward of Maisy point, it is more diversified, and, in the neighbour hood of point Percee, which bears S. by E. i E. easterly 224, miles from cape Barfleur, are high chalk cliffs visible 12 or 15 miles distant. The ports of Carentan and Isigny are in the deep bight of the Grand Vay, westward of point Maisy. From point Percee, point Beuzeval, which may be considered the southern boundary of the estuary of the Seine, bears S.E. by E. £ E. 33^ miles, the intervening coast, described hereafter in detail, consisting partly of cliffs of chalk or of rock and brown clay, and partly of low sand-hills with a moderately high and well cultivated interior. The ports within this space are, Port-en-Bessin, Courseulles, Oyestreham, and Caen, the latter 9 miles above Oyestreham on the river Orne, and the river Dives just westward of the Beuzeval hill. From Beuzeval point, the white chalk cliffs of cape de la Heve bear N.E. \ N. 13 miles, the whole intervening space being occupied by the shallows, banks, and channels of the entrance of the Seine, on the southern shore of which is the harbour of Trouville, and the ports of Honfleur and Quillebœuf ; whilst, on the northern shore, is the large and important port of Havre, with Harfleur and others, the river being navigable for large vessels as high as Rouen. From cape de la Heve, the chalk cliffs forming the coast line trend almost directly N.E. \ N. northerly 11 miles to cape D'Antifer, the shore being safe of approach within one mile for the whole distance between the two capes but without port or harbour of any descrip tion. SOUNDINGS.— The depths in the Baie de la Seine are very regular, varying, in line between cape Barfleur and cape D'Antifer, from 24 fathoms near the former to 18 fathoms near the latter, and from those depths decreasing very gradually towards the off-lying banks in the south-western part of the bay, towards the southern and eastern shores, and towards the extensive flats off the mouth of the Seine. PORT BARFLEUR.— The entrance to this little port bears S.£W. 14; miles from cape Barfleur lighthouse, and its position is clearly indicated by the church standing on the northern point of entrance. The port is only 3 cables long and 2 cables wide, dries at low water, springs, is sheltered by the land from South round by West to N.N.E., and is protected from the sea during strong easterly winds by the Antiquaires and other rocks lying in front of the entrance.* A small jetty of stonework extends 53 yards in a southerly direction from the northern point of entrance, and a breakwater or jetty, 220 yards long, extends N.N.E. 4. E. from the southern entrance point ; the head of the northern jetty bears from the outer end of the breakwater or southern jetty about W.N.W. more than half a cable distant. The bottom of the port is generally mud, mixed with broken shells, sand, and gravel, and good for vessels taking the ground, but there are some rocky patches which should be avoided. The best and most commodious berths are near the entrance, where the bottom is soft and the tide rises higher than elsewhere ; vessels using them must moor securely to the large iron rings fixed in the rocks, as they are exposed to easterly winds, and to the sea, at springs, when the Antiquaires rocks are covered. Vessels loading or unloading lie alongside the North quay where the bottom is 4 feet above the lowest tides ; the bottom over the rest of the port is from 4 to 10 feet above that level. Alongside the North quay, there are from 16 to 17 feet at high water springs, from 18 to 20 feet at equinoctial springs, and from 9 to 10 feet at neaps ; vessels of less than 9 feet draught can, therefore, enter the harbour at high water with any tide. The port of Barfleur has 420 yards of substantial stone-built quay frontage, but its distance from any railway makes it of no commercial importance. Its trade, carried on by small coasters, is represented by about 100 vessels of an aggregate of 3,150 tons entering annually, and, of these, about half enter in ballast. Granite for building purposes is extensively quarried in its neighbourhood. The little traffic carried on is in flax, hemp, vegetables, fruit, butter, oysters, and fish. Dangers. — The outer danger in approaching port Barfleur is the Ridin des Dents, a rocky shoal on which is a dangerous patch with only 9 feet water about a mile from the shore, and bearing * See Admiralty plan -.—Port Barfleur on Sheet XI., No. 2.613.

The Anglais rocks bear about N.E. by E. 4 E. 4 cables from the North jetty end, and the Vinberge rock, the highest head, uncovers 7 feet. The Hintar rock E. by S. 4. S. nearly 2 cables from Vinberge rock, and, E.N.E. half a mile from the breakwater end, uncovers b\ feet ; a large iron ring is fixed on it for the convenience of vessels warping into harbour or anchoring near it in the road. Buoys and Beacons.— On the northern side of the entrance, two red buoys, the outer having a staff and vane, mark the Anglais rocks ; they bear N.E. £ E. and S.W. £ W. distant 14 cables from each other, the Vinberge rock lying midway between them ; a red buoy marks the Ronde rock at the entrance, it is only a quarter of a cable from the breakwater end, and vessels entering must pass between it and the breakwater. On the southern side are, a black buoy with staff and vane marking the Hintar rock, two beacons marking respectively the Raie and Grosse-Haie rocks, and a black buoy marking the Hoisier rock near the breakwater. There is also a third beacon marking the Fourquie rock a short distance south-eastward of the entrance. A Life-Boat is stationed at port Barfleur. LIGHTS. — Two fixed ivhite lights, dioptric and of the fifth order, are exhibited from square towers, one, 23 feet above high water, on a point on the southern side of the harbour, If cables within the breakwater end ; the other, at the head of the harbour, 43 feet above high water, and bearing S.W. by W. 4 W. 309 yards from the former ; both may be seen in clear weather from a distance of 9 miles, and when in line they lead to the entrance. Two small fixed red lights are also shown, one near the head of the breakwater or southern jetty ; the other, near the head of the northern jetty. These two red lights in line lead through the southern passage up to the harbour entrance. Fog" Bell. — The bell of the white church of St. Vaast at Barfleur is sounded continuously during foggy weather for one hour about the time of high water. (See note, page 10.) Directions. — A vessel rounding cape Barfleur from the west ward and bound to port Barfleur, after passing the swell at the outer end of Barfleur race, should take care not to go westward of Pernelle and Monfarville church towers in line bearing S.W., unless of very 2B 2

The two harbour lighthouses by day, or lights by night, in line bearing S.W. by W. \ W. lead through the channel to the port between the western rocks of the Antiquaires reef and the dangers bordering the shore between cape Barfleur and the northern point of the port, leaving on the starboard hand the three red buoys already described, and on the port hand the black buoys and beacons. The channel narrows considerably between the Hintar and the Anglais rocks, and, from thence to the entrance, it is only 120 yards wide. At the entrance, it is only about 50 yards wide between the Ronde buoy and the head of the South jetty or breakwater. Anchorage. — Vessels arriving before high water with off-shore winds, may anchor in Barfleur road, which is a small deep between the Plateau des Antiquaires and the Gaillarde and Anglais rocks. The best anchorage is in about 5 fathoms, good holding ground, with the lower leading light a little open to the left of the higher light, or with Pernelle and Monfarville church towers in line S.W. ; and, Crabet mill, without sails, just open northward of Masse point. This anchorage should be used during off-shore winds only and in fine weather ; should a vessel, however, be surprised in it by strong northerly or easterly winds, she must moor with open hawse to the northward, and with the heaviest anchor to the eastward ; the anchorage being of small extent, it will be necessary to shorten in and tauten the cables as the water falls to prevent tailing on the rocks. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in port Barfleur at 8h. 59m. ; at the foot of the North quay, equinoctial springs rise from 18 to 20 feet ; ordinary springs, 17 feet ; and, ordinary neaps, 13 feet. Neaps range 9 feet. The tides are very regular, but with strong prevailing south-westerly winds the water rises higher, and, with strong and lasting winds in the opposite direction, remains lower than the general level ; this is also the case in all the harbours of the bay of the Seine. The mean duration of the rising tide is 5h. 50m., and of the falling tide 6h. 35m., but the duration of the rising tide between a neap and the following spring tide exceeds 6 hours and sometimes reaches 64; hours, whilst between a spring and the following neap it is below the mean. The first part of the flood stream follows the direction of the shore from cape Barfleur, and crosses the road and channel. Its greatest rate does not exceed 3 knots and it decreases suddenly at
