This eddy is weak about high water, but its rate increases as soon as the tide begins to fall. Moulard Point is low and bears S. by E. \ E. 1\ miles from Barfleur church. Rocks which uncover at low water lie off the point, and rocky ground with shoal patches extends about a mile from the shore. The Basse Orientale du Moulard is the outer or eastern patch ; it has 26 feet water, lies E. 4_ N. 9 cables from the Moulard rock beacon turret, and, from it, Crabet mill is on with the northern extreme of l'llet at Barfleur. Vessels should keep a mile from the coast between Barfleur and this point whilst the Moulard rock is uncovered. The Moulard is a granite rock on which stands a white beacon turret If cables south-eastward of Moulard point ; this rock uncovers 23 feet at the lowest tides, and is a useful and necessary mark to all who navigate along this part of the coast ; for, when it is covered and the sea smooth , there is water for large vessels over all the hidden dangers between cape Barfleur and La Hougue. Pointe de Saire * is the first prominent point southward of cape Barfleur ; Pernelle hill rises N.W. by W. 3 miles from the point, the church on its summit forming the most remarkable object on this part of the coast. Reville battery is at the extreme of Saire point, and one of the lights used in entering La Hougue r#ad at night is shown from its south-western face ; see page 392. Ridins des Ecraoulettes are sand-banks about a mile from the shore a little northward of the church towers of Pernelle and Reville in line, with not less than 28 feet on their shoalest parts ; Gatteville church tower and the Moulard rock beacon turret in line N.N.W. 4. W. ; or, La Hougue fort tower on with the highest house of the lazaretto on the western side of Tatihou island E.N.E. lead eastward. Dranguet rocks. — About half a mile southward of the Ecraoulettes are the Dranguet rocks, which also extend in patches a mile from the shore. They are dangerous even for small vessels, and there is a high sea over them during a weather tide. The outer rock which uncovers is half a mile from the shore and is marked by a red beacon turret surmounted by a ball. Barfleur church tower on with the Moulard beacon turret leads eastward of the outer shoal, * See Admiralty chart, Rade de la Hougue No. 2,743 ; scale, m = two inches.

The Pont de Saire, or Saire bridge, is a sort of rocky causeway extending a mile south-eastward from Saire point to the line of La Hougue fort tower touching the north-western angle of Fort de l'llet W. £ S., which latter is just southward of Tatihou island. With an on-shore wind, the sea runs very high on this bridge as long as the tide makes north-eastward, i.e., from half flood to low water by the shore. Basses de Reville and de Pernelle. — Several rocky patches lie outside the Pont de Saire, but they are dangerous only in bad weather. Those farthest out are, the Reville with 27 feet, and the Pernelle with 36 feet water. They are 5 cables apart and both lie with Barfleur lighthouse on with Moulard rock beacon turret N. \ W., the Reville 1\ miles, and the Pernelle 1£ miles from Saire point ; the western mark for the Pernelle is, Morsaline light house showing southward of Fort de l'Het W. \ N. northerly. The Coast. — From Saire point, the direction of the coast changes and trends south-westward. St. Vaast point, on which stands the church of the small town from whence the point takes its name, bears S.W. by W. £ W. 1£ miles from Saire point, and the intermediate coast forms a deep bight, at the head of which the waters of the little river Saire, after winding round the northern side of Pernelle hill, lose themselves on a low sandy beach. The fortified island of Tatihou, the small Fort de l'llet on the rocks close southward of that island, and the rocks which surround them, partly close the entrance to this bight ; at low water, they join the mainland by a beach of gravel, sand, and rock ; the whole of the bay from St. Vaast point to the outer rocks of the lie de Tatihou and from thence to La Hougue point being dry, or nearly so, at the lowest tides. The narrow rocky peninsula of La Hougue extends one mile S.W. from St. Vaast point. Fort La Hougue occupies its southern and highest part ; near its centre on the western side is the remarkable old round tower of La Hougue. Westward and north ward of the fort is a sandy bay, one mile in depth and width, but which, at low water, dries completely out to and beyond the extreme point of La Hougue. ST. VAAST.— This small tidal harbour is on the northern side of St. Vaast point, northward of a jetty of masonry extending E. 4 N—

Chap, ix.] 391 THE COAST. — ST. VAAST. 440 yards from the shore, and with an iron lighthouse at its end. From South round by West to North it is sheltered by the land and by this jetty ; and, from the high sea and strong winds from the eastward, by Tatihou island. To protect the harbour from north easterly winds, two breakwaters of rough stone have been constructed ; of these, the South breakwater is 280yards in length N.N.W. and S.S.E.; the North breakwater, 176 yards in length and about North and South in direction. From the northern end of the South breakwater, the southern end of the North breakwater is distant only about 60 yards in an easterly direction, thus overlapping the South breakwater when approaching from the north-eastward. The entrance to the harbour is either between these two breakwaters, or round the end of the South breakwater, between it and a small jetty running off in a north-easterly direction from the main jetty to protect the building and repairing slip just within it. Both entrances are narrow, but the last named is that generally used and is 130 feet wide. The quay frontage is very extensive considering the requirements of the port, being no less than 470 yards in length. The bottom of the harbour is a mixture of sand, gravel, and a little mud, great quantities of rock having been removed and levelled ; the berths are good alongside the quays, but farther off they are hard, the rocks being thinly covered ; here small vessels have to be supported by their legs, and vessels of greater burthen by heaps of fagots placed under their bilges. On the western side, the bottom dries 6 feet, and, on the eastern side, 4 feet above the level of the lowest tides ; at high water, ordinary springs, there are at the berths from 13 to 14 feet water, and, at the lowest neaps, 7 to 8 feet ; the harbour is, therefore, inaccessible to vessels over 12 feet draught under any circumstances. The town of St. Vaast communicates by road through Barfleur with Cherbourg, from which it is distant 24 miles, and from Valogne it is distant by road 114; miles. It contains about 3,500 inhabitants, and the formation of the port, which is entirely artificial, was only commenced in the year 1826. It has a fine hospital, considerable oyster and other fisheries, and its chief foreign trade is with England for coal, and with the Baltic for timber About 800 vessels, including fishing craft and coasters, of an aggregate of 35,000 tons, enter the port annually ; the exports are chiefly fruit and cattle, but are unimportant, vessels usually leaving in ballast. The southern passage to the harbour is between the rocky ridge extending southward from the jetty to La Hougue fort on the

The Plateau du Ouest-Drix spreads out southward of these rocky groups and on it is a shoal spot of 15 feet, 3 cables S. £ E. from the Dent. VAAST.— DIRECTIONS. — PORT DE LA HOUGUE. 393 Harbour lights.— A small fixed red light, visible 5 miles, is shewn from the lighthouse on the outer end of St. Vaast jetty ; and, a small fixed green light visible 2 miles, from the extreme northern end of the small jetty at St. Vaast harbour, opposite the southern end of the South breakwater. Fog signal. — A bell is sounded continuously in foggy weather at the outer end of St. Vaast jetty. (See note, page 10.) A Life-Boat is stationed at St. Vaast Directions. — When bound into St. Vaast harbour, Morsaline lighthouse about a quarter of a point open southward of La Hougue lighthouse W. by N. £ N. leads 2\ cables southward of the 15-feet patch on the Ouest-Drix flat, and when the spire of Reville church opens westward of Fort de l'llet, steer for the end of the jetty, taking care to give a good berth to the remains of three wrecked vessels lying south-westward of Fort de l'llet. Morsaline lighthouse, exactly midway between La Hougue lighthouse and the large tower in the middle of La Hougue fort, leads between the Ouest-Drix patch and the Gavendest ; but, this passage should not be attempted when the sea is heavy, nor should it be used by a stranger at night. It is difficult to leave St. Vaast harbour with the wind between S.W. and S.E., both flood and ebb running to the northward ; but, even with those winds, small vessels with good pilots may leave the harbour at high water, springs, and pass out northward of Tatihou island, keeping about a cable from its northern shore in passing. Tides. — During the whole of the flood, the stream runs northward between St. Vaast jetty and Tatihou island, and, with the falling tide, it follows the same direction until the highest part of the beach joining that island to the land is uncovered, which is at about half ebb. With both streams, at their greatest strength, a strong eddy forms at the end of the jetty and extends over the whole harbour, and with a fresh wind from North to N.E. there is a very confused sea within ; under these circumstances, vessels placed too far from the jetty strike heavily before they float, and also before they ground on the ebb. Port de la Hougue is merely a grounding place, 4 cables long and one cable wide, westward and under the ramparts of La Hougue fort, which partially shelters it from easterly winds ; the water here is generally smooth, but there is considerable sea when it

394 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. blows freshly from S.S.W. round by East to N.E. It admits vessels of about 14 feet draught at high water, springs, and of 9 feet draught at neaps, but since the completion of St. Vaast harbour it is quite deserted ; it might, however, afford useful shelter in bad weather to a vessel of moderate draught compelled to run ashore. The best grounding place is a cable distant from the fort, between the parallels of La Hougue tower and of the wooden storehouse at the foot of the glacis northward of the fort ; this space is bounded westward by a shallow channel which receives all the water flowing from the land. The bottom abreast of the tower dries 74_ feet, and from thence rises gradually towards the northern part of the bay. The bottom is hard, being a mixture of muddy sand and gravel, and yields but little under vessels when aground. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in port de la Hougue at 8h. 42m. The tide rises abreast of La Hougue tower from 14 to 15 feet at springs, and from 74 to %\ feet at the lowest neaps ; in the southern part, it rises 2 or 3 feet higher. Fresh winds from S.W. to West raise the tide a foot or two higher than in calm weather, and winds from N.E. to North have a contrary effect. DANGERS. — The following shoals must be avoided when approaching Port de la Hougue, especially if there is any sea on : — The Manquet, a small isolated rock which uncovers 6 feet E.S.E. a short half mile from La Hougue lighthouse, and which, from its advanced position, is much in the way of vessels navigating between La Hougue and St. Vaast. As already described, a black conical buoy is moored near the eastern edge of this rock. Roche Joly, the top of which uncovers 3 feet, bears W. by S. £ S. 64 cables from La Hougue lighthouse, and, at high water, the sea breaks on it in bad weather. Jean de la Dune is a small group of four rocky heads which only uncover at springs ; the highest head, awash at low water, bears S.S.W. £ W. 7 cables from La Hougue lighthouse. The summits of Jean de la Dune, the Joly, and another rock southward of it, are the highest heads of the Verdieres reef, a rocky flat, lying nearly parallel with the shore, and on which there is a heavy sea with on shore winds. Both the Roche Joly and Jean de la Dune are cleared by keeping Pernelle spire a little open eastward of the Du Loup white beacon, standing on the sands in port de la Hougue.

Chap, ix.] PORT AND RADE DE LA HOUGUE. 395 Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station in Fort de la Hougue, 110 yards north-eastward of the tower. RADE de la HOUGUE.— This anchorage is south-eastward of port de la Hougue, and, although the sand-banks in its vicinity are well known to be shifting, it affords good anchorage for vessels of deep draught. It extends westward as far as the spires of Reville and St. Vaast churches in line N.N.E., and, eastward, as far as the Ouest-Drix flat and the northern part of the Bane de la Rade ; its northern limit is the parallel of the Dent and Gavendest rocks, both marked by red buoys ; and, its southern boundary, the small sand-bank named the Haut-fond de la Grande Rade, on which the least water is 27 feet. The holding ground is good in almost every part of this anchorage, and vessels are well sheltered by the land from winds between S.S.W. and N-W-, which are frequent and dangerous in winter ; but, it is open to winds from N.N.E. to S.S.E., which, even when moderate, send in a troublesome swell, but when blowing with any strength raise a heavy sea. Vessels suspected of having contagious diseases on board are sent from all the northern parts of France to ride out their quarantine in this roadstead, and, at times, many such may be seen at anchor in it. The lazaretto is on the western side of Tatihou island. The Grande Rade is a small deep in the southern part of La Hougue road about 6 cables long in a N.E. and S.W. direction, and 2 cables wide, where large vessels may anchor in excellent holding ground. The best position is in the centre of the deep in from 7 to 8 fathoms, with the church towers of Pernelle and St. Vaast in one N. by W. W. ; and, the Bois de la Ville midway between Quineville church tower and a guard-house on the shore. The Petite Rade is the space included between the Grande Rade and the rocks off La Hougue fort, but good holding ground does not extend much eastward of the line of Reville light touching the south-eastern angle of Fort de l'llet. Between this limit and the Grande Rade, the bottom is of sand and broken shells, and the holding ground is indifferent ; fresh easterly winds also throw in a heavy sea. Pilots anchor vessels in about 4 fathoms, good holding ground, in the space which has the following limits : — Quetehou church tower on with La Hougue point ; Morsaline and La Hougue lighthouses in line ; and, Reville lighthouse open a little eastward of Fort de l'llet.

396 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. From this anchorage, vessels of moderate draught may, if necessary, run for refuge into port de la Hougue. If drawing over 9 feet, however, and therefore unable to enter either St. Vaast or port de la Hougue during the lowest neaps, such vessels should anchor in the northern part of La Hougue road, where the holding ground is good, and they are in some degree sheltered from strong north-easterly winds and sea by Tatihou island and the rocks southward of it. Bane de la Rade. — This bank, of which the northern portion bounds the Rade de la Hougue in a south-easterly direction, is, within the 5-fathoms line, 3£ miles long N. 4. W. and S. \ E. and, abreast of its shoalest part one mile from the northern end, three quarters of a mile wide. There are from 11 to 15 feet on the shoalest parts ; and the northern end, where there are 19 feet close to the 5-fathoms edge, lies one cable eastward of Reville spire on with the tower on Tatihou island ; and, with La Hougue lighthouse bearing N.W. £ W. From this point, the Haut-Fond du Bane de la Rade, a bank with from 4£ to 5 fathoms, extends in a north-easterly direction about 6 cables, to where cape Barfleur and Reville lighthouses are in line N. 4 E. ; and, La Hougue lighthouse bears W.N.W. Directions. — The entrance to La Hougue roadstead is between the shoal spot of 15 feet on the Plateau du Ouest-Drix and the northern part of the Bane de la Rade, sometimes called the Bee shoal, which bear from each other N. £ W. and S. £ E. distant 9 cables. Approaching La Hougue road from the northward, the mariner should take care that his vessel is not drifted southward of it by the flood stream, which, from the extreme of Barfleur race to about 3 miles off Saire point, runs southward, following the direction of the coast, at the rate of 3 knots, at springs ; close to Saire point, it changes its direction suddenly to the South-west. Vessels of deep draught should keep outside the off-lying shoal patches by attending to the marks already given for clearing them. When southward of the shoal water off Saire point, and to avoid the dangers eastward of Tatihou island, cape Barfleur lighthouse must be kept open eastward of Reville lighthouse until Morsaline and La Hougue lighthouses are in line, then steer about W.S.W. for the Grande Rade. Running in on this course near low water, cape Barfleur light will be hidden for a few moments by Tatihou tower ; directly it re-appears westward of the tower bearing N. by E. a vessel should anchor. To anchor in the northern part of La Hougue road by day or night, run in with Morsaline lighthouse just open southward of

Chap. IX.] RADE DE LA HOUGUE. — ILES ST MARCOUF. 397 La Hougue lighthouse, in order to pass about a cable southward of the shoal patch on the Ouest-Drix, and anchor as soon as Reville light is hidden by Fort de l'llet, or by the tower on Tatihou should the light be seen above the fort, which may be the case towards high water. Tidal Streams.— In the middle of La Hougue road, the stream of flood, at springs, begins about 4£ hours before high water in the port, see page 394, and runs about W.S.W. It attains its greatest rate, 2\ knots, about 2£ hours before high water in the harbour, and its mean duration is 5h. 20m. The ebb stream commences about 25 minutes after high water in the port, its mean duration is 7h. 10m., its direction N.E. and E.N.E., and its greatest rate, 24. knots, occurs about 4h. 20m. after high water. ILES ST. MARCOUF.— These two islands and the rocks round them which uncover at low water, with the Bastin rock, are nearly midway between port de la Hougue and the entrance to the Grand Vay, their outer edge being upwards of 4 miles from the coast, and they occupy a space about 8 cables long E.N.E. and W.S.W. and 2\ cables wide. They are but little above the level of high water, but the fort and especially the large case-mated tower on the highest point of the ile du Large, or eastern island, may be seen from 9 to 12 miles distant. These islands, distinguished by the names ile du Large and ile de Terre, are separated by a narrow channel, in which it would be dangerous to anchor in bad weather, as the tidal streams run through with great rapidity ; but, a coasting vessel having missed La Hougue road, with a strong north-westerly wind and flood tide, may anchor during the remainder of the flood in a small bight, named Mannette, on the southern shore of the ile de Terre, provided she is moored securely and steadied by a hawser to the shore, for the eddies formed by the points of that island occasion a heavy sea. LIGHT. — An occulting white light of the fifth order, eclipsed every four seconds, is exhibited from the fort on the ile du Large, the eastern St. Marcouf island, at 56 feet above high water ; in clear weather, it is visible from a distance of 9 miles. Bane de St. Marcouf extends 3 miles in a N.N.W. direction from St. Marcouf ile du Large, and the soundings vary from 26 to 34 feet between it and the southern part of the Bane de la Rade, which lies three quarters of a mile nearer the land. Both banks

398 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. consist of large masses of sand and broken shells, the Bane de St. Marcouf having from 7 to 12 feet on its shoalest parts. The tides cross them obliquely, and occasion strong eddies even in calm weather, and with easterly winds or northerly gales the sea breaks violently upon both banks from half ebb to half flood. St. Marcouf bank has off its northern end a narrow ridge of sand, or Haut-fond, running about If miles in an easterly direction nearly at right angles with the Bane de la Rade, with 4£ fathoms at its eastern extreme and from 54. to 7 fathoms at other parts, and from 10 to 8 fathoms on either side close to ; as it lies nearly across the tidal streams, the eddies produced by this narrow bank, at springs, cause a high sea when it blows hard. St. Marcouf light bearing S. by W., or, cape Barfleur lighthouse open eastward of the Moulard rock beacon turret, lead outside this bank. Bane du Cardonnet extends in a S.E. direction 64^ miles from St. Marcouf ile de Terre to about N. by E. \ E. easterly 3^ miles from Grand Camp church, and forms, at about 4 miles from the coast, a barrier in front of the Grand Vay ; from its south-eastern extreme in 6 fathoms, Colleville church tower is on with point Percee S.S.E. 4 E. easterly. The bank consists of sand and broken shells, and its shoalest spots of from 4 to 10 feet extend from West to S.S.E., about a mile from the island ; it slopes gradually towards the South, but its northern side is steep-to, which causes the sea to break with great violence on it with strong winds from the northward or east ward, or when there is much swell on, and especially during the ebb tide. Farther eastward towards the meridian of Maisy church, the depths on the bank vary from 14 to 17 feet, and the water gradually deepens towards its south-eastern extreme. CHANNEL between ILES ST. MARCOUF and the COAST. — The south-eastern entrance to this channel is about on the meridian of the old ruined mill at Criqueville, and it terminates north-westward at La Hougue roadstead ; it is deep, having 9 fathoms at its south-eastern entrance, gradually shoaling to 54; or 6 fathoms in the North-west, and for deep draught vessels its navigable width is from 1 to 2 miles. It affords good anchorage in moderate weather and with off-shore winds, except W.S.W. of St. Marcouf islands where a rocky bottom about three quarters of a mile wide almost crosses the channel from the shore, and also E.S.E. and S.E. of Quineville, where the rocky shoals of St. Floxel of 4 fathoms water extend If miles from the land. The anchorage

Chap. IX.] fLES ST. MARCOUF.— SHOALS.— CHANNELS. 399 in the south-eastern part, off the entrance to the Grand Vay, is known as Capelle road. The dangers to be avoided at low water are, the north-western part of the Cardonnet, which forms a small bank with from 10 to 14 feet water lying in a N.W. and S.E. direction, three quarters of a mile westward of St. Marcouf ile de Terre ; the rocky shoals of St. Floxel, before mentioned, which extend from the land as far as Pernelle church open 2° eastward of La Hougue tower ; and, the Bavequien rocks, which uncover at low water and border the beach from the parallel of St. Marcouf church as far as the bearing E.N.E. from Quineville church. Local authorities state that a well-found vessel might ride out a heavy gale from the north-eastward in this channel, under shelter of the high parts of the Cardonnet, the St. Marcouf, or the Rade banks, which break the violence of the sea ; it is, however, but precarious shelter and should only be resorted to as a last resource when a vessel is embayed and finds it impossible to gain an offing, for the sea in such weather is sure to be very heavy in the channel between the banks on the flood, and a breaking sea is caused by the weather tide on the ebb. If a vessel is obliged to bring up in this channel, such an anchorage should be chosen, that in case she parts or is compelled to run ashore, she may do so where there is some chance of safety for the crew. The Magdeleine bank at the entrance of the Grand Vay should be carefully avoided, as it is of hard sand, and a vessel running on it in bad weather would certainly go to pieces. Directions. — The channel between the St. Marcouf and Cardonnet banks and the coast may be taken, even at low water, if the weather is moderate and strict attention be paid to the lead. With a fair wind, point Percee and Huppain wood in line S.E. leads in the deepest water between the meridian of Maisy church and St. Marcouf ile de Terre. From thence, steer about N.N.W. until Pernelle church tower, bearing about N. \ W., is 3° or 4° open eastward of La Hougue tower ; keep this mark on until Quineville church bears W.S.W., then haul out north-eastward for the Rade de la Hougue. Tidal Streams. — In the channel between the iles St. Marcouf and the shore, the rate of the streams, at springs, is about 3 knots, and their maximum rate is about the time of half flood and half ebb in port de la Hougue, see page 394. The direction of the flood through La Hougue road is W.S.W. ; at the northern end of

400 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. St. Marcouf bank, S.W. by W.; round the iles St. Marcouf, S.S.W.; on the middle of the Cardonnet bank, South ; and, about a mile eastward of the end of that bank, S.E. In mid-channel, however, the flood stream runs nearly parallel with the shore from the rade de la Hougue as far as the meridian of the iles St. Marcouf, it then turns S.S.W. towards the entrance of the Grand Vay, beyond which it again follows the direction of the shore. The ebb is rather weaker than the flood and runs nearly in an opposite direction. At neaps, both streams are feeble except at the entrance of the Grand Vay. GRAND VAY. — The shore is flat and for the most part com posed of sand-hills from port de la Hougue to the entrance of the Grand Vay, which is an indentation of the coast in the south-western part of the Baie de la Seine ; it is about 4 miles wide and 6 miles deep, and at its head are the small tidal harbours of Carentan and Isigny. The entrance to this deep bight is about 5 miles south ward of the iles St. Marcouf ; it is choked with sand and would probably cease to be navigable but for the extensive harbour works and the periodical freshets from the small rivers Taute and Douve on its western shore, and, Vire and Aure on its eastern shore, whose channels afford sufficient depth for vessels of moderate draught to reach Isigny and Carentan at high tides. Formerly the tide flowed far into the interior, inundating the low lands bordering the rivers ; to remedy this, dykes were constructed at the mouth of each river, with flood gates which close with the rising tide. The church of Ste. Marie du Mont stands conspicuously 2\ miles from the western shore, and the fine church spire at Maisy and the village and church at Grand Camp serve to mark clearly the eastern side of the entrance to the Grand Vay. Magdeleine bank. — The entrance to the Grand Vay is more than half closed by the Magdeleine bank, which uncovers at low water nearly 24_ miles from the western shore and is a continua tion of the sandy strand, half a mile wide, bordering the coast from port de la Hougue southward. The highest parts of this bank are scarcely covered at high water, neaps, and it is considered the most dangerous of the Grand Vay banks, for the streams cross it with great rapidity, and raise a heavy sea on a weather tide. The sand also of which it is composed is so hard that a vessel grounding on it in bad weather would have but little chance. Buoy.— A large bell buoy, painted with black and red bands, is moored off the northern edge of the shoal in about 12 feet water ;

Chap. IX.] 401 GRAND VAY.— CAPELLE ROADS. from it, St. Marcouf light bears N. by E. 4^ miles ; Maisy church spire S. E. by S. 4 miles ; and, the church of Ste. Marie jdu Mont S.W. by W. 4. W. 44 miles. The Ravine bank is an extension of Brevand point, dividing the lower courses of the rivers Taute and Vire. It extends as far northward as the parallel of Maisy point, its summit barely covered at spring tides and the greater part of its surface dry during neaps. The whole space between Maisy point and this bank is occupied by shifting sands ; that named the Feraillon is the only one that does not change its surface, being covered with gravel, beneath which there is said to be solid rock. There is little danger in grounding on the sands within the Grand Vay with smooth water during the dry summer season, for the tides then have but little strength ; but, during abundant rains or with equinoctial tides, the ebb stream is very strong and heaps up the sand under vessels aground, causing them to list over and capsize. MAISY POINT, the eastern point of the Grand Vay, is very low but defended against the heavy sea which sometimes rolls in by the Roches de Grand Camp, a ledge fronting the coast and extending 14^ miles westward and 2£ miles eastward of the point. Buoys. — The Roches de Grand Camp are marked by four black buoys moored from a quarter to half a mile outside their outer edge. LIGHT. — From a mast 875 yards westward of Grand Camp church is exhibited, at 26 feet above high water, a fixed ivhite light visible in clear weather from a distance of 6 miles. Capelle roads. — There is good anchorage off the entrance of the Grand Vay in Capelle roads, where, in moderate weather, vessels may remain until the tide has risen sufficiently to allow of their entering the narrows. This anchorage, about a mile in extent, is bounded westward by the line of Carentan church tower on with the eastern houses of Grand Vay hamlet ; eastward, by the rocky bottom which terminates in the direction of the small redoubt near the shore on with Maisy spire bearing S. £ W. ; and, northward, by the high land of Menil, which rises eastward of port-en-Bessin, on with point Percee ; the latter mark also leads outside the rocky ledge and dangers off Grand Camp. A. 2771. Wt. 17197. 2C

CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER, [Chap. IX. 402 The best berth is, with the end of Menil cliffs on with, or a little open northward of, point Percee ; and, the small redoubt open about a quarter of a point eastward of Maisy spire. At this anchorage, the flood runs S.S.W. and S.W. by S., and the stream changes about half an hour before high water. The most favourable time for entering the narrows is about 14, hours before high water, but, with a head wind, it is prudent to weigh in time to arrive abreast of Grouin point on the eastern shore of the Grand Vay before the commencement of the ebb. ISIGNY, on the eastern side of and 6 miles from the entrance of the Grand Vay, is on the river Aure which joins the Vire just below the town, both rivers being guided to the point of junction between dykes, and, from thence, in one channel in a N. by E. direction, also between embankments or dykes of rough stone, their inner ends above the level of the highest tides and their outer parts awash at high water, neaps. The eastern dyke extends for a distance of 3,046 yards, the western dyke being more than 600 yards longer and ending abreast of Grouin point and about 1£ cables from it. The width between the dykes at the entrance is 102 yards and it narrows to 92 yards at their inner end ; their whole tidal length is marked at short intervals by beacons, red on the starboard hand and black on the port hand in entering. At the town, the width between the quays is only 90 feet ; there is a stone quay 256 feet in length, two small unloading slips, and also building and repairing slips. The staple of the town is butter, of which a large quantity is exported annually, also grain, colza oil, and stone. The population is about 2,500, and the trade is represented by the entry of about 130 vessels annually, of an aggregate of about 9,000 tons. The high road from Paris to Cherbourg passes through Isigny, and, three miles distant from it, is a station on the Paris and Cherbourg railway. The harbour is reported to be gradually deepening since the com pletion of the dykes and embankments, the silting up during the summer, when there is but little water in the Aure, being more than counterbalanced by the scour of the freshets occasioned periodically by heavy rains. There are 134; feet at high water, springs, at the foot of the quay, and 19 or 20 feet in the channel between the dykes, Vessels may lighten, if necessary, during neaps, at Grouin or Beuzeville before proceeding up to Isigny. The Passe d'lsigny, between the western end of the Roches de Grand Camp and the Feraillon bank, is the channel leading from the sea to the dyke heads and thence to Isigny. It is well marked by

Chap, ix.] PORTS ISIGNY AND CARENTAN. 403 buoys and beacons as far as Grouin point, from whence, as before stated, the submersible dykes between which the channel then lies are also marked by beacons at short intervals up to Isigny ; the dis tance from abreast of the inner black buoy of the Roches de Grand Camp to the dyke-ends is nearly 3 miles, and, notwithstanding all the aids to navigation, it is prudent for a stranger to take a pilot. LIGHTS. — There are at Isigny two fixed white leading lights, bearing N. by E. and S. by W. from each other, and 654 yards apart. They are dioptric, of the fourth order, and are respectively 26 and 43 feet above high water, and visible in clear weather from distances of 9 and 12 miles. The lower light is at the point of junction of the Aure and Vire rivers, and the two lights in line lead up the channel between the dykes. CARENTAN, on the river Taute, about 9 miles from the entrance and on the western side of the Grand Vay where the Vire and Taute canal terminates, has also a tidal harbour with a Bassin-a- flot or wet dock at its head. The Bassin-a-flot is entered by a lock 136 feet long, 40 feet wide, and with 17 feet 3 inches over the sill at high water, springs, and 11 feet 7 inches at neaps ; it is nearly 1,600 yards in length by 197 feet in width, its shores thickly planted with trees until near the town, at the upper end, where are 800 feet of substantial stone quay frontage ; the quays communicating by well- paved roads with the railway station about 400 yards distant, From the entrance of the Bassin-a-flot, dykes awash at high water, neaps, at all their outer part, like those of Isigny, the success of which led to the construction of these, extend no less than 7,000 yards, terminating abreast of the little village of Grand Vay. The width between these dykes or embankments at the entrance is 132 yards, narrowing to 71 yards near the upper end ; and, the depth between is 17 feet at high water, springs, and about 14 feet at neaps. The Carentan channel receives the waters of the Vire and Taute canal as well as of the rivers Taute and Douve, and its depth is main- tained and gradually increased by the extensive modern embankments assisted by the scour of these united streams. Entering from seaward, the channel commences near the Grand Vay bell buoy, see page 400, and is well marked on either side for nearly 3 miles up to the dyke-ends by numerous buoys ; the dyke-ends and the whole of their submersible parts are marked by beacons at short intervals, red buoys and beacons being left on the starboard hand in entering, black buoys and beacons on the port hand, as usual. The least water in the channel 2C2

[Chap. IX. 404 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER, between the buoys at high water, neaps, is said to be 15 feet, but being very liable to change, it is dangerous to attempt it without a pilot ; for, to ground on any of the banks at the entrance of the Grand Vay with a strong north-easterly wind, or on the borders of the channel within the entrance during the rainy season when the ebb tide is very strong, would probably cause the loss of the vessel. The town of Carentan contains about 3,000 inhabitants and is the centre of a fertile grazing district ; it was formerly a fortress, but its ramparts have been levelled and ditches filled in. It has a handsome church and spire, manufactures of lace and cotton goods, and a trade in cattle, horses, hemp, flax, butter, building materials, &c. ; besides its coasting trade, the chief traffic is with Southampton and with Norway and Sweden. It is on the direct Paris and Cherbourg rail way, as well as communicating with Cherbourg, Granville, and other places by the national high roads. LIGHTS.— Two fixed leading lights on wooden scaffoldings are exhibited as a guide through the channel of Carentan : viz., a red light on the sea bank 16 feet, and a white light at Brevand 49 feet, above high water ; the upper ivhite light is distant 940 yards S.W. \ W. from the lower and is visible in clear weather 7 miles ; the lower red light being visible 9 miles. The lights show through an arc of 32°, their maximum intensity being when in line, which is the leading mark for the channel. Tides. — The flood stream, at springs, loses its strength when the Grand Vay banks are covered. It crosses the Magdeleine bank with some rapidity, until 3^ or 4 hours flood, and inclines towards the inner banks, which renders the entrance to the channel somewhat difficult with a head wind. The beginning of the ebb is weak, but as soon as the banks begin to uncover its rate rapidly increases. The COAST.— From point Maisy, on the eastern side of the entrance to the Grand Vay, to point Percee, the distance is 54 miles, the general trend of the coast being about E. by S. \ S. ; a mile east ward of Grand Camp church, the land suddenly rises and a perpen dicular chalk cliff about 400 feet high commences, which may be seen 12 or 15 miles off. The land above the cliff is level and without any conspicuous object on it except the church of St. Pierre du Mont, which stands in the midst of a clump of tall trees. From point Percee, cape Manvieux bears S.E. by E. easterly distant 114 miles, the little harbour of Port-en-Bassin lying between them ; and, nearly as far as St. C6me-de-Fresne chapel, 14 miles eastward of

Chap. IX.] THE COAST. — POINT MAISY TO RIVER ORNE. 405 cape Manvieux, the land as seen from the offing appears nearly a level plain upwards of 400 feet above the sea, overtopped only by the church towers and groups of trees surrounding the villages. When nearer the coast, it presents a great variety of aspect ; the chalk cliffs continue to about a mile south-eastward of point Percee, and, from thence as far as the guard-house at Ste. Honorine, the high table-land recedes somewhat from the coast, the shore being low, sandy, and bounded by low sand-hills, in front of which is a beach of muddy sand and shingle about 2 or 3 cables. wide at low water. Between Ste. Honorine guard-house, and St. Come chapel, the shore is again precipitous, consisting of high cliffs of rock and brown clay intersected by narrow valleys, of which some are as deep as the level of high-water mark, but the greater part are only half the depth of the cliffs. Vessels of deep draught may approach to within a mile of the coast between point Percee and cape Manvieux without danger. Eastward of the chapel of St. C6me-de-Fresne, the appearance of the coast changes from cliffs of rock and brown clay to gracefully undulating hills, richly cultivated, and rising with a gentle slope behind the shore as far as the left bank of the river Orne. From cape Manvieux to the Semaphore near St. Aubin point, a distance of 84 miles, the coast trends E. by S. £ S. ; and, from thence, S.E. £ E. 74 miles to the mouth of the Orne at Oyestreham. In the vicinity of Courseulles, the entrance to which is If miles westward of St. Aubin Semaphore, the shore is again of low sand-hills, except in front of the village of St. Aubin, where its direction begins to trend more south-eastward. The highest parts of the Plateau du Calvados are joined to this part of the coast and render a near approach to it dangerous. The different parts of the coast may be recognized from seaward by the clumps of trees surrounding the villages and by the church towers appearing above them. Tailleville hill, south-eastward of Courseulles, is remarkable, as is also the hill at Amfreville on the eastern bank of the Orne, not far from the mouth of that river. Between the low water rocks in front of most of the villages along the coast, there exist small deposits of muddy sand and gravel, called Naus or Anneaux, which afford no shelter with northerly winds, but where, at the commencement of the fine season, the villagers fit out large fishing boats of from 8 to 10 feet draught, when laden. During the winter these boats remain either at Courseulles or in the Orne. Between St. Aubin point and Lyon, the shore is rather high : in other parts it is chiefly sand-hills.

IX. 406 Grand Camp is a little village on the shore between point Maisy and Criqueville and backed by a low hill ; its position is marked at night by the small fixed ivhite light described at page 401. It is an important fishing station, and the inhabitants, principally fisher men and sailors, fit out about forty boats of from 12 to 40 tons burthen, and of from 5 to 10 feet draught ; these boats are moored to buoys on a small sandy strand, dry throughout at low water, springs, and protected from the high sea with on-shore winds by the Grand Camp rocks. Some of the pilots for the Grand Vay reside in this village and others at Isigny. A Life-Boat is stationed at Grand Camp. Point Percee is the north-eastern point of the high chalk cliffs which border the shore from about a mile eastward of Grand Camp to a mile south-eastward of point Percee. The point projects but little and is remarkable only from the change in the direction of the coast. A flat of sand and gravel, divided into several parallel banks, extends about E.N.E. three quarters of a mile from the point ; the eddies occasioned by these banks, which lie across the tidal streams, cause a slight race on a weather tide, but it is not dangerous to decked vessels. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station on point Percee. PORT-EN-BESSIN * is seven miles eastward of point Percee ; it is at the opening of one of the most considerable of the valleys which intersect the high cliffs of rock and brown clay on this part of the coast. The opening is about 130 yards wide between the cliff of Huppain on the West and of Castel on the East. Within the opening, the valley suddenly widens and forms a circular plain more than a mile in diameter, of which the level is from 15 to 20 feet above high water ; it is almost entirely surrounded by gently sloping hills. The shore in front of the valley is a steep beach of small pebbles and shingle, and, when the sea is smooth, affords a good grounding place for fishing boats, which are hove up out of the reach of the sea by capstans. Fronting this beach is a break in the rocks which border the shore, forming a natural basin, 140 yards wide and 2 cables long, with sand and gravel bottom, having 21 feet in it at high water, ordinary springs, and 27 feet at equinoctial springs. Chap. IX.] 407 PORT-EN-BESSIN. 1845, and up to 1860, no less than £1,000,000 has been expended in the attempt to transform this small natural basin into a harbour of refuge. Two massive moles, their bases 550 yards apart, extend from the shore, their ends curving towards each other and leaving an entrance about 110 yards wide ; the western mole is 500 yards in length, the eastern mole 35 yards less. Several mooring buoys are laid down within this space, but, with northerly winds, in weather when a vessel would require refuge, the sea is so high and the surf so great that it would be impossible to run for this harbour and unsafe for any vessel already in it. The village of Bessin has a population of about 800, it is con nected with the city of Bayeux, about 6 miles distant, by road, and, through it, with the general railway system; it has a large and grow ing fishery but its coasting and other trade is insignificant; a few small vessels of about 150 tons arrive annually during the fine season with coal from England and timber from the Baltic, and sail again in ballast. A Life-Boat is stationed at Port-en-Bessin. LIGHTS. — A fixed white lower light, visible 6 miles, is shown from a wooden staff at Port-en-Bessin at 90 feet above high water. An upper red or white tidal light 131 feet above high water is also exhibited S.W. southerly 79 yards from the fixed white lower light ; it shows red when there are less than 11 feet water on the banks within the port, and is then visible 9 miles. At all other times it shows white and is visible 14 miles, but whether showing ivhite or red it can only be seen within 18° on each side of the centre of the channel, its brilliancy decreasing as its distance from the centre increases. Both upper and lower lights are catoptric and of the fifth order ; when in line they show the direction of the entrance. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Port-en-Bessin at 8h. 57m. ; equinoctial springs rise 26 feet; ordinary springs 20 feet; neaps 15^ feet. There are 27 feet water between the mole-heads at high water, springs, and 224 feet at neaps. Tide signals are made from a mast on the inner end of the eastern mole; they indicate the depth within that mole. At low water, abundant springs of fresh water issue from apertures in the rocks which dry at that time. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on the cliff just westward of Port-en-Bessin.

408 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. Arromanches, a pretty little fishing village used as a watering-place by the inhabitants of Bayeux, stands on the sea shore at the entrance of a wide valley three quarters of a mile east ward of cape Manvieux ; and, as it is very conspicuous from seaward, it serves to point out the position of that cape, which otherwise has little to distinguish it but its height, and the steep cliff in which it terminates. The villagers fit out small half-decked fishing vessels which, by means of capstans, they heave up a shingle beach much resembling that at Port-en-Bessin. A rocky shore, which uncovers seaward nearly half a mile at low water and forms a point advancing in an easterly direction from cape Manvieux, arrests the sea during northerly winds, and diminishes the violence of the surf on the beach, which is otherwise very exposed. PLATEAU de CALVADOS.— This rocky flat commences just eastward of Arromanches, and extends 13 miles eastward along the coast, as far as Lyon. The parts of the flat which uncover are, the Calvados rock, from which the name of the flat is derived ; the Roches de Ver ; the Essarts de Langrune ; and, the Roches de Lyon. A tradition exists that a forest of chestnut trees, called the forest of Hautefeuille, originally covered the rocks which dry at low water between Bernieres and Lyon, and that its destruction took place about 300 years since ; roots of chestnut trees are said to be found in the tissues of these rocks, and they are so difficult to extract, and the wood so hard that it blunts the best tools. Calvados Rock is one mile from the shore, its north-western edge bearing N. by E. E. 14 miles from St. C6me-de-Fresne chapel. It is about half a mile long W.N.W. and E.S.E., and 3 cables wide ; its western part is highest, and uncovers 3 feet above the lowest tides. The chapel on with the spire of Bazanville church, which stands on the top of the hills two miles inland, bearing S. \ W., leads three cables westward. The north-western end of the Plateau de Calvados bears N.E. by E. one mile from the western edge of the Calvados rock; it is steep-to, and, from this point, preserves a distance of from 1\ to 2\ miles from the shore as far as Essarts point, the north-eastern extreme of the flat, which lies 3 cables westward of Langrune and Douvres church spires in line bearing S.S.W. £ W. ; with Ver lighthouse bearing W. \ N. ; and, Oyestreham semaphore, at the entrance of the river Orne, S.S.E. \ E. easterly. From Essarts point, which is 24. miles from the shore, the

Chap. IX.] PLATEAU DE CALVADOS.— ANCHORAGE. 409 edge of the flat turns sharply southward, and, approaching the coast within a mile, continues at that distance until it is lost beneath the sands which dry westward of the mouth of the river Orne. Essarts point is the most dangerous part of the plateau, having on it only 4 feet water and rising suddenly from a depth of 20 feet; it occasions a change in the direction of the tidal streams and causes a race, during springs, on a weather tide. There is but little water on all parts of the flat, and, the rocks being uneven, a heavy sea breaks on them when it blows hard from the northward. Buoys. — A black buoy is moored 5 cables N.N.W. from the north western edge of the Plateau de Calvados and rather more than one mile from the western edge of the Calvados rock. A red bell buoy is moored in 7 fathoms N.E. by E. one mile from Essarts point, with Langrune and Douvres spires in line ; and, the outer black buoy at the entrance of the Oyestreham channel S.S.E. 4 E. easterly 5£ miles. Caution. — Both the buoys marking this flat are liable to drift, therefore their being in position cannot always be depended on. Anchorage. — A small anchorage with good holding ground, named the Fosse d'Espagne, lies midway between Arromanches and the Calvados rock, in a small elbow formed by the steep western side of the Calvados flat. The best position in which to anchor is in about 20 feet water, with Crepon church tower seen between those of Mevaisnes and Asnelles ; and, the tall spire of Bernieres on with the houses of Ver hamlet nearest to Ver lighthouse ; this anchorage is entirely exposed to all but off-shore or moderate easterly winds. The soundings deepen rather suddenly outside the Calvados flat ; but, there is no good anchorage ground at a less distance than a mile from its deep western edge, or than 2 miles from its eastern edge. Directions. — Vessels of deep draught may approach to within about a mile of the shore, even at low water, between point Percee and cape Manvieux, but it is imprudent to stand in so near with northerly winds. Coasters keeping close in, with off-shore winds, should be on their guard against the gusts which proceed from the valleys. Good holding ground may be found at 2 or 3 miles from the coast, where vessels sometimes anchor to await the turn of the tide. The tidal streams follow nearly the direction of the shore, and their greatest strength, at springs, does not exceed 3| knots. In approaching the Essarts point of the Calvados flat from the eastward, keep northward of Ver church tower on with the clump of

CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. 410 trees at Epine,* bearing W. \ S., until Langrune and Douvres spires are in line S.S.W. £ W. In rounding the point from the eastward, keep Lyon church tower open westward of the western house of St. Aubin-d'Arquenay village, bearing about South, until the line of Langrune and Douvres spires in one is crossed. LIGHT.— Pointe de Ver lighthouse stands 800 yards inland upon the slope of a small hill 4£ miles eastward of Cape Manvieux and 10\ miles westward of the entrance to the river Orne ; it is a square tower from which is exhibited at 138 feet above high water a fixed white light, varied by a bright flash every four minutes ; the flash is preceded and followed by a short eclipse which is not total when within the distance of 6 miles. The light is dioptric, of the third order, and is visible in clear weather from a distance of 18 miles. By day, Ver lighthouse may be easily recognised in approaching it from eastward or westward ; but, between the bearings of S.E. and S.W., it is difficult to distinguish on account of the high land behind it, The light was established to give warning of approach to the Calvados flat and to afford means of avoiding that danger ; but, it is very useful to vessels from the westward with southerly winds bound to Havre, who, after passing cape Barfleur, sight this light, if possible, 9 or 12 miles distant, and, from thence, steer for the lights on cape de la Heve which then soon appear to the eastward. By this means, they avoid making the land too far northward of Havre and the consequent delay in entering their port. COURSEULLES. — This small tidal harbour, 24_ miles eastward of Ver lighthouse and 84_ miles westward of Oyestreham near the entrance of the river Orne, is in fact the channel through which the waters of the river Seulle are conducted, intercepted by a dam which forms the head of the inner harbour or Bassin-a-flot, in which they are retained or discharged at pleasure by means of sluices into the outer harbour, and from thence through the channel to sea. The entrance channel is between two wooden jetties running nearly parallel with each other ; the western jetty is 196 yards in length, the eastern jetty not quite so long. The width between them is only 122 feet at their outer end and 90 feet at their inner end, and there * This olump of trees, called the Bois des Epines, consists of a few large elms, is very conspicuous, and being used as a landmark, the local authorities are careful to preserve it. It stands at the foot of the hills between Ver lighthouse and the Chateau de Vaux, at nearly a quarter of a mile from the shore.

Chap. IX.] POINTE DE VER LIGHT.— COURSEULLES. 411 are 13 feet water on the bar 50 yards outside the western pier at high water, springs. The channel within the jetty-heads is somewhat deeper, though subject to temporary accumulations of sand, but, in ordinary weather, at high water, springs, it admits vessels of 10 or 12 feet draught. At the inner end of the jetties is the outer harbour, a mere widening of the channel between rough stone embankments, with numerous sets of berthing piles and extensive quays averaging 60 feet in width. The outer harbour is 635 yards long with a maximum width of only 49 yards. At its head is the entrance to the inner harbour or Bassin a-flot, which is by a single pair of flood-gates, with a depth over the sill of 14 feet at high water, springs, and 9 feet at neaps ; and, a width of 32 feet. Its length is 320 yards, and width 614 yards ; on its western side, a slip occupies a space of 1584^ yards. The depth in the Bassin-a-flot is about 14 feet 6 inches at high water, springs, and is lowered to about 10 feet at low water by the sluices before mentioned. It also has ample quay accommodation of very solid construction. Courseulles has the advantage of direct railway communication with Caen through the little town of Luc, a thriving watering place between Courseulles and Oyestreham, and, from thence, with the general system of France. Its trade, however, with the exception of a rather extensive fishery, is small, its imports being coal and Baltic timber, and its exports nil. The total annual tonnage entering the port, including a few small steamers, is about 28,000 tons. The waters of the Seulle are not sufficiently rapid or abundant to maintain a deep straight channel through the sands extending half a mile in front of the entrance and terminating seaward at the Ver rocks, the Germain rock, and the Essarts de Bernieres. The channel is distinctly marked as far as 2 cables outside the jetties ; beyond that distance, the water spreads out and flows in a number of small shifting streams. Buoys. — A black buoy with staff and ball is moored a little southward of the Marguerite rock, and about three quarters of a mile N. by E. from the jetty-heads ; the Marguerite rock is awash at low water. Nearer the harbour, the channel is marked by 3 buoys, viz., a red buoy to be left on the starboard hand in entering, a black buoy to be left on the port side, and, the third and largest, a buoy painted with red and black bands, farther out where the channel ceases to be well defined ; this buoy may be passed on either side. All these inner buoys are moored securely in order that vessels approaching

412 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. the harbour with a head wind may use them for warping. To do this, they should contrive to get up to the outer buoy, where there are several feet more water than on the bar, a full hour before high water, and so have time to warp into harbour during the remainder of the flood. The sea is smooth at the entrance with southerly winds ; and, if the ebb prevents their entering, they may remain aground without danger. The sand frequently accumulates westward of the entrance, forming banks so high as to prevent access to the western jetty -head, except by the channel itself. This drifting of the sand renders it difficult and even dangerous to enter the harbour with stormy winds between West and N.N.W. when vessels have wind, sea, and also the flood tide on their broadsides. Winds between N.N.E. and E.N.E. cause much sea at the entrance, but vessels of suitable draught may always enter with those winds at high tide ; the services of a pilot are, however, always essential to a stranger. LIGHTS. — A. fixed ivhite light of the fifth order is exhibited at 30 feet above high water, from a mast on Courseulles western jetty head ; it is visible in clear weather 6 miles, but is said to be frequently hidden by fog and mist. A. fixed green light 25 feet above high water and visible 4 miles, is shown from an iron standard on the eastern jetty, 23 feet from the head. This light is exhibited only when there are less than 64 feet in the channel. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Courseulles at 9h. 7m. ; ordinary springs rise 20 feet, neaps 154 feet. Tide Signals. — The depth of water in the channel commencing at 6£ feet is signalled from a mast and yard erected on the shore near the inner end of the eastern jetty ; see page 8. Directions.— The mound and trees at Tailleville, the fine spire at Bernieres, and Ver lighthouse, are all excellent objects by which the position of Courseulles may be determined from a distance. With northerly winds, a vessel should run for the harbour either between the Germain rock, which uncovers 4 feet, and the Essarts de Bernieres ; or, between the Ver rocks and the Germain, which are separated from each other by channels, through which, with an on-shore wind, it is advisable to pass in order to avoid the sea which sometimes breaks on these rocks. Chap. IX.] COURSEULLES.— ORNE RIVER. 413 S.W. by W. leads to the harbour entrance between the Germain and the Essarts de Bernieres. Beny spire on with the small church tower at Courseulles S. 4; E. leads between the Ver rocks and the Germain, and a little westward of the Vallette rock on which the sea breaks ; but, in running for the harbour from this side, it is better to pass eastward of the Vallette rock by bringing Beny spire on with a little mound on which there is a small battery, a cable eastward of the eastern jetty, bearing South ; this leads direct to the outer red and black harbour buoy, passing one cable eastward of the Vallette and the same distance westward of the Marguerite rock, which latter is awash at low water and is at the south-western extreme of the shelf of rock separating the Courseulles deep from the Anneau de la Marguerite.* During several hours of the tide, in ordinary weather, vessels may cross the outer shoals and find safe anchorage either in the Anneau de la Marguerite in from 3 to 4£ fathoms, or in the Fosse de Courseulles in 24; fathoms, and wait until there is sufficient depth for them to enter Courseulles harbour. The layer of mud covering the rock at these anchorages is both deep and stiff. ORNE RIVER. — The river Orne has its source near Seez, and from thence it trends in a north-westerly direction until it enters the department of Calvados, where it turns to N. by E., in passing Caen ; here it becomes navigable, and, 9 miles below that town, finds its way into the sea between the sand-hills of Siege and Merville points, nearly 10 miles eastward of Courseulles and more than a mile eastward of Oyestreham church. At low water, the river formerly ran by winding channels through the wide expanse of sand which dries 2 miles out from the shore at the entrance. To obtain a greater depth of water, a submersible dyke, marked by beacons, was constructed, commencing just inside Merville point and extending 1£ miles in a north-westerly direction outside Siege point and ending about 1^ cables north-eastward of the pier-heads of Oyestreham, thus confining the stream to one channel, which, turning sharply round Siege point, flows between the land and the dyke for its whole length north-westward and, from thence, through the sands to the sea in front of Oyestreham in a general N. by E. direction. This channel, therefore, forms the entrance to Oyestreham and also to the river Orne itself ; but, since the construction of the direct * A rock with only 2} feet water has been found 109 yards westward of the buoy marking the Marguerite rock. Vessels must, therefore, be careful not to come eastward of the leading mark given until southward of that buoy.

[Chap. IX. 414 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. canal from Oyestreham to Caen, in which a depth of 14 feet 6 inches is maintained, the navigation by the river to that city, except by the small Havre passenger steamers, has been entirely abandoned and needs no further notice, though vessels of 8 or 9 feet draught may still use it. The sand-banks in the lower course of the river, and off its entrance, are shifting and change their height, shape, and position almost every tide, rendering it most imprudent to venture in without a pilot ; for, to ground on them would almost always involve the loss of the vessel. The parts least subject to change are those near low water mark ; they are always covered during neaps and only uncover a short time at springs. The banks formed on this part of the shore are named by the pilots battures, and, with strong northerly winds, there is a heavy sea on them on the flood and breakers on the ebb. The Oiseaux, the high banks on the western side of the entrance, have a decided tendency to extend eastward, thus slowly forcing the channel and its entrance in that direction. CAEN is 9 miles from the sea by the river, and 7^ miles by the canal ; it is at the confluence of the rivers Orne and Odon, is on the Paris and Cherbourg railway, and is a place of great importance, with a population in 1886 of 43,809. It may be con sidered a double port, having its wet dock or Bassin-a-flot entered by the Oyestreham canal, and its natural tidal grounding harbour in the bed of the river Orne, which also has an entrance into the Bassin a-flot, and some quay frontage but little used now. The Bassin-a-flot is rectangular, is entered from the canal by a lock 40 feet wide at the gates, is 622 yards in length by 55 yards in width, and has a general depth of 15 feet. It has good quays, steam cranes, and two careening slips for small vessels, but no dry dock. It communicates with an inner basin with 1350 yards of quays, on which rails are laid, and vessels unload direct into railway trucks. Coals may be obtained with facility, though not often required, at from 16s. to 18s. per ton, about 3000 tons being usually in stock. There is, however, a deficiency of general supplies for shipping, and also of store accommodation, considering the growing trade of the port ; and, facilities for repairs of machinery are very limited. The hospital of the hotel Dieu is open to sailors in case of illness or accident, a small fee only being required. In the year 1887, 541 vessels of an aggregate of 159,138 tons, arrived at Caen. The imports are chiefly coal and timber ; the exports, Caen stone, barley, colza oil, cake, &c.

Chap. IX.] CAEN. — OYESTREHAM HARBOUR. 415 OYESTREHAM HARBOUR— This harbour, which forms the entrance to the canal de Caen, was constructed to remedy the numerous difficulties presented to navigation at the entrance of the river Orne, and in its tortuous course to Caen ; it consists of a fine tidal basin with stone quays on either side 14; cables eastward of Oyestreham battery, communicating directly by means of the canal, already described, with the port of Caen ; through this canal, vessels of from 12 to 14 feet draught can proceed to that port, the ser vices of a tug being always obtainable at Oyestreham. The tidal basin is 320 yards long and 100 yards wide, forming, in the midst of the sand-hills, a small harbour which admits vessels of 17 feet draught ; at its head is a lock 328 feet long, 23 feet over the outer sill, and 54 feet wide, by which vessels bound for Caen enter the canal at high water. The tidal basin has for its entrance from seaward, a channel 409 yards long and 44 yards wide, enclosed between two jetties of unequal length, opening into the outer elbow of the channel of the Orne, as described at page 413. These jetties are built up to the level of high water, neaps, and the western jetty is the longest. Unfortunately, the volume of water discharged by the Orne, though aided by the recent lengthening of its submersible dyke and by periodical sluicings from the Oyestreham canal, is not sufficient to overcome the silting up at the pier-heads caused by the easterly drift of the sands, and, in November 1884, the authorities reported that the sand-bank marked by three beacons at the outer end of the western jetty, had extended 55 yards eastward, leaving only a narrow channel by the eastern jetty.* Buoys. — Two red buoys mark the western side of the channel leading to the entrance of Oyestreham harbour and mouth of the Orne, and four black buoys the eastern side. The outer red buoy is 5| cables from the western jetty-head ; the inner red buoy is moored a little eastward of the same jetty head. The outer black buoy bears N. by E. 4 E. easterly, nearly 14 miles from the western jetty-head, and may be passed close to on its * On the 18th April 1888, the French authorities again reported that this bank, after being completely removed by dredging in the preceding year, had again formed ; and, at this date, commencing from about 30 feet northward of the West pier-head, it extended along inside and against this pier until within about 64 feet of the extreme of the East pier; a large portion dries; its greatest breadth, about 64 feet, is midway between the extremes of the two piers, and the channel, by the East pier is no more than 95 feet wide.

416 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. western side. The second black buoy is \\ cables from the same jetty, and the channel lies between it and the outer red buoy. The third black buoy lies close to the northern end of the submersible dyke and about E. by N. \ N. 1\ cables from the western jetty-head. The fourth black buoy, which is only useful to vessels entering the channel leading to Siege point, is about half a cable eastward of the eastern jetty-head and within the line of the submersible dyke. Pilots. — There are several pilots at Oyestreham ; it is said that they will meet a vessel, even during northerly gales, at a quarter of a mile outside the harbour's mouth. The channel leading to the entrance of Oyestreham harbour being so very liable to change, as before remarked, no vessel should attempt it without a pilot ; the depth, however, may be calculated approximately by deducting 8 feet from the known height of tide at Havre. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station at Oyestreham 34; cables westward of the jetties ; it is among the sand-hills and not easily made out. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in Oyestreham harbour, at 9h. 38m. ; springs rise 21 feet, neaps 16 feet. With strong westerly winds for several successive days, the water falls less and rises higher ; with easterly winds, the contrary is the case. Tide Signals. — The usual tide signals are shown from a mast near the western jetty-head ; see page 8. A Life-Boat is stationed at Oyestreham. LIGHTS. — A small green tidal light, of 4 miles range, is shown from a mast 66 feet from the western jetty -head ; it is lighted 3 hours before and extinguished 3 hours after high water. A red light, visible 4 miles, is shown from an iron post at the end of the eastern jetty. A while fixed light of the fifth order is shown from 3 hours before to 3 hours after high water, from an iron lighthouse, painted white, at the eastern side of the lock entrance at the head of Oyestreham tidal basin. This light is 64 feet above high water and visible 10 miles distant ; when seen between those at the jetty -heads, it leads in the best water when near the jetties. Fog Bell. — A bell is sounded continuously in foggy weather from the western jetty. (See note, page 10.)

Chap. IX.] OYESTREHAM. — RADE DE CAEN. — RIVER DIVES. 417 Directions. — The most favourable winds for entering Oyestreham harbour are those from N.W. round by North to E.S.E. When they are moderate, the sea is not heavy on the banks, but it must be borne in mind that with sufficient water for entering, the tide is always running eastward ; however, with a good pilot and the wind anywhere between the points indicated, a vessel may enter the harbour by day or night without the aid of the steam-tug, leaving all black buoys on the port hand, and red buoys on the starboard hand. Without a pilot, on account of the shifting nature of the sands forming the channel, it should never be attempted by a stranger. RADE de CAEN, about 3 miles N.N.W. from Oyestreham jetties, affords good anchorage with off-shore winds for vessels wait ing tide to enter the harbour, but it would be dangerous to be caught there by strong winds from the opposite direction. The eastern limit of the road is the meridian of Oyestreham battery; its northern limit, Bernieres spire on with the houses on St. Aubin point ; and, its southern limit, Bernieres spire on with the small church tower at St. Aubin. Pilots usually place large vessels between these limits in about 6 fathoms water, with Luc church tower open half a point southward of Beny spire ; here, they can weigh and stand off-shore if the wind should veer to the northward. THE RIVER DIVES.— The entrance to this river lies about E. by S. 6 miles from Oyestreham jetties, the intermediate coast being composed of sand-hills, or dunes, several of which are sufficiently high to be recognised at the distance of 5 or 6 miles. A sandy strand, about half a mile wide at low water, borders the coast, but, in front of the river entrance, it now dries for 1£ miles and gradually increases in width. In fine weather and with no swrell, this river admits vessels of 11 or 12 feet draught, at springs, and 7 feet at neaps ; but, with much fresh water in the river, and when the channel and berths are washed out, or during equinoctial tides, vessels of 15 feet draught may enter with a smooth sea. At all tides, the few small vessels using this little harbour lie on the grounding places within the entrance and are well sheltered by Cabourg point. They are safe, although in an uneasy position, for, the bottom being stiff and unyielding, they cannot stand upright. Those that only remain one tide are placed on the left bank of the river, and those that take in or discharge cargo, alongside a small quay or near the steep bank of the Mauvais-Pas, at the foot of the Balise de Dives, a hillock near the entrance. [Chap. IX. 418 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. The waters of the Dives run out over the sandy strand just described. Attempts have been made by means of a sub mersible dyke to confine and deepen the channel, but with only partial success ; it trends N. \ E. half a mile from the entrance and then inclines more easterly as far as the outer edge of the sand, which is abrupt and, with strong winds between North and West, causes a heavy sea at the entrance on the flood, and breakers as soon as the ebb stream begins to gain strength. The little harbour of Dives is by nature much better calculated to make a really good harbour than any of those previously described in the Baie de la Seine. It has, however, no railway connection, and its trade is entirely unimportant and declining. It is remarkable as being the port from which William the Conqueror embarked with his army for the conquest of England. Buoys and Beacons. — Three wooden beacons and four buoys, two red and two black, mark the entrance channel ; the two inner beacons are on either side of the channel near the shore, one at the western edge close to the foot of Cabourg point, the other about a cable from it on the eastern edge. The third beacon is also on the eastern side, 3 or 4 cables farther out. The beacons are seldom moved, but the buoys are shifted wmenever the course of the channel undergoes any decided alteration. There are, in addition, two beacons surmounted by discs on the shore which act as leading marks by day, as the lights do by night. The lower leading beacon is coloured red, black, and white ; and is close to the tower of the high light. The high leading beacon is on the slope of Beuzeval hill and is black. The lower beacon is move able, to suit the line of direction to the changes of the channel. LIGHTS. — Two fixed red lights, visible 9 miles, through an arc of 32°, are established on the eastern side of the mouth of the river Dives ; when in line, they mark the fairway into the channel. The lower light is shown only so long as there is a depth of 6| feet or more. They bear about N. 4 E. and S. h W. from each other and are 195 yards apart ; they are respectively 148 and 10 feet above high water, the lower light being shown from a moveable wooden structure, the upper light from a stone turret. Directions. — Northerly winds are the best for entering the river Dives, but it is necessary to wait for high water, whatever the vessel's draught, except at springs, when with a smooth sea, small vessels may venture in an hour after high water, if there is wind enough to

Chap, ix.] RIVER DIVES.— SEINE ESTUARY. 419 stem the tide. With off-shore winds, the entrance should only be attempted by small vessels, and they should be prepared for the heavy gusts coming down from the high land through the valleys. The pilots have no good boats for boarding vessels outside the entrance in bad weather. A vessel, therefore, compelled to enter the river with a strong northerly wind, must contrive to be about 14_ miles from the shore on the meridian of the Balise de Dives at high water. From thence, bring the leading beacons in line, and steer in between the entrance beacons, leaving the two black buoys and outer beacon on the port hand and the two red buoys on the starboard hand ; when near the entrance between the two inner beacons, a pilot will be met with to conduct her to the grounding place. Anchorage. — There is good anchorage off the entrance to the Dives 14 or 2 miles from the shore, where, in fine weather, a vessel may remain until there is sufficient water in the channel. With a turning wind into the river, it is necessary to anchor in order to retain a favourable position ; for, the velocity of the flood stream is here considerably increased by the indraught of the river Seine, and a vessel remaining under sail would be drifted to leeward of the entrance. No vessel should, however, remain at anchor unless the weather continues fine and the wind is off-shore ; should it come from seaward, with no certainty of entering the river at high water, it is necessary to weigh without delay and seek refuge either at Havre or Honfleur. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at the entrance of the river Dives at 9h. 39m. ; springs rise 21 feet, neaps 16 feet ; but, in the shoalest part of the channel abreast of the eastern beacon, where the bottom is 8 feet above the level of the lowest tides, the water rises about 16 or 17 feet at ordinary springs, 18 or 19 feet at equinoctial springs, and 7 or 8 feet at neaps. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on the summit of point Beuzeval, about one mile eastward of the entrance of the river Dives. ESTUARY of the SEINE.— The low coast from the river Orne, consisting of sand-hills, terminates with the left bank of the river Dives, and the land suddenly rises upon its opposite bank. Beuzeval hill, which commands the entrance to the Dives, and cape de la Heve, which bears N.E. N. 13 miles from Beuzeval point, are the most western of the high lands between which lies the estuary of 2D3

420 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. ix. the Seine ; and, an imaginary line drawn from Beuzeval point to cape de la Heve may be considered the boundary between the sea and river navigation. In fact, this line is approximately the western limit of the accumulation of sand and mud deposited by the waters of the Seine, forming dangerous shoals in the mouth of that river ; no vessel of deep draught should approach this limit, nor should small vessels, except during high water, unless bound to. Havre, Honfleur, Rouen, or any other port of the Seine. It is also in the neighbour hood of this limit that the flood stream of the river begins to acquire its strength.* The principal banks obstructing the mouth of the Seine are, the Trouville, the Ratier, the Amfard, the Hauts de la Rade, and the Eclat, the higher parts of which uncover at low water ; the two first are near the southern shore, the Amfard in the centre, and the two last near the northern shore, between Havre and cape de la Heve. In 1855, it was found that the Hauts de la Rade and the Eclat had not undergone any perceptible alteration since 1834, but the banks southward and eastward of them had altered considerably. The Amfard and Ratier banks divide the mouth of the Seine into three channels of about equal breadth, which, at low water, have no issue eastward and abut on the shifting sands, then uncovered, within the river. In these channels, the stream runs 7 or 8 knots at springs, and 4 or 5 knots at neaps, and vessels of deep draught should avoid approaching them during the flood, for if once they should be carried amongst these sands and ground on them, they would certainly be lost ; nor could they be saved by anchoring, for anchors will not hold in the shifting sand, and the violence of the stream, which increases its velocity in advancing eastward, is irresistible. The inner part of the estuary is encumbered by a vast mass of these shifting sands which dry when the sea retires, and through which the tidal streams and the waters of the river force a channel with so changeable a position that the interval of a few days only is sometimes sufficient to transport it from one bank of the river to the other. Vessels are exposed to great danger if they attempt this channel without the assistance of the pilots of Quillebœuf, who are specially appointed to conduct vessels above Havre and Honfleur. It is the duty of these pilots to watch the changes in the position of the banks, and to mark the actual direction of the channel by beacons, see page 422.
