Chap, ix.] 421 SEINE ESTUARY — THE BORE. in sufficient number to meet the requirements of navigation. At either of these places, vessels bound up the Seine can also procure steam-tugs, which are now generally used to ensure a speedy passage past the dangers of the lower Seine. The bed of the river being inclined towards the sea, the flood stream is checked for some time at the commencement of the rising tide, but as soon as the accumulation of water overcomes the obstacles in its way it rushes through the channels and over the banks, losing little of its rapidity until the banks are entirely covered ; it is then that the river becomes navigable. In summer, the ebb stream has rather less speed but runs longer than the flood ; during the rainy season, and at the melting of the snow, it has in general more strength than the flood. The channel of the Seine undergoes such frequent and extraordinary changes that a description of it would be entirely useless to mariners. We will therefore only give some general extracts from the " Remarks on the Navigation of the Seine," by Mons. Bailly, Marine Surveyor : — " The Seine is subject to the phenomenon of the Mascaret, or Bore, which by the mariners of the place is named the Flot. It takes place as soon as the tide begins to rise, and may be known by a sort of roller, which extends from one bank of the river to the other, and advances with greater or less rapidity according to the range of the tide. It is always accompanied by a loud noise, which announces its approach, and is followed by the undulations occasioned by the reflux of the waters of the river. At Quillebœuf it attains its greatest strength, but it extends far beyond, and is sometimes to be found above Rouen. " The greater number of accidents that happen to vessels navigating the Seine may be attributed to this Bore ; for should a vessel from any cause take the ground, it frequently happens, especially during springs, that when the flood reaches her she is thrown on her broad side and buried in the sand set in motion by the strength of the stream, and as it is then impossible to send any assistance she becomes, in almost every case, a lost vessel. The number of masts sticking up in various parts of the river testify that these misfortunes are not unfrequent, and the greatest attention should therefore be paid by commanders of vessels ascending the river until they arrive at Quillebœuf, where they can be secured to the quay before their vessels are exposed to the danger of grounding in the channel. If they cannot arrive at this position before the end of the flood they must hasten to take shelter either at Honfleur or Havre, whilst there is yet sufficient water in the narrow channels. Generally speaking,

422 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. they should not attempt to ascend or descend the river without a leading wind or in tow of a steam-vessel. "Sailing vessels at Havre or Honfleur intending to ascend the Seine, should leave those ports directly they float, and, with a leading wind, they may expect to reach Quillebœuf before the ebb begins to be felt. This navigation, however, can only be undertaken with safety during springs, for, at neaps, the depth of water is not sufficient for vessels of much draught to navigate the lower part of the river. Most vessels waiting at Havre for springs to ascend the river, quit the harbour on the ebb preceding the flood which is to take them up to Quillebœuf, and anchor in the Petite Rade ; by doing so, they avoid the loss of time which the getting out of the harbour would occasion with westerly winds, and do not run the risk of losing a favourable tide." Caution. — To show the danger attending the Bore ; on the 8th February, 1871, H.M. gunboat Pheasant, while at anchor off Quille bœuf, lost a bower anchor and 30 fathoms of chain. The vessel at the time was riding to the ebb, which was running at the rate of 4 or 5 knots, when the Bore, without any warning, came up the river in two waves of from 6 to 8 feet in height and travelling at the rate of 6 to 7 knots ; this caused the cable to part, but, steam being ready, the vessel was soon under control and no further damage was done. In the Seine, there is no interval at all of slack water between the ebb and flood tides, and, on the occasion referred to, the moment the Bore had passed, the flood was making up at the rate of 6 or 7 knots. After the flood tide, there is always some interval of slack water. The bore appears principally at springs, but varies greatly in size, and does not take place with any regularity ; it is therefore impossible to know beforehand whether there will be one or not.* Tides. — Under exceptional circumstances of tide, a vessel drawing 23 feet water can get up to Rouen, but, under ordinary circumstances, it is not safe to count on more than 17 or 18 feet water, between Havre and Rouen, at springs, and 14 feet at neaps.t Pilotage Regulations. — The following regulations for the pilotage of the lower Seine were issued by the Chef de la Marine at Havre, in February, 1887 : — " 1. Bane de Seine. — The deposits of sand and mud washed down by the river Seine extend far beyond the shoals at the river's mouth and form an extensive submarine flat and slope, agreeing somewhat in shape with the curve of the bank bordering the shore from Port en-Bessin to the meridian of the Dives. This flat, on which the soundings increase slowly and regularly towards the offing, occupies the whole breadth of the mouth of the river, and may be said to terminate northward on about the parallel of cape de la Heve ; but, on the parallel of Havre, a narrow tongue of shoal water, named the Bane de Seine, extends 15^ miles westward of it ; it is steep-to on its southern side, slopes gradually to the northward, and is not dangerous, having from 7 to 9 fathoms water at its outer part, but the

CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. Chap IX. 424 streams cross it obliquely and cause eddies upon its steep edge, where the sea is high during northerly gales on a weather tide. The Bane de Seine and the deep southward of it, called by the pilots the Parfond, are useful guides in establishing the position of a vessel during fogs or thick weather, when the navigation can only be carried on by means of the lead. From the western extreme of the bank, in 9 fathoms, cape de la Heve lighthouses bear E. by S. 4. S. 14 miles, and Ver lighthouse S.W. by W. \ W. 13 miles. DANGERS AT THE ENTRANCE OF THE SEINE — Bane de Trouville.— This bank of muddy sand, the south westernmost of the shifting banks at the mouth of the Seine, is about 24; miles long in an E. by N. \ N. direction from abreast of the entrance to Trouville, and from half a mile to one mile wide, with general depths of from 3 to 7 feet water. It is, however, very difficult to define its extent westward, the water deepening so very gradually in that direction that at 2\ miles farther there are only 9 feet water. A portion of its surface on the inner edge of the bank, about three quarters of a mile long and one cable wide, either dries from one to 4 feet or is awash at low water, springs ; this part lies in a N.E. and S.W. direction, about 4 cables from the shore abreast of Hennequeville. The sea is exceedingly heavy on this bank, with the wind from W.S.W. round by West to N N.E. Buoys. — A Black and red buoy is moored westward of the Bane de Trouville in about 8 feet water, 14. miles N.W. westerly from Trouville pier-heads. A red buoy with a vane is moored a mile northward of the bank, between it and the outer extreme of the Ratelets.* Villerville Channel. — The Bane de Trouville is separated from the shore by the Villerville channel, a narrow passage which is entered on the parallel of Trouville church. It is possible to enter the Seine by this channel, see page 426, which in 1878 had depths of from 14 to 20 feet, clayey mud ; vessels may anchor in 14 feet abreast of the mouth of the Touques, during an unfavourable tide. The streams follow the direction of the channel, and, in calm weather, the flood, at springs, runs about 5£ hours and ends 15 or 20 minuses after high water at Havre ; its greatest rate is about 4 knots, near half flood ; the ebb is rather weaker. * The relative positions of the buoys marking the Trouville. Ratelets. and Ratier banks, will be better understood by referring to the Admiralty chart than by any written description.

Chap. IX.] 425 THE SEINE — DANGERS AT ENTRANCE. Bane du Ratier, abreast of Villerville and 14 miles from the shore, with the Ratelets, a prolongation of the bank westward, forms one of the most dangerous shoals at the mouth of the Seine. The bank is of an irregular shape, and its surface, which dries from one to 12 feet above the lowest tides, is covered with a large quantity of stones and rolled shingle ; but, its base isa mass of compact brown clay and consequently not subject to change. That part of the surface which uncovers, including the Ratelets, is 3£ miles long in a W. by N. and E. by S. direction and forms a shelter from the flood stream to the banks of shifting sand eastward of it. From the western extreme of the Ratelets, in 6 feet, cape de la Heve light houses bear N. by E. \ E. 54. miles. The eastern limit of the red light at Deauville, see page 428, passes about two thirds of a mile westward of that part of the Ratelets bank which uncovers, in 7 or 8 feet water. The Bane du Ratier covers towards half flood, and the sea runs high over it with strong winds between West and North, but, with the latter wind, it shelters in some degree the channel southward of it. Buoys. — The southern side of the Ratelets and Ratier is marked by three buoys, viz. : — a red and black buoy 2 cables south-westward of the Ratelets bank and only 4 cables north-eastward of the red buoy moored northward of the Trouville bank ; a black and white buoy abreast of the outer elbow of the Ratier ; and, a black and red buoy close to the eastern end of the high drying part of the bank. On its northern side are, a large red buoy with staff and vane and a small red buoy near the eastern end. The large red buoy with staff and vane, called the N.W. Ratier buoy, lies with Fatouville lighthouse on with the pier-heads at Honfleur. Vessels going up the Seine northward of the Ratier bank, steer direct for this as a fairway buoy and leave it on the starboard hand. The other buoys described as marking the Ratier are very small, and cannot be seen until a vessel is nearly on them. (See note on preceding page.) Bane d' Amfard lies about 2 miles northward of the Ratier, and, like the latter, its base is a mass of browm clay and its surface is covered with large shingle ; it, also, shelters the bank of shifting sand eastward of it. This bank uncovers about 6 feet at low water,

Small vessels may pass northward of this bank at low water, by keeping the church spire at Harfleur open a quarter of a point northward of the guard house on Neiges point. The passage between the Amfard and the shore eastward of Havre is one of the entrances to the main channel of the Seine. Buoy. — A buoy painted with red and black bands, surmounted by staff and vane, is moored at the western extreme of the Bane d' Amfard, close to a patch which dries 2 feet, and about S. £ W. 1£ miles from the lighthouse on the eastern side of the entrance to Havre. ■ The position of the buoy is, however, liable to change in consequence of alterations in the form and depth of water on the bank. The description of the Eclat, Hauts de la Rade, and other shoals on the northern side of the estuary, chiefly concern the approaches to Havre, and will be included in their proper place in describing that port which is near the entrance on the right or northern bank of the estuary of the Seine, see page 440. We now return to the left or southern bank. LEFT BANK of the ESTUARY of the SEINE— From the entrance of the river Dives to the hill of Notre Dame de Grace, which commands the town and harbour of Honfleur, the left bank of the estuary of the Seine trends about 14 miles E. by N. A N., and the coast is bordered by high hills, terminating abruptly towards the sea in cliffs of brown clay and stone, and in large landslips, except in front of three valleys where the shore is low and sandy. The widest and most remarkable of these valleys is that through which the little river Touques finds its way into the sea. This valley is 2 miles wide at the sea shore, but narrows suddenly 400 yards inland ; it may be recognised from a great distance off-shore by the town of Trouville, which is built at the foot of a high steep hill on the eastern side of the entrance of the river ; its suburb, Deauville, being on the western side. Vessels of more than 9 feet draught should be cautious in ap proaching the coast when within 44 or 5 miles westward of the Touques, as the flat, with only from 3 to 10 feet water, there extends 1\ miles from the shore and increases in width in going eastward, so

Chap, ix.] 427 THE SEINE. — LEFT BANE. — TROUVILLE. that off the entrance of the Touques no more than 12 feet water is to be found in any direction at a distance of 3| miles. Eastward of the Touques, the coast is bordered by uneven rocks which dry at low water and terminate 3 miles E.N.E. from Trouville in Villerville point. This point extends three quarters of a mile in a N.W. by N. direction from Villerville village and the ledge off it is dangerous to vessels proceeding through the Villerville channel, see page 424, but is marked by a red buoy in 6 feet at its edge, 7 cables from the shore. If the buoy should be gone, this rocky point will be avoided when passing northward of it, by keeping Roque point opening and shutting in with Fonds cliff E. £ S. southerly. Roque point is a high greyish-white cliff, perpendicular towards the river side, and may be easily recognised, being the first point on the left bank of the Seine which is seen to open out from Fonds cliff when coming from the South-west. TROUVILLE.— Touques River.— The entrance to this river lies E. by N. \ N. northerly 74_ miles from that of the Dives, and is between two piers extending seaward in a N. by W. direction. The West pier extends 625 yards from point Deauville on the western side of the river, and the sands dry at low water 4 cables beyond the pier-head. The East pier does not extend so far from point Cahotte on the eastern side, the pier-heads bearing from each other about E.S.E. and W.N.W. The sands of Deauville form the western side of the channel from the pier-head to the low water line, and it is marked by three red buoys ; but, from the East pier head, a low dyke of rough stone, intended to prevent the eastern sands from drifting into the channel, extends a considerable distance and is marked close to on its western side by three black buoys. The channel between the piers is 164 feet wide ; the deepest water, about 19 or 20 feet, at springs, being towards the West pier. Within the piers the harbour opens out, and, on the eastern side are the quays of Cahotte and of Trouville old harbour extending up to the bridge, with good grounding berths alongside for vessels up to 12 or 14 feet draught. On the western side, its entrance facing the quays of Cahotte point, is the wet dock or basin, 986 feet long, 263 feet wide, with 20 feet over the sill at high water, springs, and 154; feet at neaps. This basin is surrounded by extensive quays ; and, in it, vessels of 15 feet draught can lie afloat at all times and unload direct into railway trucks, the railway station being just at the head of the basin and rails laid along the quays.

CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. ix. 428 The port of Trouville has no dry dock, though a half tide dock is about to be constructed, nor can repairs of any importance be effected. It has a public and a private hospital, both available for seamen in case of need. From 3,000 to 5,000 tons of coal are usually in stock at this port, and steamers in the basin are readily supplied at about 22s. per ton. The chief import is coal, of which between 60,000 and 70,000 tons arrive annually ; the other imports are wood, cement, ice, &c. The exports are unimportant, In 1887, the trade of the port, exclusive of its large fishing industry, was represented by the entry of 161 vessels, of which two thirds were steamers, of an aggregate of 49,549 tons. Trouville, formerly a small fishing port and village, has since 1860 expanded into a place of considerable commercial importance as well as having become a fashionable watering place. In 1886, it had a population of 6,308, and its suburb Deauville, across the river, 2,228 inhabitants. The railway station is at Deauville, and the communication is through Lisieux with the Cherbourg and Paris line. Trouville has also steamers running daily between it and Havre, for both passengers and goods, the passage lasting about 45 minutes. The small town of Touques is on the river about 2 miles above Trouville, and, at springs, vessels of light draught can ascend as high as Quai-au-Coq, a small place 5^. miles in the interior, where there is sufficient water for them to remain afloat. A Life-Boat is stationed at Trouville. Chap. IX.] TROUVILLE. — HONFLEUR. 429 Fog Signal. — A bell is sounded continuously during fogs from the eastern pier-head. (See note, page 10.) Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Trouville, at 9h. 20m. Springs rise 22 feet, neaps 18 feet, and the neap range is 124 feet. The lowest neaps rise 11 feet above the sands at the entrance in the channel ; springs, 16 to 17 feet. Tide Signals. — The usual tide signals (see page 8) are shown from a mast at Cahotte point, near the inner end of the East pier. Directions. — Westerly winds are the most favourable for entering the river Touques ; sailing vessels should not enter until half an hour before high water, but, with a leading wind, they may continue to enter until half an hour after high water, as the ebb is easily stemmed. At the entrance of the channel, in all weathers, there is almost a certainty of procuring pilots, though a heavy sea runs here when it blows hard from the westward. With off-shore winds, small vessels may anchor in about 10 feet water and L| miles from the beach abreast of the plain of Villers, which is 3 miles south-westward of the river entrance ; here they may remain until the tide has risen sufficiently for them to enter : but, with the wind from N.W. they should anchor in the Villerville channel between the Trouville bank and the coast, with the ruins of the chateau de Lasse on with the houses on Cahotte point, bearing S. by W. 4. W. ; if the wind should then freshen and back to West or S.W., they will be able to run through the channel and take refuge at Honfleur. The Coast. — From the mouth of the Touques, the steep coast trends 3 miles E.N.E. as far as the small village of Villerville, which stands rather high ; it then bends more eastward for 4 miles to the hill of Notre Dame de Grace, one of the highest and the most conspicuous hill in the estuary of the Seine, which is 34 miles wide between this point and Hoc point on the northern shore. The only part of the coast from Trouville to Honfleur where the shore is low and accessible at high water is eastward of Villerville, and between it and Vasoui. HONFLEUR. — This port is at the entrance of a beautiful valley, open to the North-east, and just eastward of the hill of Notre Dame de Grace. It is sheltered by the land on all sides, and the wind never raises such a sea as to make it dangerous to enter, Being so

IX. near Havre, it neither has nor needs mnch plant for repairing vessels, and its building yards, from which, in 1866, 29 vessels of 9,000 tons in the aggregate were launched, are now comparatively deserted. The trade of the port steadily progresses notwithstanding, and in 1887, 1,304 vessels, of a total tonnage of 213,014 tons, entered. The exports are chiefly dairy and agricultural produce to the value annually of £1,360,000. The imports are principally timber and coals, valued at £300,000. The steamers of the London and South Western, and of the London, Brighton, and South Coast railways run regularly between it and Southampton and Newhaven respectively. The railway station is on the eastern side of the harbour, and the line connects with the general system of the country at Lisieux. Honfleur has both a sailor's home and a hospital, and its population, in 1886, amounted to 9,726. An ample supply of coal at from 16s. to 20s. per ton can always be obtained, there being usually about 2,000 tons in stock. Steamers are coaled lying afloat at their ordinary berths alongside the quays in the basins. The port consists of an outer tidal harbour, and of four wet docks or Bassins-a-flot, viz : — the Bassin de l'Ouest, the Bassin du Centre, the Bassin de l'Est, and the Fourth basin, of later construction, and now (1888) lengthened 200 yards. Provision is made by means of sluices, a large Bassin de Chasses, and other reservoirs of water for scouring them, as well as the channel leading into the port ; there is also a small tidal harbour on the western side, which serves chiefly for steamboats and small craft employed in the daily transport of passengers and country produce to Havre. The Bassin de l'Ouest is 427 feet long by 256 feet wide, and its depth is 18 feet at high water, extraordinary springs, 17 feet at ordinary springs, and nearly 10 feet at neaps. The Bassin du Centre is 427 feet long by 296 feet wide, and its depth is 214; feet at extraordinary springs, 20£ feet at ordinary springs, and 13 feet at neaps. The Bassin de l'Est is 986 feet long by 236 feet wide, and its depth is 22£ feet at extra ordinary springs, 21£ feet at ordinary springs, and 144; feet at neaps. The fourth basin is 1181 feet long by 243 feet wide, and is 16 inches deeper than the Bassin de l'Est. Quay frontage and storage are very ample, and all modern appliances, steam cranes, &c, are available for the rapid loading or unloading of ships. The entrance of the port is between two piers, partly stone and partly timber, 230 feet apart, and it is open to N. by E. The West pier extends 370 yards from the shore ; and, from its head, the

Chap. IX.] 431 HONFLEUR. northern end of the breakwater of the Bassin de Chasses, under construction, which forms the eastern side of the entrance, bears E. \ N. about 300 feet. The East pier is prolonged by a rough stone submersible dyke 650 yards long, constructed in 1886, to direct the channel and periodical flushings in order to overcome the rapid silting up to which this port appears to become more and more liable ; the dyke is marked by branches of trees at frequent intervals. The shifting sands uncover 2 or 3 cables beyond the pier-heads. The direction of the channel being very subject to change, is marked by red and black buoys, their positions being shifted as occasion may require. The red buoys are on the western side of the channel and the black buoys on the eastern side, according to the buoyage regulations in force at French ports. Vessels at high water, springs, usually pass over the small banks which form at the entrance of the channel, but it is dangerous for vessels under any circumstances to enter without a pilot, the sand being so moveable, and the streams, which set obliquely across the channel, so rapid that a laden vessel grounding during a high tide would run great risk of being totally lost. The depths in the channel were formerly 23 feet at high water, equinoctial springs ; 21 feet at ordinary springs ; and, 11\ feet at neaps. The old channel has, however, entirely disappeared, and the effect of the new dyke and sluicing arrangements is as yet not sufficiently developed for more to be said than that the depths are very un certain.* Tides and Tidal Signals. — It is high water, full and change, in port Honfleur, at 9h. 29m.; springs rise 23 feet ; neaps 18 feet, The usual tide signals, see page 8, are made from a mast on the East jetty near the Tidal lighthouse. Westerly winds of any duration serve to raise the water, and easterly winds have a contrary effect. During rainy weather and at the melting of the snow, the freshets of the Seine are abundant, and with strong westerly winds they contribute greatly to raise the water in the port, At high water, the tide remains slack only 15 or 20 minutes, but the change in height from half an hour before to half an hour after high water not being more than 3 or 4 inches, the gates of the basins can remain open for that time without inconvenience. * In 1887, consequent upon the silting up of the harbour, a steamer of only 16 feet draught had to wait four days in the outer tidal harbour for a sufficiently high tide to admit her into the docks. At that time, the large Bassin de Chasses, opened only in 1881, had itself silted up until there were only about 2 feet water in it at springs, — Vice Consul's report 1887,

Tide Light. — From a round brick tower on the eastern pier at the entrance to the tidal harbour, is shown a fixed ivhite light, varied by red and green flashes ; it is 39 feet above high water and visible 9 miles. This light is shown only when there are 6^ feet or more in the channel ; each red flash indicates 3j additional feet, and each green flash three quarters of a foot more. Thus, with the ivhite light showing, two red flashes followed by one green flash signifies that the depth in the channel is 13£ feet, With the white light showing, one red flash followed by three green flashes signifies a depth of 12 feet. The light is visible in clear weather from a distance of 22 miles. DIRECTIONS. — Honfleur is accessible to vessels of moderately deep draught during springs ; those arriving at the mouth of the Seine, at neaps, must wait for water to enter the passages leading to Honfleur either under sail, with the wind from W.S.W. round by West to N.N.E., or at anchor in the Grande Rade off Havre if the wind be off the land ; if remaining only a day or two for sufficient water, they may anchor in Carosse roads in 5 or 6 fathoms, mud and sand, with cape de la Heve lighthouses in line N.E. £ N. ; and,

At this anchorage, the stream runs towards the Seine until 4 hours flood ; its greatest strength is at 3 hours before high water at Havre and does not exceed 4 knots. Vessels having only a few hours to wait for tide, should keep under sail westward of cape de la Heve lighthouses in line, and a little northward of the line of the Hospital point lighthouse at Honfleur on with Fatouville lighthouse bearing S.E. by E. \ E. ; but, should the strength of the tide drift them towards the river, they must anchor before passing these limits. Passes de Honfleur. — Two narrrow passages lead to Honfleur. The North passage is between the Amfard and Ratier banks and is the main channel into the Seine. Pilots take sailing vessels through this channel with the wind between W.N.W. and N.N.E., but, with contrary winds, although there is room to work, large vessels are usually towed. Hospital point lighthouse on with Fatouville light house S.E. by E. \ E. leads through the passage just northward of the N.W. Ratier buoy and up to a position where a sight of the pier heads at the entrance of the port may be obtained ; but, as a vessel must cross the banks of shifting sand which dry at low water and whose height is very variable, it is extremely imprudent and dangerous for a large vessel to attempt it without a pilot. Small coasters may do so at 'i\ or 4 hours flood during springs, and half an hour before high water at neaps. The South passage is between the Ratier and Trouville banks ; its leading line is, the northern extreme of Fonds cliff, Honfleur, on with Roque point, remarkable for its grey tint and its perpendicu larly steep shore, E. by S. In running through, this mark must be kept on until abreast of Vasoui ; from thence to Honfleur, keep between 2 and 3 cables from the shore. At night, you may be certain that you are in this channel when Roque light is just open of Fonds cliff. This passage is generally taken by sailing vessels with the wind between S.S.E. and W.N.W. ; coasters may run through it at 2\ hours, and larger vessels at 34^ hours flood ; but, with a leading wind, during springs, it should not be entered by large vessels until 4 hours flood, as, between Villerville and Honfleur, that stream runs with great rapidity in the direction of the passage. The flood stream, at springs, commences 5 hours before high water at Havre and runs 54 hours ; its greatest velocity is towards half flood and is sometimes 7 knots between Vasoui and Honfleur. With strong southerly winds, vessels should be on their guard against the heavy gusts which rush down the narrow valleys between Penne de Pic and Honfleur ; vessels have sometimes been dismasted by them. Small vessels, when bound to Honfleur from the South-west, may use the Villerville channel, between the Trouville bank and the coast ; but, in doing so, they must proceed with caution by the lead and haul off in time to give a good berth to the rocky ledge off Villerville ; having passed the red buoy at its outer extreme, they may proceed by the leading mark for the South channel. Entering Honfleur. — The most favourable winds for a sailing vessel to enter this port are those between W.S.W. and E.N.E. round by North. The channel is crossed obliquely by the flood and ebb streams, and their extreme velocity, at springs, is from 5 to 6 knots The flood stream runs 5^ hours and ends just at high water; it is during the 15 or 20 minutes interval of slack tide which then ensues that a pilot prefers to take in a vessel of deep draught, there being then but little difficulty in following the course of the channel. Plenty of sail should be carried in passing through the outer part of the channel, and an anchor should be always ready to let go in case a sudden shift of wind or the heave of the sea should force the vessel out of the channel. In the event of such an accident, a signal for a steam-tug should immediately be made, by hanging the colours under the bowsprit. If the entrance is missed, anchor at once and await the arrival of the tug ; or, failing her, with the commencement of the ebb, quit the river as speedily as possible. With a fresh southerly wind, it is necessary to guard against the sudden off-shore gusts before referred to ; they are frequently felt under the hill of Notre Dame de Grace and blow strongly down the valley at Honfleur. With a head wind or a calm, a steam-tug should always be obtained and when nearing the entrance channel the tow rope should be well shortened in, and great attention paid to follow exactly the wake of the tow-boat, for the smallest deviation in the steerage is here sufficient to run the vessel ashore. About one mile eastward of cape de la Heve, however, commences a broad alluvial flat which, for a distance of 4 miles, fronts the high chalk formation. The town and port of Havre occupies the western portion of this flat, and the little town of Harfleur is at its eastern end, at the entrance to one of the deepest valleys. CAPE DE LA HEVE, formerly known by the name of Chef de Caux, is 2\ miles N.N.W. of the entrance to Havre, and forms the western point of the chalky cliffs which terminate the plain of Caux. The cape is perpendicular about half way down from its summit, the foot of the cliff being covered with the debris of frequent slips and fallen masses. LIGHTS. — On the summit of cape de la Heve stand two light houses, each 66 feet high, from which are exhibited two fixed white electric lights of the first order ; the lights are 397 feet above high water and visible in clear weather 27 miles. The lighthouses are square white buildings bearing N.E. £ N. and S.W. £ S. distant 107 yards from each other ; the southern lighthouse stands 100 yards from the edge of the cliff. The intensity of the lights is doubled in thick fogs. The lead should be frequently used when approaching these lights from the westward, especially if the Ver light has not been sighted ; and, in coming from the north eastward it should be noted that the lights become masked by the heights of Bleville on a S.W. by S. bearing. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on cape de la Heve, it stands midway between the two lighthouses but westward of their line. Tide Signals. — A signal station is established about 2 cables S.S.E. from cape de la Heve lighthouses, from which is repeated, for the benefit of vessels in the offing or roads, the tide signals made at the tide station at the inner end of the North jetty at Havre. HAVRE. — The town, tidal harbour, and large Bassins-a-flot or wet docks of this important port occupy the western part of the low plain, before described. In 1887, the foreign trade entering the port was represented by 2,658 vessels measuring 2,163,005 tons, and the coasting trade by 2,977 vessels measuring 382,197 tons. Steamers 2E2

IX. of the largest size run to all parts of the world, and by means of the railway to Rouen and Paris, as well as by its extensive and constant steam river traffic, Havre has excellent means of communication with the interior of France. The principal imports are cotton, coals, coffee, hides, timber, dye woods, petroleum, tobacco, palm oil, wheat, wood, &c, &c. The principal exports are silks and ribbons, broadcloths, cotton goods, lace, gloves, shoes, millinery, wines, brandy, &c, &c. The population of the town in 1886 was 112,074. There is a town hospital available for seamen in case of accident or illness, a Sailor's Home, and also reading rooms for seamen. Coals are to be obtained in any quantity, the stock on hand being usually from 10,000 to 12,000 tons, and the price from 14s. to 16s. per ton. Vessels are coaled alongside the quays in the docks either from carts or barges or both. Many of the wet docks have water for the largest sized merchant vessels at all times. Every kind of supply is plentiful and good. Tidal Harbour. — The entrance to the tidal harbour, or Avant port, lies S.S.E. 24 miles from cape de la Heve and is open to the heavy sea which rolls in with strong westerly winds. The entrance is between two jetties, of which the longest is on the northern side and shelters the entrance from westerly winds ; the South jetty is short, and joins the dock walls on the eastern side. The harbour is accessible at high water to vessels drawing from 22 to 24 feet during five or six days at springs ; that is to say, a day or two before full and change, and three or four days after. It is bordered by wide and commodious quays on all sides. The North quay is used by passenger steamers for the Seine and neigh bouring ports. Steam-tugs lie alongside the Floride quay ; and, the rest of the tidal harbour is used by vessels waiting for spring tides to go up the Seine and by coasting craft, Dredging operations are constantly in progress both in the harbour and basins, and periodical flushings take place in order to preserve and deepen the entrance channel. The harbour does not dry out at low water, springs, there being always at least 3 feet in the channel. The bank outside the southern jetty is a continuation of the bank in Heure bay ; and, like it, is of shingle cemented together by mud, forming a hard bottom in which anchors take hold with great difficulty. The bottom of the entrance channel is of the same description, but, inside, the shingle is covered

Chap. ix.] HAVRE. — BASINS AND DOCKS. 437 with a layer of mud which forms excellent beds for vessels to ground upon. Basins. — There are at Havre nine basins or wet docks with ample quay accommodation and storage, and which communicate with the tidal harbour and with each other by gates. The basins are named the Bassins du Roi, de la Barre, Vauban, de la Floride, de l'Eure, Bellot, du Commerce, de la Citadelle, and Bassin-dock. The Bassin de l'Eure is the largest, and into both it and the Bassin Bellot vessels of 28 feet draught can enter at all tides, the depth of water on the sill of the Bassin de l'Eure being 33 feet 9 inches at high water springs, and 29 feet 5 inches at neaps, that on the sill of the Bassin Bellot being about 9 inches less ; in both cases, this is a considerably greater depth than the approaches to the port give. The width of the entrance to the Bassin de l'Eure, which is the basin used by the large trans-atlantic steamers, is 100 feet. The entrances to the other basins are from 68 feet to 37j feet wide, the latter being the width of the entrance into the Vauban basin, where British colliers lie. Enormous additional works are projected which, if carried out in their entirety, will involve an expenditure of nearly £3,000,000, and will throw the whole of the present docks into the rear of the vast new docks to be constructed along the present sea-front. The sills of the gates of the Bassins du Roi and de la Barre, are 34^ feet above the level of the lowest springs ; the western end of the Bassin de la Floride has been thrown open to the tidal harbour and now forms a convenient shelter for coasters and wind-bound vessels ; its eastern end is formed into a half-tide dock. The gates of the Bassins du Roi and de la Barre can remain open without in convenience until the water has fallen 2 feet below high water which, both at spring and neap tides, takes place about 14; hours after high water slack ; and, as these gates are opened by the pressure of the rising tide about as long before the commencement of slack water, it follows that the basins can communicate with the harbour during 34; or 4 hours of each tide. Dry Docks. — Havre has four dry docks completed and in use : — No. 1, is 423 feet long on the blocks, is 98 feet wide, and has 29 feet 3 inches over the sill at springs ; Nos. 2, 3, and 4 are respectively 146, 179, and 228 feet long, 35 feet 9 inches, 42 feet, and 52 feet wide, and 22 feet 9 inches, 24 feet, and 26 feet deep. Two additional graving docks are to be completed by 1889, one being 460 feet in length on the blocks or 492 feet over all ; the other, 377 feet over all. There are also a floating dock capable of lifting a ship of 800 tons,

Life-BoatS. — Three life-boats are stationed at Havre or in its immediate vicinity. Pilots. — The pilots of Havre are numerous and skilful, and are paid according to the distance piloted. According to regulations, the greatest distance is to cape Barfleur, and the least is, outside the banks at the entrance of the harbour; there is great competition among them, however, and being provided with excellent boats, they frequently meet vessels as far westward as the Casquets. Those who pilot vessels out of harbour are bound to conduct them clear of the outlying banks ; if they consent to take them farther, they are paid 15 francs, or by special agreement. Steam-tugs are always in readiness, and the signal for their services being required is, an ensign suspended under the bowsprit. Grand Quai. — On the Grand quai within the harbour, a fixed green light, visible 8 miles, is shown from an iron support at 56 feet above high water. This light on with that on the South jetty leads between the Haut du Sud-Ouest and the Haut de Quarante and up to the harbour entrance. Fog Signal. — A fog trumpet is sounded in thick or foggy weather near the lighthouse on the North jetty ; it gives a blast of 8 seconds, duration, followed by an interval of from 45 to 50 seconds. It is sounded from 3 hours before until 4 hours after high water. Should the trumpet be out of order a bell is sounded instead. (See note, page 10.) Strong and lasting westerly winds have sometimes raised the water to the level of the quay, but this rarely happens. The wind, how ever, has great influence on the height of the tide. The freshets of the Seine, during a rainy season or the melting of the snow, also contribute greatly to raise the water in the harbour, and it has been remarked that the highest tides have almost always occurred during the strongest freshets. Havre has the great advantage over most of the harbours on the French side of the channel, of a long period of slack tide at high water. The maximum duration of this high wrater slack has been observed to be lh. 15m., the minimum from 20 to 25 minutes, and the mean interval 57 minutes. This long period of slack water is very valuable to the traffic of the port, as it allows several vessels to enter or leave the docks on the same tide. During the months of May, June, and July, the duration of slack water is, with some exceptions, generally less than the mean ; the rest of the year it continues almost always an hour or more. At springs, the duration of the flood is 5h. 10m., and of the ebb 7h. 15m. DANGERS Off HAVRE.— The approaches to Havre are obstructed by banks of stones and shingle which form a belt of dangers fronting the shore between Neiges point, If miles eastward of the entrance, and cape de la Heve. The highest parts of this belt are, the Bane de l'Bclat, Hauts de da Rade, and Haut de la Petite Rade. PETITE RADE DE HAVRE is the anchorage inside the banks just described between Havre and cape de la Heve. It is well sheltered with the wind from N.E. round by East to S.E. but is open to all others, and strong breezes between North and W.S.W. send in a heavy sea. The holding ground is good, and anchors take such firm hold in the clay that there is sometimes great difficulty in weighing, especially when vessels have been riding to strong westerly winds. It should, however, only be used as a temporary anchorage where vessels may wait, with off-shore winds, for sufficient water to enter the harbour, but they should not remain there in unsettled weather, nor if it blows strongly from the westward. Small vessels are placed nearer the shore, with Fatouville light house open northward of the North jetty lighthouse; but, no nearer the shore than to have cape de la Heve southern lighthouse bearing North. The holding ground here is so good that, unless she parted, a small vessel with a good scope of cable would be in no danger during a westerly gale. Directions. — The only practicable entrance to the Petite Rade de Havre for vessels of moderate draught at low water, is between the cliffs of cape de la Heve and the northern ridge of the Eclat, but a stranger should not use it without a pilot. The least depth midway between the northern ridge and the shore is 13 feet. To enter this channel, steer for the southern lighthouse on the cape on a S.E. \ E. bearing ; this leads northward of the whistle buoy just outside the Eclat bank, and 3 cables northward of No. 1 buoy ; when about 3 cables from the cliffs, the vessel is in mid-channel and must then bear away southward for No. 8 red buoy, moored between the northern ridge of the Eclat and the shore, taking care not to approach so near the land as to entirely lose sight of the lantern of the northern lighthouse. Small vessels, locally acquainted, run for the anchorage in the Petite Rade at low water, passing either northward or southward of the southern ridge of the Eclat ; the lead and chart are the only guides for these channels. GRANDE RADE de HAVRE, is simply an anchorage in the open sea N.W. by W. 5 miles from cape de la Heve. Vessels of deep draught having to wait for springs to enter Havre, sometimes anchor here in quite fine weather or with off-shore winds, but they should be prepared to weigh instantly on any change in the weather. The holding ground is excellent, and, from a vessel in the centre of the anchorage in 9 fathoms water, cape de la Heve bears S.E. by E. ; Fatouville lighthouse on with the North jetty lighthouse at Havre S.E. easterly ; and, the outer whistle buoy S. \ E. easterly about 2h miles. When bound into Havre from the Grande Rade, with the wind from E.N.E. round by East to S.W., weigh as soon as the flood has acquired strength, so as to be near the Hauts de la Rade before the stream changes its direction north-eastward. When near these

444 CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. banks, the directions for entering the harbour presently given must be attended to. With a fair wind, weigh so as to be at the harbour's mouth at the proper time for entering. Tidal Streams.— Grande and Petite Rade.— The flood stream begins in the Petite Rade about 14; hours after the tide has begun to rise in the harbour, or about 4 hours before high water there. Its first direction is S. by E. for 2 hours, with a velocity of from 2g to 3 knots ; it then turns to E.S.E. and the stream becomes imperceptible until high water in the harbour, when it again acquires strength, runs N.N.W., and ends in that direction 14; hours after. The ebb commences immediately and runs N.N.W. for 3 hours or until 4Jr hours after high water in the harbour ; it then turns to W.S.W. and ends in a S.W. direction a few minutes before the flood commences. At the northern entrance into the road, the streams follow the same course, but the flood does not end until 2 hours after high water. The ebb runs N.N.W. during 24; or 3 hours, and then turns W.S.W. and S.S.W. When the tide is out in the harbour, the ebb runs S.S.W. from 14^ to 2 knots, and it ends in this direction a little before the flood stream commences at this spot, or about 4 hours before high water in the harbour. Vessels running into this road at low water should be aware of this stream of tide when passing the shoal patches. The flood stream begins to be felt in the Grande Rade about 4 hours before high water at Havre. An hour after, it runs S. by W. at the rate of about 3 knots, and continues to run towards the Seine until 24 hours before high water ; its direction is then E.S.E., losing little of its strength, and then E.N.E. In the latter direction, its rate increases to 2\ or 3 knots at the time of high water in the harbour ; it then decreases in strength and ends about 2 hours after, running N.E. by N. The ebb commences almost as soon as the flood ends, slack water lasting only about a quarter of an hour at springs. This stream turns round by West, and about 3 hours after high water its direction is N.W., but it does not attain its greatest strength of 2\ knots until it runs W:S.W., or about 5 hours after high water ; it then slackens gradually as it turns to the southward, where it ends. DIRECTIONS.— Entering Havre.— Although steam navi gation is largely in the ascendant at this port, and even for sailing vessels the services of steam-tugs are always available, yet to those who prefer to enter independently of these aids the following

Chap. IX.] HAVRE. — TIDAL STREAMS. — DIRECTIONS. 445 directions will be useful, observing that no stranger should attempt it without a pilot. Vessels arriving off the port some hours before the tide serves, should remain outside the banks off the entrance until the tide has risen sufficiently to pass over them. The stream runs into the Seine from the commencement of the flood until 2 hours before high water ; but, there is no fear of being drawn into the river if vessels keep westward of the line of cape de la Heve lighthouses in one bearing N.E. £ N., or if cape d'Antifer is kept a few degrees open westward of cape de la Heve ; taking care at the same time not to go southward of the line of the Chateau d'Orcher, which stands near the shore about 2 miles eastward of Harfleur, on with the projecting angle of the wall enclosing the Floride basin bearing E. \ S. With a fresh breeze from W.N.W. round by North to E.S.E., there is no difficulty in turning to windward and keeping a position ; but, with all other winds, keep as near as possible to the line of the chateau and the Floride wall in one, because at about 2 hours before high water in the harbour, when the Seine is nearly filled, the flood stream turns to E.S.E., losing part of its strength, and then to N.E. In the latter direction, it runs with the same velocity as when it ran up the Seine, and retains it until nearly 24; hours after high water ; should a sailing vessel, at that time, be so far northward as the parallel of cape de la Heve, it would be almost impossible for her to reach the harbour in time to get in. With strong winds from N.N.W. round by West to W.S.W., it is necessary to keep under sail 6 or 8 miles to windward of the harbour until there is sufficient water to enter ; but, with moderate winds from S.W. round by South to E.N.E., during calm weather, or at the times of the freshets of the Seine, it is better to anchor in Carosse road, see page 432, or, between that road and the line of the Chateau d'Orcher on with the projecting angle of La Floride wall E. 4 S. Vessels can always get into harbour from the anchorage in the Petite Rade even during calms or head winds. When vessels of deep draught have failed in entering, and the direction of the wind and late hour of the tide do not permit a second attempt, they should at once run out of the Seine ; but, small vessels may take shelter under Hoc point, see page 451, whilst the tide is high. The flood stream entering the Seine, crosses the direction of the entrance channel into Havre at right angles, and renders access to the harbour for a sailing vessel difficult under certain circumstances, which should be understood.

CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. 446 The North jetty projects into the strength of the flood stream and occasions an eddy, the strength and extent of which depend on the velocity of that stream and on the range of the tide. About 3 hours before high water, when the stream begins to acquire its greatest strength, which is 4 or 5 knots at springs, the eddy extends as far as Heure bay, and forms along the shores of that bay and along the walls of La Floride, a rapid counter stream, of which one portion turns round the end of the South jetty and enters the harbour, whilst the other runs sharply against the North jetty, along which it forms a disturbed eddy. This action of the streams continues until about 14; hours before high water in the harbour ; but, at this time, the Seine, being nearly full, can no longer receive all the water running towards it from all points of the estuary, the stream here accordingly slackens, whilst towards the left bank, where the flood follows nearly the same direc as if the Seine did not exist or was barred off, the stream, not finding any issue upwards, crosses the Seine obliquely north-eastward ; this direction, however, soon changes and becomes more northerly as the river fills. When this cross stream has reached Hoc point, a portion runs along shore westAvard and produces the stream named the Verhaule, which, at the entrance of Havre, takes the same direction as the eddy on the flood, just described, and immediately follows it, but in much greater volume, the Verhaule passing round the North jetty and running to the North-west, The effect of these different eddy streams on the flood tide, is to raise a high and confused sea at the entrance of the harbour when it blows strongly from the westward. The Verhaule, of which a part enters and helps to fill the harbour, is in fact the last part of the flood ; but, it runs in an opposite direction to the stream during the first hours of the rising tide and helps to keep vessels in the entrance channel, thus facilitating their entrance with westerly winds. Its greatest strength is about three quarters of an hour before high water and it continues to run until the harbour is filled, when it decreases gradually and is hardly perceptible at the end of slack water. The ebb then commences and at first is feeble, but, in an hour's time, it gains strength and runs towards the North and N.N.W. in the same direction as the Verhaule when near its end. The deviation of the flood stream, occasioned by each of the pro jecting angles of the quays bordering the entrance, is another difficulty in entering Havre with a scant wind, especially if a vessel has entered before the basins and harbour are filled.

Chap, ix.] 447 HAVRE. — DIRECTIONS. It appears, therefore, that for vessels intending to remain in the outer harbour, the best time to enter is at high water slack, but this is rather too late for those entering the basins. They, on the contrary, should enter as soon as the tides serves, so as to have time to secure before the beginning of the ebb. The anchors should be ready for letting go before entering, and one should be placed conveniently for anchoring by the stern ; warps and hawsers also should be coiled clear for use on deck and ready to run out in case of need. The best time of tide for a sailing vessel to enter, must however depend greatly on the direction of the wind. With a fresh westerly wind, she may run in even whilst the counter stream along the walls of La Floride is at its greatest strength, care being taken to keep in mid-channel so as not to drift on the North jetty. With fresh winds between W.S.W. and N.N.W., the Verhaule causes a violent sea, and it is then best not to enter until the end of slack water, when the sea is rather less confused and the tide slack in the entrance channel. With the wind sufficiently strong between S.S.W. and E.S.E. to stem the tide, she may enter before the Verhaule commences. Should the wind, however, be between E.S.E. and N.E., it is advisable to secure the services of a steam-tug, the arrangements for tracking vessels formerly in vogue having been entirely superseded by towing. Boats are always ready at the entrance and in the harbour to run out warps for hauling the vessel into her berth as may be necessary. To Havre from the "Westward. — Generally speaking, in a sailing vessel, the direction of the wind met with in the entrance of the Channel should determine the choice of the landfall to be made in order to take a fresh departure for Havre, see also Directions page 370. With the wind from E.N.E. round by North to W.S.W., the English coast should be made between the Lizard and Portland Bill, but not eastward of the Bill for, should the wind then back more to the southward, it would be impossible for a sailing vessel to fetch Havre with the flood stream running. As soon as the position of the vessel is ascertained, a course should be shaped to sight cape Barfleur lighthouse. Steamers from the southward endeavour to sight Ushant, and sailing vessels, in clear weather, with the wind between W.S.W. and S.S.E. may do the same. The points of the French coast which should then be sought for in succession are, Ushant ; the high land between Ushant and ile de Bas ; Guernsey, a sight of which assists in making or clearing the Casquets ; and lastly,

CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. 448 Alderney, and the high land at the back of cape de la Hague. If this passage is adopted, however, great attention must be paid to the tidal streams when running between the ile de Bas and Guernsey as the ship's course crosses their direction nearly at right angles. During the ebb there is no danger, as that stream runs towards the N.N.W., but the flood sets strongly into the gulf of St. Malo and is very rapid at springs. At 10 miles from the coast between Ushant and ile de Bas, the flood stream ends about 24^ hours after high water by the shore. As Guernsey and the Casquets are approached, the greatest care must be taken to keep well clear of them, the rate of the flood stream between them being from 4 to 5 knots, at springs ; a vessel should therefore always pass well westward and only just within sight of the Casquets. When north-westward of the Casquets, follow the directions given at page 370 until eastward of cape de la Hague to avoid the race of Alderney and the strong tides in that neighbour hood ; and, from thence, the course is about E.S.E. to make cape Barfleur lighthouse, taking care to keep from 3 to 6 miles from the coast in order to avoid the numerous dangers which border it. By whatever route a vessel has come, when cape Barfleur light house or the high land at Pernelle is made out, a course should be shaped to make the land between cape de la Heve and cape d'Antifer, or direct for the former cape, according as the wind inclines from the northward or southward. After passing cape Barfleur and having entered the bay of the Seine, the first land seen when steering as described will be that which bounds the estuary of the Seine on either side. The high land of the plain of Caux should be ahead and on the port bow, terminating towards the coast in chalk cliffs of dazzling whiteness, which, when lighted up by the sun, are plainly distinguished from 18 to 20 miles off ; and, on the starboard hand to the southward, will be the hills bordering the left bank of the Seine from Honfleur to the river Dives ; their rounded shape, and especially their dark colour, distinguish them from those to the northward. When the meridian of cape Barfleur is crossed towards the com mencement of the flood, that is, about 5| or 6 hours before hio-h water at Havre, see table, page 383, a vessel with a leading wind may arrive off Havre in time to save the tide. On passing the meridian of Barfleur at the commencement of the ebb, or about one hour after high water at Havre, a course should be shaped for cape d'Antifer and only sufficient sail carried to stem the tide, which, in the middle

Chap. IX.] 449 HAVRE. — DIRECTIONS. of the bay, runs 34; or 4 knots, at springs, about 44^ hours after high water at Havre. Should the position of Havre be made out before the commencement of the flood, sail must be so regulated as not to arrive off the harbour's mouth until there is sufficient water to enter. At night, with the wind between North and West, a course should be shaped from cape Barfleur to make the land between cape de la Heve and cape d'Antifer. Cape de la Heve and Fecamp lights are good guides to the vessel's position ; to prevent her approaching too near the land, it should be borne in mind that Fecamp light is concealed by the high land at Etretat on an E. £ N. bearing, and, cape de la Heve lights, by the hillocks at Bleville on a S.W. by S. bearing ; therefore, if Fecamp light is shut in whilst those on cape de la Heve are visible, the land will be made southward of cape d'Antifer ; and, if the lights on cape de la Heve should be shut in whilst the light at Fecamp is visible, it is necessary at once to haul out to open cape de la Heve lights again and to get to the southward, the vessel being evidently several miles northward of her position. Fecamp light will not be lost sight of at the distance of 6 or 7 cables off cape d'Antifer, nor cape de la Heve lights at the same distance off the coast between cape d'Antifer and Cauville. Thus, should it be desired to maintain a position during the night by turning to wind ward between cape d'Antifer and Cauville, go about, when standing in for the land, the instant the lights on the cape disappear, and in standing off-shore during the flood, tack when Fecamp light reappears ; but, during the ebb, the off-shore board may be continued farther without inconvenience. With a moderate breeze and smooth water, a vessel may anchor on the line of Fecamp light eclipsed by the land, provided she is some miles southward of the parallel of cape d'Antifer. The holding ground is excellent as far as 5 miles off-shore between that cape and the Grande rade, but nearer the coast, between Bleville guard-house and Cauville, the bottom is covered with heaps of large stones for 1\ miles off-shore. It may be proper here to remark that between capes de la Heve and d'Antifer, at 4 or 5 miles from the shore, the flood stream, at springs, runs at the rate of 2 or 3 knots to the N.E. for 4 hours, i.e., from 2 hours before to 2 hours after high water at Havre ; it then slackens and turns more northward, so that a vessel caught by a contrary wind when southward of cape d'Antifer, would be unable during that period to reach Havre by turning to windward close A. 2771. CAPE BARFLEUR TO CAPE D'ANTIFER. [Chap. IX. 450 in-shore, but she may reach the Grande rade by keeping at least 4 miles from the coast. During the freshets of the Seine, vessels intending to enter Havre must avoid being set northward of the parallel of cape de la Heve. When rounding cape Barfleur with a south-westerly wind, from a position about 6 miles northward of that cape, haul up S.E. by S. or S.E. to sight the Ver light ; and, when on its meridian, keep away two or three points to sight cape de la Heve lights and steer for the anchorage in the Grande rade ; or, with a pilot on board, Havre may be steered for if the tide serves, and sail so regulated as not to arrive off the harbour's mouth until there is sufficient water to enter, see directions page 444. With a head wind, long boards should be made across the bay of the Seine by day as well as by night, recollecting that the flood stream ends in the bav nearly 2h hours before high water at Havre. To Havre from the Eastward. — In clear weather, with the wind between North and East, the Pas de Calais channel, between the Ridge bank or Colbart and the French coast, may be taken, and from thence a SW. £ W. course leads between the Bassurelle and Vergoyer banks direct for cape d'Antifer ; Fecamp light will be seen in following this course, and is a good guide at night. This channel is also used in fine weather when the wind is between South and East, keeping 4 or 5 miles from cape Grisnez, and passing outside the Bassure de Baas bank. When southward of the river Somme, and westward of the meridian of Dieppe, the coast may be neared if necessary ; but, should the wind veer to S.W., a vessel should quit the French coast immediately and, if it increases to a gale, seek the sheltered anchorage in Dungeness East Road. With the wind from N.N.W. round by West to W.S.W., the Dover channel between the Varne and the English coast should be used. From Beachy head, cape de la Heve bears S.S.W. 73 miles, and the passage with westerly winds is made more advantageously on the ebb than on the flood ; vessels, therefore, having held their own to wind ward, and in sight of Beachy head lighthouse, to the end of the flood, should then stretch across so as to arrive abreast of cape d'Antifer at the beginning of the following flood and in time to enter Havre at high water. Fecamp light is an excellent guide for the landfall on the French coast, and, in clear weather, will be seen in a 20-miles run after Beachy head light has been lost sight of. Heure Bay. — Between Havre and Hoc point, the shore and adjacent land is low but defended against the sea by an artificial

Chap. IX.] HAVRE. — DIRECTIONS. — HARFLEUR. 451 embankment abutting the wall which encloses the southern part of Havre as far as the middle of Heure bay, and, from thence to Hoc point, by a high natural bank of shingle. Heure bay seems to have been hollowed out by the violent eddy during the flood previously described, and is filled with shingle cemented together with mud, which uncovers from 9 to 13 feet at low water. In bad weather, whatever the direction of the wind, the sea breaks directly on the shore during the flood, and any vessel then missing the entrance to Havre and driving on shore in this bay would to a certainty be totally wrecked. Hoc Point. — This low point, composed of a mass of rolled shingle, is 34^ miles eastward of Havre, and 14 miles S.S.W. of Harfleur. It may be recognized by two large houses built to serve as a lazaretto, by the lighthouse, and by a guard-house about 200 yards from the lighthouse. The point projects considerably from the shore and occasions a strong eddy during the flood. This eddy stirs up the sand and hollows out a deep, the extent and depth of which are variable ; but, small vessels bound for Harfleur, or intending to ascend the Seine, lie aground without danger, sheltered by the point, and await spring tides. The bottom in this deep is sand and shingle, and vessels are moored securely as near as possible to either of its sides. The eddy on the flood is troublesome and the ebb stream very rapid. A good anchorage to await tide may be found a cable from the shore south-westward of Hoc point, with Harfleur steeple seen between the two warehouses of the lazaretto, but it is not safe for vessels to go there before 3 hours flood, nor to remain there after 3 hours ebb. LIGHT. — A fixed white light, dioptric and of the fifth order, is exhibited at 39 feet above high water from the circular lighthouse on Hoc point, and is visible in clear weather from a distance of 10 miles. HARFLEUR. — This little port dries out every tide, and small vessels ground on the slopes of mud forming the steep banks of the little river Lizarde which empties itself into the Seine about a mile below Harfleur at the head of the bay, which is 24. miles wide between Hoc point and the hill at Orcher. The lower course of the river was cleared out in 1838, and its waters formed a channel through the sands as far out as Hoc point, but, in 1869, this channel was completely choked up, and what little trade the port formerly had, has been almost entirely transferred to Havre and Fecamp. 2F2

The Coast. — From cape de la Heve, the coast trends N.E. \ N. northerly for 11 miles to cape d'Antifer, and consists of chalk cliffs with strata of flint from 320 to 370 feet high, which, with on-shore winds, have no accessible spot. Half a mile northward of cape de la Heve is the shore end of the telegraph cable communicating through Ballin skellig bay, Ireland, with America. Between cape de la Heve and the little valley of St Jouin, 84; miles farther northward, the crown of the cliffs only is perpendicular, enormous masses of flints shattered down from the cliffs above being banked up against them. It is supposed that the action of the sea causes a constant movement of these masses southward along the coast, and that they have largely contributed to form the banks south-westward of cape de la Heve, which obstruct the approaches to Havre and the Seine. Northward of St. Jouin, the cliffs, including cape d'Antifer, are quite perpendicular, the sea washing their base, and in the afternoon when lighted up by the sun their brightness is so dazzling that they may be seen 21 miles distant. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on cape d'Antifer. Tidal Streams in the Bay of the Seine,— The tidal wave of flood, after having traversed the western portion of the Channel, is much contracted as it advances eastward between Cherbourg and the Isle of Wight, and, in consequence of this compression, its velocity is greatly increased, especially towards the French coast. As soon as it has passed the meridian of cape Barfleur, its southern portion turns rapidly in every direction between South and East, to fill up the space occupied by the bay of the Seine ; whilst the northern portion, or that part northward of a line drawn from cape Barfleur to cape d'Antifer, follows its original direction almost as far as the meridian of the river Orne, where it begins to curve to East and E. by N. A considerable portion of the water which enters the bay, after rounding cape Barfleur with great rapidity, forms a stream which takes a S.E. by S. direction towards the mouth of the Seine. The southern part of this stream runs along the shore of the bay, and follows its sinuosities from point Percee to the mouth of the Orne, and then turns towards the Seine ; the northern part turns obliquely towards the coast between Havre and cape d'Antifer, and then bends back to S.S.W. and S.S.E. towards the Seine. Thus, the mouth of the Seine being the point towards which all these streams are directed, the river becomes full at two thirds flood, and the water within having attained the level of that without, the streams lose their strength and are forced eastward, and run towards E.N.E. and N.E. ;

Chap, ix.] 453 BAIE DE LA SEINE. — TIDAL STREAMS. in fact, in the direction they would have naturally followed from the commencement of the tide if the Seine had not existed. The ebb stream in the interior of the bay, when at its greatest strength, runs in the opposite direction to the flood ; but, northward of the line drawn from cape Barfleur to cape d'Antifer, its direction is W. by N. The windings of the coast modify the direction of both streams near the shore, and, behind each projecting point, there is an eddy depending on the strength of the tide for its extent, During springs, the flood stream is more rapid than the ebb. It commences suddenly and is not long in gaining strength ; the ebb, on the contrary, is slower in establishing itself. When stream and wind are in the same direction, the rate and duration of the stream is increased in proportion to the strength of the wind ; but, when the wind blows from a direction opposed to the stream, it has little effect on it.

ASPECT Of COAST.— Cape Grisnez bears from cape d'Antifer N.E. \ E. easterly 89 miles, the coast between forming a bight to the South-east, 106 miles in circuit and receding 24 miles from a line connecting the two points. The high cliffs of chalk and flint, described in the preceding chapter, extend from cape de la Heve to within about 4 miles north-eastward of Treport, near the town of Ault, and beyond them commences a low coast fronted by a sandy beach on which three wide valleys open out and give issue to the waters of the rivers Somme, Authie, and Canche. This low coast extends to within about 4 miles of Boulogne ; the land then rises abruptly and the shore con tinues steep, with a few exceptions, as far as cape Grisnez. All the harbours between capes d'Antifer and Grisnez dry at spring tides, and are inaccessible to vessels of deep draught at neaps.* The cliffs between cape d'Antifer and Ault are precipitous, their foot resting upon a narrow shelf of rock covered at all times of tide. A telegraph cable connecting with Beachy head leaves the shore just northward of the cape. The ports of Fecamp, St. Valery-en-Caux, Dieppe, and Treport, at about equal distances from each other, are at the entrances of wide valleys forming breaks in the line of cliffs. The land crowning the cliffs is for the most part level in its whole extent, but the monotonous aspect of the coast is varied by towns and villages near the sea, and by the verdure of the sides and bottoms of the valleys, which contrasts strongly with the uniform white of the cliffs. As the openings of all the valleys are dissimilar in some points, it is easy to distinguish them from each other, even from a considerable distance in the offing. * See Admiralty Charts : — North coast of France, sheet XII., Trouville to Dieppe. [Chap. X. 456 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. The cliffs remarkable for their height are, that of Fagnet point, the northern point of entrance to the valley of Fecamp, on which stands a chapel dedicated to Notre Dame du Salut and Fecamp lighthouse ; the cliff of Catellier, with a small mound on its summit, which forms the western side of the Pallud, a wide valley watered by the Durdent river ; the cliff of St. Leger, three quarters of a mile westward of St. Valery-en-Caux, marked by a church tower, the only remaining part of the church ; the cliff of Sotteville, rendered remarkable by a large guard-house and a heavy-looking church tower overtopping a row of trees ; and, the cliff at Criel, 3| miles south-westward of Treport, which is the highest of all and is surmounted by Mont Joli-Bois, a large hillock covered with heath. When sailing close to the coast with off-shore winds, vessels must be on their guard against the squalls which rush down the valleys ; the most violent are felt abreast of the openings which do not reach down to the beach. The entrances of the rivers Somme, Authie, and Canche, are in the low land which extends over a space of 35 miles, from half a mile north-eastward of Ault to the foot of the hills of which the most western parts form cape Alprech ; they are all obstructed by banks of shifting sand which extend far outside their openings and dry at low water, springs. The small harbours of Vimereux and Amble teuse having been destroyed by the sea and abandoned as such, no longer admit vessels of any description. Approaching the Coast. — The shore between cape d'Antifer and point d'Ailly, about 5 miles westward of Dieppe, is without danger, and large vessels may coast it at the distance of 14 miles ; but, eastward of this point, the approach to the shore is dangerous for vessels of deep draught, for, from the meridian of point d'Ailly to that of Treport, are banks of sand and shells, usually called Ridins, some of them lying as much as 11 miles from the shore; and, eastward and northward of these, is the shoal bottom forming the base of the shifting sands obstructing the mouths of the Somme, Authie, and Canche rivers, which extends even northward of the latter. Outside these shoals, and towards the middle of the Channel, are several long submarine banks of sand, converging in direction towards cape Grisnez. These banks lie generally about E.N.E. and W.S.W., nearly in the direction of the tidal streams ; but, the Riding or ridges, point N.N.W. and S.S.E. in a direction perpendicular to the banks and consequently across the streams. There are spots with only 2 or 3 fathoms on several of the banks, which are therefore very dangerous for large vessels at all times, while some are so only at low water.

Chap. X.] THE COAST — CAUTION. — CAPE D'ANTIFER. 457 At full and change, the tidal streams form strong eddies at the steep edges of these banks, and in bad weather, or with a fresh breeze on a weather tide, small vessels crossing the eddies subject themselves to a heavy sea. The greater part of the Ridins need be avoided only on account of the eddies they occasion, but shoal spots have been found on some, which at low water in bad weather would be dangerous to vessels of deep draught. CAUTION.— During strong winds from W.S.W. round by West to N.N.W. the coast eastward of point d'Ailly is dangerous to be near, and shipwrecks are of frequent occurrence ; vessels therefore of every description at such times should keep a good offing, and when obliged to approach the coast, must do so with great caution ; for, although the general mass of the bank described appears to be stationary, great attention should be paid to the lead and to observing the confused state of the sea in the various eddies, so as to guard against meeting suddenly with dangers which may be of recent formation. The lights indicating the positions of headlands and dangers between capes d'Antifer and Grisnez, are so disposed that at night, in clear weather, two can always be seen at a time, and most of the harbours show tide lights whilst there is sufficient water for them to be entered. It is important to notice that along the coast between cape de la Heve and the town of Ault, a space of 67 miles, the wind, when it blows in a direction perpendicular or nearly so to the direction of the coast, does not blow home but is reflected by the cliffs, and its effect is to a certain extent neutralized for some distance towards the offing. Thus, except in front of the wide valleys where the direct wind meets with no obstacle, a zone is formed off and parallel with the coast, where the wind is light but the sea much agitated and the waves run towards the shore. On the other hand, when the wind forms an acute angle with the coast, the reflected wind tends to increase the force of the direct wind near the shore. CAPE D'ANTIFER, as already noticed, differs but little from the adjacent land, and is only remarkable from the red house and white mast of the Semaphore station about 30 yards from the edge of the cliff, and from the change in the direction of the coast which there takes place. The cape is rounded and terminates in a perpen dicular chalk cliff 320 feet high, of which the foot is washed by the sea ; in clear weather it may be seen 21 miles distant. Vessels of any draught may approach to within 2 or 3 cables of it without danger even at low water ; from thence, the coa6t trends about E. by N. 9 miles to Fecamp and may be approached to about 4 cables.
