ETRET AT, a large fishing village and fashionable watering place, with a standing population of about 2,000, is on the shore at the entrance of a wide valley open to the North-west ; the houses are built on low land defended from the incursions of the sea by a natural high shingle beach, up which the fishermen heave their boats out of reach of the surf by means of capstans ; the beach is backed in the neighbourhood of the casino by pavement in masonry. Semaphore. — On the North-eastern cliffs of the little bay of Etretat is a semaphore station. The cliffs both eastward and westward of Etretat are very remarkable. They form sharp projecting points with openings in them resembling arches and doorways. Half a cable south-westward of the point, and westward of the village, is the Aiguille d'Etretat, a high rock, or rather the remains of fallen cliff, so named from its pyramidal form. The eastern part of the beach at Etretat is bordered by rocks which uncover at low water. Abreast of Etretat, the shoal bottom, with less than 8 fathoms, extends a mile off-shore, and, when the flood stream is at its greatest strength, a great eddy, named by local mariners the Hardiers, is formed and extends eastward as far as the Vaudieu rock, making the sea hollow and heavy when the wind is fresh from the eastward. IPORT, a fishing village and watering-place, 4\ miles eastward of Etretat and W. by S. f S. 2\ miles from the entrance to Fecamp, stands, like Etretat, at the entrance of a valley on low land near the sea, and is sheltered by a natural high shingle beach, strengthened by a small stone jetty and sea wall of masonry. The beach in front of the village is encumbered by rocks which uncover at low- water, and is not accessible to fishing boats until after the first hour's flood. The bluff point of Chicart witlr the rocks at its foot, afford a little shelter to the beach against westerly winds, but it is quite open northward, and when the sea is high the boats are hauled up on the beach. t t Between Etretat and Iport, at 1\ miles from Etretat point, called also the Porte Orientale, and less than a cable from the cliffs, is the Guillemot rock, which resembles a ruined column and rises 160 feet above the rocks which uncover along the shore. Half way between this rock and the Porte Orientale, but a little nearer the cliffs than the Guillemot, is the great Vaudieu rock about 53 feet high, with a one -fathom patch just outside it. These two rocks, like the Etretat needle, seem to be the remains of ancient cliffs. The base of the

Chap. X.] 459 ETRETAT. — IPORT. — FECAMP. Guillemot is so worn by the sea that it is probable it may fall ere long. FECAMP, of which the population in 1886 was 13,122, is a commercial, fishing, and refitting port of growing importance ; it is 9 miles eastward of cape d'Antifer, at the entrance of a fine valley watered by the rivers Valmont and Ganzeville. It consists of an outer tidal harbour, from which the Berigny wet dock and the Gayant tidal basin are entered. At the head of the latter is a large Bassin de Chasses or reservoir for flushing and scouring the harbour entrance by means of sluices. These flushings are not often required now, the extension of the South jetty in recent years having completely arrested the formation of the sand and gravel bar which formerly obstructed the entrance, and, in conjunction with extensive blasting operations in the rocky bed of the entrance channel, having caused a general deepening of the channel.* The entrance is open to N.W. by W., and is between two stone jetties at the foot of the high cliff forming Fagnet point, The jetty heads bear N.E. and S.W. from each other and are 227 feet apart, the channel narrowing to 131 feet within ; here, it was until recently enclosed by low wood-works or stockades which have been entirely removed, and the deep water channel within the jetty-heads is now marked by red lights or flags to be left on the port side in entering, and by green lights or flags on the starboard side. The entrance channel has about one foot of water at the lowest tides. The South jetty was formerly only 172 feet long, and was built at the end of the natural high shingle beach which shelters the harbour, to arrest the progress of the shingle along the coast from the South-west, and to oblige it to take a direction outwards from the entrance ; wdien extended, as before stated, level with the North jetty, it completely answered its purpose. The North jetty, 326 feet long, is built on the rocks which uncover at the foot of Fagnet point, and forms a con tinuation of the quay on the northern side of the harbour. The outer portion of both jetties is now straight instead of curved as formerly. The depth in the entrance channel is always greater than inside the harbour ; at high water, ordinary springs, it is 24 feet, and at neaps 18 feet. The back-water of Fecamp is very powerful for scouring out the channel when required, and it can be done both through the Gayant * See enlarged plan of Fecamp, on Admiralty chart, No. 2,612.

460 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. and Berigny basins. The sluices can always maintain the channel leading up to the lock gates of the Berigny basin, which, like the entrance channel, was deepened by removing the rocky bottom to a depth of 6 feet below low water, springs ; a bed of sand has formed over this rocky bottom, easily removed if required, but the depths throughout are now (1888) ample for the requirements of the port. The Tidal Harbour is nearly 2 cables long N.E. and S.W. by one cable wide, and dries 2 or 3 feet alongside the quays at low water, springs. A high and strong natural dyke of shingle cemented with mud forms its western side ; its other sides are bordered by quays. With a fresh westerly wind, a heavy sea runs into the entrance channel, and, reaching the interior of the harbour, occasions a surf distressing to vessels moored along the eastern quay and sometimes causes damage. The bottom for the most part is a mixture of chalky mud, sand, and gravel, and affords a tolerably good bed for grounding on. The Berigny Basin, or wet dock, is between the tidal harbour and the south-western angle of the Bassin de Chasses, into which flow all the running streams of the valley. The Berigny basin is 405 yards long in a S.E.-gE. direction from its entrance and 110 yards wide ; the bottom, of gravel cemented together by mud, is about the level of low water, springs ; the gates keep the water at a depth of 17 feet 8 inches, but at high water, springs, there are 24 feet 3 inches. New iron gates are about to be hung which will retain the water at the height of the tide of the day. The basin is surrounded by quays on which are steam cranes travelling on rails and all con veniences for loading and unloading. It communicates with the Gayant tidal basin by a lock 33 feet wide with 23 feet over the sill at high water, springs ; and, with the outer harbour, by means of a lock 54 feet wide, the sill of which is 6 feet below the level of low water, springs, and it admits vessels of any draught that can enter the harbour. The Gayant tidal basin is chiefly used by coasters and by the large deep sea fishing fleet equipped at Fecamp. Alterations are now (1888) in progress in this basin and in the Bassin de Chasses by which another tidal basin and wet dock will shortly be added to the port. The railway station is at the head of the Berigny basin ; it unites with the main line for Paris at Beuzeville. Havre is distant about

Chap. X.] FECAMP. 461 24 miles by road, but Fecamp has no regular steam communication by sea with any port. It has large fish-curing establishments, and building yards where the Newfoundland and other deep sea fishing craft are constructed, as also a gridiron 150 feet long, but no dry dock. Repairs to vessels, both wood and iron, can be effected and moderate repairs to machinery. In 1887, the trade of the port, exclusive of its large fishing interest, was represented by the entry of 178 vessels of an aggregate of 44,869 tons. The exports are chiefly wines, spirits, flints, &c. ; the imports, coal, timber, wheat, cement, salt, &c. There is a good hospital available for seamen in cases of illness. Coals are always to be obtained, the average stock on hand being about 1,000 tons, and the port is convenient for steamers up to 300 feet in length. Vessels coal either in the Berigny or in the tidal basin, and from 200 to 300 tons can be put on board in a day. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on Fagnet point 120 yards eastward of the lighthouse. LIGHTS. — Fecamp lighthouse, a square tower 59 feet high, stands on the summit of Fagnet point at about 93 yards from the edge of the cliff and exhibits at 374 feet above high water a fixed ivhite light, dioptric and of the first order, visible 20 miles ; its position, on the crest of a hill rising abruptly from a deep grassy valley watered by abundant streams, causes it to be frequently obscured by mist or completely hidden by fogs. Fecamp harbour has the following lights : — South jetty. — A. fixed red light is shown from an iron standard 11 yards from the jetty-head, visible 5 miles. North j etty. — From a round turret 43 feet above high water and 58 yards within the jetty-head is exhibited a fixed white light, varied by a flash every three minutes ; the flashes are preceded and followed by short eclipses. This light is shown only whilst there are more than 10£ feet water in the entrance channel ; it is dioptric of the fourth order, and visible 12 miles in clear weather. A vessel approaching the harbour from the eastward does not open this light until it bears southward of S.W. by W., as, westward of that bearing, it is masked by Fagnet cliff. Fog bell. — A bell is sounded during foggy weather from the North jetty ; it sounds continuously for two minutes at short intervals ; during the intervals a single stroke of the bell denotes

[Chap. X. 462 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. that there are 13 feet water in the channel ; 2 strokes, that there are 16£ feet, and so on. (See note, page 10.) Life-Boat.— A life-boat is stationed at Fecamp, and there is a mortar apparatus on each jetty. Tides.— It is high water, full and change, in Fecamp harbour at lOh. 44m. ; springs rise 23 feet ; neaps 17 feet. There are 24 feet in the entrance channel, at high water, ordinary springs, if it is clear of all deposit of shingle which appears now to create no difficulty. Strong westerly winds for several successive days raise the tides one or two feet higher in the harbour but cause a heavy sea at the entrance ; the contrary is the case with the wind from the eastward. The duration of slack water is not more than 15 or 20 minutes at the utmost, and consequently the entrance to the wet dock is only open for about half an hour. Tide Signals.— The usual tide signals are made from a flagstaff on the inner part of the South jetty, see page 8. Pilots. — Four qualified pilots are stationed at Fecamp ; their limits are, Saint-Jouin to the south- westward, and Veulettes to the north-eastward. Directions. — Fecamp harbour, since the great modern improve ments, is not generally difficult to enter, but it is dangerous when it blows strongly from the westward on account of the heavy sea off the entrance ; for, should a vessel then miss the harbour and ground on the rocks off Fagnet point, she would be totally lost. If the weather is doubtful, look out for the signal as to whether the harbour is practicable, see page 8, and, if not, haul off at once. A steam-tug is stationed at the port and every assistance is given to warp or track vessels in or out, boats and men being always ready at the entrance when the weather permits. Vessels arriving off the harbour towards low water, with the wind between W.S.W. and W.N.W., should steer for the land about Etretat, and keep to windward of the harbour until the tide serves to run in. With the wind between N.N.W. and E.N.E., the land should be made about Vattetot and Iport ; and, if the wind should come off-shore and there is a chance of losing the tide, anchorage may be found about 14; miles from the coast near the meridian of Iport in 10 fathoms water, and tolerably good holding ground, with Etretat needle on

Chap. X.] FECAMP. — DIRECTIONS. 463 with the Porte Orientale, and the bell tower of the abbaye at Fecamp on with the last slope of the hills a little southward of the houses of the town. On arriving only two or three hours before high water, a vessel might anchor closer in-shore but in such a position that she may be able to fetch the entrance of the harbour. These anchorages, however, are only good for a few hours, unless the weather is quite fine. One of the difficulties when entering Fecamp harbour is the eastern stream of flood, which continues to be felt across the jetty-heads for about half an hour after high water in the harbour and runs even at that time at the rate of 14 knots eastward along the coast at a cable outside the heads, so that a sailing vessel approaching the entrance on the starboard tack requires to be well to windward or she may be driven to leeward of the North jetty and miss the port. With a fair wind, or when close hauled, sufficient sail should be carried to get quickly into harbour, and it must be so balanced that the helm may be answered with the greatest promptitude. In heavy weather, the worst sea is from 250 to 350 yards outside the jetty-heads. With the wind from N.W. or N.E., squalls and baffling winds are very apt to occur when in the entrance channel. The method generally adopted when entering the harbour with a fair wind without the steam-tug, is to stand fairly in between the jetties and then the sails may be clewed up, and the vessel will be tracked up to her berth. If intending to enter the Berigny basin, the harbour should be entered at least three quarters of an hour before high water ; but, if the vessel is to remain in the tidal harbour, it may be entered later. Caution. — Care must be taken on quitting Fecamp harbour with a westerly wind, to avoid being drifted by the flood on the Charpen tiers shoals, which join the rocks at Fagnet point and extend west ward as far as the line of St. Leonard's spire on with the North jetty head S.S.W. To pass well outside the swell caused by these shoals, keep Grinval valley open, so that the new guard-house may appear above the middle of the cleft by which the descent is made to the beach. The Coast from Fecamp trends E. by N. 4 N. 10 miles to Catellier point and then E. \ S. 5 miles to St. Valery-en-caux, and consists of the high perpendicular cliffs of chalk and flint before described intersected by numerous valleys, of which the greater part do not reach down to the level of the beach. A shelf of irregular rocks,

464 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. which uncover at low water, borders the shore, but no part of it projects farther than about 3 cables from the cliffs, so that large vessels may approach the shore to about half a mile at any time of tide. The appearance of this part of the coast is dull and uniform ; the land seen above the cliffs is apparently level and only varied by occasional clumps of trees surrounding farms and villages. Above these trees occasionally appear church towers, the most conspicuous being those of Senneville, Sassetot, St. Martin-aux-Bunaux, Conteville, and St. Leger ; the last named stands near the edge of the cliff three quarters of a mile westward of St. Valery, has a tall isolated spire, and may be seen from a great distance in the offing. ST. VALERY-EN-CATJX, a town of 4,200 inhabitants, has a small bar harbour and is at the entrance of a narrow valley between high hills ; the depths at the entrance vary greatly according to the state of the bar, but, as a rule, it admits vessels of about 14 feet draught at high water, springs, but only fishing and small coasting craft during neaps ; as it has as yet no railway communication nearer than Motteville, on the Paris and Havre line, its trade is small, the annual entry of tonnage being about 13,000 and not increasing. Mackerel, herring, and cod fisheries are carried on, and coals, Baltic and Norway timber, wine, brandy, &c, are imported, vessels usually leaving in ballast. The port consists of a channel between two jetties of unequal length, leading into a small tidal harbour, and of a reservoir for backwater, a part of which serves as a wet dock. The western jetty is the longest ; it is 377 yards long, including 129 yards of open pile work. The eastern jetty is 169 yards long, its head bears from the western jetty-head S.E. by E. 100 yards, but the width between the jetties is only 65 yards at the outer parti and 40 yards at the inner. The width of the navigable channel is still further reduced by the vast mass of shingle which collects inside the channel against the West jetty leaving a space of only about 22 yards, and this space is with difficulty kept open along the East jetty by sluicing, and an average but by no means reliable depth of 20 feet preserved at high water, springs, and of 13 or 14 feet at neaps. The tidal harbour is 34^ acres in extent and has quays on its eastern and western sides, and a small building and repairing slip for fishing craft, In the centre it has about the same depth as the entrance channel, but dries as much as 13 feet alongside the quays ; the bottom is soft and good for grounding but strong northerly winds send in so much sea as not only to break vessels

Chap. X.] 465 ST. VALERY-EN-CAUX. — BAR. away from their moorings but also to make it unsafe to open the lock gates into the wet dock. Vessels in the tidal harbour should be placed parallel with the quay and the moorings watched as the scouring water is let out, for its rapidity is such that it will under mine those which have grounded at right angles or diagonally to its direction. The wet dock or basin is a part of the flushing reservoir, 6 acres in size, the whole reservoir being 174 acres ; it communicates with the tidal harbour by means of a small lock 138 feet long with sluice gates 30 feet wide, and has a depth of 18 feet over the sill at high water, springs, and of 11 or 12 feet at neaps. The valley of St. Valery, of which the town and harbour occupy the entrance, is about two cables wide, and is at the head of a small bight in the coast. The rocky ledge which uncovers at the foot of the cliff along the coast has an opening in it in front of the valley, and the space between consists of a beach of chalky mud and cemented shingle 24; cables wide, on which the shingle, always working along from the westward, is deposited. The channel leading to the harbour runs through this beach, and its direction when between the jetties is about North and South. Bar. — The beach uncovers, during springs, one cable outside the western jetty, and the shingle borne from the westward forms on it a bar in front of the entrance, one end of which sometimes joins the West jetty-head, but generally leaves a channel from 40 to 50 yards wide between it and that jetty-head. The scouring water not having force enough to open a passage through the bar, runs out generally by its eastern end. The bar rises if westerly winds continue, and a south-westerly gale brings an enormous mass of shingle on the beach ; the higher the bar the more it extends north-eastward, forcing the outer part of the channel eastward. The entrance has sometimes been completely closed by shingle ; when this has occurred an opening has been made by manual labour, and increased by repeated scourings. Various improvements made in the entrance have, however, prevented the accumulation of gravel becoming so dangerous to navigation as formerly, though it is still very difficult to contend with, and there is almost always a high bank against the inner part of the West jetty, narrowing the entrance to the tidal harbour. When strong easterly winds blow for any length of time, the surf drives the shingle from the entrance, lowering the bar and dividing it into several parts, and then by copious flushings the channel is sometimes completely cleared. East Jetty.— A fixed red light, visible 2 miles, is shown from the East jetty-head. Fog Signals.— At the West jetty-head, a bell gives 20 strokes followed by an interval of 20 seconds. A double stroke sounded in the middle of each interval denotes that there are 84_ feet or more in the entrance channel. (See note, page 10.) Tide Signals.— The usual tide signals, see page 8, are made from a mast on the West jetty ; — the signal-man also signals by hand the direction to take for the deepest water. Life-Boat.— There is a life-boat and also a mortar apparatus, at St. Valery-en-caux, in case of shipwreck. Pilots. — Three qualified pilots are stationed at this port, and, considering the varying depths and shifting nature of the bar, it need scarcely be added that no stranger should enter without a pilot. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on the highest and most prominent point of the coast just westward of the entrance to Stl Valery-en-caux. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at St. Valery-en-caux at lOh. 46m. springs rise 27 feet ; neaps 21^ feet. The depth in the entrance channel, however, as already explained, varies greatly, but about 20 feet at springs and 13 or 14 feet at neaps is the average ; with fresh westerly winds, the water is a foot higher, and, with easterly winds, a foot lower than the ordinary rise. During springs, when the outer shingle banks are all covered, the flood stream forms a great eddy in the elbow eastward of the jetties which runs westward along the shore of the elbow and along the outer side of the eastern jetty. This eddy, named the Sciade, much resembles the Verhaule at Havre ; a part of it, after rounding the East jetty-head, enters the entrance channel, whilst the principal portion crossing the channel obliquely, runs along the West jetty and rounds its head as soon as the flood stream outside slacks, which takes place about a quarter of an hour before high water. The eddy is usually

Chap. X.] ST. VALERY-EN-CAUX. — DIRECTIONS. 467 more rapid with westerly than with easterly winds, and, with the former, when at its greatest strength shortly after high water, it assists to keep vessels in the channel. The flood stream continues to be felt at a short distance outside the jetties for more than half an hour after high water in the harbour, and is a great inconvenience when entering with westerly winds, or when the sea is high, if the entrance round the West jetty -head happens to be closed and it is necessary to round the bar well to the eastward to get into the entrance channel. Directions. — Vessels unable to enter St. Valery-en-caux harbour during neaps must keep at sea until springs, except with off-shore winds in fine weather, when they may anchor at from half to three quarters of a mile from the shore, between the guard-house at Cinq Trous and St. Leger, in from 5 to 10 fathoms water, tolerably good holding ground. Arriving off the entrance at springs, with only a few hours to wait for sufficient water, they should, with westerly winds, make short boards between Catellier point and St_ Leger, or if the wind is from the eastward they should maintain a position off the harbour. When standing in-shore, eastward of the entrance,, care must be taken to keep Catellier point well open north ward of the point formed by the cliffs near Sussette valley bearing about W. 4 S. to avoid the Ridins, a dangerous bank of sand and gravel E. by N. f N. three quarters of a mile from the West jetty head, on which are only 2 feet at low water, and a high sea during a weather tide. There is no difficulty in entering the harbour, whatever the direction of the wind, provided the entrance channel runs at the foot of the West jetty-head where there is then generally sufficient water at about 20 yards from the head at half an hour before high water, and if the wind does not admit of sailing between the jetties a vessel will be tracked in by a crew always in attendance ; but, it is difficult of access when the bar joins the foot of the West jetty-head and the only channel open is northward and eastward of the bar, and it would then be very imprudent to attempt it without a pilot, especially with the wind between South and West. When the state of the sea prevents pilots going out, they attend on the jetties to signal the course to be followed to round the bar and enter the channel. The most favourable moment to enter with westerly winds is when the Sciade or eddy is at its greatest strength, that is, from half an hour before to half an hour after high water ; the anchors should be clear and sufficient sail carried for the vessel to answer her helm quickly. With winds between North and East, it is advisable to enter before 2G 2

[Chap. X. 468 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. the Sciade has acquired its full strength, for fear of being drifted on the West jetty. With northerly winds, there is a high sea on the bar and plenty of sail should be carried in crossing it, as the wind reflected by the cliffs decreases the force of the true wind and if the surf is not crossed rapidly a heavy sea may be shipped. There is not much difficulty in quitting the harbour, as it can only be attempted in moderate weather, but care must be taken to choose a favourable time of tide ; thus, with easterly winds, vessels should leave the jetty before high water whilst the flood stream has still much strength, but with westerly winds they should not leave until the ebb stream is well established. THE COAST. — From St. Valery-en-caux, the coast, a high per pendicular cliff of chalk and flint, trends E. 4 S. southerly 15 miles to Dieppe ; point d'Ailly, 5 miles westward of Dieppe, extending con siderably northward of that line. The first projecting point, 5 miles eastward of St. Valery is that of Sotteville, which may be known at a great distance by a heavy-looking church tower rising above the trees of the village from which the point takes its name, and by a conspicuous guard-house. The shelf of rock bordering the shore extends about 2 cables from this point, which should not be approached within 3| cables by vessels hugging the coast with off-shore winds. Raz de St. Michel. — Between Sotteville point and point d'Ailly are three wide valleys, separated by high cliffs, occupying half the interval between these points. The middle or St. Aubin's valley descends to the shore, and on its eastern side the waters of the river Dun open a passage through the shingle beach. The rocks which uncover at the foot of the cliffs extend 3 cables from the shore on both sides of this valley, and in front of it an irregular rocky bottom, with from 14 to 20 feet water, projects a mile from the shore. This extension, lying at right angles with the tidal streams, causes the raz or race of St. Michel, a strong eddy dangerous at low water to small vessels sailing near the coast with off-shore winds ; but, Catellier cliff kept well open of the point formed by the cliffs near Sussette valley W. 4 S. leads outside it, Point d'Ailly is of a rounded form, and although less elevated than many other points of the coast, may be easily recognised, as the perpendicular chalk cliff forms only half its height ; a thick bed of clay and vegetable mould, lying above the chalk, sloping down to the edge of the cliff.

Chap. X.] THE COAST.— POINT, LIGHT, AND ROCHES D'AILLY. 469 LIGHT. — A little within point d'Ailly stands a square tower, 66 feet high, which exhibits at 305 feet above high water, a revolving ivhite light, the eclipses of which take place every minute, but are not total within the distance of 12 miles. The light is dioptric, of the first order, and in clear weather may be seen 24 miles distant. Fog Signal.— At 328 yards south-westward of the lighthouse, a steam trumpet gives two consecutive blasts every forty seconds, each blast lasting three seconds with an interval between the two of two seconds ; the first blast is a high note, the second a low note. (See note, page 10.) Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station at point d'Ailly, 329 yards S.W. h W. from the lighthouse. Roches d'Ailly. — The shore eastward and westward of point d'Ailly, from the valley of Pourville to that of Quiberville, is bordered by the Roches d'Ailly, a bank consisting of blocks of freestone, which uncover at low water and terminate in a point half a mile N.N.E. of the lighthouse. The Galere, a rock with two heads, higher and larger than the rest, rises from the middle of the bank, and when its summit is covered there are about 21 or 22 feet water in the entrance to Dieppe. The square church tower of St. Jacques, at Dieppe, 2° or 3° open eastward of the cliff on which are the ramparts of the castle bearing E. by S. £ S. leads half a cable northward of the bank. Grand and Petit Eeamias and Ridin de Dieppe.— On the meridian of point d'Ailly, the western part of the Ridins or Ridges, those heaps of sand and broken shells noticed at page 456, is found ; they extend 11 miles in the offing, and eastward as far as the meridian of Treport. Those northward of point d'Ailly are divided into two groups, and not having less than 7 fathoms water, with from 12 to 15 fathoms round them, they can only be dangerous from the heavy sea on them in bad weather ; the Petit Eeamias, the northern group, lies 7 miles, and the Grand Eeamias, the southern group, 4 miles from the shore. Ridin de Dieppe. — The Ridins generally are not dangerous but the sea runs high in the eddies formed by them on a weather tide. The Ridin de Dieppe, or Frilandais, however, which lies N.N.E. E. easterly 10 miles from Dieppe, is an exception to this rule, for vessels of deep draught might strike on it at low water,

470 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. springs, and small vessels are liable to ship heavy seas when crossing it in bad weather. When this part of the coast was surveyed in 1835 it was 2 miles in length, N.N.W. and S.S.E., the highest part being half a mile long, with from 23 to 27 feet water. As it is probable that these Ridins, being composed of substances easily set in motion, are liable to change their position, the mariner will act prudently when in their vicinity by keeping at a distance from any great eddies, their strength being generally in proportion to the shallowness of the water by which they are occasioned. The Tidal Streams follow the direction of the coast between St. Valery-en-caux and Dieppe, and their rate, at springs, is about 34^ knots ; but, near points Sotteville and d'Ailly they run 4 knots. About the time the rocks off point d'Ailly begin to cover, an eddy stream setting westward, commences in-shore off the Varengeville coast, and continues until the end of the flood. Under the lee of Dieppe West jetty also, at about a cable distance, a similar eddy is caused ; it runs westward close round the East jetty-head and joins the stream entering the harbour.* DIEPPE. f — This important and growing commercial and fishing port lies E. f S. 5 miles from point d'Ailly, and the town with its suburb, Le Pollet, occupies the entire entrance of a valley nearly a mile wide, wdiich is watered by the rivers Arques, Bethune, and Aure. The population of Le Pollet, which is eastward of Dieppe and connected with it by movable bridges, are chiefly engaged in the herring, oyster, and cod fisheries. The principal imports are coals, coke, timber, pig iron, woollen and cotton manufactured goods, agricultural machinery, pottery, &c. The exports are manufactured silks, Paris and Lyons goods, wines, spirits, fruits, vegetables, flints, &c. There are sugar refineries, rope-walks, paper-mills, ship yards, a gridiron in the outer port, and a heaving-down pontoon in the Berigny dock ; a graving dock is proposed, and until it is constructed heavy repairs to steamers or sailing vessels cannot be effected. The foreign and coasting trades are active, and, in 1887, 1,641 vessels of an aggregate tonnage of 527,281 tons entered the port. Steamers ply daily between Dieppe and Newhaven, two or three times a week with Grimsby, and bi-monthly with Christiania. Dieppe being on one of the main routes between London and Paris is in * From observations made in 1878 it would appear that the strength of the tidal streams in the immediate neighbourhood of Dieppe is at least one knot less than is here given. t See Admiralty plan of the port of Dieppe, No. 1073 ; scale, m = 5 inches.

Chap, x.] DIEPPE. — DOCKS. 471 excellent and easy communication with all parts of France. The population in 1886 amounted to 23,050. There is a good hospital to which foreign sailors are admitted on payment for medical attendance, and there is a British Seamen's reading room supported by voluntary contributions. Coals can always be obtained in any quantity and at low price. Vessels are coaled either in the tidal harbour or in the basins. The port has undergone great improvements lately and important works are still (1888) in progress ; those completed since 1880 are, the setting back of the East pier, which increases the width of the channel to a minimum of 82 yards ; the lengthening of the West pier by 55 yards ; the rebuilding of several quays ; and, the construction of an additional basin or wet dock, and also a half -tide dock. In its present condition the port consists of an Outer port or tidal harbour with an area of 21 acres, a New port, also tidal and of about the same dimensions, and four wet docks or basins, viz : — the Duquesne, Berigny, Half- Tide, and New dock. Wet docks. — The Duquesne dock has an area of nearly 10 acres, is 54 feet wide at the entrance, and has 24 feet 6 inches over the sill at high water, springs, and 17 feet 8 inches at neaps ; it is in direct communication with the tidal harbour. The Berigny dock opens into the Duquesne, has an area of nearly 9 acres, is 46 feet wide at the entrance, and has 23 feet 4 inches over the sill at high water, springs, and 16 feet 7 inches at neaps. The Half-tide and New docks, both constructed in the bed of the old Bassin de Chasses, are entered from the New port. The Half-tide dock is 492 feet long and 328 feet wide ; the entrance gates are 59 feet wide, and have 33 feet over the sill of the N.W. gates at high water, springs, and 26 feet 4 inches at neaps ; the sill of the S.E. gates have 34 feet less. The New dock has a large area, being no less than 1,700 feet long by 360 feet wide, but a portion of the buildings in connection with it are not yet complete, and there are no quays on its eastern side. The dimensions of the entrance are the same as of the Duquesne. The new channel through the Pollet suburb, under construction, and to be completed in 1889, will give direct access from the Outer port to the New port and thus to the Half-tide and New docks with entrances 59 feet wide. Until this channel is completed, admission to these docks is through the Duquesne dock into the New port by the old sluice lock of the Retenue. The depth of the docks is that of the adjoining lock gates, except the

[Chap. x. 472 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. Half -tide dock, in which there are 1 foot 6 inches of water at low water, springs. The docks have very extensive quay frontage, with rails laid, numerous steam cranes, and every appliance for loading and dis charging cargo. The Duquesne dock is opened every tide, day and night, for all vessels, but the Berigny dock is only opened at night for steamers. Admittance to the other docks is subject to certain conditions resulting from the works still in progress. The principal works now in progress (1888) are, the dredging and deepening of the entrance channel and outer harbour, the opening of the channel through the Pollet suburb to the New port before mentioned, and the erection of hydraulic machinery for the motive power of the port works. The harbour is sheltered from all winds, and its docks admit vessels of about 23 feet draught at high water, springs, and of about 17 feet at neaps ; the largest as yet received into the docks drew 20£ feet. Pilots. — Sixteen pilots and four assistants, under the orders of a chief pilot, are stationed at Dieppe, they cruise in the offing in decked boats. When the state of the sea is such as to prevent them boarding vessels in the offing, they remain on the jetty-heads and direct them by waving their hats. Vessels drawing 10 feet water may enter the channel from 2\ to 3 hours before high water, and, with a fresh leading wind, for 3 hours after high water ; vessels of deep draught are usually taken in during the last hour of the flood. The bottom alongside the quays of the tidal harbour is a mixture of mud and shingle, it is about 3 feet at the North quay, and 4 or 5 feet at the South quay above the level of ordinary spring tides. Vessels here are exposed to considerable surf when the sea is high at the entrance, especially when there are only from 6 to 10 feet water in the entrance channel. The Entrance Channel is on the eastern side of the valley nearly 2 cables from the high cliffs of Femme-Grosse point ; it is about 650 yards long and commencing in a S.S.E. direction curves southward and then westward into the Outer or tidal harbour, at the south-eastern corner of which is the new channel under construction into the New port. Its inner part is enclosed between the northern quays of the town and Le Pollet suburb. The outer part of the channel was formerly liable to be obstructed by shingle driven alongshore during westerly winds, and the scouring waters could not keep down these

Chap, x.] DIEPPE. — PILOTS. — LIGHTS. 473 accumulations ; modern improvements, however, seem to have over come the difficulty. In 1882 the shingle bar was only just above the level of low water, springs; since then, the depths have been increased and maintained by dredging, the flushings being no longer necessary. The bottom of the channel and Outer port are still undergoing dredging, with the object of obtaining a depth at low water, ordinary springs, of 8 feet throughout ; practically it may be considered now (1888) as at about the level of low water, equinoctial springs. A high sea runs at the entrance with winds from W.S.W. round by West to N.E. ; those from the westward, especially, cause a heavy confused sea. LIGHTS. — The following lights are established on the jetties at Dieppe. "West jetty. — A. fixed white light, dioptric and of the fifth order, is shown at 43 feet above high water from a stone tower 38 yards from the old jetty-head and visible in clear weather from a distance of 10 miles. A fixed green light of small power is shown provisionally from the outer end of the prolongation of the West jetty. It is 62 yards out side the white light, and is 24 feet above high water. To avoid the works projecting from the West jetty-head, vessels should pass at least 13 yards clear of the green light, the position of which, during the day, is marked by a green flag. Fog bell. — A fog bell is sounded from the house on the West jetty continuously for 2 minutes, at short intervals ; one stroke sounded in the intervals indicates a depth of 13 feet in the entrance channel, 2 strokes, Vo\ feet, and so on ; see note, page 10. East Jetty.— Fixed and Tidal Lights.— Three fixed white lights are shown from a mast 11 yards from the East jetty-head ; they are respectively 22^, 30, and 35^ feet above high water. The lower light is permanent throughout the night and is visible at 10 miles. The middle light is tidal, visible 10 miles, and is shown from 2 .', hours before until 2 hours after high water. The upper light is also tidal and" visible 10 miles ; it is lighted 2 hours before, and extinguished at high water. The two latter are not lighted when from the state of the sea the harbour is inaccessible. As a guide to vessels entering, when from the state of the weather pilots cannot get on board, the mast which

CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. 474 carries the lights is kept in a vertical position while the vessel pre serves her proper course ; but, should she deviate, the mast is inclined to that side towards which she should steer. Vessels desirous of profiting by these signals should show two lights, one forward and one aft. A fixed white light is shown from a beacon erected near the East jetty, westward of the southern portion of the breakwater ; the beacon serves to indicate the position of the piles of the old pier, and by day carries a red flag. Tide Signals.— The usual tide signals, see page 8, commencing from a depth of 6| feet, are made from a flagstaff on the West jetty. A ivhite flag with blue border, hoisted at the entrance of the harbour indicates that the basins are open. Special Signals for steamers.— When one or more steamers are about to enter or quit the port, a red flag is hoisted at the outer end of the West jetty, and also at the inner end of the East jetty ; whilst these are displayed, access to the entrance channel is forbidden to all other vessels ; those already within it, however, are to continue their movements. A ivhite flag with a blue border hoisted above a red flag indicates that vessels may enter but not leave the port, The same flags reversed, that vessels may leave but not enter. At night, red and ivhite lights are substituted for the flags. The tide signals as well as the special signals are repeated approximately from two masts near the semaphore. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on the cliff of la Femme-Grosse, 530 yards from the entrance to Dieppe and E.N.E. from the lighthouse on the West jetty. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Dieppe at llh. 6m. ; springs rise 27 feet, neaps 204 feet. There are in the entrance channel and Outer port about 29 feet at ordinary springs ; 31 feet at equinoctial springs ; and, 22 or 23 feet at neaps. At spring tides, high water slack lasts 10 minutes ; at neaps, 30 or 40 minutes. Fresh westerly winds cause the tide to rise a foot or 18 inches higher than in calm weather, and easterly winds have a contrary effect. The highest tide takes place about 52 hours after full and change, and the least tide occurs about 63 hours after the quadrature. The mean duration of the rising tide on the beach at Dieppe is 5h. 40m., and of the falling tide 6h. 45m.

Chap, x.] DIEPPE. — TIDES. — DIRECTIONS. 475 A Life-Boat is stationed at Dieppe, and there is a mortar life saving apparatus on each pier. Directions. — The hill and cliff separating the valleys of Pour ville and Dieppe, and the chapel of St. Nicholas on the summit of the hill, are marks which assist in recognising the position of Dieppe when approaching it from the northward or north-westward. The valley of Pourville is the most remarkable valley on this part of the coast, being the only one eastward of point d'Ailly that descends to the beach ; it is watered by the little river Scic, which finds a passage through the shingle to the sea. Two steam-tugs are stationed at this port, and a vessel of deep draught arriving off it during neaps is entitled to a pilot to take charge of her at sea, until there is sufficient depth to enter at springs. When standing for the land with westerly winds towards the hour of low water, a position to windward should be maintained by making short tacks between point d'Ailly and St. Nicholas' chapel until there is water to run for the West jetty-head ; with easterly winds, a vessel should keep on the meridian of the chapel. With off-shore winds in fine weather, or in a calm, she may anchor for a few hours in 34; fathoms water, about half a mile from the shore, North or N.N.W. of St. Nicholas' chapel. This anchorage is called Dieppe road, but it affords no shelter with northerly winds and should be left with all speed, and a good offing gained, if there is any appearance of wind from that direction. In standing for the harbour, the West jetty-head should be steered for, whatever the direction of the wind, because, at half a cable outside the jettyr-heads, the eastern stream continues to be felt 40 minutes after high water in the harbour, and it runs at the rate of H knots during the whole time vessels of deep draught can enter. With a light wind, if this precaution is not taken, the vessel will be drifted eastward of the entrance. The West jetty-head should be approached with caution, and, if no pilot is on board, sufficient sail should be carried to execute quickly any change of course the pilots on the jetty may direct. Moderate winds from N.N.W. round by North to E.N.E. are the most favourable for entering Dieppe ; with all other winds it is necessary for a vessel either to secure the services of a steam-tug, or to steer for the weather jetty to be tracked in. The valley of Dieppe has a great influence on the direction of off-shore winds ; thus, if the wind is E.S.E. in the offing it will be S.S.E. at the entrance of the harbour ; and, if West outside, it will be S.W. in the harbour and

476 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. entrance channel. W.S.W. winds are reflected by the high cliff between Le Pollet suburb and Femme-Grosse point, and their force much weakened ; a vessel, therefore, running for the harbour with the wind between W.S.W. and W.N.W. should carry good sail to cross the broken water caused by these winds at the entrance. The COAST from Dieppe trends E. by N. 4 N. Northerly 13^ miles to Treport, and, like that westward of Dieppe, consists of high per pendicular cliffs of chalk and flint, intersected by numerous valleys. The telegraph cable connecting with Beachy head leaves the shore, a short distance eastward of Dieppe. The land adjacent to the cliffs is slightly undulating, the highest parts being in the vicinity of Penly village and on the western point of the entrance of Criel vallejr, where the cliff is surmounted by Mont Joli-bois, a remarkable conical mound covered with heath, of which the base is half a mile wide.* The valleys, which may be recognised from the offing, are those of Puits, Belleville, Berneval, PenlyT, Neuvillette, Criel, and Mesnil. Puits valley descends to the shore a mile eastward of Dieppe, and at the top of its eastern steep edge are the remains of the Camp de Cesar, an ancient Roman encampment. The valleys of Berneval and Penly, the third and fourth eastward of Dieppe, are separated by perpendicular high land, a third of a mile in length, and communicate with the beach by ravines hollowed out bjT the floods caused by heavy rains. Criel valley, at the foot of Mont Joli-Bois, is half a mile wide at its entrance and is watered by the little river Yeres, which forces a passage for itself through the beach. When off the entrance of the valley, with it bearing S. by W. or S.S.W., the little town and spire of Criel will be seen up the valley about a mile from the shore. The valley of Mesnil is 2 miles westward of Treport, and is the last valley before reaching that place ; it descends almost to the level of the beach. The whole of this coast is bordered by a rocky ledge which dries at low water, and a large quantity of shingle is heaped up at the foot of the cliffs. Throughout the greater part of its extent, the ledge is not more than 2 cables wide, but in three places it projects farther and is dangerous to small vessels hugging the coast with off shore winds. From abreast of Belleville valley to the rocks at the foot of Mers cliff, eastward of Treport, a beach of muddy sand and gravel dries at low water in front of the ledge bordering the shore. Roches du Heaume. — The westernmost projection of this ledge * See Admiralty chart :— North coast of France, sheet XIII., Dieppe to Boulogne. No. 2,611 ; scale, ?»=0'5 inch.

Chap. X.] DANGERS OFF DIEPPE AND TREPORT. 477 extends half a mile from the shore in front of Berneval and Penly valleys ; the rocks are uneven, and the Roches du Heaume, the highest heads, uncover 5 or 6 feet at its outer edge. Roches du Muron. — The second projection of the ledge fronts the valley of Mesnil ; it extends 4 cables from the shore, and on it are the Roches du Muron, a rocky group which uncovers 8 feet and bears N.W. 3 cables from the guard-house at Mesnil. The Haumes and Granges Rocks, the easternmost projection of the ledge, lie three quarters of a mile westward of the entrance to Treport and 34; cables from the cliffs ; they consist of small ridges of rock rising above the sands. The Haumes, the western ridge, has several heads, of which the highest uncovers 85 feet. The Granges, the eastern ridge, is nearly 4 cables from the West jetty of Treport, and its highest part at the south-eastern point of the ridge uncovers 6 feet ; its northern part, W. by N. £ N. 3 cables from the jetty-head, uncovers only a foot. Between the Granges and the Haumes there is an isolated rock which uncovers 14f feet. Between the meridians of Dieppe and Treport, the bottom is uneven and the depths irregular as far as 4 or 5 miles from the shore. The principal inequalities met with are the heaps of sand and broken shells named the Ridins de Belleville, de Neuvillette, de Treport, and the Franc-Marque bank. Ridins de Belleville, about 3 miles from the shore in a N.N.W. direction from Berneval valley, are narrow ridges running parallel with each other in a N.N.W. and S.S.E. direction, the least water on them being about 25 feet. The tidal streams occasion strong eddies amongst these ridges, and vessels subject themselves to a heavy sea by crossing them in bad weather during a weather tide ; see also remarks on Ridins, pages 456 and 469, 470. Ridins de Neuvillette are small narrow sand-banks, on which there are from 3f to 5 fathoms. They commence about 6 cables from the shore abreast of Neuvillette valley and extend nearly 2 miles into the offing. The eddies on them are in general less dangerous than those on the Ridins de Belleville. Ridins de Treport are four narrow ridges running parallel with each other in a N.N.W. and S.S.E. direction, at from 2\ to 34^ miles from the coast, and 1\ miles in extent from East to West. The westernmost ridge, N.W. 3| miles from the entrance of Treport, has only 22 feet water ; the others have from 23 to 25 feet on their highest parts.

[Chap. X. 478 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. Bane Franc-Marque, from its south-western extreme, N. | E. If miles from the entrance of Treport, is 14, miles long in a N.E. \ E. and S.W. \ W. direction, and 7 cables wide, with depths of from 13 to 17 feet. It appears to be the outer part of the bank, equally shoal, which extends from the shore, and, trending W.S.W., joins it with a depth of 19 feet. Anchorage.— The holding ground is in general good along the coast between Dieppe and Treport, and vessels may anchor with off shore winds during an adverse tide, but in such a position that they can gain an offing should the wind change and blow on the land. From Mont Joli-Bois to Treport there are many patches where the bottom consists of a black substance which appears to be peat, and here the anchors penetrate so deeply that they are difficult to weigh. There is anchorage to await tide, with off-shore winds and fine weather, 2 miles westward of Treport and 14, miles from the shore abreast of Mesnil valley, in 7 fathoms, sand and broken shells. The mariners of Treport call this the Petite rade ; the Grande rade is half a mile farther out and has excellent holding ground with muddy bottom. At either anchorage a vessel should weigh and quit the coast at the first appearance of bad weather. A bottom, on which the soundings are less than 5 fathoms, extends a mile from the shore in front of Criel valley, and again at Treport, from whence its outer edge runs parallel with the coast as far as the meridian of Mers and then turns back westward round the Franc-Marque bank, leaving a small deep with excellent holding ground in 44^ fathoms water, between that bank and the shore. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on the edge of the cliff nearly half a mile westward of Treport, r TREPORT is a commercial and fishing port with a population of about 4000, situated at the entrance of Bresle valley, the easternmost but one of all those valleys which break the uniform outline of the cliffs between cape d'Antifer and the river Somme. The entrance to the valley is half a mile wide, between abrupt hills rising 295 feet above the sea, and at the foot of the cliff in the southern part of the valley stands the town of Treport, its houses overlooked by a terrace and a large church built half way up the hill. The village of Mers stands on the slope of the hills on the northern side of the valley ; and, a little eastward of it, on a plain surrounded by hills covered with wood, is the Chateau d'Eu and the town of that name.

Chap, x.] TREPORT. 479 The railway station is on the northern side of the port close to the sea ; by it, Treport is connected with the northern net-work of railways by a branch line to Longpre-les-corps-Saints. The opening of this line gave a great impulse to trade, and projects for the improve ment of the port, including the lengthening of the jetties and deepen ing of the channels, were at once taken in hand and have been in great measure carried out. The principal imports are coal and timber ; the exports, the products from the Bresle valley and goods from mid-France, and even from Switzerland ; this trade is main tained chiefly by a service of small steamers going or returning twice a week between here and London. Exclusive of a large fishing trade, about 250 vessels of 45,000 tons enter the port annually, one third being steamers. The port consists of the entrance channel between two wooden jetties, a tidal harbour, a wet dock, and an immense reservoir of scouring water immediately behind the tidal harbour with a surface of 200,000 square yards, communicating with the river Bresle by means of the Penthievre canal. The entrance channel is obstructed by a high bank fronting the West pier, and by a bar abreast of it rising 3 or 4 feet above the general level of the bottom of the channel ; in fine weather, therefore, the harbour admits vessels of about 16 feet draught at high water, springs, and of 9 or 10 feet draught at neaps ; and, being at the head of the elbow formed in the coast between capes d'Antifer and Grisnez, it offers a useful refuge to small craft driven in-shore by stress of weather between Dieppe and the mouth of the river Somme. Bar. — The beach, which uncovers 2 cables outside the West jetty head, is bounded westward by the Haumes and Granges rocks already described, and eastward, by the rocks which dry at the foot of the high cliffs at Mers point, It is a mixture of sand, gravel, and shingle cemented together by chalky mud, and forms a hard ground on which a high sea runs with an on-shore wind. With hard north westerly winds, the shingle drifting from the westward accumulates before and in the entrance and forms a high bank which joins the West jetty-head, extending from thence in a N.N.E. and N.E. direction. In 1878 this bank uncovered 19 feet, and in 1882 it almost closed the port and necessitated the cutting of a channel right through it. Since this was done, the lengthening of both jetties has been accomplished and the channel extended about 120 yards sea ward. It is impossible to speak with confidence of the permanent effect of these works until farther experience has been obtained.

480 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. The Entrance Channel is about 2 cables long in a S. by E. \ E. direction from the West jetty-head ; its eastern side is formed by the East jetty abutting against the western extreme of the natural beach which protects Bresle valley from the sea and shelters the harbour from the northward ; this jetty has been lengthened about 35 yards since the year 1886. Its western side is bounded by the wall which supports the terrace joining the quays of the harbour, and by open pilework, the top of which serves as a road for the tracking crew and forms a communication between the terrace and the West jetty-head. The West jetty is now (1888) more than 200 yards long and joins the terrace near the commencement of the open pilework. The deepest side of the channel is near the East jetty. The Tidal Harbour is 14^ cables long and a cable wide. The freestone bottom is visible almost throughout its whole extent, but at the foot of the quays it is covered with mud and shingle sufficiently soft to ground on. The best berths are in the northern angle of the harbour close to the railway, where the little London steamers lie and unload. In all other parts, with on-shore winds, there is much surf, and vessels strike heavily before they ground. The wet dock or basin is 1,476 feet long East and West, by 115 feet wide ; it is formed at the mouth of the river Bresle, that river being deepened and embanked as a canal from the basin at Treport to Eu, having 13 feet water, and terminating in a small wet dock in the north-western part of that town. The lock entrance at Treport is 254; feet wide at the bottom, has 13 feet over the sill at high water, springs, and is 147^ feet long, communicating with the harbour by means of double floodgates ; it retains at all times a depth of 13 feet to enable vessels that can enter it to remain afloat, the surplus waters of the Bresle flowing over a weir into the tidal harbour. The improvements now (1888) in progress at Treport have for their object the general deepening of the entrance channel and tidal harbour, in order to admit vessels of 164^ feet at all tides. Pilots.— Two pilots and two assistant pilots are stationed at Treport, they also conduct vessels by the canal to Eu. Their services can always be obtained in moderate weather, and, considering the shifting nature of the shingle banks at the entrance and the alterations in progress at the port, no stranger should attempt this harbour without a pilot. LIGHTS.— A red tower stands at the new West jetty-head at Treport, 370 feet outside the position of the old lighthouse ; from

Chap, x.] TREPORT. — DIRECTIONS 481 it, a fixed ivhite tidal light is shown so long as there are 64^ feet water in the shoalest part of the bar and entrance channel. The light is dioptric, of the fifth order, 44 feet above high water, and visible in clear weather at 9 miles. An additional red light is shown if from any cause the entrance is impracticable. A. fixed red light, visible 5 miles, is shown from an iron pole at 23 feet above the sea and 21 feet from the outer end of the East jetty. Fog Signal. — In foggy weather a bell is sounded from the West jetty, see note, page 10. It gives 14 strokes every 12 seconds ; a double stroke in the intervals signifies that there are at least 64 feet water in the channel. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Treport at llh. 9m., springs rise 27 feet, neaps 21 feet. Slack water lasts 10 or 15 minutes at springs, but with north-easterly winds its duration is half an hour. Tidal Signals. — The usual tide signals, see page 8, are made from a mast on the West jetty whilst there are 64 feet and upwards in the shallowest part of the bar and entrance. A red flag at the same mast indicates that the entrance is im practicable. A white flag with blue border hoisted at the mast at the lock entrance indicates that the basin is open. A blue flag at the mast on the East pier and at the sluice gates of the Bassin de Chasses indicates that they are or are about to be opened. The signal-staff on the East jetty works on a pivot and has two black vanes. When the pilots are unable to board vessels in the offing, they incline it to the right or left, according as the vessel should keep to starboard or to port. When the movable part is kept horizontal, the entrance is inaccessible. Directions. — If a vessel's draught admits of her entering Treport, she has nothing to fear in ordinary weather from the banks and Ridins in its vacinity, but for the reasons already given they should be avoided when there is much wind. In running for the harbour from the west ward or northward, with westerly winds, much before high water, the land should be made about Criel valley, under Mont Joli-Bois, so that a position may be retained to windward of the harbour until there is sufficient depth to enter. At night, the lights of Ailly and Cayeux are excellent guides for Treport. A. '2771. Wt. 7242. 2H

[Chap. X. 482 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. With a strong S.W. wind, to avoid passing too close to the Haumes and Granges rocks on which the sea breaks even at high water, the East pier-head should be brought a little open of the West pier-head before hauling in for the latter. Vessels of the deepest draught the port admits should enter between half an hour before and half an hour after high water, springs ; and, as the flood or north-eastern stream runs across the entrance at the rate of from 14^ to 2 knots at 3 or 4 cables outside the jetties, and continues to be felt with less velocity until lj hours after high water, they must avoid being drifted to leeward of the entrance, which, however, is rarely missed in moderate weather. In running for the harbour with a strong wind from the offing, when the pilots cannot go out to meet vessels and the sea is high on the beach and bar, the anchors should be clear for letting go, hawsers coiled on deck, an anchor ready to moor by the stern, and sufficient sail carried to perform any necessary manœuvre. These arrange ments being completed, and no signal being made that the bar is not practicable, steer to pass close to the West jetty-head and watch for indications of alterations in the course being made at the flagstaff on the East jetty, or, as it is approached, by the pilots on the West jetty, who indicate by signs the courses to be steered in entering the channel. With a strong westerly wind, should a vessel be driven to leeward of the entrance and be unable to regain an offing, she should anchor and wait until the ebb stream commences, if the state of the weather permits, and then weigh and gain an offing ; but, if the sea is too high near the shore, where indeed the holding is not good, she should anchor in the small deep under the lee of the Franc-Marque bank, see page 478, where she will be in some degree sheltered, and with two anchors down and a long scope of cable out she might ride out the flood and gain an offing on the ebb. If the wind is too far north ward to reach this deep or to claw off the coast, the only resource is to run stem on the shingle beach with all sail set, as near as possible to the East jetty ; the shingle yields readily under a vessel, and if she takes the ground near the top of high water the crew will be saved. With off-shore winds, the harbour should be entered before high water. With a moderate wind and smooth sea, a vessel may easily get close in to the West jetty-head, and a crew is always at hand on one or the other jetty, according to the direction of the wind, to track in. With strong off-shore winds, violent squalls come down from the cliffs and out of the valleys, and it often happens that when standing

(Jhap. x.] DIRECTIONS FOR TREPORT. — CAYEUX. 483 for the jetty on the starboard tack, a vessel is taken aback in the midst of the rollers on the bar. When leaving the harbour, bound northward, in order to avoid the banks which uncover at the mouth of the Somme river and which ex tend as far out as the bearing N.E. \ N. from the entrance to Treport, do not go eastward of the line of the eastern extreme of the wood surrounding Grange farm, above Treport, a quarter of a point open westward of the summit of the cliff at Mers point bearing about S.W. by S. ; bearing in mind that the flood stream runs eastward for at least 1\ hours after high water in the harbour and for still longer in proportion as the distance from the shore is increased. THE COAST.— The white cliffs bordering the coast from cape de la Heve terminate at the eastern part of the town of Ault, which lies E. by N. \ N. about 4 miles from Treport and occupies the entrance and the north-eastern slope of a deep narrow valley at the head of the bight between capes d'Antifer and Grisnez. Nine valleys break the uniformity of the coast between Treport and Ault, and the shore is bordered by a rocky shelf which in some places uncovers a quarter of a mile from the cliffs at low water, the sea leaving a narrow space of hard sand in front of the shelf. The hills trend away from the shore in an E. by N. direction from Ault to the left bank of the river Somme and the coast becomes low, the hills joining by easy slopes the alluvial plain which lies between them and the sea. This plain is low, marshy, and level, and is defended from the sea by a natural high shingle beach. Behind the beach, which is 2 cables -wide, are meadows and cultivated lands, and in front it slopes down to hard sands which uncover half a mile out. The coast between Treport and Cayeux is inaccessible with on shore winds, and a heavy sea runs in upon it during westerly gales. The beach between Ault and the first guard-house northward of it is exposed to all the violence of winds between W.S.W. and N.W., and the high sea occasioned by these winds drives the shingle collected at the foot of the cliffs between Treport and Ault rapidly towards and beyond the guard-house. After westerly gales, it frequently happens that little or no shingle remains on this part of the beach, and but for a small artificial dyke constructed here, the sea would undoubtedly make an inroad on the plain. Cayeux. — The low coast which commences at Ault trends nearly in a straight line 5 miles north-eastward to the town of Cayeux which is a mile in extent and stands on the shore in the midst of sand hills. The town is partly inhabited by fishermen, who, as the coast 2H2
