X. affords no shelter, haul their boats up above high-water mark in summer, and, in winter, place them in the little harbour of Hourdel within the mouth of the Somme. The only remarkable objects on this part of the coast are the houses of Cayeux, its church, particularly the bell tower, and five windmills in and around the town. In westerly gales, the sea heaps up, in front of the northern part of the town, a great quantity of sand, which is carried away by high winds into the interior. Within a mile southward of Cayeux church is a sheet of water named the Hable d'Ault, where the greater part of the fresh water of the plain is collected. Until the year 1767 this Hable (a corruption of the word havre or haven) communicated with the sea by a channel into which the fishing-boats of Ault and Cayeux, as well as small coasters, could run for shelter, but successive invasions of shingle filled it up. Vessels of deep draught should not approach the coast between Mont Joli-Bois and Cayeux, nor should small vessels unless bound to Treport or the river Somme. The depth is only 5 fathoms at 3 miles from the shore between Treport and Cayeux ; outside this, the soundings generally increase slowly to 8 and 9 fathoms at 6 or 7 miles in the offing, but, as before explained, vessels must be on their guard against small banks or Ridins with less than 5 fathoms on them. The sand-banks which uncover at the mouth of the Somme extend south-westward beyond Cayeux ; with Cayeux church bearing S.E. by E., they dry out nearly 14^ miles from the shore at spring tides. LIGHTS. — A round white tower, which at a distance resembles a Doric column, stands near the shore one mile north-eastwrard of Cayeux ; it exhibits, at 92 feet above high water, a fixed white light, varied every four minutes by a bright flash which is preceded and followed by a short eclipse. The light is dioptric, of the third order, and visible in clear weather at 15 miles ; but, the local fog rising from the low damp ground covered with wood in the rear of the lighthouse sometimes obscures it. Tide Light.— A fixed white tidal light, visible 6 miles, is shewn from a mast 3,835 yards S.W. by W. southerly from Cayeux light, as a guide to the South channel into the Somme. It is lighted at 34 hours flood, and extinguished at 14 hours ebb.

Chap. X.] 485 CAYEUX. — ESTUARY OF THE SOMME. Fog Bell. — A bell is sounded every three seconds at the tide light station during the continuance of fog, independently of the state of the tide. (See note, page 10.) Tide Signals. — Day tide signals, see page 8, are made at the port of Hourdel, at Cayeux lighthouse flagstaff, and at the tidal light south-westward of Cayeux. At Hourdel, commencing at a depth of 9| feet, every rise of 1 foot 8 inches is signalled, and repeated at Cayeux lighthouse ; but, at the tidal light station, only the rising or falling of the tide is signalled by the hoisting of a flag from 3^ hours before high water at the entrance of the South pass, to 1£ hours after high water. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station about 100 yards south-westward of Cayeux lighthouse. Life Boat. — A life-boat is stationed at Cayeux. The ESTUARY Of the SOMME— This estuary lies between the town of Cayeux and St. Quentin point, which bear N.E. by N. and S.W. by S. from each other, distant 6£ miles. It is bounded on the South by the plain of which Cayeux occupies the north-western angle, and, on the North and North-east, by the low lands of Marquen terre and the Favieres marshes. The little harbours of Hourdel, St. Valery-sur-Somme, and Crotoy, are within the estuary ; the two first on the southern, the last on the northern bank. Vessels of from 15 to 18 feet draught can get up to Hourdel harbour at springs, and of 8 feet draught at neaps. The Crotoy channel, when not obstructed by sand-banks, as it sometimes is, admits vessels of 12 or 13 feet draught at ordinary springs. The channel leading up to St. Valery has been so improved that vessels drawing 13 or 14 feet can easily get up to that town, which is the outport to Abbeville, with which it communicates by a canal 74. miles long. Left Bank of the Somme. — From Cayeux, the left bank of the river takes a north-easterly direction for 34 miles to Hourdel point and is 6kirted by an immense quantity of shingle of an average breadth of 3 cables, which, as far as 2 miles from Cayeux, is covered by sand-hills of moderate height ; but, from Cayeux lighthouse to Hourdel point, the shingle is uncovered and lies in a series of undula tions, parallel with each other, and with the shore. Hourdel point in many respects resembles Hoc point in the Seine ; both increase by successive deposits of shingle, and the eddy on the flood has given them nearly the same shape.

[Chap. X. 486 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. Between Hourdel point and St. Valery-sur-Somme, the shore is low and, until lately, formed a bay 2£ miles long and half a mile deep, the land being defended from the incursion of the sea by an embank ment, in front of which was some marshy land and a wide beach, parts of which hardly covered at high water, springs ; the whole of this bay has now either nearly filled up or been reclaimed. The town of St. Valery with its suburb La Ferte* occupies a space of 14^ miles along the shore, and is built on the northern slope of a group of hills forming the northern point of the high land between the rivers Somme and Bresle ; the north-western hill, the most conspicuous from the offing, has on its summit a clump of tall trees and a windmill. The harbour of St. Valery is at the eastern part of the town, and for all practical purposes the navigation of the Somme ends here ; for, since the waters of this river and of the streams flowing into it above Abbeville have been diverted into and run out by the canal, the sand which the flood stream drives into the river has in a great measure filled up its former bed, so that even lighters drawing about 3 feet water can hardly get up to the village of Grand Port, on the right bank, 5 miles above St. Valery. Right Bank of the Somme. — The northern shore of this estuary trends in a N.N.W. and S.S.E. direction ; the most con spicuous object on it is the little town of Crotoy, built on a pro jecting point 24. miles E. by S.f S. from Hourdel point, and 1% miles N.N.E. from St. Valery ; the ruins of its fortifications, four windmills showing above the ruins, the church tower, and the roofs of some of the houses, serve to mark its position from a distance. The coast for 4 miles eastward of Crotoy is low, and an embank ment follows all its sinuosities, protecting the adjacent land from the sea. The southern part of St. Quentin point, as seen from Crotoy, is about 4 miles N.N.W. 4 W. from that town, and, in the intervening space, the coast recedes a mile and forms a bay, at the head of which the little river Maie, which receives a large portion of the waters of the Marquenterre, loses itself running over the beach. The only objects that attract attention on this low coast are the windmill at St. Pierre, three quarters of a mile northward of Crotoy, and St. Firmin church tower, N.N.E. 3 miles from Crotoy. St. Quentin Point is rounded and is a slight projection a mile and a half northward of the point visible from Crotoy, and from which the coast undergoes a sudden change in direction. The

Chap, x.] RIVER SOMME. — BANKS. — CHANNELS. 487 only object which serves to mark St. Quentin point from seawTard, is a guard-house built among the sand-hills on the point, These hills are higher than those on the coast to the S.S.E. and may be seen in clear weather 8 or 10 miles distant. Banks in the mouth of the Somme. — The whole space included between the shores of the estuary just described, is nearly filled with an immense mass of sand which uncovers and which extends 14^ miles seaward of a line drawn from Cayeux to St. Quentin point. The surface of this sand is subject to great changes from the effect of wind and tide, it being every day furrowed afresh by the tidal streams and heaped into banks of which the shape and height are extremely variable. From the parallel of Cayeux to that of St. Quentin point, the banks at the entrance taken as a whole slope gradually seaward but are steep towards the land ; their high parts extend from N.W. of Cayeux lighthouse to North of Hourdel point and are not covered at the lowest neaps ; the highest part of all in the northern part of the bay, called l'llet by the fishermen, is nearly 30 feet above low-water mark and only covers at the highest spring tides. Entrance Channels. — None but fishing-boats or small coasters, piloted by local seamen, can enter the Somme by the narrow winding channel under St. Quentin point. The two principal entrances are through the southern part of the banks ; the entrance to the South pass being abreast of Cayeux, and that of the North-west pass, north-westward of the lighthouse. These passes are subject to such incessant changes from the shifting of the sands that a detailed description of them is impossible. They always, however, show a disposition to return to or to regain very nearly the positions assigned them on the Admiralty Chart. They are separated from each other by a bank, of which some parts uncover 11 or 12 feet at the lowest tides. The two channels meet and form one channel, sometimes above and sometimes below Hourdel, but again separate ; one portion taking the direction of Crotoy, the other of St. Valery. Though their outer parts are nearly dry at low water, they do not dry throughout, but, as far as the meridian of St. Quentin point, have a succession of depressions, some with as much as 18 feet water, these depressions being separated from each other by shallow bars. Eastward of the meridian named, the bottoms of the channels are everywhere above the level of low water, but they do not dryT entirely, though in no part is there sufficient water for even the smallest coasters to lie

Cape d5antiFer to cape grisnez. [Chap. X. 488 afloat. In 1878, the average height of the bottoms of the channels above low water, springs, at Hourdel, Crotoy, and St. Valery, was 15 feet. When, as is usual, the two narrow channels just described unite and form one channel between Cayeux lighthouse and Hourdel point, it is from thence called the Somme channel, is generally about 2 cables wide, and follows the direction of the shore ; but when the junction takes place eastward of Hourdel point, as it did in 1878, the South Pass is the only one by which that port can be directly reached. Buoys. — The following buoys mark the approaches to the Somme : — An automatic whistle buoy is moored in about 44; fathoms, with Cayeux lighthouse bearing E. \ N. 4^ miles. Two red bell buoys lie at the edge of the sands in from 16 to 20 feet water ; they are about 34 miles apart, and nearly on the line given at page 483 for clearing the sands, viz., the eastern extreme of Grange farm wood a quarter of a point open of the summit of Mers point cliff S.W. by S. The northern buoy is northward of the N.W. pass ; the southern buoy is northward of the South pass, 2 miles N.W. by W. \ W. from Cayeux church tower and on the same bearing from Cayeux lighthouse as the whistle buoy. Two buoys with masts mark the entrance on either side to each Pass, and, from thence inwards, red and black buoys according to the French system (see page 9) mark the channels. Above Hourdel, the channels for Crotoy and St. Valery, respectively, are marked on the starboard hand by perches with rectangular vanes, and on the port hand by perches with skeleton balls. The buoys and perches marking the channels are liable to be shifted and the channels themselves to change, but the greatest care is taken to keep them in position. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Cayeux, at llh. 5m. ; springs rise 274^ feet, neaps 21 feet. At Hourdel, where the bottom is 11 feet above the low water level, ordinary springs rise from 20 to 21 feet, and neaps about 10 feet. At St. Valery, it is high water, full and change, at llh. 46m., and the tide rises at springs 17 or 18 feet above the bottom of the harbour, and at neaps about 8 feet. At Crotoy, the tide rises about 15 feet in the harbour at springs, and only 4 feet at neaps, with about a foot more in the entrance. In all these harbours, strong westerly winds raise the tides a foot or two and easterly winds have a contrary effect.

Chap. X.] RIVER SOMME.— BUOYS. — TIDES.— DIRECTIONS. 489 Tidal Streams. — At 3 hours flood, the stream in the Somme channel runs 6 or 7 knots, at springs ; but when the channel widens the stream in some degree loses strength. The greater part of the banks of shifting sand, near Hourdel point, do not cover until 2\ hours flood. From this cause, and until this time, the rapid stream through the Somme channel continues to run north-eastward between these bankB and the eastern edge of the high bank barring the mouth of the Somme, and does not run eastward until joined by the stream which enters from the North-west, and by that flowing in along the edge of the beach on the northern shore of the estuary, by which time the banks are generally covered. The stream then follows the course of this northern beach until abreast of Crotoy, when the banks turn it south-eastward towards St. Valery. When the banks around Hourdel point are covered, the flood finds a passage along the southern shore of the estuary and its speed slackens considerably. The channel formed by the tide along this shore is sinuous, uneven, extremely variable, and, as a rule, not so deep as that leading to Crotoy, from which it is separated by shifting sands. Both these channels, as before stated, are well marked by perches and buoys, but neither should ever be attempted without a pilot. Pilots. — Pilotage is obligatory for vessels over 10 tons. Pilots are stationed at Cayeux, Crotoy, and St. Valery, and in moderate weather they cruise at sea. Those of Cayeux do not take vessels beyond Hourdel unless no pilot for St. Valery or Crotoy presents himself. Those of Crotoy only are allowed to take vessels to any port in the Somme. Two Steam-tugS are stationed in the Somme, and when not engaged are usually on the look-out for vessels outside the entrance channels. Directions. — No vessels off the mouth of the Somme should stand into less than 64^ fathoms, unless bound into the river : in which case, with westerly winds, and before there is sufficient water to pass through either of the outer channels, they should maintain a position on the meridian of Mers cliff, and south-westward of Cayeux church tower ; or, if the weather permits, they may anchor in about 1\ fathoms, good holding ground, on the meridian of the cliff and W. by N. of Cayeux ; with off-shore winds, they may anchor a little westward of the large bell buoys moored outside the banks.

CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. 490 and no vessel should attempt to enter wdthout a pilot. The tide signals, see pages 484-5, make known when the narrows are practicable, and then, With a fair wind, a vessel may enter under sail ; or, with a foul wind, secure the aid of a steam-tug. It sometimes happens that the state of the sea does not admit of pilots going out to vessels requiring them, or to the assistance of those embayed off the mouth of the Somme and obliged to run in, which is always practicable towards high water, springs, when the signals can be seen and the position of the buoys at the entrance of the channels has been ascertained. To supply as far as possible the want of a pilot on board, a tall flagstaff, with the upper part working on a pivot, has been erected half a mile north-eastward of Cayeux lighthouse ; on this, a flag is hoisted and is inclined to the right or left as may be necessary to direct a vessel in the channels ; if she has entered and is steering a proper course, the flagstaff is kept in a vertical position, if not, it is drooped on the side towards which she should steer. These signals are made to vessels of all sizes when they have demanded a pilot. Vessels having entered, but finding themselves unable to reach either of the ports, should run aground under cover of one of the points or under the lee of a bank where they will be sheltered from the stream, for those grounding on the soft shifting sands in the strength of the stream are liable to be undermined by it and capsize. At night, pilots will not risk bringing vessels in, except it be moonlight or very clear and fine. HOURDEL.— When the Hable d'Ault, see page 484, was closed the bight within Hourdel point served as a refuge for the Cayeux fishing boats, but the constant increase of the sands threatening to fill it up, an artificial harbour was made to shelter coasting craft. It consists of a small tidal basin, from 270 to 325 yards long and 76 yards wide, and a Reservoir or Bassin de Chasses for clearing the entrance by sluicing. It will contain about 30 vessels well secured, but, except for the Cayeux fishery, its trade is entirely unimportant. As the direction of the entrance is athwart the tidal streams, which are very strong except just at high water, it is imprudent to attempt to enter without a pilot, who, if unable to board a vessel in the offing, can at all times do so after she has passed through the outer channels LIGHT.— A fixed white tidal light, of the fifth order, visible 6 miles, is shown from a mast on Hourdel point. It is lighted as soon as there are eighteen inches water in the harbour entrance and extinguished 3 hours after high water.

Chap. x.J HOURDEL. — ST. VALERY-SUR-SOMME. 491 Fog signal. — A bell is sounded every three seconds in foggy weather ; it commences to sound one hour before the flood, and con tinues to sound until three hours after high water (See note, page 10.) ST. VALERY-SUR-SOMME is 34, miles above Hourdel point, from which its entrance bears S.E. \ S. Its tidal harbour is, properly speaking, the continuation of the Somme canal outside the lock. An earthern embankment, 1,100 yards long, which begins at the lock and terminates in an open stockade 70 yards long, shelters it from North to East, and a low dyke parallel with the shore preserves the channel between it and the shore as far as the lighthouse. On the West and South, it is bounded by the shore of La Ferte suburb, a part of which, 438 yrards long, has been converted into a quay, and along the shore as far as the lighthouse there is a towing path which was continued as a low dyke across the sands as far as Hourdel harbour, but has sunk beneath them. The population of St. Valery is about 4,000. It is the only commercial port of the Somme and by means of the Somme canal is connected with Abbeville and with the general canal system of France, and, by the branch railway to Noyelles, with the railway system. About 250 vessels, of an aggre gate of 50,000 tons, enter the port annually. The exports are chalk, vegetables, sand, and ballast ; and the imports, wood, coal, pig iron, &c. The harbour is quite sheltered from wind and sea, and can berth from 30 to 35 vessels alongside the quays ; they ground on a bottom of chalky mud mixed with sand and some shingle. A regular depth is maintained in the harbour by daily flushings from the canal. LIGHTS.— A fixed red light of the fifth order, 25 feet high, and visible 4 miles, is exhibited from an iron pole at the end of the towing path in front of St. Harold's tower, St. Valery. A. fixed green light, 25 feet above high water, and visible 4 miles, is exhibited from an iron pillar at the mole-head on the port hand in entering the harbour of St. Valery. Tides. — The tide begins to rise in the harbour about 3 hours after the commencement of the flood on Cayeux beach, and it fills in about 2^ hours ; at 4 hours ebb it is quite dry, see also page 488. Canal de la Somme, on the left or southern bank of the river, is 74; miles in length ; it commences at the village of Sur-Somme, 2 miles below Abbeville, and terminates at the head of St. Valery harbour in a lock, 656 feet long and 164 feet wide, in which vessels

492 CAPE d'antifer TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. x. bound to or from Abbeville lie afloat. Horses are always in readiness to track vessels but with a fair wind they sometimes sail. The mean depth of water maintained in the canal is 7 ft. 9 in. above the sill of the lock, which is 16 feet above the level of the lowest tides, and 3 ft. 3 in. above the level of the grounding berths at the foot of the quay in the harbour. The water mayr be lowered to 64^ feet over the sill and raised to 18 feet ; a certain portion is passed through the flushing sluices daily. The maximum draught of vessels admitted into the canal is 11 feet. PORT d' ABBEVILLE, in the western part of the town of Abbeville, extends 600 yards along the right bank of the Somme, from the ramparts to the bridge which unites the Hocquet and the Marcadet quarters of the town. A quay extends the whole length of the port, and the railway is alongside the quay ; the river is sufficiently deep along the quay to admit of vessels drawing 11 feet remaining afloat. About 60 small vessels arrive at Abbeville by the canal yearly, their total tonnage being about 6,000 tons. The towm contains about 18,000 inhabitants, and though walled and formerly a place of some strength, is no longer classed as a fortress. Being on the railway line between Amiens and Boulogne it is in direct com munication with Paris. CROTOY. — The port consists of a natural creek sheltered from the sea by the little promontory on which the town of Crotoy stands. The harbour works comprise wooden pile work on the side of the town forming the quayT, and, on the other side, a reservoir or Bassin de Chasses for flushing and keeping open the channel ; at the head of the harbour, the Canal de Maie conducts the waters from the pond at Rue and the Favieres marshes into the Somme, and contributes to keep the entrance open. Crotoy occupies an advantageous position as relates to the circuitous course the flood stream takes in the mouth of the Somme during the time it has most strength ; it is equally accessible with the prevailing winds by either Pass, and the channel up to the entrance of Crotoy is almost always 3 feet deeper than either to Hourdel or St. Valery ; nevertheless, the construction of the Canal de la Somme, on the opposite shore, has entirely destroyed its trade, which, beyond the few fishing boats belonging to the harbour, is now represented by about a dozen vessels calling annually. LIGHT.— A fixed white tidal light, of the fifth order, visible 6 miles, is shown at 26 feet above high water from a post on the

Chap, x.] 493 ABBEVILLE. — CROTOY. — SOMME BANKS. promontory of Crotoy. It is lighted on a rising tide as soon as there are 3 feet water at the entrance, and extinguished 2 hours after high water, see " Tides," page 488. BANCS de la SOMME.— The off-lying banks, generally called the Somme banks, are the Bassurelle de la Somme, the Quemer, the Battur, and the south-western part of the Bassure de Baas. Those dangerous banks lying in Dover strait, the Varne, Ridge or Colbart. Bassurelle, Ridins, and Vergoyer, are fully described in Channel Pilot, Part I. There is always sufficient water on the Somme banks to admit of vessels crossing them when bound for the mouth of the Somme. From the south-western end of the Bassure de Baas the land can be seen only in fine weather ; the eddies on the banks occasion a heavy sea when it blows hard, but the soundings on them differ sufficiently from those in the channels between to enable the mariner to know his position with reference to the banks and the land. The Quemer and the Bassurelle de la Somme appear to be extensions of that immense mass of sand and broken shells which forms the sub marine slope along the shore from St. Valery-en-Caux to the mouth of the river Canche. The Bassurelle de la Somme and the Quemer spread south-westward across the mouth of the Somme ; the Quemer ends about 10^ miles N.W. by W. £ W. and the Bassurelle de la Somme 10 miles W. by N. 4, N. from Cayeux lighthouse ; the channel separating them has no opening north-eastward, but terminates in the depth of 7 fathoms about 5 miles W.N.W. of St. Quentin point. Neither of these banks are dangerous, but they are joined to the shore by a shoal bottom on which the depth is less than 5 fathoms, and which extends nearly 5 miles into the offing. This shoal bottom terminates in two points projecting in the direction of each of the banks, the first b"\ miles W. f S. from St. Quentin point, the other 74; miles W. by S. 4 S. from Routhiauville point ; the latter is the most dangerous, as there are only 18 feet water 5 miles from the point on the same bearing. The Battur is in the channel separating the Quemer from the Bassure de Baas, and carries a depth of from 6 to 8 fathoms. It is not dangerous to vessels of any draught, but the eddies over it cause a heavy sea when it blows hard. From its south-western extreme, Cayeux lighthouse bears about S.E. f S. 13 miles; and, from its

494 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ [Chap. X. north-eastern end, the lighthouse on Haut-Banc point S.E. by E. 6^ miles. The Bassure de Baas is a narrow bank of sand and shells, about 35 miles long from its northern end, which is 3i miles south-westward of cape Grisnez and H miles from the shore abreast of Audrecelles ; it follows nearly the direction of the coast as far as the mouth of the river Canche and then curves gradually westward, terminating about 17 miles from the shore a little southward of the parallel of the mouth of the river Authie, and 19 miles N.W. northerly from Cayreux lighthouse. From its northern end, as far as 5 miles southward of the Canche, it is dangerous to vessels of deep draught and, at low water, its highest parts may be touched by vessels of light draught when there is any sea on . The shoalest and most dangerous spot is a small flat, half a mile long N.N.E. and S.S.W., with only 12 feet on its southern part and 16 or 17 feet on its northern end, which lies nearly7 in the direction of the column of the Grande Armee, sometimes known as Buona parte's column, three quarters of a mile northward of Boulogne, on with Heurt fort bearing E.N.E. ; and, from it, that fort bears N.E. by E. | E. ; cape Alprech lighthouse E. \ N. ; Gravois windmill E. by S. \ S. ; and, the summit of Mont St. Frieux S. by E. f E. ; the sea breaks with great violence on the whole of the flat during strong westerly winds. For 14 miles southward of this flat, as far as W. 4 S. 8 miles from Touquet point, the shoalest parts of the Bassure de Baas form a succession of long narrow flats where the depths vary from 18 to 26 feet, and where the sea breaks heavily when it blows hard from the westward. There are no dangers in the channel between the bank and the shore, but, with a strong breeze on a weather tide, a high sea runs on some shoal spots of from 54, to 8 fathoms lying nearly in the middle of that channel. During bad weather, with winds between West and N.N.W., the sea is less disturbed in this channel than out side the Bassure de Baas, especially from abreast of the mouth of the Canche northward to cape Alprech. Directions. — As the eastern side of the Bassure de Baas is steep to, the lead is an uncertain guide for avoiding the 12-feet patch on its northern part when running through the channel between the bank and the shore ; but, by steering with Creche point opening and shutting in with Heurt fort, a vessel keeps in mid-channel when between the parallels of Gravois windmill and the guard-house on the hills a quarter of a mile northward of Brone rivulet.

X.] SOMME BANKS. — ESTUARY OF THE AUTHIE. 495 Great attention should be paid to the lead when approaching the channel between the Bassure de Baas and the Vergoyer from the northward, for the northern part of the latter presents a steep pro jecting point approaching the French coast at the outer edge of the 20-fathoms line of soundings. A vessel running from the southward through this channel, which is 5 miles wide and carries a depth of from 14 to 23 fathoms, avoids the Vergoyer by keeping in from 15 to 16 fathoms throughout the whole length of the channel. THE COAST.— From St. Quentin point, the coast, which is low and bordered by ranges of sand-hills, trends NN,E.}E.4| miles to Routhiauville point, at the southern side of the mouth of the river Authie, and the only objects rising above the sand-hills and visible in clear weather are, the tall spire of St. Quentin church and the wind mill at Royons. The intermediate shore is fronted by a strand which dries 1^ miles south- westward from St. Quentin point, and West 14 miles from Routhiauville point ; between these points it dries out generally only half a mile. Caution. — Great caution is necessary to avoid being caught on this part of the coast by strong westerly winds, for they cause a high sea over the shoal bottom extending 5 miles from the shore and increase the speed of the flood, which in calm weather runs 3 knots. The same winds also decrease the rate of the ebb, and no dependence can be placed on the strength of this stream to assist a vessel in clawing off the coast. The ESTUARY Of the AUTHIE is comprised between point Routhiauville and Haut-Banc or Berck point, which bear N. by E. and S. by W. 24^ miles from each other, and extends eastward 2\ miles to its head, where it is about 3 cables wide with the river Authie flowing into it from the southward. The entrance is filled with an enormous accumulation of sand and broken shells which dries at half tide, and, at low water, springs, uncovers 14^ miles westward of the meridian of Haut-Banc point . Routhiauville point is covered with sand-hills, and the only remarkable object near it is a guard house standing amongst the highest hills about 2 cables southward of the point. A sand-bank, barely covered at high water, neaps, joins this point and extends in a circuit of more than a mile between the bearings N.N.W. and N.E. from the guard-house. A similar bank surrounds Haut-Banc point and projects a mile between the bearings W.S.W. and S.S.E. from the point.

496 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. The channel into the Authie is principally kept open by the flood stream which sets in with great rapidity until the banks are covered. The 'entrance is between the banks just described, and the channel varies in position by the shifting of the banks and is sometimes divided into two passes ; it runs in an easterly direction from the outer edge of the sands and terminates in a narrow trench along side a low rough stone dyke, constructed in order to turn the ebb stream away from the northern bank and thus put a stop to the erosion of that bank and of Haut-Banc point. Fishermen haul their boats up here and the channel is marked by little red and black buoys, but the changes are so frequent that it is quite possible the channel may eventually fill up altogether. The bottom of the grounding places and the higher parts of the channel are 15 or 16 feet above the low water level. The banks of the Authie have undergone great changes of late years, the tendency of the estuary being to move bodily northward. Between 1835 and 1878, Routhiauville point advanced about 550 yards northward and Haut-Banc point receded about 450 yards in the same direction. The dyke referred to is of modern construction and, with other works for the protection of the northern shore, seemed, in 1882, to be fairly answering its purpose. Haut-Banc or Berck point may be easily recognised by day by its circular white lighthouse and guard-house standing near it on the sand-hills, which are sufficiently high to be seen in clear weather 7 or 8 miles distant. LIGHT.— Berck lighthouse exhibits, at 115 feet above high water, an occulting ivhite light, the eclipses taking place every five seconds ; the light is visible from a distance of 17 miles ; it is obscured when bearing S. \ W. through an angle of 20', by the clock of the Hospital. The hospital is a very large building, close to the shore, erected by the municipality of Paris for the treatment of invalid children. A Life-Boat is stationed near the lighthouse, and there is also a life-saving mortar apparatus. Directions.— The mouth of the river Authie is dangerous to approach during the flood, especially with westerly winds, on account of the stream which then runs into it with great rapidity and might draw a vessel on the banks where she would become a total wreck, the buoys for the use of the -small fishing vessels of about 5 feet

Chap. X.] ESTUARIES OF THE RIVERS AUTHIE AND CANCHE. 497 draught belonging to Grofniers not being sufficient guides for a stranger to enter the channel. No vessel, indeed, however small her draught, should ever attempt the entrance, unless in charge of one of the fishermen of Berck or of Groffliers, who alone are in a position to know the changes taking place in the channel. The COAST from Haut-Banc point trends N.N.E. \ E. 8 miles to Touquet point at the entrance of the river Canche. The shore is low, sandy, and bordered by a range of sand-hills of moderate height. A sandy strand half a mile wide uncovers at the foot of the sand-hills, and joins the accumulation of sand which obstructs the entrances of the rivers Authie and Canche. The low plain adjoining the shore extends to the foot of the hills 3 or 4 miles inland and is divided in its whole length into two nearly equal parts by a chain of sand-hills, much higher than those near the beach, and which may be seen 8 or 9 miles distant. This chain of hills may be mistaken for those bordering the beach, although they are 14 or 2 miles inland, and it is important to guard against this mistake when turning to windward in-shore in hazy weather. The objects which serve as distinguishing marks on this part of the coast are, the windmills of Verton and St. Jossee, on the hills in the interior ; the chain of sand-hills just described ; the lighthouses on Haut-Banc and Touquet points ; the five guard-houses standing at nearly equal distances on the sand-hills along the coast ; and, the hospital, church tower, and windmills at Berck-sur-mer. This church tower stands on the plain E. by N. 1\ miles from Haut-Banc point, and is an excellent landmark ; at a distance it resembles a large sloop under sail. The inhabitants of Berck, Cuque, and Merlimont, fit out about fifty fishing boats of from 2 to 9 tons burden, which they ground at high water on the beach just northward of Haut-Banc point. The ESTUARY Of the CANCHE, known locally as the bay of Etaples, is 2 miles wide between Touquet and Lornel points, the northern and southern limits of the entrance, and runs 3 miles inland in a S.S.E. direction. Like the estuaries of the Somme and the Authie, it is filled up by a mass of sand and broken shells which is left dry at half ebb and uncovers at low water 14, miles outside the entrance, and, like the Authie estuary, inclines to move bodily northward and also to become narrower, Touquet point having extended northward 330 yards since 1835, and Lomel point having receded about 200 yards in the same period. The entrance points and A. 2771. Wt. 2742. 2 I

[Chap. X. 498 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. shores of the river consist of sand-hills of moderate height, of which the shapes are frequently changed by westerly gales. ETAPLES.— From Touquet point, the southern shore of the estuary trends S.E. by S. as far as abreast of the small port of Etaples, which, though in ancient times a place of considerable importance, has now nothing but its rather extensive fishery, its general trade having been entirely destroyed by the silting up of the bay, which now only admits vessels of 9 feet draught, at springs, as far as Etaples, where the grounding berths are muddy sand, and are on the north western side of the town where there is a wooden quay and piles for mooring vessels. The northern shore is low and winding ; between Etaples, which stands on the northern bank of the river, and Lornel point, its general trend is N.N.W. and the two shores converge towards each other, the river, abreast of the town, being only a quarter of a mile wide. The surf and westerly winds heap up the sand round Touquet point, where it forms a bank barely covered at high water, neaps, and extending in a circuit of nearly a mile between the bearings N.N.W. and N.N.E. from the point. This bank shelters the inner part of the bay, and fishing craft unable to reach Etaples in one tide lie aground in the channel in safety^ under its lee. About this part, and just before reaching the outer end of the dyke presently described, the bottom of the channel rises to 13 feet above the level of low water, and from thence to Etaples it is from that to 16 feet above that level. A similar bank to that round Touquet point lies in front of Lornel point and extends nearly a mile in a W.S.W. direction ; between these banks is the entrance channel into the river. The streams of flood and ebb are both very rapid through the channel so long as the banks are uncovered, but their rate does not exceed 3 knots during the last hour of the flood and the first hour of the ebb. With westerly gales, the sea is high at the entrance, and the waves caused by a strong south-westerly wind cross it obliquely. The Entrance Channel runs between the banks, as described, in an easterly direction towards the Camiers lighthouses on the northern shore of the river ; from thence, it follows the northern shore, at a short distance, up to Etaples. Above and within point Touquet, the channel has in recent years been saved from entire destruction by the building of the submersible dyke of rough chalk stones, before referred to, nearly 2 miles in length up to and abreast of Etaples, where its end is connected with the southern shore, thus forming

Chap, x.] ETAPLES. — TOUQUET POINT LIGHTS. 499 the channel, about 70 yards wide, on its northern side between the town quays and the dyke. On the side of the town a similar dyke is partially constructed with the object of still further restricting and deepening the channel. Half a mile above Etaples the viaduct of the Northern railway crosses the river. By means of this line the town is in direct com munication with Boulogne on the North, and also with Amiens and Paris. Pilots. — Two pilots and an assistant pilot are stationed at Etaples. When they are unable to get out to a vessel, they come as far as the weather permits and signal the direction to be taken by hand. The smallest vessel, without local knowledge, should not think of attempt ing this channel without a pilot. Buoys. — The entrance channel into the Canche is marked by two large buoys, viz. : a black buoy on its northern side and a red bell buoy on its southern side, from thence the channel up to Etaples is well marked by red and black buoys as far as the dyke, which is marked by black poles and white buoys, a large red buoy being moored on the northern side half a mile below Etaples quay. The positions of the buoys are frequently changed to suit the variations in the channel. LIGHTS.— Touquet point.— Two octagonal lighthouses, 273 yards apart, bearing N. by E. \ E. and S. by W. 4 W. from eacn other, stand on Touquet point ; each exhibits a fixed white electric light at 174 feet above high water, and visible in clear weather 20 miles. Camiers. — Two lights are also shown from lighthouses erected on the sand-hills of Camiers. The upper lighthouse is of iron, and painted white ; it exhibits at 121 feet above high water a fixed white light, visible 9 miles in clear weather. The lower light is shown from a white square stone tower which exhibits at 54 feet above high water a fixed red light visible 9 miles. It bears W. £ S. 798 yards from the upper light and is only visible within an arc of 16° on either side of the line of bearing ; it is only lighted when there are less than 6| feet water in the channel . Note. — The lights at Camiers wei*e originally established as lead ing lights for the channel. The constant movement of the channel northward has quite thrown them out of that line, but they are still maintained as they afford useful indications to the fishermen ; on no account, however, should they be taken, either by day or night, as affording a leading mark for the entrance. 212

[Chap. X. 500 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on Touquet Point, 440 yards northward of the Northern lighthouse. Directions. — At night, the heavy sea and sand-banks at the mouth of the river Canche may be avoided by keeping cape Grisnez light well open westward of cape Alprech light. By day, the extreme of cape Grisnez should be kept about half a point open westward of cape Alprech. Though vessels should never attempt to enter the mouth of the Canche without a pilot or some person of local experience, they may be driven to do so by bad weather, or by finding themselves embayed amongst the sand-banks. The pilots reside at Etaples, and as it is impossible for them to board vessels outside when it blows hard from the westward, they then meet them under shelter of the bank joining Touquet point. Vessels without pilots, seeking shelter, should endeavour as soon as possible to get sight of the outer red bell buoy, and it is important not to pass northward of the parallel of Touquet point before it is sighted, for, if set too far northward by the flood stream, which is running at its greatest strength outside the banks at the time of high water at Etaples, it is impossible to regain the entrance. The most favourable time for entering the Canche is about one hour before high water, for the stream then runs into the channel with sufficient strength to assist a vessel in threading her way, and the water still rises enough to float her should she take the ground. Pass between the black and red buoys, leaving the black to port and the red to starboard, as usual. At springs, pilots place vessels drawing 10 or 11 feet water, when not bound to or unable to reach Etaples, in the elbow above Touquet point ; here they lie in safety even during westerly gales, protected by the high bank which joins Touquet point, and which dries from 21 to 23 feet above the level of the lowest tides. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in the mouth of the Canche at 11 h. 20 m. ; the tide rises in the entrance channel, where the bottom is about 3 feet above the low water level, 29 feet at high water, springs, and 23 feet at neaps ; at the outer end of the dyke north-eastward of Touquet point, where the bottom is 13 feet above the level of the lowest tides, 16 feet at ordinary springs, and 10 feet at neaps. At Etaples quay, springs rise 114. feet, and neaps about 6 feet above the surface of the grounding berths which dry 16 or 17 feet above the low water level. The flood stream does not check the

Chap. X.] RIVER CANCHE. — DIRECTIONS. — CAUTION. 501 current of the Canche until about 3 hours after the tide has begun to rise on the outer edge of the sand-banks at the entrance ; it rises in front of Etaples 14^ hours before high water and falls for about 3 hours afterwards. Caution. — The slight elevation of the land, as well as the dangers bordering the shore, render the navigation of the coast for the 25 miles from Cayeux to the mouth of the Canche, extremely dangerous in foggy or snowy weather, or during strong westerly gales ac companied by rain, when the weather is generally dark, the land covered with mist, and the most brilliant lights difficult to distinguish. Moreover, with these gales, a few hours suffice to raise a heavy sea in the eastern part of the Channel, and especially on the edge of the great submarine slope which extends off-shore from St. Valery-en- Caux to the river Canche, and this alone causes a considerable drift ; but, in addition, westerly gales tend to drive the water towards the head of the bight formed between capes d'Antifer and Grisnez, and greatly7 influence the direction of the tidal streams, see page 515. It may be seen, therefore, how important it is that a vessel should not run into the eastern part of the Channel without her position being well ascertained by bearings of cape Barfleur light, or of St. Catherine's light, Isle of Wight, and without using every precaution after these lights are lost sight of. The only safeguard is the frequent use of the lead ; and, if lights cannot be distinguished or the position is from any cause doubtful, vessels should keep in at least 20 fathoms water whatever be the time of tide ; this not only keeps a vessel clear of the dangers near the shore, but also of the off-lying banks between the mouth of the Somme and Dover channel. The COAST from Lornel point trends N. by E. 4. E. 84, miles to cape Alprech, and from thence N. E. f E. 2 miles to Boulogne. The shore is low, bordered by sand-hills of moderate height, and runs in a straight line from the mouth of the Canche to that of the Brone rivulet, which finds its way into the sea 2 miles southward of cape Alprech, and is the northern limit of the low sandy shore forming the coast-line for the whole distance of 34 miles from the town of Ault, near Treport, A mile northward of the rivulet the coast is low with hills sloping down towards it, and, on their sides, several houses of the village of Equihen may be seen ; beyond this, the coast is steep, and is formed of clay and of schistose rocks of a dark grey colour.

X. 502 The high land separating the courses of the rivers Canche and Liane, which latter runs into the sea at Boulogne, extends westward to within 1^ miles of the coast and terminates near the meridian of Etaples in a chain of hills, of which many are sufficiently high to be seen in clear weather 25 miles distant. These hills are excellent landmarks for the pilots on this coast, who call them the terres de Tourmont or Tourmont-land, and on the highest of them are Faux and Houlette windmills, which are visible at a great distance ; the former stands 24; miles north-eastward, and the latter 34; miles N.N.E., of Etaples. At 1£ miles from the coast and 2\ miles northward of Houlette mill, in front of the Tourmont-land, is Mont St. Frieux, one of the most remarkable objects between the river Canche and Boulogne. It consists of four mounds or hillocks, veryT near each other, rising from the same base and occupying a space of 1\ miles North and South ; from its isolated position, as well as from the height of the hillocks, it may be seen in clear weather at the same distance as the Tourmont-land. On the highest of the hills northward of Brone rivulet is the church of St. Etienne-au-Mont and the windmills of Gravois, Alprech, Portel, and Outreau, all of which may be seen a considerable distance at sea. The sandy beach, which extends the whole length of this part of the coast almost to cape Alprech, uncovers at low water half a mile out from the foot of the sand-hills, but northward of Brone rivulet the shore is bordered byr a shelf of irregular rocks which dry a cable outside high- water mark. CAPE ALPRECH is a perpendicular rocky cliff of a brownish red colour, 135 feet above the level of high- water ; the foot of the cliff is skirted by a shelf of rock covered with boulders which dries a cable out at low water. From the cape, the coast turns sharply north-eastward, and is high and steep-to within 4 cables of the jetties of Boulogne.* LIGHTS.— A square lighthouse, 33 feet high, stands on the summit of cape Alprech about 87 yards from the edge of the cliff, near the tower of the old semaphore, and 2\ miles south- west ward from the entrance to Boulogne. It exhibits, at 161 feet above high water, a fixed ivhite light, varied every two minutes by a red flash, which flash is preceded and followed by a short eclipse. It is dioptric, of the fifth order, and visible in clear weather from a distance of 12 miles. * See Admiralty Chart :— Dungeness to the Thames, including Dover Strait, No. 1895 ; scale, •»;=0,68 of an inch.

Chap. X.] CAPE ALPRECH. — PORTEL. — BOULOGNE. 503 A. fixed ivhite leading light is shown from a shed N. £ E. 164 yards from Alprech lighthouse ; it is 144 feet above high water, and visible in clear weather from a distance of 9 miles. The two lights in line lead 24. cables seaward of the outer part of the new South-west mole of Boulogne, in course of construction and near completion. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on cape Alprech just southward of the lighthouse. PORTEL. — The coast between cape Alprech and Boulogne is intersected by valleys, and at the entrance of the largest is the village of Portel. This valley, 6 cables N.E. by E. of the cape, is enclosed by high land and on the summit of the hill on its northern side stands the fortress of Mont Couppes, in the interior of which is a semaphore. The rocks which uncover at low water, extend 4 cables off-shore from Portel, and, on their summit, N. £ E. about 7 cables from cape Alprech lighthouse, is the small fort of Heurt. The Lineur sunken rocks project N.N.W. 24, cables from the fort and a heavy sea runs on them with a fresh south-westerly wind. The fishermen of Portel have about 40 boats ; during the fine season, they ground them on the south-western side of a small beach in front of the village where they are sheltered during the greater part of the tide by the surrounding rocks. When the weather is threatening, they haul them above high-water mark and place them in the bed of a small rivulet which runs through the valley ; in winter they take shelter in Boulogne harbour. BOULOGNE.* — This port, occupying the entrance of the valley of the Liane, is undergoing such vast alterations that any description of it can be applicable to the present time only. The projected new port, with the works actually in progress and energetically carried on, are on such a scale as, if ever completed, to entirely alter the character of the port. The intention is to enclose about 340 acres of water space, of which a great portion is to be available for ships of the deepest draught at all times of tide. With this object, a stone pier of the strongest and most solid construction, starting from the shore under the Chatillon cliff, a mile south-westward of the present harbour entrance, has been run out 1,690 yTards in a N.N.W. \ W. direction ; it then curves for 218 yards farther until its direction becomes N.E. by N., from whence it is carried in that direction a farther distance of about 600 yards. The whole extent of this magnificent work, without a break, is 2,344 yards ; and, of this length, the last 600 yards alone remain to be completed ; this * See Admiralty Plan of Boulogne, No. 438, m = 49 inches.

Sheltered by the completed portion of the new West pier, extensive works for the accommodation of shipping are in progress along the shore between it and the present harbour. Buoys.* — The following buoys mark the works in progress : — 1. A red bell buoy with reflector is moored in about 7 fathoms water, 14 cables W.S.W. from the curve at the elbow of the new West pier. 2. A red buoy with staff and globe lies about 14 cables W. | N. from the northern end of the outer part of the same pier now under construction and above the level of low water.
