The principal objects recognised when approaching Boulogne are, Mont St. Frieux, already described, see page 502, Mont Lambert H miles to the eastward, the highest land in the neighbourhood of Boulogne, and the column of the Grande Armee on the high land a mile northward of the town. The entrance to the harbour bears N.W. £ W. from the summit of Mont Lambert, and W. £ S. from the column ; the former is 589 feet, and the head of the statue on the column 448 feet above the level of the sea. * In addition to the two buoys here described, the French Government gave notice that on the 1st April, 1887, an experimental red automatic whistle buoy was moored a quarter of a cable westward of the bell buoy with reflector.

Chap. X.] 505 BOULOGNE. — BUOYS. — ENTRANCE. The town stands chiefly on the eastern side of the harbour, and is built in the form of an amphitheatre in and on the sides of a small valley enclosed between high hills. The buildings most easily recognised from the sea are the bell-tower and cupola of the new cathedral in the upper town, the church spire in the lower town, the marine baths, the windmill half way up the hill south-eastward of the baths, and the church of St. Pierre des Marins on the cliff. Entrance Channel.— The two piers enclosing the channel into the harbour are of unequal length and run out across a sandy strand which uncovers half a mile from the shore at the lowest tides. The piers are 230 feet apart, and, from the entrance, which has a S.E. by S. direction, curve slightly eastward. The sand formerly spread itself at times across the entrance, forming a bar rising higher than the bottom of the channel, but the depths have been greatly improved since 1882 by dredging and scouring, the object being to render it deep enough for the Folkestone steamers to enter at low water. This object has in fact been effected, and, since April 1885, the daily service of steamers has been at fixed times instead of tidal as formerly. The South-west pier is 735 yards long and consists of a stone foundation on which is wooden pile-work filled in and planked up to high- water mark, which shelters the channel from the high sea during south-westerly gales. The North-east pier, 547 yards long, curves and lies parallel with the South-west pier, and also consists of a stone foundation surmounted by open pile-work. In order that the scouring water may follow the course of the channel beyond the South-west pier-head, a low submersible dyke 500 yards long, composed of rough stonework for 150 yards and continued in strong pile-work the remainder of its length, has been extended from the North-east pier-head. The position of this dyke, of which the top is from 3 to 9 feet above the level of low water, is marked, by day, by a mast surmounted by a ball at the North-east pier-head being on with the lighthouse 33 yards within that pier-head. By night, the mast bears a fixed green light, and the two lights in line indicate its position. Sailing vessels should not attempt the entrance channel during heavy westerly gales, and even steamers run great risk : but it should be always borne in mind that when Boulogne is impracticable on account of the weather, Calais can be entered, and vice versa. Harbour. — The harbour consists of the Tidal harbour or Import dock, with an inner port and reservoir or Retenue de Chasses at its head, and a Wet dock or Basin. The North-east pier joins the quays of Boulogne tidal harbour or import dock, which is 3£ cables long and

506 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. one cable wide, and along the quays on this side are berthed the Thames steamers, and are the landing-places for the goods traffic of the South-Eastern Railway. The bottom at the foot of this quay rises at parts as much as 6^ feet above the level of the lowest tides, and is hard and unfit for sharp laden vessels to ground on for more than a few days, considerable swell being felt here with strong westerly winds. At high water, neaps, those drawing from 12 to 13 feet can come alongside ; vessels of deeper draught lie aground there for four or five days. There are other berths in the Tidal harbour on the western side between the inner end of the South-west pier and the Basin ; and, at the northern end of the Quai Chanzy, which separates the Import dock from the Basin, is the railway station and the landing stage for the Folkstone steamers, alongside of which are from 9 to 12 feet at low water. There is also a slip-way for building or repairing small vessels, and a gridiron and careening place adjoining the slip. The Basin or wet dock is on the western side of the Import dock, and its entrance is through a lock at its northern end. The Basin has an area of 17 acres with a quay frontage of 1,150 yards. The lock has double gates, is 69 feet wide between them, and 328^ feet in length ; the depth over the sills is 29 feet at springs, and 23 feet at neaps. The Basin itself has about 18 inches more water, but the bottom is hard and only lightly coated with mud. Coals can be obtained in moderate quantities at about 16s. per ton. Vessels coal without difficulty either in the Tidal harbour or in the Basin. Slight repairs to machinery can be effected, but, there being no dry dock, serious defects of hull cannot be made good. Stores and supplies generally are cheap and plentiful. Trade, &C— The general trade of the port is extensive. In 1886 the number of vessels entering was 1,986, of an aggregate of 491,248 tons. The principal imports are coal, cast iron, iron ore, steel, wool, machinery, timber, beer, flax and tow, cotton, &c. ; the exports, wine, spirits, cement, grain, fruit and vegetables, Parisian articles, &c. &c. The herring and mackerel fisheries employ a considerable capital and several vessels are fitted out for the Iceland cod fishery. The coasting trade is active ; there is daily communication by steamer with Folkstone, thus connecting the South-eastern Railway of England with the Northern Railway of France, and several times a week with London and Goole. The population of the town in 1886 was 45,916, of whom about one fifth were English. There is a small British Seaman's Institute with recreation and reading rooms.

Chap. X.] 507 BOULOGNE.— TRADE.— LIGHTS. LIGHTS. — The following lights mark the new West Pier and the entrance to Boulogne harbour : — New West Pier.— In August, 1888, from the lighthouse near the extreme of this pier, and 115 feet bevond the extreme of the part then submerged at high water, an experimental light was exhibited at 42 feet above the sea. The light is quick flashing, of the fifth order, is fed by compressed oil gas, and is visible 8 miles. South-west Pier.— Tide Lights.— From a round tower at the pier-head are shown two vertical fixed ivhite lights of the fourth order, visible 11 miles ; the upper light is 43 feet, the lower light 33 feet, above the level of high water, springs. The upper light is exhibited as soon as there are 9£ feet water in the entrance channel ; the lower light, at high water ; both lights are extinguished when the water falls to 9£ feet. From an iron support, 47 yards within the vertical lights and 29 feet above the sea, is shown a fixed red light, visible about 4 miles. This light is obscured by the tidal lighthouse through an arc of 4° 20' when bearing between S.S.E. and S.S.E. 4 E. North-east Pier. — A fixed red light, dioptric and of the fourth order, is exhibited from a white tower 33 yards from the North-east pier-head ; it is 46 feet above the sea and visible 8 miles. A fixed green light is exhibited at an elevation of 33 feet, from the mast on the North-east pier-head from which, during the day, a ball is exhibited ; it stands about 30 yards in advance of the lighthouse. The green and red lights in line, as before stated, show the direction of the low submersible dyke extending from the North-east pier-head. The South-west pier red light on with the North-east pier red light E. by S. 4; S. leads northward of the works in progress at the outer end of the new West pier. Vessels making the harbour should keep northward of this line. Fog Signals. — Two sirens are sounded together on the South west pier-head, as follows : — one siren gives a continuous sound, the other of greater power gives a group of two sounds (low, high), about every 50 seconds ; each sound is of about 2h seconds duration, and the two sounds of each group are separated by an interval of 4 seconds. Should the sirens be damaged, a bell is sounded about 50 times a minute. During foggy weather, and so long as there are 61 feet or more water in the entrance channel, a bell is sounded 60 times a minute from the light-keeper's house at the South-west pier-head. (See note, page 10.)

508 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. Tide Signals. — The usual day tide signals, see page 8, are made from a signal-staff at the South-west pier-head, commencing from a depth of &\ feet. When the sluices of the scouring waters are going to be opened a blue flag is hoisted at the tide signal flag-staff, and also at a staff near the sluice gates. Other signals are made from a mast at the inner end of the North east pier. A blue triangle indicates a ship approaching ; a red triangle by day, or a red light by night, signals the approach of one of the regular packets. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in the port of Boulogne at llh. 25., springs rise 284^ feet, neaps 23 feet above the level of the soundings on the chart, which are those of low water, equinoctial springs. Strong westerly winds raise the tide a foot or two higher, and those from the eastward have a contrary effect. Sometimes it may be necessary to cross a temporary bar at the entrance, and an allowance should be made for the 'scend of the sea, which runs high at the entrance with fresh westerly winds. The tide is slack at high water, springs, for about 20 minutes with westerly, and 15 minutes with easterly winds, and vessels can be moved in the harbour during one hour and a half ; at neaps, the slack continues about 40 minutes. Tidal Streams. — At 3 miles westward of Boulogne, outside the Bassure de Baas, the flood or north-eastern stream begins to acquire its greatest strength at the time of high water in the harbour, main tains it for about 2 hours, and ceases at 3£ hours after high water. At a short distance outside the pier-heads, its greatest strength is at the time of high water in the harbour, and it ceases at 2£ hours afterwards. The eddies on the flood, occasioned by the great pro jection of the South-west pier from the shore, are very strong as soon as the sands are covered. These eddies extend into the bay northward of the North-east pier, and about the time of high water in the harbour they form a counter stream running north-westward along the eastern face of that pier ; this eddy stream, as previously described, after rounding the pier-head, divides, one part entering the channel, the other crossing it rapidly towards the South-west pier-head.* Steam-tugS. — The services of steam-tugs may always be obtained when required. * As early as 1882 the pilots reported that the building of the new West pier was affecting the action of the tides at the entrance of the harbour, the rate of the flood, and consequently of the eddy on the flood near the pier-heads, having become perceptibly reduced. It is probable that as the works extend, further modifications will follow.

Chap, x.] BOULOGNE ROADS. — DIRECTIONS. 509 Pilots. — Eight pilots and three assistant pilots are stationed at Boulogne ; they cruise at sea in good decked boats, but if they are unable to get to sea in bad weather, either a pilot or the lighthouse keeper, from the top of the lighthouse on the South-west pier, directs vessels entering as to the course to be steered by waving his hat, Should there be several vessels running for the harbour, the signal is for the vessel nearest the entrance. If the sea is too heavy to enter the channel, vessels should bear up at once for Calais ; for, as before stated, when Boulogne harbour is impracticable on account of the high sea, that of Calais can be entered, and the contrary. Life-Boats. — There are three life-boats stationed at Boulogne ; one is near the centre of the North-east pier ; the second, northward of that pier on the beach, near the baths ; the third, southward of the harbour, at the end of the Chatillon sand-hills. BOULOGNE ROADS. — Good anchorage may be found in about 4£ fathoms, 8 cables outside the pier-heads, on a narrow strip of hard clay about 7 cables long North and South, and a cable wide. It is the very space which will be occupied by the breakwater of the new harbour, should that work ever be proceeded with. This bottom is bounded on its western side by the rocky bottom known as Vhuitriere or the oyster bed, which begins at cape Alprech and extends without interruption northward as far as the parallel of Ambleteuse. The best anchorage is between the lines of the colonnade of the new cathedral on with the guard-house of Chatillon battery, which stands on the sand-hills a little southward of the South-west pier ; and, the fort on Mont Lambert on with the belfry tower in the upper town, the small fort at Ambleteuse bearing about N.E. by N. Vessels of moderate draught waiting to enter Boulogne may remain at this anchorage during fine weather, and, with a long scope of cable out, even if caught there by a strong westerly wind ; those of deep draught, however, would be in danger of striking the bottom when tailing in-shore at low water. Vessels arriving off the harbour some time before high water may anchor well to the southward off the elbow of the new West pier, and outside the line of the buoys, in 8 or 9 fathoms. DIRECTIONS.— From the "Westward. — Vessels approaching Boulogne from the westward, with the wind between South and West, should take the channel between the Bassure de Baas and the Vergoyer banks, and if they arrive on the parallel of Mont St. Frieux at low water, short tacks should be made in the Channel between

510 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. that parallel and the line of the column of the Grande Armee on with the lighthouse on the South-west pier-head. With the wind between South and East, the channel between the Bassure de Baas and the shore should be taken, and short boards made southward of the line of the column and lighthouse in one until the tide has risen sufficiently to enter the harbour ; or, weather permitting, they may anchor in Boulogne roads. Vessels of the deepest draught may at all times cross over the Bassure de Baas in front of Boulogne. One of the deepest parts is with the column of the Grande Armee on with the lighthouse on the South-west pier bearing E. £ N. ; but, as the harbour is neared, it must be borne in mind that this line leads directly for the elbow of the new West pier ; therefore, having crossed the Bassure de Baas, a vessel should keep to the northward until the red lights on the North-east and South-west piers are in line, which line leads north ward of the outermost works in progress and of the lighthouse at the extreme of the new West pier. From the Northward. — With the wind between North and West, vessels from the northward should pass westward of the Bassure de Baas, and, if the wind is fresh, they should wait outside this bank until the time for entering ; but, with a light wind, the bank should be crossed on the parallel of Creche fort and a position be maintained a short distance to windward of the entrance. If the wind is between North and East, it is better to take the channel between the Bassure de Baas and the land and then anchor, if the weather permits, in such a position as to have the wind a point or two free for running into port. The high land in the vicinity of Boulogne modifies the direction of the wind in the harbour, and sometimes when it is S.S.W. outside it is South or S.S.E. within. Strong winds from the N.E. come off in violent squalls from the high land northward of the harbour. Sailing vessels should endeavour to enter during the last hour of the flood, which assists their being tracked in, and a tracking crew will be always found on the piers. With a fresh leading wind, they may be able to stem the first hour of the ebb, and even the freshets of the river Liane, and get up to the berths in the harbour ; but, whatever the strength and direction of the wind, plenty of sail should be carried on entering the channel in order to stem the eddy between the pier-heads, which is at its greatest strength about the time of high water in the harbour. This eddy, after doubling the North-east pier-head, divides, one part entering the channel, the other

Chap, x.] BOULOGNE. — DIRECTIONS. 511 crossing it rapidly towards the South-west pier-head ; it must be guarded against when the wind is light, and, if the wind is off shore, a boat should be sent for the tracking rope. Generally speak ing, when the wind is from West round by South to N.E., steer close to the South-west pier-head ; with a fresh breeze from anywhere between N.E. and West keep in mid-channel ; and, in light winds, procure a steam-tug, or steer for the South-west pier to take in the tracking rope. Should a vessel miss the entrance during strong westerly winds and be unable to claw off the land, she should endeavour to pass close round the northern side of the North-east pier and run ashore under its lee. If this occurs at half or three quarters of an hour after high water, there is some chance of getting her afloat again, and at all events the crew are safe. Steam-vessels, or those in tow, will find the deepest water in entering by keeping near the submerged dyke projecting from the North-east pier-head, which they may do by keeping the light house on that pier a little open westward of the mast with a ball at the pier-head. Vessels leaving the port for the northward should do so as soon as they are afloat, and with a favourable wind may make sail at once from their berths. Those bound westward, unless with a fresh fair breeze outside to enable them to over-run the flood stream, should not quit the entrance channel until the latest moment, or they will be compelled to anchor outside to await the ebb stream. Anchorage. — Vessels arriving off Boulogne in fine weather during neaps, and unable from their draught to enter, may anchor in about 10 fathoms, good holding ground, at the eastern edge of the Bassure de Baas, abreast of Vimereux. If surprised here by strong north-easterly winds, they can make for Ambleteuse road ; or, if a south-westerly gale should oblige them to seek refuge, they can run for the Downs or take shelter to leeward of the coast in the neigh bourhood of Calais. The COAST. — Creche point, bearing N.E. by N. 1£ miles from Boulogne South-west pier-head, is, as well as the intermediate coast, high and steep, and is at the western extreme of the range of hills separating the valley of the Liane from that watered by the river Wimille, on one of the .highest points of which range stands the column of the Grande Armee. At 1^ cables north-westward of the steep cliff is the small fort of Creche built on the rocks extending from the foot of the point.

512 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. The coast continues steep for nearly a mile from Creche point, but from thence to Vimereux it is bordered by high sand-hills. Three quarters of a mile north-eastward of Creche fort and a quarter of a mile from the shore is Croi tower, a small semi-circular fort of two tiers built on the rocks which uncover at low water, and rising 50 feet above the level of the beach. From "Vimereux to Oies point, which bears N.N.E. £ E. 2 miles from Creche point, the coast is steep, but from thence to Audrecelles village, 2 miles farther northward, it is bordered by sand-hills of middling height covered with verdure. At 14^ miles northward of Oies point is the village of Ambleteuse, built on the northern side of Ambleteuse harbour, and, with the windmill on the high ground northward of the village, easily recognisable from the sea. Ambleteuse fort, like Croi tower, had two tiers of guns. From Ambleteuse to the village of Audrecelles, the shore consists of sand-hills covered with bent grass and intersected by small rivulets, through which the sea runs in upon the land at high water. This village stands on the shore, and is also defended by a small semi circular fort ; the church and windmills behind the village, are conspicuous objects and may be seen at some distance. From Audrecelles to Ridin point about 2 miles farther northward, the land adjoining the shore gradually rises and forms a succession of hills separated from each other by valleys, of which some run down to the coast ; but, between Ridin point and cape Grisnez, the land is more level and the cliff perpendicular, and, being nearly as high as cape Alprech, may be seen 12 to 15 miles distant. Between Ambleteuse and the rocks at Oies point, the beach is of sand and dries out 3j cables ; but, from Ambleteuse to Ridin point its breadth decreases and it consists of rocks covered with sand. The coast from Ridin point to cape Grisnez is bordered by a rocky shelf of which the projecting points do not extend beyond H cables from the foot of the cliffs. Coasters, with off-shore winds, should be cautious when approaching the shore between Croi tower and Audre celles, as a shoal bottom of uneven rock, on which there are only about 10 feet water, extends 5 or 6 cables from the coast. Vimereux, formerly a harbour, but now abandoned, is 1£ miles north-eastward of Creche fort, at the head of a small elbow in the shore between that fort and Oies point, The harbour was excavated, at the commencement of the present century, at the mouth of the river Wimille, to accomodate vessels of the flotilla intended for the invasion of England ; a freshet of that river having in after years

Chap, x.] 513 THE COAST. — VIMEREUX. — AMBLETEUSE. broken down the sluice gates, the channel and piers were destroyed and the harbour filled up with sand and shingle. The waters of the river still follow their old channel but the bottom has risen so much that, at springs, there are only 5 or 6 feet in what used to be the harbour ; its destruction has caused the almost total desertion of the village which is now nearly covered with sand. Ambleteuse, a mile northward of Oies point, is, like Vimereux, so far as its harbour is concerned, in a complete state of ruin ; it is at the mouth of the little river Selack and great improvements were made at the beginning of the present century with the same object as at Vimereux. The ruins of a stone jetty-head and some piles in the north-western part of the harbour still mark the outline of a basin in which the vessels of the flotilla were placed, but it is now filled with sand and mud and has only 4 feet water in it at springs. The village has some reputation as a watering place. Ambleteuse Roads comprise the space between the Bassure de Baas and the coast, and extend from the parallel of Vimereux to that of Audrecelles. Vessels of deep draught bound to the northern ports of the Channel, or to Calais or Dunkerque, await spring tides in these roads if they arrive during neaps with northerly winds, and are fairly sheltered during gales from N.E. round by East to South ; the sea, however, is very heavy here when it blows strongly on a weather tide. The best anchorage is between the parallel of Vimereux and the line of the church towers of Ambleteuse and Bazinghen in one E. £ N., and a little in-shore of the rocky ground forming the western limit of the anchorage of Boulogne and which extends northward to the parallel of Ambleteuse. By not anchoring eastward of the small tower of Renard, a mile south-eastward of Portel, on with Boulogne South-west pier lighthouse S. 4 W., large vessels are in a good position to weigh should it blow strongly from the westward. A good berth for a vessel of deep draught is N.W. by W. of Vimereux, with Renard tower open about a quarter of a point westward of the South-west pier lighthouse, in about 8 fathoms hard muddy clay ; or, in 9 fathoms, good holding ground of muddy sand, with the lighthouse and Renard tower in line ; and, Bazinghen church tower open a little northward of Ambleteuse fort E. £ N. Large merchant vessels may anchor in 7 fathoms, hard sand and broken shells, on the latter bearing ; and, the column of the Grande Armee on with Croi fort. A. 2771. Wt. 17197. 2 K

514 CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. [Chap. X. Boulogne pilots call the space between the eastern edge of the Bassure de Baas and the rocky bottom which bounds the anchorage in Ambleteuse road, the Parfondingue ; they state that ships of the deepest draught, requiring to remain some days in the roads, should be placed in the Parfondingue between the lines of the column of the Grande Armee on with the southern slope of Creche point, and Bazinghen tower on with Ambleteuse fort ; here they have sufficient room to weigh and round cape Grisnez if it comes on to blow hard from the S.W. : or, if it shifts to West or N.W., the crest of the bank shelters them from the heavy sea. To ride out a gale, they should be moored with open hawse to the westward and their anchors laid with a long scope of cable N.E. and S.W. in the direc tion of the tidal streams. Tides. — Abreast of Ambleteuse, at equinoctial springs, the greatest rate of the flood or north-eastern stream is from 3| to 4 knots, and, in ordinary weather, this rate continues nearly 24^ hours ; the stream follows nearly the direction of the channel and ends about 3£ hours after the time of high water at Boulogne. The ebb is less rapid, continues longer, and ends 24 hours before high water. The direc tion of the wind has great influence on both streams. Buoy. — An automatic whistle buoy, painted red and black in horizontal bands, is moored about 1£ miles from the shore N.W. by W. of Audrecelles, and 24 miles S.W. £ S. from cape Grisnez. CAPE GRISNEZ is 84 miles northward of Boulogne ; from it, cape Alprech bears S.S.W. 104 miles ; Dungeness W.N.W 23| miles ; South Foreland N. £ W. 17£ miles ; and, Beachy Head W. £ N. 524, miles. This cape, 167 feet high, is one of the most remarkable head lands on the northern coast of France and is visible in clear weather 14 or 15 miles ; from it, the coast changes its direction abruptly eastward, and this precipitous rocky cliff, as well as those southward and eastward of it, is of a dark grey colour and takes a purple tint when lighted up by the sun. A lighthouse stands on the south-western extreme of a small spot of level land crowning the cape ; some works of defence may also be seen rising above the same level land, and a guard-house at its extreme near the crest of the cliff. Large masses of rock lie at the foot of the cape, and a rocky shelf, partly covered with sand, dries at low water a quarter of a mile out from the cliffs ; the cape should, therefore, be given a berth of at least 4 cables when passing it.

Chap, x.] 515 CAPE GRISNEZ. — PAS DE CALAIS. LIGHT. — Cape Grisnez lighthouse is circular, 79 feet high from base to vane, a quarter of a mile southward of the cape, and about 100 yards from the edge of the cliff : it exhibits at 226 feet above high water an electric flashing light, showing three white flashes at intervals of three seconds, followed by an interval of twelve seconds, during which one red flash is shown. It is visible in clear weather 22 miles, but, in ordinary weather, the luminous glare caused byr it can be seen as much as 35 or 40 miles distant. This light cannot be mistaken for the light at Calais, which is also electric and white, but shows successive groups of four white flashes, with intervals between the groups three times as long as the intervals between the flashes of each group, nor for that at cape Alprech, which is white but not electric, and is varied every two minutes by a red flash. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station close to cape Grisnez lighthouse. PAS de CALAIS. — The narrowest part of this channel is 8£ miles wide, between the Ridge or Colbart shoal and cape Grisnez ; from thence, it runs nearly parallel with the coast as far as Boulogne, and then in a S.W. by W. \ W. direction between the Bassurelle and Vergoyer shoals. With easterly winds, it is to be preferred to the Dover channel between the Varne and the English shore ; it is both wider and deeper, and is a continuation of the deep soundings channel of the North Sea in which the depth is above 20 fathoms. It is easily navigated by the lead either with a leading or beating wind, and even during fog or snow, the only danger being the northern end of the Ridge which rises abruptly' from the depth of 20 fathoms. To avoid the northern end of the Ridge, a vessel turning to wind ward in the Pas de Calais, either by day or night, when northward of the parallel of cape Grisnez and standing westward, should not bring the South Foreland lighthouses eastward of N. by E. ; and, when southward of that parallel, she should not go into less than 20 fathoms. A bearing of the Varne light-vessel is also very useful for avoiding this shoal. Tides and Tidal Streams.— (See also table page 518)— It is high water, full and change, on the beach a little eastward of cape Grisnez at llh. 27m., ordinary springs rise 214; feet, extraordinary springs 27 feet, neaps 16£ feet ; at Dungeness, at lOh. 45m., springs rise 2K2

[Chap. X. CAPE D'ANTIFER TO CAPE GRISNEZ. 516 21£ feet, neaps 19 feet ; and, at the Varne and Ridge shoals, at lOh. 40m. Within a circuit of 2 miles round the cape, the streams run stronger than at a greater distance from the shore ; the flood, or north-eastern stream, beginning 2 hours before and ending 3£ hours after high water at Boulogne, and running 4 knots when at its greatest strength, at springs. Between the Ridge and the shore, the north-eastern stream runs with much greater strength than the south western. The tidal streams, on the French coast, in the northern in-shore part of the English Channel are nearly of the same duration as in the bay of the Seine, the north-eastern stream running about 54; hours, and the south-western stream 64; hours. Towards the middle of the Channel, the streams run straight, throughout its length, until they have attained their greatest strength, when they follow the bends of the coast to a distance of 7 miles in the offing. In-shore of these limits, as soon as the north-eastern stream begins to be felt it turns towards the shore, but, as its strength increases, it tends more to its principal direction, viz., that which it follows when at its greatest strength and retains for the greatest length of time ; when its rate begins to decrease, it turns off-shore and takes different directions until the end of the tide. The south-western stream runs with less velocity and undergoes the same changes, but with this difference, that it varies much more in direction. At the Varne and Ridge shoals, the north-eastern stream does not commence until 44; hours flood, nor the south-western stream until 4£ hours ebb ; making 64 hours of north-eastern and 54; hours of south-western stream. Strong south-westerly gales prolong the north-eastern stream nearly an hour, and retard proportionally the south-western stream ; so that on some occasions, on the Ridge especially, 8 hours north eastern and only 4 hours south-western streams have been found. The rate of both streams increases in proportion to the narrowing of the Channel, and, in the channels between the banks, this rate is increased from half ebb to half flood. Between the Vergoyer and the shore, both streams make about an hour sooner than farther in the offing. Caution. — The deep bight in the coast between capes d'Antifer and Grisnez, constrains the flood stream to change its course about the meridian of point d'Ailly, and to turn E. by N. obliquely towards the coast between the river Somme and cape Grisnez ; but, with strong westerly winds, it runs much farther eastward and turns suddenly only a short distance from the • shore, causing a high sea.

519 CHAPTER XI. CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. VARIATION IN 1888. Cape Grisnez 16° 25' W* Dunkerque 16° 10' W-. The COAST from cape Grisnez trends E. by N. \ N. northerly 6 miles to cape Blanc-Nez, the intermediate land is high and may be seen in clear weather from 15 to 20 miles distant ; but, beyond the latter cape, the shore bends more eastward, the high land turns in a south-easterly direction towards the interior, and a level plain extends from its foot to the coast where it terminates in a low sandy shore bordered by ranges of sand-hills, of which the highest are visible only from 7 to 10 miles. Between the capes, the shore forms a slight bay, at the head of which is the village of Wissant, inhabited by fishermen, 2 miles inland of which is Mont Couple, 525 feet above the sea level. From about a mile eastward of cape Grisnez, where the cliffs of that cape terminate, to 1\ miles north-eastward of Wissant, where the steep cliffs recommence, the coast is low and bordered by sand hills.* Cape Blanc-Nez owes its name to the high chalk cliff in which it terminates. It forms no marked projection, but its position may be recognized from a good distance at sea by the guard-house on the summit of the steep mound which crowns it, and which is the northern extreme of a range of hills joining Mont Couple. The last slopes of the high land forming the cape, as well as the steep coast in which they terminate, extend 1^ miles eastward, nearly as far as the village of Sangatte, and at this village commences the low sandy shore, which is the distinguishing feature of the remaining part of the French and of the Belgian coasts. The sand-hills are low to within \\ miles of Sangatte, but they gradually rise in height as they approach * See Admiralty charts : — Dover strait, No. 1,895 ; scale m = 068 of an inch : North sea, sheet 1, Dover and Calais to Orfordness and Scheveningen, No. 1,046 ; scale, m = 0-3 of an inch : and, Calais to river Schelde, No. 1872 ; scale, m = 07 of an inch.

520 [Chap. XI. CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. Calais, spreading into several parallel ranges which approach within 2 or 3 cables of the shore. The principal objects on this part of the coast are, the windmill of Coquelles about 2 miles inland on the last slopes of the range of hills extending eastward of cape Blanc-Nez ; the windmill at Nieulay, northward of this ; the red buildings at Trouie or the Salines, about half way between Sangatte and Calais and about N.N.E. from Coquelles windmill, which are useful marks to the pilots, who call them les maisons rouges; and, the ramparts and citadel of Calais which rise above the sand-hills and may be seen some distance at sea. The strand in front of Sangatte is only a quarter of a mile wide at low water, but near the West pier at Calais it dries out half a mile. Within a quarter of a mile of it there are several shoal patches of 7 or 8 feet, and no vessel should get amongst them at low water. Telegraph cables. — The shore end of the cable connecting with the English coast, westward of Dover, is landed in the bight just eastward of cape Grisnez. Another cable leaving the shore at Sangatte is landed at the South Foreland. Bane a la Ligne. — The great prominence of cape Grisnez, together with the sudden change in direction of the coast which there occurs, occasions an extensive eddy north-eastward of it during the flood. The eddy no doubt caused the formation of this bank of sand and broken shells, which extends E.N.E. 4^ miles nearly from the cape, and nearly 2 miles from the shore abreast of Wissant. Its shoalest part uncovers from 4 to 6 feet at low water, springs, and towards its north-eastern extreme are several heaps of sand, named La Barriere, on the highest of which are only from 4 to 9 feet water ; the sea runs high on them with a fresh breeze on a weather tide. The south-western end of the bank has gradually joined itself to the land just eastward of the cape, and there is now, therefore, no channel at low water between the bank and the land where formerly there existed a passage several feet deep, but a new channel, called the North-west channel, has been formed near the middle of the bank. Buoy. — A red buoy with a triangular top marks the north eastern end of the Barriere sand. From it, Wissant bears S. £ E. easterly, and cape Grisnez lighthouse S.W. |W.; it lies a quarter of a mile northward of the 4-feet patch. The Gardes Rocks.— The shore between capes Grisnez and Blanc-Nez is bordered by a sandy strand, uncovering in some places

Chap. XI.] THE COAST — DANGERS OFF. 521 4 cables seaward at low water. In front of all the steep parts of the coast, flat rocks rise above the sand, and amongst them and farthest from the shore are the Gardes rocks which uncover 7 feet ; from their outer extreme, Wissant church tower bears S.W. by S. 2 miles ; and, the guard-house on cape Blanc-Nez, E. by N. 1^ miles. The Quenocs and Rouge-Ridin.— A rocky bottom, joining the shore and partly covered with sand, extends from the Gardes to Sangatte village, and 2 miles into the offing between the bearings N.N.W. and E.N.E. from cape Blanc-Nez ; its shoalest part forms two distinct dangerous flats of irregular rocks, named the Quenocs and Rouge-Ridin. The Quenocs, the western flat, is about half a mile in diameter, it has two heads with only 9 feet water ; from its centre, the guard house on cape Blanc-Nez bears S. by E. £ E. about 1^ miles ; and, Sangatte church tower E. by S. £ S. 2\ miles. The Rouge-Ridin is nearer the shore, and nearly a mile in extent W.S.W. and E.N.E. ; from its shoalest head of 6 feet near the western end, the guard-house on cape Blanc-Nez bears S. \ E. one mile. A shoal head of 9 feet also lies on the eastern edge of this flat, with the guard-house bearing S.S.W. \ W. 1\ miles, and Sangatte church tower E.S.E. 1\ miles. The sea runs high on both flats with a fresh breeze on a weather tide. Sangatte church tower on with Coquelles windmill S.E., leads half a mile northward of the Rouge-Ridin. Buoy. — A red bell buoy with reflector is moored in 3 or 4 fathoms water off the northern side of the Quenocs ; from it, Calais West pier-head bears E. \ S. 6 miles ; the Barriere buoy S.W. by W. \ W. westerly 2^ miles ; and, the shore is distant nearly 1^ miles. Ridin de Calais. — This bank, about 4 miles long E.N.E. and W.S.W., commences N. by E. 1^ miles from Sangatte, and ends N. £ E. about 2\ miles from the entrance to Calais. Its general depth varies from 5 to 8 fathoms ; the shoalest part is near the centre where for 1^ miles may be found spots of from 25 to 28 feet water ; from the south-western shoal head of 25 feet, the entrance to Calais bears S.E. by E. \ E. 2f miles. The bank is dangerous at low water for vessels of deep draught only, but it occasions strong eddies and during fresh northerly winds there is a heavy sea on it, and breakers in north-easterly gales. RIDINS de la RADE, also named the Tetes, their western end in 30 feet commencing nearly a mile N. by W. from Calais pier heads, extend from thence eastward and south-eastward, and consist

[Chap. XI. 522 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. of many heaps of sand, on the highest of which are only 4 feet water. This spot bears N.E. by E. £ E. 9^ cables from the east pier head. Another patch of 18 feet bears N. by E. \ E. 9 cables from the same pier-head, and at varying distances between these bearings are several spots of from 6 to 9 and 16 feet water. These banks have steadily decreased in depth during the last fifty years and appear still to have the same tendency. A heavy sea runs on them with on-shore winds. Buoys.— A black bell buoy with perch and cross is moored in the centre of the deep between the Quenocs and these Ridins ; from it, Calais West pier-head bears E. by S. \ S. 3| miles ; and, the Quenocs buoy W. by S. nearly 3 miles. A red buoy with perch and globe lies in 10 fathoms near the eastern end of the Ridin de Calais ; from it, Calais pier-heads bear S. i E. 2\ miles ; Walde lighthouse S.E. by E. \ E. 3£ miles ; and, Out-Ruytingen West buoy N.E. £ N. northerly 5£ miles. RADE de CALAIS, comprised between the Ridin de Calais and the sands westward of Calais harbour, affords anchorage with off-shore winds to vessels arriving off the harbour a few hours before the tide permits them to enter. A convenient position, in about 9 fathoms water and one mile from the shore, is, with Sangatte church tower on with cape Blanc-Nez guard-house W. by S. £ S ; and, Calais lighthouse S.E. \ E. At night, keep cape Grisnez light opening and shutting in with the cliffs at cape Blanc-Nez and anchor when Calais light bears S.E. \ E. The road carries a depth of from 10 to 14 fathoms towards the Ridin de Calais, and from 7 to 9 fathoms at half a mile from the steep edge of the beach, with sandy bottom mixed with broken shells ; but, according to the pilots, the anchors penetrate into good holding ground beneath the sand, and ships of the largest size have ridden out north-westerly gales under the southern part of the Ridin. The holding ground is not so good near the shore. The anchorage is sheltered by the land from W.S.W. round to S.E., but it is quite open in all other directions. The Ridin can scarcely be considered as a shelter, although the waves break with great violence during a northerly gale on its whole extent ; the sea, how ever, is much quieter here than in the offing, and a vessel with good ground gear might ride out a gale in the northern part of the road. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station on the shore about 6 cables westward of Calais West pier.

Chap, xi.] ROAD AND PORT OF CALAIS. 523 CALAIS. — This port consists of a tidal harbour and a small basin named the Bassin du petit Paradis, both of which dry at low water ; a wet dock or basin under the ramparts of the citadel in which the largest vessels that can enter the harbour lie afloat ; and, a large reservoir containing the scouring water. The entrance is 11^ miles eastward of cape Grisnez ; S.E. \ E. 22 miles from Dover pier ; and, S.E. \ S. 20j miles from the South Foreland. In fine weather and with smooth water, vessels of at least 20 feet draught can enter the harbour at high water, springs, and of 15 feet at neaps ; but, with northerly winds, even when the sea is not too high to enter, vessels above 17 feet draught should not attempt it at springs, nor above 12^ feet at neaps. The average depth at the entrance and up to the Quai de Maree has, however, been greatly increased of late years by dredging and is maintained by flushing, but it varies in depth, north-easterly winds having a tendency to form a bar at the entrance.* With W.S.W. gales, which render the navigation of the English Channel so dangerous, the tide rises a foot or two higher than usual, and mariners should remember that when it blows strongly from between West and South and Boulogne is impracticable, Calais can be entered ; and, on the contrary, when it blows hard between North and E.N.E. and it is impossible to enter Calais, Boulogne can be entered. Calais has some foreign and a brisk coasting trade ; the vessels belonging to the port are chiefly employed in the cod, herring, and mackerel fisheries. In 1886 the population, including that of St. Pierre, now united with Calais under the one name, the ancient fortifi cations separating them having been levelled, was 54,000. The imports are coal, iron, wood, jute, woollens, cottons, &c. ; the exports, straw, eggs, silks, Parisian goods, &c. The number of vessels entering the port annually is about 2,000, of an aggregate of 500,000 tons. There is always a moderate stock of coals at reasonable prices and every facility for coaling either in the harbour or wet dock ; there is a gridiron and careening slip, but no establishments for repairs of consequence to vessels or machinery. The English and French mails cross the channel between Dover and Calais three times each way daily, the distance being accomplished under ordinary circumstances in 1£ hours. The Entrance Channel is about 328 feet wide between the piers and runs about 5 cables in a S.S.E. \ E. direction from * See Admiralty plan of Calais, No. 2,556 ; scale in = 5 inches.

[Chap. XI. 524 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. the pier-heads to the entrance of the flushing reservoir. The pier heads bear from each other N.E. by E. and S.W. by W. ; both have been lengthened about 800 feet by open pilework, through which, as well as in front of the entrance, both flood and ebb streams flow across the direction of the channel. This arrange ment prevents the sand accumulating in front of the entrance, but it is a serious inconvenience to vessels entering or leaving at high water, as the north-eastern stream is then running at its greatest strength. The West pier has a small opening, about 1| cables from the end, to enable boats to load with sand from that side. At its inner end, it terminates in the towing path passing under the glacis of Fort Risban. The East pier has a quay with berths for the steam-packets, and cranes for landing goods and placing them at once in the trains, which run on the pier ; it is called the Quai de Maree, and has throughout its length a depth of 10£ feet at low water, springs ; it is chiefly used when there is not sufficient water alongside the Courgain quay in the harbour. The Harbour begins where the East pier joins the wall of the quay at the eastern part of the town. This wall continues along the whole length of the harbour, except where interrupted by the entrance to the Paradis basin, and by the sluice of the citadel ditch. The harbour is about 2,296 feet long by 230 feet wide, and its least central depth is that of low water, springs. The quays are spacious ; the Courgain or Colonne quay, between the Paradis basin and the East pier, is where vessels arriving after high water, or preparing to quit the harbour, are placed, and about one half of the quay between the entrance to the Paradis basin and the citadel sluice, is reserved for the mail and passage steamers ; the other half is for merchant vessels, and this part of the tidal harbour is known as the Import Dock. The railway station is on the Import dock quay, and, from it, sidings or branches run along both sides of the wet and import docks and, as before stated, to the Quai de Maree. There is a large crane which might be used for masting, and many smaller ones for loading or unloading ordinary cargo. The Wet dock has its entrance at the head of the Import dock ; it has an area of 20,000 square yards, with 590 yards extent of quays. The entrance between the gates is 55£ feet wide, and the sill is at the level of low water, ordinary springs. Its length is 1,230 feet, and its width 246 feet. Both harbour and wet dock are well sheltered from wind and sea ; a swell, however, runs into the

Chap. XI.] CALAIS. — DOCKS. — TIDES. 525 entrance channel, the harbour, and the Paradis basin from half flood to half ebb when it blows strongly from the northward, and vessels alongside the Colonne quay then strike heavily upon a hard shingle bottom. The berths in the Import dock, westward of the entrance to the Paradis basin, are on both sides soft and good. New docks are in progress, especially a tidal harbour and wet dock for the mail steamers, which it is expected will be opened in the course of the year 1889, also a large flushing reservoir on the sands eastward of the piers, which will be filled each tide and discharged into the entrance channel at low water through a sluice near the east pier-head, in such volume as to wash away the bar outside and maintain a deep channel. All these new works are on the eastern side of the present harbour and town. Pilots. — Seven pilots are stationed at Calais ; they cruise in small schooners as far westward as Dungeness, and as far northward as the Galloper light- vessel. When the pilots are not able to get to sea, they indicate to approaching vessels the course to be steered by means of a mast working on a hinge at the East pier-head ; this mast is inclined towards the side towards which the vessel should steer. Steam-tug. — A steam-tug is attached to the port. Life-BoatS. — In case of shipwreck, there is a life-preserving mortar and apparatus at three distinct stations at Calais, and also two life-boats ; one of the latter is stationed on the eastern side, the other on the western side of the harbour. Tides and Tide Signals.— It is high water, full and change, in Calais harbour at llh. 49m. ; springs rise 21 feet ; neaps 17 feet. The slack at high water, springs, lasts about 20 minutes, and large vessels can be moved in the harbour during a period of 1^ hours. The slack at neaps often lasts for three quarters of an hour. The tides rise higher with strong winds from N.W. to W.S.W. than with those from East to S.S.E. The usual day tide signals, see page 8, are made from a mast close to the lighthouse on the East pier-head. Tidal Streams. — The mean duration of the flood or eastern stream, at springs, in front of the entrance is 5^ hours, and of the ebb 1\ hours. At half a mile outside the piers, the flood runs 2^ or 3 hours after high water in the harbour, and with strong westerly winds, ±\ or 5 hours ; with easterly winds, it continues only 1^ or 2 hours after high water in the harbour. The rate of the flood at extraordinary springs is 4^ knots.

526 [Chap. XI. CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. LIGHTS.— Calais Lighthouse, octagonal and 167 feet high, stands on one of the bastions of the fortifications at the north-eastern side of the town, and exhibits, at 190 feet above high water and visible 25 miles, an electric, group-flashing, white light, showing successive groups of four white flashes, with intervals between the groups three times as long as the intervals between the flashes of each group. West Pier. — A fixed red light, 23 feet above high water and visible 4 miles, is exhibited from a mast at the outer end of the West pier. This light is not shown in bad weather, access to the West pier-head being then impracticable. East Pier — Tide Lights. — From a white turret at the East pier-head 19 feet high and 27 feet above high water, the following tide lights, visible 9 miles distant, are shown, and are similar to those used at Dunkerque : — A. fixed red light indicates less than &\ feet but tide rising. A fixed green light indicates less than 6^ feet and tide falling. A fixed ivhite light indicates the depth from 6^ feet to 7£ feet. A fixed white light varied by groups of red and green flashes indicates depths of more than 1\ feet. The groups of coloured flashes are separated by intervals of eighty seconds, and the flashes in each group by intervals of five seconds ; each red flash showing an additional 3 feet 4 inches to the initial height of 6Jy feet, and each green flash adding 10 inches more. Whilst the tide is rising, the fixed light, of either colour, is eclipsed for a short interval every eighty seconds; and, when it is falling, the light is eclipsed twice in quick succession every eighty seconds ; these eclipses occur nearly in the middle of the intervals separating groups of flashes. No eclipse takes place at or about high water. Fog Signals. — A bell is sounded continuously in foggy weather from the turret of the East jetty during the time the port is accessible ;* see also note, page 10. For the use of the Mail Service, during foggy weather, a gun is fired from the East pier-head every five minutes at the time the mail steamer is expected. DIRECTIONS.— From the Westward.— As a general rule, cape Blanc-Nez should be sighted when bound either to Calais, * As no one is specially appointed to sound this bell, it often happens that it is not sounded. — " Pilote des Cotes Nord de France," Vol. 2, 1884.

Chap. XI.] CALAIS. — LIGHTS. — DIRECTIONS. 527 Gravelines, or Dunkerque. The most favourable winds for entering Calais harbour are those from W.S.W. round by North to East. Moderate on-shore winds only cause a heavy swell on the beach, but when strong they send in a heavy sea and it is then dangerous to enter. Under these circumstances, which are frequent in winter, vessels bound for the northern ports of France should immediately run for Boulogne ; and, it should be borne in mind that at this, and at all French ports of any importance a red flag is shown at the tide signal-staff when the port is rendered inaccessible by weather. Vessels running for Calais from the South-west, when on the parallel of and about a mile from cape Grisnez, should steer about N.E. by E. \ E., taking care not to bring the extreme of the cape westward of S.W. W. in order to keep outside the Barriere and the Quenocs rocks.- When Sangatte church tower is on with Coquelles windmill, S.E., steer about E.S.E. for the centre of Calais, leaving the black bell buoy on the port-hand ; and, when abreast of it, or when Audinghen church tower, near cape Grisnez, is hidden behind the cliff at cape Blanc-Nez, if there is water sufficient to enter the harbour a course should be shaped for the entrance ; if not, an anchorage should be sought for in the southern part of Calais road. The largest vessels the harbour admits, may pass at all times of tide between the Quenocs and the Barriere, by keeping Sangatte church tower on with either of the three towers of Calais ; they may also pass between the Rouge-Ridin and the shore, from half flood to half ebb. At Night, cape Grisnez light should not be brought westward of S.W. i W. to avoid the Barriere and the Quenocs, and when Calais light bears E.S.E., steer about E. by S. ; then, if the ebb or western stream is running, anchor as soon as cape Grisnez light is about to be hidden behind the cliff at cape Blanc-Nez ; but, if the flood, and there is sufficient water in the entrance, steer for the red light on the West pier-head which must be rounded close to. From the Northward. — Between one third flood and two thirds ebb in Calais harbour, either by day or night, vessels from the northward with a fresh fair wind may run directly for the entrance over the Ridin de Calais, where there is then sufficient water. If late on the ebb, run on the meridian of cape Blanc- Nez until Sangatte church tower is on with Coquelles windmill S.E. ; then steer, if the weather is favourable, for the anchorage in the southern part of Calais road.

[Chap. XI. 528 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. At Night, steer for Calais light on an E.S.E. bearing until Cape Grisnez light bears W.S.W., then steer E. \ S. until Cape Grisnez light is just masked behind Cape Blanc-Nez, when anchor if the ebb is running, or, if the flood, steer for the harbour. Entering the Harbour.— The most favourable time for entering Calais harbour with an on-shore wind is at high water ; but, with the wind abeam or ahead, at half or three quarters of an hour before that time, so as to have time to be tracked up to the quays, or into the wet dock. It should- 'be borne in mind, however, that during calm weather, at half a mile outside the entrance, the flood or eastern stream continues to be felt 2\ or 3 hours, and with strong westerly winds 4^ or 5 hours after high water in the harbour, and is at its greatest strength at the time of high water there. For this reason, whatever the direction of the wind, the West pier-head should be steered for, to avoid being set eastward of the entrance, and this precaution is particularly necessary when standing for the harbour on the starboard tack ; the bower anchors and a stern anchor should then be ready for letting go, and hawsers ready to run out in the event of being drifted on the East pier. All sail should be carried, especially with the wind right aft, to stem the flood and to pass quickly through the swell at the entrance. Should a vessel with a strong westerly wind and without a pilot miss the entrance, she must anchor immediately as near as possible to the East pier-head and take in a pilot, whose assistance will then be indispensable. Vessels may get out of harbour and gain an offing on a weather tide against a head wind by making sail from the end of the West pier. BANKS Off the NORTH COAST of FRANCE.— The approach to this low and dangerous coast is obstructed by numerous banks of grey and black sand, which extend as far as 15 miles from the shore on the meridian of Calais, and 42 miles in a north-easterly direction from Dunkerque. They are all long and narrow, and con verge in direction towards the straits of Dover. Their shoalest spots may be touched upon by vessels of almost any draught, and the eddies they occasion cause a hollow sea which breaks on them when it blows hard. Those farthest from the land lie on the eastern side of the 20-fathoms line of soundings, which, in the southern part of the North Sea, is the eastern limit of the deep known as the deep soundings channel, which begins in Dover strait and ends at about lat. 53° 20' N.

Chap, xi.] DUNKERQUE AND OTHER BANKS. 529 The banks are all steep-to on their in-shore edge and extend with a gentle slope towards the offing, and, as they rise from the sub marine bank of sand, gravel, and broken shells which joins the shore, and on which there are everywhere less than 20 fathoms, the simple precaution of not going into less than that depth ensures keeping outside all these banks. The lights at cape Grisnez and Calais are in a good position to point out at night their western limit ; the electric flashing light at Dunkerque, seen in clear weather 20 miles, gives notice of approach to the greater part of them, and the navigation is still further facilitated by the two light-vessels moored within the Hinder banks, by that north-eastward of the Ruytingen, and by others more in-shore. The dangers of the in-shore navigation can only be avoided by placing the vessel in charge of a good pilot, for the banks are all so liable to changes in their formation that no description of them can be considered permanently reliable ; generally speaking, none of the banks should be approached except a vessel is bound for one of the harbours on the coast. The banks are divided into two groups, those nearest the shore, eleven in number, being named the Dunkerque banks ; others, six in number, lying some distance from the coast and northward of the Dunkerque banks, were but little known until surveyed by the late Captain W. Hewett, R.N., in H.M.S. Fairy between 1831-1840; they are, the Fairy, North Hinder, West Hinder, East Hinder, and Bligh banks, and Thornton ridge. DUNKERQUE BANKS, eleven in number, extend 15 miles from the coast between the meridians of Calais and the frontier of Belgium. Their names are, the Sandettie, Out-Ruytingen, In Ruytingen, Bergues, Dyck (the north-eastern part of which is called the Cliff-d'Islande or East Clif), In-Ratel, Out-Ratel, Haut-fond de Gravelines, Breedt, Smal, and the bank bounding Dunkerque road to the northward, of which different parts are named Snouw, Braeck, Hils, and Traepegeer. Sandettie\ in Flemish the Zand-detie, called also by local French mariners the Ourting, is the outer and westernmost of the Dun kerque banks ; it is about 12 miles long E. by N. \ N. and W. by S. i S., its breadth varying from 4 cables to a mile. Its southern and south eastern edges are steep-to, having from 19 to 20 fathoms water at less than half a cable from the southern edge, but its slope is more gradual towards the North-west and this side may be easily avoided by the lead. 530 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. [Chap. XL There are two shallow flats on this bank over which it is dangerous to pass in bad weather. The eastern flat, with only 21 feet water, bears N.W. by N. 18 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse, and N.E. by N. 17 miles from that at Calais ;. and, the centre of the western flat, on which there are only 20 feet, lies W. by S. 3£ miles from the eastern flat ; N.W. i N. from Dunkerque lighthouse ; and, N.N.E. £ E. from that at Calais. Besides these flats, other heaps of sand, with from 21 to 25 feet water, extend H miles in a W. by S. direction from the western flat, but, on other parts of the bank, the depths vary from 31 to 46 feet. The Sandettie, rising suddenly from comparatively deep water, causes strong ripplings, and, with a fresh breeze, the sea is heavy around it and breaks on the shoal flats. From the south-western end of the bank, which is steep-to, in 8 or 9 fathoms, the following lights may be seen in clear weather : — Cape Grisnez S.W. S. 20 miles ; Calais S. by W. 12i miles ; Gravelines S.S.E. £ E. 15 miles ; Dunkerque S.E. £ E. 22 miles and just visible ; and, South Foreland lights W. by N. 16 miles. In the daytime, in clear weather, the summit of Mont Couple may be recognized bearing S.S.W. \ W. nearly 19 miles ; also, the South Foreland and the white cliffs near Dover. The north eastern end of the Sandettie, on which there are 9 fathoms water, bears N. by W. £ W. 18 miles from Dunkerque light, and N.N.W. W. 6£ miles from Ruytingen light-vessel. Out-Ruytingen, midway between the coast of France and the Sandettie, is separated from the latter by a channel from 5 to 6 miles wide, with soundings of from 14 to 20 fathoms. Its western end is about 7 miles from the shore on the meridian of Calais lighthouse ; from thence, it extends 7 miles eastward and then curves 9 miles in an E.N.E. direction to the position of the light-vessel, beyond which to the 10-fathoms line it extends 2^ miles farther, but with nothing less than 7 fathoms water. The bank rises almost per pendicularly from the bottom on its south-eastern side, but falls with a gentle slope north-westward. Those parts on which there are less than 5 fathoms water form two flats, with a channel of from 5 to 9 fathoms and 2 miles wide between them ; from the centre of this channel, GraveJines lighthouse bears S.S.E. 4 E., and Calais lighthouse S.W. \ S. ; vessels bound to either of these ports may pass over the shoal between these flats at any time of tide, with Gravelines light house bearing S. by E. £ E. leaving Nos. 2 and 4 buoys on the starboard hand and No. 7 buoy on the port hand.

Chap. XL] 531 OUT-RUYTINGEN BANK. The western flat, of the Out-Ruytingen, within a depth of 5 fathoms, is 7 cables wide and 3^- miles long from West to East and has less than 3 fathoms for 2 miles of this extent ; from its shoalest spot of only 10 feet, the church tower of St. Pierre-les-Calais is on with Fienne windmill S.S.W. \ W. ; Calais lighthouse S.W. by S. 8£ miles ; Gravelines lighthouse S.E. by S. ; and, Dunkerque light house S.E. by E. \ E. The eastern flat within the 5-fathoms line is 9 miles long, and from 4 to 9 cables wide ; on its northern part are patches with only 15 feet water ; on other parts, the depths vary from 18 to 23 and 26 feet. The Out-Ruytingen occasions strong eddies and with a fresh breeze the sea breaks on the shoalest parts and is heavy on its edges. There are irregularities of bottom extending westward of this bank as far as the bearing N. \ W. from Calais lighthouse, and small vessels should avoid crossing them in bad weather on account of the high sea they occasion. LIGHT- VESSEL. — About one mile from the eastern end of the eastern flat of Out-Ruytingen, and in 10 fathoms water, is moored a light-vessel exhibiting at 33 feet above the sea a red revolving light, which attains its greatest brilliancy every half minute, and is visible in clear weather from a distance of 10 miles. The vessel, with mast and ball, is painted red, with Ruytingen in white letters on each side ; she lies about HJr miles N. by W. \ W. from Dunkerque lighthouse ; N.E. by N. northerly 13 miles from Gravelines light house ; and, S.W. by W. \ W. Yi\ miles from the West Hinder light-vessel. Fog-bell. — A bell is sounded in foggy weather for one minute every three minutes, and continuously in reply to vessels. Buoys. — Three buoys mark the north-western side of the Out- Ruytingen great bank, viz. : — North-east buoy, No. 3, black with staff and diamond, in 10 fathoms, about 1£ miles W. \ S. from the Ruytingen light- vessel ; and, N.N.W. 12 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse. Middle buoy, No. 5, black with a cylinder, in 9 fathoms, N.W. \ N. from Dunkerque lighthouse ; N.E. by E. from Calais lighthouse ; and, S.W. by W. \ W. 4 miles from the North-east buoy. South-west buoy, No. 7, black with staff and cone, point upwards, in 8 fathoms, near the western end of the eastern flat, W. by S. nearly 4 miles from the Middle buoy ; and, N.E. \ E. 11 miles from Calais lighthouse. 2L 2

XI; 532 Three buoys also mark the Out-Ruytingen little bank, viz. : — North buoy, No. 2, red with staff and cone, point downwards, in 6.V fathoms, W. by N. £ N. 2 miles from No. 7 buoy ; and, N.N.W. westerly 9^ miles from Gravelines lighthouse. South buoy, No. 4, red with two cones joined at their points, in 11 fathoms, S.W. £ S. U miles from No. 2 buoy ; W. £ S. 3 miles nearly from No. 7 buoy ; N.W. £ W. 8 miles from the Dyck light-vessel ; N.N.W. £ W. 8£ miles from Gravelines lighthouse ; and, N.E. £ N. 8£ miles from Calais lighthouse. West buoy, No. 9, chequered black and ivhite with cone surmounted by a ball, in 6^ fathoms, W. \ N. 2^ miles from No. 4 buoy ; N.W. lQJj miles from Gravelines lighthouse ; and, N. by E. £ E. 7^ miles from Calais lighthouse. In-Ruytingen.— The body of this bank lies 2^ miles eastward of the northern part of the Out-Ruytingen, and, including all shoal soundings of less than 8^ fathoms, it is 8 miles long W.S.W. and E.N.E., and its greatest width is 3 miles. From its western extreme, Dunkerque lighthouse bears about S. by E. £ E. 9£ miles ; and, from its north-eastern extreme, S. by W. \ W. 12£ miles. The In-Ruytingen is of triangular form and its irregular depths cause an uneasy sea.' The parts with less than 26 feet water form two flats, separated by depths of from 5 to 6 fathoms. The western flat occupies the centre of the bank and is 2\ miles long North and South and 2 miles wide, with as little as 9 feet in the centre, from which depth, Dunkerque lighthouse seen midway between Cassel and the spires at Bergues bears S. | E. ; and, Ruytingen light vessel N.W. 2\ miles nearly. The eastern flat is at the north-eastern part of the bank and is H miles long ; its shoalest spot has 14 feet water. The channel between the In-Ruytingen and Out-Ruytingen carries a depth of from 15 to 8 fathoms. Vessels may pass through it by keeping Ruytingen light -vessel on with Gravelines lighthouse bearing S.W. by S. southerly, and, having passed the light-vessel on either side, by then keeping her on the opposite bearing astern. Bergues. — This bank lies one mile northward of the north eastern flat on the In-Ruytingen, and its least depth, 23 feet, bears N. \ E. easterly 13 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse. The eastern end of the bank is on the meridian and 15 miles distant from Dun kerque, from thence it extends 3£ miles W. by S. Some ridges with

Chap. XL] IN-RUYTINGEN AND DYCK BANKS. 533 t from 6 to 8 fathoms extend 4 miles eastward of the shoalest part of this bank, and, with a fresh breeze on a weather tide, a heavy sea runs in the eddies on their edges, as well as on the edges of the Bergues. Buoy.— A black buoy with staff and ball, No. 1, lies in 11 fathoms on the northern side of the shoal part of the Bergues, ; from it, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S. \2 W. westerly 13f miles ; Ruytingen light-vessel S.W. by W. £ W. about 5 miles ; and, West-Hinder light vessel N.E. by E. \ E. 8 miles. WEST, MIDDLE, and EAST DYCK form one continuous narrow shoal, on which the several banks are separated by depths of less than 6 fathoms. The south-western end of the shoal in 8 fathoms commences N.N.E. £ E. 6 miles from Calais lighthouse ; and, S. by E. \ E. 2 miles from Out-Ruytingen West buoy, No. 9 ; from thence, it runs eastward nearly parallel With the coast for 18 miles, almost to the meridian of Dunkerque, and then trends N.E. £ E. 13j miles. The part between its western extreme and the meridian of Gravelines is the West Dyck or Orteil ; the central part, between Gravelines and Grande Synthe, the Middle or the Dyck ; and, the eastern part is the East Dyck or Clif-d'Islande. West Dyck or Orteil is 9 miles in length, and its greatest breadth is about half a mile. From the least depth, 15 feet, Gravelines light house bears South 5| miles ; and, the Dyck light-vessel S.S.E. £ E. 3£ miles. For 2^ miles both eastward and westward of this shoal part, the depths are from 19 to 25 feet, and, towards the western end. N.E. 65 miles from Calais lighthouse, is a small patch with 27 feet water. Small vessels should avoid passing near some patches of from 7 to 10 fathoms which lengthen out this bank westward almost to the meridian of Calais, as there is a confused sea on their edges with a fresh breeze on a weather tide. Middle Dyck or The Dyck is one continuous flat, 5^ miles long E. by N. and W. by S., from 5 to 8 cables wide, and has from one to 5 fathoms water, the shoalest spot being near the eastern end. The bank commences N.N.E. \ E. 6 miles from Gravelines lighthouse, and ends N. by W. \ W. 7 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse. The shoalest part of this flat is 4 miles long, on which the depths vary from 6 to 12 and 18 feet. From the centre to the eastern end it is extremely dangerous, being steep-to on all sides, but especially towards the North-west, where, at 2 cables distance, there are from 14 to 15 fathoms water.

[Chap. XI 534 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. Gravelines lighthouse S.W. by S. leads between the West and Middle Dyck in about 19 feet water. East Dyck or Clif-d'Islande is separated from the Middle Dyck by a channel nearly 2 miles wide, in which the least depth is about 6 fathoms. The south-western end of this bank lies North a little westerly 7 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse, and, from thence, trends N.E. £ E. about 14 miles. It is very dangerous throughout its whole extent, as it rises abruptly like a wall from soundings of from 11 to 17 fathoms. Its shoalest part, a flat 3 miles long, on the greater part of which there are only from 6 to 9 feet water, commences near the south-western end of the bank and extends north-eastward to the meridian of Dunkerque lighthouse. On the other flats of the bank the depths are irregular, varying from 10 to 17 feet. The north-eastern end of the East Dyck is a formidable danger ; here the depths are only from 3 to 4 fathoms and the sea is always disturbed around it, as it rises abruptly from depths of 15 and 17 fathoms and is therefore difficult to be avoided by the lead, however quickly hove. From the shoal spot of 3 fathoms, the West Hinder light-vessel bears N.W. 3^ miles ; Dunkerque lighthouse N.E. £ N. 19 miles ; and; Ostende lighthouse S.E. E. 16 miles ; but, this end of the bank being so far from the low land, the most remarkable objects can be recognised, even 'from the mast-head, only in very clear weather ; at such times, Dunkerque light may be seen 5 or 6 miles farther. DYCK LIGHT-VESSEL, moored in about 6 fathoms 3 miles in-shore of the shoalest part of the West Dyke and N.E. \ E. 2£ miles from Gravelines pier-head lights, shows at 39 feet above the sea, a flashing ivhite light visible 11 miles. The flashes occur every twenty seconds and are preceded and followed by short eclipses. The vessel is painted with red and black bands, has the word Dyck in white letters on each side, and carries a cage painted red at her mast-head. Fog bell. — In foggy weather, a bell is sounded for one minute every three minutes, and continuously in reply to a passing vessel. From the Dyck light-vessel, the Snouw light-vessel bears E. by S. \ S. 2£ miles. The two light-vessels in line lead through the West Pass into Dunkerque road. In-Ratel. — This bank is, properly speaking, only a branch of the Middle Dyck, being joined to its south-western end by a narrow

Chap. XL] DYCK, RATEL, AND GRAVELINES BANKS. 535 4-fathoms sandy ridge ; it is high and steep-to on all sides, and, from its western end in 22 feet, N. \ E. 5^ miles from Mardick church tower, it trends E. £ N. 7 miles, where, on and near its eastern end, at between 6 and 7 miles N.N.E. \ E. from Dunkerque lighthouse, shoal ground of from 15 to 25 feet rises suddenly from soundings of 7 or 8 fathoms. Its extreme breadth, about a mile, is near the middle of the bank where there is a shoal flat 2 miles long with only from I to 9 feet water, and with less than 6 feet for more than a mile of its extent, From this dangerous part, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S. by E. \ E. 5| miles. The channel separating the In-Ratel from the Breedt in-shore of it, is barred between the western flats of these banks by a heap of sand on which are about 3£ fathoms water. There are 8 and 12 fathoms in this channel at a short distance eastward and westward of this bar. Out-Ratel is an isolated bank, and within the 5-fathoms line is 9 miles long and about a mile wide ; it lies south-eastward of and parallel with the East Dyck, from which it is separated by a deep channel from 2 to 2\ miles wide. Its name, meaning rattle, is perhaps derived from the noise caused by the heavy sea on it in bad weather. Near its south-western end, about a mile northward of the eastern end of the Breedt, is a dangerous flat with only 8 feet water. This shoal spot lies N.E. \ N. 10 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse ; from thence, the bank extends N.E. by E. easterly Si miles, including the shoal patches of 3£ and 4 fathoms near its north-eastern extreme. The Out-Ratel, having for 7| miles of its extent only from 9 to 15 feet water, ought not to be crossed, even by small vessels, without great care. It is separated from the East Dyck, as well as from the eastern end of the Breedt, by soundings of from 7 to 12 fathoms. A bank, 1£ miles long with only 25 feet water, lies N.N.W. £ W. 1^ miles from its north-eastern end, and is separated from it by soundings of from 10 to 13 fathoms. When in-shore of the West Hinder, by not bringing Ostende lighthouse eastward of S.E. S., a vessel keeps north-eastward of all the banks between the East Dyck and Middelkercke bank, which latter is the most western of the Ostende banks. The West Hinder light-vessel also affords a good mark for clearing them, but constant attention should be paid to the lead. Haut-Fond de Gravelines, a small sandy flat a mile in extent on which the least water is 19 feet, lies 1^ miles westward of the western end of the Breedt bank ; from the shoalest spot Gravelines lighthouse

[Chap. XL 536 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. bears S. by W. £ W. 3£ miles ; and, Dunkerque lighthouse open north ward of the Snouw light-vessel S.E. by E. £ E. easterly 9£ miles. Buoy. — A spindle buoy marks the eastern extreme of the Haut fond de Gravelines ; from it, the Dyck light-vessel bears S. £ W., and the Snouw bell and reflector buoy, S.E. \ E. easterly. Breedt Bank.— This is the largest of the Dunkerque banks, and joins the In-Ratel by a bar of sand with 3£ fathoms water. Its western extreme in 5 fathoms bears N. by W. 3£ miles from Gravelines point ; N.E. \ N. 4£ miles from Gravelines lighthouse ; and, N.E. £ E. 1£ miles from the Dyck light-vessel. From thence, it trends E. £ S. <o\ miles, and then E. by N. £ N. 8£ miles to its eastern extreme in 5 fathoms, which bears N.E. \ E. 10 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse ; and, N.N.W. 9^ miles from Fumes. There are three dangerous flats on the Breedt, with channels across the bank between them with not less than 15 feet water, The western flat, with only 2 feet least water, is 2\ miles long, lies 3 miles from the shore, is half a mile wide, and, from its centre, Mardick church tower bears South. The middle flat, which is the largest, is . of an oval shape, H miles long by 1\ miles wide ; from its shoalest part, where, in 1879, 2\ feet was the least depth found though formerly it used to uncover 5 feet, Dunkerque pier-heads bear South about 3 miles. The channel between this and the western flat has from 3 to ?>\ fathoms. The eastern flat is 5 miles long N.E. by E. \ E. and S.W. by W. \ W., and 6 cables wide ; it commences N.N.E. \ E. 4 miles from Dunkerque lighthouse and extends to within 1£ miles of the eastern end of the bank ; there are shoal patches of only 6 feet, and general depths of from 8 to 9 feet, on this flat ; its western end is separated from the eastern end of the middle flat by an interval of one mile, with from 2 to 2£ fathoms water ; but all these banks are very liable to temporary changes in form and depth. East Breedt Bank is a continuation north-eastward of the Smal Bank ; within the 5-fathoms line, it is one mile wide and 5 miles long N.E. 7j E. and S.W. \ W. ; its shoalest part, commencing near the south-western end, is 3 miles long and half a mile wide, with from 13 to 18 feet water. From the south-western end of this flat, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S.W. £ W. 14^ miles; and, Nieuport pier-heads S.S.E. \ E. 6| miles. The north-eastern extreme of the bank terminates in some shoal patches of 25 feet, of which the most

Chap. XL] BREEDT, SMAL, AND DUNKERQUE ROAD BANKS. 537 eastern bears N. f E. from Nieuport and is 9 miles distant from the pier-heads. From this position, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S.W . £ W. 19^ miles ; and, Ostende lighthouse S.E. | E. easterly 10 miles. Smal Bank.— The western end of this bank lies 2\ miles from Dunkerque lighthouse, with the lighthouse and church tower in line ; it is connected with the middle flat of Breedt bank by a bar with only 12 or 13 feet water, and has as little as 2 feet within half a mile of this end. From its western end, it trends E. \ N. 6 miles and then N.E. by E. \ E. 8^ miles to its north-eastern end, which bears about N. by E. from Fumes, and N. by W. \ W. westerly 5i miles from Nieuport pier-heads. The southern part of this bank, near its north-eastern end, joins Nieuport bank by a narrow bar with 18 feet water ; here the towers at Fumes are on with the eastern part of a high sand-hill, named Broers-Duyn, bearing South. These banks bomid Nieuport road on the North, and are extremely steep to near their point of junction. Besides the small 2-feet flat at its western end, a dangerous flat about 8 miles long, with from one to 9 feet water, rises from the Smal bank, commencing N.E. \ N. 3 miles from Dunkerque light house and extending without interruption as "far as N. by W. \ W. from Furnes. It is joined to the flat on Hils bank, in-shore of it, by a shoal bar of from 10 to 12 feet ; from the centre of which bar, Dunkerque church tower is just open eastward of Leuguenaerd tower. Between the eastern end of this flat and the north-eastern extreme of the bank, are several patches of from 9 to 16 feet water. BANK bounding DUNKERQUE ROAD.— The successive parts of this long bank are, the Snouw, Braeck, Hils, and Traepegeer. From the western end of the Snouw in 5 fathoms to the point of junction with the shore of the eastern part of the Traepegeer, the length of the united banks is not less than 16^ miles ; their width, from 3 cables to a mile. They give shelter to Dunkerque road, which is entered from the westward by the West pass', and from the eastward by the Zuydcoote pass, the whole of the southern side of the banks being well buoyed. See page 550. Snouw bank, the western part of the long bank just described, is 4 miles in length E. \ S. and W. \ N. with less than 3 fathoms, and its highest parts form a narrow flat 2^ miles long with as little as 2 feet water at one part. The western end of the Snouw is 2 miles from the shore at Gravelines point ; N.E. \ E. 4 miles from Gravelines light house ; and, W.N.W. 7-j% miles from Dunkerque lighthouse.

538 [Chap. XL CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE.
