Buoy. — A bell buoy with reflector, painted with red and black bands, is moored at the western end of the Snouw bank ; from it, the Snouw light-vessel bears E.S.E. 1^ miles ; the Dyck light-vessel W. \ N. 1\ miles nearly ■ and, Gravelines lighthouse N.E. E. 4 miles. LIGHT-VESSEL.— The Snouw light-vessel, painted with red and black bands, carries a ball at her mast-head and has her name, Snouw, painted in white letters on both sides ; she lies in about 11 fathoms in the West Pass, near the western end of the Snouw, and shows a fixed red' light, visible in clear weather 7 miles. This light -vessel bears E. by S. \ S. 2£ miles from the Dyck light-vessel ; the two light-vessels in line lead into Dunkerque road. Fog bell. — In foggy weather a bell is sounded for one minute every three minutes, and continuously in reply to passing vessels. Braeck bank is only separated from the Snouw by a narrow 21-feet channel. It is about 5 miles long E. by S. and W. by N., beginning abreast of the centre of the Snouw, about 1£ miles from the shore on the meridian of Mardick, and ending just eastward of the meridian of Dunkerque. On its highest parts, which form a flat from one to 3 cables wide, are only from one to 2 feet water, and some patches even dry at the lowest tides. The Braeck is steep-to, its sides rising from the bottom like a wall, and with northerly winds the sea breaks upon it with great fury. Its western end in 3£ fathoms and the shallow flats extending from the shore, are connected by a sandy shoal or bar running in a W.S.W. direction across the West Pass. On this bar, there are from 5 to 5£ fathoms, deepening to 7 or 8 fathoms the moment it is passed in either direction. Hils bank is a continuation of the Braeck, extending 3^ miles farther in an easterly direction and terminating suddenly in the Zuydcoote Pass, the narrow 19-feet channel which separates it from the Traepegeer bank. This end of Hils bank, at its south-eastern angle, is only 1^ miles from the shore ; and, N. \ W. from Zuydcoote tower, in ruins, and called also Sables or Sands tower. From this angle, the edge of the bank extends N.E. \ N. 1\ miles, forming the north-western side of the Zuydcoote Pass. The highest part of the bank forms a flat from 2 to 8 cables wide, on the southern part of which, large patches dry as much as 6 feet at low water about N.E. by E. from Dunkerque lighthouse ; and, on the remainder, are only from one

Chap.XI.] SNOUW,BRAECK,HILS,TRAEPEGEER, AND FAIRY BANKS. 539 to 6 feet. The southern side rises precipitously from depths of from 7^ to 10 fathoms, rendering it exceedingly dangerous, but for the buoys marking its edge, to vessels turning to windward in the eastern part of Dunkerque road. Traepegeer bank bounds Dunkerque road eastward, and its western end forms the eastern side of the East or Zuydcoote Pass. The Traepegeer joins the shore in the neighbourhood of Broers-Duyn, the high sand-hill before mentioned, and from thence extends along the coast to the entrance of Nieuport. Its western extreme, on which there are from 7 to 13 feet water, is only 2 cables from the south eastern angle of Hils bank, and bears N. E. from Zuydcoote or Sables tower ; the outer part of the bank extends from 2f to If miles from the shore, and the depths vary between 6 and 18 feet, though one part, near the centre and on the outer side, has only one foot water. BANKS NORTH of DUNKERQUE BANKS.— These banks, referred to at page 529, are dangerous, not only from their shallowness and their being so liable to change in form that anything but the latest charts may be very misleading, but also from their being at so great a distance from the shore and directly in the route of vessels bound for the Schelde. See also the caution at page 563 as to the slight rise of tides on these banks. Fairy bank, a high sandy ridge with from 3£ to 9 fathoms water, is on the eastern side of the deep-soundings channel, and the channel between it and the West Hinder is 2£ miles wide. From its southern end in 8 fathoms, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S. \ W. westerly 18 miles ; and, the West Hinder light -vessel East 6£ miles. From thence, it extends N.E. easterly 9^ miles, its greatest breadth not exceeding 8 cables. There are two flats on this bank ; that near the middle, with less than 5 fathoms water, is 2\ miles long, and, from its shoalest spot of 3£ fathoms, Dunkerque lighthouse bears S. by W. \ W. 22 miles ; the Galloper light-vessel N. by W. £ W. westerly 25^ miles ; and, the West Hinder light-vessel S.E. \ S. 4^ miles. The other flat is near the northern end of the bank ; from its shoalest spot of 5^ fathoms, the West Hinder light-vessel bears South 6 miles. Dunkerque lighthouse may be seen in clear weather from the southern end of the Fairy bank. A shoal about 8 miles in length, with from 6^ to 9 fathoms water, lies 2 miles westward of and nearly parallel with the Fairy bank.

540 [Chap. XL CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. North Hinder, a dangerous sand-bank, situated like the Fairy on the eastern side of the deep-soundings channel, is 7 miles long N.E. by N. and S.W. by S., and from 5 to 8 cables wide, the general depth being from 6 to 9 fathoms ; but, on its southern part, a narrow flat with only 4 and 5 fathoms extends 2\ miles southward from about the middle of the bank, and is steep-to on its eastern side. The northern end of the bank lies E.S.E. southerly 24^ miles from the Galloper light-vessel ; and, the southern end, N.E. \ E. easterly 8 miles from the Fairy. The North Hinder may be considered as an extension of the Fairy, and between these banks are three flats, of which two, with from 8 to 10 fathoms water, occupy a space 3 miles in length midway between the banks ; the third, with 9 fathoms, lies 2 miles eastward of the northern end of the Fairy. Vessels should not go eastward of a line joining the Fairy to the North Hinder under any circumstances unless bound to the Schelde. LIGHT-VESSEL.— The North Hinder light-vessel is moored in 20 fathoms water, on the eastern side of the bank ; she exhibits from her mainmast-head, at 40 feet above the sea, a flashing white light at intervals of eight or ten seconds, visible in clear weather 11 miles. The vessel has two masts, is coloured red, and has the words Noord-Hinder painted in large white letters on her sides. During the day she carries a red ball at her mainmast-head. Fog Signal. — In thick or foggy weather a bell is struck every quarte/ of an hour, preceded and followed by strokes of a gong. Note. — If the apparatus of the light is out of repair, a fixed white light will be exhibited in lieu of the flashing light, and a flare light will be shown every ten minutes just above the bulwarks. If the light-vessel is out of position, neither the flashing light nor the usual riding-light will be shown, but red lights will be exhibited at bow and stern. Buoy. — A red buoy with the word Hinder in white letters is moored in 6 fathoms water at the northern end of the shoal flat of the North Hinder, and N. £ E. 2 miles from the light-vessel. Vessels of deep draught should keep northward of the buoy if crossing the North Hinder, and must bear in mind that the buoy being in its correct position cannot be depended on.

Chap. XL] HINDER BANKS. 541 West Hinder, a sand-bank 15 miles long within the 10-fathoms line, and from 7 cables to 1£ miles wide, lies eastward of the Fairy and southward of the North Hinder. Its southern end in 9 fathoms bears N.N.E. 18| miles from Dunkerque ; N.W. by W. £ W. 4 miles from the north-eastern end of the East Dyck ; and, E. £ S. 5 miles from the southern end of the Fairy ; from thence, the bank trends N.E. £ E. 8^ miles and then N.N.E. £ E. 6^ miles to its northern end, which is \\ miles S.S.E. of the southern end of the North Hinder. A flat occupies nearly the whole length of the bank and forms a continuous crest on which the depths are from 9£ to ih fathoms. By daylight, the West Hinder may generally be known by the tide ripples over it ; but the lead should be kept carefully hove when approaching this or any of the Flemish banks. The only passage practicable for large vessels bound to Flushing and intending to enter the Schelde by the Wieling Gat, is between the Out-Ruytingen, Bergues, and East Dyck on the one side ; and, the Fairy and West Hinder on the other. LIGHT-VESSEL.— Near the south-western end of the West Hinder bank, and On its eastern side, in 17 fathoms water, and in lat. 51° 22' 30" N., long. 2° 26' 26" E., is moored a light-vessel which exhibits at 40 feet above the sea a revolving light visible in clear weather 12 miles, and showing two white faces and one red face successively, with half minute intervals between each face. The vessel is black with a red streak, with the words West Hinder painted on each side, and a skeleton framework at her mast-head. From the light-vessel, Wielingen light-vessel bears E. by S. \ S. southerly 29^ miles ; the northern end of the East Dyke bank in 5 fathoms S.E. £ E. 3£ miles ; and, the Bergues bank buoy S.W. by W. \ W. 8 miles. Note. — Should the revolving apparatus be out of order, it will be replaced by two fixed lights, vertical ; the upper red, the lower white, and a white flare light will be shown every ten minutes. Should the light-vessel drift from her station, the revolving light will be replaced by three fixed lights, vertical, the centre light red, the other two ivhite ; by day, in this latter case, a red flag will be hoisted at the mainmast-head. Should the light-vessel require assistance ; by day, she will show the flags NIC. of the International Code ; by night, in addition to the distinguishing and anchor lights, a white light will be shown at the taffrail and a red rocket will be fired every fifteen minutes.

542 [Chap. XL CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. Fog Signal- — During foggy weather a siren is sounded, giving a prolonged blast at two minute intervals. Should the siren be out of order, the signal will be a bell sounded repeatedly at two minute intervals. East Hinder, a sand-bank 11 miles long N.E. by N. and S.W. by S., within a depth of 10 fathoms, and 6 or 7 cables wide, lies eastward of the West and North Hinder ; it has three flats, with from 3£ to 5 fathoms on them and 6 or 7 fathoms between them, which occupy 8£ miles of its extent. The bank is steep-to on both sides and separated from the North Hinder by a channel 3 miles wide with from 16 to 19 fathoms water ; and, from the West Hinder, by a channel 1£ miles wide with from 15 to 19 fathoms wTater. The northern end of the bank, in 9 fathoms, lies S.E. £ S. 4 miles nearly from the northern end of the North Hinder ; and, the southern end, N.E. by N. 8| miles from the northern extreme of the East Dyck. Its central shoal spot of 3£ fathoms bears S.E. by E. £ E. 3 miles from the North Hinder light-vessel. About midway between the southern end of the East Hinder and the East Dyck, there is a narrow shoal 41 miles long with from 5 to 8 fathoms water ; it lies 1^ miles eastward of the West Hinder and its southern extreme is 2 miles northward of the northern end of the East Dyck. Bligh Bank, also of sand, is 10^ miles long, from 5 cables to 1£ miles wide, and lies about 3 miles eastward of and nearly parallel with the East Hinder. Its northern end in 10 fathoms is in lat, 51° 41V N., long. 2° 48' 45" E., and lies N.W. i, W. 25^ miles from West Kapelle lighthouse ; and, S.E. by E. £ E. easterly 32 miles from the Galloper light-vessel. Its southern end, in 5£ fathoms, lies E. by N. 5 miles nearly from the southern extreme of the East Hinder ; and, N.E. \ E. 13 miles from 3 fathoms on the northern end of the East Dyck. This bank is also steep-to and has irregular depths of from 4£ to 9 fathoms. About 3 miles from its southern end, a flat, 1^ miles long with 4£ fathoms water, rises abruptly from soundings of from 14 to 18 fathoms. There is also a 5-fathoms patch near the northern end of the bank. Another patch, with 9 fathoms water, lies V3 miles northward of Bligh bank, and the soundings for 25. miles N.N.E. and N.E. by N. are irregular, in some places there being only 13 or 14 fathoms ; from whence it follows that the lead is an uncertain guide when approaching the Hinder or Bligh banks from the north-eastward.

Chap, XL] HINDER, BLIGH, AND THORNTON BANKS. 543 Thornton Ridge.— Within a depth of 9 fathoms, this sand-bank is 13 miles long E. by N. \ N. and W. by S. \ S. with a mean but very varied breadth of 1-^ miles ; it rises from soundings of from 12 to 17 fathoms 14 or 15 miles from the coast of Belgium. A flat, 2£ miles long and half a mile wide, with from 2 to 3 fathoms water, lies towards the eastern end of the ridge ; the shoalest spot of 2 fathoms bearing N.N.E. 19 miles from Ostende lighthouse. The general depth on the other parts of the ridge is from 6 to 9 fathoms. The land in the neighbourhood of West Kapelle, and the lights of West Kapelle and of Ostende, may be seen from this ridge in clear weather. The western end of Thornton ridge lies S.S.E. 3 miles from the South extreme of Bligh bank, and the space between is the least dangerous channel for large vessels intending to pass betwreen the banks when bound northward from Dunkerque with south-westerly winds. Buoy. — A red and white chequered buoy with staff and ball is moored in 6 fathoms a short distance north-eastward of the shoal flat ; from it, the Wandelaar light-vessel bears S. by W. 12£ miles ; and, West Kapelle light S.E. by E. £ E. 17 miles. It is proposed to supersede this buoy by a somewhat similar one, which will, however, at night show a quick flashing gas light, visible 5 miles. Nearly midway between Bligh bank and Thornton ridge are three narrow shoals occupying a space of 9 miles in an E.N.E. and W.S.W. direction and With from 8 to 9 fathoms water. The western shoal bears E. S. 3£ miles from the flat on Bligh bank, and N.W. £ N. 5+ miles from the shoalest spot on Thornton ridge. A succession of shoals, with from 6 to 9 fathoms water, also lie between Thornton ridge and the Out-Ratel, within sight of Ostende light, They occupy a space 10 miles long in an easterly and westerly direction, and the shoalest spot on them, 5^ fathoms, bears N. by E. \ E. 11 miles from Ostende lighthouse ; none are dangerous, and they are only mentioned here as they may be crossed by vessels coming out of the Zuydcoote Pass and are useful in assuring such that they are in a good and safe track. The COAST. — The sand-hills forming the coast between Calais and Gravelines may be seen in clear weather at 8 or 9 miles, but some of them are so low that embankments are thrown up as a protection against the sea. The only objects that can be recognised

[Chap. XL 544 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. on the level land adjoining the shore are, the two windmills at Walde, Oye church spire, and two windmills standing near Oye village. At low water, the sandy strand extends a mile from the shore between Calais and the meridian of Walde windmills, as well as off the entrance to Gravelines ; but, along the intermediate coast, its breadth varies from half to three quarters of a mile. Depths of less than 4 fathoms adjoining the beach, extend nearly 2 miles from the shore N.N.E. of Calais church and abreast of Gravelines, and about a mile from the shore between Walde and Oye windmills ; between the outer edge of these soundings and high-water mark, the slope of the bottom is steep and somewhat irregular, which tends to cause a heavy sea with on-shore winds. WALDE LIGHT. — Near the outer edge of the sandy strand which dries at low water, springs, 8 cables from the shore at Walde point, and 3 miles E. by N. £ N. northerly from Calais lighthouse, is an iron beacon 59 feet high, from whieh, at 34 feet above high water, is exhibited a light showing white and red alternately during twenty seconds, the red flash lasting four seconds, the white flash sixteen seconds, with no eclipse between ; the light is visible in clear weather 11 miles. Telegraph Cable. — The telegraph cable between France and Denmark (from Calais to Fano island), leaves the shore near the Huttes d'Oye, in longitude 2° 2' E., and lies in a N. l E. direction for U miles to latitude 51° 7' 10" N., and longitude 1° 59' 39" E., at which point it takes the direction of N.E. § N., passing close westward of No. 7 Out-Ruytingen buoy. The first of these directions is indicated by two beacons on the shore, each surmounted by a hexagonal prism, partly white and partly red. Vessels should not anchor in the direction indicated by these beacons. CAUTION. — Shipwrecks are frequent between Calais and Grave lines ; they are in great measure attributable to neglect of the lead, and to inattention or want of knowledge as to the times of change of the tidal streams, which are much later at the Galloper light-vessel, from whence vessels from the North Sea usually take their departure, than on the French coast. GRAVELINES.— The entrance to this small tidal harbour lies 10 miles eastward of Calais, and its position may be easily recognised by the houses of the village of Fort Phillippe built close to the sea

Chap. XL] 545 WALDE LIGHT. — GRAVELINES. on each side of the entrance channel, by a windmill about a quarter of a mile eastward of the village, and by the fine tower of the light house. The port itself is situate under the ramparts of the north western part of the town of Gravelines, at the mouth of the river Aa, but about a mile within the coast-line ; from the offing, however, the town, except the towers of the Cathedral, is hidden from view by trees. About 200 vessels, of which a fair proportion are steamers, enter the port annually bringing about 25,000 tons of merchandise ; the principal imports being wood, coal, woollen goods, bricks, and cement ; the exports, eggs, fruit, vegetables, &c. Vessels are also fitted out for the herring, cod, and mackerel fisheries. The popula tion of the port is about 8,500. The harbour is accessible to vessels of 15 feet draught at high water, springs. At weak springs, those of ll1 or 12 feet can enter it during 5 or 6 days, that is to say, for 2 or 3 days before full and change, and 3 days after. It affords good shelter, at springs, to vessels of about 12 feet draught during westerly gales, especially those between W.S.W. and W.N.W., when the sea is not heavy at the entrance ; but, the bar should be crossed at about high water. In a gale from E.N.E. or East, vessels should run in with the flood, for, after high water, there is some difficulty in stemming the ebb. The tide rises much higher with strong northerly winds, but, as the sea is then very high at the entrance, no vessel drawing more than 12 feet should attempt to enter, unless embayed and with no possibility of reaching Dunkerque road, which is the only place on this coast where, with strong northerly winds, a vessel may find a partially sheltered anchorage. Bar. — The entrance to the channel leading into Gravelines harbour is frequently obstructed by a bar formed of the sand driven in by westerly winds and sea. The height and extent of this bar depend both on the duration of these winds and on the body of fresh water running out of the harbour. At its medium state, it is from 2 to 3 feet above the level of the fresh water running through the channel when the tide is out, or 5 or 6 feet above the level of the lowest tides. When the great freshets of the river Aa are accompanied by north-easterly winds, it sometimes disappears altogether for several days. The Entrance Channel runs S. by E. £ E. 2 miles in a direct line from the jetty-heads and consists of two distinct parts, one A. 2771. Wt. 7242. . 2M

[Chap. XI. 546 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. bounded by the beach and sands which dry at low water ; the other, by the land from the village of Fort Phillippe to Gravelines. The outer part of the channel, 8 cables long and 305 feet wide at the entrance, is enclosed between two low stone jetties, of which, that on the eastern side does not cover at high water for the greater part of its length from the shore, and is terminated by 330 yards of wooden jetty with a timber pier-head. The stone end of the western jetty is 18 feet above the level of low water, and at high water it is covered throughout but its position is marked by wooden beacons ; the outer beacon off the entrance being larger than those marking the jetty ; these beacons, being secured by strong woodwork, have hitherto served as warping posts for vessels entering, but, to prevent the silting up of the entrance, the western pier is being raised similarly to the eastern one, and this work is near completion. Abreast of the jetty-heads, the level of the fresh water of the river when the tide is out, is 3 feet above the level of low water, extra ordinary springs. The inner part of the channel, between the village of Fort Phillippe and the harbour, is rather more than a mile long and half a cable wide, and is enclosed between embankments which serve for towing paths. The deposit in the channel forms a steep slope on either side, which, in the summer, is partially cleared away by scouring waters released by sluices from the fosses of the fortifications; but, at other seasons, the abundant freshets of the river Aa caused by rain and by the melting of the snow, clear both harbour and entrance channel of the mud and sand which accu mulate in dry weather. The Tidal Harbour is on the north-western side of the town, and is only about 1£ cables long, occupying half the breadth of the channel by which the course of the Aa has been straightened between the ditches of the western part of the fortifications and the entrance channel. There is a small gridiron and careening place in this harbour where vessels of 150 or 200 tons can be received. The berths of muddy sand, alongside the stone or wooden quays border ing the whole length of the harbour on the town side, are 4| feet above the level of low water, springs. The swell from outside never reaches the tidal harbour. The Wet Dock, or Bassin-a-flot, is 1,082 feet long by 147 feet wide ; it is entered from the tidal harbour by dock gates 32£ feet wide, and it again communicates with the river Aa, and hence with

Chap. XI.] 547 GRAVELINES.— LIGHTS.— TIDES. the inland navigation by other flood gates. It is also in communica tion with the railway by means of a siding. The sill at the entrance is on the level of low water, springs ; at high water, springs, there are 18 feet water, and at ordinary neaps, 15 feet over it. Semaphore. — There is a semaphore station close to the light house. LIGHTS.— Gravelines Lighthouse, a white circular tower resembling a Doric column, stands at the Eastern side of the entrance, in the western part of the village of Little Fort Phillippe, at 175 yards from the shore, and 65 yards from the eastern bank of the entrance channel. It exhibits, at 95 feet above high water, a fixed white light, dioptric and of the third order, visible at 15 miles. West Jetty. — A fixed green tidal light, visible 4 miles, is exhibited from iron supports above a shed on the new West jetty head ; this light is 25 feet above high water and is shown from two hours before to two hours after high water. East Jetty. — A. fixed red light, visible 4 miles, is shown from a similar structure on the East jetty-head ; this light is exhibited all night, and is also 25 feet above high water. Tide Signals. — The usual day tide signals, see page 8, are in use at this port. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, in Gravelines harbour at noon, springs rise 19 feet, neaps 15 feet. And, above the level of the fresh water stream at the harbour entrance when the tide is out, which is about 3 feet above the level of the lowest tides, equinoctial springs rise 20 feet ; ordinary springs, 18 feet ; ordinary neaps, 12 to 15 feet. A deduction of 2 feet from these heights gives the rise on the bar when in its medium state. Strong winds from N.W. to N.N.W. cause the tide to rise higher, and those from S.E. have a contrary effect. The tide rises slowly for the first three hours, but its rise is rapid from the third to the fourth hour ; it then slacks gradually until high water. At springs, the high water slack in the harbour continues about 15 minutes in calm weather, from 20 to 30 minutes with westerly winds, and 10 minutes at the utmost with off-shore winds ; but, as there is little rise or fall for the last half hour's flood and the first half hour's ebb, there is practically a period of 1£ hours for moving vessels in and out without danger of grounding. Pilots. — Eight pilots are stationed at Gravelines ; they cannot get 2M2

[Chap. XI. 548 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. out to vessels when the sea is high on the bar, in which case they go as far as they can and wave a flag to indicate the direction in which vessels should steer. A Life-Boat is stationed at Gravelines. A Steam-Tug is stationed at the port and available when required. Directions.— Vessels arriving off Gravelines harbour some time before the tide serves, may anchor northward of Oye church spire, at 1^ or 2 miles from the shore, in from 5 to 8 fathoms, excellent holding ground ; this anchorage, however, is only safe during fine weather, for the sea is heavy with on-shore winds. The most favourable winds for entering the harbour are those from N.N.W. to N.E., but, if fresh, they cause a high sea at the entrance, and it is then necessary to be quite certain there is sufficient water over the bar to avoid striking. With fresh winds from W.S.W. to W.N.W., the sea is smooth on the bar, but there is some difficulty in getting through the entrance channel when the low part of the jetties are covered, for the flood stream and sea crossing it may drift a vessel on the East jetty. The entrance is easy with north-easterly winds when they are sufficiently strong for a vessel to stem the flood or eastern stream, which is at its greatest strength at the time of high water in the harbour. With a head wind, a vessel is either tracked or towed in. The best time for entering the harbour is about an hour before high water, although the stream at that time runs strongly across the entrance and there is some difficulty in keeping in the deepest parts of the channel ; but, if the vessel takes the ground off Fort Phillippe, with a rising tide, she will float again before high water and get up to the harbour. Bower and stern anchors must be ready to let go, and hawsers to run out, should she be drifted on the East jetty. Sufficient sail should always be carried to ensure good steerage, especially during the autumn and winter months when it often blows fresh in the offing whilst the breeze is light near the shore ; vessels, therefore, under suitable sail in the offing, must be prepared to make more sail as they approach the harbour or they may be in considerable danger in the heavy swell on the bar. In entering the channel with westerly winds, whatever their strength, or with light easterly winds, keep close past the West jetty-head. With fresh easterly winds, run directly for the middle of the entrance.

Chap. XL] GRAVELINES.— DIRECTIONS. — MARDICK BANK. 549 The COAST. — From the entrance to Gravelines, that of Dunkerque bears E. \ S. southerly 10 miles ; the low plain behind the shore between the two places presents no remarkable objects visible from any distance at sea. The only high lands visible in clear weather are, the Great and Little Cassel, two isolated hills S. \ W. from Dunkerque. The town of Cassel stands on the summit of the Great Cassel ; the other hill is of a conical form The buildings recognisable near the coast are, the tower and light house at Dunkerque, and the church towers of Grande and Petite Synthe and of Mardick. Gravelines point, bearing E. \ S. southerly 4 miles from Gravelines jetty-heads, is of a rounded form, and the sand-hills com posing it lie in several parallel ridges and are visible in clear weather 9 or 10 miles ; at its outer extreme is a large wooden beacon. A chain of sand-hills covered with verdure extends 2 miles in a W.S.W. direction from the point, and those bordering the shore for about 2 miles eastward are about the same height as those at the point, but, beyond this, and to within a short distance of Dunkerque, they are covered with bent grass and lie in parallel ridges half a mile in the rear of an embankment fronted by low land which covers at high water, springs. Between the entrance of Gravelines and Gravelines point, the sands dry more than half a mile out from the beach, at springs ; abreast of the point, they dry 3 cables ; and, between the point and Dunkerque, 6 or 8 cables. The sand carried eastward by strong westerly winds, is arrested by the' jetties at Dunkerque and accumulates between Mardick and Dunkerque, where it forms an immense heap of which the highest parts barely cover at springs. Of all the obstacles to the improvement of Dunkerque, this high bank of drift sand is the most difficult to combat ; for, drifting over the West jetty, it formerly caused a bank several feet high to form at the jetty-head and across the entrance, and this bank is only kept under by constant dredging assisted by flushings. Mardick Bank, Fosse de Mardick, &c— The soundings off this part of the coast, within a depth of 5 fathoms, are very irregular and the sea heavy with on-shore winds. Between the entrance to Gravelines and Gravelines point, these soundings extend in places 2 miles and upwards from the shore ; and, on these shallows, the Mardick bank, with a general width of 5 or 6 cables and from 7 to 18 feet water, extends 3| miles parallel with the shore, its western

[Chap. XI 550 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. end joining the shore sands about one mile eastward of Gravelines jetties. Another shoal, of which the outer edge is steep-to, joins the strand between Mardick and Dunkerque, and, extending 1\ miles from the shore, forms, with the Mardick bank, the southern side of the West Pass ; its western end in 3 fathoms is 6 cables eastward of the eastern end of the Mardick bank, and bears N. by W. \ W. from Mardick church tower. In-shore of this and of the Mardick bank, is the Fosse de Mardick, a deep which has from 19 to 33 feet water but should always be avoided as each end terminates in a blind channel. WEST PASS into DUNKERQUE ROAD.— From the buoy with bell and reflector, marking the western extreme of the Snouw bank, to abreast of Dunkerque jetty-heads, this pass is 7 miles long, and it lies between the shoal flats joining the shore and the Snouw and Braeck banks. The entrance to it, as well as the direction it follows, is marked by the following buoys : — A bell buoy with reflector, painted with red and black bands, as described at page 538, is moored at the western extreme of the Snouw at the entrance of the Pass, and must be left on the port hand in entering. On the northern side of the Pass are five black buoys, each with a staff and globe, and all to be left on the port hand in entering : — No. 1 buoy is moored nearly midway between the buoy with bell and reflector and the Snouw light-vessel. No. 3 buoy is on the southern edge of the Snouw, E. £ S. If miles from No. 1 buoy, and nearly 1\ miles E. \ N. from the Snouw light vessel. No. 5 buoy is 1^ miles E. by S. \ S. from No. 3. buoy and near the western edge of the Braeck bank ; but, a narrow spit from this bank, with from 17 to 21 feet water, extends half a mile westward from the buoy, and is dangerous to vessels of deep draught running into Dunkerque road with a strong westerly wind, at low water. No. 7 buoy is in 20 feet water on the southern edge of the Braeck bank, about a mile eastward of No. 5 buoy. No. 9 buoy is also on the southern edge of the Braeck bank, about a mile eastward of No. 7 buoy. From it, Dunkerque jetty-heads bear S.E. £ S. If miles. On the southern side of the West Pass are seven red buoys, each with a staff and cross, moored on the outer edge of the dangerous flats joining the shore, all of which should be left on the starboard hand in entering.

Chap. XI.] PASSES INTO DUNKERQUE ROAD. 551 No. 2 buoy marks the N.W. edge of Mardick bank, and bears S.W. £ S. 7 cables from the Dyck light-vessel, and N.E. £ E. 2 miles from Gravelines jetty-heads. From the buoy, the Snouw bell and reflector buoy bears E. by N. 4. N. 2 miles nearly, and the Snouw light-vessel E. \ S. 34 miles. A pilot vessel is generally at anchor near this buoy. No. 4 buoy lies on the northern edge of the Mardick bank, about If miles E. f S. from No. 2 buoy, and S. by W. \ W. 6 cables from the bell and reflector buoy. At this point, the narrows of the West Pass commence. No. 6 buoy is at the north-eastern edge of the Mardick bank, about one mile eastward of No. 4 buoy, and about 6 cables southward of No. 1 black buoy on the opposite side of the Pass. No. 8 buoy marks the north-western edge of the bank next east ward of Mardick bank ; it lies one mile eastward of No. 6 buoy, and S.E. by E. \ E. about 6 cables from the Snouw light-vessel. No. 10 buoy lies in about 16 feet, If miles E. by S. from No. 8 buoy, and rather less than 5 cables south-westward of No. 5 black buoy on the opposite side of the Pass. No. 12 buoy lies in about 16 feet, If miles eastward of No. 10 buoy, and S. \ E. less than 5 cables from No. 7 black buoy on the opposite side of the Pass. No. 14 buoy, in about 5 fathoms, is 9 cables eastward of No. 12 buoy ; from it, No. 9 black buoy bears N.N.E. \ E. 5 cables, and Dunkerque jetty-heads S.E. by E. 1£ miles. The northern limit of the eastern part of Dunkerque road is marked by two red buoys, Nos. 8 and 6 : No. 8, the western buoy, is moored on the southern edge, near the eastern end, of the Braeck bank, N.E. \ E. 11 cables from Dunkerque jetty-heads, and E. by S. £ S. If miles from No. 9 black buoy. No. 6 eastern red buoy is on the southern edge of Hils bank, E. \ S. 1£ miles from No. 8 red buoy. ZUYDCOOTE or EAST PASS into DUNKERQUE ROAD. — This pass is very narrow; it lies between Hils and Traepegeer banks and has from 19 to 22 feet water, see also page 539 ; its limits are defined by one black and two red buoys. No. 2, the northern red buoy, with staff and ball, marks the north eastern edge of Hils bank. No. 4, red buoy is at the south-eastern angle of Hils bank, and, from it, No. 6 red buoy bears W. \ S. southerly 2\ miles, the edge of the bank curving southward of this line, midway between the buoys.

[Chap. XL 552 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. No. 1 black buoy marks the north-western edge of the Traepegeer ; from it, No. 2 red buoy bears W. £ S. 1\ miles. Caution. — The red buoys on the eastern slope of Hils bank, which is very steep, have sometimes drifted across the Zuydcoote Pass to the western slope of the Traepegeer ; this has frequently happened to No. 4 red buoy. Mariners should therefore be on their guard, though the greatest care is taken to keep the buoyage of both Passes in proper condition, a Government steamer being specially assigned for that duty. Directions. — The general direction through the Zuydcoote Pass from the eastward is about S.W. \ W., with No. 4 red buoy on the port bow until past No. 2 red buoy, when No. 4 should be brought gradually on the starboard bow ; this leads through in the deepest water. When the flood or eastern stream begins to be felt in Dunkerque road, which is about the time of half flood in the harbour, the tide has risen 9 feet in the Zuydcoote Pass, and the largest vessels that can enter Dunkerque may at that time pass over the south-western end of the Traepegeer by keeping the spires of Bergues church open about a degree westward of Leffrinckoucke church tower bearing about S.S.W. \ W. If a vessel's draught permits her to turn through the Zuydcoote Pass between half flood and half ebb, the lead must be hove quickly to avoid coming suddenly upon Hils bank ; and, in standing eastward, she should not open the spires of Bergues more than two degrees eastward of Leffrinckoucke church tower. At Night, small vessels entering by this Pass, and unable to distinguish the colour of the first buoy they see, cannot do wrong in passing close eastward of it ; for, if it should be No. 1 black buoy of the Traepegeer, there is enough water for them for 4 cables eastward of it, and if it should be No. 2 red buoy of the Hils bank, by keeping eastward of it they will be in the middle of the Pass. DUNKERQUE ROAD being narrow, and only sheltered by banks of which the greater part are always covered, can only be considered as a temporary anchorage for merchant vessels whose draught permits them to enter the harbour. In heavy weather, sharp vessels deeply laden might be in some danger from the sea, but, with this exception, the pilots consider that a vessel with good ground tackle may ride out a gale from the offing ; and, in the winter of 1870-71, a French squadron remained for many months

Chap. XL] 553 DUNKERQUE ROAD. — TIDAL STREAMS. in the road and reported favourably of it ; the banks, even at high water, affording sufficient shelter to ships of large size. The road is comprised between the 5-fathoms line in-shore, and the Braeck, Hils, and Traepegeer banks, on the off-shore side. It extends from the western end of the shallow flat of the Braeck, north eastward of Mardick tower, to the entrance of the Zuydcoote Pass, and is separated into two deeps by a sandy bottom 3 cables wide, of which the centre lies N.N.W. £ W. from Dunkerque lighthouse. There are from 5 to 8 fathoms on this sandy bottom, but the holding ground is bad in the deepest water. The Great road or western deep, with from 8 to 9 fathoms, good holding ground, commences N.E. of Mardick tower, extends to the sandy bottom just mentioned, and is in some degree sheltered from the sea during northerly gales by the high flat on the Braeck bank. It is in this part of the road that vessels of deep draught anchor, with westerly winds and a heavy sea, when they have to wait for high water to enter Dunkerque. Small vessels under similiar circum stances may anchor N.W. about a mile from the harbour entrance, in the southern part of the sandy bottom, the holding ground there being good and the depth from 5 to 7 fathoms : this is also a good position for all vessels with off-shore winds. The Little road or eastern deep commences with Heuguenar towTer on with Dunkerque lighthouse, and extends to the Zuydcoote Pass ; in it, the depths vary from 8 to 11 fathoms, and the holding ground is good, especially N.N.E. of Dunkerque. Large vessels remaining some time in Dunkerque road should anchor in this deep between the lines of Heuguenar tower touching the eastern side of the light house, and the same tower on with Dunkerque tower ; here they are better sheltered than in the western deep during gales from N.N.W. to E.N.E. by the high flats on Braeck and Hils bank ; and, in the event of parting, it is much less dangerous to run ashore eastward than westward of Dunkerque. In any part of the road, vessels should have a spare anchor ready if the wind veers and threatens to blow hard from the northward. Tidal Streams. — The first of the flood stream in Dunkerque road comes from N.N.W. ; as it gains strength it turns more eastward, and, at its greatest speed, which lasts about two hours, it runs straight through the road. It then decreases rapidly, and, after a few minutes slack water, the ebb stream commences, running N.N.W. at first, and, as its rate increases, turning westward, and running parallel with the coast when at its greatest strength ; towards

554 [Chap. XL CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. the end of the tide, its direction is W.S.W. and S.S.W. The flood or eastern stream runs for 2£ or 3 hours after high water in the harbour ; see tides, page 557. DUNKERQUE, 10 miles eastward of Gravelines, formerly an arsenal and naval port, is now the principal French commercial port in the North Sea. The town stands at the junction of the Bergues, Bourbourg, and Fumes canals, and the public buildings are spacious, handsome, and regular. As this port is one principal outlet for the great manufacturing Departement du Nord, the trade by sea is very large. The cod and herring fisheries are also carried on with great activity. The average of the six years, 1882-87, shows that the trade of the port is represented by 2,669 vessels entering annually, their aggregate tonnage being 1,052,632 tons. The population in 1886 amounted to 39,195. There is a town hospital at which foreign sailors are received at two francs per diem; cases of small-pox or typhoid are sent to the Lazaret, where the charges are much higher. There is also a Sailor's Home and British Seamen's Institute. The principal imports, to the amount of over 1,200,000 tons annually, are, ores, coal, cereals, seeds, molasses, nitrate of soda, wood, wool, flax, petroleum, jute, and pig iron. The exports, about 180,000 tons annually, are principally coal, forage, potash, rails, and casks. Dunkerque is in railway communication with all parts of France and the Continent, and through Fumes with Belgium. The telegraph service is also very good. By sea, there is regular steam service to London, Hull, Goole, Leith, Rotterdam, St. Petersburgh, Havre, Bordeaux, and Marseilles. The port consists of an entrance channel leading to an outer tidal harbour, at the end of which is an inner tidal harbour and four wet docks or basins. Great improvements have been effected in the entrance and tidal harbours of late years by dredging and other wise, and extensive harbour works are still (1888) in progress. In addition to the present wet docks, others with an area of 47 acres are either under construction or projected, as well as four dry docks, of which two, not yet completed, are 360 feet in length, and will take vessels up to 328 feet on the keel. There are building yards where fishing craft of from 30 to 150 tons are built, and also vessels up to 800 tons for the foreign and coasting trade. Steam coal is always plentiful and moderate in price, that of French coal delivered on board being about 14s. per ton. Vessels usually coal in the Basins ; if they coal alongside the wharf in the tidal harbour, they lie aground in about 4 feet at low water. All necessary supplies

Chap. XL] DUNKERQUE. — ENTRANCE CHANNEL. 555 for shipping are readily obtainable, but moderate repairs only to hull or machinery can be effected until one of the dry docks is completed, though there is a patent slip capable of receiving vessels up to 1,000 tons, as well as a large gridiron. Vessels drawing from 19 to 22, or even 23, feet can enter the port at high water, springs ; but, for three or four days after each quarter, about 4 feet must be deducted from that draught. Northerly gales cause such a high sea outside the jetties that vessels above 14 feet draught should not attempt to run in at such times unless the pilots judge the entrance practicable ; small vessels may enter at the top of high water by carrying all possible sail to get through the heavy sea, but, at neaps, the entrance is inaccessible during these gales to all except coasters. The Entrance Channel is about one mile long N.N.W. and S.S.E., and 230 feet wide ; it is enclosed partly by the citadel quay and the extension of the town quay as far as the Cunette sluice, and partly between wooden jetties extending across the sands which uncover at low water. The sand forces itself into the channel through the openings in the pilework and through the entrance, especially during dry weather and at neaps. Water from the canals of the interior and from the ditches of the town, is used to scour the harbour and entrance channel, but, although the stream is rapid, it has so far to run that its effect does not extend much beyond the jetty-heads, and does not suffice to keep the entrance clear. Constant dredging by steam dredges of peculiar construction, however, in conjunction with flushing, enables the harbour authorities to maintain a depth both within and outside the jetties of at least 5 feet water at the lowest tides. During rainy weather, and at the melting of the snow, when the water in the interior is abundant, the stream runs strongly out of the channel all the time the flood is weak and is checked only when the tide rises rapidly ; it recovers its course as soon as the tide slacks, about half an hour before high water, and as soon as the ebb makes it acquires great strength. This stream causes very little in convenience to vessels of deep draught entering before high water, but, as soon as the tide begins to fall, they must have a strong fair wind to get through against it. Vessels lying anywhere in the inner parts of the channel, require to be well secured in strong northerly winds, when the swell makes itself felt both in the entrance channel and outer tidal harbour. The Outer Tidal Harbour occupies the space between the

556 [Chap. XL CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. town and the citadel, is about 3 cables long, from 400 to 500 feet wide, and surrounded by quays where several lines of steamers have their regular berths. It dries at springs, and the bottom is a mixture of sand, shingle, and mud, vessels lying alongside the quays on a much thicker bottom of mud than in the inner tidal harbour. Strong northerly winds cause the swell to enter this harbour for about 2 or 3 hours each tide, but it does not inconvenience a vessel well secured. The Inner Tidal Harbour communicates directly with the outer harbour and dries at low water ; it is bordered by quays, partly of stone and partly pile fronted. On its southern side are building yards, and the entrances to the wet docks are from this harbour. Wet Docks. — The four wet docks, or bassins-a-flot, are named respectively, the Bassin Freycinet, du Commerce, de la Marine, and de l'Arriere Port. The Bassin Freycinet, or de l'Ouest, has an area of 19| acres, and an entrance lock 394 feet long and 66 feet broad, with a depth over the sill at high water, springs, of 24 feet 5 inches. This basin has quays only on the side near the town, the other side being merely embankments through which will be the openings to the large new basins under construction. Improved connection with the canal system of the interior by means of two locks is also being completed . The Bassin du Commerce, of 13^ acres area, communicates with the inner tidal harbour, and also with the Bassin de la Marine, by lock gates, and directly with the Bassin de l'Arriere Port. It has good stone quays on its eastern and western sides. The Bassin de la Marine, of 1\ acres area, is surrounded by quays, and the Bassin de l'Arriere Port, of 6 acres, has a wooden quay on its western side. The depth over the sills of the Bassin du Commerce, de la Marine, and de l'Arriere Port, is in each case about 20 feet 9 inches at high water, springs ; and 17 feet 6 inches at neaps. The largest vessel yet admitted to any of the docks was a steamer of 2,550 tons, and 23 feet 3 inches draught of water. LIGHTS.— Dunkerque Lighthouse, a yellow brick towei 187 feet high, stands between the inner end of the West jetty an^ the ruins of Fort Risban. It bears S. by E. \ E. 875 yards from th6 West jetty-head, and exhibits, at 193 feet above high water, a group flashing electric light of the first order showing successive groups of two ivhite flashes each, the interval between two consecutive groups being three times as long as the interval between the two flashes of a group. The light is visible in clear weather 20 miles.

Chap. XL] 557 DUNKERQUE. — DOCKS. — LIGHTS. — TIDES. Hueguenar.— A. fixed white light of the fifth order, and 85 feet above high water, is exhibited from the Huguenar tower S.S.E. 2,406 yards from the entrance. This light, specially intended to indicate the direction of the entrance channel, shows its brightest light in the direction of N.N.W., and on that bearing is visible from 10 to 12 miles. Right or left of this direction, the light is visible only within an angular space of 10° or 12°, and from a distance of 5 or 6 miles. East Jetty-head. — A fixed green light is shown from the extreme of the East jetty at 26 feet above high water, and is visible 4 miles. Tidal Light. — West jetty. — From a white tower 49 feet within the West jetty-head, at 33 feet above the sea, is exhibited a tidal light, visible 9 miles, varying in colour, and indicating by colour and flashes the state of the tide, every 10 inches of rise above a depth of 6^ feet being shown, thus : — When the tide is less than 6| feet above low water, springs, and rising, the light shows red; when less than 6^ feet and falling, the light shows green ; when between 6 \ and 7^ feet the light shows ivhite. With 7^ feet and upwards, the light shows white with groups of coloured flashes at intervals of eighty seconds. The flashes in each group are shown at intervals of five seconds, each red flash adding 3 feet 4 inches to the initial height of 6^ feet, and each green flash 10 inches more. With a rising tide, the fixed light, whether red or white, is eclipsed for a short period every eighty seconds ; and, with a falling tide, the fixed light, ivhite or green, is eclipsed twice in quick succession during the same period. At or near high water, the light is not eclipsed. When the fixed white light is varied by groups of coloured flashes, the eclipses take place about the middle of the interval separating the groups. Tides. — It is high water, full and change, at Dunkerque, at Oh. 8m. ; springs rise 16£ feet, neaps 13^ feet ; and, 6 feet added to the rise gives about the average depth at high water throughout the entrance channel. Strong northerly winds raise the tide 2 or 3 feet higher, but the sea is then heavy at the entrance. When easterly winds prevail, springs do not rise much higher than neaps with fresh westerly winds. In the harbour, in calm weather, high water slack lasts about 15 minutes ; with westerly winds, 20 or 25 minutes ; and, with off-shore winds, 10 minutes. A short distance outside the jetties, the flood or eastern stream runs 2£ or 3 hours after high water in the harbour.

558 [Chap. XI. CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. Tide Signals. — The day tide signals are those in use at all French ports, see page 8. They are made from a flagstaff on the terrace of a little building S.S.E. 109 yards from Dunkerque light hours, between the West jetty and Fort Risban. Semaphore. — There is a Semaphore station at Dunkerque : it is just in front of the lighthouse. Pilots. — There are 36 qualified pilots at Dunkerque, they are unable to get out of harbour when there is a heavy sea at the entrance, which is frequently the case ; but, three pilot vessels are always cruising at sea. Their stations are, one between Dungeness and the Downs, another near the Ruytingen light-vessel, and a third near the Dyck light-vessel. They all have the word Dunkerque in large black letters on their sail and a large black anchor beneath that word. They always endeavour to meet large vessels, but small ones requiring a pilot should make the signal directly they sight a pilot vessel. Steam-Tugs. — The port is well supplied with steam-tugs, whose services are always available. A Life-Boat is stationed at Dunkerque. DIRECTIONS— From the Westward.— With the wind from N.N.W. round by West to S.S.W., vessels should endeavour to make the land about cape Grisnez, and, from about 2 miles north-westward of that cape, steer N.E. by E. \ E. 10 miles, or until Mont Couple bears about S.S.W. and the entrance to Calais S.E. From thence, the course to the Dyck light-vessel, at the entrance of the West Pass into Dunkerque road, is E. \ S. southerly 15£ miles; this leads about 8 cables northward of the red perch and globe buoy marking the Ridin de Calais. In approaching the West Pass, bring the Dyck and Snouw light vessels in line E. by S. £ S., and steer for them ; keep southward of both light-vessels and of the red and black bell buoy with reflector in passing them, and then with the light-vessels in line astern W. by N. 4. N., run in, leaving all black buoys on the port hand and red buoys on the starboard hand up to Dunkerque Great road ; but, if proceeding east ward beyond the entrance of the harbour to the Little road, it must be bome in mind that the colour of the buoys is reversed, red buoys marking that road on the port hand, if coming from the westward. Vessels of deep draught running in with a strong westerly wind, at

Chap, xl] 559 DUNKERQUE. — PILOTS. — DIRECTIONS. low water, should avoid the 21-feet spit which extends 5 cables westward of No. 5 black buoy, by keeping over towards No. 10 red buoy in this part of the Pass. Large vessels, having to wait for high water to enter Dunkerque, anchor in the Pass between Nos. 7 and 9 black buoys. With the wind between N.N.E. and E.N.E., long boards should be made in the Pas de Calais until Calais bears S.S.E. -^ E., when a vessel should stand in for the land, keeping the lead going quickly to avoid crossing the Ridin de Calais. Boards of about 3 miles may be made between the West Dyck and the 5-fathoms edge of soundings towards the shore, but, from the meridian of Gravelines lighthouse to the entrance of the West Pass, short tacks should be made near the edge of these soundings, bearings of the Dyck and Snouw light vessels enabling this to be done with great confidence. At Night, with westerly winds, after running past cape Grisnez as directed, until Calais light bears S.E. \ S. and cape Grisnez light S.W. \ W. westerly, steer E. \ S. for the Dyck light-vessel ; the Snouw light-vessel will be sighted shortly after the Dyck, then steer for them in line bearing E. by S. \ S., and, passing close south ward of both bring them in line astern, and so run on through Dunkerque road, anchoring in about 8 fathoms, with Heuguenar tower light seen between the two jetty lights S.S.E. From the Northward. — When bound from the North Sea to Dunkerque, or other French ports on this coast, endeavour to make the land about cape Blanc-Nez whatever the direction of wind or time of tide. The land south-westward of this cape, as far as cape Grisnez, may be seen in ordinary weather about 18 miles, and Mont Couple and the hills around it, 22 or 23 miles. The course from about 3 or 4 miles eastward of the Galloper light-vessel is S.S.W. \ W. ; this leads eastward of the Four-mile knolls or North Falls Head, and when the North Foreland lighthouse bears W. by N. \ N., steer S.W. \ S. to pass midway between the Falls Tail and the south-western end of the Sandettie bank. In clear weather, there is no difficulty in turning to windward over this ground ; when thick or foggy, the lead must be kept going quickly to avoid standing into less than 20 fathoms. From a well defined position, ships may pass between the Great and Little banks of Out-Ruytingen by steering for Gravelines light house bearing S. by E. £ E. easterly, and taking great care to main tain that bearing ; the least water in this route is 7>\ fathoms, on

[Chap. XI. 560 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. crossing the West Dyck bank. On bringing the Dyck and Snouw light-vessels in line, proceed as before directed for Dunkerque roads. The same routes may be safely taken at night when the lights are distinctly seen. At Night, the lights at the South Foreland, cape Griznez, Calais, and even Dunkerque, may be seen in clear weather when a vessel is midway between the Falls Tail and the south-western end of the Sandettie ; from this position, if the wind is from the eastward, Calais light may be steered for, or, if from the westward, the land between Calais and cape Grisnez ; but, to keep a safe distance from the coast on either of these courses, it is necessary in the former case not to bring cape Grisnez light westward of S.W. by W., nor Gravelines light eastward of S.E. by E. \ E. ; and, in the latter, not to bring cape Grisnez light westward of S.W. \ W., nor Calais light eastward of S.E. by S. Having attained either of the positions indicated by these bearings, the Dyck light-vessel and Dunkerque road may be steered for as before directed from the westward. With strong northerly winds, it is not prudent to approach within 5 miles of the coast, nor to bring Gravelines light eastward of S.E. by E. With strong westerly winds, vessels sometimes pass westward of the Galloper and the Falls, or between the Galloper and Four-mile knolls and then westward of the Falls, in order to get smoother water. The course from about 2 miles westward of the Galloper is S.W. \ S., and a run of about 34 miles on that course brings the vessel up to the East Goodwin light-vessel and well southward of the Falls Tail ; both cape Grisnez and Calais lights will then be in sight if the weather is clear. Entering Dunkerque. — Have good hawsers ready to moor head and stern, anchors clear, and, with a fair wind, a heavy anchor ready to bring up by the stern. All possible sail should be carried to pass quickly through the breakers at the entrance, where fresh northerly winds raise a heavy sea, and the best time then for running in, is, at high water. When within the entrance channel there is no difficulty in reaching the harbour. Strong winds between N.W. and S.S.W. cause a heavy swell at the entrance. At such times, keep close to the West jetty -head and western side of the channel until sheltered by that part of the jetty which is boarded up, as the flood or eastern stream setting through the open pilework runs with great rapidity towards the East jetty.

Chap. XL] 561 DUNKERQUE. — DIRECTIONS. This stream, as before explained, is at its greatest strength about half an hour before high water in the harbour. With moderate westerly winds, the most favourable time to enter, if a vessel's draught permits, is, when the stream slackens, or about half or three quarters of an hour after high water in the harbour. Strong easterly winds also raise a high sea at the entrance on a weather tide ; with these winds, steer for the East jetty-head, and then run along the eastern side of the channel. When it blows hard between S.S.W. and S.S.E., vessels cannot enter under sail and the services of a steam-tug are requisite ; but, if preferred, as the sea is then smooth in the road, they may remain there without danger. During light winds, every effort should be made to close with the West jetty-head to avoid being drifted eastward of the entrance by the flood stream, which runs at its greatest strength outside the jetties the whole of the time large vessels can enter. The best time for those of light draught to run in, is, directly the signal shows sufficient water and before the flood has attained much strength. Leaving Dunkerque. — Sailing vessels bound westward or to the northern ports of the North Sea, either wait for favourable winds or are towed out to positions from which to make sail. The gates of the wet docks are opened one hour before and closed about half an hour after high water. Winds with southing in them are the most favourable for leaving, but on-shore winds, when strong, forbid all egress. If bound westward, vessels should leave the harbour directly they float if the wind is sufficiently strong to stem the flood stream ; but, with a light wind, they should not start until near the top of high water, and then anchor in the road for the stream to slacken. On quitting the West Pass, steer with the Dyck and Snouw light -vessels in line astern, and then, a W. £ N. course leads northward of the Ridin de Calais ; and, when Calais lighthouse bears S.E. £ S., or cape Grisnez lighthouse S.W. £ W., a S.W. by W. £ W. course leads a safe distance westward of that cape. If bound northward, and the vessel's draught permits her crossing the banks northward of Dunkerque, the entrance channel should be left as early as possible before high water ; but, this passage should never be attempted without a fresh fair wind to enable her to run quickly over the banks, and it must be borne in mind that there may be quite 4 feet less water in crossing the Braeck bank than in the entrance channel. When clear of the jetties, steer N. £ W. to get the spire at Petite Synthe on with the guard-house about a A. 2771. Wt. 17197. 2 N

562 [Chap. XL CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. mile westward of Dunkerque lighthouse S.W. £ S. ; then steer N.E. £ N. with this mark on, crossing in succession the Braeck, Smal, and East Breedt banks, until the lead shows that the vessel is near the eastern edge of the East Dyck bank, when a N.E. by E. course for 35 miles leads between Thornton ridge and Bligh bank. The soundings on this latter course are from 14 to 19 fathoms. A cast of 9 or 10 fathoms may be had on the two narrow shoals between Thornton ridge and Bligh bank. If the vessel's draught does not permit of her crossing these banks, leave the harbour as soon as she floats so as to get the full benefit of the eastern stream, and, when outside the jetties, steer through the Zuydcoote pass ; see page 551. When clear of the Pass, steer E.N.E. through the West deep until Furnes is on with Broers-Duyn, see next paragraph, bearing South, when the vessel will be crossing the narrow shoal joining the Smal and Nieuport banks. From thence, a N.E. \ N. course for 35 miles leads through the North channel and clear of all the banks. The only inconvenience in following this course is, the crossing of the tidal stream in an oblique direction, which must be allowed for. Ostende light may be seen in ordinary weather until within 2 miles of the southern part of Thornton ridge. THE COAST.— From Dunkerque to the frontier of Belgium, 7 miles distant, and for 25 miles beyond it as far as Blankenberg, the coast trends nearly in a straight line E. by N. \ N. The shore being low, sandy, and bordered by sand-hills, has a dull uniform appearance, the only objects that can be recognized on the level plain in the interior being the clumps of trees surrounding villages, church towers, and windmills. Between Dunkerque and the frontier a large beacon named the Pilot's mast, and some revenue guard houses, may be seen on the sand-hills near the shore, and the old ruined tower, known as Sables tower, amongst the sand-hills near Zuydcoote ; and, beyond the frontier, the towers of Furnes, the ramparts and church tower of Nieuport, and the Broers-Duyn, a high sand-hill bearing North from Furnes, which is flattened at the summit and may be easily recognized at sea by its being totally free from verdure, whilst those near it are of a brown colour and covered with bent grass. The sandy strand bordering the coast abreast of Dunkerque Little Road, dries a quarter of a mile out from the shore at low water, and the depths outside it increase gradually to 1\ fathoms at a mile from the shore. To ground in bad weather on this part of

Chap. XL] 563 THE COAST. — TIDAL STREAMS. the coast on a falling tide is less fatal than on the beach between Dunkerque and Mardick, for, whatever the violence of wind and surf, if a vessel runs stem on to the beach she makes a bed in the sand and the tide soon leaves her, especially if she takes the ground about half an hour after high water, at springs. Assistance can then be afforded to the crew and they may be saved if they remain on board until the tide has left her ; whereas a vessel grounding on the high beach westward of Dunkerque, almost always becomes a total wreck, often with loss of crew, at whatever time of tide she runs ashore. TIDES AND TIDAL STREAMS.— On the northern coast of France, as well as on the English shore from Dover to the North Foreland, the tide, at springs, takes 5£ hours to rise from the level of low water to that of high water, and 7^ hours to fall from that level to low water ; but these durations vary according to the moon's age ; that of the flood increases progressively from full or change to the following quarter, whilst that of the ebb decreases, so that two or three days after the quarter, the duration of the ebb is as long as the flood ; it then increases gradually until the following full or change, and that of the flood decreases. In calm weather, both streams in the offing have respectively about the same duration as the rising and falling tide on the shore, and their rate is in proportion to the range of tide ; the times of the change of stream, however, do not coincide with the times of high and low water by the shore. The flood or eastern stream is generally less rapid than the ebb, but the rate and duration of both are influenced by the winds. It has not yet been ascertained by any decisive experiments whether the range of the tides between the northern coast of France and the estuary of the Thames is equal to that observed on the surrounding shores. All that is positively known on the subject is, that as far as 15 or 16 miles from the French coast, the vertical motion of the tides seems to follow very nearly the same law as on the shore ; they take place at the same times and appear to rise in an equal degree ; but, if the rise of water, at springs, on this coast, at Calais for example, is compared with that observed at the same tides on the coasts of Holland and Belgium, as well as at several positions in the estuary of the Thames, and especially at Orfordness, it would appear that beyond the distance of 15 or 16 miles from the French coast, in a N.N.E. and E.N.E. direction, the range of tide decreases in the same manner as on the shores. It is even probable that this 2 N 2

[Chap. XL 564 CAPE GRISNEZ TO DUNKERQUE. decrease is very rapid, for, in the middle of the North sea, between Holland and England, there are not more than 2 feet difference between high and low water ; the mariner, therefore, in determining his position by the depths on the chart, should diminish the allowance required for rise of tide according to his distance from the nearest shore. The tides on the coasts of France, Belgium, and Holland, as well as on the coast of England from Dover to the North Foreland, are chiefly affected by the tidal wave which traverses in about 8 hours the whole extent of the English channel. The flood or eastern stream, when at its greatest strength, takes an E.N.E. course, and its direction is only changed near the shore by the bends of the coast. The tides on the English coast, northward of the North Foreland, are produced by a similar tidal wave, which, after having doubled the northern extreme of the British islands, extends southward along the eastern coasts of Scotland and England and runs directly towards the estuary of the Thames. The flood or southern stream, when at its greatest strength, runs parallel with the English coast, but when it has reached the parallel of Orfordness, and the Thames opens out, it turns to W.S.W. in an opposite direction to that which the flood stream follows near the coast of France. But, as the changes of stream in the offing occur later than near the shore, in proportion to the distance from the land, the stream of flood on the French coast evidently mingles with the ebb stream from the mouth of the Thames, somewhere in the neighbourhood of the Gabbard and Galloper banks. CAUTION. — Mariners should bear in mind that the direction of the tidal stream in the offing, either in the North sea or Channel, is not to be taken as a sign of the rise or fall of the tide ; for, a vessel would be exposed to the greatest danger if she ran with the flood stream towards a shoal lying far from the land, under the idea that in consequence of the direction of the stream the water was rising on that shoal, and that she might venture to cross it. The flood stream only ceases to be felt in the vicinity of some of those banks which are farthest out from the coasts of France and Belgium, when it is nearly low water on the shore. When desirous of crossing a bank lying within 15 or 16 miles of the French coast, an approximate calculation should always be made of the number of feet the tide has risen above the soundings shown on the chart.
